"
Upon
my
word
,
friend
,
"
said
I
,
"
you
have
almost
made
me
long
to
try
what
a
robber
<EOS>
I
should
make
.
"
<EOS>
"

is
a

art
in

,

did
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

,
"

,
"
there
's
a

in

.

EPOCH
<EOS>
THE
FIRST
.
 
<EOS>
1703
.
 
<EOS>
JONATHAN
WILD
.
      
<EOS>
JACK
SHEPPARD
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
I.
 
<EOS>
The
Widow
and
her
Child
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
night
of
Friday
,
the
26th
of
November
,
1703
,
and
at
the
hour
of
eleven
,
the
door
of
a
miserable
habitation
,
situated
in
an
obscure
quarter
of
the
Borough
of
Southwark
,
known
as
the
Old
Mint
,
was
opened
;
and
a
man
,
with
a
lantern
in
his
hand
,
appeared
at
the
threshold
.
<EOS>
This
person
,
whose
age
might
be
about
forty
,
was
attired
in
a
brown
double
-
breasted
frieze
coat
,
with
very
wide
skirts
,
and
a
very
narrow
collar
;
a
light
drugget
waistcoat
,
with
pockets
reaching
to
the
knees
;
black
plush
breeches
;
grey
worsted
hose
;
and
shoes
with
round
toes
,
wooden
heels
,
and
high
quarters
,
fastened
by
small
silver
buckles
.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
three
-
cornered
hat
,
a
sandy
-
coloured
scratch
wig
,
and
had
a
thick
woollen
wrapper
folded
round
his
throat
.
<EOS>
His
clothes
had
evidently
seen
some
service
,
and
were
plentifully
begrimed
with
the
dust
of
the
workshop
.
<EOS>
Still
he
had
a
decent
look
,
and
decidedly
the
air
of
one
well
-
to
-
do
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
In
stature
,
he
was
short
and
stumpy
;
in
person
,
corpulent
;
and
in
countenance
,
sleek
,
snub
-
nosed
,
and
demure
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
behind
this
individual
,
came
a
pale
,
poverty
-
stricken
woman
,
whose
forlorn
aspect
contrasted
strongly
with
his
plump
and
comfortable
physiognomy
.
<EOS>
She
was
dressed
in
a
tattered
black
stuff
gown
,
discoloured
by
various
stains
,
and
intended
,
it
would
seem
,
from
the
remnants
of
rusty
crape
with
which
it
was
here
and
there
tricked
out
,
to
represent
the
garb
of
widowhood
,
and
held
in
her
arms
a
sleeping
infant
,
swathed
in
the
folds
of
a
linsey
-
woolsey
shawl
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
her
emaciation
,
her
features
still
retained
something
of
a
pleasing
expression
,
and
might
have
been
termed
beautiful
,
had
it
not
been
for
that
repulsive
freshness
of
lip
denoting
the
habitual
dram
-
drinker
;
a
freshness
in
her
case
rendered
the
more
shocking
from
the
almost
livid
hue
of
the
rest
of
her
complexion
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
be
more
than
twenty
;
and
though
want
and
other
suffering
had
done
the
work
of
time
,
had
wasted
her
frame
,
and
robbed
her
cheek
of
its
bloom
and
roundness
,
they
had
not
extinguished
the
lustre
of
her
eyes
,
nor
thinned
her
raven
hair
.
<EOS>
Checking
an
ominous
cough
,
that
,
ever
and
anon
,
convulsed
her
lungs
,
the
poor
woman
addressed
a
few
parting
words
to
her
companion
,
who
lingered
at
the
doorway
as
if
he
had
something
on
his
mind
,
which
he
did
not
very
well
know
how
to
communicate
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
good
night
,
Mr.
Wood
,
"
said
she
,
in
the
deep
,
hoarse
accents
of
consumption
;
"
and
may
God
Almighty
bless
and
reward
you
for
your
kindness
!
<EOS>
You
were
always
the
best
of
masters
to
my
poor
husband
;
and
now
you
've
proved
the
best
of
friends
to
his
widow
and
orphan
boy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poh
!
<EOS>
poh
!
<EOS>
say
no
more
about
it
,
"
rejoined
the
man
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
done
no
more
than
my
duty
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
and
neither
deserve
nor
desire
your
thanks
.
'
<EOS>
Whoso
giveth
to
the
poor
lendeth
to
the
Lord
;
'
that
's
my
comfort
.
<EOS>
And
such
slight
relief
as
I
can
afford
should
have
been
offered
earlier
,
if
I
'd
known
where
you
'd
taken
refuge
after
your
unfortunate
husband's--
"
 
"
Execution
,
you
would
say
,
Sir
,
"
added
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
with
a
deep
sigh
,
perceiving
that
her
benefactor
hesitated
to
pronounce
the
word
.
<EOS>
"
You
show
more
consideration
to
the
feelings
of
a
hempen
widow
,
than
there
is
any
need
to
show
.
<EOS>
I
'm
used
to
insult
as
I
am
to
misfortune
,
and
am
grown
callous
to
both
;
but
I
'm
_
not
_
used
to
compassion
,
and
know
not
how
to
take
it
.
<EOS>
My
heart
would
speak
if
it
could
,
for
it
is
very
full
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
time
,
long
,
long
ago
,
when
the
tears
would
have
rushed
to
my
eyes
unbidden
at
the
bare
mention
of
generosity
like
yours
,
Mr.
Wood
;
but
they
never
come
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
wept
since
that
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
trust
you
will
never
have
occasion
to
weep
again
,
my
poor
soul
,
"
replied
Wood
,
setting
down
his
lantern
,
and
brushing
a
few
drops
from
his
eyes
,
"
unless
it
be
tears
of
joy
.
<EOS>
Pshaw
!
"
<EOS>
added
he
,
making
an
effort
to
subdue
his
emotion
<EOS>
,
"
I
ca
n't
leave
you
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
I
must
stay
a
minute
longer
,
if
only
to
see
you
smile
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
re
-
entered
the
house
,
closed
the
door
,
and
,
followed
by
the
widow
,
proceeded
to
the
fire
-
place
,
where
a
handful
of
chips
,
apparently
just
lighted
,
crackled
within
the
rusty
grate
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
this
interview
took
place
had
a
sordid
and
miserable
look
.
<EOS>
Rotten
,
and
covered
with
a
thick
coat
of
dirt
,
the
boards
of
the
floor
presented
a
very
insecure
footing
;
the
bare
walls
were
scored
all
over
with
grotesque
designs
,
the
chief
of
which
represented
the
punishment
of
Nebuchadnezzar
.
<EOS>
The
rest
were
hieroglyphic
characters
,
executed
in
red
chalk
and
charcoal
.
<EOS>
The
ceiling
had
,
in
many
places
,
given
way
;
the
laths
had
been
removed
;
and
,
where
any
plaster
remained
,
it
was
either
mapped
and
blistered
with
damps
,
or
festooned
with
dusty
cobwebs
.
<EOS>
Over
an
old
crazy
bedstead
was
thrown
a
squalid
,
patchwork
counterpane
;
and
upon
the
counterpane
lay
a
black
hood
and
scarf
,
a
pair
of
bodice
of
the
cumbrous
form
in
vogue
at
the
beginning
of
the
last
century
,
and
some
other
articles
of
female
attire
.
<EOS>
On
a
small
shelf
near
the
foot
of
the
bed
stood
a
couple
of
empty
phials
,
a
cracked
ewer
and
basin
,
a
brown
jug
without
a
handle
,
a
small
tin
coffee
-
pot
without
a
spout
,
a
saucer
of
rouge
,
a
fragment
of
looking
-
glass
,
and
a
flask
,
labelled
"
_
Rosa
Solis
_
.
<EOS>
"
Broken
pipes
littered
the
floor
,
if
that
can
be
said
to
be
littered
,
which
,
in
the
first
instance
,
was
a
mass
of
squalor
and
filth
.
 
<EOS>
Over
the
chimney
-
piece
was
pasted
a
handbill
,
purporting
to
be
"
_
<EOS>
The
last
Dying
Speech
and
Confession
of
_
TOM
SHEPPARD
,
_
<EOS>
the
Notorious
Housebreaker
,
who
suffered
at
Tyburn
on
the
25th
of
February
,
1703
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
"
This
placard
was
adorned
with
a
rude
wood
-
cut
,
representing
the
unhappy
malefactor
at
the
place
of
execution
.
<EOS>
On
one
side
of
the
handbill
a
print
of
the
reigning
sovereign
,
Anne
,
had
been
pinned
over
the
portrait
of
William
the
Third
,
whose
aquiline
nose
,
keen
eyes
,
and
luxuriant
wig
,
were
just
visible
above
the
diadem
of
the
queen
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
a
wretched
engraving
of
the
Chevalier
de
Saint
George
,
or
,
as
he
was
styled
in
the
label
attached
to
the
portrait
,
James
the
Third
,
raised
a
suspicion
that
the
inmate
of
the
house
was
not
altogether
free
from
some
tincture
of
Jacobitism
.
 
<EOS>
Beneath
<EOS>
these
prints
,
a
cluster
of
hobnails
,
driven
into
the
wall
,
formed
certain
letters
,
which
,
if
properly

,
produced
the
words
,
"
<EOS>
_
Paul
Groves
,
cobler
;
_
"
and
under
the
name
,
traced
in
charcoal
,
appeared
the
following
record
of
the
poor
fellow
's
fate
,
"
<EOS>
_
Hung
himsel
in
this
rum
for
luv
off
licker
;
<EOS>
_
"
accompanied
by
a

unhappy

dangling

.
<EOS>
A
farthing

,

,

upon

,
which
,
owing

Wood
,
was

than

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
but

,

Sheppard
,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

"

"
but
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

"
anything
's

.
<EOS>
But

"

"
it

choice
canary
,

do

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Take

,

"
 
<EOS>
"
I

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"
<EOS>

;
"
while

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lord

!
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
Like

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
_

he

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

"

"
 
The

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

.
"
<EOS>
And

Van
Gal
--
Gal
<EOS>
--

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

but

,

<EOS>
He

Scherprechter
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

It
's
not
an
offer
,
"
continued
he
,
"
that
I
'm
likely
to
make
,
or
you
're
likely
to
receive
every
day
in
the
year
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
muttering
some
remarks
,
which
we
do
not
care
to
repeat
,
reflecting
upon
the
consistency
of
the
sex
,
he
was
preparing
once
more
to
depart
,
when
Mrs.
Sheppard
stopped
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
till
to
-
morrow
,
"
implored
she
,
"
and
if
I
_
can
_
bring
myself
to
part
with
him
,
you
shall
have
him
without
another
word
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
time
to
consider
of
it
,
"
replied
Wood
sulkily
,
"
there
's
no
hurry
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
angry
with
me
,
Sir
,
"
cried
the
widow
,
sobbing
bitterly
,
"
pray
do
n't
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
am
undeserving
of
your
bounty
;
but
if
I
were
to
tell
you
what
hardships
<EOS>
I
have
undergone
--
to
what
frightful
extremities
I
have
been
reduced
--
and
to
what
infamy
I
have
submitted
,
to
earn
a
scanty
subsistence
for
this
child
's
sake,--if
you
could
feel
what
it
is
to
stand
alone
in
the
world
as
I
do
,
bereft
of
all
who
have
ever
loved
me
,
and
shunned
by
all
who
have
ever
known
me
,
except
the
worthless
and
the
wretched,--if
<EOS>
you
knew
(
and
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
you
may
be
spared
the
knowledge
!
)
<EOS>
how
much
affliction
sharpens
love
,
and
how
much
more
dear
to
me
<EOS>
my
child
has
become
for
every
sacrifice
I
have
made
for
him,--if
you
were
told
all
this
,
you
would
,
I
am
sure
,
pity
rather
than
reproach
me
,
because
I
can
not
at
once
consent
to
a
separation
,
which
I
feel
would
break
my
heart
.
<EOS>
But
give
me
till
to
-
morrow
--
only
till
to
-
morrow
--
I
may
be
able
to
part
with
him
then
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
worthy
carpenter
was
now
far
more
angry
with
himself
than
he
had
previously
been
with
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
and
,
as
soon
as
he
could
command
his
feelings
,
which
were
considerably
excited
by
the
mention
of
her
distresses
,
he
squeezed
her
hand
warmly
,
bestowed
a
hearty
execration
upon
his
own
inhumanity
,
and
swore
he
would
neither
separate
her
from
her
child
,
nor
suffer
any
one
else
to
separate
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Plague
on't
!
<EOS>
"
added
he
:
"
I
never
meant
to
take
your
babby
from
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
'd
a
mind
to
try
whether
you
really
loved
him
as
much
as
you
pretended
.
<EOS>
I
was
to
blame
to
carry
the
matter
so
far
.
<EOS>
However
,
confession
of
a
fault
makes
half
amends
for
it
.
<EOS>
A
time
_
may
_
come
when
this
little
chap
will
need
my
aid
,
and
,
depend
upon
it
,
he
shall
never
want
a
friend
in
Owen
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
the
carpenter
patted
the
cheek
of
the
little
object
of
his
benevolent
professions
,
and
,
in
so
doing
,
unintentionally
aroused
him
from
his
slumbers
.
<EOS>
Opening
a
pair
of
large
black
eyes
,
the
child
fixed
them
for
an
instant
upon
Wood
,
and
then
,
alarmed
by
the
light
,
uttered
a
low
and
melancholy
cry
,
which
,
however
,
was
speedily
stilled
by
the
caresses
of
his
mother
,
towards
whom
he
extended
his
tiny
arms
,
as
if
imploring
protection
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
he
would
leave
me
,
even
if
I
could
part
with
him
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
smiling
through
her
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
he
would
,
"
acquiesced
the
carpenter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
friend
like
the
mother
,
for
the
babby
knows
no
other
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
that
's
true
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
"
for
if
I
had
_
not
_
been
a
mother
,
I
would
not
have
survived
the
day
on
which
I
became
a
widow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
think
of
that
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
said
Wood
in
a
soothing
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
thinking
of
it
,
Sir
,
"
answered
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
never
get
poor
Tom
's
last
look
out
of
my
head
,
as
he
stood
in
the
Stone
-
Hall
at
Newgate
,
after
his
irons
had
been
knocked
off
,
unless
I
manage
to
stupify
myself
somehow
.
<EOS>
The
dismal
tolling
of
St.
Sepulchre
's
bell
is
for
ever
ringing
in
my
ears
--
oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
that
's
the
case
,
"
observed
Wood
,
"
I
'm
surprised
you
should
like
to
have
such
a
frightful
picture
constantly
in
view
as
that
over
the
chimney
-
piece
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
good
reasons
for
placing
it
there
,
Sir
;
but
do
n't
question
me
about
them
now
,
or
you
'll
drive
me
mad
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Sheppard
wildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
we
'll
say
no
more
about
it
,
"
replied
Wood
;
"
and
,
by
way
of
changing
the
subject
,
let
me
advise
you
on
no
account
to
fly
to
strong
waters
for
consolation
,
Joan
.
<EOS>
One
nail
drives
out
another
,
it
's
true
;
but
the
worst
nail
you
can
employ
is
a
coffin
-
nail
.
<EOS>
Gin
Lane
's
the
nearest
road
to
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
;
but
if
it
shortens
the
distance
and
lightens
the
journey
,
I
care
not
,
"
retorted
the
widow
,
who
seemed
by
this
reproach
to
be
roused
into
sudden
eloquence
.
"
<EOS>
To
those
who
,
like
me
,
have
never
been
able
to
get
out
of
the
dark
and
dreary
paths
of
life
,
the
grave
is
indeed
a
refuge
,
and
the
sooner
they
reach
it
the
better
.
<EOS>
The
spirit
I
drink
may
be
poison,--it
may
kill
me,--perhaps
<EOS>
it
<EOS>
_
is
_
killing
me:--but
<EOS>
so
would
hunger
,
cold
<EOS>
,
misery,--so
would
my
own
thoughts
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
gone
mad
without
it
.
<EOS>
Gin
is
the
poor
man
's
friend,--his
sole
set
-
off
against
the
rich
man
's
luxury
.
<EOS>
It
comforts
him
when
he
is
most
forlorn
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
treacherous
,
it
may
lay
up
a
store
of
future
woe
;
but
it
insures
present
happiness
,
and
that
is
sufficient
.
<EOS>
When
I
have
traversed
the
streets
a
houseless
wanderer
,
driven
with
curses
from
every
door
where
I
have
solicited
alms
,
and
with
blows
from
every
gateway
where
I
have
sought
shelter,--when
<EOS>
I
have
crept
into
some
deserted
building
,
and
stretched
my
wearied
limbs
upon
a
bulk
,
in
the
vain
hope
of
repose,--or
,
worse
than
all
,
when
,
frenzied
with
want
,
I
have
yielded
to
horrible
temptation
,
and
earned
a
meal
in
the
only
way
I
could
earn
<EOS>
one,--when
<EOS>
I
have
felt
,
at
times
like
these
,
my
heart
sink
within
me
,
I
have
drank
of
this
drink
,
and
have
at
once
forgotten
my
cares
,
my
poverty
,
my
guilt
.
<EOS>
Old
thoughts
,
old
feelings
,
old
faces
,
and
old
scenes
have
returned
to
me
,
and
I
have
fancied
myself
<EOS>
happy,--as
happy
as
I
am
now
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
she
burst
into
a
wild
hysterical
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
creature
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
call
this
frantic
glee
happiness
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
the
happiness
I
have
known
for
years
,
"
returned
the
widow
,
becoming
suddenly
calm
,
"
and
it
's
short
-
lived
enough
,
as
you
perceive
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
,
Mr.
Wood
,
"
added
she
in
a
hollow
voice
,
and
with
a
ghastly
look
,
"
gin
may
bring
ruin
;
but
as
long
as
poverty
,
vice
,
and
ill
-
usage
exist
,
it
will
be
drunk
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
God
forbid
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Wood
,
fervently
;
and
,
as
if
afraid
of
prolonging
the
interview
,
he
added
,
with
some
precipitation
,
"
<EOS>
But
I
must
be
going
<EOS>
:
I
've
stayed
here
too
long
already
.
<EOS>
You
shall
hear
from
me
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
again
arresting
his
departure
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
just
recollected
that
my
husband
left
a
key
with
me
,
which
he
charged
me
to
give
you
when
I
could
find
an
opportunity
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
key
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Wood
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
I
lost
a
very
valuable
one
some
time
ago
.
<EOS>
What
's
it
like
,
Joan
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
small
key
,
with
curiously
-
fashioned
wards
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
mine
,
I
'll
be
sworn
,
"
rejoined
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
who
'd
have
thought
of
finding
it
in
this
unexpected
way
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
too
sure
till
you
see
it
,
"
said
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
fetch
it
for
you
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
trouble
you
to
hold
the
child
,
then
,
for
a
minute
,
while
I
run
up
to
the
garret
,
where
I
've
hidden
it
for
safety
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
_
may
_
trust
him
with
you
,
Sir
,
"
added
she
,
taking
up
the
candle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
leave
him
,
if
you
're
at
all
fearful
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
Wood
,
receiving
the
little
burthen
with
a
laugh
.
"
Poor
thing
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
he
,
as
the
widow
departed
on
her
errand
,
"
she
's
seen
better
days
and
better
circumstances
than
she
'll
ever
see
again
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
Strange
,
I
could
never
learn
her
history
.
<EOS>
Tom
Sheppard
was
always
a
close
file
,
and
would
never
tell
whom
he
married
.
<EOS>
Of
this
I
'm
certain
,
however
,
she
was
much
too
good
for
him
,
and
was
never
meant
to
be
a
journeyman
carpenter
's
wife
,
still
less
what
is
she
now
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
's
in
the
right
place
,
at
all
events
;
and
,
since
that
's
the
case
,
the
rest
may
perhaps
come
round,--that
is
,
if
she
gets
through
her
present
illness
.
<EOS>
A
dry
cough
's
the
trumpeter
of
death
.
<EOS>
If
that
's
true
,
she
's
not
long
for
this
world
.
<EOS>
As
to
this
little
fellow
,
in
spite
of
the
Dutchman
,
who
,
in
my
opinion
,
is
more
of
a
Jacobite
than
a
conjurer
,
and
more
of
a
knave
than
either
,
he
shall
never
mount
a
horse
foaled
by
an
acorn
,
if
I
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
course
of
the
carpenter
's
meditations
was
here
interrupted
by
a
loud
note
of
lamentation
from
the
child
,
who
,
disturbed
by
the
transfer
,
and
not
receiving
the
gentle
solace
to
which
he
was
ordinarily
accustomed
,
raised
his
voice
to
the
utmost
,
and
exerted
his
feeble
strength
to
escape
.
<EOS>
For
a
few
moments
Mr.
Wood
dandled
his
little
charge
to
and
fro
,
after
the
most
approved
nursery
fashion
,
essaying
at
the
same
time
the
soothing
influence
of
an
infantine
melody
proper
to
the
occasion
;
but
,
failing
in
his
design
,
he
soon
lost
all
patience
,
and
being
,
as
we
have
before
hinted
,
rather
irritable
,
though
extremely
well
-
meaning
,
he
lifted
the
unhappy
bantling
in
the
air
,
and
shook
him
with
so
much
good
will
,
that
he
had
well
-
nigh
silenced
him
most
effectually
.
<EOS>
A
brief
calm
succeeded
.
<EOS>
But
with
returning
breath
came
returning
vociferations
;
and
the
carpenter
,
with
a
faint
hope
of
lessening
the
clamour
by
change
of
scene
,
took
up
his
lantern
,
opened
the
door
,
and
walked
out
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II
.
 
<EOS>
The
Old
Mint
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
habitation
terminated
a
row
of
old
ruinous
buildings
,
called
Wheeler
's
Rents
;
a
dirty
thoroughfare
,
part
street
,
and
part
lane
,
running
from
Mint
Street
,
through
a
variety
of
turnings
,
and
along
the
brink
of
a
deep
kennel
,
skirted
by
a
number
of
petty
and
neglected
gardens
in
the
direction
of
Saint
George
's
Fields
.
<EOS>
The
neighbouring
houses
were
tenanted
by
the
lowest
order
of
insolvent
traders
,
thieves
,
mendicants
,
and
other
worthless
and
nefarious
characters
,
who
fled
thither
to
escape
from
their
creditors
,
or
to
avoid
the
punishment
due
to
their
different
offenses
;
for
we
may
observe
that
the
Old
Mint
,
although
it
had
been
divested
of
some
of
its
privileges
as
a
sanctuary
by
a
recent
statute
passed
in
the
reign
of
William
the
Third
,
still
presented
a
safe
asylum
to
the
debtor
,
and
even
continued
to
do
so
until
the
middle
of
the
reign
of
George
the
First
,
when
the
crying
nature
of
the
evil
called
loudly
for
a
remedy
,
and
another
and
more
sweeping
enactment
entirely
took
away
its
immunities
.
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
the
encouragement
thus
offered
to
dishonesty
,
and
the
security
afforded
to
crime
,
this
quarter
of
the
Borough
of
Southwark
was
accounted
(
at
the
period
of
our
narrative
)
<EOS>
the
grand
receptacle
of
the
superfluous
villainy
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
Infested
by
every
description
of
vagabond
and
miscreant
,
it
was
,
perhaps
,
a
few
degrees
worse
than
the
rookery
near
Saint
Giles
's
and
the
desperate
neighbourhood
of
Saffron
Hill
in
our
own
time
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
on
the
very
site
of
the
sordid
tenements
and
squalid
courts
we
have
mentioned
,
where
the
felon
openly
made
his
dwelling
,
and
the
fraudulent
debtor
laughed
the
object
of
his
knavery
to
scorn
--
on
this
spot
,
not
two
centuries
ago
,
stood
the
princely
residence
of
Charles
Brandon
,
the
chivalrous
Duke
of
Suffolk
,
whose
stout
heart
was
a
well
of
honour
,
and
whose
memory
breathes
of
loyalty
and
valour
.
<EOS>
Suffolk
House
,
as
Brandon
's
palace
was
denominated
,
was
subsequently
converted
into
a
mint
by
his
royal
brother
-
in
-
law
,
Henry
the
Eighth
;
and
,
after
its
demolition
,
and
the
removal
of
the
place
of
coinage
to
the
Tower
,
the
name
was
still
continued
to
the
district
in
which
it
had
been
situated
.
 
<EOS>
Old
and
dilapidated
,
the
widow
's
domicile
looked
the
very
picture
of
desolation
and
misery
.
<EOS>
Nothing
more
forlorn
could
be
conceived
.
<EOS>
The
roof
was
partially
untiled
;
the
chimneys
were
tottering
;
the
side
-
walls
bulged
,
and
were
supported
by
a
piece
of
timber
propped
against
the
opposite
house
;
the
glass
in
most
of
the
windows
was
broken
,
and
its
place
supplied
with
paper
;
while
,
in
some
cases
,
the
very
frames
of
the
windows
had
been
destroyed
,
and
the
apertures
were
left
free
to
the
airs
of
heaven
.
<EOS>
On
the
groundfloor
the
shutters
were
closed
,
or
,
to
speak
more
correctly
,
altogether
nailed
up
,
and
presented
a
very
singular
appearance
,
being
patched
all
over
with
the
soles
of
old
shoes
,
rusty
hobnails
,
and
bits
of
iron
hoops
,
the
ingenious
device
of
the
former
occupant
of
the
apartment
,
Paul
Groves
,
the
cobbler
,
to
whom
we
have
before
alluded
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
owing
to
the
untimely
end
of
this
poor
fellow
that
Mrs.
Sheppard
was
enabled
to
take
possession
of
the
premises
.
<EOS>
In
a
fit
of
despondency
,
superinduced
by
drunkenness
,
he
made
away
with
himself
;
and
when
the
body
was
discovered
,
after
a
lapse
of
some
months
,
such
was
the
impression
produced
by
the
spectacle
--
such
the
alarm
occasioned
by
the
crazy
state
of
the
building
,
and
,
above
all
,
by
the
terror
inspired
by
strange
and
unearthly
noises
heard
during
the
night
,
which
were
,
of
course
,
attributed
to
the
spirit
of
the
suicide
,
that
the
place
speedily
enjoyed
the
reputation
of
being
haunted
,
and
was
,
consequently
,
entirely
abandoned
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
Mrs.
Sheppard
found
it
;
and
,
as
no
one
opposed
her
,
she
at
once
took
up
her
abode
there
;
nor
was
she
long
in
discovering
that
the
dreaded
sounds
proceeded
from
the
nocturnal
gambols
of
a
legion
of
rats
.
 
<EOS>
A
narrow
entry
,
formed
by
two
low
walls
,
communicated
with
the
main
thoroughfare
;
and
in
this
passage
,
under
the
cover
of
a
penthouse
,
stood
Wood
,
with
his
little
burthen
,
to
whom
we
shall
now
return
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mrs.
Sheppard
did
not
make
her
appearance
quite
so
soon
as
he
expected
,
the
carpenter
became
a
little
fidgetty
,
and
,
having
succeeded
in
tranquillizing
the
child
,
he
thought
proper
to
walk
so
far
down
the
entry
as
would
enable
him
to
reconnoitre
the
upper
windows
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
A
light
was
visible
in
the
garret
,
feebly
struggling
through
the
damp
atmosphere
,
for
the
night
was
raw
and
overcast
.
<EOS>
This
light
did
not
remain
stationary
,
but
could
be
seen
at
one
moment
glimmering
through
the
rents
in
the
roof
,
and
at
another
shining
through
the
cracks
in
the
wall
,
or
the
broken
panes
of
the
casement
.
<EOS>
Wood
was
unable
to
discover
the
figure
of
the
widow
,
but
he
recognised
her
dry
,
hacking
cough
,
and
was
about
to
call
her
down
,
if
she
could
not
find
the
key
,
as
he
imagined
must
be
the
case
,
when
a
loud
noise
was
heard
,
as
though
a
chest
,
or
some
weighty
substance
,
had
fallen
upon
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
Before
Wood
had
time
to
inquire
into
the
cause
of
this
sound
,
his
attention
was
diverted
by
a
man
,
who
rushed
past
the
entry
with
the
swiftness
of
desperation
.
<EOS>
This
individual
apparently
met
with
some
impediment
to
his
further
progress
;
for
he
had
not
proceeded
many
steps
when
he
turned
suddenly
about
,
and
darted
up
the
passage
in
which
Wood
stood
.
 
<EOS>
Uttering
a
few
inarticulate
<EOS>
ejaculations,--for
he
was
completely
out
of
breath,--the
fugitive
placed
a
bundle
in
the
arms
of
the
carpenter
,
and
,
regardless
of
the
consternation
he
excited
in
the
breast
of
that
personage
,
who
was
almost
stupified
with
astonishment
,
he
began
to
divest
himself
of
a
heavy
horseman
's
cloak
,
which
he
threw
over
Wood
's
shoulder
,
and
,
drawing
his
sword
,
<EOS>
seemed
to
listen
intently
for
the
approach
of
his
pursuers
.
 
<EOS>
The
appearance
of
the
new
-
comer
was
extremely
prepossessing
;
and
,
after
his
trepidation
had
a
little
subsided
,
Wood
began
to
regard
him
with
some
degree
of
interest
.
<EOS>
Evidently
in
the
flower
of
his
age
,
he
was
scarcely
less
remarkable
for
symmetry
of
person
than
for
comeliness
of
feature
;
and
,
though
his
attire
was
plain
and
unpretending
,
it
was
such
as
could
be
worn
only
by
one
belonging
to
the
higher
ranks
of
society
.
<EOS>
His
figure
was
tall
and
commanding
,
and
the
expression
of
his
countenance
(
though
somewhat
disturbed
by
his
recent
exertion
)
was
resolute
and
stern
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
a
cry
burst
from
the
child
,
who
,
nearly
smothered
by
the
weight
imposed
upon
him
,
only
recovered
the
use
of
his
lungs
as
Wood
altered
the
position
of
the
bundle
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
turned
his
head
at
the
sound
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
Heaven
!
"
cried
he
in
a
tone
of
surprise
,
"
you
have
an
infant
there
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
I
have
,
"
replied
Wood
,
angrily
;
for
,
finding
that
the
intentions
of
the
stranger
were
pacific
,
so
far
as
he
was
concerned
,
he
thought
he
might
safely
venture
on
a
slight
display
of
spirit
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
well
you
have
n't
crushed
the
poor
little
thing
to
death
with
this
confounded
clothes'-bag
.
<EOS>
But
some
people
have
no
consideration
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
child
may
be
the
means
of
saving
me
,
"
muttered
the
stranger
,
as
if
struck
by
a
new
idea
:
"
I
shall
gain
time
by
the
expedient
.
<EOS>
Do
you
live
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
,
"
answered
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
.
<EOS>
The
door
is
open
,
so
it
is
needless
to
ask
leave
to
enter
.
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
stranger
,
as
shouts
and
other
vociferations
resounded
at
no
great
distance
along
the
thoroughfare
,
"
not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
.
<EOS>
Give
me
that
precious
charge
,
"
he
added
,
snatching
the
bundle
from
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
escape
,
I
will
reward
you
.
<EOS>
Your
name
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Owen
Wood
,
"
replied
the
carpenter
;
"
I
've
no
reason
to
be
ashamed
of
it
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
a
fair
exchange
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Yours
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
hesitated
.
<EOS>
The
shouts
drew
nearer
,
and
lights
were
seen
flashing
ruddily
against
the
sides
and
gables
of
the
neighbouring
houses
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Darrell
,
"
said
the
fugitive
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
are
discovered
,
answer
no
questions
,
as
you
value
your
life
.
<EOS>
Wrap
yourself
in
my
cloak
,
and
keep
it
.
<EOS>
Remember
!
<EOS>
not
a
word
!
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
huddled
the
mantle
over
Wood
's
shoulders
,
dashed
the
lantern
to
the
ground
,
and
extinguished
the
light
.
<EOS>
A
moment
afterwards
,
the
door
was
closed
and
bolted
,
and
the
carpenter
found
himself
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
"
<EOS>
cried
he
,
as
a
thrill
of
apprehension
ran
through
his
frame
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Dutchman
was
right
,
after
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
exclamation
had
scarcely
escaped
him
,
when
the
discharge
of
a
pistol
was
heard
,
and
a
bullet
whizzed
past
his
ears
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
voice
in
triumph
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
,
then
,
rushed
up
the
entry
,
and
,
seizing
the
unlucky
carpenter
by
the
collar
,
presented
a
drawn
sword
to
his
throat
.
<EOS>
This
person
was
speedily
followed
by
half
a
dozen
others
,
some
of
whom
carried
flambeaux
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mur
--
der
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Wood
,
struggling
to
free
himself
from
his
assailant
,
by
whom
he
was
half
strangled
.
 
<EOS>
"
Damnation
!
"
exclaimed
one
of
the
leaders
of
the
party
in
a
furious
tone
,
snatching
a
torch
from
an
attendant
,
and
throwing
its
light
full
upon
the
face
of
the
carpenter
;
"
this
is
not
the
villain
,
Sir
Cecil
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
find
,
Rowland
,
"
replied
the
other
,
in
accents
of
deep
disappointment
,
and
at
the
same
time
relinquishing
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
sworn
I
saw
him
enter
this
passage
.
<EOS>
And
how
comes
his
cloak
on
this
knave
's
shoulders
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
his
cloak
,
of
a
surety
,
"
returned
Rowland
"
Harkye
,
sirrah
,
"
<EOS>
continued
he
,
haughtily
interrogating
Wood
;
"
where
is
the
person
from
whom
you
received
this
mantle
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Throttling
a
man
is
n't
the
way
to
make
him
answer
questions
,
"
replied
the
carpenter
,
doggedly
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
get
nothing
out
of
me
<EOS>
,
I
can
promise
you
,
unless
you
show
a
little
more
civility
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
waste
time
with
this
fellow
,
"
interposed
Sir
Cecil
,
"
and
may
lose
the
object
of
our
quest
,
who
,
beyond
doubt
,
has
taken
refuge
in
this
building
.
<EOS>
Let
us
search
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Just
then
,
the
infant
began
to
sob
piteously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hist
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rowland
,
arresting
his
comrade
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
that
!
<EOS>
We
are
not
wholly
at
fault
.
<EOS>
The
dog
-
fox
can
not
be
far
off
,
since
the
cub
is
found
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
tore
the
mantle
from
Wood
's
back
,
and
,
perceiving
the
child
,
endeavoured
to
seize
it
.
<EOS>
In
this
attempt
he
was
,
however
,
foiled
by
the
agility
of
the
carpenter
,
who
managed
to
retreat
to
the
door
,
against
which
he
placed
his
back
,
kicking
the
boards
vigorously
with
his
heel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Joan
!
<EOS>
Joan
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
he
,
"
open
the
door
,
for
God
's
sake
,
or
I
shall
be
murdered
,
and
so
will
your
babby
!
<EOS>
Open
the
door
quickly
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Knock
him
on
the
head
,
"
thundered
Sir
Cecil
,
"
or
we
shall
have
the
watch
upon
us
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
fear
of
that
,
"
rejoined
Rowland
:
"
such
vermin
never
dare
to
show
themselves
in
this
privileged
district
.
<EOS>
All
we
have
to
apprehend
is
a
rescue
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
hint
was
not
lost
upon
Wood
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
raise
an
outcry
,
but
his
throat
was
again
forcibly
griped
by
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
Another
such
attempt
,
"
said
the
latter
,
"
and
you
are
a
dead
man
.
<EOS>
Yield
up
the
babe
,
and
I
pledge
my
word
you
shall
remain
unmolested
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
yield
it
to
no
one
but
its
mother
,
"
answered
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sdeath
!
<EOS>
do
you
trifle
with
me
,
sirrah
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Rowland
fiercely
.
"
<EOS>
Give
me
the
child
,
or--
"
 
As
he
spoke
the
door
was
thrown
open
,
and
Mrs.
Sheppard
staggered
forward
.
<EOS>
She
looked
paler
than
ever
;
but
her
countenance
,
though
bewildered
,
did
not
exhibit
the
alarm
which
might
naturally
have
been
anticipated
from
the
strange
and
perplexing
scene
presented
to
her
view
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
it
,
"
cried
Wood
,
holding
the
infant
towards
her
;
"
take
it
,
and
fly
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
put
out
her
arms
mechanically
.
<EOS>
But
before
the
child
could
be
committed
to
her
care
,
it
was
wrested
from
the
carpenter
by
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
These
people
are
all
in
league
with
him
,
"
cried
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"
But
do
n't
wait
for
me
,
Sir
Cecil
.
<EOS>
Enter
the
house
with
your
men
.
<EOS>
I
'll
dispose
of
the
brat
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
injunction
was
instantly
obeyed
.
<EOS>
The
knight
and
his
followers
crossed
the
threshold
,
leaving
one
of
the
torch
-
bearers
behind
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Davies
,
"
said
Rowland
,
delivering
the
babe
,
with
a
meaning
look
,
to
his
attendant
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Davies
,
drawing
a
little
aside
.
<EOS>
And
,
setting
down
the
link
,
he
proceeded
deliberately
to
untie
his
cravat
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
God
!
will
you
see
your
child
strangled
before
your
eyes
,
and
not
so
much
as
scream
for
help
?
"
said
Wood
,
staring
at
the
widow
with
a
look
of
surprise
and
horror
.
<EOS>
"
Woman
,
your
wits
are
fled
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
it
seemed
;
for
all
the
answer
she
could
make
was
to
murmur
distractedly
,
"
I
ca
n't
find
the
key
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Devil
take
the
key
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
They
're
about
to
murder
your
child--_your
_
child
,
I
tell
you
!
<EOS>
Do
you
comprehend
what
I
say
,
Joan
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
hurt
my
head
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
pressing
her
hand
to
her
temples
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
,
for
the
first
time
,
Wood
noticed
a
small
stream
of
blood
coursing
slowly
down
her
cheek
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Davies
,
who
had
completed
his
preparations
,
extinguished
the
torch
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
over
,
"
groaned
Wood
,
"
and
perhaps
it
's
<EOS>
as
well
her
senses
are
gone
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
'll
make
a
last
effort
to
save
the
poor
little
creature
,
if
it
costs
me
my
life
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
with
this
generous
resolve
,
he
shouted
at
the
top
of
his
voice
,
"
Arrest
!
<EOS>
arrest
!
<EOS>
help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
<EOS>
seconding
the
words
with
a
shrill
and
peculiar
cry
,
well
known
at
the
time
to
the
inhabitants
of
the
quarter
in
which
it
was
uttered
.
 
<EOS>
In
reply
to
this
summons
a
horn
was
instantly
blown
at
the
corner
of
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
"
Arrest
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mint
!
<EOS>
Mint
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Death
and
hell
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rowland
,
making
a
furious
pass
at
the
carpenter
,
who
fortunately
avoided
the
thrust
in
the
darkness
;
"
will
nothing
silence
you
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Help
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wood
,
renewing
his
cries
.
<EOS>
"
Arrest
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jigger
closed
!
"
shouted
a
hoarse
voice
in
reply
.
<EOS>
"
All
's
bowman
,
my
covey
.
<EOS>
Fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
We
'll
be
upon
the
ban
-
dogs
before
they
can
shake
their
trotters
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
alarm
was
sounded
more
loudly
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Another
horn
now
resounded
from
the
further
extremity
of
the
thoroughfare
;
this
was
answered
by
a
third
;
and
presently
a
fourth
,
and
more
remote
blast
,
took
up
the
note
of
alarm
.
<EOS>
The
whole
neighbourhood
was
disturbed
.
<EOS>
A
garrison
called
to
arms
at
dead
of
night
on
the
sudden
approach
of
the
enemy
,
could
not
have
been
more
expeditiously
,
or
effectually
aroused
.
<EOS>
Rattles
were
sprung
;
lanterns
lighted
,
and
hoisted
at
the
end
of
poles
<EOS>
;
windows
thrown
open
;
doors
unbarred
;
and
,
as
if
by
magic
,
the
street
was
instantaneously
filled
with
a
crowd
of
persons
of
both
sexes
,
armed
with
such
weapons
as
came
most
readily
to
hand
,
and
dressed
in
such
garments
as
could
be
most
easily
slipped
on
.
<EOS>
Hurrying
in
the
direction
of
the
supposed
arrest
,
they
encouraged
each
other
with
shouts
,
and
threatened
the
offending
parties
with
their
vengeance
.
 
<EOS>
Regardless
as
the
gentry
of
the
Mint
usually
were
(
for
,
indeed
,
they
had
become
habituated
from
their
frequent
occurrence
to
such
scenes
,
)
of
any
outrages
committed
in
their
streets
;
deaf
,
as
they
had
been
,
to
the
recent
scuffle
before
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
door
,
they
were
always
sufficiently
on
the
alert
to
maintain
their
privileges
,
and
to
assist
each
other
against
the
attacks
of
their
common
enemy
--
the
sheriff
's
officer
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
by
the
adoption
of
such
a
course
(
especially
since
the
late
act
of
suppression
,
to
which
we
have
alluded
,
)
that
the
inviolability
of
the
asylum
could
be
preserved
.
<EOS>
Incursions
were
often
made
upon
its
territories
by
the
functionaries
of
the
law
;
sometimes
attended
with
success
,
but
more
frequently
with
discomfiture
;
and
it
rarely
happened
,
unless
by
stratagem
or
bribery
,
that
(
in
the
language
of
the
gentlemen
of
the
short
staff
)
an
important
caption
could
be
effected
.
<EOS>
In
order
to
guard
against
accidents
or
surprises
,
watchmen
,
or
scouts
,
(
as
they
were
styled
,
)
were
stationed
at
the
three
main
outlets
of
the
sanctuary
ready
to
give
the
signal
in
the
manner
<EOS>
just
described
:
bars
were
erected
,
which
,
in
case
of
emergency
;
could
be
immediately
stretched
across
the
streets
:
doors
were
attached
to
the
alleys
;
and
were
never
opened
without
due
precautions
;
gates
were
affixed
to
the
courts
,
wickets
to
the
gates
,
and
bolts
to
the
wickets
.
<EOS>
The
back
windows
of
the
houses
(
where
any
such
existed
)
were
strongly
barricaded
,
and
kept
constantly
shut
;
and
the
fortress
was
,
furthermore
,
defended
by
high
walls
and
deep
ditches
in
those
quarters
where
it
appeared
most
exposed
.
<EOS>
There
was
also
a
Maze
,
(
the
name
is
still
retained
in
the
district
,
)
into
which
the
debtor
could
run
,
and
through
the
intricacies
of
which
it
was
impossible
for
an
officer
to
follow
him
,
without
a
clue
.
<EOS>
Whoever
chose
to
incur
the
risk
of
so
doing
might
enter
the
Mint
at
any
hour
;
but
no
one
was
suffered
to
depart
without
giving
a
satisfactory
account
of
himself
,
or
producing
a
pass
from
the
Master
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
every
contrivance
that
ingenuity
could
devise
was
resorted
to
by
this
horde
of
reprobates
to
secure
themselves
from
danger
or
molestation
.
<EOS>
Whitefriars
had
lost
its
privileges
;
Salisbury
Court
and
the
Savoy
no
longer
offered
places
of
refuge
to
the
debtor
;
and
it
was
,
therefore
,
<EOS>
doubly
requisite
that
the
Island
of
Bermuda
(
as
the
Mint
was
termed
by
its
occupants
)
<EOS>
should
uphold
its
rights
,
as
long
as
it
was
able
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
,
meantime
,
had
not
remained
idle
.
<EOS>
Aware
that
not
a
moment
was
to
be
lost
,
if
he
meant
to
render
any
effectual
assistance
to
the
child
,
he
ceased
shouting
,
and
defending
himself
in
the
best
way
he
could
from
the
attacks
of
Rowland
,
by
whom
he
was
closely
pressed
,
forced
his
way
,
in
spite
of
all
opposition
,
to
Davies
,
and
dealt
him
a
blow
on
the
head
with
such
good
will
that
,
had
it
not
been
for
the
intervention
of
the
wall
,
the
ruffian
must
have
been
prostrated
.
<EOS>
Before
he
could
recover
from
the
stunning
effects
of
the
blow
,
Wood
possessed
himself
of
the
child
:
and
,
untying
the
noose
which
had
been
slipped
round
its
throat
,
had
the
satisfaction
of
hearing
it
cry
lustily
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
Sir
Cecil
and
his
followers
appeared
at
the
threshold
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
escaped
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
knight
;
"
we
have
searched
every
corner
of
the
house
without
finding
a
trace
of
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Back
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
hear
those
shouts
?
<EOS>
Yon
fellow
's
clamour
has
brought
the
whole
horde
of
jail
-
birds
and
cut
-
throats
that
infest
this
place
about
our
ears
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
torn
in
pieces
if
we
are
discovered
.
<EOS>
Davies
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
calling
to
the
attendant
,
who
was
menacing
Wood
with
a
severe
retaliation
,
"
do
n't
heed
him
;
but
,
if
you
value
a
whole
skin
,
come
into
the
house
,
and
bring
that
woman
with
you
.
<EOS>
She
may
afford
us
some
necessary
information
.
"
 
<EOS>
Davies
reluctantly
complied
.
<EOS>
And
,
dragging
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
who
made
no
resistance
,
along
with
him
,
entered
the
house
,
the
door
of
which
was
instantly
shut
and
barricaded
.
 
<EOS>
A
moment
afterwards
,
the
street
was
illumined
by
a
blaze
of
torchlight
,
and
a
tumultuous
uproar
,
mixed
with
the
clashing
of
weapons
,
and
the
braying
of
horns
,
announced
the
arrival
of
the
first
detachment
of
Minters
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
rushed
instantly
to
meet
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hurrah
!
"
shouted
he
,
waving
his
hat
triumphantly
over
his
head
.
"
<EOS>
Saved
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
it
's
all
bob
,
my
covey
!
<EOS>
You
're
safe
enough
,
that
's
certain
!
<EOS>
"
responded
the
Minters
,
baying
,
yelping
,
leaping
,
and
howling
around
him
like
a
pack
of
hounds
when
the
huntsman
is
beating
cover
;
"
but
,
where
are
the
lurchers
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
asked
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
traps
!
"
responded
a
bystander
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
shoulder
-
clappers
!
<EOS>
"
added
a
lady
,
who
,
in
her
anxiety
to
join
the
party
,
had
unintentionally
substituted
her
husband
's
nether
habiliments
for
her
own
petticoats
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
ban
-
dogs
!
"
thundered
a
tall
man
,
whose
stature
and
former
avocations
had
procured
him
the
nickname
of
"
The
long
drover
of
the
Borough
market
.
"
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
where
are
they
?
<EOS>
"
chorussed
the
mob
,
flourishing
their
various
weapons
,
and
flashing
their
torches
in
the
air
;
"
we
'll
starve
'em
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
trembled
.
<EOS>
He
felt
he
had
raised
a
storm
which
it
would
be
very
difficult
,
if
not
impossible
,
to
allay
.
<EOS>
He
knew
not
what
to
say
,
or
what
to
do
;
and
his
confusion
was
increased
by
the
threatening
gestures
and
furious
looks
of
the
ruffians
in
his
immediate
vicinity
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
gentlemen
,
"
stammered
he
,
at
length
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
he
say
?
<EOS>
"
roared
the
long
drover
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
says
he
do
n't
understand
flash
,
"
replied
the
lady
in
gentleman
's
attire
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cease
your
confounded
clutter
!
"
said
a
young
man
,
whose
swarthy
visage
,
seen
in
the
torchlight
,
struck
Wood
as
being
that
of
a
Mulatto
.
<EOS>
"
You
frighten
the
cull
out
of
his
senses
.
<EOS>
It
's
plain
he
do
n't
understand
our
lingo
;
as
,
how
should
he
?
<EOS>
Take
pattern
by
me
;
"
and
as
he
said
this
he
strode
up
to
the
carpenter
,
and
,
slapping
him
on
the
shoulder
,
propounded
the
following
questions
,
accompanying
each
interrogation
with
a
formidable
contortion
of
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
Curse
you
!
<EOS>
Where
are
the
bailiffs
?
<EOS>
Rot
you
!
<EOS>
have
you
lost
your
tongue
?
<EOS>
Devil
seize
you
!
<EOS>
you
could
bawl
loud
enough
a
moment
ago
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Silence
,
Blueskin
!
"
interposed
an
authoritative
voice
,
immediately
behind
the
ruffian
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
me
have
a
word
with
the
cull
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
<EOS>
ay
!
"
<EOS>
cried
several
of
the
bystanders
,
"
let
Jonathan
kimbaw
the
cove
.
<EOS>
He
's
got
the
gift
of
the
gab
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
accordingly
drew
aside
,
and
the
individual
,
in
whose
behalf
the
movement
had
been
made
immediately
stepped
forward
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
man
of
about
two
-
and
-
twenty
,
who
,
without
having
anything
remarkable
either
in
dress
or
appearance
,
was
yet
a
noticeable
person
,
if
only
for
the
indescribable
expression
of
cunning
pervading
his
countenance
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
small
and
grey
;
as
far
apart
and
as
sly
-
looking
as
those
of
a
fox
.
<EOS>
A
physiognomist
,
indeed
,
would
have
likened
him
to
that
crafty
animal
,
and
it
must
be
owned
the
general
formation
of
his
features
favoured
such
a
comparison
.
<EOS>
The
nose
was
long
and
sharp
,
the
chin
pointed
,
the
forehead
broad
and
flat
,
and
connected
,
without
any
intervening
hollow
,
with
the
eyelid
;
the
teeth
when
displayed
,
seemed
to
reach
from
ear
to
ear
.
<EOS>
Then
his
beard
was
of
a
reddish
hue
,
and
his
complexion
warm
and
sanguine
.
<EOS>
Those
who
had
seen
him
slumbering
,
averred
that
he
slept
with
his
eyes
open
.
<EOS>
But
this
might
be
merely
a
figurative
mode
of
describing
his
customary
vigilance
.
<EOS>
Certain
it
was
,
that
the
slightest
sound
aroused
him
.
<EOS>
This
astute
personage
was
somewhat
under
the
middle
size
,
but
fairly
proportioned
,
inclining
rather
to
strength
than
symmetry
,
and
abounding
more
in
muscle
than
in
flesh
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
seem
,
from
the
attention
which
he
evidently
bestowed
upon
the
hidden
and
complex
machinery
of
the
grand
system
of
villany
at
work
around
him
,
that
his
chief
object
in
taking
up
his
quarters
in
the
Mint
,
must
have
been
to
obtain
some
private
information
respecting
the
habits
and
practices
of
its
inhabitants
,
to
be
turned
to
account
hereafter
.
 
<EOS>
Advancing
towards
Wood
,
Jonathan
fixed
his
keen
gray
eyes
upon
him
,
and
demanded
,
in
a
stern
tone
whether
the
persons
who
had
taken
refuge
in
the
adjoining
house
,
were
bailiffs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
know
of
,
"
replied
the
carpenter
,
who
had
in
some
degree
recovered
his
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
presume
you
've
not
been
arrested
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
,
"
answered
Wood
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
guessed
as
much
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
'll
next
inform
us
why
you
have
occasioned
this
disturbance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
this
child
's
life
was
threatened
by
the
persons
you
have
mentioned
,
"
rejoined
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
excellent
reason
,
i
'
faith
!
"
exclaimed
Blueskin
,
with
a
roar
of
surprise
and
indignation
,
which
was
echoed
by
the
whole
assemblage
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
we
're
to
be
summoned
from
our
beds
and
snug
firesides
,
because
a
kid
happens
to
squall
,
eh
?
<EOS>
By
the
soul
of
my
grandmother
,
but
this
is
too
good
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
intend
to
claim
the
privileges
of
the
Mint
?
"
said
Jonathan
,
calmly
pursuing
his
interrogations
amid
the

.
<EOS>
"
Is
your
person
in
danger
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
from
my
creditors
,
"
replied
Wood
,
significantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
he
post
the
cole
?
<EOS>
Will
he
come
down
with
the
dues
?
<EOS>
Ask
him
that
?
"
cried
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
,
"
pursued
Jonathan
;
"
my
friend
desires
to
know
if
you
are
willing
to
pay
your
footing
as
a
member
of
the
ancient
and
respectable
fraternity
of
debtors
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
owe
no
man
a
farthing
,
and
my
name
shall
never
appear
in
any
such
rascally
list
,
"
replied
Wood
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
why
I
should
be
obliged
to
pay
for
doing
my
duty
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
this
child
would
have
been
strangled
.
<EOS>
The
noose
was
at
its
throat
when
I
called
for
help
.
<EOS>
I
knew
it
was
in
vain
to
cry
'
murder
!
'
<EOS>
in
the
Mint
,
so
I
had
recourse
to
stratagem
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
I
must
say
you
deserve
some
credit
for
your
ingenuity
,
at
all
events
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
repressing
a

;
"
but
,
before
you
put
out
your
foot
so
far
,
it
would
have
been
quite
as
prudent
to
consider
how
you
were
to
draw
it
back
again
.
<EOS>
For
my
own
part
,
I
do
n't
see
in
what
way
it
is
to
be
accomplished
,
except
by
the
payment
of
our
customary
fees
.
<EOS>
Do
not
imagine
you
can
at
one
moment
avail
yourself
of
our
excellent
regulations
(
with
which
you
seem
sufficiently
well

)
,
and
the
next
break
them
with
impunity
.
<EOS>
If
you
assume
the
character
of
a
debtor
for
your
own
convenience
,
you
must
be
content
to
maintain
it
for
ours
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
not
been
arrested
,
we
have
been
disturbed
;
and
it
is
but
just
and
reasonable
you
should
pay
for
occasioning
such
disturbance
.
<EOS>
By
your
own
showing
you
are
in
easy
<EOS>
circumstances,--for
<EOS>
it
is
only
natural
to
presume
that
a
man
who
owes
nothing
must
be
in
a
condition
to
pay
liberally,--and
<EOS>
you
can
not

the
loss
of
such

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
However
illogical
and

these
arguments
might

Wood
,
and
however
he
might
dissent
from
the
latter
proposition
<EOS>
,
he
did
not
deem

expedient
to
make

;
and
the

proceeded
with
his

amid
the
general

of
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
perhaps
exceeding
my
authority
in
demanding
so
slight

sum
,
"
continued
Jonathan
,
modestly
,
"
and
the
Master
of
the
Mint
may
not

to
let

off
so

.
<EOS>
He
will
be
here
in
a
moment

so
,
and
you
will
then
learn
his
determination
.
<EOS>
In
the
mean
time
,
let
me
advise
you
as
a
friend
not
to
irritate
him
by
a
refusal
,
which
would
be
as
useless
as
vexatious
.
<EOS>
He
has
a
very
summary
mode
of
dealing
with
refractory
persons
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
My
best
endeavours
shall
be
used
to
bring
you
off
,
on
the
easy
terms
I
have
mentioned
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
call
ten
guineas
easy
terms
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
,
with
a
look
of

.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
should
expect
to
purchase
the
entire
freehold
of
the
Mint
for
less

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Many
a
man
has
been

to

double
the
amount
to
get
his
head
from
under
the
Mint
pump
,
"
<EOS>
observed
Blueskin
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
the
gentleman
take
his
own

,
"
said
Jonathan
,
mildly
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
sorry
to
persuade
him
to
do
anything
his
calmer
judgment
might
disapprove
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Exactly
my
sentiments
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
force
him
for
the
world
:
but
if
he
do
n't
tip
the
stivers
,
may
I
be
cursed
if
he
do
n't
get
a
taste
of
the
_
aqua

_
.
<EOS>
Let
's
have
a

kinchen
that
_
ought
_
to
have
been
throttled
,
"
added

,

child

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
stars
!
<EOS>
here
's
a
pretty

-
cheat
to
make

fuss
about
--
ho
!
ho
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Deal
with
me

think

,

,
"
exclaimed

;
"
but
,
for
mercy
's

do

child
!
<EOS>
Let

be
taken
to
its
mother
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
who
is

mother
?
"
asked
Jonathan
,
in
an

.
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
frankly
,
and
speak
under
your
breath
.
<EOS>
Your
own
safety
--
the
child
's
safety
--
depends
upon
your
candour
.
"
 
<EOS>
While
Mr.
Wood
underwent
this
examination
,
Blueskin
felt
a
small
and
trembling
hand
placed
upon
his
own
,
and
,
turning
at
the
summons
,
beheld
a
young
female
,
whose
features
were
partially
concealed
by
a
loo
,
or
half
mask
,
standing
beside
him
.
<EOS>
Coarse
as
were
the
ruffian
's
notions
of
feminine
beauty
,
he
could
not
be
insensible
to
the
surpassing
loveliness
of
the
fair
creature
,
who
had
thus
solicited
his
attention
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
was
,
in
some
measure
,
hidden
by
a
large
scarf
,
and
a
deep
hood
drawn
over
the
head
contributed
to
her
disguise
;
still
it
was
evident
,
from
her
lofty
bearing
,
that
she
had
nothing
in
common
,
except
an
interest
in
their
proceedings
,
with
the
crew
by
whom
she
was
surrounded
.
 
<EOS>
Whence
<EOS>
she
<EOS>
came,--who
<EOS>
she
was,--and
what
she
<EOS>
wanted,--were
questions
which
naturally
suggested
themselves
to
Blueskin
,
and
he
was
about
to
seek
for
some
explanation
,
when
his
curiosity
was
checked
by
a
gesture
of
silence
from
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
said
she
,
in
a
low
,
but
agitated
voice
;
"
would
you
earn
this
purse
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
no
objection
,
"
replied
Blueskin
,
in
a
tone
intended
to
be
gentle
,
but
which
sounded
like
the
murmuring

of
a
playful
bear
.
<EOS>
"
How
much
is
there
in
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
contains
gold
,
"
replied
the
lady
;
"
but
I
will
add
this
ring
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
to
earn
it
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Blueskin
,
with
a
disgusting
leer,--"cut
a
throat
--
or
throw
myself
at
your
feet
--
eh
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
that
child
,
"
returned
the
lady
,
with
difficulty
overcoming
the
loathing
inspired
by
the
ruffian
's

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I
see
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Blueskin
,
winking
significantly
,
"
Come
nearer
,
or
they
'll
observe
us
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
<EOS>
--
I
wo
n't
hurt
you
.
<EOS>
I
'm
always
agreeable
to
the
women
,
bless
their
kind
hearts
!
<EOS>
Now
!
<EOS>
slip
the
purse
into
my
hand
.
<EOS>
Bravo!--the
best
cly
-
faker
of
'em
all
could
n't
have
done
it
better
.
<EOS>
And
now
for
the
fawney
--
the
ring
I
mean
.
<EOS>
I
'm
no

judge
of
these
articles
,
Ma'am
;
but
I
trust
to
your
honour
not
to
palm
off
paste
upon

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
diamond
,
"
said
the
lady
,
in
an
agony
of
distress,--"the
child
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
diamond
!
<EOS>
Here
,
take
the
kid
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
slipping
the
infant
adroitly
under
her

.
"
<EOS>
And
so
this
is
a
diamond
,
"
added
he
,

the
brilliant
from

:
"
it
does
sparkle
almost
as

as
your

.
<EOS>
By
the
by
,
my
dear
,
I
forgot

ask
your
name
--
perhaps
you
'll
oblige

with

now
?
<EOS>
Hell
and
the
devil!--gone
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
looked
around
in
vain
.
<EOS>
The
lady
had
disappeared
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
III
.
 
<EOS>
The
Master
of
the
Mint
.
  
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
meanwhile
,
having
ascertained
the
parentage
of
the
child
from
Wood
,
proceeded
to
question
him
in
an
under
tone
,
as
to
the
probable
motives
of
the
attempt
upon
its
life
;
and
,
though
he
failed
in
obtaining
any
information
on
this
point
,
he
had
little
difficulty
in
eliciting
such
particulars
of
the
mysterious
transaction
as
have
already
been
recounted
.
<EOS>
When
the
carpenter
concluded
his
recital
,
Jonathan
was
for
a
moment
lost
in
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
Devilish
strange
!
"
<EOS>
thought
he
,
chuckling
to
himself
;
"
queer
business
!
<EOS>
Capital
trick
of
the
cull
in
the
cloak
to
make
another
person
's
brat
stand
the
brunt
for
his
own
--
capital
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
Wo
n't
do
,
though
.
<EOS>
He
must
be
a
sly
fox
to
get
out
of
the
Mint
without
my
knowledge
.
<EOS>
I
've
a
shrewd
guess
where
he
's
taken
refuge
;
but
I
'll
ferret
him
out
.
<EOS>
These
bloods
will
pay
well
for
his
capture
;
if
not
,
_
he
'll
_
pay
well
to
get
out
of
their
hands
;
so
I
'm
safe
either
way
--
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
Blueskin
,
"
he
added
aloud
,
and
motioning
that
worthy
,
"
follow
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
he
set
off
in
the
direction
of
the
entry
.
<EOS>
His
progress
,
however
,
was
checked
by
loud
acclamations
,
announcing
the
arrival
of
the
Master
of
the
Mint
and
his
train
.
 
<EOS>
Baptist
Kettleby
(
for
so
was
the
Master
named
)
was
a
"
goodly
portly
man
,
and
a
corpulent
,
"
<EOS>
whose
fair
round
paunch
bespoke
the
affection
he
entertained
for
good
liquor
and
good
living
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
quick
,
shrewd
,
merry
eye
,
and
a
look
in
which
duplicity
was
agreeably
veiled
by
good
humour
.
<EOS>
It
was
easy
to
discover
that
he
was
a
knave
,
but
equally
easy
to
perceive
that
he
was
a
pleasant
fellow
;
a
combination
of
qualities
by
no
means
of
rare
occurrence
.
<EOS>
So
far
as
regards
his
attire
,
Baptist
was
not
seen
to
advantage
.
<EOS>
No
great
lover
of
state
or
state
costume
at
any
time
,
he
was
generally
,
towards
the
close
of
an
evening
,
completely
in
dishabille
,
and
in
this
condition
he
now
presented
himself
to
his
subjects
.
<EOS>
His
shirt
was
unfastened
,
his
vest
unbuttoned
,
his
hose
ungartered
;
his
feet
were
stuck
into
a
pair
of
pantoufles
,
his
arms
into
a
greasy
flannel
dressing
-
gown
,
his
head
into
a
thrum
-
cap
,
the
cap
into
a
tie
-
periwig
,
and
the
wig
into
a
gold
-
edged
hat
.
<EOS>
A
white
apron
was
tied
round
his
waist
,
and
into
the
apron
was
thrust
a
short
thick
truncheon
,
which
looked
very
much
like
a
rolling
-
pin
.
 
<EOS>
The
Master
of
the
Mint
was
accompanied
by
another
gentleman
almost
as
portly
as
himself
,
and
quite
as
deliberate
in
his
movements
.
<EOS>
The
costume
of
this
personage
was
somewhat
singular
,
and
might
have
passed
for
a
masquerading
habit
,
had
not
the
imperturbable
gravity
of
his
demeanour
forbidden
any
such
supposition
.
<EOS>
It
consisted
of
a
close
jerkin
of
brown
frieze
,
ornamented
with
a
triple
row
of
brass
buttons
;
loose
Dutch
slops
,
made
very
wide
in
the
seat
and
very
tight
at
the
knees
;
red
stockings
with
black
clocks
,
and
a
fur
cap
.
<EOS>
The
owner
of
this
dress
had
a
broad
weather
-
beaten
face
,
small
twinkling
eyes
,
and
a
bushy
,
grizzled
beard
.
<EOS>
Though
he
walked
by
the
side
of
the
governor
,
he
seldom
exchanged
a
word
with
him
,
but
appeared
wholly
absorbed
in
the
contemplations
inspired
by
a
broadbowled
Dutch
pipe
.
 
<EOS>
Behind
the
illustrious
personages
<EOS>
just
described
marched
a
troop
of
stalwart
fellows
,
with
white
badges
in
their
hats
,
quarterstaves
,
oaken
cudgels
,
and
links
in
their
hands
.
<EOS>
These
were
the
Master
's
body
-
guard
.
 
<EOS>
Advancing
towards
the
Master
,
and
claiming
an
audience
,
which
was
instantly
granted
,
Jonathan
,
without
much
circumlocution
,
related
the
sum
of
the
strange
story
he
had
just
learnt
from
Wood
,
omitting
nothing
except
a
few
trifling
particulars
,
which
he
thought
it
politic
to
keep
back
;
and
,
with
this
view
,
he
said
not
a
word
of
there
being
any
probability
of
capturing
the
fugitive
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
roundly
asserted
that
his
informant
had
witnessed
that
person
's
escape
.
 
<EOS>
The
Master
listened
,
with
becoming
attention
,
to
the
narrative
,
and
,
at
its
conclusion
,
shook
his
head
gravely
,
applied
his
thumb
to
the
side
of
his
nose
,
and
,
twirling
his
fingers
significantly
,
winked
at
his
phlegmatic
companion
.
<EOS>
The
gentleman
appealed
to
shook
his
head
in
reply
,
coughed
as
only
a
Dutchman
_
can
_
cough
,
and
raising
his
hand
from
the
bowl
of
his
pipe
,
went
through
precisely
the
same
mysterious
ceremonial
as
the
Master
.
 
<EOS>
Putting
his
own
construction
upon
this
mute
interchange
of
opinions
,
Jonathan
ventured
to
observe
,
that
it
certainly
was
a
very
perplexing
case
,
but
that
he
thought
something
_
might
_
be
made
of
it
,
and
,
if
left
to
him
,
he
would
undertake
to
manage
the
matter
to
the
Master
's
entire
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
,
ja
,
Muntmeester
,
"
said
the
Dutchman
,
removing
the
pipe
from
his
mouth
,
and
speaking
in
a
deep
and
guttural
voice
,
"
leave
the
affair
to
Johannes
.
<EOS>
He
'll
settle
it
bravely
.
<EOS>
And
let
ush
go
back
to
our
brandewyn
,
and
hollandsche
genever
.
<EOS>
Dese
ere
not
schouts
,
as
you
faind
,
but
jonkers
on
a
vrolyk
;
and
if
dey'd
chanshed
to
keel
de
vrow
Sheppard
's
pet
lamb
,
dey'd
have
done
her
a
servish
,
by
shaving
it
from
dat
unpleasant
complaint
,
de
hempen
fever
,
with
which
its
laatter
days
are
threatened
,
and
of
which
its
poor
vader
died
.
<EOS>
Myn
Got
!
<EOS>
haanging
runs
in
some
families
,
Muntmeester
.
<EOS>
It
's
hereditary
,
like
de
jigt
,
vat
<EOS>
you
call
it
--
gout
--
haw
!
<EOS>
haw
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
child
_
is
_
destined
to
the
gibbet
,
Van
Galgebrok
,
"
replied
the
Master
,
joining
in
the
laugh
,
"
it
'll
never
be
choked
by
a
footman
's
cravat
,
that
's
certain
;
but
,
in
regard
to
going
back
empty
-
handed
,
"
continued
he
,
altering
his
tone
,
and
assuming
a
dignified
air
,
"
it
's
quite
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
With
Baptist
Kettleby
,
to
engage
in
a
matter
is
to
go
through
with
it
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
this
is
an
affair
which
no
one
but
myself
can
settle
.
<EOS>
Common
offences
may
be
decided
upon
by
deputy
;
but
outrages
perpetrated
by
men
of
rank
,
as
these
appear
to
be
,
must
be
judged
by
the
Master
of
the
Mint
in
person
.
<EOS>
These
are
the
decrees
of
the
Island
of
Bermuda
,
and
I
will
never
suffer
its
excellent
laws
to
be
violated
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
of
the
Mint
,
"
added
he
,
pointing
with
his
truncheon
towards
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
house
,
"
forward
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hurrah
!
"
shouted
the
mob
,
and
the
whole
phalanx
was
put
in
motion
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
a
martial
flourish
,
proceeding
from
cow
's
horns
,
tin
canisters
filled
with
stones
,
bladders
and
cat
-
gut
,
with
other
sprightly
,
instruments
,
was
struck
up
,
and
,
enlivened
by
this
harmonious
accompaniment
,
the
troop
reached
its
destination
in
the
best
possible
spirits
for
an
encounter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
us
in
,
"
said
the
Master
,
rapping
his
truncheon
authoritatively
against
the
boards
,
"
or
we
'll
force
an
entrance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
But
as
no
answer
was
returned
to
the
summons
,
though
it
was
again
,
and
more
peremptorily
,
repeated
,
Baptist
seized
a
mallet
from
a
bystander
and
burst
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
Followed
by
Van
Galgebrok
and
others
of
his
retinue
,
he
then
rushed
into
the
room
,
where
Rowland
,
Sir
Cecil
,
and
their
attendants
,
stood
with
drawn
swords
prepared
to
receive
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Beat
down
their
blades
,
"
cried
the
Master
;
"
no
bloodshed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Beat
out
their
brains
,
you
mean
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
with
a
tremendous
imprecation
;
"
no
half
measures
now
,
Master
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Had
n't
you
better
hold
a
moment
's
parley
with
the
gentlemen
before
proceeding
to
extremities
?
"
suggested
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Agreed
,
"
responded
the
Master
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Surely
,
"
he
added
,
staring
at
Rowland
,
"
<EOS>
either
I
'm
greatly
mistaken
,
or
it
is--
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
mistaken
,
Baptist
,
"
returned
Rowland
with
a
gesture
of
silence
;
"
it
is
your
old
friend
.
<EOS>
I
'm
glad
to
recognise
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
'm
glad
your
worship
's
recognition
does
n't
come
too
late
,
"
observed
the
Master
.
<EOS>
"
But
why
did
n't
you
make
yourself
known
at
once
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
forgotten
the
office
you
hold
in
the
Mint
,
Baptist
,
"
replied
Rowland
.
"
<EOS>
But
clear
the
room
of
this
rabble
,
if
you
have
sufficient
authority
over
them
.
<EOS>
I
would
speak
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
but
one
way
of
clearing
it
,
your
worship
,
"
said
the
Master
,
archly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
"
replied
Rowland
.
"
<EOS>
Give
them
what
you
please
.
<EOS>
I
'll
repay
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
right
,
pals
,
"
cried
Baptist
,
in
a
loud
tone
;
"
the
gentlemen
and
I
have
settled
matters
.
<EOS>
No
more
scuffling
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
meaning
of
all
this
?
"
demanded
Sir
Cecil
.
<EOS>
"
How
have
you
contrived
to
still
these
troubled
waters
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
chanced
upon
an
old
ally
in
the
Master
of
the
Mint
,
"
answered
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
We
may
trust
him
,
"
he
added
in
a
whisper
;
"
he
is
a
staunch
friend
of
the
good
cause
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Blueskin
,
clear
the
room
,
"
cried
the
Master
;
"
these
gentlemen
would
be
private
.
<EOS>
They
've
_
paid
_
for
their
lodging
.
<EOS>
Where
's
Jonathan
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Inquiries
were
instantly
made
after
that
individual
,
but
he
was
nowhere
to
be
found
.
 
<EOS>
"
Strange
!
"
observed
the
Master
;
"
I
thought
he
'd
been
at
my
elbow
all
this
time
.
<EOS>
But
it
do
n't
much
matter
--
though
he
's
a
devilish
shrewd
fellow
,
and
might
have
helped
me
out
of
a
difficulty
,
had
any
occurred
.
<EOS>
Hark
ye
,
Blueskin
,
"
continued
he
,
addressing
that
personage
,
who
,
in
obedience
to
his
commands
,
had
,
with
great
promptitude
,
driven
out
the
rabble
,
and
again
secured
the
door
,
"
a
word
in
your
ear
.
<EOS>
What
female
entered
the
house
with
us
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Blood
and
thunder
!
"
exclaimed
Blueskin
,
afraid
<EOS>
,
if
he
admitted
having
seen
the
lady
,
of
being
compelled
to
divide
the
plunder
he
had
obtained
from
her
among
his
companions
,
"
how
should
I
know
?
<EOS>
D'ye
suppose
I
'm
always
thinking
of
the
petticoats
?
<EOS>
I
observed
no
female
;
but
if
any
one
_
did
_
join
the
assault
,
it
must
have
been
either
Amazonian
Kate
,
or
Fighting
Moll
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
woman
I
mean
did
not
join
the
assault
,
"
rejoined
the
Master
,
"
but
rather
seemed
to
shun
observation
;
and
,
from
the
hasty
glimpse
I
caught
of
her
,
she
appeared
to
have
a
child
in
her
arms
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
most
probably
,
it
was
the
widow
Sheppard
,
"
answered
Blueskin
,
sulkily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Right
,
"
said
the
Master
,
"
I
did
n't
think
of
her
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
've
another
job
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Propose
it
,
"
returned
Blueskin
,
inclining
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Square
accounts
with
the
rascal
who
got
up
the
sham
arrest
;
and
,
if
he
do
n't
tip
the
cole
without
more
ado
,
give
him
a
taste
of
the
pump
,
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
go
through
the
whole
course
,
"
replied
Blueskin
,
with
a
ferocious
grin
,
"
unless
he
comes
down
to
the
last
grig
.
<EOS>
We
'll
lather
him
with
mud
,
shave
him
with
a
rusty
razor
,
and
drench
him
with
_
aqua
pompaginis
_
.
<EOS>
Master
,
your
humble
servant.--Gentlemen
,
your
most
obsequious
trout
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
effected
his
object
,
which
was
to
get
rid
of
Blueskin
,
Baptist
turned
to
Rowland
and
Sir
Cecil
,
who
had
watched
his
proceedings
with
much
impatience
,
and
remarked
,
"
Now
,
gentlemen
,
the
coast
's
clear
;
we
've
nothing
to
interrupt
us
.
<EOS>
I
'm
entirely
at
your
service
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IV
.
 
<EOS>
The
Roof
and
the
Window
.
  
<EOS>
Leaving
them
to
pursue
their
conference
,
we
shall
follow
the
footsteps
of
Jonathan
,
who
,
as
the
Master
surmised
,
and
,
as
we
have
intimated
,
had
unquestionably
entered
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
at
the
beginning
of
the
affray
,
when
he
thought
every
one
was
too
much
occupied
with
his
own
concerns
to
remark
his
absence
,
he
slipped
out
of
the
room
,
not
for
the
purpose
of
avoiding
the
engagement
(
for
cowardice
was
not
one
of
his
failings
)
,
but
because
he
had
another
object
in
view
.
<EOS>
Creeping
stealthily
up
stairs
,
unmasking
a
dark
lantern
,
and
glancing
into
each
room
as
he
passed
,
he
was
startled
in
one
of
them
by
the
appearance
of
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
who
seemed
to
be
crouching
upon
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
,
however
,
that
she
did
not
notice
him
,
Jonathan
glided
away
as
noiselessly
as
he
came
,
and
ascended
another
short
flight
of
stairs
leading
to
the
garret
.
<EOS>
As
he
crossed
this
chamber
,
his
foot
struck
against
something
on
the
floor
,
which
nearly
threw
him
down
,
and
stooping
to
examine
the
object
,
he
found
it
was
a
key
.
<EOS>
"
Never
throw
away
a
chance
,
"
thought
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
knows
but
this
key
may
open
a
golden
lock
one
of
these
days
?
"
<EOS>
And
,
picking
it
up
,
he
thrust
it
into
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
Arrived
beneath
an
aperture
in
the
broken
roof
,
he
was
preparing
to
pass
through
it
,
when
he
observed
a
little
heap
of
tiles
upon
the
floor
,
which
appeared
to
have
been
recently
dislodged
.
"
<EOS>
He
_
has
_
passed
this
way
,
"
cried
Jonathan
,
exultingly
;
"
I
have
him
safe
enough
.
"
<EOS>
He
then
closed
the
lantern
,
mounted
without
much
difficulty
upon
the
roof
,
and
proceeded
cautiously
along
the
tiles
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
was
now
profoundly
dark
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
had
to
feel
his
way
.
<EOS>
A
single
false
step
might
have
precipitated
him
into
the
street
;
or
,
if
he
had
trodden
upon
an
unsound
part
of
the
roof
,
he
must
have
fallen
through
it
.
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
to
guide
him
;
for
though
the
torches
were
blazing
ruddily
below
,
their
gleam
fell
only
on
the
side
of
the
building
.
<EOS>
The
venturous
climber
gazed
for
a
moment
at
the
assemblage
beneath
,
to
ascertain
that
he
was
not
discovered
;
and
,
having
satisfied
himself
in
this
particular
,
he
stepped
out
more
boldly
.
<EOS>
On
gaining
a
stack
of
chimneys
at
the
back
of
the
house
,
he
came
to
a
pause
,
and
again
unmasked
his
lantern
.
<EOS>
Nothing
,
however
,
could
be
discerned
,
except
the
crumbling
brickwork
.
<EOS>
"
Confusion
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Jonathan
:
"
can
he
have
escaped
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
The
walls
are
too
high
,
and
the
windows
too
stoutly
barricaded
in
this
quarter
,
to
admit
such
a
supposition
.
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
be
far
off
.
<EOS>
I
shall
find
him
yet
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
have
it
,
"
he
added
,
after
a
moment
's
deliberation
;
<EOS>
"
he
's
there
,
I
'll
be
sworn
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
once
more
enveloping
himself
in
darkness
,
he
pursued
his
course
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
now
reached
the
adjoining
house
,
and
,
scaling
the
roof
,
approached
another
building
,
which
seemed
to
be
,
at
least
,
one
story
loftier
than
its
neighbours
.
<EOS>
Apparently
,
Jonathan
was
well
acquainted
with
the
premises
;
for
,
feeling
about
in
the
dark
,
he
speedily
discovered
a
ladder
,
up
the
steps
of
which
he
hurried
.
<EOS>
Drawing
a
pistol
,
and
unclosing
his
lantern
with
the
quickness
of
thought
,
he
then
burst
through
an
open
trap
-
door
into
a
small
loft
.
 
<EOS>
The
light
fell
upon
the
fugitive
,
who
stood
before
him
in
an
attitude
of
defence
,
with
the
child
in
his
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
,
acting
upon
the
information
he
had
obtained
from
Wood
;
"
I
have
found
you
at
last
.
<EOS>
Your
servant
,
Mr.
Darrell
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
!
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
fugitive
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
friend
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
uncocking
the
pistol
,
and
placing
it
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
I
know
you
are
a
friend
?
"
asked
Darrell
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
should
I
do
here
alone
if
I
were
an
enemy
?
<EOS>
But
,
come
,
do
n't
let
us
waste
time
in
bandying
words
,
when
we
might
employ
it
so
much
more
profitably
.
<EOS>
Your
life
,
and
that
of
your
child
,
are
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
What
will
you
give
me
to
save
you
from
your
pursuers
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
Can
_
you
do
so
?
"
asked
the
other
,
doubtfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
and
will
.
<EOS>
Now
,
the
reward
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
but
an
ill
-
furnished
purse
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
escape
,
my
gratitude--
"
 
"
Pshaw
!
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Jonathan
,
scornfully
.
<EOS>
"
Your
gratitude
will
vanish
with
your
danger
.
<EOS>
Pay
fools
with
promises
.
<EOS>
I
must
have
something
in
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
all
I
have
about
me
,
"
replied
Darrell
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
--
well
,
"
grumbled
Jonathan
,
"
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
must
be
content
.
<EOS>
An
ill
-
lined
purse
is
a
poor
recompense
for
the
risk
I
have
run
.
<EOS>
However
,
come
along
.
<EOS>
I
need
n't
tell
you
to
tread
carefully
.
<EOS>
You
know
the
danger
of
this
breakneck
road
as
well
as
I
do
.
<EOS>
The
light
would
betray
us
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
closed
the
lantern
.
 
<EOS>
"
Harkye
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
Darrell
;
"
one
word
before
I
move
.
<EOS>
I
know
not
who
you
are
;
and
,
as
I
can
not
discern
your
face
,
I
may
be
doing
you
an
injustice
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
something
in
your
voice
that
makes
me
distrust
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
attempt
to
play
the
traitor
,
you
will
do
so
at
the
hazard
of
your
life
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
hazarded
my
life
in
this
attempt
to
save
you
,
"
returned
Jonathan
boldly
,
and
with
apparent
frankness
;
"
this
ought
to
be
sufficient
answer
to
your
doubts
.
<EOS>
Your
pursuers
are
below
.
<EOS>
What
was
to
hinder
me
,
if
I
had
been
so
inclined
,
from
directing
them
to
your
retreat
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
replied
Darrell
.
"
<EOS>
Lead
on
!
"
 
<EOS>
Followed
by
Darrell
,
Jonathan
retraced
his
dangerous
path
.
<EOS>
As
he
approached
the
gable
of
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
house
,
loud
yells
and
vociferations
reached
his
ears
;
and
,
looking
downwards
,
he
perceived
a
great
stir
amid
the
mob
.
<EOS>
The
cause
of
this
uproar
was
soon
manifest
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
and
the
Minters
were
dragging
Wood
to
the
pump
.
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
carpenter
struggled
violently
,
but
ineffectually
.
<EOS>
His
hat
was
placed
upon
one
pole
,
his
wig
on
another
.
<EOS>
His
shouts
for
help
were
answered
by
roars
of
mockery
and
laughter
.
<EOS>
He
continued
alternately
to
be
tossed
in
the
air
,
or
rolled
in
the
kennel
until
he
was
borne
out
of
sight
.
<EOS>
The
spectacle
seemed
to
afford
as
much
amusement
to
Jonathan
as
to
the
actors
engaged
in
it
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
contain
his
satisfaction
,
but
chuckled
,
and
rubbed
his
hands
with
delight
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
Heaven
!
"
cried
Darrell
,
"
it
is
the
poor
fellow
whom
I
placed
in
such
jeopardy
a
short
time
ago
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
cause
of
his
ill
-
usage
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
you
are
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
laughing
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
what
of
that
?
<EOS>
It
'll
be
a
lesson
to
him
in
future
,
and
will
show
him
the
folly
of
doing
a
good
-
natured
action
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
perceiving
that
his
companion
did
not
relish
his
pleasantry
and
fearing
that
his
sympathy
for
the
carpenter
's
situation
might
betray
him
into
some
act
of
imprudence
,
Jonathan
,
without
further
remark
,
and
by
way
of
putting
an
end
to
the
discussion
,
let
himself
drop
through
the
roof
.
<EOS>
His
example
was
followed
by
Darrell
.
<EOS>
But
,
though
the
latter
was
somewhat
embarrassed
by
his
burthen
,
he
peremptorily
declined
Jonathan
's
offer
of
assistance
.
<EOS>
Both
,
however
,
having
safely
landed
,
they
cautiously
crossed
the
room
,
and
passed
down
the
first
flight
of
steps
in
silence
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
a
door
was
opened
below
;
lights
gleamed
on
the
walls
;
and
the
figures
of
Rowland
and
Sir
Cecil
were
distinguished
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
Darrell
stopped
,
and
drew
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
betrayed
me
,
"
said
he
,
in
a
deep
whisper
,
to
his
companion
;
"
but
you
shall
reap
the
reward
of
your
treachery
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
still
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Jonathan
,
in
the
same
under
tone
,
and
with
great
self
-
possession
:
"
I
can
yet
save
you
.
<EOS>
And
see
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
as
the
figures
drew
back
,
and
the
lights
disappeared
;
"
it
's
a
false
alarm
.
<EOS>
They
have
retired
.
<EOS>
However
,
not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
.
<EOS>
Give
me
your
hand
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
hurried
Darrell
down
another
short
flight
of
steps
,
and
entered
a
small
chamber
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
Closing
the
door
,
Jonathan
next
produced
his
lantern
,
and
,
hastening
towards
the
window
,
undrew
a
bolt
by
which
it
was
fastened
.
<EOS>
A
stout
wooden
shutter
,
opening
inwardly
,
being
removed
,
disclosed
a
grating
of
iron
bars
.
<EOS>
This
obstacle
,
which
appeared
to
preclude
the
possibility
of
egress
in
that
quarter
,
was
speedily
got
rid
of
.
<EOS>
Withdrawing
another
bolt
,
and
unhooking
a
chain
suspended
from
the
top
of
the
casement
,
Jonathan
pushed
the
iron
framework
outwards
.
<EOS>
The
bars
dropped
noiselessly
and
slowly
down
,
till
the
chain
tightened
at
the
staple
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
free
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
grating
forms
a
ladder
,
by
which
you
may
descend
in
safety
.
<EOS>
I
learned
the
trick
of
the
place
from
one
Paul
Groves
,
who
used
to
live
here
,
and
who
contrived
the
machine
.
<EOS>
He
used
to
call
it
his
fire
-
escape
--
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
I
've
often
used
the
ladder
for
my
own
convenience
,
but
I
never
expected
to
turn
it
to
such
good
account
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
Sir
,
have
I
kept
faith
with
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
,
"
replied
Darrell
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
is
my
purse
;
and
I
trust
you
will
let
me
know
to
whom
I
am
indebted
for
this
important
service
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
matters
not
who
I
am
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
taking
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
As
I
said
before
,
I
have
little
reliance
upon
_
professions
_
of
gratitude
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
how
it
is
,
"
sighed
Darrell
,
"
but
I
feel
an
unaccountable
misgiving
at
quitting
this
place
.
<EOS>
Something
tells
me
I
am
rushing
on
greater
danger
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
best
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
sneeringly
;
"
but
if
I
were
in
your
place
<EOS>
I
would
take
the
chance
of
a
future
and
uncertain
risk
to
avoid
a
present
and
certain
peril
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
replied
Darrell
;
"
the
weakness
is
past
.
<EOS>
Which
is
the
nearest
way
to
the
river
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
an
awkward
road
to
direct
you
,
"
returned
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
if
you
turn
to
the
right
when
you
reach
the
ground
,
and
keep
close
to
the
Mint
wall
,
you
'll
speedily
arrive
at
White
Cross
Street
;
White
Cross
Street
,
if
you
turn
again
to
the
right
,
will
bring
you
into
Queen
Street
;
Queen
Street
,
bearing
to
the
left
,
will
conduct
you
to
Deadman
's
Place
;
and
Deadman
's
Place
to
the
water
-
side
,
not
fifty
yards
from
Saint
Saviour
's
stairs
,
where
you
're
sure
to
get
a
boat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
point
I
aim
at
,
"
said
Darrell
as
he
passed
through
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
said
Jonathan
,
aiding
his
descent
;
"
you
had
better
take
my
lantern
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
useful
to
you
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
'll
give
me
in
return
some
token
,
by
which
I
may
remind
you
of
this
occurrence
,
in
case

meet
again
.
<EOS>
Your
glove
will
suffice
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
it
is
;
"
replied
the
other
,
tossing
him
the

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Are
you
sure
these
bars
touch
the
ground
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
come
within
a
yard
of
it
,
"
answered
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Safe
!
"
shouted
Darrell
,
as
he
effected
a
secure

.
"
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
,
"
muttered
Jonathan
,
"
having
started
the
hare
,
I
'll
now
unleash
the
hounds
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
praiseworthy
determination
,
he
was
hastening
down
stairs
,
with
the
utmost
rapidity
,
when
he
encountered
a
female
,
whom
he
took
,
in
the
darkness
,
to
be
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
The
person
caught
hold
of
his
arm
,
and
,
in

to
disengage

,
detained

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
asked
she
,
in
an
agitated
whisper
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
his
voice
;
but
I
saw
them
on
the
stairs
,
and
durst
not
approach
him
,
for
fear
of
giving
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
mean
the
fugitive
,
Darrell
,
he
has
escaped
through
the
back
window
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
she
gasped
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
women
are
forgiving
creatures
,
I
must
say
,
"
observed
Jonathan
,
sarcastically
.
<EOS>
"
You
thank
Heaven
for
the

of
the
man
who
did

best
to
get
your
child
's

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
asked
the
female
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
mean
what
I
say
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
do
n't
know
that
this
Darrell
so
contrived

,
that
your
child
should
be
mistaken
for

own
;
by
which
means
it
had
a
narrow
escape
from
a
tight

,
I
can
assure
you
.
<EOS>
However
,
the
scheme
answered
well
enough
,
for
Darrell
has
got
off
with
his
own
brat
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
this
is
not
my
child
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

have
a
child
there
,

,
"
answered
Jonathan
,
a

;
"
for
I

your

Blueskin
,
who
is

in

,
unless
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Merciful

!
"
exclaimed

female
.
<EOS>
"
Whose
child
can
this
be
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
the
devil
should
I
know
!
"
replied
Jonathan

.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
did
n't
drop
through

,

?
<EOS>
Are
you
quite
sure
it
's
flesh
and
blood
?
"
<EOS>
asked
he
,
playfully

till

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
child
!
<EOS>
my
child
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
rushing
from

room
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
the
mother
of
this
child
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
person
who
had
first

,
addressing
Mrs.

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
--
I
am
!
"
cried
the
widow
,
snatching
the
babe
,
and
pressing
it
to
her

with
rapturous

<EOS>
"
God
be
thanked
,
I
have
found
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
both
good
reason
to
be
grateful
,
"
added
the
lady
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sblood
!
"
cried
Jonathan
,
who
had
listened

the

with

,
"
I
've
been
nicely
done
here
.
<EOS>
Fool
that
I
was
to
part
with
my
lantern
!
<EOS>
But
I
'll
soon
set
myself

.
<EOS>
What
ho
!
<EOS>
lights
!
<EOS>
lights
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
,

he

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
shall
I
fly
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the

,

.
<EOS>
"
They
will
kill
me
,
if
they
find

,
as

.
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>
my

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Make

,
Madam
,
"

,

;
"
they

are

!
<EOS>
to
the

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,
"
this
room
<EOS>
--
I

--
<EOS>
it

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
shut
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
open
,
"
replied
the
lady
,
rushing
towards
it
,
and
springing
through
the
outlet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
?
<EOS>
"
thundered
Jonathan
,
who
at
this
moment
reached
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
flown
up
stairs
,
"
replied
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
lie
,
hussy
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Jonathan
,
rudely
pushing
her
aside
,
as
she
vainly
endeavoured
to
oppose
his
entrance
into
the
room
;
"
she
is
here
.
<EOS>
Hist
!
"
<EOS>
cried
he
,
as
a
scream
was
heard
from
without
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
G--
!
<EOS>
she
has
missed
her
footing
.
"
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
momentary
and
terrible
silence
,
broken
only
by
a
few
feeble
groans
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Cecil
,
who
with
Rowland
and
some
others
had
entered
the
room
rushed
to
the
window
with
a
torch
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
down
the
light
,
and
a
moment
afterwards
beckoned
,
with
a
blanched
cheek
,
to
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
sister
is
dead
,
"
said
he
,
in
a
deep
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
blood
be
upon
her
own
head
,
then
,
"
replied
Rowland
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
Why
came
she
here
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
could
not
resist
the
hand
of
fate
which
drew
her
hither
,
"
replied
Sir
Cecil
,
mournfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Descend
and
take
charge
of
the
body
,
"
said
Rowland
,
conquering
his
emotion
by
a
great
effort
,
"
I
will
join
you
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
This
accident
rather
confirms
than
checks
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
The
stain
upon
our
family
is
only
half
effaced
:
I
have
sworn
the
death
of
the
villain
and
his
bastard
,
and
I
will
keep
my
oath
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Sir
,
"
he
added
,
turning
to
Jonathan
,
as
Sir
Cecil
and
his
followers
obeyed
his
injunctions
,
"
you
say
you
know
the
road
which
the
person
whom
we
seek
has
taken
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
give
no
information
gratis
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
,
then
,
"
said
Rowland
,
placing
money
in

hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
find
him
at
St.
Saviours
's
stairs
,
"
answered
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
about
to
cross
the
river
.
<EOS>
You
'd
better
lose
no
time
.
<EOS>
He
has
got
five
minutes
'
start
of
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
sent
him
the
longest
way
about
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
words
were
scarcely
pronounced
,
when
Rowland
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
to
see
the
end
of
it
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
shortly
afterwards
passing
through
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Master
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Three
persons
only
were
left
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
These
were
the
Master
of
the
Mint
,
Van
Galgebrok
,
and
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
bad
business
<EOS>
this
,
Van
,
"
observed
Baptist
,
with
a
prolonged
shake
of
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
,
ja
,
Muntmeester
,
"
said
the
Hollander
,
shaking
his
head
in
reply;--"very
bad
--
very
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
then
they
're
staunch

of
our
friend
over

water
,
"
continued

,
winking

;
"
<EOS>
so
we
must
e'en
hush
it
up
in
the
best

we
can
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
,
"
answered

.
"
<EOS>
But
--
sapperment!--I
wish
they
had
n't
broken
my
pipe
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
JONATHAN
WILD
promises
well
,
"
observed
the
Master
,
after

:
"
he
'll
become
a

man
.
<EOS>
Mind
,
I
,
Baptist
Kettleby
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
be

nevertheless
,
"

Hollander
,
giving

ugly

.
<EOS>
"
Mind
,
I
,
Rykhart
Van
Galgebrok
predict

.
<EOS>
And
now
let
's

back

the
Shovels
,
and
finish

brandewyn
and

,
Muntmeester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
cried

,

,
