;
"
were
it
not
for
my
child
,
I
should
wish
to
be
in
the
place
of
that
unfortunate
lady
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
V.
 
<EOS>
The
Denunciation
.
  
<EOS>
For
a
short
space
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
remained
dissolved
in
tears
.
<EOS>
She
then
dried
her
eyes
,
and
laying
her
child
gently
upon
the
floor
,
knelt
down
beside
him
.
"
<EOS>
Open
my
heart
,
Father
of
Mercy
!
"
<EOS>
she
murmured
,
in
a
humble
tone
,
and
with
downcast
looks
,
"
and
make
me
sensible
of
the
error
of
my
ways
.
<EOS>
I
have
sinned
deeply
;
but
I
have
been
sorely
tried
.
<EOS>
Spare
me
yet
a
little
while
,
Father
!
<EOS>
not
for
my
own
sake
,
but
for
the
sake
of
this
poor
babe
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
utterance
was
here
choked
by
sobs
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
it
is
thy
will
to
take
me
from
him
,
"
she
continued
,
as
soon
as
her
emotion
permitted
her,--"if
he
must
be
left
an
orphan
amid
strangers
,
implant
,
<EOS>
I
beseech
thee
,
a
mother
's
feelings
in
some
other
bosom
,
and
raise
up
a
friend
,
who
shall
be
to
him
what
I
would
have
been
.
<EOS>
Let
him
not
bear
the
weight
of
my
punishment
.
<EOS>
Spare
him!--pity
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
she
arose
,
and
,
taking
up
the
infant
<EOS>
,
was
about
to
proceed
down
stairs
,
when
she
was
alarmed
by
hearing
the
street
-
door
opened
,
and
the
sound
of
heavy
footsteps
entering
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
,
widow
!
<EOS>
"
shouted
a
rough
voice
from
below
,
"
where
the
devil
are
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
returned
no
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
something
to
say
to
you
,
"
continued
the
speaker
,
rather
less
harshly
;
"
something
to
your
advantage
;
so
come
out
<EOS>
o
'
<EOS>
your
hiding
-
place
,
and
let
's
have
some
supper
,
for
I
'm
infernally
hungry.--D'ye
hear
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Still
the
widow
remained
silent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
you
wo
n't
come
,
I
shall
help
myself
,
and
that
's
unsociable
,
"
pursued
the
speaker
,
evidently
,
from
the
noise
he
made
,
suiting
the
action
to
the
word
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Devilish
nice
ham
<EOS>
you
've
got
here!--capital
pie!--and
,
as
I
live
,
a
flask
of
excellent
canary
.
<EOS>
You
're
in
luck
to
-
night
,
widow
.
<EOS>
Here
's
your
health
in
a
bumper
,
and
wishing
you
a
better
husband
than
your
first
.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
your
own
fault
if
you
do
n't
soon
get
another
and
a
proper
young
man
into
the
bargain
.
<EOS>
Here
's
his
health
likewise
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
mum
still
.
<EOS>
You
're
the
first
widow
I
ever
heard
of
who
could
withstand
that
lure
.
<EOS>
I
'll
try
the
effect
of
a
jolly
stave
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
struck
up
the
following
ballad:--
 
<EOS>
SAINT
GILES
'S
BOWL.[A
]
 
<EOS>

:

]
     
I.
     
<EOS>
Where
Saint
-
Giles
'
church
stands
,
once
a
la
-
zar
-
house
    
stood
;
And
,
chain'd
to
its
gates
,
was
a
ves
-
sel
of
wood
;
<EOS>
A
    
broad
-
bottom'd
bowl
,
from
which
all
the
fine
fellows
,
Who
    
pass'd
by
that
spot
,
on
their
way
to
the
gallows
,
Might
    
tipple
strong
beer
,
Their
spirits
to
cheer
,
And
drown
,
in
a
    
sea
of
good
li

,
all

!
<EOS>
For
nothing
the
    
tran
-
sit
to
Ty
-
burn
beguiles
,
So
well
as
a
    
draught
from
the
Bowl
of
Saint
Giles
!

II
.

By
many

,

,

<EOS>

,

!
<EOS>
_
 
<EOS>
"
Devil
seize
the
woman
!
"
<EOS>
growled
the
singer
,
as
he
brought
his
ditty
to
a
close
;
"
will
nothing
tempt
her
out
?
<EOS>
Widow
Sheppard
,
I
say
,
"
he
added
,
rising
,
"
do
n't
be
afraid
.
<EOS>
It
's
only
a
gentleman
come
to
offer
you
his
hand
.
'
<EOS>
He
that
woos
a
maid',--fol
-
de
-
rol--(hiccupping).--I'll
soon
find
you
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
whose
distress
at
the
consumption
of
the
provisions
had
been
somewhat
allayed
by
the
anticipation
of
the
intruder
's
departure
after
he
had
satisfied
his
appetite
,
was
now
terrified
in
the
extreme
by
seeing
a
light
approach
,
and
hearing
footsteps
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
Her
first
impulse
was
to
fly
to
the
window
;
and
she
was
about
to
pass
through
it
,
at
the
risk
of
sharing
the
fate
of
the
unfortunate
lady
,
when
her
arm
was
grasped
by
some
one
in
the
act
of
ascending
the
ladder
from
without
.
<EOS>
Uttering
a
faint
scream
,
she
sank
backwards
,
and
would
have
fallen
,
if
it
had
not
been
for
the
interposition
of
Blueskin
,
who
,
at
that
moment
,
staggered
into
the
room
with
a
candle
in
one
hand
,
and
the
bottle
in
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
're
here
,
are
you
?
"
said
the
ruffian
,
with
an
exulting
laugh
:
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
looking
for
you
everywhere
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
"
implored
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard,--"pray
<EOS>
let
me
go
.
<EOS>
You
hurt
the
child
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
hear
how
you
've
made
it
cry
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Throttle
the
kid
!
"
rejoined
Blueskin
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
stop
its
squalling
,
I
will
.
<EOS>
I
hate
children
.
<EOS>
And
,
if
I
'd
my
own
way
,
I
'd
drown
'em
all
like
a
litter
o
'
puppies
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Well
knowing
the
savage
temper
of
the
person
she
had
to
deal
with
,
and
how
likely
he
was
to
put
his
threat
into
execution
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
did
not
dare
to
return
any
answer
;
but
,
disengaging
herself
from
his
embrace
,
endeavoured
meekly
to
comply
with
his
request
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
widow
,
"
continued
the
ruffian
,
setting
down
the
candle
,
and
applying
his
lips
to
the
bottle
neck
as
he
flung
his
heavy
frame
upon
a
bench
,
"
I
've
a
piece
o
'
good
news
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Good
news
will
be
news
to
me
.
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Guess
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
,
attempting
to
throw
a
gallant
expression
into
his
forbidding
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
trembled
violently
;
and
though
she
understood
his
meaning
too
well
,
she
answered,--"I
ca
n't
guess
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
"
returned
the
ruffian
,
"
to
put
you
out
o
'
suspense
,
as
the
topsman
remarked
to
poor
Tom

<EOS>
he
turned
him
off
,
I
'm
come
to
make
you
an
honourable
proposal
o
'

.
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
refuse
me
,
I
'm

;
so
no

need

said
about
the
matter
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
,
we
'll
go
to
the
Fleet
and
get
spliced
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
shake
so
.
<EOS>
What
I
said
about
your
brat
was
all
stuff
.
<EOS>
I
did
n't
mean
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
my
way
when
I
'm
ruffled
.
<EOS>
I
shall
take
to
him
as
nat'ral
as
if
he
were
my
own
flesh
and
<EOS>
blood
afore
<EOS>
long.--I'll
give
him
the
edication
of
a
prig,--teach
him
<EOS>
the
use

his
forks
betimes,--and
make
him
,
in

,
as
clever

as

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
shrieked
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
"
never
!
<EOS>
never
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
<EOS>
what
's
this
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Blueskin
,
springing
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do

mean

say
that
if
I
support
your
kid
,
I
sha

bring
him
up
how
I

--
eh
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,
but

,
"
replied
the
widow

;
"
you

better
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leave

!
"
echoed
the
ruffian
,
with

;
"
--not

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not

,
"
rejoined

poor

;
"
there
's
some
one
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
But

were

.
<EOS>
And
Blueskin
,
who
,
for
a

,
had
looked

,
concluding
it
was
a

,
now

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
do
,
widow
,
"
said

,

,
while

"
<EOS>
so

.
<EOS>
Come
,

,

,

listen

.
<EOS>
Your
kid
has
already
brought
me
good

,
and
may
bring
me
still

if
his
edication
's

.
<EOS>
This
purse
,
"
he

,

,
"

,

for
him
just
now
by

,
who

on

.
<EOS>
If
I
'd
been
in

,
instead
of
Jonathan
Wild
,
that

would
n't
have
happened
.
"
 
<EOS>
As

,

was

without
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
Who
's

!
<EOS>
it

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
Jonathan
Wild
,
"
<EOS>
returned
the
widow
,
endeavouring
to

.
<EOS>
"
I

I

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
He
_
protect
_

_
,
<EOS>
"

,

;
"
you
have

.
<EOS>
If

's

,

that
he
laid

's

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Man
!
"
screamed

Sheppard
,

that

,
"
begone
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
To
--
to
--
<EOS>
no

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Go
--
go
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
what
you
mean
,
"

,

,

,
in

,

"
you

I.
He

.
<EOS>

,
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
But
d
--
<EOS>
n
him
!
<EOS>
let
's
talk
<EOS>
o
'

.
<EOS>
Look

's

,
and

a
mint
o
'

.
<EOS>
It
shall

.
<EOS>
Look

,

.
<EOS>
The
lady
's

's

,
but

I

<EOS>
A
-
L

I
-

-

--
<EOS>
Aliva

T

--
<EOS>
Trencher

.
<EOS>
Aliva
Trencher
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Aliva
Trenchard
!
<EOS>
"

Mrs.
Sheppard
,

;
"
is

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,

,
now
I
look
again
<EOS>
it
_

Trenchard
.
<EOS>
How
came

to

?
<EOS>
Have

before
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

--
long
,

,

,
"

,

;
"
but

is

--
<EOS>
quite

.
<EOS>
Where
_
can
_
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Devil
knows
,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
The

's

,

.
<EOS>
Here
,

on

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.

snatched

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Set
down

kid
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
!
"
screamed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
struggling
to

,
and
holding

at

;
"
have

on
this

!
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
child
,
alarmed

,
added
its

to
its

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
Set
it
down
,
I
tell
you
,
"
thundered
Blueskin
,
"
or
I
shall
do
it
a
mischief
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
Uttering
a
terrible
imprecation
,
Blueskin
placed
the
knife
between
his
teeth
,
and
endeavoured
to
seize
the
poor
woman
by

.
<EOS>
In
the
struggle
her
cap
fell
off
.
<EOS>
The
ruffian
caught
hold
of
her
hair
,
and
held
her
fast
.
<EOS>
The
chamber
rang
with
her
shrieks
.
<EOS>
But
her
cries
,
instead
of
moving
her
assailant
's
compassion
,
only
added
to
his
fury
.
<EOS>
Planting
his
knee
against
her
side
,
he
pulled
her
towards
him
with
one
hand
,
while
with
the
other
he
sought
his
knife
.
<EOS>
The
child
was
now
within
reach
;
and
,
in
another
moment
,
he
would
have
executed
his
deadly
purpose
,
if
an
arm
from
behind
had
not
felled
him
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
who
had
been
stricken
down
by
the
blow
that
prostrated
her
assailant
,
looked
up
,
she
perceived
Jonathan
Wild
kneeling
beside
the
body
of
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
He
was
holding
the
ring
to
the
light
,
and
narrowly
examining
the
inscription
.
 
<EOS>
"
Trenchard
,
"
he
muttered
;
"
Aliva
Trenchard
--
they
were
right
,
then
,
as
to
the
name
.
<EOS>
Well
,
if
she
survives
the
accident
--
as
the
blood
,
who
styles
himself
Sir
Cecil
,
fancies
she
may
do
--
this
ring
will
make
my
fortune
by
leading
to
the
discovery
of
the
chief
parties
concerned
in
this
strange
affair
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
poor
lady
alive
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sblood
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
,
hastily
thrusting
the
ring
into
his
vest
,
and
taking

heavy

's

with
which
he
had
felled
<EOS>
Blueskin,--"I
thought
you
'd
been
senseless
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
she
alive
?
"
repeated
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
to
you
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Jonathan
,
gruffly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nothing
--
nothing
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
"
<EOS>
But
pray
tell
me
if
her
husband
has
escaped
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her
husband
!
"
echoed
Jonathan
scornfully
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
_
husband
_
has
little
to
fear
from
his
wife
's
kinsfolk
.
<EOS>
Her
_
lover
_
,
Darrell
,
has
embarked
upon
the
Thames
,
where
,
if
he
's
not
capsized
by
the
squall
,
(
for
it
's
blowing
like
the
devil
,
)
<EOS>
he
stands
a
good
chance
of
getting
his
throat
cut
by
his
pursuers
--
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
I
tracked
'em
to
the
banks
of
the
river
,
and
should
have
followed
to
see
it
out
,
if
the
watermen
had
n't
refused
to
take
me
.
<EOS>
However
,
as
things
have
turned
up
,
it
's
fortunate
that
I
came
back
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
indeed
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
"
most
fortunate
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
_
you
_
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
;
"
do
n't
flatter
yourself
that
I
'm
thinking
of
you
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
might
have
butchered
you
and
your
brat
before
I
'd
have
lifted
a
finger
to
prevent
him
,
if
it
had
n't
suited
my
purposes
to
do
so
,
and
_
he
_
had
n't
incurred
my
displeasure
.
<EOS>
I
never
forgive
an
injury
.
<EOS>
Your
husband
could
have
told
you
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
had
he
offended
you
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
answered
Jonathan
,
sternly
.
"
<EOS>
He
thwarted
my
schemes
twice
.
<EOS>
The
first
time
,
I
overlooked
the
offence
;
but
the
second
time
,
when
I
had
planned
to
break
open
the
house
of
his
master
,
the
fellow
who
visited
you
to
-
night,--Wood
,
the
carpenter
of
Wych
Street,--he
betrayed
me
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
would
bring
him
to
the
gallows
,
and
I
was
as
good
as
my
word
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
so
,
"
replied
Mrs
Sheppard
;
"
and
for
that
wicked
deed
you
will
one
day
be
brought
to
the
gallows
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
before
I
have
conducted
your
child
thither
,
"
retorted
Jonathan
,
with
a
withering
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
ejaculated
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
paralysed
by
the
threat
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
that
sickly
brat
lives
to
be
a
man
,
"
continued
Jonathan
,
rising
,
"
I
'll
hang
him
upon
the
same
tree
as
his
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pity
!
"
shrieked
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
be
his
evil
genius
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Jonathan
,
who
seemed
to
enjoy
her
torture
.
 
<EOS>
"
Begone
,
wretch
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
mother
,
stung
beyond
endurance
by
his
taunts
;
"
or
I
will
drive
you
hence
with
my
curses
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Curse
on
,
and
welcome
,
"
jeered
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
raised
her
hand
,
and
the
malediction
trembled
upon
her
tongue
.
<EOS>
But
ere
the
words
could
find
utterance
,
her
maternal
tenderness
overcame
her
indignation
;
and
,
sinking
upon
her
knees
,
she
extended
her
arms
over
her
child
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
mother
's
prayers
--
a
mother
's
blessings
,
"
she
cried
,
with
the
fervour
almost
of
inspiration
,
"
will
avail
against
a
fiend
's
malice
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
turning
carelessly
upon
his
heel
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
as
he
quitted
the
room
,
the
poor
widow
fell
with
her
face
upon
the
floor
.

Footnote
A
:
<EOS>
At
the
hospital
of
Saint
Giles
for
Lazars
,
the
prisoners
conveyed
from
the
City
of
London
towards
Tyburn
,
there
to
be
executed
for
treasons
,
felonies
,
or
other
trespasses
,
were
presented
with
a
Bowl
of
Ale
,
thereof
to
drink
,
as
their
last
refreshing
in
this
life.--_Strype
's
Stow
.

.

.

.

.

<EOS>
CHAPTER
VI
.
 
<EOS>
The
Storm
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
liberated
by
his
persecutors
,
Mr.
Wood
set
off
at
full
speed
from
the
Mint
,
and
,
hurrying
he
scarce
knew
whither
(
for
there
was
such
a
continual
buzzing
in
his
ears
and
dancing
in
his
eyes
,
as
almost
to
take
away
the
power
of
reflection
)
,
he
held
on
at
a
brisk
pace
till
his
strength
completely
failed
him
.
 
<EOS>
On
regaining
his
breath
,
he
began
to
consider
whither
chance
had
led
him
;
and
,
rubbing
his
eyes
to
clear
his
sight
,
he
perceived
a
sombre
pile
,
with
a
lofty
tower
and
broad
roof
,
immediately
in
front
of
him
.
<EOS>
This
structure
at
once
satisfied
him
as
to
where
he
stood
.
<EOS>
He
knew
it
to
be
St.
Saviour
's
Church
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
up
at
the
massive
tower
,
the
clock
tolled
forth
the
hour
of
midnight
.
<EOS>
The
solemn
strokes
were
immediately
answered
by
a
multitude
of
chimes
,
sounding
across
the
Thames
,
amongst
which
the
deep
note
of
Saint
Paul
's
was
plainly
distinguishable
.
<EOS>
A
feeling
of
inexplicable
awe
crept
over
the
carpenter
as
the
sounds
died
away
.
<EOS>
He
trembled
,
not
from
any
superstitious
dread
,
but
from
an
undefined
sense
of
approaching
danger
.
<EOS>
The
peculiar
appearance
of
the
sky
was
not
without
some
influence
in
awakening
these
terrors
.
<EOS>
Over
one
of
the
pinnacles
of
the
tower
a
speck
of
pallid
light
marked
the
position
of
the
moon
,
then
newly
born
and
newly
risen
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
profoundly
dark
;
but
the
wind
,
which
had
begun
to
blow
with
some
violence
,
chased
the
clouds
rapidly
across
the
heavens
,
and
dispersed
the
vapours
hanging
nearer
the
earth
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
the
moon
was
totally
eclipsed
;
at
others
,
it
shed
a
wan
and
ghastly
glimmer
over
the
masses
rolling
in
the
firmament
.
<EOS>
Not
a
star
could
be
discerned
,
but
,
in
their
stead
,
streaks
of
lurid
radiance
,
whence
proceeding
it
was
impossible
to
determine
,
shot
ever
and
anon
athwart
the
dusky
vault
,
and
added
to
the
ominous
and
threatening
appearance
of
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
these
prognostications
of
a
storm
,
and
feeling
too
much
exhausted
from
his
late
severe
treatment
to
proceed
further
on
foot
,
Wood
endeavoured
to
find
a
tavern
where
he
might
warm
and
otherwise
refresh
himself
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
he
struck
off
into
a
narrow
street
on
the
left
,
and
soon
entered
a
small
alehouse
,
over
the
door
of
which
hung
the
sign
of
the
"
Welsh
Trumpeter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
have
a
glass
of
brandy
,
"
said
he
,
addressing
the
host
.
 
<EOS>
"
Too
late
,
master
,
"
replied
the
landlord
of
the
Trumpeter
,
in
a
surly
tone
,
for
he
did
not
much
like
the
appearance
of
his
customer
;
"
just
shut
up
shop
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Zounds
!
<EOS>
David
Pugh
,
do
n't
you
know
your
old
friend
and
countryman
?
"
exclaimed
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Owen
Wood
,
is
it
you
?
"
cried
David
in
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
makes
you
out
so
late
?
<EOS>
And
what
has
happened
to
you
,
man
<EOS>
,
eh?--you
seem
in
a
queer
plight
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
the
brandy
,
and
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
replied
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
wife
--
hostess
--
fetch
me
that
bottle
from
the
second
shelf
in
the
corner
<EOS>
cupboard.--There
,
Mr.
Wood
<EOS>
,
"
cried
David
,
pouring
out
a
glass
of
the
spirit
,
and
offering

to
the
carpenter
,
"
that
'll
warm
the
cockles
of
your
heart
.
<EOS>
Do

be
afraid
,
man,--off
with
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
right
Nantz
.
<EOS>
I
keep
it
for
my
own
drinking
,
"
he
added
in
a
lower
tone
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
having
disposed
of
the
brandy
,
and
pronounced
himself
much
better
,
hurried
close
to
the
fire
-
side
,
and
informed
his
friend
in
a
few
words
of
the
inhospitable
treatment
he
had
experienced
from
the
gentlemen
of
the
Mint
;
whereupon
Mr.
Pugh
,
who
,
as
well

the
carpenter
,
was
a
descendant
of
Cadwallader
,
waxed
extremely
wrath
;
gave

to
a

of

-

in
the
Welsh

;
and
was
just

to
express
the
greatest

to
catch
some

the
rascals
at
the
Trumpeter
,
when
Mr.
Wood
cut
him
short
by
stating
his
intention
of
crossing
the
river
as
soon
as
possible
in
order
to
avoid
the
storm
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
storm
!
"
exclaimed
the
landlord
.
"
<EOS>
Gadzooks
!
<EOS>
I
thought
something
was
coming

;
for
when

looked
at
the
weather
-
glass
an
hour
ago
,
it
had
sunk
lower
than
I
ever

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall

a
durty

on

,
to
a
sartinty
,
landlord
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

never

,

follerin

,

knowed

.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
a
souple
o
'
porpusses

this

'
,

ha
'
bin

'
about
i
'
the

abuv

Bridge
all

;

say

,

proves

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

;
"
what

,

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do

affront

,
Owen

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Enough
's

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

wo

,
and
must

,
Owen
,
"

,
"
there

will

as

.
<EOS>
Halloa
,
Ben
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,
shaking

,

,

having

wanted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Holloa
!
<EOS>
my
hearty
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ben
,
starting
to
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
gentleman
wants
a
pair

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
to
,
master
?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Arundel

,
"
replied
Wood
,
"
the
nearest

to
Wych
Street
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
master
,
"
said
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hark
'
ee
,
Ben
,
"

,

;
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
,
old
saltwater
?
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
'Cos

's

a
-

up
<EOS>
as'll
perwent
<EOS>
you
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

'
ee
<EOS>
what
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
They
'll

--

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
and
the
waterman
,
meanwhile
,
proceeded
in
the
direction
of
St.
Saviour
's

.
<EOS>
Casting

at
the
old

of
the
Bishop
of
Winchester
(
whose

formerly

river
)
,
called
the
Clink
,
which
gave
its

to

,
along
which
he
walked
:
and

,

,

in

through

,
the

followed
his
companion
down
an
opening
to
the
right
,
and
presently
arrived
at
the
water
-
side
.
 
<EOS>
Moored
to
the
steps
,
several
wherries
were
dancing
in
the
rushing
current
,
as
if
impatient
of
restraint
.
<EOS>
Into
one
of
these
the
waterman
jumped
,
and
,
having
assisted
Mr.
Wood
to
a
seat
within
it
,
immediately
pushed
from
land
.
<EOS>
Ben
had
scarcely
adjusted
his
oars
,
when
the
gleam
of
a
lantern
was
seen
moving
towards
the
bank
.
<EOS>
A
shout
was
heard
at
a
little
distance
,
and
,
the
next

,
a
person
rushed
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Boat
there
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
voice
,
which
Mr.
Wood

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll

a
waterman
asleep

one

ere
craft
,
if
you
look

,
Sir
,
"

Ben
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't

take
me

?
"
urged

;
"
I
'll

.
<EOS>
I
've

here

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
child
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Wood
;
it
must
be
the
fugitive
Darrell
.
"
<EOS>
Hold
hard
,
"
cried

,
addressing
the

;
"
I
'll
give
the

lift
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Unpossible
,
master
,
"
rejoined
Ben
;
"
the
tide
's
running
down
like
a
mill

,
and
the
wind
's
right
in
our

.
<EOS>
Old
saltwater
was
right
.
<EOS>
We
shall
have
a
reg'lar
squall
afore
we
gets
across
.
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
how
the
wanes
creaks
on
old
Winchester
House
?
<EOS>
We
shall
have
a
touch
on
it
ourselves
presently
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
lose
my
wager
if
I
stay
a
moment
longer
--
so
here
goes
.
<EOS>
"
Upon
which
,
he
plunged
his
oars
deeply
into
the
stream
,
and
the
bark
shot
from

strand
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
's
anxiety
respecting
the
fugitive
was
speedily
relieved
by
hearing
another
waterman
busy
himself
in
preparation
for
starting
;
and
,
shortly
after
,
the
dip
of
a
second

of
oars
sounded
upon
the
river
.
 
<EOS>
"
Curse
me
,
if
I
do
n't
think
all
the
world
means
to
cross
the
Thames
this
fine
night
,
"
observed
Ben
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
One'd
think
it
rained
fares
,
as
well
as
blowed
great
guns
.
<EOS>
Why
,
there
's
another
party
on
the
stair
-
head
inquiring
arter
scullers
;
and
,
by
the
mass
!
<EOS>
they
appear
in
a
greater
hurry
than
any
on
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
His
attention
being
thus
drawn
to
the
bank
,
the
carpenter
beheld
three
figures
,
one
of
whom
bore
a

,
leap
into
a
wherry
of
a
larger
size
than
the
others
,
which
immediately
put
off
from
shore
.
<EOS>
Manned
by
a

of
watermen
,
who
rowed
with
great

,
this

dashed
through
the
current
in
the
track
of
the
fugitive
,
of
whom
it
was
evidently
in
pursuit
,
and
upon
whom
it
perceptibly
gained
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
strained
his
eyes
to
catch
a
glimpse
of
the
flying
skiff
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
only
discern
a
black
and
shapeless
mass
,
floating
upon
the
water
at
a
little
distance
,
which
,
to
his

fancy
,
appeared
absolutely
standing
still
.
<EOS>
To
the
practised
eye
of
the
waterman
matters
wore
a
very
different
air
.
<EOS>
He
perceived
clearly
enough
,
that
the
chase
was
moving
quickly
;
and
he
was
also
aware
,
from
the
increased
rapidity
with
which
the
oars
were
urged
,
that
every
exertion
was
made
on
board
to
get
out
of
the
reach
of
her
pursuers
.
<EOS>
At
one
moment
,
it
seemed
as
if
the
flying
bark
was
about
to
put
to
shore
.
<EOS>
But
this
plan
(
probably
from
its
danger
)
was
instantly
abandoned
;
not
,
however
,
before
her
momentary
hesitation
had
been
taken
advantage
of
by
her
pursuers
,
who
,
redoubling
their
efforts
at
this
juncture
,
materially
lessened
the
distance
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
Ben
watched
these
manoeuvres
with
great
interest
,
and
strained
every
sinew
in
his
frame
to
keep
ahead
of
the
other
boats
.
 
<EOS>
"
Them
's
catchpoles
,
I
s'pose
,
Sir
,
arter
the
gemman
with
a
writ
?
<EOS>
"
he
observed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Something
worse
,
I
fear
,
"
Wood
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
do
n't
think
as
how
they
're
crimps
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
Ben
inquired
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
I
think
,
"
Wood
answered
sulkily
;
and
he
bent
his
eyes
upon
the
water
,
as
if
he
wished
to
avert
his
attention
forcibly
from
the
scene
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
something
that
inspires
a
feeling
of
inexpressible
melancholy
in
sailing
on
a
dark
night
upon
the
Thames
.
<EOS>
The
sounds
that
reach
the
ear
,
and
the
objects
that
meet
the
eye
,
are
all
calculated
to
awaken
a
train
of
sad
and
serious
contemplation
.
<EOS>
The
ripple
of
the
water
against
the
boat
,
as
its
keel
cleaves
through
the
stream
--
the
darkling
current
hurrying
by
--
the
indistinctly
-
seen
craft
,
of
all
forms
and
all
sizes
,
hovering
around
,
and
making
their
way
in
ghost
-
like
silence
,
or
warning
each
other
of
their
approach
by
cries
,
that
,
heard
from
afar
,
have
something
doleful
in
their
note
--
<EOS>
the
solemn
shadows
cast
by
the
bridges
--
the
deeper
gloom
of
the
echoing
arches
--
the
lights
glimmering
from
the
banks
--
the
red
reflection
thrown
upon
the
waves
by
a
fire
kindled
on
some
stationary
barge
--
the
tall
and
fantastic
shapes
of
the
houses
,
as
discerned
through
the
obscurity;--these
,
and
other
sights
and
sounds
of
the
same
character
,
give
a
sombre
colour
to
the
thoughts
of
one
who
may
choose
to
indulge
in
meditation
at
such
a
time
and
in
such
a
place
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
otherwise
with
the
carpenter
.
<EOS>
This
was
no
night
for
the
indulgence
of
dreamy
musing
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
night
of
storm
and
terror
,
which
promised
each
moment
to
become
more
stormy
and
more
terrible
.
<EOS>
Not
a
bark
could
be
discerned
on
the
river
,
except
those
already
mentioned
.
<EOS>
The
darkness
was
almost
palpable
;
and
the
wind
which
,
hitherto
,
had
been
blowing
in
gusts
,
was
suddenly
lulled
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dead
calm
.
<EOS>
But
this
calm
was
more
awful
than
the
previous
roaring
of
the
blast
.
 
<EOS>
Amid
this
portentous
hush
,
the
report
of
a
pistol
reached
the
carpenter
's
ears
;
and
,
raising
his
head
at
the
sound
,
he
beheld
a
sight
which
filled
him
with
fresh
apprehensions
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
light
of
a
torch
borne
at
the
stern
of
the
hostile
wherry
,
he
saw
that
the
pursuers
had
approached
within
a
short
distance
of
the
object
of
their
quest
.
<EOS>
The
shot
had
taken
effect
upon
the
waterman
who
rowed
the
chase
.
<EOS>
He
had
abandoned
his
oars
,
and
the
boat
was
drifting
with
the
stream
towards
the
enemy
.
<EOS>
Escape
was
now
impossible
.
<EOS>
Darrell
stood
erect
in
the
bark
,
with
his
drawn
sword
in
hand
,
prepared
to
repel
the
attack
of
his
assailants
,
who
,
in
their
turn
,
seemed
to
await
with
impatience
the
moment
which
should
deliver
him
into
their
power
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
not
to
tarry
long
.
<EOS>
In
another
instant
,
the
collision
took
place
.
<EOS>
The
watermen
,
who
manned
the
larger
wherry
,
immediately
shipped
their
oars
,
grappled
with
the
drifting
skiff
,
and
held
it
fast
.
<EOS>
Wood
,
then
,
beheld
two
persons
,
one
of
whom
he
recognised
as
Rowland
,
spring
on
board
the
chase
.
<EOS>
A
fierce
struggle
ensued
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
shrill
cry
,
instantly
succeeded
by
a
deep
splash
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
about
,
waterman
,
for
God
's
sake
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
,
whose
humanity
got
the
better
of
every
personal
consideration
;
"
some
one
is
overboard
.
<EOS>
Give
way
,
and
let
us
render
what
assistance
we
can
to
the
poor
wretch
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
over
with
him
by
this
time
,
master
,
"
replied
Ben
,
turning
the
head
of
his
boat
,
and
rowing
swiftly
towards
the
scene
of
strife
;
"
but
d
--
<EOS>
n
<EOS>
him
<EOS>
,
he
was
the
chap
as
hit
poor
Bill
Thomson
just
now
,
and
I
do
n't
much
care
if
he
should
be
food
for
fishes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
Ben
spoke
,
they
drew
near
the
opposing
parties
.
<EOS>
The
contest
was
now
carried
on
between
Rowland
and
Darrell
.
<EOS>
The
latter
had
delivered
himself
from
one
of
his
assailants
,
the
attendant
,
Davies
.
<EOS>
Hurled
over
the
sides
of
the
skiff
,
the
ruffian
speedily
found
a
watery
grave
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
spring
-
tide
at
half
ebb
;
and
the
current
,
which
was
running
fast
and
furiously
,
bore
him
instantly
away
.
<EOS>
While
the
strife
raged
between
the
principals
,
the
watermen
in
the
larger
wherry
were
occupied
in
stemming
the
force
of
the
torrent
,
and
endeavouring
to
keep
the
boats
,
they
had
lashed
together
,
stationary
.
<EOS>
Owing
to
this
circumstance
,
Mr.
Wood
's
boat
,
impelled
alike
by
oar
and
tide
,
shot
past
the
mark
at
which
it
aimed
;
and
before
it
could
be
again
brought
about
,
the
struggle
had
terminated
.
<EOS>
For
a
few
minutes
,
Darrell
seemed
to
have
the
advantage
in
the
conflict
.
<EOS>
Neither
combatant
could
use
his
sword
;
and
in
strength
the
fugitive
was
evidently
superior
to
his
antagonist
.
<EOS>
The
boat
rocked
violently
with
the
struggle
.
<EOS>
Had
it
not
been
lashed
to
the
adjoining
wherry
,
it
must
have
been
upset
,
and
have
precipitated
the
opponents
into
the
water
.
<EOS>
Rowland
felt
himself
sinking
beneath
the
powerful
grasp
of
his
enemy
.
<EOS>
He
called
to
the
other
attendant
,
who
held
the
torch
.
<EOS>
Understanding
the
appeal
,
the
man
snatched
his
master
's
sword
from
his
grasp
,
and
passed
it
through
Darrell
's
body
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
a
heavy
plunge
told
that
the
fugitive
had
been
consigned
to
the
waves
.
 
<EOS>
Darrell
,
however
,
rose
again
instantly
;
and
though
mortally
wounded
,
made
a
desperate
effort
to
regain
the
boat
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
child
!
"
<EOS>
he
groaned
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
reminded
,
"
answered
Rowland
,
who
had
witnessed
his
struggles
with
a
smile
of
gratified
vengeance
;
"
I
had
forgotten
the
accursed
imp
in
this
confusion
.
<EOS>
Take
it
,
"
he
cried
,
lifting
the
babe
from
the
bottom
of
the
boat
,
and
flinging
it
towards
its
unfortunate
father
.
 
<EOS>
The
child
fell
within
a
short
distance
of
Darrell
,
who
,
hearing
the
splash
,
struck
out
in
that
direction
,
and
caught
it
before
it
sank
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
sound
of
oars
reached
his
ears
,
and
he
perceived
Mr.
Wood
's
boat
bearing
up
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
waterman
,
"
exclaimed
the
benevolent
carpenter
.
<EOS>
"
I
see
him!--row
for
your
life
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
way
to
miss
him
,
master
,
"
replied
Ben
coolly
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
keep
still
.
<EOS>
The
tide'll
bring
him
to
us
fast
enough
.
"
 
<EOS>
Ben
judged
correctly
.
<EOS>
Borne
along
by
the
current
,
Darrell
was
instantly
at
the
boat
's
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
Seize
this
oar
,
"
vociferated
the
waterman
.
 
<EOS>
"
First
take
the
child
,
"
cried
Darrell
,
holding
up
the
infant
,
and
clinging
to
the
oar
with
a
dying
effort
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
it
me
,
"
returned
the
carpenter
;
"
all
's
safe
.
<EOS>
Now
lend
me
your
own
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
strength
fails
me
,
"
gasped
the
fugitive
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
climb
the
boat
.
<EOS>
Take
my
child
to
--
<EOS>
it
is
--
<EOS>
oh
God!--I
am
sinking
--
<EOS>
take
it
--
take
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
shouted
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
Darrell
attempted
to
reply
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
only
utter
an
inarticulate
exclamation
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
his
grasp
relaxed
,
and
he
sank
to
rise
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Rowland
,
meantime
,
alarmed
by
the
voices
,
snatched
a
torch
from
his
attendant
,
and
holding
it
over
the
side
of
the
wherry
,
witnessed
the
incident
just
described
.
 
<EOS>
"
Confusion
!
"
<EOS>
cried
he
;
"
there
is
another
boat
in
our
wake
.
<EOS>
They
have
rescued
the
child
.
<EOS>
Loose
the
wherry
,
and
stand
to
your
oars
--
quick
--
quick
!
"
 
<EOS>
These
commands
were
promptly
obeyed
.
<EOS>
The
boat
was
set
free
,
and
the
men
resumed
their
seats
.
<EOS>
Rowland
's
purposes
were
,
however
,
defeated
in
a
manner
as
unexpected
as
appalling
.
 
<EOS>
During
the
foregoing
occurrences
a
dead
calm
prevailed
.
<EOS>
But
as
Rowland
sprang
to
the
helm
,
and
gave
the
signal
for
pursuit
,
a
roar
like
a
volley
of
ordnance
was
heard
aloft
,
and
the
wind
again
burst
its
bondage
.
<EOS>
A
moment
before
,
the
surface
of
the
stream
was
black
as
ink
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
whitening
,
hissing
,
and
seething
like
an
enormous
cauldron
.
<EOS>
The
blast
once
more
swept
over
the
agitated
river
:
whirled
off
the
sheets
of
foam
,
scattered
them
far
and
wide
in
rain
-
drops
,
and
left
the
raging
torrent
blacker
than
before
.
<EOS>
The
gale
had
become
a
hurricane
:
that
hurricane
was
the
most
terrible
that
ever
laid
waste
our
city
.
<EOS>
Destruction
everywhere
marked
its
course
.
<EOS>
Steeples
toppled
,
and
towers
reeled
beneath
its
fury
.
<EOS>
Trees
were
torn
up
by
the
roots
;
many
houses
were
levelled
to
the
ground
;
others
were
unroofed
;
the
leads
on
the
churches
were
ripped
off
,
and
"
shrivelled
up
like
scrolls
of
parchment
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
on
land
or
water
was
spared
by
the
remorseless
gale
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
vessels
lying
in
the
river
were
driven
from
their
moorings
,
dashed
tumultuously
against
each
other
,
or
blown
ashore
.
<EOS>
All
was
darkness
,
horror
,
confusion
,
ruin
.
<EOS>
Men
fled
from
their
tottering
habitations
,
and
returned
to
them
scared
by
greater
dangers
.
<EOS>
The
end
of
the
world
seemed
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
time
of
universal
havoc
and
despair,--when
all
London
quaked
at
the
voice
of
the
storm,--the
carpenter
,
who
was
exposed
to
its
utmost
fury
,
fared
better
than
might
have
been
anticipated
.
<EOS>
The
boat
in
which
he
rode
was
not
overset
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
her
course
had
been
shifted
immediately
after
the
rescue
of
the
child
;
and
,
in
consequence
of
this
movement
,
she
received
the
first
shock
of
the
hurricane
,
which
blew
from
the
southwest
,
upon
her
stern
.
<EOS>
Her
head
dipped
deeply
into
the
current
,
and
she
narrowly
escaped
being
swamped
.
<EOS>
Righting
,
however
,
instantly
afterwards
,
she
scudded
with
the
greatest
rapidity
over
the
boiling
waves
,
to
whose
mercy
she
was
now
entirely
abandoned
.
<EOS>
On
this
fresh
outburst
of
the
storm
,
Wood
threw
himself
instinctively
into
the
bottom
of
the
boat
,
and
clasping
the
little
orphan
to
his
breast
,
endeavoured
to
prepare
himself
to
meet
his
fate
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
occupied
,
he
felt
a
rough
grasp
upon
his
arm
,
and
presently
afterwards
Ben
's
lips
approached
close
to
his
ear
.
<EOS>
The
waterman
sheltered
his
mouth
with
his
hand
while
he
spoke
,
or
his
voice
would
have
been
carried
away
by
the
violence
of
the
blast
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
up
,
master
,
"
groaned
Ben
,
"
<EOS>
nothin'
short
of
a
merracle
can
save
us
.
<EOS>
The
boat
's
sure
to
run
foul
o
'
the
bridge
;
and
if
she
'
scapes
stavin
'
above
,
she
'll
be
swamped
to
a
sartainty
below
.
<EOS>
There
'll
be
a
fall
of
above
twelve
foot
<EOS>
o
'
water
,
and
think
o
'
that
on
a
night
as
'
ud
blow
a
whole
fleet
to
the
devil
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
_
did
_
think
of
it
,
and
groaned
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
help
us
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
;
"
we
were
mad
to
neglect
the
old
sailor
's
advice
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
troubles
me
,
"
rejoined
Ben
.
<EOS>
"
I
tell
'
ee
<EOS>
what
,
master
,
if
you
're
more
fortinate
nor
I
am
,
and
get
ashore
,
give
old
saltwater
your
fare
.
<EOS>
I
pledged
my
thumb
that
,
dead
or
alive
,
I
'd
pay
the
wager
if
I
lost
;
and
I
should
like
to
be
as
good
as
my
word
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
--
I
will
,
"
replied
Wood
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
Was
that
thunder
?
"
<EOS>
he
faltered
,
as
a
terrible
clap
was
heard
overhead
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
;
it
's
only
a
fresh
gale
,
"
<EOS>
Ben
returned
:
"
hark
!
<EOS>
now
it
comes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Lord
have
mercy
upon
us
,
miserable
sinners
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wood
,
as
a
fearful
gust
dashed
the
water
over
the
side
of
the
boat
,
deluging
him
with
spray
.
 
<EOS>
The
hurricane
had
now
reached
its
climax
.
<EOS>
The
blast
shrieked
,
as
if
exulting
in
its
wrathful
mission
.
<EOS>
Stunning
and
continuous
,
the
din
seemed
almost
to
take
away
the
power
of
hearing
.
<EOS>
He
,
who
had
faced
the
gale
,
would
have
been
instantly
stifled
.
<EOS>
Piercing
through
every
crevice
in
the
clothes
,
it
,
in
some
cases
,
tore
them
from
the
wearer
's
limbs
,
or
from
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
It
penetrated
the
skin
;
benumbed
the
flesh
;
paralysed
the
faculties
.
<EOS>
The
intense
darkness
added
to
the
terror
of
the
storm
.
<EOS>
The
destroying
angel
hurried
by
,
shrouded
in
his
gloomiest
apparel
.
<EOS>
None
saw
,
though
all
felt
,
his
presence
,
and
heard
the
thunder
of
his
voice
.
<EOS>
Imagination
,
coloured
by
the
obscurity
,
peopled
the
air
with
phantoms
.
<EOS>
Ten
thousand
steeds
appeared
to
be
trampling
aloft
,
charged
with
the
work
of
devastation
.
<EOS>
Awful
shapes
seemed
to
flit
by
,
borne
on
the
wings
of
the
tempest
,
animating
and
directing
its
fury
.
<EOS>
The
actual
danger
was
lost
sight
of
in
these
wild
apprehensions
;
and
many
timorous
beings
were
scared
beyond
reason
's
verge
by
the
excess
of
their
fears
.
 
<EOS>
This
had
<EOS>
well
nigh
been
the
case
with
the
carpenter
.
<EOS>
He
was
roused
from
the
stupor
of
despair
into
which
he
had
sunk
by
the
voice
of
Ben
,
who
roared
in
his
ear
,
"
The
bridge!--the
bridge
!
"
    
CHAPTER
VII
.
 
<EOS>
Old
London
Bridge
.
  
<EOS>
London
,
at
the
period
of
this
history
,
boasted
only
a
single
bridge
.
<EOS>
But
that
bridge
was
more
remarkable
than
any
the
metropolis
now
possesses
.
<EOS>
Covered
with
houses
,
from
one
end
to
the
other
,
this
reverend
and
picturesque
structure
presented
the
appearance
of
a
street
across
the
Thames
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
Grace
-
church
Street
,
with
all
its
shops
,
its
magazines
,
and
ceaseless
throng
of
passengers
,
were
stretched
from
the
Middlesex
to
the
Surrey
shore
.
<EOS>
The
houses
were
older
,
the
shops
gloomier
,
and
the
thoroughfare
narrower
,
it
is
true
;
but
the
bustle
,
the
crowd
,
the
street
-
like
air
was
the
same
.
<EOS>
Then
the
bridge
had
arched
gateways
,
bristling
with
spikes
,
and
garnished
<EOS>
(
as
all
ancient
gateways
ought
to
be
)
with
the
heads
of
traitors
.
<EOS>
In
olden
days
it
boasted
a
chapel
,
dedicated
to
Saint
Thomas
;
beneath
which
there
was
a
crypt
curiously
constructed
amid
the
arches
,
where
"
was
sepultured
Peter
the
Chaplain
of
Colechurch
,
who
began
the
Stone
Bridge
at
London
:
"
and
it
still
boasted
an
edifice
(
though
now
in
rather
a
tumbledown
condition
)
which
had
once
vied
with
a
palace,--we
mean
Nonesuch
House
.
<EOS>
The
other
buildings
stood
close
together
in
rows
;
and
so
valuable
was
every
inch
of
room
accounted
,
that
,
in
many
cases
,
cellars
,
and
even
habitable
apartments
,
were
constructed
in
the
solid
masonry
of
the
piers
.
 
<EOS>
Old
London
Bridge
(
the
grandsire
of
the
present
erection
)
was
supported
on
nineteen
arches
,
each
of
which
     
Would
a
Rialto
make
for
depth
and
height
!
 
<EOS>
The
arches
stood
upon
enormous
piers
;
the
piers
on
starlings
,
or
jetties
,
built
far
out
into
the
river
to
break
the
force
of
the
tide
.
 
<EOS>
Roused
by
Ben
's
warning
,
the
carpenter
looked
up
and
could
just
perceive
the
dusky
outline
of
the
bridge
looming
through
the
darkness
,
and
rendered
indistinctly
visible
by
the
many
lights
that
twinkled
from
the
windows
of
the
lofty
houses
.
<EOS>
As
he
gazed
at
these
lights
,
they
suddenly
seemed
to
disappear
,
and
a
tremendous
shock
was
felt
throughout
the
frame
of
the
boat
.
<EOS>
Wood
started
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
He
found
that
the
skiff
had
been
dashed
against
one
of
the
buttresses
of
the
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jump
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ben
,
in
a
voice
of
thunder
.
 
<EOS>
Wood
obeyed
.
<EOS>
His
fears
supplied
him
with
unwonted
vigour
.
<EOS>
Though
the
starling
was
more
than
two
feet
above
the
level
of
the
water
,
he
alighted
with
his
little
charge
--
which
he
had
never
for
an
instant
quitted
--
in
safety
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Poor
Ben
was
not
so
fortunate
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
was
preparing
to
follow
,
the
wherry
containing
Rowland
and
his
men
,
which
had
drifted
in
their
wake
,
was
dashed
against
his
boat
.
<EOS>
The
violence
of
the
collision
nearly
threw
him
backwards
,
and
caused
him
to
swerve
as
he
sprang
.
<EOS>
His
foot
touched
the
rounded
edge
of
the
starling
,
and
glanced
off
,
precipitating
him
into
the
water
.
<EOS>
As
he
fell
,
he
caught
at
the
projecting
masonry
.
<EOS>
But
the
stone
was
slippery
;
and
the
tide
,
which
here
began
to
feel
the
influence
of
the
fall
,
was
running
with
frightful
velocity
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
make
good
his
hold
.
<EOS>
But
,
uttering
a
loud
cry
,
he
was
swept
away
by
the
headlong
torrent
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
heard
the
cry
.
<EOS>
But
his
own
situation
was
too
perilous
to
admit
of
his
rendering
any
assistance
to
the
ill
-
fated
waterman
.
<EOS>
He
fancied
,
indeed
,
that
he
beheld
a
figure
spring
upon
the
starling
at
the
moment
when
the
boats
came
in
contact
;
but
,
as
he
could
perceive
no
one
near
him
,
he
concluded
he
must
have
been
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
In
order
to
make
Mr.
Wood
's
present
position
,
and
subsequent
proceedings
fully
intelligible
,
it
may
be
necessary
to
give
some
notion
of
the
shape
and
structure
of
the
platform
on
which
he
had
taken
refuge
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
said
,
that
the
pier
of
each
arch
,
or
lock
of
Old
London
Bridge
,
was
defended
from
the
force
of
the
tide
by
a
huge
projecting
spur
called
a
starling
.
<EOS>
These
starlings
varied
in
width
,
according
to
the
bulk
of
the
pier
they
surrounded
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
all
pretty
nearly
of
the
same
length
,
and
built
somewhat
after
the
model
of
a
boat
,
having
extremities
as
sharp
and
pointed
as
the
keel
of
a
canoe
.
<EOS>
Cased
and
ribbed
with
stone
,
and
braced
with
horizontal
beams
of
timber
,
the
piles
,
which
formed
the
foundation
of
these
jetties
,
had
resisted
the
strong
encroachments
of
the
current
for
centuries
.
<EOS>
Some
of
them
are
now
buried
at
the
bottom
of
the
Thames
.
<EOS>
The
starling
,
on
which
the
carpenter
stood
,
was
the
fourth
from
the
Surrey
shore
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
three
yards
in
width
,
and
a
few
more
in
length
;
but
it
was
covered
with
ooze
and
slime
,
and
the
waves
continually
broke
over
it
.
<EOS>
The
transverse
spars
before
mentioned
were
as
slippery
as
ice
;
and
the
hollows
between
them
were
filled
ankle
-
deep
with
water
.
 
<EOS>
The
carpenter
threw
himself
flat
upon
the
starling
to
avoid
the
fury
of
the
wind
.
<EOS>
But
in
this
posture
he
fared
worse
than
ever
.
<EOS>
If
he
ran
less
risk
of
being
blown
over
,
he
stood
a
much
greater
chance
of
being
washed
off
,
or
stifled
.
<EOS>
As
he
lay
on
his
back
,
he
fancied
himself
gradually
slipping
off
the
platform
.
<EOS>
Springing
to
his
feet
in
an
ecstasy
of
terror
,
he
stumbled
,
and
had
well
nigh
realized
his
worst
apprehensions
.
<EOS>
He
,
next
,
tried
to
clamber
up
the
flying
buttresses
and
soffits
of
the
pier
,
in
the
hope
of
reaching
some
of
the
windows
and
other
apertures
with
which
,
as
a
man
-
of
-
war
is
studded
with
port
-
holes
,
the
sides
of
the
bridge
were
pierced
.
<EOS>
But
this
wild
scheme
was
speedily
abandoned
;
and
,
nerved
by
despair
,
the
carpenter
resolved
to
hazard
an
attempt
,
from
the
execution
,
almost
from
the
contemplation
,
of
which
he
had
hitherto
shrunk
.
<EOS>
This
was
to
pass
under
the
arch
,
along
the
narrow
ledge
of
the
starling
,
and
,
if
possible
,
attain
the
eastern
platform
,
<EOS>
where
,
protected
by
the
bridge
,
he
would
suffer
less
from
the
excessive
violence
of
the
gale
.
 
<EOS>
Assured
,
if
he
remained
much
longer
where
he
was
,
he
would
inevitably
perish
,
Wood
recommended
himself
to
the
protection
of
Heaven
,
and
began
his
perilous
course
.
<EOS>
Carefully
sustaining
the
child
which
,
even
in
that
terrible
extremity
,
he
had
not
the
heart
to
abandon
,
he
fell
upon
his
knees
,
and
,
guiding
himself
with
his
right
hand
,
crept
slowly
on
.
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
entered
the
arch
,
when
the
indraught
was
so
violent
,
and
the
noise
of
the
wind
so
dreadful
and
astounding
,
that
he
almost
determined
to
relinquish
the
undertaking
.
<EOS>
But
the
love
of
life
prevailed
over
his
fears
.
<EOS>
He
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
The
ledge
,
along
which
he
crawled
,
was
about
a
foot
wide
.
<EOS>
In
length
the
arch
exceeded
seventy
feet
.
<EOS>
To
the
poor
carpenter
it
seemed
an
endless
distance
.
<EOS>
When
,
by
slow
and
toilsome
efforts
,
he
had
arrived
midway
,
something
obstructed
his
further
progress
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
huge
stone
placed
there
by
some
workmen
occupied
in
repairing
the
structure
.
<EOS>
Cold
drops
stood
upon
Wood
's
brow
,
as
he
encountered
this
obstacle
.
<EOS>
To
return
was
<EOS>
impossible,--to
raise
himself
certain
destruction
.
<EOS>
He
glanced
downwards
at
the
impetuous
torrent
,
which
he
could
perceive
shooting
past
him
with
lightning
swiftness
in
the
gloom
.
<EOS>
He
listened
to
the
thunder
of
the
fall
now
mingling
with
the
roar
of
the
blast
;
and
,
driven
almost
frantic
by
what
he
heard
and
saw
,
he
pushed
with
all
his
force
against
the
stone
.
<EOS>
To
his
astonishment
and
delight
it
yielded
to
the
pressure
,
toppled
over
the
ledge
,
and
sank
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
hubbub
and
tumult
around
him
,
that
the
carpenter
could
not
hear
its
plunge
into
the
flood
.
<EOS>
His
course
,
however
,
was
no
longer
interrupted
,
and
he
crept
on
.
 
<EOS>
After
encountering
other
dangers
,
and
being
twice
,
compelled
to
fling
himself
flat
upon
his
face
to
avoid
slipping
from
the
wet
and
slimy
pathway
,
he
was
at
length
about
to
emerge
from
the
lock
,
when
,
to
his
inexpressible
horror
,
he
found
he
had
lost
the
child
!
 
<EOS>
All
the
blood
in
his
veins
rushed
to
his
heart
,
and
he
shook
in
every
limb
as
he
made
this
discovery
.
<EOS>
A
species
of
vertigo
seized
him
.
<EOS>
His
brain
reeled
.
<EOS>
He
fancied
that
the
whole
fabric
of
the
bridge
was
cracking
over
head,--that
the
arch
was
tumbling
upon
him,--that
the
torrent
was
swelling
around
him
,
whirling
him
off
,
and
about
to
bury
him
in
the
deafening
abyss
.
<EOS>
He
shrieked
with
agony
,
and
clung
with
desperate
tenacity
to
the
roughened
stones
.
<EOS>
But
calmer
thoughts
quickly
succeeded
.
<EOS>
On
taxing
his
recollection
,
the
whole
circumstance
rushed
to
mind
with
painful
distinctness
.
<EOS>
He
remembered
that
,
before
he
attempted
to
dislodge
the
stone
,
he
had
placed
the
child
in
a
cavity
of
the
pier
,
which
the
granite
mass
had
been
intended
to
fill
.
<EOS>
This
obstacle
being
removed
,
in
his
eagerness
to
proceed
,
he
had
forgotten
to
take
his
little
charge
with
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
possible
the
child
might
be
in
safety
.
<EOS>
And
so
bitterly
did
the
carpenter
reproach
himself
with
his
neglect
,
that
he
resolved
,
at
all
risks
,
to
go
back
in
search
of
it
.
<EOS>
Acting
upon
this
humane
determination
,
he
impelled
himself
slowly
<EOS>
backwards,--for
he
did
not
dare
to
face
the
blast,--and
with
incredible
labour
and
fatigue
reached
the
crevice
.
<EOS>
His
perseverance
was
amply
rewarded
.
<EOS>
The
child
was
still
safe
.
<EOS>
It
lay
undisturbed
in
the
remotest
corner
of
the
recess
.
 
<EOS>
So
overjoyed
was
the
carpenter
with
the
successful
issue
of
his
undertaking
,
that
he
scarcely
paused
a
moment
to
recruit
himself
;
but
,
securing
the
child
,
set
out
upon
his
return
.
<EOS>
Retracing
his
steps
,
he
arrived
,
without
further
accident
,
at
the
eastern
platform
of
the
starling
.
<EOS>
As
he
anticipated
,
he
was
here
comparatively
screened
from
the
fury
of
the
wind
;
and
when
he
gazed
upon
the
roaring
fall
beneath
him
,
visible
through
the
darkness
in
a
glistening
sheet
of
foam
,
his
heart
overflowed
with
gratitude
for
his
providential
deliverance
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
moved
about
upon
the
starling
,
Mr.
Wood
became
sensible
that
he
was
not
alone
.
<EOS>
Some
one
was
standing
beside
him
.
<EOS>
This
,
then
,
must
be
the
person
whom
he
had
seen
spring
upon
the
western
platform
at
the
time
of
the
collision
between
the
boats
.
<EOS>
The
carpenter
well
knew
from
the
obstacle
which
had
interfered
with
his
own
progress
,
that
the
unknown
could
not
have
passed
through
the
same
lock
as
himself
.
<EOS>
But
he
might
have
crept
along
the
left
side
of
the
pier
,
and
beneath
the
further
arch
;
whereas
,
Wood
,
as
we
have
seen
,
took
his
course
upon
the
right
.
<EOS>
The
darkness
prevented
the
carpenter
from
discerning
the
features
or
figure
of
the
stranger
;
and
the
ceaseless
din
precluded
the
possibility
of
holding
any
communication
by
words
with
him
.
<EOS>
Wood
,
however
,
made
known
his
presence
to
the
individual
by
laying
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
started
at
the
touch
,
and
spoke
.
<EOS>
But
his
words
were
borne
away
by
the
driving
wind
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
all
attempts
at
conversation
with
his
companion
in
misfortune
in
vain
,
Wood
,
in
order
to
distract
his
thoughts
,
looked
up
at
the
gigantic
structure
standing
,
like
a
wall
of
solid
darkness
,
before
him
.
<EOS>
What
was
his
transport
on
perceiving
that
a
few
yards
above
him
a
light
was
burning
.
<EOS>
The
carpenter
did
not
hesitate
a
moment
.
<EOS>
He
took
a
handful
of
the
gravelly
mud
,
with
which
the
platform
was
covered
,
and
threw
the
small
pebbles
,
one
by
one
,
towards
the
gleam
.
<EOS>
A
pane
of
glass
was
shivered
by
each
stone
.
<EOS>
The
signal
of
distress
was
evidently
understood
.
<EOS>
The
light
disappeared
.
<EOS>
The
window
was
shortly
after
opened
,
and
a
rope
ladder
,
with
a
lighted
horn
lantern
attached
to
it
,
let
down
.
 
<EOS>
Wood
grasped
his
companion
's
arm
to
attract
his
attention
to
this
unexpected
means
of
escape
.
<EOS>
The
ladder
was
now
within
reach
.
<EOS>
Both
advanced
towards
it
,
when
,
by
the
light
of
the
lantern
,
Wood
beheld
,
in
the
countenance
of
the
stranger
,
the
well
-
remembered
and
stern
features
of
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
The
carpenter
trembled
;
for
he
perceived
Rowland
's
gaze
fixed
first
upon
the
infant
,
and
then
on
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
<EOS>
_
is
_
her
child
!
"
<EOS>
shrieked
Rowland
,
in
a
voice
heard
above
the
howling
of
the
tempest
,
"
risen
from
this
roaring
abyss
to
torment
me
.
<EOS>
Its
parents
have
perished
.
<EOS>
And
shall
their
wretched
offspring
live
to
blight
my
hopes
,
and
blast
my
fame
?
<EOS>
Never
!
"
<EOS>
And
,
with
these
words
,
he
grasped
Wood
by
the
throat
,
and
,
despite
his
resistance
,
dragged
him
to
the
very
verge
of
the
platform
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
juncture
,
a
thundering
crash
was
heard
against
the
side
of
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
A
stack
of
chimneys
,
on
the
house
above
them
,
had
yielded
to
the
storm
,
and
descended
in
a
shower
of
bricks
and
stones
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
carpenter
a
moment
afterwards
stretched
out
his
hand
,
scarcely
knowing
whether
he
was
alive
or
dead
,
he
found
himself
alone
.
<EOS>
The
fatal
shower
,
from
which
he
and
his
little
charge
escaped
uninjured
,
had
stricken
his
assailant
and
precipitated
him
into
the
boiling
gulf
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
ill
wind
that
blows
nobody
good
,
"
thought
the
carpenter
,
turning
his
attention
to
the
child
,
whose
feeble
struggles
and
cries
proclaimed
that
,
as
yet
,
life
had
not
been
extinguished
by
the
hardships
it
had
undergone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
little
creature
!
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
,
pressing
it
tenderly
to
his
breast
,
as
he
grasped
the
rope
and
clambered
up
to
the
window
:
"
if
thou
hast
,
indeed
,
lost
both
thy
parents
,
as
that
terrible
man
said
just
now
,
thou
art
not
wholly
friendless
and
deserted
,
for
I
myself
will
be
a
father
to
thee
!
<EOS>
And
in
memory
of
this
dreadful
night
,
and
the
death
from
which
I
have
,
been
the
means
of
preserving
thee
,
thou
shalt
bear
the
name
of
THAMES
DARRELL
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
No
sooner
had
Wood
crept
through
the
window
,
than
nature
gave
way
,
and
he
fainted
.
<EOS>
On
coming
to
himself
,
he
found
he
had
been
wrapped
in
a
blanket
and
put
to
bed
with
a
couple
of
hot
bricks
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
His
first
inquiries
were
concerning
the
child
,
and
he
was
delighted
to
find
that
it
still
lived
and
was
doing
well
.
<EOS>
Every
care
had
been
taken
of
it
,
as
well
as
of
himself
,
by
the
humane
inmates
of
the
house
in
which
he
had
sought
shelter
.
 
<EOS>
About
noon
,
next
day
,
he
was
able
to
move
;
and
the
gale
having
abated
,
he
set
out
homewards
with
his
little
charge
.
 
<EOS>
The
city
presented
a
terrible
picture
of
devastation
.
<EOS>
London
Bridge
had
suffered
a
degree
less
than
most
places
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
almost
choked
up
with
fallen
stacks
of
chimneys
,
broken
beams
of
timber
,
and
shattered
tiles
.
<EOS>
The
houses
overhung
in
a
frightful
manner
,
and
looked
as
if
the
next
gust
would
precipitate
them
into
the
river
.
<EOS>
With
great
difficulty
,
Wood
forced
a
path
through
the
ruins
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
work
of
no
slight
danger
,
for
every
instant
a
wall
,
or
fragment
of
a
building
,
came
crashing
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Thames
Street
was
wholly
impassable
.
<EOS>
Men
were
going
hither
and
thither
with
barrows
,
and
ladders
and
ropes
,
removing
the
rubbish
,
and
trying
to
support
the
tottering
habitations
.
<EOS>
Grace
-
church
Street
was
entirely
deserted
,
except
by
a
few
stragglers
,
whose
curiosity
got
the
better
of
their
fears
;
or
who
,
like
the
carpenter
,
were
compelled
to
proceed
along
it
.
<EOS>
The
tiles
lay
a
foot
thick
in
the
road
.
<EOS>
In
some
cases
they
were
ground
almost
to
powder
;
in
others
,
driven
deeply
into
the
earth
,
as
if
discharged
from
a
piece
of
ordnance
.
<EOS>
The
roofs
and
gables
of
many
of
the
houses
had
been
torn
off
.
<EOS>
The
signs
of
the
shops
were
carried
to
incredible
distances
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
a
building
might
be
seen
with
the
doors
and
windows
driven
in
,
and
all
access
to
it
prevented
by
the
heaps
of
bricks
and
tilesherds
.
 
<EOS>
Through
this
confusion
the
carpenter
struggled
on;--now
ascending
,
now
descending
the
different
mountains
of
rubbish
that
beset
his
path
,
at
the
imminent
peril
of
his
life
and
limbs
,
until
he
arrived
in
Fleet
Street
.
<EOS>
The
hurricane
appeared
to
have
raged
in
this
quarter
with
tenfold
fury
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
scarcely
knew
where
he
was
.
<EOS>
The
old
aspect
of
the
place
was
gone
.
<EOS>
In
lieu
of
the
substantial
habitations
which
he
had
gazed
on
overnight
,
he
beheld
a
row
of
falling
scaffoldings
,
for
such
they
seemed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
dismal
and
depressing
sight
to
see
a
great
city
thus
suddenly
overthrown
;
and
the
carpenter
was
deeply
moved
by
the
spectacle
.
<EOS>
As
usual
,
however
,
on
the
occasion
of
any
great
calamity
,
a
crowd
was
scouring
the
streets
,
whose
sole
object
was
plunder
.
<EOS>
While
involved
in
this
crowd
,
near
Temple
<EOS>
Bar,--where
the
thoroughfare
was
most
dangerous
from
the
masses
of
ruin
that
impeded
it,--an
<EOS>
individual
,
whose
swarthy
features
recalled
to
the
carpenter
one
of
his
tormentors
of
the
previous
night
,
collared
him
,
and
,
with
bitter
imprecations
accused
him
of
stealing
his
child
.
<EOS>
In
vain
Wood
protested
his
innocence
.
<EOS>
The
ruffian
's
companions
took
his
part
.
<EOS>
And
the
infant
,
in
all
probability
,
would
have
been
snatched
from
its
preserver
,
if
a
posse
of
the
watch
(
sent
out
to
maintain
order
and
protect
property
)
had
not
opportunely
arrived
,
and
by
a
vigorous
application
of
their
halberts
dispersed
his
persecutors
,
and
set
him
at
liberty
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
then
took
to
his
heels
,
and
never
once
looked
behind
him
till
he
reached
his
own
dwelling
in
Wych
Street
.
<EOS>
His
wife
met
him
at
the
door
,
and
into
her
hands
he
delivered
his
little
charge
.
  
<EOS>
END
OF
THE
FIRST
EPOCH
.
     
<EOS>
EPOCH
<EOS>
THE
SECOND
.
 
<EOS>
1715
.
 
<EOS>
THAMES
DARRELL
.
       
<EOS>
CHAPTER
I.
 
<EOS>
The
Idle
Apprentice
.
  
<EOS>
Twelve
years
!
<EOS>
How
many
events
have
occurred
during
that
long
interval
!
<EOS>
how
many
changes
have
taken
place
!
<EOS>
The
whole
aspect
of
things
is
altered
.
<EOS>
The
child
has
sprung
into
a
youth
;
the
youth
has
become
a
man
;
the
man
has
already
begun
to
feel
the
advances
of
age
.
<EOS>
Beauty
has
bloomed
and
faded
.
<EOS>
Fresh
flowers
of
loveliness
have
budded
,
expanded
,
died
.
<EOS>
The
fashions
of
the
day
have
become
antiquated
.
<EOS>
New
customs
have
prevailed
over
the
old
.
<EOS>
Parties
,
politics
,
and
popular
opinions
have
changed
.
<EOS>
The
crown
has
passed
from
the
brow
of
one
monarch
to
that
of
another
.
<EOS>
Habits
and
tastes
are
no
longer
the
same
.
<EOS>
We
,
ourselves
,
are
scarcely
the
same
we
were
twelve
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Twelve
years
ago
!
<EOS>
It
is
an
awful
retrospect
.
<EOS>
Dare
we
look
back
upon
the
darkened
vista
,
and
,
in
imagination
retrace
the
path
we
have
trod
?
<EOS>
With
how
many
vain
hopes
is
it
shaded
!
<EOS>
with
how
many
good
resolutions
,
never
fulfilled
,
is
it
paved
!
<EOS>
Where
are
the
dreams
of
ambition
in
which
,
twelve
years
ago
,
we
indulged
?
<EOS>
Where
are
the
aspirations
that
fired
us
--
the
passions
that
consumed
us
then
?
<EOS>
Has
our
success
in
life
been
commensurate
with
our
own
desires
--
with
the
anticipations
formed
of
us
by
others
?
<EOS>
Or
,
are
we
not
blighted
in
heart
,
as
in
ambition
?
<EOS>
Has
not
the
loved
one
been
estranged
by
doubt
,
or
snatched
from
us
by
the
cold
hand
of
death
?
<EOS>
Is
not
the
goal
,
towards
which
we
pressed
,
further
off
than
ever
--
the
prospect
before
us
cheerless
as
the
blank
behind?--Enough
of
this
.
<EOS>
Let
us
proceed
with
our
tale
.
 
<EOS>
Twelve
years
,
then
,
have
elapsed
since
the
date
of
the
occurrences
detailed
in
the
preceding
division
of
this
history
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
we
were
beneath
the
sway
of
Anne
:
we
are
now
at
the
commencement
of
the
reign
of
George
the
First
.
<EOS>
Passing
at
a
glance
over
the
whole
of
the
intervening
period
;
leaving
in
the
words
of
the
poet
,
     
--The
growth
untried
    
Of
that
wide
gap--
 
we
shall
resume
our
narrative
at
the
beginning
of
June
,
1715
.
 
<EOS>
One
Friday
afternoon
,
in
this
pleasant
month
,
it
chanced
that
Mr.
Wood
,
who
had
been
absent
on
business
during
the
greater
part
of
the
day
,
returned
(
perhaps
not
altogether
undesignedly
)
at
an
earlier
hour
than
was
expected
,
to
his
dwelling
in
Wych
Street
,
Drury
Lane
;
and
was
about
to
enter
his
workshop
,
when
,
not
hearing
any
sound
of
labour
issue
from
within
,
he
began
to
suspect
that
an
apprentice
,
of
whose
habits
of
industry
he
entertained
some
doubt
,
was
neglecting
his
employment
.
<EOS>
Impressed
with
this
idea
,
he
paused
for
a
moment
to
listen
.
<EOS>
But
finding
all
continue
silent
,
he
cautiously
lifted
the
latch
,
and
crept
into
the
room
,
resolved
to
punish
the
offender
in
case
his
suspicions
should
prove
correct
.
 
<EOS>
The
chamber
,
into
which
he
stole
,
like
all
carpenters
'
workshops
,
was
crowded
with
the
implements
and
materials
of
that
ancient
and
honourable
art
.
<EOS>
Saws
,
hammers
,
planes
,
axes
,
augers
,
adzes
,
chisels
,
gimblets
,
and
an
endless
variety
of
tools
were
ranged
,
like
a
stand
of
martial
weapons
at
an
armoury
,
in
racks
against
the
walls
.
<EOS>
Over
these
hung
levels
,
bevels
,
squares
,
and
other
instruments
of
measurement
.
<EOS>
Amid
a
litter
of
nails
without
heads
,
screws
without
worms
,
and
locks
without
wards
,
lay
a
glue
-
pot
and
an
oilstone
,
two
articles
which
their
owner
was
wo
nt
to
term
"
his
right
hand
and
his
left
.
<EOS>
"
On
a
shelf
was
placed
a
row
of
paint
-
jars
;
the
contents
of
which
had
been
daubed
in
rainbow
streaks
upon
the
adjacent
closet
and
window
sill
.
<EOS>
Divers
plans
and
figures
were
chalked
upon
the
walls
;
and
the
spaces
between
them
were
filled
up
with
an
almanack
for
the
year
;
a
godly
ballad
,
adorned
with
a
rude
wood
-
cut
,
purporting
to
be
"
_
<EOS>
The
History
of
Chaste
Susannah
_
;
"
an
old
print
of
the
Seven
Golden
Candlesticks
;
an
abstract
of
the
various
Acts
of
Parliament
against
drinking
,
swearing
,
and
all
manner
of
profaneness
;
and
a
view
of
the
interior
of
Doctor
Daniel
Burgess
's
Presbyterian
meeting
-
house
in
Russell
Court
,
with
portraits
of
the
reverend
gentleman
and
the
principal
members
of
his
flock
.
<EOS>
The
floor
was
thickly
strewn
with
sawdust
and
shavings
;
and
across
the
room
ran
a
long
and
wide
bench
,
furnished
at
one
end
with
a
powerful
vice
;
next
to
which
three
nails
driven
into
the
boards
served
,
it
would
appear
from
the
lump
of
unconsumed
tallow
left
in
their
custody
,
as
a
substitute
for
a
candlestick
.
<EOS>
On
the
bench
was
set
a
quartern
measure
of
gin
,
a
crust
of
bread
,
and
a
slice
of
cheese
.
<EOS>
Attracted
by
the
odour
of
the
latter
dainty
,
a
hungry
cat
had
contrived
to
scratch
open
the
paper
in
which
it
was
wrapped
,
displaying
the
following
words
in
large
characters:--"THE
HISTORY
OF
THE
FOUR
KINGS
,
OR
CHILD
'S
BEST
GUIDE
TO
THE
GALLOWS
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
as
if
to
make
the
moral
more
obvious
,
a
dirty
pack
of
cards
was
scattered
,
underneath
,
upon
the
sawdust
.
<EOS>
Near
the
door
stood
a
pile
of
deal
planks
,
behind
which
the
carpenter
ensconced
himself
in
order
to
reconnoitre
,
unobserved
,
the
proceedings
of
his
idle
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
on
tiptoe
,
on
a
joint
-
stool
,
placed
upon
the
bench
,
with
his
back
to
the
door
,
and
a
clasp
-
knife
in
his
hand
,
this
youngster
,
instead
of
executing
his
appointed
task
,
was
occupied
in
carving
his
name
upon
a
beam
,
overhead
.
<EOS>
Boys
,
at
the
time
of
which
we
write
,
were
attired
like
men
of
their
own
day
,
or
certain
charity
-
children
of
ours
;
and
the
stripling
in
question
was
dressed
in
black
plush
breeches
,
and
a
gray
drugget
waistcoat
,
with
immoderately
long
pockets
,
both
of
which
were
evidently
the
cast
-
off
clothes
of
some
one
considerably
his
senior
.
<EOS>
Coat
,
on
the
present
occasion
,
he
had
none
,
it
being
more
convenient
,
as
well
as
agreeable
to
him
,
to
pursue
his
avocations
in
his
shirtsleeves
;
but
,
when
fully
equipped
,
he
wore
a
large
-
cuffed
,
long
-
skirted
garment
,
which
had
once
been
the
property
of
his
master
.
 
<EOS>
In
concealing
himself
behind
the
timber
,
Mr.
Wood
could
not
avoid
making
a
slight
shuffling
sound
.
<EOS>
The
noise
startled
the
apprentice
,
who
instantly
suspended
his
labour
,
and
gazed
anxiously
in
the
direction
<EOS>
whence
he
supposed
it
proceeded
.
<EOS>
His
face
was
that
of
a
quick
,
intelligent
-
looking
boy
,
with
fine
hazel
eyes
,
and
a
clear
olive
complexion
.
<EOS>
His
figure
was
uncommonly
slim
even
for
his
age
,
which
could
not
be
more
than
thirteen
;
and
the
looseness
of
his
garb
made
him
appear
thinner
than
he
was
in
reality
.
<EOS>
But
if
his
frame
was
immature
,
his
looks
were
not
so
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
possess
a
penetration
and
cunning
beyond
his
years
--
to
hide
a
man
's
judgment
under
a
boy
's
mask
.
<EOS>
The
glance
,
which
he
threw
at
the
door
,
was
singularly
expressive
of
his
character
:
it
was
a
mixture
of
alarm
,
effrontery
,
and
resolution
.
<EOS>
In
the
end
,
resolution
triumphed
,
as
it
was
sure
to
do
,
over
the
weaker
emotions
,
and
he
laughed
at
his
fears
.
<EOS>
The
only
part
of
his
otherwise
-
interesting
countenance
,
to
which
one
could
decidedly
object
,
was
the
mouth
;
a
feature
that
,
more
than
any
other
,
is
conceived
to
betray
the
animal
propensities
of
the
possessor
.
<EOS>
If
this
is
true
,
it
must
be
owned
that
the
boy
's
mouth
showed
a
strong
tendency
on
his
part
to
coarse
indulgence
.
<EOS>
The
eyes
,
too
,
though
large
and
bright
,
and
shaded
by
long
lashes
,
seemed
to
betoken
,
as
hazel
eyes
generally
do
in
men
,
a
faithless
and
uncertain
disposition
.
<EOS>
The
cheek
-
bones
were
prominent
:
the
nose
slightly
depressed
,
with
rather
wide
nostrils
;
the
chin
narrow
,
but
well
-
formed
;
the
forehead
broad
and
lofty
;
and
he
possessed
such
an
extraordinary
flexibility
of
muscle
in
this
region
,
that
he
could
elevate
his
eye
-
brows
at
pleasure
up
to
the
very
verge
of
his
sleek
and
shining
black
hair
,
which
,
being
closely
cropped
,
to
admit
of
his
occasionally
wearing
a
wig
,
gave
a
singular
bullet
-
shape
to
his
head
.
<EOS>
Taken
altogether
,
his
physiognomy
resembled
one
of
those
vagabond
heads
which
Murillo
delighted
to
paint
,
and
for
which
Guzman
d'Alfarache
,
Lazarillo
de
Tormes
,
or
Estevanillo
Gonzalez
might
have
sat:--faces
that
almost
make
one
in
love
with
roguery
,
they
seem
so
full
of
vivacity
and
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
There
was
all
the
knavery
,
and
more
than
all
the
drollery
of
a
Spanish
picaroon
in
the
laughing
eyes
of
the
English
apprentice
;
and
,
with
a
little
more
warmth
and
sunniness
of
skin
on
the
side
of
the
latter
,
the
resemblance
between
them
would
have
been
complete
.
 
<EOS>
Satisfied
,
as
he
thought
,
that
he
had
nothing
to
apprehend
<EOS>
,
the
boy
resumed
his
task
,
chanting
,
as
he
plied
his
knife
with
redoubled
assiduity
,
the
following
--
not
inappropriate
strains:--
     
<EOS>
THE
NEWGATE
STONE
.
     
<EOS>
When
Claude
Du
Val
was
in
Newgate
thrown
,
    
He
carved
his
name
on
the
dungeon
stone
;
    
Quoth
<EOS>
a
dubsman
,
who
gazed
on
the
shattered
wall
,
    
<EOS>
"
You
have
carved
your

,
Claude
Du
Val
,
        
_
<EOS>
With
your
chisel
so
fine
,
tra
la
_
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
S
wants
a
little
deepening
,
"
mused

apprentice
,
retouching
the
letter
in
question
;
"
ay
,
that
's
better
.
"
     
<EOS>
Du
Val
was
hang'd
,
and
the
next
who
came
    
<EOS>
On
the
selfsame

inscribed
his

:
    
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
<EOS>
quoth

,
with

<EOS>
,
    
"
Tom
Waters
_
your
_
doom
is
the

!
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
With
your

so

,
tra
la
_
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
,
tut
,
"
he

,
"
<EOS>
what
a
fool
I
am
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
I
ought

have
cut
John
,

Jack
.
<EOS>
However
,
it
do
n't
signify
.
<EOS>
Nobody
ever
called

John
,
that
I

.
<EOS>
So
I
dare

I
was

Jack
.
<EOS>
Deuce
take

!
<EOS>
I
was
very
near
spelling
my
name
with
one
P.
     
<EOS>
Within
that
dungeon
lay
Captain
Bew
,
    
Rumbold
and
Whitney
--
a
jolly

!
    
<EOS>
All
carved

on

,
and
all
    
Share

of
the
brave
Du
Val
!
        
_
<EOS>
With

<EOS>

,

_
!
 
<EOS>
"
Save

!
"
<EOS>

,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
this
beam
does

;

I

,

the

<EOS>
No
fear
<EOS>
o

.
<EOS>
The

of

gallows
would
never

,

.
     
<EOS>
Full
twenty
highwaymen
blithe

,
    
Rattled

in
that

;
    
Of

there

<EOS>
Who

.
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>

,

_
!
 
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
cried

,

,

.
<EOS>
Claude
du

himself
could

ha

"
 
<EOS>
The

(

,

,

<EOS>
[

:
Jack
Sheppard
(
signature
)
]
 
<EOS>
"
I
've

Wood

,

,
"
cried

,
as

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
devil
you
have
!
"
thundered
a

from

,
that
filled

with

.
<EOS>
"
Come
down
,
sirrah
,
and
I
'll
teach

how
to
deface
my
walls
in
future
.
<EOS>
Come
down
,
I
say
,

,

I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
Mr.
Wood
caught
hold
of
Jack
's
leg
,
and
dragged

off

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
'll
turn
highwayman
<EOS>
,

,

?
"

,

<EOS>
the
mails
,
like
Jack
Hall
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

Jack

,
"
if

in

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Amazed
at
the
boy
's
assurance
,
Wood
left
off
boxing

ears
for
a
moment
,
and
,
looking

steadfastly
,
said
in
a
grave

,
"
Jack
,
Jack
,
you
'll
come
to

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Better
be
hanged
than
hen
-
pecked
,
"
retorted
the
lad
with
a
malicious

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
,
sirrah
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
,
reddening
with
anger
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
dare
to
insinuate
that
Mrs.
Wood
governs
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
plain
you
ca
n't
govern
yourself
,
at
all
events
,
"
replied
Jack
coolly
;
"
but
,
be
that
as
it

,
I
wo
n't
be
struck
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
echoed
Wood

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
call

,

nothing
?
<EOS>
Zounds
!
<EOS>
you
incorrigible
rascal
,
many
a
master
would
have
taken
you
before
a

,
and

in
Bridewell
for

.
<EOS>
But
I
'll

,

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,

,

;
"
but
I
would

to
lay

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
glanced
at
the
hardy
offender
,
and
not
liking
the
expression
of
his
countenance
,
thought
it
advisable
to
postpone
the
execution
of
his

to
a

.
<EOS>
So
,
by
way

,
he
resolved
to
question
him
further
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
did
you
learn
the
song
I
heard
just
now
?
<EOS>
"
he
demanded
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
At
the
Black
Lion
in

street
,
"
replied
Jack
,
without

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
worst
house
in
the

--
the

and

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
And
who
taught

you
--
the

,
Joe
Hind
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
;
one
Blueskin
,
a
fellow

Lion
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

that

that

to

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
white
wall
is

's
paper
,
Jack,--remember
that
,
"

Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pretty

!
<EOS>
Why
,

you

.
<EOS>
He
was

at

last
Old
Bailey

;
and

.
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

"

"

<EOS>

A

,

<EOS>

Hem

"

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Speak

"

.
<EOS>
"
If

,

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

"
<EOS>

,

"
for

.
<EOS>
Do

know

,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Where

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

at
the
Lion
!
<EOS>
and
who
,
though
he
slouched
his
hat
over
his
eyes
,
and
muffled
his
chin
in
a
handkerchief
,
must
have
been
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
did
_
he
_
get
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Wood
,
in
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
ca
n't
say
.
<EOS>
But
he
promised
to
give
me
a
couple
of
guineas
if
I
'd
ascertain
whether
it
fitted
your
locks
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Zounds
!
"
exclaimed
Wood
;
"
it
's
my
old
master
-
key
.
<EOS>
This
key
,
"
he
added
,
taking
it
from
the
boy
,
"
was
purloined
from
me
by
your
father
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
What
he
intended
to
do
with
it
is
of
little
consequence
now
.
<EOS>
But
before
he
suffered
at
Tyburn
,
he
charged
your
mother
to
restore
it
.
<EOS>
She
lost
it
in
the
Mint
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
must
have
stolen
it
from
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
,
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
hastily
;
"
but
only
let
me
have
it
<EOS>
till
to
-
morrow
,
and
if
I
do
n't
entrap
him
in
a
snare
from
which
,
with
all
his
cunning
,
he
shall
find
it
difficult
to
escape
,
my
name
's
not
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
through
your
design
,
Jack
,
"
returned
the
carpenter
,
gravely
;
"
but
I
do
n't
like
under
-
hand
work
.
<EOS>
Even
when
you
've
a
knave
to
deal
with
,
let
your
actions
be
plain
,
and
above
-
board
.
<EOS>
That
's
my
maxim
;
and
it
's
the
maxim
of
every
honest
man
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
great
matter
,
I
must
own
,
to
bring
Jonathan
Wild
to
justice
.
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
consent
to
the
course
you
would
pursue
--
at
least
,
not
till
I
've
given
it
due
consideration
.
<EOS>
In
regard
to
yourself
,
you
've
had
a
very
narrow
escape
.
<EOS>
Wild
's
intention
,
doubtless
,
was
to
use
you
as
far
as
he
found
necessary
,
and
then
to
sell
you
.
<EOS>
Let
this
be
a
caution
to
you
in
future
--
with
whom
,
and
about
what
you
deal
.
<EOS>
We
're
told
,
that
'
Whoso
is
partner
with
a
thief
hateth
his
own
soul
.
'
<EOS>
Avoid
taverns
and
bad
company
,
and
you
may
yet
do
well
.
<EOS>
You
promise
to
become
a
first
-
rate
workman
.
<EOS>
But
you
want
one
quality
,
without
which
all
others
are
valueless
.
<EOS>
You
want
industry
--
you
want
steadiness
.
<EOS>
Idleness
is
the
key
of
beggary
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
conquer
this
disgraceful
propensity
in
time
,
you
'll
soon
come
to
want
;
and
then
nothing
can
save
you
.
<EOS>
Be
warned
by
your
father
's
fate
.
<EOS>
As
you
brew
so
must
you
drink
.
<EOS>
I
've
engaged
to
watch
over
you
as
a
son
,
and
I
_
will
_
do
so
as
far
as
I
'm
able
;
but
if
you
neglect
my
advice
,
what
chance
have
I
of
benefitting
you
?
<EOS>
On
one
point
I
've
made
up
my
mind
--
you
shall
either
obey
me
,
or
leave
me
.
<EOS>
Please
yourself
.
<EOS>
Here
are
your
indentures
,
if
you
choose
to
seek
another
master
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
will
_
obey
you
,
master,--indeed
<EOS>
I
will
!
"
<EOS>
implored
Jack
,
seriously
alarmed
at
the
carpenter
's
calm
displeasure
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
.
<EOS>
Good
words
,
without
deeds
,
are
rushes
and
reeds
.
<EOS>
And
now
take
away
those
cards
,
and
never
let
me
see
them
again
.
<EOS>
Drive
away
the
cat
;
throw
that
measure
of
gin
through
the
window
;
and
tell
me
why
you
've
not
so
much
as
touched
the
packing
-
case
for
Lady
Trafford
,
which
I
particularly
desired
you
to
complete
against

.
<EOS>
It
must
be
sent
home
this
evening
.
<EOS>
She
leaves
town
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
ready
in
two
hours
,
"
answered
Jack
,
seizing
a
piece
of
wood
and
a
plane
;
"
it
is
n't
more
than
four
o'clock
.
<EOS>
I
'll
engage
to
get
the
job
done
by
six
.
<EOS>
I
did
n't
expect
you
home
before
that
hour
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Jack
,
"
said
Wood
,

,
"
where
there
's
a
will
there
's
a
way
.
<EOS>
You
can
do
anything
you

.
<EOS>
I
wish

get

to
imitate
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
understand
the

of
a
carpenter
much

than
he
does
,
"
replied
Jack
,
adroitly
adjusting
the

,
and

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"

Wood
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
was

your

,
"
observed
Jack
,
as

on

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've

,

,
"

Wood
;
"
nor
shall
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
had
the
hard

,

,
"

Jack
,
"
<EOS>
But
I
wo
n't
complain
.
<EOS>
I
'd
do
anything
for
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
Thames
Darrell
would
do
anything
for
you
,
Jack
,
"
replied
a

.
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
,
father
!
"
continued

,

.
"
<EOS>
Has
Jack

?
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
I
'm

'll

best

.
<EOS>
Wo

you
,
Jack
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
will
,
"

Sheppard
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
When
it
thunders
,
the
thief
becomes
honest
,
"
muttered
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
help
you
,
Jack
?
"
asked
Thames
,
taking

a
plane
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
let
him
alone
,
"
interposed
Wood
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
undertaken
to

this

by
six

,
and
I
wish
to
see
whether
he
'll

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
have
hard

to

by

,
father
,
"
remonstrated
Thames
;
"
you
'd
better
let
me

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
no

,
"
rejoined
Wood
peremptorily
.
<EOS>
"
A
little
extra
exertion
will
teach
him
the

of

at
the
proper
season
.
<EOS>
Lost
ground
must
be
regained
.
<EOS>
I
need
scarcely
ask
whether
you
've
executed
your
appointed
task
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
You
're
never
behindhand
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
turned
away
at
the
question
,
which
he
felt
might
be
construed
into
a
reproach
.
<EOS>
But
Sheppard
answered
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Darrell
's
job
was
done
early
this
morning
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
if
I
'd
attended
to
his
advice
,
the

-
case
would
have
been

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
trusted
too
much
to
your
own
skill
,
Jack
,
"
rejoined
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
work
as
fast
as
you
,
I
might
afford
to
be
as
idle
.
<EOS>
See
how
he
gets
on
,
father
,
"
he
added
,
appealing
to
Wood
:
"
the
box
seems
to
grow
under
his
hands
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
noble
-
hearted
little
fellow
,
Thames
,
"
rejoined
Wood
,
casting
a
look
of
pride
and
