at
his
adopted
son
,
whose
head
he
gently
patted
;
"
and
give
promise
of
a
glorious
manhood
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
was
,
indeed
,
a
youth
of
whom
a
person
of
far
greater
worldly
consequence
than
the
worthy
carpenter
might
have
been
justly
proud
.
<EOS>
Though
a
few
months
younger
than
his
companion
Jack
Sheppard
,
he
was
half
a
head
taller
,
and
much
more
robustly
formed
.
<EOS>
The
two
friends
contrasted
strikingly
with
each
other
.
<EOS>
In
Darrell
's
open
features
,
frankness
and
honour
were
written
in
legible
characters
;
while
,
in
Jack
's
physiognomy
,
cunning
and
knavery
were
as
strongly
imprinted
.
<EOS>
In
all
other
respects
they
differed
as
materially
.
<EOS>
Jack
could
hardly
be
accounted
good
-
looking
:
<EOS>
Thames
,
on
the
contrary
,
was
one
of
the
handsomest
boys
possible
.
<EOS>
Jack
's
complexion
was
that
of
a
gipsy
;
Darrell
's
as
fresh
and
bright
as
a
rose
.
<EOS>
Jack
's
mouth
was
coarse
and
large
;
Darrell
's
small
and
exquisitely
carved
,
with
the
short
,
proud
upper
lip
,
which
belongs
to
the
highest
order
of
beauty
.
<EOS>
Jack
's
nose
was
broad
and
flat
;
<EOS>
Darrell
's
straight
and
fine
as
that
of
Antinous
.
<EOS>
The
expression
pervading
the
countenance
of
the
one
was
vulgarity
;
of
the
other
,
that
which
is
rarely
found
,
except
in
persons
of
high
birth
.
<EOS>
Darrell
's
eyes
were
of
that
clear
gray
which
it
is
difficult
to
distinguish
from
blue
by
day
and
black
at
night
;
and
his
rich
brown
hair
,
which
he
could
not
consent
to
part
with
,
even
on
the
promise
of
a
new
and
modish
peruke
from
his
adoptive
father
,
fell
in
thick
glossy
ringlets
upon
his
shoulders
;
whereas
Jack
's
close
black
crop
imparted
the
peculiar
bullet
-
shape
we
have
noticed
,
to
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
While
Thames
modestly
expressed
a
hope
that
he
might
not
belie
the
carpenter
's
favourable
prediction
,
Jack
Sheppard
thought
fit
to
mount
a
small
ladder
placed
against
the
wall
,
and
,
springing
with
the
agility
of
an
ape
upon
a
sort
of
frame
,
contrived
to
sustain
short
spars
and
blocks
of
timber
,
began
to
search
about
for
a
piece
of
wood
required
in
the
work
on
which
he
was
engaged
.
<EOS>
Being
in
a
great
hurry
,
he
took
little
heed
where
he
set
his
feet
;
and
a
board
giving
way
,
he
must
have
fallen
,
if
he
had
not
grasped
a
large
plank
laid
upon
the
transverse
beam
immediately
over
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
care
,
Jack
,
"
shouted
Thames
,
who
witnessed
the
occurrence
;
"
that
plank
is
n't
properly
balanced
.
<EOS>
You
'll
have
it
down
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
the
caution
came
too
late
.
<EOS>
Sheppard
's
weight
had
destroyed
the
equilibrium
of
the
plank
:
it
swerved
,
and
slowly
descended
.
<EOS>
Losing
his
presence
of
mind
,
Jack
quitted
his
hold
,
and
dropped
upon
the
frame
.
<EOS>
The
plank
hung
over
his
head
.
<EOS>
A
moment
more
<EOS>
and
he
would
have
been
crushed
beneath
the
ponderous
board
,
when
a
slight
but
strong
arm
arrested
its
descent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
from
under
it
,
Jack
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
hold
it
much
longer
--
<EOS>
it'll
break
my
wrist
.
<EOS>
Down
we
come
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
letting
go
the
plank
,
which
fell
with
a
crash
,
and
leaping
after
Sheppard
,
who
had
rolled
off
the
frame
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
the
work
of
a
minute
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
bones
broken
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Thames
,
laughing
at
Jack
,
who
limped
towards
the
bench
,
rubbing
his
shins
as
he
went
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
with
affected
indifference
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
mercy
you
both
escaped
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wood
,
only
just
finding
his
tongue
.
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
'm
all
in
a
cold
sweat
.
<EOS>
How
came
you
,
Sir
,
"
he
continued
,
addressing
Sheppard
,
"
to
venture
upon
that
frame
.
<EOS>
I
always
told
you
some
accident
would
happen
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
scold
him
,
father
,
"
interposed
Thames
;
"
he
's
been
frightened
enough
already
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
since
you
desire
it
,
I
'll
say
no
more
,
"
returned
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
You
hay'n't
hurt
your
arm
,
I
trust
,
my
dear
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
sprained
it
a
little
,
that
's
all
,
"
answered
Thames
;
"
the
pain
will
go
off
presently
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
_
are
_
hurt
,
"
cried
the
carpenter
in
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
Come
down
stairs
directly
,
and
let
your
mother
look
at
your
wrist
.
<EOS>
She
has
an
excellent
remedy
for
a
sprain
.
<EOS>
And
do
you
,
Jack
,
attend
to
your
work
,
and
mind
you
do
n't
get
into
further
mischief
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Had
n't
Jack
better
go
with
us
?
"
said
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
His
shin
may
need
rubbing
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
,
"
rejoined
Wood
,
hastily
.
<EOS>
"
A
little
suffering
will
do
him
good
.
<EOS>
I
meant
to
give
him
a
drubbing
.
<EOS>
That
bruise
will
answer
the
same
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
,
"
said
Sheppard
in
a
low
voice
,
as
he
threw
a
vindictive
glance
at
the
carpenter
,
"
I
sha
n't
forget
this
.
<EOS>
You
've
saved
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
<EOS>
you
'd
do
as
much
for
me
any
day
,
and
think
no
more
about
it
.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
your
turn
to
save
mine
next
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
and
I
sha
n't
be
easy
till
my
turn
arrives
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
Jack
,
"
whispered
Thames
,
who
had
noticed
Sheppard
's
menacing
glance
,
and
dreaded
some
further
indiscretion
on
his
part
,
"
if
you
really
wish
to
oblige
me
,
you
'll
get
that
packing
-
case
finished
by
six
o'clock
.
<EOS>
You
_
can
_
do
it
,
if
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
_
will
_
,
if
I
can
,
depend
upon
it
,
"
answered
Sheppard
,
with
a
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
manfully
resumed
his
work
;
while
Wood
and
Thames
quitted
the
room
,
and
went
down
stairs
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II
.
 
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
.
  
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
's
arm
having
been
submitted
to
the
scrutiny
of
Mrs.
Wood
,
was
pronounced
by
that
lady
to
be
very
much
sprained
;
and
she
,
forthwith
,
proceeded
to
bathe
it
with
a
reddish
-
coloured
lotion
.
<EOS>
During
this
operation
,
the
carpenter
underwent
a
severe
catechism
as
to
the
cause
of
the
accident
;
and
,
on
learning
that
the
mischance
originated
with
Jack
Sheppard
,
the
indignation
of
his
helpmate
knew
no
bounds
;
and
she
was
with
difficulty
prevented
from
flying
to
the
workshop
to
inflict
summary
punishment
on
the
offender
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
how
it
would
be
,
"
she
cried
,
in
the
shrill
voice
peculiar
to
a
shrew
,
"
when
you
brought
that
worthless
hussy
's
worthless
brat
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
I
told
you
no
good
would
come
of
it
.
<EOS>
And
every
day
's
experience
proves
that
I
was
right
.
<EOS>
But
,
like
all
your
overbearing
sex
,
you
must
have
your
own
way
.
<EOS>
You
'll
never
be
guided
by
me
--
never
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
my
love
,
you
're
entirely
mistaken
,
"
returned
the
carpenter
,
endeavouring
to
deprecate
his
wife
's
rising
resentment
by
the
softest
looks
,
and
the
meekest
deportment
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
,
however
,
was
this
submission
from
producing
the
desired
effect
,
that
it
seemed
only
to
lend
additional
fuel
to
her
displeasure
.
<EOS>
Forgetting
her
occupation
in
her
anger
,
she
left
off
bathing
Darrell
's
wrist
;
and
,
squeezing
his
arm
so
tightly
that
the
boy
winced
with
pain
,
she
clapped
her
right
hand
upon
her
hip
,
and
turned
,
with
flashing
eyes
and
an
inflamed
countenance
,
towards
her
crest
-
fallen
spouse
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
almost
choked
with
passion,--"_I
_
<EOS>
advised
you
to
burthen
yourself
with
that
idle
and
good
-
for
-
nothing
pauper
,
who'm
you
ought
rather
to
send
to
the
workhouse
than
maintain
at
your
own
expense
,
did
I
!
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
_
advised
you
to
take
him
as
an
apprentice
;
and
,
so
far
from
getting
the
regular
fee
with
him
,
to
give
him
a
salary
?
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
_
advised
you
to
feed
him
,
and
clothe
him
,
and
treat
him
like
his
betters
;
to
put
up
with
his
insolence
,
and
wink
at
his
faults
?
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
_
counselled
all
this
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
You
'll
tell
me
next
,
I
dare
say
,
that
I
recommended
you
to
go
and
visit
his
mother
so
frequently
under
the
plea
of
charity
;
to
give
her
wine
,
and
provisions
,
and
money
;
to
remove
her
from
the
only
fit
quarters
for
such
people
--
the
Mint
;
and
to
place
her
in
a
cottage
at
Willesden
,
of
which
you
must
needs
pay
the
rent
?
<EOS>
Marry
,
come
up
!
<EOS>
charity
should
begin
at
home
.
<EOS>
A
discreet
husband
would
leave
the
dispensation
of
his
bounty
,
where
women
are
concerned
,
to
his
wife
.
<EOS>
And
for
my
part
,
if
I
were
inclined
to
exercise
my
benevolence
at
all
,
it
should
be
in
favour
of
some
more
deserving
object
than
that
whining
,
hypocritical
Magdalene
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
the
knowledge
of
this
feeling
on
your
part
,
my
love
,
that
made
me
act
without
your
express
sanction
.
<EOS>
I
did
all
for
the
best
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
is--
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
Mrs.
Sheppard
is
,
without
your
information
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
have
n't
forgotten
her
previous
history
.
<EOS>
You
've
your
own
reasons
,
no
doubt
,
for
bringing
up
her
son
--
perhaps
,
I
ought
rather
to
say
_
your
_
son
,
Mr.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
my
love
,
these
accusations
are
most
groundless
--
this
violence
is
most
unnecessary
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
endure
the
odious
baggage
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
may
never
come
near
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
never
may
,
my
love
,
"
humbly
acquiesced
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
my
house
to
be
made
a
receptacle
for
all
your
natural
children
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
Answer
me
that
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Winny
,
"
said
Thames
,
whose
glowing
cheek
attested
the
effect
produced
upon
him
by
the
insinuation
;
<EOS>
"
Winny
,
"
said
he
,
addressing
a
pretty
little
damsel
of
some
twelve
years
of
age
,
who
stood
by
his
side
holding
the
bottle
of
embrocation
,
"
help
me
on
with
my
coat
,
please
.
<EOS>
This
is
no
place
for
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
my
dear
,
sit
down
,
"
interposed
Mrs.
Wood
,
softening
her
asperity
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
said
about
natural
children
does
n't
apply
to
_
you
_
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
suppose
,
"
she
added
,
with
a
scornful
glance
at
her
helpmate
,
"
that
I
would
pay
him
the
compliment
of
thinking
he
could
possibly
be
the
father
of
such
a
boy
as
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
lifted
up
his
hands
in
mute
despair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Owen
,
Owen
,
"
pursued
Mrs.
Wood
,
sinking
into
a
chair
,
and
fanning
herself
<EOS>
violently,--"what
<EOS>
a
fluster
you
have
put
me
into
with
your
violence
,
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
And
at
the
very
time
,
too
,
when
you
know
I
'm
expecting
a
visit
from
Mr.
Kneebone
,
on
his
return
from
Manchester
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
him
see
me
in
this
state
for
the
world
.
<EOS>
He
'd
never
forgive
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poh
,
poh
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
invariably
takes
part
with
me
,
when
any
trifling
misunderstanding
arises
between
us
.
<EOS>
I
only
wish
he
was
not
a
Papist
and
a
Jacobite
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jacobite
!
"
echoed
Mrs.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
Marry
,
come
up
!
<EOS>
Might
n't
he
just
as
reasonably
complain
of
your
being
a
Hanoverian
and
a
Presbyterian
?
<EOS>
It
's
all
matter
of
opinion
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
my
love
,
"
she
added
,
with
a
relenting
look
,
"
I
'm
content
to
make
up
our
quarrel
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
promise
me
not
to
go
near
that
abandoned
hussy
at
Willesden
.
<EOS>
One
ca
n't
help
being
jealous
,
you
know
,
even
of
an
unworthy
object
.
"
 
<EOS>
Glad
to
make
peace
on
any
terms
,
Mr.
Wood
gave
the
required
promise
,
though
he
could
not
help
thinking
that
if
either
of
them
had
cause
to
be
jealous
<EOS>
he
was
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
,
we
may
be
permitted
to
offer
an
observation
upon
the
peculiar
and
unaccountable
influence
which
ladies
of
a
shrewish
turn
so
frequently
exercise
over
--
we
can
scarcely
,
in
this
case
,
say
--
their
lords
and
masters
;
an
influence
which
seems
not
merely
to
extend
to
the
will
of
the
husband
,
but
even
to
his
inclinations
.
<EOS>
We
do
not
remember
to
have
met
with
a
single
individual
,
reported
to
be
under
petticoat
government
,
who
was
not
content
with
his
lot,--nay
,
who
so
far
from
repining
,
did
not
exult
in
his
servitude
;
and
we
see
no
way
of
accounting
for
this
apparently
inexplicable
conduct
--
for
which
,
among
other
phenomena
of
married
life
,
various
reasons
have
been
assigned
,
though
none
entirely
satisfactory
to
us
--
except
upon
the
ground
that
these
domineering
dames
possess
some
charm
sufficiently
strong
to
counteract
the
irritating
effect
of
their
tempers
;
some
secret
and
attractive
quality
of
which
the
world
at
large
is
in
ignorance
,
and
with
which
their
husbands
alone
can
be
supposed
to
be
acquainted
.
<EOS>
An
influence
of
this
description
appeared
to
be
exerted
on
the
present
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
worthy
carpenter
was
restored
to
instant
good
humour
by
a
glance
from
his
helpmate
;
and
,
notwithstanding
the
infliction
he
had
just
endured
,
he
would
have
quarrelled
with
any
one
who
had
endeavoured
to
persuade
him
that
he
was
not
the
happiest
of
men
,
and
Mrs.
Wood
the
best
of
wives
.
 
<EOS>
"
Women
must
have
their
wills
while
they
live
,
since
they
can
make
none
when
they
die
,
"
observed
Wood
,
as
he
imprinted
a
kiss
of
reconciliation
on
the
plump
hand
of
his
consort;--a
sentiment
to
the
correctness
of
which
the
party
chiefly
interested
graciously
vouchsafed
her
assent
.
 
<EOS>
Lest
the
carpenter
should
be
taxed
with
too
much
uxoriousness
,
it
behoves
us
to
ascertain
whether
the
personal
attractions
of
his
helpmate
would
,
in
any
degree
,
justify
the
devotion
he
displayed
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
Mrs.
Wood
had
the
advantage
of
her
husband
in
point
of
years
,
being
on
the
sunny
side
of
forty,--a
period
pronounced
by
competent
judges
to
be
the
most
fascinating
,
and
,
at
the
same
time
,
most
critical
epoch
of
woman
's
existence,--whereas
,
he
was
on
the
shady
side
of
fifty,--a
term
of
life
not
generally
conceived
to
have
any
special
recommendation
in
female
eyes
.
<EOS>
In
the
next
place
,
she
really
had
some
pretensions
to
beauty
.
<EOS>
Accounted
extremely
pretty
in
her
youth
,
her
features
and
person
expanded
as
she
grew
older
,
without
much
detriment
to
their
original
comeliness
.
<EOS>
Hers
was
beauty
on
a
large
scale
no
doubt
;
but
it
was
beauty
,
nevertheless
:
and
the
carpenter
thought
her
eyes
as
bright
,
her
complexion
as
blooming
,
and
her
figure
(
if
a
little
more
buxom
)
quite
as
captivating
as
when
he
led
her
to
the
altar
some
twenty
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
,
in
anticipation
of
Mr.
Kneebone
's
visit
,
Mrs.
Wood
was
dressed
with
more
than
ordinary
care
,
and
in
more
than
ordinary
finery
.
<EOS>
A
dove
-
coloured
kincob
gown
,
embroidered
with
large
trees
,
and
made
very
low
in
front
,
displayed
to
the
greatest
possible
advantage
,
the
rounded
proportions
of
her
figure
;
while
a
high
-
heeled
,
red
-
leather
shoe
did
not
detract
from
the
symmetry
of
a
very
neat
ankle
,
and
a
very
small
foot
.
<EOS>
A
stomacher
,
fastened
by
imitation
-
diamond
buckles
,
girded
that
part
of
her
person
,
which
should
have
been
a
waist
;
a
coral
necklace
encircled
her
throat
,
and
a
few
black
patches
,
or
mouches
,
as
they
were
termed
,
served
as
a
foil
to
the
bloom
of
her
cheek
and
chin
.
<EOS>
Upon
a
table
,
where
they
had
been
hastily
deposited
,
on
the
intelligence
of
Darrell
's
accident
,
lay
a
pair
of
pink
kid
gloves
,
bordered
with
lace
,
and
an
enormous
fan
;
the
latter
,
when
opened
,
represented
the
metamorphosis
and
death
of
Actæon
.
<EOS>
From
her
stomacher
,
to
which
it
was
attached
by
a
multitude
of
glittering
steel
chains
,
depended
an
immense
turnip
-
shaped
watch
,
in
a
pinchbeck
case
.
<EOS>
Her
hair
was
gathered
up
behind
,
in
a
sort
of
pad
,
according
to
the
then
prevailing
mode
;
and
she
wore
a
muslin
cap
,
and
pinners
with
crow
-
foot
edging
.
<EOS>
A
black
silk
fur
-
belowed
scarf
covered
her
shoulders
;
and
over
the
kincob
gown
hung
a
yellow
satin
apron
,
trimmed
with
white
Persian
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
spite
of
her
attractions
,
we
shall
address
ourselves
to
the
younger
,
and
more
interesting
couple
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
almost
find
in
my
heart
to
quarrel
with
Jack
Sheppard
for
occasioning
you
so
much
pain
,
"
observed
little
Winifred
Wood
,
as
,
having
completed
her
ministration
to
the
best
of
her
ability
,
she
helped
Thames
on
with
his
coat
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
you
could
find
in
your
heart
to
quarrel
with
any
one
,
Winny
;
much
less
with
a
person
whom
I
like
so
much
as
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
My
arm
's
nearly
well
again
.
<EOS>
And
I
've
already
told
you
the
accident
was
not
Jack
's
fault
.
<EOS>
So
,
let
's
think
no
more
about
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
strange
<EOS>
you
should
like
Jack
so
much
dear
Thames
.
<EOS>
He
does
n't
resemble
you
at
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
reason
why
I
like
him
,
Winny
.
<EOS>
If
he
_
did
_
resemble
me
,
I
should
n't
care
about
him
.
<EOS>
And
,
whatever
you
may
think
,
I
assure
you
,
Jack
's
a
downright
good
-
natured
fellow
.
"
 
<EOS>
Good
-
natured
fellows
are
always
especial
favourites
with
boys
.
<EOS>
And
,
in
applying
the
term
to
his
friend
,
Thames
meant
to
pay
him
a
high
compliment
.
<EOS>
And
so
Winifred
understood
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
she
said
,
in
reply
,
"
I
may
have
done
Jack
an
injustice
.
<EOS>
I
'll
try
to
think
better
of
him
in
future
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
if
you
want
an
additional
inducement
to
do
so
,
I
can
tell
you
there
's
no
one
--
not
even
his
mother
--
whom
he
loves
so
well
as
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Loves
!
"
echoed
<EOS>
Winifred
,
slightly
colouring
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
loves
,
Winny
.
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
he
sometimes
indulges
the
hope
of
marrying
you
,
when
he
grows
old
enough
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
said
anything
to
offend
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
no
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
would
n't
have
me
positively
dislike
Jack
Sheppard
,
you
'll
never
mention
such
a
subject
again
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
"
she
added
,
blushing
yet
more
deeply
,
"
it
is
n't
a
proper
one
to
talk
upon
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
to
change
it
,
"
replied
Thames
,
gravely
<EOS>
,
"
suppose
I
should
be
obliged
to
leave
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Winifred
looked
as
if
she
could
not
indulge
such
a
supposition
for
a
single
moment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
"
she
said
,
after
a
pause
,
"
you
do
n't
attach
any
importance
to
what
my
mother
has
just
said
.
<EOS>
_
She
_
has
already
forgotten
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
_
I
_
never
can
forget
it
,
Winny
.
<EOS>
I
will
no
longer
be
a
burthen
to
those
upon
whom
I
have
no
claim
,
but
compassion
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
in
a
low
and
mournful
,
but
firm
voice
,
the
tears
gathered
thickly
in
Winifred
's
dark
eyelashes
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
in
earnest
,
Thames
,
"
she
replied
,
with
a
look
of
gentle
reproach
,
"
you
are
very
foolish
;
and
,
if
in
jest
,
very
cruel
.
<EOS>
My
mother
,
I
'm
sure
,
did
n't
intend
to
hurt
your
feelings
.
<EOS>
She
loves
you
too
well
for
that
.
<EOS>
And
I
'll
answer
for
it
,
she
'll
never
say
a
syllable
to
annoy
you
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
tried
to
answer
her
,
but
his
voice
failed
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
<EOS>
I
see
the
storm
has
blown
over
,
"
cried
Winifred
,
brightening
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
mistaken
,
Winny
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
alter
my
determination
.
<EOS>
I
shall
quit
this
roof
to
-
morrow
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
little
girl
's
countenance
fell
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
nothing
without
consulting
my
father--_your
_
father
,
Thames
,
"
she
implored
.
<EOS>
"
Promise
me
that
.
"
 
"
<EOS>
Willingly
.
<EOS>
And
what
's
more
,
I
promise
to
abide
by
his
decision
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
I
'm
quite
easy
,
"
cried
Winifred
,
joyfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
he
wo
n't
attempt
to
prevent
me
,
"
rejoined
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
The
slight
smile
that
played
upon
Winifred
's
lips
seemed
to
say
that
_
she
_
was
not
quite
so
sure
.
<EOS>
But
she
made
no
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
case
he
should
consent--
"
 
"
He
never
will
,
"
interrupted
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
case
he
_
should
_
,
I
say
,
"
continued
Thames
,
"
will
_
you
_
promise
to
let
Jack
Sheppard
take
my
place
in
your
affections
,
Winny
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
replied
the
little
damsel
,
"
I
can
never
love
any
one
so
much
as
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Excepting
your
father
.
"
 
<EOS>
Winifred
was
going
to
say
"
No
,
"
but
she
checked
herself
;
and
,
with
cheeks
mantling
with
blushes
,
murmured
,
"
I
wish
you
would
n't
tease
me
about
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
foregoing
conversation
,
having
been
conducted
throughout
in
a
low
tone
,
and
apart
,
had
not
reached
the
ears
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Wood
,
who
were
,
furthermore
,
engaged
in
a
little
conjugal
_
tête
-
à
-
tête
_
of
their
own
.
<EOS>
The
last
observation
,
however
,
caught
the
attention
of
the
carpenter
's
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
you
're
saying
about
Jack
Sheppard
?
<EOS>
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
was
just
observing--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
!
"
echoed
Mrs.
Wood
,
glancing
angrily
at
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
another
instance
of
your
wilfulness
and
want
of
taste
.
<EOS>
Who
but
_
<EOS>
you
_
would
have
dreamed
of
giving
the
boy
such
a
name
?
<EOS>
Why
,
it
's
the
name
of
a
river
,
not
a
Christian
.
<EOS>
No
gentleman
was
ever
called
Thames
,
and
Darrell
_
is
_
a
gentleman
,
unless
the
whole
story
of
his
being
found
in
the
river
is
a
fabrication
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
you
forget--
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mr.
Wood
,
I
forget
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
've
an
excellent
memory
,
thank
God
!
<EOS>
And
I
perfectly
remember
that
everybody
was
drowned
upon
that
occasion
--
except
yourself
and
the
child
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
love
you
're
beside
yourself--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
beside
myself
to
take
charge
of
your--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
?
<EOS>
"
interposed
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use
,
"
observed
Thames
quietly
,
but
with
a
look
that
chilled
the
little
damsel
's
heart;--"my
resolution
is
taken
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
at
least
appear
to
forget
that
Mr.
Kneebone
is
coming
,
my
dear
,
"
ventured
Mr.
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
!
<EOS>
so
I
do
,
"
exclaimed
his
amiable
consort
.
"
<EOS>
But
you
_
do
<EOS>
_
agitate
me
so
much
.
<EOS>
Come
into
the
parlour
,
Winifred
,
and
dry
your
eyes
directly
,
or
I
'll
send
you
to
bed
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
,
I
desire
you
'll
put
on
your
best
things
,
and
join
us
as
soon
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Thames
,
you
need
n't
tidy
yourself
,
as
you
've
hurt
your
arm
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
will
excuse
you
.
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
if
there
is
n't
his
knock
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
'm
in
such
a
fluster
!
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
she
snatched
up
her
fan
,
cast
a
look
into
the
glass
,
smoothed
down
her
scarf
,
threw
a
soft
expression
into
her
features
,
and
led
the
way
into
the
next
room
,
whither
she
was
followed
by
her
daughter
and
Thames
Darrell
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
III
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jacobite
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
William
Kneebone
was
a
woollen
-
draper
of
"
credit
and
renown
,
"
whose
place
of
business
was
held
at
the
sign
of
the
Angel
(
for
,
in
those
days
,
every
shop
had
its
sign
)
,
opposite
Saint
Clement
's
church
in
the
Strand
.
<EOS>
A
native
of
Manchester
,
he
was
the
son
of
Kenelm
Kneebone
,
a
staunch
Catholic
,
and
a
sergeant
of
dragoons
,
who
lost
his
legs
and
his
life
while
fighting
for
James
the
Second
at
the
battle
of
the
Boyne
,
and
who
had
little
to
bequeath
his
son
except
his
laurels
and
his
loyalty
to
the
house
of
Stuart
.
 
<EOS>
The
gallant
woollen
-
draper
was
now
in
his
thirty
-
sixth
year
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
handsome
,
jolly
-
looking
face
;
stood
six
feet
two
in
his
stockings
;
and
measured
more
than
a
cloth
-
yard
shaft
across
the
shoulders
--
athletic
proportions
derived
from
his
father
the
dragoon
.
<EOS>
And
,
if
it
had
not
been
for
a
taste
for
plotting
,
which
was
continually
getting
him
into
scrapes
,
he
might
have
been
accounted
a
respectable
member
of
society
.
 
<EOS>
Of
late
,
however
,
his
plotting
had
assumed
a
more
dark
and
dangerous
complexion
.
<EOS>
The
times
were
such
that
,
with
the
opinions
he
entertained
,
he
could
not
remain
idle
.
<EOS>
The
spirit
of
disaffection
was
busy
throughout
the
kingdom
.
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
eve
of
that
memorable
rebellion
which
broke
forth
,
two
months
later
,
in
Scotland
.
<EOS>
Since
the
accession
of
George
the
First
to
the
throne
in
the
preceding
year
,
every
effort
had
been
made
by
the
partisans
of
the
Stuarts
to
shake
the
credit
of
the
existing
government
,
and
to
gain
supporters
to
their
cause
.
<EOS>
Disappointed
in
their
hopes
of
the
restoration
of
the
fallen
dynasty
after
the
death
of
Anne
,
the
adherents
of
the
Chevalier
de
Saint
George
endeavoured
,
by
sowing
the
seeds
of
dissension
far
and
wide
,
to
produce
a
general
insurrection
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
No
means
were
neglected
to
accomplish
this
end
.
<EOS>
Agents
were
dispersed
in
all
directions
--
offers
the
most
tempting
held
out
to
induce
the
wavering
to
join
the
Chevalier
's
standard
.
<EOS>
Plots
were
hatched
in
the
provinces
,
where
many
of
the
old
and
wealthy
Catholic
families
resided
,
whose
zeal
for
the
martyr
of
their
religion
(
as
the
Chevalier
was
esteemed
)
,
sharpened
by
the
persecutions
they
themselves
endured
,
rendered
them
hearty
and
efficient
allies
.
<EOS>
Arms
,
horses
,
and
accoutrements
were
secretly
purchased
and
distributed
;
and
it
is
not
improbable
that
,
if
the
unfortunate
prince
,
in
whose
behalf
these
exertions
were
made
,
and
who
was
not
deficient
in
courage
,
as
he
proved
at
the
battle
of
Malplaquet
,
had
boldly
placed
himself
at
the
head
of
his
party
at
an
earlier
period
,
he
might
have
regained
the
crown
of
his
ancestors
.
<EOS>
But
the
indecision
,
which
had
been
fatal
to
his
race
,
was
fatal
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
delayed
the
blow
till
the
fortunate
conjuncture
was
past
.
<EOS>
And
when
,
at
length
,
it
_
was
_
struck
,
he
wanted
energy
to
pursue
his
advantages
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
must
not
anticipate
the
course
of
events
.
<EOS>
At
the
precise
period
of
this
history
,
the
Jacobite
party
was
full
of
hope
and
confidence
.
<EOS>
Louis
the
Fourteenth
yet
lived
,
and
expectations
were
,
therefore
,
indulged
of
assistance
from
France
.
<EOS>
The
disgrace
of
the
leaders
of
the
late
Tory
administration
had
strengthened
,
rather
than
injured
,
their
cause
.
<EOS>
Mobs
were
gathered
together
on
the
slightest
possible
pretext
;
and
these
tumultuous
assemblages
,
while
committing
the
most
outrageous
excesses
,
loudly
proclaimed
their
hatred
to
the
house
of
Hanover
,
and
their
determination
to
cut
off
the
Protestant
succession
.
<EOS>
The
proceedings
of
this
faction
were
narrowly
watched
by
a
vigilant
and
sagacious
administration
.
<EOS>
The
government
was
not
deceived
(
indeed
,
every
opportunity
was
sought
by
the
Jacobites
of
parading
their
numbers
,
)
as
to
the
force
of
its
enemies
;
and
precautionary
measures
were
taken
to
defeat
their
designs
.
<EOS>
On
the
very
day
of
which
we
write
,
namely
,
the
10th
of
June
1715
,
Bolingbroke
and
Oxford
were
impeached
of
high
treason
.
<EOS>
The
Committee
of
Secrecy
--
that
English
Council
of
Ten
--
were
sitting
,
with
Walpole
at
their
head
;
and
the
most
extraordinary
discoveries
were
reported
to
be
made
.
<EOS>
On
the
same
day
,
moreover
,
which
,
by
a
curious
coincidence
,
was
the
birthday
of
the
Chevalier
de
Saint
George
,
mobs
were
collected
together
in
the
streets
,
and
the
health
of
that
prince
was
publicly
drunk
under
the
title
of
James
the
Third
;
while
,
in
many
country
towns
,
the
bells
were
rung
,
and
rejoicings
held
,
as
if
for
a
reigning
monarch:--the
cry
of
the
populace
almost
universally
being
,
"
No
King
George
,
but
a
Stuart
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
adherents
of
the
Chevalier
de
Saint
George
,
we
have
said
,
were
lavish
in
promises
to
their
proselytes
.
<EOS>
Posts
were
offered
to
all
who
chose
to
accept
them
.
<EOS>
Blank
commissions
,
signed
by
the
prince
,
to
be
filled
up
by
the
name
of
the
person
,
who
could
raise
a
troop
for
his
service
,
were
liberally
bestowed
.
<EOS>
Amongst
others
,
Mr.
Kneebone
,
whose
interest
was
not
inconsiderable
with
the
leaders
of
his
faction
,
obtained
an
appointment
as
captain
in
a
regiment
of
infantry
,
on
the
conditions
above
specified
.
<EOS>
With
a
view
to
raise
recruits
for
his
corps
,
the
warlike
woollen
-
draper
started
for
Lancashire
,
under
the
colour
of
a
journey
on
business
.
<EOS>
He
was
pretty
successful
in
Manchester,--a
town
which
may
be
said
to
have
been
the
head
-
quarters
of
the
disaffected
.
<EOS>
On
his
return
to
London
,
he
found
that
applications
had
been
made
from
a
somewhat
doubtful
quarter
by
two
individuals
,
for
the
posts
of
subordinate
officers
in
his
troop
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
,
or
,
as
he
would
have
preferred
being
styled
,
Captain
Kneebone
,
was
not
perfectly
satisfied
with
the
recommendations
forwarded
by
the
applicants
.
<EOS>
But
this
was
not
a
season
in
which
to
be
needlessly
scrupulous
.
<EOS>
He
resolved
to
judge
for
himself
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
was
introduced
to
the
two
military
aspirants
at
the
Cross
Shovels
in
the
Mint
,
by
our
old
acquaintance
,
Baptist
Kettleby
.
<EOS>
The
Master
of
the
Mint
,
with
whom
the
Jacobite
captain
had
often
had
transactions
before
,
vouched
for
their
being
men
of
honour
and
loyalty
;
and
Kneebone
was
so
well
satisfied
with
his
representations
,
that
he
at
once
closed
the
matter
by
administering
to
the
applicants
the
oath
of
allegiance
and
fidelity
to
King
James
the
Third
,
and
several
other
oaths
besides
,
all
of
which
those
gentlemen
took
with
as
little
hesitation
as
the
sum
of
money
,
afterwards
tendered
,
to
make
the
compact
binding
.
<EOS>
The
party
,
then
,
sat
down
to
a
bowl
of
punch
;
and
,
at
its
conclusion
,
Captain
Kneebone
regretted
that
an
engagement
to
spend
the
evening
with
Mrs.
Wood
,
would
preclude
the
possibility
of
his
remaining
with
his
new
friends
as
long
as
his
inclinations
prompted
.
<EOS>
At
this
piece
of
information
,
the
two
subordinate
officers
were
observed
to
exchange
glances
;
and
,
after
a
little
agreeable
raillery
on
their
captain
's
gallantry
,
they
begged
permission
to
accompany
him
in
his
visit
.
<EOS>
Kneebone
,
who
had
drained
his
glass
to
the
restoration
of
the
house
of
Stuart
,
and
the
downfall
of
the
house
of
Hanover
,
more
frequently
than
was
consistent
with
prudence
,
consented
;
and
the
trio
set
out
for
Wych
Street
,
where
they
arrived
in
the
jolliest
humour
possible
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IV
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
and
his
Friends
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
was
scarcely
seated
before
Mr.
Kneebone
made
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
To
her
great
surprise
and
mortification
he
was
not
alone
;
but
brought
with
him
a
couple
of
friends
,
whom
he
begged
to
introduce
as
Mr.
Jeremiah
Jackson
,
and
Mr.
Solomon
Smith
,
chapmen
,
(
or
what
in
modern
vulgar
parlance
would
be
termed
bagmen
)
travelling
to
procure
orders
for
the
house
of
an
eminent
cloth
manufacturer
in
Manchester
.
<EOS>
Neither
the
manners
,
the
looks
,
nor
the
attire
of
these
gentlemen
prepossessed
Mrs.
Wood
in
their
favour
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
on
their
presentation
,
Mr.
Jeremiah
Jackson
and
Mr.
Solomon
Smith
received
something
very
like
a
rebuff
.
<EOS>
Luckily
,
they
were
not
easily
discomposed
.
<EOS>
Two
persons
possessing
a
more
comfortable
stock
of
assurance
could
not
be
readily
found
.
<EOS>
Imitating
the
example
of
Mr.
Kneebone
,
who
did
not
appear
in
the
slightest
degree
disconcerted
by
his
cool
reception
,
each
sank
carelessly
into
a
chair
,
and
made
himself
at
home
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Both
had
very
singular
faces
;
very
odd
wigs
,
very
much
pulled
over
their
brows
;
and
very
large
cravats
,
very
much
raised
above
their
chins
.
<EOS>
Besides
this
,
each
had
a
large
black
patch
over
his
right
eye
,
and
a
very
queer
twist
at
the
left
side
of
his
mouth
,
so
that
if
their
object
had
been
disguise
,
they
could
not
have
adopted
better
precautions
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
thought
them
both
remarkably
plain
,
but
Mr.
Smith
decidedly
the
plainest
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
His
complexion
was
as
blue
as
a
sailor
's
jacket
,
and
though
Mr.
Jackson
had
one
of
the
ugliest
countenances
imaginable
,
he
had
a
very
fine
set
of
teeth
.
<EOS>
That
was
something
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
One
peculiarity
she
did
not
fail
to
notice
.
<EOS>
They
were
both
dressed
in
every
respect
alike
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
Mr.
Solomon
Smith
seemed
to
be
Mr.
Jeremiah
Jackson
's
double
.
<EOS>
He
talked
in
the
same
style
,
and
pretty
nearly
in
the
same
language
;
laughed
in
the
same
manner
,
and
coughed
,
or
sneezed
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Jackson
took
an
accurate
survey
of
the
room
with
his
one
eye
,
Mr.
Smith
's
solitary
orb
followed
in
the
same
direction
.
<EOS>
When
Jeremiah
admired
the
Compasses
in
the
arms
of
the
Carpenter
's
Company
over
the
chimney
-
piece
,
or
the
portraits
of
the
two
eminent
masters
of
the
rule
and
plane
,
William
Portington
,
and
John
Scott
,
Esquires
,
on
either
side
of
it
,
Solomon
was
lost
in
wonder
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Jackson
noticed
a
fine
service
of
old
blue
china
in
an
open
japan
closet
,
Mr.
Smith
had
never
seen
anything
like
it
.
<EOS>
And
finally
,
when
Jeremiah
,
having
bestowed
upon
Mrs.
Wood
a
very
free
-
and
-
easy
sort
of
stare
,
winked
at
Mr.
Kneebone
,
his
impertinence
was
copied
to
the
letter
by
Solomon
.
<EOS>
All
three
,
then
,
burst
into
an
immoderate
fit
of
laughter
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
's
astonishment
and
displeasure
momentarily
increased
.
<EOS>
Such
freedoms
from
such
people
were
not
to
be
endured
.
<EOS>
Her
patience
was
waning
fast
.
<EOS>
Still
,
in
spite
of
her
glances
and
gestures
,
Mr.
Kneebone
made
no
effort
to
check
the
unreasonable
merriment
of
his
companions
,
but
rather
seemed
to
encourage
it
.
<EOS>
So
Mrs.
Wood
went
on
fuming
,
and
the
trio
went
on
laughing
for
some
minutes
,
nobody
knew
why
or
wherefore
,
until
the
party
was
increased
by
Mr.
Wood
,
in
his
Sunday
habiliments
and
Sunday
buckle
.
<EOS>
Without
stopping
to
inquire
into
the
cause
of
their
mirth
,
or
even
to
ask
the
names
of
his
guests
,
the
worthy
carpenter
shook
hands
with
the
one
-
eyed
chapmen
,
slapped
Mr.
Kneebone
cordially
on
the
shoulder
,
and
began
to
laugh
as
heartily
as
any
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
could
stand
it
no
longer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
're
all
bewitched
,
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
we
are
,
Ma'am
,
by
your
charms
,
"
returned
Mr.
Jackson
,
gallantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
captivated
,
Ma'am
,
"
added
Mr.
Smith
,
placing
his
hand
on
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
and
Mr.
Wood
laughed
louder
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
,
"
said
the
lady
bridling
up
,
"
my
request
may
,
perhaps
,
have
some
weight
with
_
<EOS>
you
<EOS>
_
.
<EOS>
I
desire
,
Sir
,
you
'll
recollect
yourself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
,
"
she
added
,
with
a
glance
at
that
gentleman
,
which
was
meant
to
speak
daggers
,
"
will
do
as
he
pleases
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
the
chapmen
set
up
another
boisterous
peal
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
offence
,
I
hope
,
my
dear
Mrs.
W
,
"
said
Mr.
Kneebone
in
a
conciliatory
tone
.
<EOS>
"
My
friends
,
Mr.
Jackson
and
Mr.
Smith
,
may
have
rather
odd
ways
with
them
;
but--
"
 
"
They
_
have
_
very
odd
ways
,
"
interrupted
Mrs.
Wood
,
disdainfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Our
worthy
friend
was
going
to
observe
,
Ma'am
,
that
we
never
fail
in
our
devotion
to
the
fair
sex
,
"
said
Mr.
Jackson
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
Ma'am
!
"
echoed
Mr.
Smith
,
"
upon
my
conscience
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
the
hospitable
carpenter
,
"
I
dare
say
Mr.
Kneebone
and
his
friends
would
be
glad
of
a
little
refreshment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
shall
have
it
,
then
,
"
replied
his
better
half
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
You
base
ingrate
,
"
she
added
,
in
a
whisper
,
as
she
flounced
past
Mr.
Kneebone
on
her
way
to
the
door
,
"
how
could
you
bring
such
creatures
with
you
,
especially
on
an
occasion
like
this
,
when
we
have
n't
met
for
a
fortnight
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Could
n't
help
it
,
my
life
,
"
returned
the
gentleman
addressed
,
in
the
same
tone
;
"
but
you
little
know
who
those
individuals
are
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
us
!
<EOS>
you
alarm
me
.
<EOS>
Who
are
they
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
assumed
a
mysterious
air
;
and
bringing
his
lips
close
to
Mrs.
Wood
's
ear
,
whispered
,
"
secret
agents
from
France
--
you
understand
--
friends
to
the
cause
--
hem
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see,--persons
of
rank
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Noblemen
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
smiled
assent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
<EOS>
Well
,
I
thought
their
manners
quite
out
o
'
the
common
.
<EOS>
And
so
,
the
invasion
really
is
to
take
place
after
all
;
and
the
Chevalier
de
Saint
George
is
to
land
at
the
Tower
with
fifty
thousand
Frenchmen
;
and
the
Hanoverian
usurper
's
to
be
beheaded
;
and
Doctor
Sacheverel
's
to
be
made
a
bishop
,
and
we
're
all
to
be
--
eh
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
All
in
good
time
,
"
returned
Kneebone
,
putting
his
finger
to
his
lips
;
"
do
n't
let
your
imagination
run
away
with
you
,
my
charmer
.
<EOS>
That
boy
,
"
he
added
,
looking
at
Thames
,
"
has
his
eye
upon
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
,
however
,
was
too
much
excited
to
attend
to
the
caution
.
 
<EOS>
"
O
,
lud
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
;
"
French
noblemen
in
disguise
!
<EOS>
and
so
rude
as
I
was
!
<EOS>
I
shall
never
recover
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
good
supper
will
set
all
to
rights
,
"
insinuated
Kneebone
.
"
<EOS>
But
be
prudent
,
my
angel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
fear
,
"
replied
the
lady
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
prudence
personified
.
<EOS>
You
might
trust
me
with
the
Chevalier
himself,--I'd
never
betray
him
.
<EOS>
But
why
did
n't
you
let
me
know
they
were
coming
.
<EOS>
I
'd
have
got
something
nice
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
we
've
only
a
couple
of
ducks
--
and
they
were
intended
for
you
.
<EOS>
Winny
,
my
love
,
come
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
want
you.--Sorry
to
quit
your
lord
--
worships
<EOS>
,
I
mean,--I
do
n't
know
what
I
mean
,
"
she
added
,
a
little
confused
,
and
dropping
a
profound
curtsey
to
the
disguised
noblemen
,
each
of
whom
replied
by
a
bow
,
worthy
,
in
her
opinion
,
of
a
prince
of
the
blood
at
the
least,--"but
<EOS>
I
've
a
few
necessary
orders
to
give
below
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
n't
mind
us
,
Ma'am
,
"
said
Mr.
Jackson
:
"
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in
the
least
,
Ma'am
,
"
echoed
Mr.
Smith
:
"
ho
!
ho
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
condescending
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Mrs.
Wood
.
"
<EOS>
Not
proud
in
the
least
,
I
declare
.
<EOS>
Well
,
I
'd
no
idea
,
"
she
continued
,
pursuing
her
ruminations
as
she
left
the
room
,
"
that
people
of
quality
laughed
so
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
French
manners
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
    
CHAPTER
V.
 
Hawk
and
Buzzard
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
's
anxiety
to
please
her
distinguished
guests
speedily
displayed
itself
in
a
very
plentiful
,
if
not
very
dainty
repast
.
<EOS>
To
the
duckling
,
peas
,
and
other
delicacies
,
intended
for
Mr.
Kneebone
's
special
consumption
,
she
added
a
few
impromptu
dishes
,
tossed
off
in
her
best
style
;
such
as
lamb
chops
,
broiled
kidneys
,
fried
ham
and
eggs
,
and
toasted
cheese
.
<EOS>
Side
by
side
with
the
cheese
(
its
never
-
failing
accompaniment
,
in
all
seasons
,
at
the
carpenter
's
board
)
came
a
tankard
of
swig
,
and
a
toast
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
there
was
a
warm
gooseberry
-
tart
,
and
a
cold
pigeon
pie
--
the
latter
capacious
enough
,
even
allowing
for
its
due
complement
of
steak
,
to
contain
the
whole
produce
of
a
dovecot
;
a
couple
of
lobsters
and
the
best
part
of
a
salmon
swimming
in
a
sea
of
vinegar
,
and
shaded
by
a
forest
of
fennel
.
<EOS>
While
the
cloth
was
laid
,
the
host
and
Thames
descended
to
the
cellar
,
whence
they
returned
,
laden
with
a
number
of
flasks
of
the
same
form
,
and
apparently
destined
to
the
same
use
as
those
depicted
in
Hogarth
's
delectable
print
--
the
Modern
Midnight
Conversation
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
now
re
-
appeared
with
a
very
red
face
;
and
,
followed
by
Winifred
,
took
her
seat
at
the
table
.
<EOS>
Operations
then
commenced
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
carved
the
ducks
;
Mr.
Kneebone
helped
to
the
pigeon
-
pie
;
while
Thames
unwired
and
uncorked
a
bottle
of
stout
Carnarvonshire
ale
.
<EOS>
The
woollen
-
draper
was
no
despicable
trencherman
in
a
general
way
;
but
his
feats
with
the
knife
and
fork
were
child
's
sport
compared
with
those
of
Mr.
Smith
.
<EOS>
The
leg
and
wing
of
a
duck
were
disposed
of
by
this
gentleman
in
a
twinkling
;
a
brace
of
pigeons
and
a
pound
of
steak
followed
with
equal
celerity
;
and
he
had
just
begun
to
make
a
fierce
assault
upon
the
eggs
and
ham
.
<EOS>
His
appetite
was
perfectly
Gargantuan
.
<EOS>
Nor
must
it
be
imagined
,
that
while
he
thus
exercised
his
teeth
,
he
neglected
the
flagon
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
his
glass
was
never
idle
,
and
finding
it
not
filled
quite
so
frequently
as
he
desired
,
he
applied
himself
,
notwithstanding
the
expressive
looks
and
muttered
remonstrances
of
Mr.
Jackson
,
to
the
swig
.
<EOS>
The
latter
gentleman
did
full
justice
to
the
good
things
before
him
;
but
he
drank
sparingly
,
and
was
visibly
annoyed
by
his
companion
's
intemperance
.
<EOS>
As
to
Mr.
Kneebone
,
what
with
flirting
with
Mrs.
Wood
,
carving
for
his
friends
,
and
pledging
the
carpenter
,
he
had
his
hands
full
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
and
just
as
a
cuckoo
-
clock
in
the
corner
struck
sis
,
Jack
Sheppard
walked
into
the
room
,
with
the
packing
-
case
under
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
in
the
right
,
you
see
,
father
,
"
observed
Thames
,
smiling
;
"
Jack
_
has
_
done
his
task
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
perceive
,
"
replied
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
am
I
to
take
it
to
?
"
asked
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
that
before
,
"
rejoined
Wood
,
testily
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
take
it
to
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
's
in
Southampton
Fields
.
<EOS>
And
,
mind
,
it
's
for
his
sister
,
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wet
your
whistle
before
you
start
,
Jack
,
"
said
Kneebone
,
pouring
out
a
glass
of
ale
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
you
're
taking
to
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
's
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Only
a
box
,
Sir
,
"
answered
Sheppard
,
emptying
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
odd
-
shaped
one
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
,
examining
it
attentively
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
can
guess
what
it
's
for
.
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
is
one
of
_
us
_
,
"
he
added
,
winking
at
his
companions
,
"
and
so
was
his
brother
-
in
-
law
,
Sir
Cecil
Trafford
.
<EOS>
Old
Lancashire
families
both
.
<EOS>
Strict
Catholics
,
and
loyal
to
the
backbone
.
<EOS>
Fine
woman
,
Lady
Trafford
--
a
little
on
the
wane
though
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
're
so
very
particular
,
"
sighed
Mrs.
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in
the
least
,
"
returned
Kneebone
,
slyly
,
"
not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
Another
glass
,
Jack
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Sir
,
"
grinned
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Off
with
it
to
the
health
of
King
James
the
Third
,
and
confusion
to
his
enemies
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Wood
<EOS>
;
"
that
is
treason
.
<EOS>
I
'll
have
no
such
toast
drunk
at
my
table
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
king
's
birthday
,
"
urged
the
woollen
draper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
_
<EOS>
my
_
king
's
,
"
returned
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
I
quarrel
with
no
man
's
political
opinions
,
but
I
will
have
my
own
respected
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
day
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Wood
;
"
here
's
a
pretty
to
-
do
about
nothing
.
<EOS>
Marry
,
come
up
!
<EOS>
I
'll
see
who
's
to
be
obeyed
.
<EOS>
Drink
the
toast
,
Jack
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
your
peril
,
sirrah
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
hanged
that
left
his
drink
behind
,
you
know
,
master
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
King
James
the
Third
,
and
confusion
to
his
enemies
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
the
carpenter
,
sitting
down
amid
the

of
the
company
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
,
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
you
deserve
to
be
hanged
for
a
rebel
as
you
are
to
your
lawful
king
and
your
lawful
master
.
<EOS>
But
since
we
must
have

,
"
he

,

,
"
listen
to

:
<EOS>
Here
's
King
George
the
First
!
<EOS>
a
long
reign
to
him
!
<EOS>
and
confusion
to
the
Popish
Pretender
and
his

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bravely
done
!
"
<EOS>
said
Wood
,
with
tears
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
kinchin
<EOS>
as
was
to
try
the
dub
for
us
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
<EOS>
muttered
Smith
to
his
companion
as
he
stole
a
glance
at
Jack
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Silence
!
"
returned
Jackson
,
in
a
deep
whisper
;
"
and
do
n't
muddle
your
brains
with
any
more
of
that
Pharaoh
.
<EOS>
You
'll
need
all
your
strength
to
grab
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
remarked
Kneebone
,
addressing
Sheppard
,
who
,
as
he
caught
the
single
but
piercing
eye
of
Jackson
fixed
upon
him
,
started
and
trembled
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
repeated
Mrs.
Wood
in
a
sharp
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
what
's
the
matter
,
boy
!
"
<EOS>
reiterated
Jackson
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
never
see
two
gentlemen
with
only
a
couple
of
peepers
between
them
before
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
I
'll
be
sworn
!
"
<EOS>
said
Smith
,
taking
the
opportunity
of
filling
his
glass
while
his
comrade
's
back
was
turned
;
"
we
're
a
nat'ral
cur'osity
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
have
a
word
with
you
,
master
?
"
said
Sheppard
,
approaching
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
syllable
!
<EOS>
"
answered
the
carpenter
,
angrily
.
"
<EOS>
Get
about
your
business
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
beckoning
to
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
But
Darrell
averted
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mistress
!
"
said
the
apprentice
,
making
a
final

to
Mrs.
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
the
room
instantly
,
sirrah
!
"
rejoined
the
lady
,
bouncing
up
,
and
giving
him
a
slap
on
the
cheek
that
made
his
eyes
flash
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
be
cursed
,
"
muttered
Sheppard
,
as
he
slunk
away
with
(
as
the
woollen
-
draper
pleasantly
observed
)
'
<EOS>
a
couple
of
boxes
in
charge
,
'
"
<EOS>
if
ever
I
try
to
be
honest
again
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
a
little
toasted
cheese
with
the
swig
,
Mr.
Smith
,
"
observed
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
an
incorrigible
rascal
,
"
he
added
,
as
Sheppard
closed
the
door
;
"
it
's
only
to
-
day
that
I
discovered--
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
asked
Jackson
,
pricking
up

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
ill
of
him
behind
his
back
,
father
,
"
interposed
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
_
I
_
were
your
father
,
young
gentleman
,
"
returned
Jackson
,
enraged
at
the
interruption
,
"
I
'd
teach
_
you
_
not
to
speak
till
you
were
spoken
to
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
was
about
to
reply
,
but
a

from
Wood
checked

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
rebuke
is
just
,
"
said
the
carpenter
;
"
at
the
same
time
,
I
'm
not
sorry
to
find
you
're
a
friend
to
fair
play
,
which
,
as
you
seem
to
know
,
is
a
jewel
.
<EOS>
Open
that
bottle
with
a
blue
seal
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
!
<EOS>
a
glass
of
brandy
will
be
no
bad
finish
to
our
meal
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
proposal
giving
general
satisfaction
,
the
bottle
circulated
swiftly
;
and
Smith
found
the
liquor
so
much
to
his
taste
,
that
he
made
it
pay
double
toll
on
its
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
son
is
a
lad
of
spirit
,
Mr.
Wood
,
"
observed
Jackson
,
in
a
slightly
-
sarcastic
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
not
my
son
,
"
rejoined
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Except
by
adoption
.
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
is--
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
husband
nicknames
him
Thames
,
"
interrupted
Mrs.
Wood
,
"
because
he
found
him
in
the
river!--ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
ha
!
"
echoed
Smith
,
taking
another
bumper
of
brandy
;
"
he
'll
set
the
Thames
on
fire
one
of
these
days
,
I
'll

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
more
than
you
'll
ever
do
,
you
drunken
fool
!
"
<EOS>
growled
Jackson
,
in
an
under
tone
:
"
be
cautious
,
or
you
'll
spoil
all
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose
we
send
for
a
bowl
of
punch
,
"
said
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
all
my
heart
!
"
replied
Wood
.
<EOS>
And
,
turning
to
his
daughter
,
he
gave
the
necessary
directions
in
a
low
tone
.
 
<EOS>
Winifred
,
accordingly
,
left
the
room
,
and
a
servant
being
despatched
to
the
nearest
tavern
,
soon
afterwards
returned
with
a
crown
bowl
of
the
ambrosian
fluid
.
<EOS>
The
tables
were
then
cleared
.
<EOS>
Bottles
and
glasses
usurped
the
place
of
dishes
and
plates
.
<EOS>
Pipes
were
lighted
;
and
Mr.
Kneebone
began
to
dispense
the
fragrant
fluid
;
begging
Mrs.
Wood
,
in
a
whisper
,
as
he
filled
a
rummer
to
the
brim
,
not
to
forget
the
health
of
the
Chevalier
de
Saint
George
--
a
proposition
to
which
the
lady
immediately
responded
by
drinking
the
toast
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Chevalier
shall
hear
of
this
,
"
whispered
the
woollen
-
draper
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Mrs.
Wood
,
delighted
at
the
idea
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
assured
her
that
he
_
did
_
say
so
;
and
,
as
a
further
proof
of
his
sincerity
,
squeezed
her
hand
very
warmly
under
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Smith
,
now
,
being
more
than
half
-
seas
over
,
became
very
uproarious
,
and
,
claiming
the
attention
of
the
table
,
volunteered
the
following
     
DRINKING
SONG
.
     
<EOS>
I.
     
Jolly
nose
!
<EOS>
the
bright
rubies
that
garnish
thy
tip
      
Are
dug
from
the
mines
of
canary
;
    
And
to
keep
up
their
lustre
<EOS>
I
moisten
my
lip
      
With
hogsheads
of
claret
and
sherry
.
     
<EOS>
II
.
     
<EOS>
Jolly
nose
!
<EOS>
he
who
sees
thee
across
a
broad
glass
      
Beholds
thee
in
all
thy
perfection
;
    
And
to
the
pale
snout
of
a
temperate
ass
      
Entertains
the
profoundest
objection
.
     
<EOS>
III
.
     
<EOS>
For
a
big
-
bellied
glass
is
the
palette
I
use
,
      
<EOS>
And
the
choicest
of
wine
is
my
colour
;
    
<EOS>
And
I
find
that
my
nose
takes
the
mellowest
hues
      
<EOS>
The
fuller
I
fill
it
--
the
fuller
!
     
<EOS>
IV
.
     
<EOS>
Jolly
nose
!
<EOS>
there
are
fools
who
say
drink
hurts
the
sight
;
      
Such
dullards
know
nothing
about
it
.
    
<EOS>
'
T
is
better
,
with
wine
,
to
extinguish
the
light
,
      
<EOS>
Than
live
always
,
in
darkness
,
without
it
!
 
<EOS>
"
How
long
may
it
be
since
that
boy
was
found
in
the
way
Mrs.
Wood
mentions
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jackson
,
as
soon
as
the
clatter
that
succeeded
Mr.
Smith
's
melody
had
subsided
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
"
replied
Wood
;
"
exactly
twelve
years
ago
last
November
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
must
be
about
the
time
of
the
Great
Storm
,
"
rejoined
Jackson
.
 
<EOS>
"
Egad
!
"
exclaimed
Wood
,
"
you
've
hit
the
right
nail
on
the
head
,
anyhow
.
<EOS>
It
_
was
_
on
the
night
of
the
Great
Storm
that
I
found
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
hear
all
particulars
of
the
affair
,
"
said
Jackson
,
"
if
it
would
n't
be
troubling
you
too
much
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
required
little
pressing
.
<EOS>
He
took
a
sip
of
punch
and
commenced
his
relation
.
<EOS>
Though
meant
to
produce
a
totally
different
effect
,
the
narrative
seemed
to
excite
the
risible
propensities
rather
than
the
commiseration
of
his
auditor
;
and
when
Mr.
Wood
wound
it
up
by
a
description
of
the
drenching
he
had
undergone
at
the
Mint
pump
,
the
other
could
hold
out
no
longer
,
but
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
gave
free
scope
to
his
merriment
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
he
cried
;
"
but
really
--
ha
!
<EOS>
ha!--you
must
excuse
me!--that
is
so
uncommonly
diverting
--
ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
Do
let
me
hear
it
<EOS>
again?--ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
rejoined
Wood
,
"
you
seem
vastly
entertained
by
my
misfortunes
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
To
be
sure
!
<EOS>
Nothing
entertains
me
so
much
.
<EOS>
People
always
rejoice
at
the
misfortunes
of
others
--
never
at
their
own
!
<EOS>
The
droll
dogs
!
<EOS>
how
_
they
_
must
have
enjoyed
it!--ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
they
did
.
<EOS>
But
_
I
_
found
it
no
laughing
matter
,
I
can
assure
you
.
<EOS>
And
,
though
it
's
a
long
time
ago
,
I
feel
as
sore
on
the
subject
as
ever
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
natural
!
<EOS>
Never
forgive
an
injury!--_I
_
never
do!--ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
Mr.
Jackson
,
I
could
almost
fancy
we
had
met
before
.
<EOS>
Your
laugh
reminds
me
of
--
of----
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Whose
,
Sir
?
"
demanded
Jackson
,
becoming
suddenly
grave
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
not
be
offended
,
I
hope
,
"
returned
Wood
,
drily
,
"
if
I
say
that
your
voice
,
your
manner
,
and
,
above
all
,
your
very
extraordinary
way
of
laughing
,
put
me
strangely
in
mind
of
one
of
the
'
droll
dogs
,
'
(
as
you
term
them
,
)
who
helped
to
perpetrate
the
outrage
I
've
just
described
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

task
,
unconscious
of
anything
having
happened
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
cried
Jackson
,
closing
the
book
and
rising
,
"
that
'll
do
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
at
twelve
I
'll
be
with
you
,
Mr.
Wood
.
<EOS>
Make
up
your
mind
as
to
the
terms
,
and
I
'll
engage
to
find
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
carpenter
,
in
an
authoritative
voice
:
"
we
ca
n't
part
thus
.
<EOS>
Thames
,
look
the
door
.
"
<EOS>
(
An
order
which
was
promptly
obeyed
.
)
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Sir
,
I
must
insist
upon
a
full
explanation
of
your
mysterious
hints
,
or
,
as
I
am
headborough
of
the
district
,
I
shall
at
once
take
you
into
custody
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jackson
treated
this
menace
with
a
loud
laugh
of
derision
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
ho
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
slapping
Smith
,
who
had
fallen
asleep
with
the
brandy
-
bottle
in
his
grasp
,
upon
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
time
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
what
?
"
grumbled
the
latter
,
rubbing
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
the
caption
!
"
replied
Jackson
,
coolly
drawing
a
brace
of
pistols
from
his
pockets
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ready
!
"
<EOS>
answered
Smith
,
shaking
himself
,
and
producing
a
similar
pair
of
weapons
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
Heaven
's
name
!
<EOS>
what
's
all
this
?
"
cried
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
still
,
and
you
'll
receive
no
injury
,
"
returned
Jackson
.
<EOS>
"
We
're
merely
about
to
discharge
our
duty
by
apprehending
a
rebel
.
<EOS>
Captain
Kneebone
!
<EOS>
we
must
trouble
you
to
accompany
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
no
intention
of
stirring
,
"
replied
the
woollen
-
draper
,
who
was
thus
unceremoniously
disturbed
:
"
<EOS>
and
I
beg
you
'll
sit
down
,
Mr.
Jackson
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Sir
!
"
thundered
the
latter
,
"
no
trifling
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
"
he
added
,
opening
a
warrant
,
"
you
'll
obey
this
mandate
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
warrant
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Kneebone
,
starting
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
Sir
,
from
the
Secretary
of
State
,
for
_
your
_
arrest
!
<EOS>
You
're
charged
with
high
-
treason
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
those
who
've
conspired
with
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
!
<EOS>
by
those
who
've
entrapped
you
!
<EOS>
You
've
long
eluded
our
vigilance
;
but
we
've
caught
you
at
last
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Damnation
!
"
exclaimed
the
woollen
-
draper
<EOS>
;
"
that
I
should
be
the
dupe
of
such
a
miserable
artifice
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
use
lamenting
now
,
Captain
!
<EOS>
You
ought
rather
to
be
obliged
to
us
for
allowing
you
to
pay
this
visit
.
<EOS>
We
could
have
secured
you
when
you
left
the
Mint
.
<EOS>
But
we
wished
to
ascertain
whether
Mrs.
Wood
's
charms
equalled
your
description
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wretches
!
"
screamed
the
lady
;
"
do
n't
dare
to
breathe
your
vile
insinuations
against
me
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
,
are
these
your
French
noblemen
?
"
 
"
Do
n't
upbraid
me
!
"
rejoined
the
woollen
-
draper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bring
him
along
,
Joe
!
"
<EOS>
said
Jackson
,
in
a
whisper
to
his
comrade
.
 
<EOS>
Smith
obeyed
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
scarcely
advanced
a
step
,
when
he
was
felled
to
the
ground
by
a
blow
from
the
powerful
arm
of
Kneebone
,
who
,
instantly
possessing
himself
of
a
pistol
,
levelled
it
at
Jackson
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Begone
!
<EOS>
or
I
fire
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
,
"
returned
Jackson
,
with
the
utmost
composure
;
"
you
're
a
headborough
,
and
a
loyal
subject
of
King
George
.
<EOS>
I
call
upon
you
to
assist
me
in
the
apprehension
of
this
person
.
<EOS>
You
'll
be
answerable
for
his
escape
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
,
I
command
you
not
to
stir
,
"
<EOS>
vociferated
the
carpenter
's
better
-
half
;
"
recollect
you
'll
be
answerable
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
do
n't
know
what
to
do
,
"
said
Wood
,
burned
by
conflicting
emotions
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
!
<EOS>
you
would
greatly
oblige
me
by
surrendering
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
replied
the
woollen
-
draper
;
"
and
if
that
treacherous
rascal
,
by
your
side
,
does

make
himself
scarce

,
I
'll
send
a
bullet
through

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
death
will
lie
at
your
door
,
"
remarked
Jackson
to
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Show
me
your
warrant
!
"
<EOS>
said
Wood
,
almost
driven
to
his
wit's
-
end
;
"
perhaps
it
is
n't
regular
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
him
who
he
is
?
"
suggested
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
good
idea
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
carpenter
.
"
<EOS>
May
I
beg
to
know
whom
I
've
the

of
adressing
?
<EOS>
Jackson
,
I
conclude
,
is
merely

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
it
signify
?
<EOS>
"
returned
the
latter
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
great
deal
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
wo
n't
disclose
your
name
,
I
will
for
you
!
<EOS>
You
are
Jonathan
Wild
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Further
concealment
is
needless
,
"
answered
the
other
,
pulling
off
his
wig
and
black
patch
,
and
resuming
his
natural
tone
of
voice
;
"
I
_
am
_
Jonathan
Wild
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Say
you
so
!
"
rejoined
Kneebone
;
"
then
be
this
your
passport
to
eternity
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
which
he
drew
the
trigger
of
the
pistol
,
which
,
luckily
for
the
individual
against
whom
it
was
aimed
,
flashed
in
the
pan
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
might
now
send
you
on
a
similar
journey
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Jonathan
,
with
a
bitter
smile
,
and
preserving
the
unmoved
demeanour
he
had
maintained
throughout
;
"
but
I
prefer
conveying
you
,
in
the
first
instance
,
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
The
Jacobite
daws
want
a
scarecrow
.
"
 
<EOS>
So

,
he
sprang
,
with
a
bound
like
that
of
a
tiger
-

,
against
the
throat
of
the
woollen
-
draper
.
<EOS>
And
so
sudden
and
well
-
directed
was
the
assault
,
that
he
completely
overthrew
his
gigantic

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lend
a
hand
with
the
ruffles
,
Blueskin
!
"
<EOS>
he
shouted
,
as
that
personage
,
who
had
just
recovered
from
the
stunning
effects
of
the
blow
,
contrived
to
pick
himself
up
.
"
<EOS>
Look
quick
,
d
--
<EOS>
n
you
,
or
<EOS>
we
shall
never
master
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Murder
!
"
shrieked
Mrs.
Wood
,
at

top

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
pistol
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
,
darting
towards
the
undischarged

dropped
by
Blueskin
in

,
and
pointing

at
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
shoot

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
yes
!
<EOS>
put
it
to
his
ear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Wood
;
"
that
's
the
surest
way
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
!
no
!
give
it
me
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Wood
,
snatching
the
pistol
,
and
rushing
to
the
door
,
against
which
he
placed

back
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
soon
settle
this
business
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
I
command
you
to
release
your
prisoner
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
will
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
who
,
with
Blueskin
's
aid
,
had
succeeded
in
slipping
a

over
the
woollen
-
draper
's
wrists
,
"
when
I
've
Mr.
Walpole
's
order
to
that
effect
--
but
not
before
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
the
consequences
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Willingly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
I
arrest
you
,
and
your
confederate
,
Joseph
Blake
,
alias
Blueskin
,
on
a
charge
of

,
"
returned
Wood
,

;
"
resist

,
if
you
dare
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
clever
device
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Jonathan
;
"
but
it
wo
n't
serve
your
turn
.
<EOS>
Let
us
pass
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Strike
the
gag
,
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
stir
a
footstep
.
<EOS>
Open
the
window
,
Thames
,
and
call
for
assistance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonathan
,
who
did
not
care
to
push
matters
too
far
,
"
let
me
have
a
word
with
you
,
Mr.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
have
no
explanations
whatever
,
"
replied
the
carpenter
,
disdainfully
,
"
except
before
a
magistrate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
state
your
charge
.
<EOS>
It
is
a

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
<EOS>
_
is
_
,
"
answered
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
recollect
this
key
?
<EOS>
Do
you
recollect
to
whom
you
gave
it
,
and
for
what
purpose
?
<EOS>
or
shall
I
refresh
your
memory
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Wild
appeared
confounded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Release
your
prisoner
,
"
continued
Wood
,
"
or
the
window
is
opened
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
advancing
towards
him
,
and
speaking
in
a
low
tone
,
"
the
secret
of
your
adopted
son
's
birth
is
known
to
me
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
his
father
's
murderer
is
also
known
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
can
help
you
to
both,--nay
,
<EOS>
I
_
will
_
help
you
to
both
,
if
you
do
not
interfere
with
my
plans
.
<EOS>
The
arrest
of
this
person
is
of
consequence
to
me
.
<EOS>
Do
not
oppose
it
,
and
I
will
serve
you
.
<EOS>
Thwart
me
,
and
I
become
your
mortal
enemy
.
<EOS>
I
have
but
to
give
a
hint
of
that
boy
's
existence
in
the
proper
quarter
,
and
his
life
will
not
be
worth
a
day
's
purchase
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
listen
to
him
,
father
,
"
cried
Thames
,
unconscious
of
what
was
passing
;
"
there
are
plenty
of
people
outside
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Make
your
choice
,
"
said
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
decide
quickly
,
I
'll
scream
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Wood
,
popping
her
head
through
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
Set
your
prisoner
free
!
"
returned
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
off
the
ruffles
,
Blueskin
,
"
rejoined
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
fixed
determination
,
"
he
added
in
a
low
tone
,
as
he
passed
the
carpenter
.
"
<EOS>
Before
to
-
morrow
night
that
boy
shall
join
his
father
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
unlocked
the
door
and
strode
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
are
some
letters
,
which
will
let
you
see
what
a
snake
you
've
cherished
in
your
bosom
,
you
uxorious
old
dotard
,
"
said
Blueskin
,
tossing
a
packet
of
papers
to
Wood
,
as
he
followed
his
leader
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Odd's
-
my
-
life
!
<EOS>
what
's
this
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
carpenter
,
looking
at
the
superscription
of
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
this
is
your
writing
Dolly
,
and
addressed
to
Mr.
Kneebone
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
writing
!
<EOS>
no
such
thing
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
lady
,
casting
a
look
of
alarm
at
the
woollen
-
draper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Confusion
!
<EOS>
the
rascal
must
have
picked
my
pocket
of
your
letters
,
"
whispered
Kneebone
,
"
What
's
to
be
done
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
to
be
done
!
<EOS>
Why
,
I
'm
undone
!
<EOS>
How
imprudent
in
you
not
to
burn
them
.
<EOS>
But
men
_
are
_
<EOS>
so
careless
,
there
's
no
trusting
anything
to
them
!
<EOS>
However
,
I
must
try
to
brazen
it
out.--Give
me
<EOS>
the
letters
,
my
love
,
"
she
added
aloud
,
and
in
her
most
winning
accents
;
"
they
're
some
wicked
forgeries
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
Madam
,
"
replied
the
carpenter
,
turning
his
back
upon
her
,
and
sinking
into
a
chair
:
"
Thames
,
my
love
,
bring
me
my
spectacles
.
<EOS>
My
heart
misgives
me
.
<EOS>
Fool
that
I
was
to
marry
for
beauty
!
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
remembered
that
a
fair
woman
and
a
slashed
gown
always
find
some
nail
in
the
way
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
VI
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
Step
towards
the
Ladder
.
  
<EOS>
If
there
is
one
thing
on
earth
,
more
lovely
than
another
,
it
is
a
fair
girl
of
the
tender
age
of
Winifred
Wood
!
<EOS>
Her
beauty
awakens
no
feeling
beyond
that
of
admiration
.
<EOS>
The
charm
of
innocence
breathes
around
her
,
as
fragrance
is
diffused
by
the
flower
,
sanctifying
her
lightest
thought
and
action
,
and
shielding
her
,
like
a
spell
,
from
the
approach
of
evil
.
<EOS>
Beautiful
is
the
girl
of
twelve,--who
is
neither
child
nor
woman
,
but
something
between
both
,
something
more
exquisite
than
either
!
 
<EOS>
Such
was
the
fairy
creature
presented
to
Thames
Darrell
,
under
the
following
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Glad
to
escape
from
the
scene
of
recrimination
that
ensued
between
his
adopted
parents
,
Thames
seized
the
earliest
opportunity
of
retiring
,
and
took
his
way
to
a
small
chamber
in
the
upper
part
of
the
house
,
where
he
and
Jack
were
accustomed
to
spend
most
of
their
leisure
in
the
amusements
,
or
pursuits
,
proper
to
their
years
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
door
ajar
,
and
,
to
his
surprise
,
perceived
little
Winifred
seated
at
a
table
,
busily
engaged
in
tracing
some
design
upon
a
sheet
of
paper
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
hear
his
approach
,
but
continued
her
occupation
without
raising
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
charming
sight
to
watch
the
motions
of
her
tiny
fingers
as
she
pursued
her
task
;
and
though
the
posture
she
adopted
was
not
the
most
favourable
that
might
have
been
chosen
for
the
display
of
her
sylphlike
figure
,
there
was
something
in
her
attitude
,
and
the
glow
of
her
countenance
,
lighted
up
by
the
mellow
radiance
of
the
setting
sun
falling
upon
her
through
the
panes
of
the
little
dormer
-
window
,
that
seemed
to
the
youth
inexpressibly
beautiful
.
<EOS>
Winifred
's
features
would
have
been
pretty
,
for
they
were
regular
and
delicately
formed
,
if
they
had
not
been
slightly
marked
by
the
small
-
pox;--a
disorder
,
that
sometimes
spares
more
than
it
destroys
,
and
imparts
an
expression
to
be
sought
for
in
vain
in
the
smoothest
complexion
.
<EOS>
We
have
seen
pitted
cheeks
,
which
we
would
not
exchange
for
dimples
and
a
satin
skin
.
<EOS>
Winifred
's
face
had
a
thoroughly
amiable
look
.
<EOS>
Her
mouth
was
worthy
of
her
face
;
with
small
,
pearly
-
white
teeth
;
lips
glossy
,
rosy
,
and
pouting
;
and
the
sweetest
smile
imaginable
,
playing
constantly
about
them
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
soft
and
blue
,
arched
over
by
dark
brows
,
and
fringed
by
long
silken
lashes
.
<EOS>
Her
hair
was
of
the
darkest
brown
,
and
finest
texture
;
and
,
when
unloosed
,
hung
down
to
her
heels
.
<EOS>
She
was
dressed
in
a
little
white
frock
,
with
a
very
long
body
,
and
very
short
sleeves
,
which
looked
(
from
a
certain
fullness
about
the
hips
,
)
as
if
it
was
intended
to
be
worn
with
a
hoop
.
<EOS>
Her
slender
throat
was
encircled
by
a
black
riband
,
with
a
small
locket
attached
to
it
;
and
upon
the
top
of
her
head
rested
a
diminutive
lace
cap
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
she
sat
was
a
portion
of
the
garret
,
assigned
,
as
we
have
just
stated
,
by
Mr.
Wood
as
a
play
-
room
to
the
two
boys
;
and
,
like
most
boy
's
playrooms
,
it
exhibited
a
total
absence
of
order
,
or
neatness
.
<EOS>
Things
were
thrown
here
and
there
,
to
be
taken
up
,
or
again
cast
aside
,
as
the
whim
arose
;
while
the
broken
-
backed
chairs
and
crazy
table
bore
the
marks
of
many
a
conflict
.
<EOS>
The
characters
of
the
youthful
occupants
of
the
room
might
be
detected
in
every
article
it
contained
.
<EOS>
Darell
's
peculiar
bent
of
mind
was
exemplified
in
a
rusty
broadsword
,
a
tall
grenadier
's
cap
,
a
musket
without
lock
or
ramrod
,
a
belt
and
cartouch
-
box
,
with
other
matters
evincing
a
decided
military
taste
.
<EOS>
Among
his
books
,
Plutarch
's
Lives
,
and
the
Histories
of
Great
Commanders
,
appeared
to
have
been
frequently
consulted
;
but
the
dust
had
gathered
thickly
upon
the
Carpenter
's
Manual
,
and
a
Treatise
on
Trigonometry
and
Geometry
.
<EOS>
Beneath
the
shelf
,
containing
these
books
,
hung
the
fine
old
ballad
of
'
_
St
.
<EOS>
George
for
England
_
'
and
a
loyal
ditty
,
then
much
in
vogue
,
called
'
_
True
Protestant
Gratitude
,
or
,
Britain
's
Thanksgiving
for
the
First
of
August
,
Being

Day
of
His

's
Happy

to
the
Throne
_
.
'
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
's
library
consisted
of
a
few
ragged

well

volumes
abstracted
from
the
tremendous

bequeathed
to
the

those
Froissarts
and

of
crime
--
the

of
Newgate
.
<EOS>
His

flash

pasted

the
wall
,
entitled
'
_
<EOS>
The
Thief
-
Catcher
's

_
,
'

'
_
Life
and
Death
of
the
Darkman
's
Budge
_
;
'
<EOS>
while
his

skill
was

in
what
he
termed
(
Jack
had
a
supreme

,
)
a
'
_
Moddle
of
his
Ma^{s
}
.
<EOS>
Jale
off
Newgate
_
;
'
another

the

;
and

<EOS>
The

,
of
his

was

,

to

a

chimney
-

of
the
time
,
described
in
Sheppard
's

'
_
Jack
Hall
a

_
.
'
<EOS>
We

not
omit
to
mention
that
a
family
group
from
the
pencil
of
little
Winifred
,
representing
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Wood
in
very
characteristic

,
occupied

.
 
<EOS>
For
a

,
Thames
regarded
the
little
girl
through
the
half
-
opened

in

.
<EOS>
On

,
a
change
came
over

,
which
,
up

this

,

.
<EOS>
Throwing

,

,
and
exclaiming,--"It
is
n't
at
all
like
him
!
<EOS>
it
is
n't
half
handsome
enough
!
"
<EOS>
was
about
to
efface

,
when
Thames
darted
into

room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
is
n't
it
like
?
"
<EOS>
he

,
endeavouring
to
gain

of

,
which
,
af

,
she

between

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
tell
you
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
blushing
deeply
,
and
clinching
her
little
hand
as

;
"
it
's
a
secret
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
soon
find
it
out
,
then
<EOS>
,
"
he
returned
,
playfully
forcing
the

from

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
look
at

,

,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
But

was
unheeded
.
<EOS>
Thames
unfolded
the
drawing
,
smoothed
out
its
creases
,
and
beheld
a
portrait
of
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
a
good

not

again
,
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,
with

;
"
you
've
acted

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel

,
dear
Winny
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Thames
,
abashed
at
his
own
rudeness
<EOS>
;
"
my
conduct
is

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll

,
"
returned
the

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
were
you
afraid

show

picture
,
Winny
?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Because

's

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
like

,
I

,

must

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Of

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Winny

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
No
;
<EOS>
but
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then

_

_

!
"
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>

--

!
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"

"

"
 
<EOS>

But

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

!
<EOS>
Winny

I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
for

really
_

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
"

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
With

<EOS>
Thames

<EOS>
His

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
From

!

"

"
     
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

as

of
me
as
she
is
of
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
likely
to
be
the
case
,
if
you
go
on
in
this
way
,
"
replied
Thames
,
sharply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
devil
would
you
have
had
me
do!--make
myself
scarce
,
eh
?
<EOS>
You
should
have
tipped
me
the
wink
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
rejoined
Thames
,
"
or
we
shall
quarrel
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
cares
if
we
do
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Sheppard
,
with
a
look
of
defiance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
said
the
other
,
sternly
;
"
do
n't
provoke
me
further
,
or
I
'll
give
you
a
thrashing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Two
can
play
at
that
game
,
my
blood
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
rising
,
and
putting
himself
into

.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
care
of

,
then
,
"
rejoined
Thames
,
doubling

,
and
advancing
towards
him
:
"
though
my
right
arm
's
stiff
,
I
can
use
it
,
as
you
'll
find
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
was
no
match
for

,
for
,

possessed
more

,
he
was
deficient

;
and
,

,

had
decidedly
the

,
a
well

on
the
_
nob
<EOS>
_
stretched
him
at

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
'll

you
to
keep

in

the
future
,
"
observed
Thames
,
as
he

Jack
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
give

,
"

Sheppard
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
let

,
it
's
not

see
the
girl
one

in

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
want
another
drubbing
,
I
perceive
,
"
said
Thames
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
.
<EOS>
Enough
's
as
good
as
a
feast
of
the
dainties
you
provide
.
<EOS>
I
'll
think
no
more
about
her
.
<EOS>
Save
us
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
as
his

,
which
Winifred
had

in

.
<EOS>
"
Is
this
_
her
_
work
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
answered

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
any

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
I
,
"
returned
Jack
,
bitterly
.
"
<EOS>
Strange
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
as

.
<EOS>
"
How
very

is
!
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

picture
should

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
but
<EOS>
it
_

resembles

's
_
<EOS>
not
_

.
<EOS>
It
's
exactly
like
a

I

in

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A

!
<EOS>
Of
whom
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
ca
n't
say
,
"

Jack
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
I
half
suspect
,
of
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
father
!
<EOS>
"

,
in

;
"
let

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Thames
took

,
and
beheld

of
a

,

--

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

right
Jack
,
"
he

:
"
this
must
have

father
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
No

,
"
answered

;
"

's

,
and

as

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
From
Lady
Trafford
's
,

I
took

box
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
you
have

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stolen
's
an
awkward
word
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
you
perceive
,
I
brought
it
away

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It

<EOS>
the
consequences
what

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
're

!
"
<EOS>

Jack
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
"
but

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

do
no

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

Thames
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>

,

;
"
do

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
"
<EOS>

Jack
,

;
"
nobody
's

and

unless
he
's
found

.
<EOS>
I
'm
safe

if

hold

.
<EOS>
Give

that

,

I

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear

,
"
said
Thames
,

;
<EOS>
"
you
well

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

"
but
I
've
my

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
dare

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Try
to
leave
the
room
,
and
see
whether
I
dare

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

"

,

"
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
Now
,

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thames

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave

!
"
<EOS>

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
But
Thames
was

from

;
and

,
if

maker

in

Winifred
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>

,

's

,
"

--

!
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
Jack

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

,
<EOS>
dear

.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
Our

's

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,

"

Sheppard
;
"
he

,

<EOS>
_

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Best

.
<EOS>
But

'm

.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
But

;

,

's

,

.
<EOS>
Above

Rowland

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

can

in
the

,
and

.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
I
contrived
,
without

,

into

.
<EOS>
I

did

;

,

,
but
,

,

!
<EOS>
with

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

"

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
"

Wood

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
And
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Come
,

's

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

appeared

blown
over
,
for

in
a

Mr.
Kneebone
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite

,
my
good
friend
<EOS>
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

,

has

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
fear

,
"
laughed
Kneebone.--"Oh
!
<EOS>
about
that
boy
,
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
His
safety
must
be
looked
to
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
's

are
not

.
<EOS>
The
rascal
will
be
at
work
before

morning
.
<EOS>
Keep
your
eye
upon
the
lad
.
<EOS>
And
mind
he
does

stir
out

your
sight
,
on
any

whatever
,
till
I
call
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear

,
"

Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

Thames
,

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Take

,
"

,
"

Thames
.
<EOS>
It

that

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
God

!
"
 
<EOS>
Upon

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
Once

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
But

_

_
<EOS>

_

<EOS>
,

ca

.
<EOS>
And
