've
made
up
my
mind
that
a
husband
ought
to
believe
only
half
that
he
hears
,
and
nothing
that
he
sees
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
An
excellent
maxim
!
<EOS>
"
replied
his
wife
,
approvingly
;
"
the
best
I
ever
heard
you
utter
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
now
go
and
look
after
Thames
,
"
observed
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
never
mind
him
:
he
'll
take
no
harm
!
<EOS>
Come
with
me
into
the
parlour
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
spare
you
at
present
.
<EOS>
Heigho
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Now
for
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
as
the
couple
entered
the
room
:
"
the
coast
's
clear
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
was
about
to
follow
,
when
he
felt
a
gentle
grasp
upon
his
arm
.
<EOS>
He
turned
,
and
beheld
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
back
presently
,
"
replied
Thames
,
evasively
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
,
I
beg
of
you
!
"
<EOS>
she
implored
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
in
danger
.
<EOS>
I
overheard
what
Mr.
Kneebone
said
,
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Death
and
the
devil
!
<EOS>
what
a
cursed
interruption
!
"
cried
Jack
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
loiter
in
this
way
,
old
Wood
will
catch
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
stir
,
I
'll
call
him
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
you
,
Jack
,
who
are
persuading
my
brother
to
do
wrong
.
<EOS>
Thames
,
"
she
urged
,
"
the
errand
,
on
which
you
're
going
,
ca
n't
be
for
any
good
,
or
you
would
n't
be
afraid
of
mentioning
it
to
my
father
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
coming
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
stamping
his
foot
,
with
vexation
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Another
moment
,
and
it
'll
be
too
late
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Winny
,
I
_
must
_
go
!
"
<EOS>
said
Thames
,
breaking
from
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
dear
Thames!--stay
!
"
cried
the
little
girl
.
"
<EOS>
He
hears
me
not
!
<EOS>
he
's
gone
!
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
<EOS>
as
the
door
was
opened
and
shut
with
violence
;
"
something
tells
me
I
shall
never
see
him
again
!
"
 
<EOS>
When
her
father
,
a
moment
afterwards
,
issued
from
the
parlour
to
ascertain
the
cause
of
the
noise
,
he
found
her
seated
on
the
stairs
,
in
an
agony
of
grief
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Thames
?
<EOS>
"
he
hastily
inquired
.
 
<EOS>
Winifred
pointed
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
Jack
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Gone
too
,
"
sobbed
his
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
uttered
something
like
an
imprecation
.
 
<EOS>
"
God
forgive
me
for
using
such
a
word
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
in
a
troubled
tone
;
"
if
I
had
n't
yielded
to
my
wife
's
silly
request
,
this
would
n't
have
happened
!
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
VII
.
 
<EOS>
Brother
and
Sister
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
same
evening
,
in
a
stately
chamber
of
a
noble
old
mansion
of
Elizabeth
's
time
,
situated
in
Southampton
Fields
,
two
persons
were
seated
.
<EOS>
One
of
these
,
a
lady
,
evidently
a
confirmed
invalid
,
and
attired
in
deep
mourning
,
reclined
upon
a
sort
of
couch
,
or
easy
chair
,
set
on
wheels
,
with
her
head
supported
by
cushions
,
and
her
feet
resting
upon
a
velvet
footstool
.
<EOS>
A
crutch
,
with
a
silver
handle
,
stood
by
her
side
,
proving
the
state
of
extreme
debility
to
which
she
was
reduced
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
easy
matter
to
determine
her
age
,
for
,
though
she
still
retained
a
certain
youthfulness
of
appearance
,
she
had
many
marks
in
her
countenance
,
usually
indicating
the
decline
of
life
,
but
which
in
her
case
were
,
no
doubt
,
the
result
of
constant
and
severe
indisposition
.
<EOS>
Her
complexion
was
wan
and
faded
,
except
where
it
was
tinged
by
a
slight
hectic
flush
,
that
made
the
want
of
colour
more
palpable
;
her
eyes
were
large
and
black
,
but
heavy
and
lustreless
;
her
cheeks
sunken
;
her
frame
emaciated
;
her
dark
hair
thickly
scattered
with
gray
.
<EOS>
When
younger
,
and
in
better
health
,
she
must
have
been
eminently
lovely
;
and
there
were
still
the
remains
of
great
beauty
about
her
.
<EOS>
The
expression
,
however
,
which
would
chiefly
have
interested
a
beholder
,
was
that
of
settled
and
profound
melancholy
.
 
<EOS>
Her
companion
was
a
person
of
no
inferior
condition
.
<EOS>
Indeed
it
was
apparent
,
from
the
likeness
between
them
,
that
they
were
nearly
related
.
<EOS>
He
had
the
same
dark
eyes
,
though
lighted
by
a
fierce
flame
;
the
same
sallow
complexion
;
the
same
tall
,
thin
figure
,
and
majestic
demeanour
;
the
same
proud
cast
of
features
.
<EOS>
But
here
the
resemblance
stopped
.
<EOS>
The
expression
was
wholly
different
.
<EOS>
He
looked
melancholy
enough
,
it
is
true
.
<EOS>
But
his
gloom
appeared
to
be
occasioned
by
remorse
,
rather
than
sorrow
.
<EOS>
No
sterner
head
was
ever
beheld
beneath
the
cowl
of
a
monk
,
or
the
bonnet
of
an
inquisitor
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
inexorable
,
and
inscrutable
as
fate
itself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Lady
Trafford
,
"
he
said
,
fixing
a
severe
look
upon
her
.
<EOS>
"
You
depart
for
Lancashire
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Have
I
your
final
answer
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
she
answered
,
in
a
feeble
tone
,
but
firmly
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
the
sum
you
require
,
but----
"
 
"
But
what
,
Madam
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
misunderstand
me
,
"
she
proceeded
.
<EOS>
"
I
give
it
to
King
James
--
<EOS>
not
so
you
:
for
the
furtherance
of
a
great
and
holy
cause
,
not
for
the
prosecution
of
wild
and
unprofitable
schemes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
bit
his
lips
to
repress
the
answer
that
rose
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
the
will
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
with
forced
calmness
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
still
refuse
to
make
one
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
have
_
made
one
,
"
replied
Lady
Trafford
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
cried
her
brother
,
starting
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rowland
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
you
strive
in
vain
to
terrify
me
into
compliance
with
your
wishes
.
<EOS>
Nothing
shall
induce
me
to
act
contrary
to
the
dictates
of
my
conscience
.
<EOS>
My
will
is
executed
,
and
placed
in
safe
custody
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
whose
favour
is
it
made
?
<EOS>
"
he
inquired
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
favour
of
my
son
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
son
,
"
rejoined
Sir
Rowland
,
moodily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
had
_
one
,
"
answered
his
sister
,
in
a
mournful
voice
;
"
and
,
perhaps
,
I
have
one
still
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
thought
so--
"
cried
the
knight
fiercely
;
"
but
this
is
idle
,
"
he
added
,
suddenly
checking
himself
.
"
<EOS>
Aliva
,
your
child
perished
with
its
father
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
by
whom
were
they
both
destroyed
?
"
demanded
his
sister
,
raising
herself
by
a
painful
effort
,
and
regarding
him
with
a
searching
glance
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
avenger
of
his
family
's
dishonour
--
by
your
brother
,
"
he
replied
,
coolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
cried
Lady
Trafford
,
her
eye
blazing
with
unnatural
light
,
and
her
cheek
suffused
with
a
crimson
stain
:
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
she
cried
,
lifting
her
thin
fingers
towards
Heaven
,
"
as
God
shall
judge
me
<EOS>
,
I
was
wedded
to
that
murdered
man
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
lie
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Sir
Rowland
,
furiously
;
"
a
black
,
and
damning
lie
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
truth
,
"
replied
his
sister
,
falling
backwards
upon
the
couch
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
swear
it
upon
the
cross
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
His
name
,
then
?
"
demanded
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
that
,
and
I
will
believe
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
now
--
not
now
!
<EOS>
"
she
returned
,
with
a
shudder
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
am
dead
you
will
learn
it
.
<EOS>
Do
not
disquiet
yourself
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
have
to
wait
long
for
the
information
.
<EOS>
Rowland
,
"
she
added
,
in
an
altered
tone
,
"
I
am
certain
I
shall
not
live
many
days
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
treat
me
in
this
way
,
you
will
have
my
death
to
answer
for
,
as
well
as
the
deaths
of
my
husband
and
child
.
<EOS>
Let
us
part
in
peace
.
<EOS>
We
shall
take
an
eternal
farewell
of
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Sir
Rowland
,
with
concentrated
fury
;
"
but
before
we
_
do
_
part
,
I
am
resolved
to
know
the
name
of
your
pretended
husband
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Torture
shall
not
wrest
it
from
me
,
"
answered
his
sister
,
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
motive
have
you
for
concealment
?
<EOS>
"
he
demanded
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
vow
,
"
she
answered,--"a
vow
to
my
dead
husband
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
looked
at
her
for
a
moment
,
as
if
he
meditated
some
terrible
reply
.
<EOS>
He
then
arose
,
and
,
taking
a
few
turns
in
the
chamber
,
stopped
suddenly
before
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
put
it
into
your
head
that
your
son
yet
lives
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
dreamed
that
I
shall
see
him
before
I
die
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dreamed
!
"
echoed
the
knight
,
with
a
ghastly
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
<EOS>
Then
learn
from
me
that
your
hopes
are
visionary
as
their
foundation
.
<EOS>
Unless
he
can
arise
from
the
bottom
of
the
Thames
,
where
he
and
his
abhorred
father
lie
buried
,
you
will
never
behold
him
again
in
this
world
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
have
compassion
on
you
,
Rowland
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
his
sister
,
crossing
her
hands
and
looking
upwards
;
"
you
have
none
on
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
will
_
have
none
till
I
have
forced
the
villain
's
name
from
you
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
stamping
the
floor
with
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rowland
,
your
violence
is
killing
me
,
"
she
returned
,
in
a
plaintive
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
name
,
I
say!--his
name
!
"
thundered
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
unsheathed
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Trafford
uttered
a
prolonged
scream
,
and
fainted
.
<EOS>
When
she
came
to
herself
,
she
found
that
her
brother
had
quitted
the
room
,
leaving
her
to
the
care
of
a
female
attendant
.
<EOS>
Her
first
orders
were
to
summon
the
rest
of
her
servants
to
make
immediate
preparations
for
her
departure
for
Lancashire
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
,
your
ladyship
?
"
ventured
an
elderly
domestic
.
 
<EOS>
"
Instantly
,
Hobson
,
"
returned
Lady
Trafford
;
"
as
soon
as
the
carriage
can
be
brought
round
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
at
the
door
in
ten
minutes
.
<EOS>
Has
your
ladyship
any
further
commands
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
stay
!
<EOS>
There
is
one
thing
I
wish
you
to
do
.
<EOS>
Take
that
box
,
and
put
it
into
the
carriage
yourself
.
<EOS>
Where
is
Sir
Rowland
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
library
,
your
ladyship
.
<EOS>
He
has
given
orders
that
no
one
is
to
disturb
him
.
<EOS>
But
there
's
a
person
in
the
hall
--
a
very
odd
sort
of
man
--
waiting
to
see
him
,
who
wo
n't
be
sent
away
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
.
<EOS>
Lose
not
a
moment
,
Hobson
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
elderly
domestic
bowed
,
took
up
the
case
,
and
retired
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
ladyship
is
far
too
unwell
to
travel
,
"
remarked
the
female
attendant
,
assisting
her
to
rise
;
"
you
'll
never
be
able
to
reach
Manchester
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
matters
not
,
Norris
,
"
replied
Lady
Trafford
:
"
I
would
rather
die
on
the
road
,
than
be
exposed
to
another
such
scene
as
I
have
just
encountered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
sympathised
Mrs.
Norris
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
afraid
from
the
scream
I
heard
,
that
something
dreadful
had
happened
,
Sir
Rowland
has
a
terrible
temper
indeed
--
a
shocking
temper
!
<EOS>
I
declare
he
frightens
me
out
of
my
senses
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Rowland
is
my
brother
,
"
resumed
Lady
Trafford
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
that
's
no
reason
why
he
should
treat
your
ladyship
so
shamefully
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
how
I
wish
,
poor
dear
Sir
Cecil
were
alive
!
<EOS>
he
'd
keep
him
in
order
.
"
 
<EOS>
Lady
Trafford
sighed
deeply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
ladyship
has
never
been
well
since
you
married
Sir
Cecil
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Norris
.
<EOS>
"
For
my
part
,
I
do
n't
think
you
ever
quite
got
over
the
accident
you
met
with
on
the
night
of
the
Great
Storm
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Norris
!
"
<EOS>
gasped
Lady
Trafford
,
trembling
violently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
<EOS>
what
have
I
said
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
attendant
,
greatly
alarmed
by
the
agitation
of
her
mistress
;
"
do
sit
down
,
your
ladyship
,
while
I
run
for
the
ratifia
and
rosa
solis
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
past
,
"
rejoined
Lady
Trafford
,
recovering
herself
by
a
powerful
effort
;
"
but
never
allude
to
the
circumstance
again
.
<EOS>
Go
and
prepare
for
our
departure
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
less
time
than
Hobson
had
mentioned
,
the
carriage
was
announced
.
<EOS>
And
Lady
Trafford
having
been
carried
down
stairs
,
and
placed
within
it
,
the
postboy
drove
off
,
at
a
rapid
pace
for
Barnet
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
VIII
.
 
<EOS>
Miching
Mallecho
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
,
meantime
,
paced
his
chamber
with
a
quick
and
agitated
step
.
<EOS>
He
was
ill
at
ease
,
though
he
would
not
have
confessed
his
disquietude
even
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Not
conceiving
that
his
sister
--
feeble
as
she
was
,
and
yielding
as
she
had
ever
shown
herself
to
his
wishes
,
whether
expressed
or
implied
--
would
depart
without
consulting
him
,
he
was
equally
surprised
and
enraged
to
hear
the
servants
busied
in
transporting
her
to
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
His
pride
,
however
,
would
not
suffer
him
to
interfere
with
their
proceedings
;
much
less
could
he
bring
himself
to
acknowledge
that
he
had
been
in
the
wrong
,
and
entreat
Lady
Trafford
to
remain
,
though
he
was
well
aware
that
her
life
might
be
endangered
if
she
travelled
by
night
.
<EOS>
But
,
when
the
sound
of
the
carriage
-
wheels
died
away
,
and
he
felt
that
she
was
actually
gone
,
his
resolution
failed
him
,
and
he
rang
the
bell
violently
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
horses
,
Charcam
,
"
he
said
,
as
a
servant
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
lingered
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sdeath
!
<EOS>
why
am
I
not
obeyed
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
knight
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
overtake
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
Use
despatch
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her
ladyship
will
not
travel
beyond
Saint
Alban
's
to
-
night
,
Sir
Rowland
,
so
Mrs.
Norris
informed
me
,
"
returned
Charcam
,
respectfully
;
"
and
there
's
a
person
without
,
anxious
for
an
audience
,
whom
,
with
submission
,
I
think
your
honour
would
desire
to
see
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Sir
Rowland
,
glancing
significantly
at
Charcam
,
who
was
a
confidant
in
his
Jacobite
schemes
;
"
is
it
the
messenger
from
Orchard
-
Windham
,
from
Sir
William
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
From
Mr.
Corbet
Kynaston
,
then
?
<EOS>
Sir
John
Packington
's
courier
was
here
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
is
from
Lord
Derwentwater
,
or
Mr.
Forster
?
<EOS>
News
_
is
_
expected
from
Northumberland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
exactly
say
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
The
gentleman
did
n't
communicate
his
business
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
'm
sure
it
's
important
.
"
 
<EOS>
Charcam
said
this
,
not
because
he
knew
anything
about
the
matter
;
but
,
having
received
a
couple
of
guineas
to
deliver
the
message
,
he
,
naturally
enough
,
estimated
its
importance
by
the
amount
of
the
gratuity
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
will
see
him
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
;
"
he
may
be
from
the
Earl
of
Mar.
But
let
the
horses
be
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
I
shall
ride
to
St.
Alban
's
to
-
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
threw
himself
into
a
chair
.
<EOS>
And
Charcam
,
fearful
of
another
charge
in
his
master
's
present
uncertain
mood
,
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
The
person
,
shortly
afterwards
ushered
into
the
room
,
seemed
by
the
imperfect
<EOS>
light,--for
the
evening
was
advancing
,
and
the
chamber
darkened
by
heavy
drapery,--to
be
a
middle
-
sized
middle
-
aged
man
,
of
rather
vulgar
appearance
,
but
with
a
very
shrewd
aspect
.
<EOS>
He
was
plainly
attired
in
a
riding
-
dress
and
boots
of
the
period
,
and
wore
a
hanger
by
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
servant
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
ducking
his
head
,
as
he
advanced
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
business
,
Sir
?
"
returned
the
other
,
stiffly
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
-
comer
looked
at
Charcam
.
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
waved
his
hand
,
and
the
attendant
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
recollect
me
,
I
presume
?
<EOS>
"
premised
the
stranger
,
taking
a
seat
.
 
<EOS>
The
knight
,
who
could
ill
brook
this
familiarity
,
instantly
arose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
disturb
yourself
,
"
continued
the
other
,
nowise
disconcerted
by
the
rebuke
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
stand
upon
ceremony
where
I
know
I
shall
be
welcome
.
<EOS>
We
_
have
_
met
before
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
rejoined
Sir
Rowland
,
haughtily
;
"
perhaps
,
you
will
refresh
my
memory
as
to
the
time
,
and
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
.
<EOS>
The
time
was
the
26th
of
November
,
1703
:
the
place
,
the
Mint
in
Southwark
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
good
memory
,
you
perceive
,
Sir
Rowland
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
knight
staggered
as
if
struck
by
a
mortal
wound
.
<EOS>
Speedily
recovering
himself
,
however
,
he
rejoined
,
with
forced
calmness
,
"
<EOS>
You
are
mistaken
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
was
in
Lancashire
,
at
our
family
seat
,
at
the
time
you
mention
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
smiled
incredulously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
brief
pause
,
during
which
the
knight
regarded
him
with
a
searching
glance
,
as
if
endeavouring
to
recall
his
features
,
"
I
will
not
gainsay
your
words
.
<EOS>
You
are
in
the
right
to
be
cautious
,
till
you
know
with
whom
you
have
to
deal
;
and
,
even
then
,
you
ca
n't
be
too
wary
.
'
<EOS>
Avow
nothing
,
believe
nothing
,
give
nothing
for
nothing
,
'
is
my
own
motto
.
<EOS>
And
it
's
a
maxim
of
universal
application
:
or
,
at
least
,
of
universal
practice
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
come
here
to
play
the
part
of
your
father
-
confessor
.
<EOS>
I
am
come
to
serve
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
what
way
,
Sir
?
"
demanded
Trenchard
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
learn
anon
.
<EOS>
You
refuse
me
your
confidence
.
<EOS>
I
applaud
your
prudence
:
it
is
,
however
,
needless
.
<EOS>
Your
history
,
your
actions
,
nay
,
your
very
thoughts
are
better
known
to
me
than
to
your
spiritual
adviser
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Make
good
your
assertions
,
"
cried
Trenchard
,
furiously
,
"
or----
<EOS>
"
 
"
To
the
proof
,
"
interrupted
the
stranger
,
calmly
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
son
of
Sir
Montacute
Trenchard
,
of
Ashton
-
Hall
,
near
Manchester
.
<EOS>
Sir
Montacute
had
three
children
--
two
daughters
and
yourself
.
<EOS>
The
eldest
,
Constance
,
was
lost
,
by
the
carelessness
of
a
servant
,
during
her
infancy
,
and
has
never
since
been
heard
of
:
the
youngest
,
Aliva
,
is
the
present
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
I
merely
mention
these
circumstances
to
show
the
accuracy
of
my
information
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
is
the
extent
of
it
,
Sir
,
"
returned
the
knight
,
ironically
,
"
you
may
spare
yourself
further
trouble
.
<EOS>
These
particulars
are
familiar
to
all
,
who
have
any
title
to
the
knowledge
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
so
,
"
rejoined
the
stranger
;
"
but
I
have
others
in
reserve
,
not
so
generally
known
.
<EOS>
With
your
permission
,
I
will
go
on
in
my
own
way
.
<EOS>
Where
I
am
in
error
,
you
can
set
me
<EOS>
right.--Your
father
,
Sir
Montacute
Trenchard
,
who
had
been
a
loyal
subject
of
King
James
the
Second
,
and
borne
arms
in
his
service
,
on
the
abdication
of
that
monarch
,
turned
his
back
upon
the
Stuarts
,
and
would
never
afterwards
recognise
their
claims
to
the
crown
.
<EOS>
It
was
said
,
that
he
received
an
affront
from
James
,
in
the
shape
of
a
public
reprimand
,
which
his
pride
could
not
forgive
.
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
though
a
Catholic
,
he
died
a
friend
to
the
Protestant
succession
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
far
you
are
correct
,
"
observed
Trenchard
;
"
still
,
this
is
no
secret
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Suffer
me
to
proceed
,
"
replied
the
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
opinions
,
entertained
by
the
old
knight
,
naturally
induced
him
to
view
with
displeasure
the
conduct
of
his
son
,
who
warmly
espoused
the
cause
he
had
deserted
.
<EOS>
Finding
remonstrances
of
no
avail
,
he
had
recourse
to
threats
;
and
when
threats
failed
,
he
adopted
more
decided
measures
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
ejaculated
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
yet
,
"
pursued
the
stranger
,
"
Sir
Montacute
had
placed
no
limit
to
his
son
's
expenditure
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
quarrel
with
Rowland
's
profusion
,
for
his
own
revenues
were
ample
;
but
he
_
did
_
object
to
the
large
sums
lavished
by
him
in
the
service
of
a
faction
he
was
resolved
not
to
support
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
the
old
knight
reduced
his
son
's
allowance
to
a
third
of
its
previous
amount
;
and
,
upon
further
provocation
,
he
even
went
so
far
as
to
alter
his
will
in
favour
of
his
daughter
,
Aliva
,
who
was
then
betrothed
to
her
cousin
,
Sir
Cecil
Trafford
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Proceed
,
Sir
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
breathing
hard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Under
these
circumstances
,
Rowland
did
what
any
other
sensible
person
would
do
.
<EOS>
Aware
of
his
father
's
inflexibility
of
purpose
,
he
set
his
wits
to
work
to
defeat
the
design
.
<EOS>
He
contrived
to
break
off
his
sister
's
match
;
and
this
he
accomplished
so
cleverly
,
that
he
maintained
the
strictest
friendship
with
Sir
Cecil
.
<EOS>
For
two
years
he
thought
himself
secure
;
and
,
secretly
engaged
in
the
Jacobite
schemes
of
the
time
,
in
which
,
also
,
Sir
Cecil
was
deeply
involved
,
he
began
to
relax
in
his
watchfulness
over
Aliva
.
<EOS>
About
this
time,--namely
,
in
November
,
1703
-
-while
young
Trenchard
was
in
Lancashire
,
and
his
sister
in
London
,
on
a
visit
,
he
received
a
certain
communication
from
his
confidential
servant
,
Davies
,
which
,
at
once
,
destroyed
his
hopes
.
<EOS>
He
learnt
that
his
sister
was
privately
married
--
the
name
or
rank
of
her
husband
could
not
be
ascertained
--
and
living
in
retirement
in
an
obscure
dwelling
in
the
Borough
,
where
she
had
given
birth
to
a
son
.
<EOS>
Rowland
's
plans
were
quickly
formed
,
and
as
quickly
executed
.
<EOS>
Accompanied
by
Sir
Cecil
,
who
still
continued
passionately
enamoured
of
his
sister
,
and
to
whom
he
represented
that
she
had
fallen
a
victim
to
the
arts
of
a
seducer
,
he
set
off
,
at
fiery
speed
,
for
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
Arrived
there
,
their
first
object
was
to
seek
out
Davies
,
by
whom
they
were
conducted
to
the
lady
's
retreat,--a
lone
habitation
,
situated
on
the
outskirts
of
Saint
George
's
Fields
in
Southwark
.
<EOS>
Refused
admittance
,
they
broke
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
Aliva
's
husband
,
who
passed
by
the
name
of
Darrell
,
confronted
them
sword
in
hand
.
<EOS>
For
a
few
minutes
he
kept
them
at
bay
.
<EOS>
But
,
urged
by
his
wife
's
cries
,
who
was
more
anxious
for
the
preservation
of
her
child
's
life
than
her
own
,
he
snatched
up
the
infant
,
and
made
his
escape
from
the
back
of
the
premises
.
<EOS>
Rowland
and
his
companions
instantly
started
in
pursuit
,
leaving
the
lady
to
recover
as
she
might
.
<EOS>
They
tracked
the
fugitive
to
the
Mint
;
but
,
like
hounds
at
fault
,
they
here
lost
all
scent
of
their
prey
.
<EOS>
Meantime
,
the
lady
had
overtaken
them
;
but
,
terrified
by
the
menaces
of
her
vindictive
kinsmen
,
she
did
not
dare
to
reveal
herself
to
her
husband
,
of
whose
concealment
on
the
roof
of
the
very
house
the
party
were
searching
<EOS>
she
was
aware
.
<EOS>
Aided
by
an
individual
,
who
was
acquainted
with
a
secret
outlet
from
the
tenement
,
Darrell
escaped
.
<EOS>
Before
his
departure
,
he
gave
his
assistant
a
glove
.
<EOS>
That
glove
is
still
preserved
.
<EOS>
In
her
endeavour
to
follow
him
,
Aliva
met
with
a
severe
fall
,
and
was
conveyed
away
,
in
a
state
of
insensibility
,
by
Sir
Cecil
.
<EOS>
She
was
supposed
to
be
lifeless
;
but
she
survived
the
accident
,
though
she
never
regained
her
strength
.
<EOS>
Directed
by
the
same
individual
,
who
had
helped
Darrell
to
steal
a
march
upon
him
,
Rowland
,
with
Davies
,
and
another
attendant
,
continued
the
pursuit
.
<EOS>
Both
the
fugitive
and
his
chasers
embarked
on
the
Thames
.
<EOS>
The
elements
were
wrathful
as
their
passions
.
<EOS>
The
storm
burst
upon
them
in
its
fury
.
<EOS>
Unmindful
of
the
terrors
of
the
night
,
unscared
by
the
danger
that
threatened
him
,
Rowland
consigned
his
sister
's
husband
and
his
sister
's
child
to
the
waves
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bring
your
story
to
an
end
,
Sir
,
"
said
Trenchard
who
had
listened
to
the
recital
with
mingled
emotions
of
rage
and
fear
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
nearly
done
,
"
replied
the
stranger.--"As
Rowland
's
whole
crew
perished
in
the
tempest
,
and
he
only
escaped
by
miracle
,
he
fancied
himself
free
from
detection
.
<EOS>
And
for
twelve
years
he
has
been
so
;
until
his
long
security
,
well
-
nigh
obliterating
remembrance
of
the
deed
,
has
bred
almost
a
sense
of
innocence
within
his
breast
.
<EOS>
During
this
period
Sir
Montacute
has
been
gathered
to
his
fathers
.
<EOS>
His
title
has
descended
to
Rowland
:
his
estates
to
Aliva
.
<EOS>
The
latter
has
,
since
,
been
induced
to
unite
herself
to
Sir
Cecil
,
on
terms
originating
with
her
brother
,
and
which
,
however
strange
and
unprecedented
,
were
acquiesced
in
by
the
suitor
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
looked
bewildered
with
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
marriage
was
never
consummated
,
"
continued
the
imperturbable
stranger
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Cecil
is
no
more
.
<EOS>
Lady
Trafford
,
supposed
to
be
childless
,
broken
in
health
and
spirits
,
frail
both
in
mind
and
body
,
is
not
likely
to
make
another
marriage
.
<EOS>
The
estates
must
,
ere
long
,
revert
to
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
man
,
or
fiend
?
"
exclaimed
Trenchard
,
staring
at
the
stranger
,
as
he
concluded
his
narration
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
complimentary
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
returned
the
other
,
with
a
grim
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
_
are
_
human
,
"
rejoined
Trenchard
,
with
stern
emphasis
,
"
I
insist
upon
knowing
whence
you
derived
your
information
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
might
refuse
to
answer
the
question
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
indisposed
to
gratify
you
.
<EOS>
Partly
,
from
your
confessor
;
partly
,
from
other
sources
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
confessor
!
<EOS>
"
ejaculated
the
knight
,
in
the
extremity
of
surprise
;
"
has
_
<EOS>
he
_
betrayed
his
sacred
trust
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
,
"
replied
the
other
,
grinning
;
"
and
this
will
be
a
caution
to
you
in
future
<EOS>
,
how
you
confide
a
secret
of
consequence
to
a
priest
.
<EOS>
I
should
as
soon
think
of
trusting
a
woman
.
<EOS>
Tickle
the
ears
of
their
reverences
with
any
idle
nonsense
<EOS>
you
please
<EOS>
:
but
tell
them
nothing
you
care
to
have
repeated
.
<EOS>
I
was
once
a
disciple
of
Saint
Peter
myself
,
and
speak
from
experience
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Trenchard
,
scarcely
able
to
credit
his
senses
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
surprised
you
've
not
asked
that
question
before
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
saved
me
much
circumlocution
,
and
you
some
suspense
.
<EOS>
My
name
is
Wild
--
Jonathan
Wild
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
the
great
thief
-
taker
indulged
himself
in
a
chuckle
at
the
effect
produced
by
this
announcement
.
<EOS>
He
was
accustomed
to
such
surprises
,
and
enjoyed
them
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
laid
his
hand
upon
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wild
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
sarcastic
tone
,
but
with
great
firmness
;
"
a
person
of
your
well
-
known
sagacity
must
be
aware
that
some
secrets
are
dangerous
to
the
possessor
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
fully
aware
of
it
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
coolly
;
"
but
I
have
nothing
to
fear
;
because
,
in
the
first
place
,
it
will
be
to
your
advantage
not
to
molest
me
;
and
,
in
the
second
,
I
am
provided
against
all
contingencies
.
<EOS>
I
never
hunt
the
human
tiger
without
being
armed
.
<EOS>
My
janizaries
are
without
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
is
furnished
with
a
packet
containing
the
heads
of
the
statement
I
have
just
related
,
which
,
if
I
do
n't
return
at
a
certain
time
,
will
be
laid
before
the
proper
authorities
.
<EOS>
I
have
calculated
my
chances
,
you
perceive
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
forgotten
that
you
are
in
my
power
,
"
returned
the
knight
,
sternly
;
"
and
that
all
your
allies
can
not
save
you
from
my
resentment
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
at
least
,
protect
myself
,
"
replied
Wild
,
with
,
provoking
calmness
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
accounted
a
fair
shot
,
as
well
as
a
tolerable
swordsman
,
and
I
will
give
proof
of
my
skill
in
both
lines
,
should
occasion
require
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
a
good
many
desperate
engagements
in
my
time
,
and
have
generally
come
off
victorious
.
<EOS>
I
bear
the
marks
of
some
of
them
about
me
still
,
"
he
continued
,
taking
off
his
wig
,
and
laying
bare
a
bald
skull
,
covered
with
cicatrices
and
plates
of
silver
.
"
<EOS>
This
gash
,
"
he
added
,
pointing
to
one
of
the
larger
scars
,
"
was
a
wipe
from
the
hanger
of
Tom
Thurland
,
whom
I
apprehended
for
the
murder
of
Mrs.
Knap
.
<EOS>
This
wedge
of
silver
,
"
pointing
to
another
,
"
which
would
mend
a
coffee
-
pot
,
serves
to
stop
up
a
breach
made
by
Will
Colthurst
,
who
robbed
Mr.
Hearl
on
Hounslow
-
Heath
.
<EOS>
I
secured
the
dog
after
he
had
wounded
me
.
<EOS>
This
fracture
was
the
handiwork
of
Jack
Parrot
(
otherwise
called
Jack
the
Grinder
)
,
who
broke
into
the
palace
of
the
Bishop
of
Norwich
.
<EOS>
Jack
was
a
comical
scoundrel
,
and
made
a
little
too
free
with
his
grace
's
best
burgundy
,
as
well
as
his
grace
's
favourite
housekeeper
.
<EOS>
The
Bishop
,
however
,
to
show
him
the
danger
of
meddling
with
the
church
,
gave
him
a
dance
at
Tyburn
for
his
pains
.
<EOS>
Not
a
scar
but
has
its
history
.
<EOS>
The
only
inconvenience
I
feel
from
my
shattered
noddle
is
an
incapacity
to
drink
.
<EOS>
But
that
's
an
infirmity
shared
by
a
great
many
sounder
heads
than
mine
.
<EOS>
The
hardest
bout
I
ever
had
was
with
a
woman
--
Sally
Wells
,
who
was
afterwards
lagged
for
shoplifting
.
<EOS>
She
attacked
me
with
a
carving
-
knife
,
and
,
when
I
had
disarmed
her
,
the
jade
bit
off
a
couple
of
fingers
from
my
left
hand
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
you
see
,
I
've
never
hesitated
and
never
_
shall
_
hesitate
to
expose
my
life
where
anything
is
to
be
gained
.
<EOS>
My
profession
has
hardened
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
with
this
,
he
coolly
re
-
adjusted
his
peruke
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
expect
to
gain
from
this
interview
,
Mr.
Wild
!
"
<EOS>
demanded
Trenchard
,
as
if
he
had
formed
a
sudden
resolution
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
now
we
come
to
business
,
"
returned
Jonathan
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
gleefully
.
<EOS>
"
These
are
my
terms
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
added
,
taking
a
sheet
of
paper
from
his
pocket
,
and
pushing
it
towards
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
Trenchard
glanced
at
the
document
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
pounds
,
"
he
observed
,
gloomily
,
"
is
a
heavy
price
to
pay
for
doubtful
secrecy
,
when
_
certain
silence
_
might
be
so
cheaply
procured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
would
purchase
it
at
the
price
of
your
head
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
knitting
his
brows
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
added
,
savagely
,
and
with
somewhat
of
the
look
of
a
bull
-
dog
before
he
flies
at
his
foe
,
"
if
it
were
my
pleasure
to
do
so
,
I
could
crush
you
with
a
breath
.
<EOS>
You
are
wholly
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
Your
name
,
with
the
fatal
epithet
of
'
dangerous
'
attached
to
it
,
stands
foremost
on
the
list
of
Disaffected
now
before
the
Secret
Committee
.
<EOS>
I
hold
a
warrant
from
Mr.
Walpole
for
your
apprehension
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Arrested
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Trenchard
,
drawing
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
up
your
blade
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
resuming
his
former
calm
demeanour
,
"
King
James
the
Third
will
need
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
intention
of
arresting
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
different
game
to
play
;
and
it
'll
be
your
own
fault
,
if
you
do
n't
come
off
the
winner
.
<EOS>
I
offer
you
my
assistance
on
certain
terms
.
<EOS>
The
proposal
is
so
far
from
being
exorbitant
,
that
it
should
be
trebled
if
I
had
not
a
fellow
-
feeling
in
the
cause
.
<EOS>
To
be
frank
with
you
,
I
have
an
affront
to
requite
,
which
can
be
settled
at
the
same
time
,
and
in
the
same
way
with
your
affair
.
<EOS>
That
's
worth
something
to
me
;
for
I
do
n't
mind
paying
for
revenge
.
<EOS>
After
all
a
thousand
pounds
is
a
trifle
to
rid
you
of
an
upstart
,
who
may
chance
to
deprive
you
of
tens
of
thousands
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
I
hear
you
aright
?
"
asked
Trenchard
,
with
startling
eagerness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
with
the
most
perfect
_
sangfroid
_
,
"
I
'll
undertake
to
free
you
from
the
boy
.
<EOS>
That
's
part
of
the
bargain
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
alive
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
"
returned
Wild
;
"
he
's
not
only
alive
,
but
likely
for
life
,
if
we
do
n't
clip
the
thread
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
caught
at
a
chair
for
support
,
and
passed
his
hand
across
his
brow
,
on
which
the
damp
had
gathered
thickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
intelligence
seems
new
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
'd
been
sufficiently
explicit
,
"
continued
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Most
persons
would
have
guessed
my
meaning
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
it
was
_
not
_
a
dream
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Sir
Rowland
in
a
hollow
voice
,
and
as
if
speaking
to
himself
.
<EOS>
"
I
_
did
_
see
them
on
the
platform
of
the
bridge
--
the
child
and
his
preserver
!
<EOS>
They
were
_
not
_
struck
by
the
fallen
ruin
,
nor
whelmed
in
the
roaring
flood,--or
,
<EOS>
if
they
_
were
_
,
they
escaped
as
I
escaped
.
<EOS>
God
!
<EOS>
I
have
cheated
myself
into
a
belief
that
the
boy
perished
!
<EOS>
And
now
my
worst
fears
are
realized
--
he
lives
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
yet
,
"
returned
Jonathan
,
with
fearful
emphasis
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
cannot
--
dare
not
injure
him
,
"
rejoined
Trenchard
,
with
a
haggard
look
,
and
sinking
,
as
if
paralysed
,
into
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
laughed
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
him
to
me
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
He
sha
n't
trouble
you
further
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Sir
Rowland
,
who
appeared
completely
prostrated
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
struggle
no
longer
with
destiny
.
<EOS>
Too
much
blood
has
been
shed
already
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
comes
of
fine
feelings
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Jonathan
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
Give
me
your
thorough
-
paced
villain
.
<EOS>
But
I
sha
n't
let
him
off
thus
.
<EOS>
I
'll
try
a
strong
dose.--Am
I
to
understand
that
you
intend
to
plead
guilty
,
Sir
Rowland
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
.
<EOS>
"
If
so
,
I
may
as
well
execute
my
warrant
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
off
,
Sir
!
"
exclaimed
Trenchard
,
starting
suddenly
backwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
that
would
bring
him
to
,
"
thought
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
the
boy
?
"
demanded
Sir
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
present
under
the
care
of
his
preserver
--
one
Owen
Wood
,
a
carpenter
,
by
whom
he
was
brought
up
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wood
!
"
exclaimed
Trenchard,--"of
Wych
Street
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
same
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
boy
from
his
shop
was
here
a
short
time
ago
.
<EOS>
Could
it
be
him
you
mean
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
That
boy
was
the
carpenter
's
apprentice
,
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
I
've
just
left
your
nephew
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Charcam
entered
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Beg
pardon
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
said
the
attendant
,
"
but
there
's
a
boy
from
Mr.
Wood
,
with
a
message
for
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
From
whom
?
"
vociferated
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
Mr.
Wood
the
carpenter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
same
who
was
here
just
now
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
Rowland
,
a
much
finer
boy
.
"
 
"
'
Tis
he
,
by
Heaven
!
"
cried
Jonathan
;
"
this
is
lucky
.
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
deep
whisper
,
"
do
you
agree
to
my
terms
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
answered
Trenchard
,
in
the
same
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
rejoined
Wild
;
"
he
shall
not
return
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
acquainted
him
with
Lady
Trafford
's
departure
?
"
said
the
knight
,
addressing
Charcam
,
with
as
much
composure
as
he
could
assume
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
the
attendant
,
"
as
you
proposed
to
ride
to
Saint
Albans
to
-
night
,
I
thought
you
might
choose
to
see
him
yourself
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
there
's
something
odd
about
the
boy
;
for
,
though
I
questioned
him
pretty
closely
concerning
his
business
,
he
declined
answering
my
questions
,
and
said
he
could
only
deliver
his
message
to
her
ladyship
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
better
not
to
send
him
away
till
I
'd
mentioned
the
circumstance
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
did
right
,
"
returned
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
asked
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
hall
,
"
replied
Charcam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Alone
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
There
's
another
lad
at
the
gate
waiting
for
him
--
the
same
who
was
here
just
now
,
that
Sir
Rowland
was
speaking
of
,
who
fastened
up
the
jewel
-
case
for
her
ladyship
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
jewel
-
case
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
I
see
it
all
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
with
a
quick
glance
.
"
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
's
fingers
are
lime
-
twigs
.
<EOS>
Was
anything
missed
after
the
lad
's
departure
,
Sir
Rowland
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
'm
aware
of
,
"
said
the
knight.--"Stay
!
<EOS>
something
occurs
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
conferred
apart
with
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wild
when
Trenchard
concluded
.
<EOS>
"
This
young
fool
is
come
to
restore
the
article
--
whatever
it
may
be
--
which
Lady
Trafford
was
anxious
to
conceal
,
and
which
his
companion
purloined
.
<EOS>
It
's
precisely
what
such
a
simpleton
would
do
.
<EOS>
We
have
him
as
safe
as
a
linnet
in
a
cage
;
and
could
wring
his
neck
round
as
easily
.
<EOS>
Oblige
me
by
acting
under
my
guidance
in
the
matter
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
I
'm
an
old
hand
at
such
things
.
<EOS>
Harkee
,
"
he
added
,
"
Mr.
What's
-
your
-
name
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Charcam
,
"
replied
the
attendant
,
bowing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
Mr.
Charcoal
,
you
may
bring
in
the
boy
.
<EOS>
But
not
a
word
to
him
of
Lady
Trafford
's
absence
--
mind
that
.
<EOS>
A
robbery
has
been
committed
,
and
your
master
suspects
this
lad
as
an
accessory
to
the
offence
.
<EOS>
He
,
therefore
,
desires
to
interrogate
him
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
necessary
to
secure
his
companion
;
and
as
you
say
he
is
not
in
the
house
,
some
caution
must
be
used
in
approaching
him
,
or
he
may
chance
to
take
to
his
heels
,
for
he
's
a
slippery
little
rascal
.
<EOS>
When
you
've
seized
him
,
cough
thrice
<EOS>
thus,--and
two
rough
-
looking
gentlemen
will
make
their
appearance
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
alarmed
by
their
manners
,
Mr.
Charcoal
.
<EOS>
They
're
apt
to
be
surly
to
strangers
,
but
it
soon
wears
off
.
<EOS>
The
gentleman
with
the
red
beard
will
relieve
you
of
your
prisoner
.
<EOS>
The
other
must
call
a
coach
as
quickly
as
he
can
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
whom
,
Sir
?
"
inquired
Charcam
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
me
--
his
master
,
Mr.
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
Mr.
Jonathan
Wild
?
"
asked
the
attendant
,
in
great
trepidation
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
am
_
,
Charcoal
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
let
my
name
frighten
you
.
<EOS>
Though
,
"
said
the
thief
-
taker
,
with
a
complacent
smile
,
"
all
the
world
seems
to
tremble
at
it
.
<EOS>
Obey
my
orders
,
and
you
've
nothing
to
fear
.
<EOS>
About
them
quickly
.
<EOS>
Lead
the
lad
to
suppose
that
he
'll
be
introduced
to
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
You
understand
me
,
Charcoal
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
attendant
did
_
not
_
understand
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
confounded
by
the
presence
in
which
he
found
himself
.
<EOS>
But
,
not
daring
to
confess
his
want
of
comprehension
,
he
made
a
profound
reverence
,
and
retired
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IX
.
 
<EOS>
Consequences
of
the
Theft
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
mean
to
act
,
Sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Trenchard
,
as
soon
as
they
were
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
circumstances
shall
dictate
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
returned
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Something
is
sure
to
arise
in
the
course
of
the
investigation
,
of
which
I
can
take
advantage
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
I
'll
convey
him
to
St.
Giles
's
round
-
house
on
my
own
responsibility
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
your
notable
scheme
!
"
<EOS>
asked
the
knight
,
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Once
there
,
"
proceeded
Wild
,
without
noticing
the
interruption
,
"
he
's
as
good
as
in
his
grave
.
<EOS>
The
constable
,
Sharples
,
is
in
my
pay
.
<EOS>
I
can
remove
the
prisoner
at
any
hour
of
the
night
I
think
fit
:
and
<EOS>
I
_
will
_
remove
him
.
<EOS>
You
must
,
know
,
Sir
Rowland
--
<EOS>
for
I
've
no
secrets
from
you
<EOS>
--
that
,
in
the
course
of
my
business
I
've
found
it
convenient
to
become
the
owner
of
a
small
Dutch
sloop
;
by
means
of
which
I
can
transmit
any
light
ware,--such
as
gold
watches
,
rings
,
and
plate
,
as
well
as
occasionally
a
bank
or
goldsmith
's
note
,
which
has
been
_
spoken
with
_
by
way
of
the
mail,--you
<EOS>
understand
me?--to
Holland
or
Flanders
,
and
obtain
a
secure
and
ready
market
for
them
.
<EOS>
This
vessel
is
now
in
the
river
,
off
Wapping
.
<EOS>
Her
cargo
is
nearly
shipped
.
<EOS>
She
will
sail
,
at
early
dawn
to
-
morrow
,
for
Rotterdam
.
<EOS>
Her
commander
,
Rykhart
Van
Galgebrok
,
is
devoted
to
my
interests
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
gets
into
blue
water
,
he
'll
think
no
more
of
pitching
the
boy
overboard
than
of
lighting
his
pipe
.
<EOS>
This
will
be
safer
than
cutting
his
throat
on
shore
.
<EOS>
I
've
tried
the
plan
,
and
found
it
answer
.
<EOS>
The
Northern
Ocean
keeps
a
secret
better
than
the
Thames
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
Before
midnight
,
your
nephew
shall
be
safe
beneath
the
hatches
of
the
Zeeslang
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
child
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Trenchard
,
abstractedly
;
"
the
whole
scene
upon
the
river
is
passing
before
me
.
<EOS>
I
hear
the
splash
in
the
water
--
I
see
the
white
object
floating
like
a
sea
-
bird
on
the
tide
--
it
will
not
sink
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sblood
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
,
in
a
tone
of
ill
-
disguised
contempt
;
"
it
wo
n't
do
to
indulge
those
fancies
now
.
<EOS>
Be
seated
,
and
calm
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
often
conjured
up
some
frightful
vision
of
the
dead
,
"
murmured
the
knight
,
"
but
I
never
dreamed
of
an
interview
with
the
living
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
'll
be
over
in
a
few
minutes
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
impatiently
;
"
in
fact
,
it
'll
be
over
too
soon
for
me
.
<EOS>
I
like
such
interviews
.
<EOS>
But
we
waste
time
.
<EOS>
Have
the
goodness
to
affix
your
name
to
that
memorandum
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
I
require
nothing
,
you
see
,
till
my
share
of
the
contract
is
fulfilled
.
"
 
<EOS>
Trenchard
took
up
a
pen
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
boy
's
death
-
warrant
,
"
observed
Jonathan
,
with
a
sinister
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
sign
it
,
"
returned
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Damnation
!
"
exclaimed
Wild
with
a
snarl
,
that
displayed
his
glistening
fangs
to
the
farthest
extremity
of
his
mouth
,
"
I
'm
not
to
be
trifled
with
thus
.
<EOS>
That
paper
_
must
_
be
signed
,
or
I
take
my
departure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
the
knight
,
haughtily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
I
'll
go
,
fast
enough
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Jonathan
,
putting
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
"
but
not
alone
,
Sir
Rowland
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
door
was
flung
open
,
and
Charcam
entered
,
dragging
in
Thames
,
whom
he
held
by
the
collar
,
and
who
struggled
in
vain
to
free
himself
from
the
grasp
imposed
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
one
of
the
thieves
,
Sir
Rowland
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
only
just
in
time
.
<EOS>
The
young
rascal
had
learnt
from
some
of
the
women
-
servants
that
Lady
Trafford
was
from
home
,
and
was
in
the
very
act
of
making
off
when
I
got
down
stairs
.
<EOS>
Come
along
,
my
Newgate
bird
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
shaking
him
with
great
violence
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
gave
utterance
to
a
low
whistle
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
things
had
gone
smoothly
,
"
he
thought
,
"
I
should
have
cursed
the
fellow
's
stupidity
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
'm
not
sorry
for
the
blunder
.
"
 
<EOS>
Trenchard
,
meanwhile
,
whose
gaze
was
fixed
upon
the
boy
,
became
livid
as
death
,
but
he
moved
not
a
muscle
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
T
is
he
!
"
<EOS>
he
mentally
ejaculated
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
your
nephew
,
Sir
Rowland
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Jonathan
,
who
sat
with
his
back
towards
Thames
,
so
that
his
features
were
concealed
from
the
youth
's
view
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
thousand
pities
,
would
n't
it
,
to
put
so
promising
a
lad
out
of
the
way
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
Devil
!
"
exclaimed
the
knight
fiercely
,
"
Give
me
the
paper
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
hastily
picked
up
the
pen
,
and
presented
it
to
Trenchard
,
who
attached
his
signature
to
the
document
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
_
am
_
<EOS>
the
devil
,
"
observed
Wild
,
"
as
some
folks
assert
,
and
I
myself
am
not
unwilling
to
believe
<EOS>
,
you
'll
find
that
I
differ
from
the
generally
-
received
notions
of
the
arch
-
fiend
,
and
faithfully
execute
the
commands
of
those
who
confide
their
souls
to
my
custody
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
hence
this
boy
,
then
,
"
rejoined
Trenchard
;
"
his
looks
unman
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Of
what
am
I
accused
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Thames
,
who
though
a
good
deal
alarmed
at
first
,
had
now
regained
his
courage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
robbery
!
"
replied
Jonathan
in
a
thundering
voice
,
and
suddenly
confronting
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
charged
with
assisting
your
comrade
,
Jack
Sheppard
,
to
purloin
certain
articles
of
value
from
a
jewel
-
case
belonging
to
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
Aha
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
,
producing
a
short
silver
staff
,
which
he
carried
constantly
about
with
him
,
and
uttering
a
terrible
imprecation
,
"
I
see
you
're
confounded
.
<EOS>
Down
on
your
marrow
-
bones
,
sirrah
!
<EOS>
Confess
your
guilt
,
and
Sir
Rowland
may
yet
save
you
from
the
gallows
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
nothing
to
confess
,
"
replied
Thames
,
boldly
;
"
I
've
done
no
wrong
.
<EOS>
Are
_
<EOS>
you
_
my
accuser
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
replied
Wild
;
"
have
you
anything
to
allege
to
the
contrary
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Only
this
,
"
returned
Thames
:
"
that
the
charge
is
false
,
and
malicious
,
and
that
_
<EOS>
you
<EOS>
_
know
it
to
be
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
I
must
search
you
my
youngster
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
sha
n't
touch
me
,
"
rejoined
Thames
;
and
,
suddenly
bursting
from
Charcam
,
he
threw
himself
at
the
feet
of
Trenchard
.
"
<EOS>
Hear
me
,
Sir
Rowland
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
innocent
,
f
have
stolen
nothing
.
<EOS>
This
person
--
this
Jonathan
Wild
,
whom
I
beheld
for
the
first
time
,
scarcely
an
hour
ago
,
in
Wych
Street
,
is
--
I
know
not
why
--
<EOS>
my
enemy
.
<EOS>
He
has
sworn
that
he
'll
take
away
my
life
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bah
!
"
interrupted
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
listen
to
this
nonsense
,
Sir
Rowland
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
_
are
_
innocent
,
boy
,
"
said
the
knight
,
controlling
his
emotion
;
"
you
have
nothing
to
apprehend
.
<EOS>
But
,
what
brought
you
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
answer
that
question
.
<EOS>
My
business
is
with
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
aware
that
I
am
her
ladyship
's
brother
?
"
returned
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
She
has
no
secrets
from
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Possibly
not
,
"
replied
Thames
,
in
some
confusion
;
"
but
I
am
not
at
liberty
to
speak
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
hesitation
is
not
in
your
favour
,
"
observed
Trenchard
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
he
consent
,
to
be
searched
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
rejoined
Thames
,
"
I
wo
n't
be
treated
like
a
common
felon
,
if
I
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
be
treated
according
to
your

,
then
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
maliciously
.
<EOS>
And
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where

"
<EOS>
asked

,
greatly

.
 
<EOS>
Thames

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
continued
Jonathan
.
"
<EOS>
But
we
'll

to

.
<EOS>
Bring
in
his
comrade
,
"
he

,
in

;
"
I
'll
take

.
<EOS>
And
do
n't

my

this

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Upon

,
with
an

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
,
of
course
,

this

Lady
Trafford
's
property
?
"
pursued
Jonathan
,
with
a
meaning

,
as
he
handed

to
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
"
replied
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
with
a

,
as

the
portrait
;
"
how
came
this
into
your
possession
,
boy
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do

you
answer
,
sirrah
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Wild
,
in
a
savage

,
and
striking

with

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ca
n't
you
speak
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
choose
,
"
replied
Thames
,
sturdily
;
"
and
your
brutality
sha
n't

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see

,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
dealing

another
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
alone
,
"
said
Trenchard
authoritatively
,
"
I
have
another

.
<EOS>
Do

whoso
portrait
<EOS>
this

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>
but
I
believe

to
be
the

of

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
Thames
;
"
he
was

while
I
was
an

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
told
you
this
is
his
portrait
?
"
demanded
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
heart
,
"
rejoined
Thames
,
firmly
;
"
which
now
tells
me
I
am
in

his

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
me
,
"
interposed
Jonathan
;
"
a
thief
-
taker
is
always
a
murderer
in
the
eyes

.
<EOS>
I
'm
almost
sorry
your
suspicions
are
unfounded
,
if
your
father
in
any

resembled
you
,
my

.
<EOS>
But
I

who
'll

father
's

;
and
that
's
a
person
not

distant
from
you
at
this
moment
--
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
As

,

,
and

entered
,

,

,
in

brown

,

,
and
a

.
<EOS>
Between
the
Jew
and
the
attendant
came
Jack
Sheppard
;
while
a

,
attracted

news
,
that

of
a
robbery
was
going

,
lingered
at
the
doorway
in
hopes
of
catching
something
of
the
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
When
Jack
was
brought
in
,
he
cast
a
rapid

around
him
,
and
perceiving
Thames
in
the
custody
of
Jonathan
,
instantly
divined
how
matters
stood
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
in
this
direction
,
Wild
gave

a
significant
wink
,
the
meaning
of
which
he
was
not
slow
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
it
over
quickly
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
in
a

to
the
thief
-

.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
nodded
assent
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
name
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
addressing
the
audacious
lad
,
who
was

as

if
nothing
material
was

.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
Sheppard
,
"
returned
the
boy
,
fixing

upon
a

of
the
Earl
of
Mar.
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
queer
cove
in

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Attend

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you

?
"
he

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
.
<EOS>
Can

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
State

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It

Trafford
's

.
"
 
<EOS>
Here

.
 
<EOS>
"
Close

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
In

,

Rowland
,
"

;
"
you
'd

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Continue

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

's

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
Darrell
;

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
!
"
<EOS>

Thames
,

.
 
<EOS>
But

took
no

.
 
<EOS>
A

;
some

.
 
<EOS>
"
Si
--
lence
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Were

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
 
<EOS>

I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Liar
!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Close

,

Charcoal
.
<EOS>
They

heard

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

;

,

.
<EOS>
You
,

,

've

.
<EOS>
To

,

,

;
and

've

<EOS>
but

Darrell
will

.
<EOS>
Now
,
for

cage
,

-

.
<EOS>
Before

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

not

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Send

Wood
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'd

,

,
"
observed

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lady
Trafford
would

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Away

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Take

,

,
"

,

Jew
;
"
I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
bearded

seized
Jack
by

,

by
the
nape
of

,

marched

,
like

in

,
with
a
boy
under

,
while
Charcam
brought
upt
the
rear
.
     
<EOS>
CHAPTER
X.
 
Mother
and
Son
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
scarcely
been
gone
a
moment
,
when
a
confused
noise
was
heard
without
,
and
Charcam
re
-
entered
the
room
,
with
a
countenance
of
the
utmost
bewilderment
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
the
man
?
"
demanded
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
ladyship--
"
faltered
the
attendant
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
her
?
"
cried
the
knight
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
returned
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Y
--
e
--
s
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
stammered
Charcam
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
devil
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
cross
-
bite
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
that
's
not
all
,
your
honour
,
"
continued
Charcam
;
"
Mrs.
Norris
says
she
's
dying
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dying
!
"
echoed
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dying
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
She
was
taken
dreadfully
ill
on
the
road
,
with
spasms
and
short
breath
,
and
swoonings,--worse
than
ever
she
was
before
.
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Norris
was
so
frightened
that
she
ordered
the
postboys
to
drive
back
as
fast
as
they
could
.
<EOS>
She
never
expected
to
get
her
ladyship
home
alive
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
God
!
"
cried
Trenchard
,
stunned
by
the
intelligence
,
"
I
have
killed
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
rejoined
Wild
,
with
a
sneer
;
"
but
do
n't
let
all
the
world
know
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
're
lifting
her
out
of
the
carriage
,
"
interposed
Charcam
;
"
will
it
please
your
honour
to
send
for
some
advice
and
the
chaplain
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Fly
for
both
,
"
returned
Sir
Rowland
,
in
a
tone
of
bitter
anguish
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
the
boys
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
hall
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her
ladyship
will
pass
through
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
;
there
's
no
other
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
bring
them
into
this
room
,
the
first
thing
--
quick
!
<EOS>
They
must
not
meet
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
added
,
as
Charcam
hastened
to
obey
his
instructions
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
has
decreed
it
otherwise
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
dejectedly
.
<EOS>
"
I
yield
to
fate
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yield
to
nothing
,
"
returned
Wild
,
trying
to
re
-
assure
him
;
"
above
all
,
when
your
designs
prosper
.
<EOS>
Man
's
fate
is
in
his
own
hands
.
<EOS>
You
are
your
nephew
's
executioner
,
or
he
is
yours
.
<EOS>
Cast
off
this
weakness
.
<EOS>
The
next
hour
makes
,
or
mars
you
for
ever
.
<EOS>
Go
to
your
sister
,
and
do
not
quit
her
till
all
is
over
.
<EOS>
Leave
the
rest
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
moved
irresolutely
towards
the
door
,
but
recoiled
before
a
sad
spectacle
.
<EOS>
This
was
his
sister
,
evidently
in
the
last
extremity
.
<EOS>
Borne
in
the
arms
of
a
couple
of
assistants
,
and
preceded
by
Mrs.
Norris
,
wringing
her
hands
and
wepping
,
the
unfortunate
lady
was
placed
upon
a
couch
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
Charcam
,
who
seemed
perfectly
distracted
by
the
recent
occurrences
,
dragged
in
Thames
,
leaving
Jack
Sheppard
outside
in
the
custody
of
the
dwarfish
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hell
's
curses
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Jonathan
between
his
teeth
;
"
that
fool
will
ruin
all
.
<EOS>
Take
him
away
,
"
he
added
,
striding
up
to
Charcam
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
remain
,
"
interposed
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
returned
Jonathan
,
with
affected
indifference
;
"
but
I
'm
not
going
to
hunt
the
deer
for
another
to
eat
the
ven'son
,
depend
on
'
t.
"
 
<EOS>
But
seeing
that
no
notice
was
taken
of
the
retort
,
he
drew
a
little
aside
,
and
folded
his
arms
,
muttering
,
"
This
whim
will
soon
be
over
.
<EOS>
She
ca
n't
last
long
.
<EOS>
I
can
pull
the
strings
of
this
stiff
-
necked
puppet
as
I
please
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
,
meantime
,
throw
himself
on
his
knees
beside
his
sister
,
and
,
clasping
her
chilly
fingers
within
his
own
,
besought
her
forgiveness
in
the
most
passionate
terms
.
<EOS>
For
a
few
minutes
,
she
appeared
scarcely
sensible
of
his
presence
.
<EOS>
But
,
after
some
restoratives
had
been
administered
by
Mrs.
Norris
,
she
revived
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rowland
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
faint
voice
,
"
I
have
not
many
minutes
to
live
.
<EOS>
Where
is
Father
Spencer
?
<EOS>
I
must
have
absolution
.
<EOS>
I
have
something
that
weighs
heavily
upon
my
mind
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
's
brow
darkened
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
sent
for
him
,
"
Aliva
,
he
answered
;
"
he
will
be
here
directly
,
with
your
medical
advisers
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
useless
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
"
Medicine
can
not
save
mo
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
sister----
"
 
"
I
should
die
happy
,
if
I
could
behold
my
child
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Comfort
yourself
,
then
,
Aliva
.
<EOS>
You
_
shall
_
behold
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
mocking
me
,
Rowland
.
<EOS>
Jests
are
not
for
seasons
like
this
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
,
by
Heaven
,
"
returned
the
knight
,
solemnly
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
us
,
Mrs.
Norris
,
and
do
not
return
till
Father
Spencer
arrives
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
ladyship----
"
hesitated
Norris
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
!
"
said
Lady
Trafford
;
"
it
is
my
last
request
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
her
faithful
attendant
,
drowned
in
tears
,
withdrew
,
followed
by
the
two
assistants
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
stepped
behind
a
curtain
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rowland
,
"
said
Lady
Trafford
,
regarding
him
with
a
look
of
indescribable
anxiety
,
"
you
have
assured
me
that
I
shall
behold
my
son
.
<EOS>
Where
is
he
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Within
this
room
,
"
replied
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
!
"
shrieked
Lady
Trafford
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
repeated
her
brother
.
"
<EOS>
But
calm
yourself
,
dear
sister
,
or
the
interview
will
be
too
much
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
am
_
calm
--
quite
calm
,
Rowland
,
"
she
answered
,
with
lips
whose
agitation
belied
her
words
.
"
<EOS>
Then
,
the
story
of
his
death
was
false
.
<EOS>
I
knew
it
.
<EOS>
I
was
sure
you
could
not
have
the
heart
to
slay
a
child
--
an
innocent
child
.
<EOS>
God
forgive
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
May
He
,
indeed
,
forgive
me
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Trenchard
,
crossing
himself
devoutly
;
"
but
my
guilt
is
not
the
less
heavy
,
because
your
child
escaped
.
<EOS>
This
hand
consigned
him
to
destruction
,
but
another
was
stretched
forth
to
save
him
.
<EOS>
The
infant
was
rescued
from
a
watery
-
grave
by
an
honest
mechanic
,
who
has
since
brought
him
up
as
his
own
son
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Blessings
upon
him
!
"
cried
Lady
Trafford
,
fervently
.
"
<EOS>
But
trifle
with
mo
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Moments
are
ages
now
.
<EOS>
Let
me
see
my
child
,
if
he
is
really
here
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Behold
him
!
"
returned
Trenchard
,
taking
Thames
(
who
had
been
a
mute
,
but
deeply
-
interested
,
witness
of
the
scene
)
by
the
hand
,
and
leading
him
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Lady
Trafford
,
exerting
all
her
strength
.
<EOS>
"
My
sight
is
failing
me
.
<EOS>
Let
me
have
more
light
,
that
I
may
behold
him
.
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
she
screamed
,
"
these
are
his
father
's
features
!
<EOS>
It
is
--
it
is
my
son
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
;
"
are
you
,
indeed
,
my
mother
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
indeed
--
my
own
sweet
boy
!
"
<EOS>
she
sobbed
,
pressing
him
tenderly
to
her
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh!--to
see
you
thus
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
,
in
an
agony
of
affliction
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
weep
,
my
love
,
"
replied
the
lady
,
straining
him
still
more
closely
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
--
quite
happy
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
During
this
touching
interview
,
a
change
had
come
over
Sir
Rowland
,
and
he
half
repented
of
what
he
had
done
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
no
longer
refuse
to
tell
me
the
name
of
this
youth
's
father
,
Aliva
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
,
Rowland
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
break
my
vow
.
<EOS>
I
will
confide
it
to
Father
Spencer
,
who
will
acquaint
you
with
it
when
I
am
no
more
.
<EOS>
Undraw
the
curtain
,
love
,
"
she
added
to
Thames
,
"
that
I
may
look
at
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
exclaimed
her
son
,
starting
back
,
as
he
obeyed
her
,
and
disclosed
Jonathan
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
silent
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
in
a
menacing
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
seen
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Lady
Trafford
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
enemy
,
"
replied
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
enemy
!
<EOS>
"
she
returned
imperfectly
comprehending
him
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
is
your
uncle
--
he
will
be
your
guardian
--
he
will
protect
you
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not
,
brother
?
"
 
"
Promise
,
"
said
a
deep
voice
in
Trenchard
's
ear
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
kill
me
,
"
cried
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
man
in
this
room
who
seeks
my
life
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
!
"
rejoined
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
these
fetters
,
"
returned
Thames
,
holding
up
his
manacled
wrists
;
"
they
were
put
on
by
my
uncle
's
command
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
shrieked
Lady
Trafford
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
,
"
whispered
Jonathan
to
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
life
--
or
yours
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
one
shall
harm
you
more
,
my
dear
,
"
cried
Lady
Trafford
.
<EOS>
"
Your
uncle
_
must
_
protect
you
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
his
interest
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
dependent
on
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
what
you
please
with
him
,
"
muttered
Trenchard
to
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
off
these
chains
,
Rowland
,
"
said
Lady
Trafford
,
"
instantly
,
I
command
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
I
_
<EOS>
will
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
advancing
,
and
rudely
seizing
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
cried
the
son
,
"
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
this
?
"
shrieked
Lady
Trafford
,
raising
herself
on
the
couch
,
and
extending
her
hands
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
God
!
<EOS>
would
you
take
him
from
me?--would
<EOS>
you
murder
him
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
His
father
's
name?--and
<EOS>
he
is
free
,
"
rejoined
Rowland
,
holding
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
Release
him
first
--
and
I
will
disclose
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Lady
Trafford
;
"
on
my
soul
,
I
will
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
then
!
"
returned
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
Too
late
!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
the
lady
,
falling
heavily
backwards,--"too
late!--oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
Heedless
of
her
cries
,
Jonathan
passed
a
handkerchief
tightly
over
her
son
's
mouth
,
and
forced
him
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
returned
,
a
moment
or
so
afterwards
,
he
found
Sir
Rowland
standing
by
the
lifeless
body
of
his
sister
.
<EOS>
His
countenance
was
almost
as
white
and
rigid
as
that
of
the
corpse
by
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
your
work
,
"
said
the
knight
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
entirely
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
calmly
;
"
though
I
should
n't
be
ashamed
of
it
if
it
were
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
you
failed
in
obtaining
the
secret
from
her
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
Women
are
hypocrites
to
the
last
--
true
only
to
themselves
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
!
"
cried
the
knight
,
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
offence
,
"
returned
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
merely
about
to
observe
that
_
I
_
am
in
possession
of
her
secret
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
tell
you
that
the
fugitive
Darrell
gave
me
a
glove
!
<EOS>
But
we
'll
speak
of
this
hereafter
.
<EOS>
You
can
_
purchase
_
<EOS>
the
information
from
me
whenever
you
're
so
disposed
.
<EOS>
I
sha
n't
drive
a
hard
bargain
.
<EOS>
To
the
point
however
.
<EOS>
I
came
back
to
say
,
that
I
've
placed
your
nephew
in
a
coach
;
and
,
if
you
'll
be
at
my
lock
in
the
Old
Bailey
an
hour
after
midnight
,
you
shall
hear
the
last
tidings
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
there
,
"
answered
Trenchard
,
gloomily
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
not
forget
the
thousand
,
Sir
Rowland
--
short
accounts
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
You
shall
have
your
reward
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee,--thank'ee
.
<EOS>
My
house
is
the
next
door
to
the
Cooper
's
Arms
,
in
the
Old
Bailey
,
opposite
Newgate
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
me
at
supper
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
bowed
and
departed
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
man
should
have
been
an
Italian
bravo
,
"
murmured
the
knight
,
sinking
into
a
chair
:
"
he
has
neither
fear
nor
compunction
.
<EOS>
Would
I
could
purchase
his
apathy
as
easily
as
I
can
procure
his
assistance
.
<EOS>
"
 
Soon
after
this
Mrs.
Norris
entered
the
room
,
followed
by
Father
Spencer
.
<EOS>
On
approaching
the
couch
,
they
found
Sir
Rowland
senseless
,
and
extended
over
the
dead
body
of
his
unfortunate
sister
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XI
.
 
<EOS>
The
Mohocks
.
  
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
,
meanwhile
,
had
quitted
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
found
a
coach
at
the
door
,
with
the
blinds
carefully
drawn
up
,
and
ascertained
from
a
tall
,
ill
-
looking
,
though
tawdrily
-
dressed
fellow
,
who
held
his
horse
by
the
bridle
,
and
whom
he
addressed
as
Quilt
Arnold
,
that
the
two
boys
were
safe
inside
,
in
the
custody
of
Abraham
Mendez
,
the
dwarfish
Jew
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
delivered
his
instructions
to
Quilt
,
who
,
with
Abraham
,
constituted
his
body
-
guard
,
or
janizaries
,
as
he
termed
them
,
Jonathan
mounted
his
steed
,
and
rode
off
at
a
gallop
.
<EOS>
Quilt
was
not
long
in
following
his
example
.
<EOS>
Springing
upon
the
box
,
he
told
the
coachman
to
make
the
best
of
his
way
to
Saint
Giles
's
.
<EOS>
Stimulated
by
the
promise
of
something
handsome
to
drink
,
the
man
acquitted
himself
to
admiration
in
the
management
of
his
lazy
cattle
.
<EOS>
Crack
went
the
whip
,
and
away
floundered
the
heavy
vehicle
through
the
deep
ruts
of
the
ill
-
kept
road
,
or
rather
lane
,
<EOS>
(
for
it
was
little
better
,
)
<EOS>
which
,
then
,
led
across
Southampton
Fields
.
<EOS>
Skirting
the
noble
gardens
of
Montague
House
,
(
now
,
we
need
scarcely
say
,
the
British
Museum
,
)
the
party
speedily
reached
Great
Russell
Street,--a
quarter
described
by
Strype
,
in
his
edition
of
old
Stow
's
famous
_
Survey
_
,
"
as
being
graced
with
the
best
buildings
in
all
Bloomsbury
,
and
the
best
inhabited
by
the
nobility
and
gentry
,
especially
the
north
side
,
as
having
gardens
behind
the
houses
,
and
the
prospect
of
the
pleasant
fields
up
to
Hampstead
and
Highgate
;
insomuch
that
this
place
,
by
physicians
,
is
esteemed
the
most
healthful
of
any
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
Neither
of
the
parties
outside
bestowed
much
attention
upon
these
stately
and
salubriously
-
situated
mansions
;
indeed
,
as
it
was
now
not
far
from
ten
o'clock
,
and
quite
dark
,
they
could
scarcely
discern
them
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
spite
of
his
general
insensibility
to
such
matters
,
Quilt
could
not
help
commenting
upon
the
delicious
perfume
wafted
from
the
numerous
flower
-
beds
past
which
they
were
driving
.
<EOS>
The
coachman
answered
by
a
surly
grunt
,
and
,
plying
his
whip
with
redoubled
zeal
,
shaped
his
course
down
Dyot
Street
;
traversed
that
part
of
Holborn
,
which
is
now
called
Broad
Street
,
and
where
two
ancient
alms
-
houses
were
,
then
,
standing
in
the
middle
of
that
great
thoroughfare
,
exactly
opposite
the
opening
of
Compston
Street
;
and
,
diving
under
a
wide
gateway
on
the
left
,
soon
reached
a
more
open
space
,
surrounded
by
mean
habitations
,
coach
-
houses
and
stables
,
called
Kendrick
Yard
,
at
the
further
end
of
which
Saint
Giles
's
round
-
house
was
situated
.
 
<EOS>
No
sooner
did
the
vehicle
turn
the
corner
of
this
yard
,
than
Quilt
became
aware
,
from
the
tumultuous
sounds
that
reached
his
ears
,
as
well
as
from
the
flashing
of
various
lanterns
at
the
door
of
the
round
-
house
,
that
some
disturbance
was
going
on
;
and
,
apprehensive
of
a
rescue
,
if
he
drew
up
in
the
midst
of
the
mob
,
he
thought
it
prudent
to
come
to
a
halt
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
stopped
the
coach
,
dismounted
,
and
hastened
towards
the
assemblage
,
which
,
he
was
glad
to
find
,
consisted
chiefly
of
a
posse
of
watchmen
and
other
guardians
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
Quilt
,
who
was
an
ardent
lover
of
mischief
,
could
not
help
laughing
most
heartily
at
the
rueful
appearance
of
these
personages
.
<EOS>
Not
one
of
them
but
bore
the
marks
of
having
been
engaged
in
a
recent
and
severe
conflict
.
<EOS>
Quarter
-
staves
,
bludgeons
,
brown
-
bills
,
lanterns
,
swords
,
and
sconces
were
alike
shivered
;
and
,
to
judge
from
the
sullied
state
of
their
habiliments
,
the
claret
must
have
been
tapped
pretty
freely
.
<EOS>
Never
was
heard
such
a
bawling
as
these
unfortunate
wights
kept
up
.
<EOS>
Oaths
exploded
like
shells
from
a
battery
in
full
fire
,
accompanied
by
threats
of
direst
vengeance
against
the
individuals
who
had
maltreated
them
.
<EOS>
Here
,
might
be
seen
a
poor
fellow
whose
teeth
were
knocked
down
his
throat
,
spluttering
out
the
most
tremendous
menaces
,
and
gesticulating
like
a
madman
:
there
,
another
,
whose
nose
was
partially
slit
,
vented
imprecations
and
lamentations
in
the
same

.
<EOS>
On
the
right
,
stood
a
bulky
figure
,
with

broken

out
of

great
-
coat
pocket
,
who
held
up
a
lantern
to

battered

to
prove
to
the
spectators
that
both
his
orbs
of
vision
were
darkened
:
on
the
left
,
a
meagre
constable
had
divested
himself
of
his
shirt
,
to
bind
up
with
greater
convenience
a
gaping
cut
in

arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
,
the
Mohocks
have
been
at

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
'

,
an
'

"

,

"

,

<EOS>

o

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

to

,

.
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
Whenever
Jack

,

;
and

,
though

,

.
<EOS>
His

,

,

,

,

,

,

quite

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
The
elastic

of
youth
resumed

;
and
,

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.

?

<EOS>
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
nothin'

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Where
to
,
honey
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
Mr.
Wood
's
,
the
carpenter
in
Wych
Street
.
<EOS>
He
lives
near
the
Black
Lion
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
Black
Lion
!
"
echoed
Terence
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
house
well
;
by
the
same
token
that
it
's
a
flash
crib
.
<EOS>
Och
!
<EOS>
many
a
mug
o
'
bubb
<EOS>
have
I
drained
wi
'
the
landlord
,
Joe
Hind
.
<EOS>
And
so
Misther
Wudd
lives
near
the
Black
Lion
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
does
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Tell

that
I
--
his

,
Thames

--
am

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames

--
is

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
boy
,

;
"
Darrell
--
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not
forget
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
mighty
quare
'
un
,
though
.
<EOS>
I
never
yet
heard
of
a
Christians
as
was
named
after
the
Shannon
or

;
and
the
Thames
is
no
better
than
a
dhurty

,
compared
wi
'

noble
strames
.
<EOS>
But
then

're
an

son
,
and
that

.
<EOS>
People
do
call

children
strange

.
<EOS>
Are
you
quite
shure
<EOS>
you
have
n't
another
alyas
,
Masther
Thames

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Darrell
,
I
tell

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
You

for

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"
hesitated
Terence
,
who
was

-

;
"
<EOS>
and
I
'd

sarve

if

could
<EOS>
,
for
you
look
like

's
son
,
and
that
goes
a

.
<EOS>
But

Wild

to

that

schames----
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
not
be
in

,
<EOS>
"

Quilt
,
who
having
secured

,
and

to

,
now

;
"
and
it
sha
n't

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
Ouns
!
"
<EOS>

,
in

,
"
would

turn

on

,

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,

-

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Come

,
my

.
<EOS>
With

,
we
're

than

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
not
for

,
"
growled

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Remember
!
"
<EOS>

,
as

along
.
 
<EOS>
"
Remember
the
devil
!
"
<EOS>

Terence
,
who
had

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do

'm
afeard
of

-

and

?
<EOS>
Not

Master
Thames
Ditton
,
I
'll

'
;
and
you
,
Misther
Quilt
Arnold
,
may

worst
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dog
!
"
exclaimed

,
turning

upon

,
"
do
you
threaten
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
the
watchman
eluded
his
grasp
,
and
,
mingling
with
the
crowd
,
disappeared
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XII
.
 
<EOS>
Saint
Giles
's
Round
-
house
.
  
<EOS>
Saint
Giles
's
Round
-
house
was
an
old
detached
fabric
,
standing
in
an
angle
of
Kendrick
Yard
.
<EOS>
Originally
built
,
as
its
name
imports
,
in
a
cylindrical
form
,
like
a
modern
Martello
tower
,
it
had
undergone
,
from
time
to
time
,
so
many
alterations
,
that
its
symmetry
was
,
in
a
great
measure
,
destroyed
.
<EOS>
Bulging
out
more
in
the
middle
than
at
the
two
extremities
,
it
resembled
an
enormous
cask
set
on
its
end,--a
sort
of
Heidelberg
tun
on
a
large
scale,--and
<EOS>
this
resemblance
was
increased
by
the
small
circular
aperture
--
it
hardly
deserved
to
be
called
a
door
--
pierced
,
like
the
bung
-
hole
of
a
barrell
,
through
the
side
of
the
structure
,
at
some
distance
from
the
ground
,
and
approached
by
a
flight
of
wooden
steps
.
<EOS>
The
prison
was
two
stories
high
,
with
a
flat
roof
surmounted
by
a
gilt
vane
fashioned
like
a
key
;
and
,
possessing
considerable
internal
accommodation
,
it
had
,
in
its
day
,
lodged
some
thousands
of
disorderly
personages
.
<EOS>
The
windows
were
small
,
and
strongly
grated
,
looking
,
in
front
,
on
Kendrick
Yard
,
and
,
at
the
back
,
upon
the
spacious
burial
-
ground
of
Saint
Giles
's
Church
.
<EOS>
Lights
gleamed
from
the
lower
rooms
,
and
,
on
a
nearer
approach
to
the
building
,
the
sound
of
revelry
might
be
heard
from
within
.
 
<EOS>
Warned
of
the
approach
of
the
prisoners
by
the
increased
clamour
,
Sharples
,
who
was
busied
in
distributing
the
Marquis
's
donation
,
affected
to
throw
the
remainder
of
the
money
among
the
crowd
,
though
,
in
reality
,
he
kept
back
a
couple
of
guineas
,
which
he
slipped
into
his
sleeve
,
and
running
hastily
up
the
steps
,
unlocked
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
,
more
leisurely
,
by
the
prisoners
;
and
,
during
their
ascent
,
Jack
Sheppard
made
a
second
attempt
to
escape
by
ducking
suddenly
down
,
and
endeavouring
to
pass
under
his
conductor
's
legs
.
<EOS>
The
dress
of
the
dwarfish
Jew
was
not
,
however
,
favourable
to
this
expedient
.
<EOS>
Jack
was
caught
,
as
in
a
trap
,
by
the
pendant
tails
of
Abraham
's
long
frock
;
and
,
instead
of
obtaining
his
release
by
his
ingenuity
,
he
only
got
a
sound
thrashing
.
 
<EOS>
Sharples
received
them
at
the
threshold
,
and
holding
his
lantern
towards
the
prisoners
to
acquaint
himself
with
their
features
,
nodded
to
Quilt
,
between
whom
and
himself
some
secret
understanding
seemed
to
subsist
,
and
then
closed
and
barred
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
"
he
growled
,
addressing
Quilt
,
"
you
know
who
's
here
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
To
be
sure
I
do
,
"
replied
Quilt
;
"
my
noble
friend
,
the
Marquis
of
Slaughterford
.
<EOS>
What
of
that
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Vot
'
o
that
!
"
echoed
Sharples
,
peevishly
:
"
Everythin
'
.
<EOS>
Vot
am
I
to
do
vith
these
young
imps
,
eh
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
you
generally
do
with
your
prisoners
,
Mr.
Sharples
,
"
replied
Quilt
;
"
lock
'em
up
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
easily
said
.
<EOS>
But
,
suppose
I
've
no
place
to
lock
'em
up
in
,
how
then
?
"
 
<EOS>
Quilt
looked
a
little
perplexed
.
<EOS>
He
passed
his
arm
under
that
of
the
constable
,
and
drew
him
aside
.
 
<EOS>
"
Vell
,
vell
,
"
growled
Sharples
,
after
he
had
listened
to
the
other
's
remonstrances
,
"
it
shall
be
done
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
confounded
inconvenient
.
<EOS>
One
do
n't
often
get
sich
a
vindfal
as
<EOS>
the
Markis----
"
 
"
Or
such
a
customer
as
Mr.
Wild
,
"
edged
in
Quilt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
,
Saint
Giles
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Sheppard
,
"
are
we
to
be
kept
here
all
night
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
day
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Sharples
:
"
wot
new
-
fledged
bantam
's
this
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
One
that
wants
to
go
to
roost
,
"
replied
Sheppard
.
"
<EOS>
So
,
stir
your
stumps
,
Saint
Giles
;
and
,
if
you
mean
to
lock
us
up
,
use
despatch
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Comin
'
!
<EOS>
comin
'
!
<EOS>
"
returned
the
constable
,
shuffling
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Coming!--so
is
midnight
--
so
is
Jonathan
Wild
,
"
retorted
Jack
,
with
a
significant
look
at
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
never
an
out
-
o
-
the
-
vay
corner
,
into
vich
you
could
shtow
these
troublesome
warmint
?
"
<EOS>
observed
Abraham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
guv'ner'll
be
here
afore
midnight
.
"
 
<EOS>
Darrell
's
attention
was
drawn
to
the
latter
part
of
this
speech
by
a
slight
pressure
on
his
foot
.
<EOS>
And
,
turning
at
the
touch
,
he
perceived
Sheppard
's
glance
fixed
meaningly
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stow
it
,
Nab
!
"
exclaimed
Quilt
,
angrily
;
"
the
kinchen
's
awake
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Awake!--to
be
sure
I
am
,
my
flash
cove
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Sheppard
;
"
I
'm
down
as
a
hammer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
just
bethought
me
of
a
crib
<EOS>
as'll
serve
their
turn
,
"
interposed
Sharples
,
"
at
any
rate
,
they
'll
be
out
<EOS>
o
'
the
vay
,
and
as
safe
as
two
chicks
in
a
coop
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Lead
the
way
to
it
then
,
Saint
Giles
,
"
said
Jack
,
in
a
tone
of
mock
authority
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
,
in
which
they
stood
,
was
a
small
entrance
-
chamber
,
cut
off
,
like
the
segment
of
a
circle
,
from
the
main
apartment
,
(
of
which
it
is
needless
to
say
it
originally
constituted
a
portion
,
)
by
a
stout
wooden
partition
.
<EOS>
A
door
led
to
the
inner
room
;
and
it
was
evident
from
the
peals
of
merriment
,
and
other
noises
,
that
,
ever
and
anon
,
resounded
from
within
,
that
this
chamber
was
occupied
by
the
Marquis
and
his
friends
.
<EOS>
Against
the
walls
hung
an
assortment
of
staves
,
brown
-
bills
,
(
weapons
then
borne
by
the
watch
,
)
muskets
,
handcuffs
,
great
-
coats
,
and
lanterns
.
<EOS>
In
one
angle
of
the
room
stood
a
disused
fire
-
place
,
with
a
rusty
grate
and
broken
chimney
-
piece
;
in
the
other
there
was
a
sort
of
box
,
contrived
between
the
wall
and
the
boards
<EOS>
,
that
looked
like
an
apology
for
a
cupboard
.
<EOS>
Towards
this
box
Sharples
directed
his
steps
,
and
,
unlocking
a
hatch
in
the
door
,
disclosed
a
recess
scarcely
as
large
,
and
certainly
not
as
clean
,
as
a
dog
-
kennel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Vill
this
do
?
"
demanded
the
constable
,
taking
the
candle
from
the
lantern
,
the
better
to
display
the
narrow
limits
of
the
hole
.
<EOS>
"
I
call
this
ere
crib
the
Little
-
Ease
,
arter
the
runaway
prentices
'
cells
in
Guildhall
.
<EOS>
I
_
have
_
squeezed
three
kids
into
it
afore
now
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
"
he
added
,
lowering
his
tone
,
"
they
wos
little
'
uns
,
and
one
on
'em
was
smothered
--
ough
!
<EOS>
ough!--how
this
cough
chokes
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
,
meanwhile
,
whose
hands
were
at
liberty
,
managed
to
possess
himself
,
unperceived
,
of
the
spike
of
a
halbert
,
which
was
lying
,
apart
from
the
pole
,
upon
a
bench
near
him
.
<EOS>
Having
secured
this
implement
,
he
burst
from
his
conductor
,
and
,
leaping
into
the
hatch
,
as
clowns
generally
spring
into
the
clock
-
faces
,
when
in
pursuit
of
harlequin
in
the
pantomime,--that
is
,
back
foremost,--broke
into
a
fit
of
loud
and
derisive
laughter
,
kicking
his
heels
merrily
all
the
time
against
the
boards
.
<EOS>
His
mirth
,
however
,
received
an
unpleasant
check
;
for
Abraham
,
greatly
incensed
by
his
previous
conduct
,
caught
him
by
the
legs
,
and
pushed
him
with
such
violence
into
the
hole
that
the
point
of
the
spike
,
which
he
had
placed
in
his
pocket
,
found
its
way
through
his
clothes
to
the
flesh
,
inflicting
a
slight
,
but
painful
wound
.
<EOS>
Jack
,
who
had
something
of
the
Spartan
in
his
composition
,
endured
his
martyrdom
without
flinching
;
and
carried
his
stoical
indifference
so
far
,
as
even
to
make
a
mocking
grimace
in
Sharples
's
face
,
while
that
amiable
functionary
thrust
Thames
into
the
recess
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
go
you
like
your
quarters
,
sauce
-
box
?
"
asked
Sharples
,
in
a
jeering
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Better
than
your
company
,
Saint
Giles
,
"
replied
Sheppard
;
"
so
,
shut
the
door
,
and
make
yourself
scarce
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
boy'll
never
rest
till
he
finds
his
vay
to
Bridewell
,
"
observed
Sharples
.
 
<EOS>
"
Or
the
street
,
"
returned
Jack
:
"
<EOS>
mind
my
words
,
the
prison
's
not
built
that
can
keep
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
that
,
young
hempseed
,
"
replied
Sharples
,
shutting
the
hatch
furiously
in
his
face
,
and
locking
it
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
get
out
o
'
that
cage
,
I
'll
forgive
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
come
along
,
gem'men
,
and
I
'll
show
you
some
precious
sport
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
two
janizaries
followed
him
as
far
as
the
entrance
to
the
inner
room
,
when
Abraham
,
raising
his
finger
to
his
lips
,
and
glancing
significantly
in
the
direction
of
the
boys
,
to
explain
his
intention
to
his
companions
,
closed
the
door
after
them
,
and
stole
softly
back
again
,
planting
himself
near
the
recess
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
few
minutes
all
was
silent
.
<EOS>
At
length
Jack
Sheppard
<EOS>
observed:--"The
coast
's
clear
.
<EOS>
They
're
gone
into
the
next
room
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Darrell
returned
no
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

,
Thames
,
"

,
in

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
did

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo

,
Jack
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
've
done
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
At

,
I
've
not

.
<EOS>
If

owe

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

_
you

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
!
"

<EOS>
"
You
've

.
"
 
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
An

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Tush
!

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

On

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

's

Arnold
,

<EOS>

"

,

"

_

!

Vot

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
When

,

,

,
    
The

;

,
    
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
 
As
Jack
concluded
his

,
the

,
and
Thames
sprang

.
 
<EOS>
This

was
so

that
it
took

completely
by

.
<EOS>
He
was
standing
at

moment
close
to

,
with

at

,
and
received
a

blow
in

.
<EOS>
He
staggered
back
a

paces
;
and
,
before
he
could

,
Thames
tripped
up

,
and
,
placing
the

of
the
spike
at

,
threatened
to
stab
him
if
he
attempted
to
stir
,
or
cry
out
.
<EOS>
Nor
had
Jack
been
idle
all
this
time
.
<EOS>
Clearing
the
recess
the
instant
after
his
companion
,
he
flew
to
the
door
of
the
inner
room
,
and
,
locking
it
,
took
out
the
key
.
<EOS>
The
policy
of
this
step
was
immediately
apparent
.
<EOS>
Alarmed
by
the
noise
of
the
scuffle
,
Quilt
and
Sharples
rushed
to
the
assistance
of
their
comrade
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
too
late
.
<EOS>
The
entrance
was
barred
against
them
;
and
they
had
the
additional
mortification
of
hearing
Sheppard
's
loud

at

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told

the
prison
was
n't

that

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're

,
<EOS>
you

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
soon

be
,
"
returned

;
"

,
"
he

,

,
"

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
What

!
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
By

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
While

,

,

--

With
pipe
and

upon
the
board
,
      
And
smiling
nymphs
around

;
    
No
tavern
could
more
mirth

Than
old
Saint
Giles
's
round
-

!
          
_
<EOS>
The
round
-
house
!
<EOS>
the

-

!
          
<EOS>
The

--
jolly

-

!
<EOS>
_
 
<EOS>
"
The
jolly
,
jolly

-

!
<EOS>
"
chorussed

,
as
