to
his
efforts
.
"
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
come
along
,
Thames
;
we
're
free
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
sho
fasht
--
not
sho
fasht
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Abraham
,
struggling
with
Thames
,
and
detaining
him
;
"
if
you
go
,
you
musht
take
me
along
vid
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Save
yourself
,
Jack
!
"
<EOS>
shouted
Thames
,
sinking
beneath
the
superior
weight
and
strength
of
his
opponent
;
"
leave
me
to
my
fate
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
replied
Jack
,
hurrying
towards
him
.
<EOS>
And
,
snatching
the
spike
from
Thames
,
he
struck
the
janizary
a
severe
blow
on
the
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
make
sure
work
this
time
,
"
he
added
,
about
to
repeat
the
blow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Thames
,
"
he
can
do
no
more
mischief
.
<EOS>
Let
us
be
gone
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
"
returned
Jack
,
leaping
up
;
"
but
I
feel
devilishly
inclined
to
finish
him
.
<EOS>
However
,
it
would
only
be
robbing
the
hangman
of
his
dues
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
was
preparing
to
follow
his
friend
,
when
their
egress
was
prevented
by
the
sudden
appearance
of
Jonathan
Wild
and
Blueskin
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XIII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Magdalene
.
  
<EOS>
The
household
of
the
worthy
carpenter
,
it
may
be
conceived
,
was
thrown
into
the
utmost
confusion
and
distress
by
the
unaccountable
disappearance
of
the
two
boys
.
<EOS>
As
time
wore
on
,
and
they
did
not
return
,
Mr.
Wood
's
anxiety
grew
so
insupportable
,
that
he
seized
his
hat
with
the
intention
of
sallying
forth
in
search
of
them
,
though
he
did
not
know
whither
to
bend
his
steps
,
when
his
departure
was
arrested
by
a
gentle
knock
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Winifred
,
starting
up
,
joyfully
,
and
proving
by
the
exclamation
that
her
thoughts
were
dwelling
upon
one
subject
only
.
<EOS>
"
There
he
is
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
not
,
"
said
her
father
,
with
a
doubtful
shake
of
the
head
.
<EOS>
"
Thames
would
let
himself
in
;
and
Jack
generally
finds
an
entrance
through
the
backdoor
or
the
shop
-
window
,
when
he
has
been
out
at
untimely
hours
.
<EOS>
But
,
go
and
see
who
it
is
,
love
.
<EOS>
Stay
!
<EOS>
I
'll
go
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
,
however
,
anticipated
him
.
<EOS>
She
flew
to
the
door
,
but
returned
the
next
minute
,
looking
deeply
disappointed
,
and
bringing
the
intelligence
that
it
was
"
only
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
almost
screamed
Mrs.
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
Sheppard
's
mother
,
"
answered
the
little
girl
,
dejectedly
;
"
she
has
brought
a
basket
of
eggs
from
Willesden
,
and
some
flowers
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
me
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Mrs.
Wood
,
in
indignant
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eggs
for
me
!
<EOS>
You
mistake
,
child
.
<EOS>
They
must
be
for
your
father
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
'm
quite
sure
she
said
they
're
for
you
,
"
replied
Winifred
;
"
but
she
_
does
_
want
to
see
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
as
much
,
"
sneered
Mrs.
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
to
her
directly
,
"
said
Wood
,
bustling
towards
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
she
has
called
to
inquire
about
Jack
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
no
such
thing
,
"
interposed
his
better
half
,
authoritatively
;
"
remain
where
you
are
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
let
me
send
her
away
,
my
dear
,
"
supplicated
the
carpenter
,
anxious
to
avert
the
impending
storm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
me
?
"
cried
the
lady
,
with
increasing
vehemence
.
"
<EOS>
Stir
a
foot
,
at
your
peril
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
love
,
"
still
remonstrated
Wood
,
"
you
know
I
'm
going
to
look
after
the
boys----
<EOS>
"
 
"
After
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
you
mean
,
Sir
,
"
interrupted
his
wife
,
ironically
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
think
to
deceive
me
by
your
false
pretences
.
<EOS>
Marry
,
come
up
!
<EOS>
I
'm
not
so
easily
deluded
.
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
I
command
you
.
<EOS>
Winny
,
show
the
person
into
this
room
.
<EOS>
I
'll
see
her
myself
;
and
that
's
more
than
she
bargained
for
,
I
'll
be
sworn
.
"
 
<EOS>
Finding
it
useless
to
struggle
further
,
Mr.
Wood
sank
,
submissively
,
into
a
chair
,
while
his
daughter
hastened
to
execute
her
arbitrary
parent
's
commission
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
length
,
I
have
my
wish
,
"
continued
Mrs.
Wood
,
regarding
her
husband
with
a
glance
of
vindictive
triumph
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
behold
the
shameless
hussy
,
face
to
face
;
and
,
if
I
find
her
as
good
-
looking
as
she
's
represented
,
I
do
n't
know
what
I
'll
do
in
the
end
;
but
I
'll
begin
by
scratching
her
eyes
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
this
temper
,
it
will
naturally
be
imagined
,
that
Mrs.
Wood
's
reception
of
the
widow
,
who
,
at
that
moment
,
was
ushered
into
the
room
by
Winifred
,
was
not
particularly
kind
and
encouraging
.
<EOS>
As
she
approached
,
the
carpenter
's
wife
eyed
her
from
head
to
foot
,
in
the
hope
of
finding
something
in
her
person
or
apparel
to
quarrel
with
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
disappointed
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
dress
--
extremely
neat
and
clean
,
but
simply
fashioned
,
and
of
the
plainest
and
most
unpretending
material,--offered
nothing
assailable
;
and
her
demeanour
was
so
humble
,
and
her
looks
so
modest
,
that
--
if
she
had
been
ill
-
looking
--
she
might
,
possibly
,
have
escaped
the
shafts
of
malice
preparing
to
be
levelled
against
her
.
<EOS>
But
,
alas
!
<EOS>
she
was
beautiful
--
and
beauty
is
a
crime
not
to
be
forgiven
by
a
jealous
woman
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
lapse
of
time
and
change
of
circumstances
have
wrought
a
remarkable
alteration
in
the
appearance
of
the
poor
widow
,
it
may
not
be
improper
to
notice
it
here
.
<EOS>
When
first
brought
under
consideration
,
she
was
a
miserable
and
forlorn
object
;
squalid
in
attire
,
haggard
in
looks
,
and
emaciated
in
frame
.
<EOS>
Now
,
she
was
the
very
reverse
of
all
this
.
<EOS>
Her
dress
,
it
has
just
been
said
,
was
neatness
and
simplicity
itself
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
,
though
slight
,
had
all
the
fulness
of
health
;
and
her
complexion
--
still
pale
,
but
without
its
former
sickly
cast,--contrasted
agreeably
,
by
its
extreme
fairness
,
with
the
dark
brows
and
darker
lashes
that
shaded
eyes
which
,
if
they
had
lost
some
of
their
original
brilliancy
,
had
gained
infinitely
more
in
the
soft
and
chastened
lustre
that
replaced
it
.
<EOS>
One
marked
difference
between
the
poor
outcast
,
who
,
oppressed
by
poverty
,
and
stung
by
shame
,
had
sought
temporary
relief
in
the
stupifying
draught,--that
worst
"
medicine
of
a
mind
diseased,"--and
those
of
the
same
being
,
freed
from
her
vices
,
and
restored
to
comfort
and
contentment
,
if
not
to
happiness
,
by
a
more
prosperous
course
of
events
,
was
exhibited
in
the
mouth
.
<EOS>
For
the
fresh
and
feverish
hue
of
lip
which
years
ago
characterised
this
feature
,
was
now
substituted
a
pure
and
wholesome
bloom
,
evincing
a
total
change
of
habits
;
and
,
though
the
coarse
character
of
the
mouth
remained
,
in
some
degree
,
unaltered
,
it
was
so
modified
in
expression
,
that
it
could
no
longer
be
accounted
a
blemish
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
the
whole
face
had
undergone
a
transformation
.
<EOS>
All
its
better
points
were
improved
,
while
the
less
attractive
ones
(
and
they
were
few
in
comparison
)
were
subdued
,
or
removed
.
<EOS>
What
was
yet
more
worthy
of
note
was
,
that
the
widow
's
countenance
had
an
air
of
refinement
about
it
,
of
which
it
was
utterly
destitute
before
,
and
which
seemed
to
intimate
that
her
true
position
in
society
was
far
above
that
wherein
accident
had
placed
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
said
the
carpenter
,
advancing
to
meet
her
,
and
trying
to
look
as
cheerful
and
composed
as
he
could
;
"
what
brings
you
to
town
,
<EOS>
eh?--Nothing
amiss
,
I
trust
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
<EOS>
whatever
,
Sir
,
"
answered
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
A
neighbour
offered
me
a
drive
to
Paddington
;
and
,
as
I
have
n't
heard
of
my
son
for
some
time
,
I
could
n't
resist
the
temptation
of
stepping
on
to
inquire
after
him
,
and
to
thank
you
for
your
great
goodness
to
us
both
<EOS>
,
I
've
brought
a
little
garden
-
stuff
and
a
few
new
-
laid
eggs
for
you
,
Ma'am
,
"
she
added
turning
to
Mrs.
Wood
,
who
appeared
to
be
collecting
her
energies
for
a
terrible
explosion
,
"
in
the
hope
that
they
may
prove
acceptable
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
nosegay
for
you
,
my
love
,
"
she
continued
,
opening
her
basket
,
and
presenting
a
fragrant
bunch
of
flowers
to
Winifred
,
"
if
your
mother
will
allow
me
to
give
it
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
touch
it
,
Winny
!
"
<EOS>
screamed
Mrs.
Wood
,
"
it
may
be
poisoned
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
afraid
,
mother
,
"
said
the
little
girl
,
smelling
at
the
bouquet
.
<EOS>
"
How
sweet
these
roses
are
!
<EOS>
Shall
I
put
them
into
water
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Put
them
where
they
came
from
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Wood
,
severely
,
"
and
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
mother
,
may
n't
I
sit
up
to
see
whether
Thames
returns
?
"
<EOS>
implored
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
can
it
matter
to
you
whether
he
returns
or
not
,
child
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Wood
,
sharply
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
spoken
.
<EOS>
And
my
word
's
law
--
with
_
<EOS>
you
_
,
at
least
,
"
she
added
,
bestowing
a
cutting
glance
upon
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
girl
uttered
no
remonstrance
;
but
,
replacing
the
flowers
in
the
basket
,
burst
into
tears
,
and
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
who
witnessed
this
occurrence
with
dismay
,
looked
timorously
at
Wood
,
in
expectation
of
some
hint
being
given
as
to
the
course
she
had
better
pursue
;
but
,
receiving
none
,
for
the
carpenter
was
too
much
agitated
to
attend
to
her
,
she
ventured
to
express
a
fear
that
she
was
intruding
.
 
<EOS>
"
Intruding
!
"
echoed
Mrs.
Wood
;
"
to
be
sure
you
are
!
<EOS>
I
wonder
how
you
dare
show
your
face
in
this
house
,
hussy
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
sent
for
me
,
Ma'am
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
humbly
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
did
,
"
retorted
Mrs.
Wood
;
"
and
I
did
so
to
see
how
far
your
effrontery
would
carry
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
'm
very
sorry
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
have
n't
given
any
unintentional
offence
?
"
said
the
widow
,
again
meekly
appealing
to
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
exchange
glances
with
him
under
my
very
nose
,
woman
!
"
shrieked
Mrs.
Wood
;
"
I
'll
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
Look
at
me
,
and
answer
me
one
question
.
<EOS>
And
,
mind
!
<EOS>
no
prevaricating
--
<EOS>
nothing
but
the
truth
will
satisfy
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
raised
her
eyes
,
and
fixed
them
upon
her
interrogator
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
not
that
man
's
mistress
?
"
demanded
Mrs.
Wood
,
with
a
look
meant
to
reduce
her
supposed
rival
to
the
dust
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
no
man
's
mistress
,
"
answered
the
widow
,
crimsoning
to
her
temples
,
but
preserving
her
meek
deportment
,
and
humble
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
false
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
too
well
acquainted
with
your
proceedings
,
Madam
,
to
believe
that
.
<EOS>
Profligate
women
are
never
reclaimed
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
He
_
has
told
me
sufficient
of
you--
"
 
"
My
dear
,
"
interposed
Wood
,
"
for
goodness
'
sake--
"
 
"
I
_
will
_
speak
,
"
screamed
his
wife
,
totally
disregarding
the
interruption
;
"
I
_
will
_
tell
this
worthless
creature
what
I
know
about
her,--and
what
I
think
of
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
now
,
my
love
--
not
now
,
"
entreated
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
_
now
_
,
"
rejoined
the
infuriated
dame
;
"
perhaps
,
I
may
never
have
another
opportunity
.
<EOS>
She
has
contrived
to
keep
out
of
my
sight
up
to
this
time
,
and
I
've
no
doubt
she
'll
keep
out
of
it
altogether
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
was
my
doing
,
dearest
,
"
urged
the
carpenter
;
"
I
was
afraid
if
you
saw
her
that
some
such
scene
as
this
might
occur
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Madam
,
I
beseech
you
,
"
interposed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
and
,
if

,

"
 
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"
life

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mighty

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

_

<EOS>

pocketed

constable
's
staff
with
which
he
thought
it
expedient
to
arm
himself
,
of
being
direfully
revenged
upon
the
thief
-
taker
:
<EOS>
a
determination
in
which
he
was
strongly
encouraged
by
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Terence
,
meanwhile
,
who
had
followed
him
,
did
not
remain
silent
,
but
recapitulated
his
story
,
for
the
benefit
of
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
The
poor
widow
was
thrown
into
an
agony
of
distress
on
learning
that
a
robbery
had
been
committed
,
in
which
her
son
(
for
she
could
not
doubt
that
Jack
was
one
of
the
boys
,
)
was
implicated
;
nor
was
her
anxiety
alleviated
by
Mrs.
Wood
,
who
maintained
stoutly
,
that
if
Thames
had
been
led
to
do
wrong
,
it
must
be
through
the
instrumentality
of
his
worthless
companion
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
there
you
're
right
<EOS>
,
you
may
dipind
,
marm
,
"
observed
Terence
.
"
<EOS>
Master
Thames
Ditt
<EOS>
--
what
's
his
blessed
name?--has
honesty
written
in
his
handsome
phiz
;
but
as
to
his
companion
,
Jack
Sheppard
,
I
think
you
call
him
,
he
's
a
born
and
bred
thief
.
<EOS>
Lord
bless
you
marm
!
<EOS>
we
sees
plenty
on
'em
in
our
purfession
.
<EOS>
Them
young
prigs
is
all
alike
.
<EOS>
I
seed
he
was
one,--and
<EOS>
a
sharp
un
,
too,--at
a
glance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
exclaimed
the
widow
,
covering
her
face
with
her
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
a
drop
of
brandy
before
we
start
,
watchman
,
"
said
Wood
,
pouring
out
a
glass
of
spirit
,
and
presenting
it
to
Terence
,
who
smacked
his
lips
as
he
disposed
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
be
persuaded
,
Joan
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
making
a
similar
offer
to
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
which
she
gratefully
declined
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
mean
to
accompany
us
,
you
may
need
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
,
Sir
,
"
returned
the
widow
,
"
but
I
require
no
support
.
<EOS>
Nothing
stronger
than
water
has
passed
my
lips
for
years
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
may
believe
as
much
of
that
as
we
please
,
I
suppose
,
"
observed
the
carpenter
's
wife
,
with
a
sneer
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
,
"
she
continued
,
in
an
authoritative
tone
,
seeing
her
husband
ready
to
depart
,
"
one
word
before
you
set
out
.
<EOS>
If
Jack
Sheppard
or
his
mother
ever
enter
this
house
again
,
I
leave
it
--
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
Now
,
do
what
you
please
.
<EOS>
You
know
_
my
_
fixed
determination
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
made
no
reply
;
but
,
hastily
kissing
his
weeping
daughter
,
and
bidding
her
be
of
good
cheer
,
hurried
off
.
<EOS>
He
was
followed
with
equal
celerity
by
Terence
and
the
widow
.
<EOS>
Traversing
what
remained
of
Wych
Street
at
a
rapid
pace
,
and
speeding
along
Drury
Lane
,
the
trio
soon
found
themselves
in
Kendrick
Yard
.
<EOS>
When
they
came
to
the
round
-
house
,
Terry
's
courage
failed
him
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
terror
inspired
by
Wild
's
vindictive
character
,
that
few
durst
face
him
who
had
given
him
cause
for
displeasure
.
<EOS>
Aware
that
he
should
incur
the
thief
-
taker
's
bitterest
animosity
by
what
he
had
done
,
the
watchman
,
whose
wrath
against
Quilt
Arnold
had
evaporated
during
the
walk
,
thought
it
more
prudent
not
to
hazard
a
meeting
with
his
master
,
till
the
storm
had
,
in
some
measure
,
blown
over
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
having
given
Wood
such
directions
as
he
thought
necessary
for
his
guidance
,
and
received
a
handsome
gratuity
in
return
for
his
services
,
he
departed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
without
considerable
demur
and
delay
on
the
part
of
Sharples
that
the
carpenter
and
his
companion
could
gain
admittance
to
the
round
-
house
.
<EOS>
Reconnoitring
them
through
a
small
grated
loophole
,
he
refused
to
open
the
door
till
they
had
explained
their
business
.
<EOS>
This
,
Wood
,
acting
upon
Terry
's
caution
,
was
most
unwilling
to
do
;
but
,
finding
he
had
no
alternative
,
he
reluctantly
made
known
his
errand
and
the
bolts
were
undrawn
.
<EOS>
Once
in
,
the
constable
's
manner
appeared
totally
changed
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
as
civil
as
he
had
just
been
insolent
.
<EOS>
Apologizing
for
their
detention
,
he
answered
the
questions
put
to
him
respecting
the
boys
,
by
positively
denying
that
any
such
prisoners
had
been
entrusted
to
his
charge
,
but
offered
to
conduct
him
to
every
cell
in
the
building
to
prove
the
truth
of
his
assertion
.
<EOS>
He
then
barred
and
double
-
locked
the
door
,
took
out
the
key
,
(
a
precautionary
measure
which
,
with
a
grim
smile
,
he
said
he
never
omitted
,
)
thrust
it
into
his
vest
,
and
motioning
the
couple
to
follow
him
,
led
the
way
to
the
inner
room
.
<EOS>
As
Wood
obeyed
,
his
foot
slipped
;
and
,
casting
his
eyes
upon
the
floor
,
he
perceived
it
splashed
in
several
places
with
blood
.
<EOS>
From
the
freshness
of
the
stains
,
which
grew
more
frequent
as
they
approached
the
adjoining
chamber
,
it
was
evident
some
violence
had
been
recently
perpetrated
,
and
the
carpenter
's
own
blood
froze
within
his
veins
as
he
thought
,
with
a
thrill
of
horror
,
that
,
perhaps
on
this
very
spot
,
not
many
minutes
before
his
arrival
,
his
adopted
son
might
have
been
inhumanly
butchered
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
impression
removed
as
he
stole
a
glance
at
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
and
saw
from
her
terrified
look
that
she
had
made
the
same
alarming
discovery
as
himself
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
now
too
late
to
turn
back
,
and
,
nerving
himself
for
the
shock
he
expected
to
encounter
,
he
ventured
after
his
conductor
.
<EOS>
No
sooner
had
they
entered
the
room
than
Sharples
,
who
waited
to
usher
them
in
,
hastily
retreated
,
closed
the
door
,
and
turning
the
key
,
laughed
loudly
at
the
success
of
his
stratagem
.
<EOS>
Vexation
at
his
folly
in
suffering
himself
to
be
thus
entrapped
kept
Wood
for
a
short
time
silent
.
<EOS>
When
he
could
find
words
,
he
tried
by
the
most
urgent
solicitations
to
prevail
upon
the
constable
to
let
him
out
.
<EOS>
But
threats
and
entreaties
--
even
promises
were
ineffectual
;
and
the
unlucky
captive
,
after
exhausting
his
powers
of
persuasion
,
was
compelled
to
give
up
the
point
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
he
was
detained
--
that
lately
occupied
by
the
Mohocks
,
who
,
it
appeared
,
had
been
allowed
to
depart,--was
calculated
to
inspire
additional
apprehension
and
disgust
.
<EOS>
Strongly
impregnated
with
the
mingled
odours
of
tobacco
,
ale
,
brandy
,
and
other
liquors
,
the
atmosphere
was
almost
stifling
.
<EOS>
The
benches
running
round
the
room
,
though
fastened
to
the
walls
by
iron
clamps
,
had
been
forcibly
wrenched
off
;
while
the
table
,
which
was
similarly
secured
to
the
boards
,
was
upset
,
and
its
contents
--
bottles
,
jugs
,
glasses
,
and
bowls
were
broken
and
scattered
about
in
all
directions
.
<EOS>
Everything
proclaimed
the
mischievous
propensities
of
the
recent
occupants
of
the
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
Here
lay
a
heap
of
knockers
of
all
sizes
,
from
the
huge
lion
's
head
to
the
small
brass
rapper
:
there
,
a
collection
of
sign
-
boards
,
with
the
names
and
calling
of
the
owners
utterly
obliterated
.
<EOS>
On
this
side
stood
the
instruments
with
which
the
latter
piece
of
pleasantry
had
been
effected,--namely
,
a
bucket
filled
with
paint
and
a
brush
:
on
that
was
erected
a
trophy
,
consisting
of
a
watchman
's
rattle
,
a
laced
hat
,
with
the
crown
knocked
out
,
and
its
place
supplied
by
a
lantern
,
a
campaign
wig
saturated
with
punch
,
a
torn
steen
-
kirk
and
ruffles
,
some
half
-
dozen
staves
,
and
a
broken
sword
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
carpenter
's
gaze
wandered
over
this
scene
of
devastation
,
his
attention
was
drawn
by
Mrs.
Sheppard
towards
an
appalling
object
in
one
corner
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
body
of
a
man
,
apparently
lifeless
,
and
stretched
upon
a
mattress
,
with
his
head
bound
up
in
a
linen
cloth
,
through
which
the
blood
had
oosed
.
<EOS>
Near
the
body
,
which
,
it
will
be
surmised
,
was
that
of
Abraham
Mendez
,
two
ruffianly
personages
were
seated
,
quietly
smoking
,
and
bestowing
no
sort
of
attention
upon
the
new
-
comers
.
<EOS>
Their
conversation
was
conducted
in
the
flash
language
,
and
,
though
unintelligible
to
Wood
,
was
easily
comprehended
by
this
companion
,
who
learnt
,
to
her
dismay
,
that
the
wounded
man
had
received
his
hurt
from
her
son
,
whose
courage
and
dexterity
formed
the
present
subject
of
their
discourse
.
<EOS>
From
other
obscure
hints
dropped
by
the
speakers
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
ascertained
that
Thames
Darrell
had
been
carried
off
--
where
she
could
not
make
out
--
by
Jonathan
Wild
and
Quilt
Arnold
;
and
that
Jack
had
been
induced
to
accompany
Blueskin
to
the
Mint
.
<EOS>
This
intelligence
,
which
she
instantly
communicated
to
the
carpenter
,
drove
him
almost
frantic
.
<EOS>
He
renewed
his
supplications
to
Sharples
,
but
with
no
better
success
than
heretofore
;
and
the
greater
part
of
the
night
was
passed
by
him
and
the
poor
widow
,
whose
anxiety
,
if
possible
,
exceeded
his
own
,
in
the
most
miserable
state
imaginable
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
about
three
o'clock
,
as
the
first
glimmer
of
dawn
became
visible
through
the
barred
casements
of
the
round
-
house
,
the
rattling
of
bolts
and
chains
at
the
outer
door
told
that
some
one
was
admitted
.
<EOS>
Whoever
this
might
be
,
the
visit
seemed
to
have
some
reference
to
the
carpenter
,
for
,
<EOS>
shortly
afterwards
,
Sharples
made
his
appearance
,
and
informed
the
captives
they
were
free
.
<EOS>
Without
waiting
to
have
the
information
repeated
,
Wood
rushed
forth
,
determined
as
soon
as
he
could
procure
assistance
,
to
proceed
to
Jonathan
Wild
's
house
in
the
Old
Bailey
;
while
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
whose
maternal
fears
drew
her
in
another
direction
,
hurried
off
to
the
Mint
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XIV
.
 
<EOS>
The
Flash
Ken
.
  
<EOS>
In
an
incredibly
short
space
of
time,--for
her
anxiety
lent
wings
to
her
feet,--Mrs
.
<EOS>
Sheppard
reached
the
debtor
's
garrison
.
<EOS>
From
a
scout
stationed
at
the
northern
entrance
,
whom
she
addressed
in
the
jargon
of
the
place
,
with
which
long
usage
had
formerly
rendered
her
familiar
,
she
ascertained
that
Blueskin
,
accompanied
by
a
youth
,
whom
she
knew
by
the
description
must
be
her
son
,
had
arrived
there
about
three
hours
before
,
and
had
proceeded
to
the
Cross
Shovels
.
<EOS>
This
was
enough
for
the
poor
widow
.
<EOS>
She
felt
she
was
now
near
her
boy
,
and
,
nothing
doubting
her
ability
to
rescue
him
from
his
perilous
situation
,
she
breathed
a
fervent
prayer
for
his
deliverance
;
and
bending
her
steps
towards
the
tavern
in
question
,
revolved
within
her
mind
as
she
walked
along
the
best
means
of
accomplishing
her
purpose
.
<EOS>
Aware
of
the
cunning
and
desperate
characters
of
the
persons
with
whom
she
would
have
to
deal,--aware
,
also
,
that
she
was
in
a
quarter
where
no
laws
could
be
appealed
to
,
nor
assistance
obtained
<EOS>
,
she
felt
the
absolute
necessity
of
caution
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
when
she
arrived
at
the
Shovels
,
with
which
,
as
an
old
haunt
in
her
bygone
days
of
wretchedness
she
was
well
acquainted
,
instead
of
entering
the
principal
apartment
,
which
she
saw
at
a
glance
was
crowded
with
company
of
both
sexes
,
she
turned
into
a
small
room
on
the
left
of
the
bar
,
and
,
as
an
excuse
for
so
doing
,
called
for
something
to
drink
.
<EOS>
The
drawers
at
the
moment
were
too
busy
to
attend
to
her
,
and
she
would
have
seized
the
opportunity
of
examining
,
unperceived
,
the
assemblage
within
,
through
a
little
curtained
window
that
overlooked
the
adjoining
chamber
,
if
an
impediment
had
not
existed
in
the
shape
of
Baptist
Kettleby
,
whose
portly
person
entirely
obscured
the
view
.
<EOS>
The
Master
of
the
Mint
,
in
the
exercise
of
his
two
-
fold
office
of
governor
and
publican
,
was
mounted
upon
a
chair
,
and
holding
forth
to
his
guests
in
a
speech
,
to
which
Mrs.
Sheppard
was
unwillingly
compelled
to
listen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
of
the
Mint
,
"
said
the
orator
,
"
when
I
was
first
called
,
some
fifty
years
ago
,
to
the
important
office
I
hold
,
there
existed
across
the
water
three
places
of
refuge
for
the
oppressed
and
persecuted
debtor
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
know
it
,
"
cried
several
voices
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
happened
,
gentlemen
,
"
pursued
the
Master
,
"
on
a
particular
occasion
,
about
the
time
I
've
mentioned
,
that
the
Archduke
of
Alsatia
,
the
Sovereign
of
the
Savoy
,
and
the
Satrap
of
Salisbury
Court
,
met
by
accident
at
the
Cross
Shovels
.
<EOS>
A
jolly
night
we
made
of
it
,
as
you
may
suppose
;
for
four
such
monarchs
do
n't
often
come
together
.
<EOS>
Well
,
while
we
were
smoking
our
pipes
,
and
quaffing
our
punch
,
Alsatia
turns
to
me
and
says
,
'
Mint
,
'
says
he
,
'
you
're
well
off
here
.
<EOS>
'--'Pretty
<EOS>
well
,
'
says
I
;
'
you
're
not
badly
off
at
the
Friars
,
for

.
<EOS>
'--'Oh
!
<EOS>
yes

,
'

?
'
<EOS>
says
<EOS>
I.--'It
's
all

,
'

;
'

<EOS>
'--'They
ca

,
'

,
'

ca
n't
<EOS>
,

,
'

,

;
'

.
<EOS>
'--'Unconstitutional
<EOS>
or

,
'

,
speaking

,
'
it

.
<EOS>
We

,

must

.
<EOS>
'--'No
fear
o
'
that
,
'

'

,
'

,

.
<EOS>
'--'It

,
'

,

'

.
<EOS>
'--'What

,
Mint
?
'
<EOS>
asked

,

,

,
'

I.--'We'll

,
'

,

,

's

;
'

Mint
.
'
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

not

;

not

hang

;
and

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
where
are

?
"
echoed
the
company
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
returned
the
Master
,
solemnly
,
"
it
is
a

they
are
NOWHERE
!
<EOS>
Had
they
hanged
the
bailiffs
,
the
bailiffs
would
not
have

.
<EOS>
We
ourselves
have
been
similarly
circumstanced
.
<EOS>
Attacked
by
an
infamous
and
unconstitutional
statute
,
passed
in
the
reign
of
the
late
usurper
,
William
of
Orange
,
(
for
I
may
remark
that
,
if

right

,
that

would
never

--
the
Stuarts
--
<EOS>
Heaven
preserve
'
em!--always
siding
with
the
debtors
)
;
attacked
in
this
outrageous
manner
<EOS>
,
I
repeat
,
it
has
been
all
but
'
_
up
_
'
with
US
!
<EOS>
But
the

by

to

,

than

;
and
,

their

were
crushed
and

,
they

more

than

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
,
I
am

that
_
<EOS>
I
_
originated
--
that
_
I
_

those
measures
.
<EOS>
I
hope
to
see
the
day
,
when
not
Southwark
alone
,
but
London
itself
shall
become
one
Mint,--when
all

shall
be
debtors
,

for

shall

shall
be

a

,
and
<EOS>
forgery

and

discontinued,--Newgate
,

,
the

,
and

<EOS>
razed
to

,

's

,

remembered

!
<EOS>
But
,

,

may
possibly

farther
off
than
I

,
we
are
bound
to
make

.
<EOS>
Take
care
of
yourselves
,
gentlemen
,
and
your
governor
will
take

.
<EOS>
Before

sit

,
I

,
which
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
is
the
health
of
a

Mr.
John
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
His
father
was
one
of
my
old
customers
,
and
I

his
son
treading

.
<EOS>
He
could
n't

in

hands
than

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen,--Mr
.
<EOS>
Sheppard
's
good

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
Baptist
's
toast
was
received
with
loud

,
and
,
as
he
sat
down
amid
the

the
company
,
and
a
universal

of
mugs

,
the

's

was

.
<EOS>
Her

wandered

over
that
riotous

,
until
it
settled
upon
one

more
riotous

disorderly
than
the
rest
,
of

her
son
formed

.
<EOS>
The
agonized
mother
could
scarcely

a

at
the
spectacle
that
met

.
<EOS>
There
sat
Jack
,
evidently
in
the

of

,
with
his

,
his

,

half

<EOS>
he

,

<EOS>
he
was
almost
past

,
one

had
passed
her

<EOS>
round

,

.
 
<EOS>
Both

ladies
possessed

.
<EOS>
The

,

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

pretty
_

_
,
(
why

,

?
)
<EOS>
teeth

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

Edgeworth

;

,

will

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

_

_
,

Poll
Maggot
<EOS>
,

,

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless

,

,

,

,

of

Thalestris

,

Medicean

.
<EOS>
A
man
's

hat,--whether

from

,

,
we
are

to

knowingly

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Maggot
,

,

;
nor

to

.
<EOS>
On

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
By

,

,

.
<EOS>
Some

;

<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>
Nor

.
<EOS>
Not

,

,

playing
at

.
<EOS>
Near

sat

,
or

,

with

,

,
for

_
suit_,--or
,

,

,

_

,

_

,
_

.
<EOS>
Next

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Amid

in

,

alone
,
we
have
said
,
rivetted
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
attention
;
and

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"

,

,

?
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
