hand
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Poll
,
help
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
exhorted
,
Mrs.
Maggot
lent
her
powerful
aid
,
and
,
between
the
two
<EOS>
,
Jack
was
speedily
relieved
from
all
fears
of
being
carried
off
against
his
will
.
<EOS>
Not
content
with
this
exhibition
of
her
prowess
,
the
Amazon
lifted
him
up
as
easily
as
if
he
had
been
an
infant
,
and
placed
him
upon
her
shoulders
,
to
the
infinite
delight
of
the
company
,
and
the
increased
distress
of
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
let
's
see
who
'll
dare
to
take
him
down
,
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nobody
shall
,
"
cried
Mr.
Sheppard
from
his
elevated
position
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
my
own
master
now
,
and
I
'll
do
as
I
please
.
<EOS>
I
'll
turn
cracksman
,
like
my
father
--
<EOS>
rob
old
Wood
<EOS>
--
he
has
chests
full
of
money
,
and
I
know
where
they
're
kept
--
I'll
rob
him
,
and
give
the
swag
to
you
,
Poll
--
<EOS>
I'll--
"
 
Jack
would
have
said
more
;
but
,
losing
his
balance
,
he
fell
to
the
ground
,
and
,
when
taken
up
,
he
was
perfectly
insensible
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
,
he
was
laid
upon
a
bench
,
to
sleep
off
his
drunken
fit
,
while
his
wretched
mother
,
in
spite
of
her
passionate
supplications
and
resistance
,
was
,
by
Blueskin
's
command
,
forcibly
ejected
from
the
house
,
and
driven
out
of
the
Mint
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XV
.
 
<EOS>
The
Robbery
in
Willesden
Church
.
  
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
the
next
day
and
night
,
the
poor
widow
hovered
like
a
ghost
about
the
precincts
of
the
debtors
'
garrison,--for
admission
(
by
the
Master
's
express
orders
,
)
was
denied
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
learn
nothing
of
her
son
,
and
only
obtained
one
solitary
piece
of
information
,
which
added
to
,
rather
than
alleviated
her
misery,--namely
,
that
Jonathan
Wild
had
paid
a
secret
visit
to
the
Cross
Shovels
.
<EOS>
At
one
time
,
she
determined
to
go
to
Wych
Street
,
and
ask
Mr.
Wood
's
advice
and
assistance
,
but
the
thought
of
the
reception
she
was
likely
to
meet
with
from
his
wife
deterred
her
from
executing
this
resolution
.
<EOS>
Many
other
expedients
occurred
to
her
;
but
after
making
several
ineffectual
attempts
to
get
into
the
Mint
unobserved
,
they
were
all
abandoned
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
about
an
hour
before
dawn
on
the
second
day
--
Sunday
--
having
spent
the
early
part
of
the
night
in
watching
at
the
gates
of
the
robbers
'
sanctuary
,
and
being
almost
exhausted
from
want
of
rest
,
she
set
out
homewards
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
walk
she
had
to
undertake
,
even
if
she
had
endured
no
previous
fatigue
,
but
feeble
as
she
was
,
it
was
almost
more
than
she
could
accomplish
.
<EOS>
Daybreak
found
her
winding
her
painful
way
along
the
Harrow
Road
;
and
,
in
order
to
shorten
the
distance
as
much
as
possible
,
she
took
the
nearest
cut
,
and
struck
into
the
meadows
on
the
right
.
<EOS>
Crossing
several
fields
,
newly
mown
,
or
filled
with
lines
of
tedded
hay
,
she
arrived
,
not
without
great
exertion
,
at
the
summit
of
a
hill
.
<EOS>
Here
her
strength
completely
failed
her
,
and
she
was
compelled
to
seek
some
repose
.
<EOS>
Making
her
couch
upon
a
heap
of
hay
,
she
sank
at
once
into
a
deep
and
refreshing
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
awoke
,
the
sun
was
high
in
Heaven
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
bright
and
beautiful
day
:
_
so
<EOS>
_
bright
,
so
beautiful
,
that
even
her
sad
heart
was
cheered
by
it
.
<EOS>
The
air
,
perfumed
with
the
delicious
fragrance
of
the
new
-
mown
grass
,
was
vocal
with
the
melodies
of
the
birds
;
the
thick
foliage
of
the
trees
was
glistening
in
the
sunshine
;
all
nature
seemed
happy
and
rejoicing
;
but
,
above
all
,
the
serene
Sabbath
stillness
reigning
around
communicated
a
calm
to
her
wounded
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
contrast
did
the
lovely
scene
she
now
gazed
upon
present
to
the
squalid
neighbourhood
she
had
recently
quitted
!
<EOS>
On
all
sides
,
expanded
prospects
of
country
the
most
exquisite
and
most
varied
.
<EOS>
Immediately
beneath
her
lay
Willesden,--the
most
charming
and
secluded
village
in
the
neighbourhood
of
the
metropolis
--
with
its
scattered
farm
-
houses
,
its
noble
granges
,
and
its
old
grey
church
-
tower
just
peeping
above
a
grove
of
rook
-
haunted
trees
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
this
spot
Mrs.
Sheppard
now
directed
her
steps
.
<EOS>
She
speedily
reached
her
own
abode,--a
little
cottage
,
standing
in
the
outskirts
of
the
village
.
<EOS>
The
first
circumstance
that
struck
her
on
her
arrival
seemed
ominous
.
<EOS>
Her
clock
had
stopped
--
stopped
at
the
very
hour
on
which
she
had
quitted
the
Mint
!
<EOS>
She
had
not
the
heart
to
wind
it
up
again
.
 
<EOS>
After
partaking
of
some
little
refreshment
,
and
changing
her
attire
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
prepared
for
church
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
she
had
so
far
succeeded
in
calming
herself
,
that
she
answered
the
greetings
of
the
neighbours
whom
she
encountered
on
her
way
to
the
sacred
edifice
--
if
sorrowfully
,
still
composedly
.
 
<EOS>
Every
old
country
church
is
beautiful
,
but
Willesden
is
the
most
beautiful
country
church
we
know
;
and
in
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
time
it
was
even
more
beautiful
than
at
present
,
when
the
hand
of
improvement
has
proceeded
a
little
too
rashly
with
alterations
and
repairs
.
<EOS>
With
one
or
two
exceptions
,
there
were
no
pews
;
and
,
as
the
intercourse
with
London
was
then
but
slight
,
the
seats
were
occupied
almost
exclusively
by
the
villagers
.
<EOS>
In
one
of
these
seats
,
at
the
end
of
the
aisle
farthest
removed
from
the
chancel
,
the
widow
took
her
place
,
and
addressed
herself
fervently
to
her
devotions
.
 
<EOS>
The
service
had
not
proceeded
far
,
when
she
was
greatly
disturbed
by
the
entrance
of
a
person
who
placed
himself
opposite
her
,
and
sought
to
attract
her
attention
by
a
number
of
little
arts
,
surveying
her
,
as
he
did
so
,
with
a
very
impudent
and
offensive
stare
.
<EOS>
With
this
person
--
who
was
no
other
than
Mr.
Kneebone
--
she
was
too
well
acquainted
;
having
,
more
than
once
,
been
obliged
to
repel
his
advances
;
and
,
though
his
impertinence
would
have
given
her
little
concern
at
another
season
,
it
now
added
considerably
to
her
distraction
.
<EOS>
But
a
far
greater
affliction
was
in
store
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
the
clergyman
approached
the
altar
,
she
perceived
a
boy
steal
quickly
into
the
church
,
and
ensconce
himself
behind
the
woollen
-
draper
,
<EOS>
who
,
in
order
to
carry
on
his
amatory
pursuits
with
greater
convenience
,
and
at
the
same
time
display
his
figure
(
of
which
he
was
not
a
little
vain
)
to
the
utmost
advantage
,
preferred
a
standing
to
a
sitting
posture
.
<EOS>
Of
this
boy
she
had
only
caught
a
glimpse;--but
that
glimpse
was
sufficient
to
satisfy
her
<EOS>
it
was
her
son,--and
,
if
she
could
have
questioned
her
own
instinctive
love
,
she
could
not
question
her
antipathy
,
when
she
beheld
,
partly
concealed
by
a
pillar
immediately
in
the
rear
of
the
woollen
-
draper
,
the
dark
figure
and
truculent
features
of
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
As
she
looked
in
this
direction
,
the
thief
-
taker
raised
his
eyes
--
those
gray
,
blood
-
thirsty
eyes!--their
glare
froze
the
life
-
blood
in
her
veins
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
averted
her
gaze
,
a
terrible
idea
crossed
her
.
<EOS>
Why
was
he
there
?
<EOS>
why
did
the
tempter
dare
to
invade
that
sacred
spot
!
<EOS>
She
could
not
answer
her
own
questions
,
but
vague
fearful
suspicions
passed
through
her
mind
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
service
proceeded
;
and
the
awful
command
,
"
_
Thou
shalt
not
steal
_
!
"
<EOS>
was
solemnly
uttered
by
the
preacher
,
when
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
who
had
again
looked
round
towards
her
son
,
beheld
a
hand
glance
along
the
side
of
the
woollen
-
draper
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
see
what
occurred
,
though
she
guessed
it
;
but
she
saw
Jonathan
's
devilish
triumphing
glance
,
and
read
in
it,--"Your
son
has
committed
a
robbery
--
here
--
in
these
holy
walls
--
he
is
mine
--
mine
for
ever
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
uttered
a
loud
scream
,
and
fainted
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XVI
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
's
House
in
the
Old
Bailey
.
  
<EOS>
Just
as
St.
Sepulchre
's
church
struck
one
,
on
the
eventful
night
of
the
10th
of
June
,
(
to
which
it
will
not
be
necessary
to
recur
,
)
<EOS>
a
horseman
,
mounted
on
a
powerful
charger
,
and
followed
at
a
respectful
distance
by
an
attendant
,
galloped
into
the
open
space
fronting
Newgate
,
and
directed
his
course
towards
a
house
in
the
Old
Bailey
.
<EOS>
Before
he
could
draw
in
the
rein
,
his
steed
--
startled
apparently
by
some
object
undistinguishable
by
the
rider,--swerved
with
such
suddenness
as
to
unseat
him
,
and
precipitate
him
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
however
,
he
was
picked
up
,
and
set
upon
his
feet
by
a
person
who
,
having
witnessed
the
accident
,
flew
across
the
road
to
his
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
hurt
<EOS>
I
hope
,
Sir
Rowland
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
this
individual
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
materially
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
replied
the
other
,
"
a
little
shaken
,
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
Curses
light
on
the
horse
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
seizing
the
bridle
of
his
steed
,
who
continued
snorting
and
shivering
,
as
if
still
under
the
influence
of
some
unaccountable
alarm
;
"
what
can
ail
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
_
know
what
ails
him
,
your
honour
,
"
rejoined
the
groom
,
riding
up
as
he
spoke
;
"
he
's
seen
somethin'
not
o
'
this
world
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Most
likely
,
"
observed
Jonathan
,
with
a
slight
sneer
;
"
the
ghost
of
some
highwayman
who
has
just
breathed
his
last
in
Newgate
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
May
be
,
"
returned
the
man
gravely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
him
home
,
Saunders
,
"
said
Sir
Rowland
,
resigning
his
faulty
steed
to
the
attendant
's
care
,
"
I
shall
not
require
you
further
.
<EOS>
Strange
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
as
the
groom
departed
;
"
Bay
Stuart
has
carried
me
through
a
hundred
dangers
,
but
never
played
me
such
a
trick
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
never
should
again
,
were
he
mine
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
If
the
best
nag
ever
foaled
were
to
throw
me
in
this
unlucky
spot
,
I
'd
blow
his
brains
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Sir
?
"
asked
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
fall
against
Newgate
is
accounted
a
sign
of
death
by
the
halter
,
"
replied
Wild
,
with
ill
-
disguised
malignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tush
!
"
exclaimed
Sir
Rowland
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
that
door
,
"
continued
the
thief
-
taker
,
pointing
to
the
gloomy
portal
of
the
prison
opposite
which
they
were
standing
,
"
the
condemned
are
taken
to
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
bad
omen
to
be
thrown
near
that
door
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
suspect
you
of
so
much
superstition
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
observed
the
knight
,
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Facts
convince
the
most
incredulous
,
"
answered
Jonathan
,
drily
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
known
several
cases
where
the
ignominious
doom
I
've
mentioned
has
been
foretold
by
such
an
accident
as
has
just
befallen
you
.
<EOS>
There
was
Major
Price
<EOS>
--
you
must
recollect
him
,
Sir
Rowland,--he
stumbled
as
he
was
getting
out
of
his
chair
at
that
very
gate
.
<EOS>
Well
,
_
he
_
was
executed
for
murder
.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
Tom
Jarrot
,
the
hackney
-
coachman
,
who
was
pitched
off
the
box
against
yonder
curbstone
,
and
broke
his
leg
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pity
he
did
n't
break
his
neck
,
for
he
was
hanged
within
the
year
.
<EOS>
Another
instance
was
that
of
Toby
Tanner--
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
interrupted
Trenchard
;
"
where
is
the
boy
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
far
hence
,
"
replied
Wild
.
"
<EOS>
After
all
our
pains
we
were
near
losing
him
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
so
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
other
,
distrustfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
hear
,
"
returned
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
the
help
of
his
comrade
,
Jack
Sheppard
,
the
young
rascal
made
a
bold
push
to
get
out
of
the
round
-
house
,
where
my
janizaries
had
lodged
him
,
and
would
have
succeeded
too
,
if
,
by
<EOS>
good
luck,--for
<EOS>
the
devil
never
deserts
so
useful
an
agent
as
I
am
,
Sir
Rowland,--I
had
n't
arrived
in
time
to
prevent
him
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
my
oldest
and
trustiest
setter
,
Abraham
Mendez
,
received
a
blow
on
the
head
from
one
of
the
lads
that
will
deprive
me
of
his
services
for
a
week
to
come,--if
,
indeed
it
does
not
disable
him
altogether
.
<EOS>
However
,
if
I
've
lost
one
servant
,
I
've
gained
another
,
that
's
one
comfort
.
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
is
now
wholly
in
my
hands
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
this
to
me
,
Sir
?
"
said
Trenchard
,
cutting
him
short
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
whatever
,
"
rejoined
the
thief
-
taker
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
much
to
me
.
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
is
to
me
what
Thames
Darrell
is
to
you
--
an
object
of
hatred
.
<EOS>
I
owed
his
father
a
grudge
:
that
I
settled
long
ago
.
<EOS>
I
owe
his
mother
one
,
and
will
repay
the
debt
,
with
interest
,
to
her
son
.
<EOS>
I
could
make
away
with
him
at
once
,
as
you
are
about
to
make
away
with
your
nephew
,
Sir
Rowland,--but
that
would
n't
serve
my
turn
.
<EOS>
To
be
complete
,
my
vengeance
must
be
tardy
.
<EOS>
Certain
of
my
prey
,
I
can
afford
to
wait
for
it
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
revenge
is
sweetened
by
delay
;
and
I
indulge
too
freely
in
the
passion
to
rob
it
of
any
of
its
zest
.
<EOS>
I
've
watched
this
lad
--
this
Sheppard
--
from
infancy
;
and
,
though
I
have
apparently
concerned
myself
little
about
him
,
I
have
never
lost
sight
of
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
have
suffered
him
to
be
brought
up
decently
--
honestly
;
because
I
would
make
his
fall
the
greater
,
and
deepen
the
wound
I
meant
to
inflict
upon
his
mother
.
<EOS>
From
this
night
I
shall
pursue
a
different
course
;
from
this
night
his
ruin
may
be
dated
.
<EOS>
He
is
in
the
care
of
those
who
will
not
leave
the
task
assigned
to
them
--
the
utter
perversion
of
his
principles
--
half
-
finished
.
<EOS>
And
when
I
have
steeped
him
to
the
lips
in
vice
and
depravity
;
when
I
have
led
him
to
the
commission
of
every
crime
;
when
there
is
neither
retreat
nor
advance
for
him
;
when
he
has
plundered
his
benefactor
,
and
broken
the
heart
of
his
mother
--
then
--
but
not
till
then
,
I
will
consign
him
to
the
fate
to
which
I
consigned
his
father
.
<EOS>
This
I
have
sworn
to
do
--
this
I
will
do
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
unless
your
skull
's
bullet
-
proof
,
"
cried
a
voice
at
his
elbow
;
and
,
as
the
words
were
uttered
,
a
pistol
was
snapped
at
his
head
,
which,--fortunately
or
unfortunately
,
as
the
reader
pleases,--only
burnt
the
priming
.
<EOS>
The
blaze
,
however
,
was
sufficient
to
reveal
to
the
thief
-
taker
the
features
of
his
intended
assassin
.
<EOS>
They
were
those
of
the
Irish
watchman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
Terry
O'Flaherty
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Jonathan
,
in
a
tone
that
betrayed
hot
the
slightest
discomposure
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Terry
O'Flaherty
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
shouting
after
the
Irishman
,
who
took
to
his
heels
as
soon
as
he
found
his
murderous
attempt
unsuccessful
;
"
you
may
run
,
but
you
'll
not
get
out
of
my
reach
.
<EOS>
I
'll
put
a
brace
of
dogs
on
your
track
,
who
'll
soon
hunt
you
down
.
<EOS>
You
shall
swing
for
this
after
next
sessions
,
or
my
name
's
not
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
I
told
you
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
added
,
turning
to
the
knight
,
and
chuckling
,
"
the
devil
never
deserts
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Conduct
me
to
your
dwelling
,
Sir
,
without
further
delay
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
sternly,--"to
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
boy
's
not
at
my
house
,
"
replied
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
other
,
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
a
place
we
call
the
Dark
House
at
Queenhithe
,
"
answered
Jonathan
,
"
a
sort
of
under
-
ground
tavern
or
night
-
cellar
,
close
to
the
river
-
side
,
and
frequented
by
the
crew
of
the
Dutch
skipper
,
to
whose
care
he
's
to
be
committed
.
<EOS>
You
need
have
no
apprehensions
about
him
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
He
's
safe
enough
now
.
<EOS>
I
left
him
in
charge
of
Quilt
Arnold
and
Rykhart
Van
Galgebrok
--
the
skipper
I
spoke
of
--
with
strict
orders
to
shoot
him
if
he
made
any
further
attempt
at
escape
;
and
they
're
not
lads
--
the
latter
especially
--
to
be
trifled
with
.
<EOS>
I
deemed
it
more
prudent
to
send
him
to
the
Dark
House
than
to
bring
him
here
,
in
case
of
any
search
after
him
by
his
adoptive
father
--
the
carpenter
Wood
.
<EOS>
If
you
choose
,
you
can
see
him
put
on
board
the
Zeeslang
yourself
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
But
,
perhaps
,
you
'll
first
accompany
me
to
my
dwelling
for
a
moment
,
that
we
may
arrange
our
accounts
before
we
start
.
<EOS>
I
've
a
few
necessary
directions
to
leave
with
my
people
,
to
put
'em
on
their
guard
against
the
chance
of
a
surprise
.
<EOS>
Suffer
me
to
precede
you
.
<EOS>
This
way
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
thief
-
taker
's
residence
was
a
large
dismal
-
looking
,
habitation
,
separated
from
the
street
by
a
flagged
court
-
yard
,
and
defended
from
general
approach
by
an
iron
railing
.
<EOS>
Even
in
the
daylight
,
it
had
a
sombre
and
suspicious
air
,
and
seemed
to
slink
back
from
the
adjoining
houses
,
as
if
afraid
of
their
society
.
<EOS>
In
the
obscurity
in
which
it
was
now
seen
,
it
looked
like
a
prison
,
and
,
indeed
,
it
was
Jonathan
's
fancy
to
make
it
resemble
one
as
much
as
possible
.
<EOS>
The
windows
were
grated
<EOS>
,
the
doors
barred
;
each
room
had
the
name
as
well
as
the
appearance
of
a
cell
;
and
the
very
porter
who
stood
at
the
gate
,
habited
like
a
jailer
,
with
his
huge
bunch
of
keys
at
his
girdle
,
his
forbidding
countenance
and
surly
demeanour
seemed
to
be
borrowed
from
Newgate
.
<EOS>
The
clanking
of
chains
,
the
grating
of
locks
,
and
the
rumbling
of
bolts
must
have
been
music
in
Jonathan
's
ears
,
so
much
pains
did
he
take
to
subject
himself
to
such
sounds
.
<EOS>
The
scanty
furniture
of
the
rooms
corresponded
with
their
dungeon
-
like
aspect
.
<EOS>
The
walls
were
bare
,
and
painted
in
stone
-
colour
;
the
floors
,
devoid
of
carpet
;
the
beds
,
of
hangings
;
the
windows
,
of
blinds
;
and
,
excepting
in
the
thief
-
taker
's
own
audience
-
chamber
,
there
was
not
a
chair
or
a
table
about
the
premises
;
the
place
of
these
conveniences
being
elsewhere
supplied
by
benches
,
and
deal
-
boards
laid
across
joint
-
stools
.
<EOS>
Great
stone
staircases
leading
no
one
knew
whither
,
and
long
gloomy
passages
,
impressed
the
occasional
visitor
with
the
idea
that
he
was
traversing
a
building
of
vast
extent
;
and
,
though
this
was
not
the
case
in
reality
,
the
deception
was
so
cleverly
contrived
that
it
seldom
failed
of
producing
the
intended
effect
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
any
one
entered
Mr.
Wild
's
dwelling
without
apprehension
,
or
quitted
it
without
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
More
strange
stories
were
told
of
it
than
of
any
other
house
in
London
.
<EOS>
The
garrets
were
said
to
be
tenanted
by
coiners
,
and
artists
employed
in
altering
watches
and
jewelry
;
the
cellars
to
be
used
as
a
magazine
for
stolen
goods
.
<EOS>
By
some
it
was
affirmed
that
a
subterranean
communication
existed
between
the
thief
-
taker
's
abode
and
Newgate
,
by
means
of
which
he
was
enabled
to
maintain
a
secret
correspondence
with
the
imprisoned
felons
:
by
others
,
that
an
under
-
ground
passage
led
to
extensive
vaults
,
where
such
malefactors
as
he
chose
to
screen
from
justice
might
lie
concealed
till
the
danger
was
blown
over
.
<EOS>
Nothing
,
in
short
,
was
too
extravagant
to
be
related
of
it
;
and
Jonathan
,
who
delighted
in
investing
himself
and
his
residence
with
mystery
,
encouraged
,
and
perhaps
originated
,
these
marvellous
tales
.
<EOS>
However
this
may
be
,
such
was
the
ill
report
of
the
place
that
few
passed
along
the
Old
Bailey
without
bestowing
a
glance
of
fearful
curiosity
at
its
dingy
walls
,
and
wondering
what
was
going
on
inside
them
;
while
fewer
still
,
of
those
who
paused
at
the
door
,
read
,
without
some
internal
trepidation
,
the
formidable
name
--
inscribed
in
large
letters
on
its
bright
brass
-
plate
--
of
JONATHAN
WILD
.
 
<EOS>
Arrived
at
his
habitation
,
Jonathan
knocked
in
a
peculiar
manner
at
the
door
,
which
was
instantly
opened
by
the
grim
-
visaged
porter
just
alluded
to
.
<EOS>
No
sooner
had
Trenchard
crossed
the
threshold
than
a
fierce
barking
was
heard
at
the
farther
extremity
of
the
passage
,
and
,
the
next
moment
,
a
couple
of
mastiffs
of
the
largest
size
rushed
furiously
towards
him
.
<EOS>
The
knight
stood
upon
his
defence
;
but
he
would
unquestionably
have
been
torn
in
pieces
by
the
savage
hounds
,
if
a
shower
of
oaths
,
seconded
by
a
vigorous
application
of
kicks
and
blows
from
their
master
,
had
not
driven
them
growling
off
.
<EOS>
Apologizing
to
Sir
Rowland
for
this
unpleasant
reception
,
and
swearing
lustily
at
his
servant
for
occasioning
it
by
leaving
the
dogs
at
liberty
,
Jonathan
ordered
the
man
to
light
them
to
the
audience
-
room
.
<EOS>
The
command
was
sullenly
obeyed
,
for
the
fellow
did
not
appear
to
relish
the
rating
.
<EOS>
Ascending
the
stairs
,
and
conducting
them
along
a
sombre
gallery
,
in
which
Trenchard
noticed
that
every
door
was
painted
black
,
and
numbered
,
he
stopped
at
the
entrance
of
a
chamber
;
and
,
selecting
a
key
from
the
bunch
at
his
girdle
,
unlocked
it
.
<EOS>
Following
his
guide
,
Sir
Rowland
found
himself
in
a
large
and
lofty
apartment
,
the
extent
of
which
he
could
not
entirely
discern
until
lights
were
set
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
He
then
looked
around
him
with
some
curiosity
;
and
,
as
the
thief
-
taker
was
occupied
in
giving
directions
to
his
attendant
in
an
undertone
,
ample
leisure
was
allowed
him
for
investigation
.
<EOS>
At
the
first
glance
,
he
imagined
he
must
have
stumbled
upon
a
museum
of
rarities
,
there
were
so
many
glass
-
cases
,
so
many
open
cabinets
,
ranged
against
the
walls
;
but
the
next
convinced
him
that
if
Jonathan
was
a
virtuoso
,
his
tastes
did
not
run
in
the
ordinary
channels
.
<EOS>
Trenchard
was
tempted
to
examine
the
contents
of
some
of
these
cases
,
but
a
closer
inspection
made
him
recoil
from
them
in
disgust
.
<EOS>
In
the
one
he
approached
was
gathered
together
a
vast
assortment
of
weapons
,
each
of
which
,
as
appeared
from
the
ticket
attached
to
it
,
had
been
used
as
an
instrument
of
destruction
.
<EOS>
On
this
side
was
a
razor
with
which
a
son
had
murdered
his
father
;
the
blade
notched
,
the
haft
crusted
with
blood
:
on
that
,
a
bar
of
iron
,
bent
,
and
partly
broken
,
with
which
a
husband
had
beaten
out
his
wife
's
brains
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
not
,
however
,
our
intention
to
furnish
a
complete
catalogue
of
these
curiosities
,
we
shall
merely
mention
that
in
front
of
them
lay
a
large
and
sharp
knife
,
once
the
property
of
the
public
executioner
,
and
used
by
him
to
dissever
the
limbs
of
those
condemned
to
death
for
high
-
treason
;
together
with
an
immense
two
-
pronged
flesh
-
fork
,
likewise
employed
by
the
same
terrible
functionary
to
plunge
the
quarters
of
his
victims
in
the
caldrons
of
boiling
tar
and
oil
.
<EOS>
Every
gibbet
at
Tyburn
and
Hounslow
appeared
to
have
been
plundered
of
its
charnel
spoil
to
enrich
the
adjoining
cabinet
,
so
well
was
it
stored
with
skulls
and
bones
,
all
purporting
to
be
the
relics
of
highwaymen
famous
in
their
day
.
<EOS>
Halters
,
each
of
which
had
fulfilled
its
destiny
,
formed
the
attraction
of
the
next
compartment
;
while
a
fourth
was
occupied
by
an
array
of
implements
of
housebreaking
almost
innumerable
,
and
utterly
indescribable
.
<EOS>
All
these
interesting
objects
were
carefully
arranged
,
classed
,
and
,
as
we
have
said
,
labelled
by
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
From
this
singular
collection
Trenchard
turned
to
regard
its
possessor
,
who
was
standing
at
a
little
distance
from
him
,
still
engaged
in
earnest
discourse
with
his
attendant
,
and
,
as
he
contemplated
his
ruthless
countenance
,
on
which
duplicity
and
malignity
had
set
their
strongest
seals
,
he
could
not
help
calling
to
mind
all
he
had
heard
of
Jonathan
's
perfidiousness
to
his
employers
,
and
deeply
regretting
that
he
had
placed
himself
in
the
power
of
so
unscrupulous
a
miscreant
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
,
at
this
time
,
was
on
the
high
-
road
to
the
greatness
which
he
subsequently
,
and
not
long
afterwards
,
obtained
.
<EOS>
He
was
fast
rising
to
an
eminence
that
no
one
of
his
nefarious
profession
ever
reached
before
him
,
nor
,
it
is
to
be
hoped
,
will
ever
reach
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
Napoleon
of
knavery
,
and
established
an
uncontrolled
empire
over
all
the
practitioners
of
crime
.
<EOS>
This
was
no
light
conquest
;
nor
was
it
a
government
easily
maintained
.
<EOS>
Resolution
,
severity
,
subtlety
,
were
required
for
it
;
and
these
were
qualities
which
Jonathan
possessed
in
an
extraordinary
degree
.
<EOS>
The
danger
or
difficulty
of
an
exploit
never
appalled
him
.
<EOS>
What
his
head
conceived
his
hand
executed
.
<EOS>
Professing
to
stand
between
the
robber
and
the
robbed
,
he
himself
plundered
both
.
<EOS>
He
<EOS>
it
was
who
formed
the
grand
design
of
a
robber
corporation
,
of
which
he
should
be
the
sole
head
and
director
,
with
the
right
of
delivering
those
who
concealed
their
booty
,
or
refused
to
share
it
with
him
,
to
the
gallows
.
<EOS>
He
divided
London
into
districts
;
appointed
a
gang
to
each
district
;
and
a
leader
to
each
gang
,
whom
he
held
responsible
to
himself
.
<EOS>
The
country
was
partitioned
in
a
similar
manner
.
<EOS>
Those
whom
he
retained
about
his
person
,
or
placed
in
offices
of
trust
,
were
for
the
most
part
convicted
felons
,
who
,
having
returned
from
transportation
before
their
term
had
expired
,
constituted
,
in
his
opinion
,
the
safest
agents
,
inasmuch
as
they
could
neither
be
legal
evidences
against
him
,
nor
withhold
any
portion
of
the
spoil
of
which
he
chose
to
deprive
them
.
<EOS>
But
the
crowning
glory
of
Jonathan
,
that
which
raised
him
above
all
his
predecessors
in
iniquity
,
and
clothed
this
name
with
undying
notoriety
--
was
to
come
.
<EOS>
When
in
the
plenitude
of
his
power
,
he
commenced
a
terrible
trade
,
till
then
unknown
--
namely
,
a
traffic
in
human
blood
.
<EOS>
This
he
carried
on
by
procuring
witnesses
to
swear
away
the
lives
of
those
persons
who
had
incurred
his
displeasure
,
or
whom
it
might
be
necessary
to
remove
.
 
<EOS>
No
wonder
that
Trenchard
,
as
he
gazed
at
this
fearful
being
,
should
have
some
misgivings
cross
him
.
 
<EOS>
Apparently
,
Jonathan
perceived
he
was
an
object
of
scrutiny
;
for
,
hastily
dismissing
his
attendant
,
he
walked
towards
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
,
you
're
admiring
my
cabinet
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
remarked
,
with
a
sinister
smile
;
"
it
_
is
_
generally
admired
;
and
,
sometimes
by
parties
who
afterwards
contribute
to
the
collection
<EOS>
themselves,--ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
This
skull
,
"
he
added
,
pointing
to
a
fragment
of
mortality
in
the
case
beside
them
,
"
once
belonged
to
Tom
Sheppard
,
the
father
of
the
lad
I
spoke
of
just
now
.
<EOS>
In
the
next
box
hangs
the
rope
by
which
he
suffered
.
<EOS>
When
I
've
placed
another
skull
and
another
halter
beside
them
,
I
shall
be
contented
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
<EOS>
To
business
,
Sir
!
"
said
the
knight
,
with
a
look
of
abhorrence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
to
business
,
"
returned
Jonathan
,
grinning
,
"
the
sooner
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
the
sum
you
bargained
for
,
"
rejoined
Trenchard
,
flinging
a
pocket
-
book
on
the
table
;
"
count
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
's
eyes
glistened
as
he
told
over
the
notes
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
given
me
more
than
the
amount
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
said
,
after
he
had
twice
counted
them
,
"
or
I
've
missed
my
reckoning
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
hundred
pounds
too
much
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
it
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
haughtily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
place
it
to
your
account
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
answered
the
thief
-
taker
,
smiling
significantly
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
shall
we
proceed
to
Queenhithe
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
cried
the
other
,
taking
a
chair
,
"
a
word
with
you
,
Mr.
Wild
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
many
as
you
please
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
resuming
his
seat
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
quite
at
your
disposal
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
question
to
propose
to
you
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
"
relating
to--
"
and
he
hesitated
.
 
<EOS>
"
Relating
to
the
father
of
the
boy
--
Thames
Darrell
,
"
supplied
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
I
guessed
what
was
coming
.
<EOS>
You
desire
to
know
who
he
was
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
Well
,
you
_
shall
_
know
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Without
further
fee
?
"
inquired
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
,
"
answered
Jonathan
,
drily
.
<EOS>
"
A
secret
is
too
valuable
a
commodity
to
be
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
But
I
said
I
would
n't
drive
a
hard
bargain
with
you
,
and
I
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
We
are
alone
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
added
,
snuffing
the
candles
,
glancing
cautiously
around
,
and
lowering
his
tone
,
"
and
what
you
confide
to
me
<EOS>
shall
never
transpire,--at
least
to
your
disadvantage
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
at
a
loss
to
understand
you
Sir
,
"
,
said
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
make
myself
intelligible
before
I
've
done
,
"
rejoined
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
I
need
not
remind
you
,
Sir
Rowland
,
that
I
am
aware
you
are
deeply
implicated
in
the
Jacobite
plot
which
is
now
known
to
be
hatching
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
ejaculated
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
therefore
,
"
pursued
Jonathan
,
"
you
are
acquainted
with
all
the
leaders
of
the
proposed
insurrection,--nay
,
must
be
in
correspondence
with
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
right
have
you
to
suppose
this
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Trenchard
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
a
moment
's
patience
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
returned
Wild
;
"
and
you
shall
hear
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
furnish
me
with
a
list
of
these
rebels
,
and
with
proofs
of
their
treason
,
I
will
not
only
insure
your
safety
,
but
will
acquaint
you
with
the
real
name
and
rank
of
your
sister
<EOS>
Aliva
's
husband
,
as
well
as
with
some
particulars
which
will
never
otherwise
reach
your
ears
,
concerning
your
lost
sister
,
Constance
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
sister
Constance
!
"
echoed
the
knight
;
"
what
of
her
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
agree
to
my
proposal
,
then
?
"
said
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
take
me
for
as
great
a
villain
as
yourself
,
Sir
?
"
said
the
knight
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
took
you
for
one
who
would
n't
hesitate
to
avail
himself
of
any
advantage
chance
might
throw
in
his
way
,
"
returned
the
thief
-
taker
,
coldly
.
<EOS>
"
I
find
I
was
in
error
.
<EOS>
No
matter
.
<EOS>
A
time
_
may
_
<EOS>
come,--and
<EOS>
that
ere
<EOS>
long,--when
you
will
be
glad
to
purchase
my
secrets
,
and
your
own
safety
,
at
a
dearer
price
than
the
heads
of
your
companions
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
ready
?
"
said
Trenchard
,
striding
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
following
him
,
"
and
so
,
"
he
added
in
an
undertone
,
"
are
your
captors
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
A
moment
afterwards
,
they
quitted
the
house
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XVII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Night
-
Cellar
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
few
minutes
'
rapid
walking
,
during
which
neither
party
uttered
a
word
,
Jonathan
Wild
and
his
companion
had
passed
Saint
Paul
's
,
dived
down
a
thoroughfare
on
the
right
,
and
reached
Thames
Street
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
period
of
this
history
,
the
main
streets
of
the
metropolis
were
but
imperfectly
lighted
,
while
the
less
-
frequented
avenues
were
left
in
total
obscurity
;
but
,
even
at
the
present
time
,
the
maze
of
courts
and
alleys
into
which
Wild
now
plunged
,
would
have
perplexed
any
one
,
not
familiar
with
their
intricacies
,
to
thread
them
on
a
dark
night
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
however
,
was
well
acquainted
with
the
road
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
was
his
boast
that
he
could
find
his
way
through
any
part
of
London
blindfolded
;
and
by
this
time
,
it
would
seem
,
he
had
nearly
arrived
at
his
destination
;
for
,
grasping
his
companion
's
arm
,
he
led
him
along
a
narrow
entry
which
did
not
appear
to
have
an
outlet
,
and
came
to
a
halt
.
<EOS>
Cautioning
the
knight
,
if
he
valued
his
neck
,
to
tread
carefully
,
Jonathan
then
descended
a
steep
flight
of
steps
;
and
,
having
reached
the
bottom
in
safety
,
he
pushed
open
a
door
,
that
swung
back
on
its
hinges
as
soon
as
it
had
admitted
him
;
and
,
followed
by
Trenchard
,
entered
the
night
-
cellar
.
 
<EOS>
The
vault
,
in
which
Sir
Rowland
found
himself
,
resembled
in
some
measure
the
cabin
of
a
ship
.
<EOS>
It
was
long
and
narrow
,
with
a
ceiling
supported
by
huge
uncovered
rafters
,
and
so
low
as
scarcely
to
allow
a
tall
man
like
himself
to
stand
erect
beneath
it
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
heat
of
the
season,--which
was
not
,
however
,
found
particularly
inconvenient
in
this
subterranean
region,--a
large
heaped
-
up
fire
blazed
ruddily
in
one
corner
,
and
lighted
up
a
circle
of
as
villanous
countenances
as
ever
flame
shone
upon
.
 
<EOS>
The
guests
congregated
within
the
night
-
cellar
were
,
in
fact
,
little
better
than
thieves
;
but
thieves
who
confined
their
depredations
almost
exclusively
to
the
vessels
lying
in
the
pool
and
docks
of
the
river
.
<EOS>
They
had
as
many
designations
as
grades
.
<EOS>
There
were
game
watermen
and
game
lightermen
,
heavy
horsemen
and
light
horsemen
,
scuffle
-
hunters
,
and
long
-
apron
men
,
lumpers
,
journeymen
coopers
,
mud
-
larks
,
badgers
,
and
ratcatchers
--
a
race
of
dangerous
vermin
recently
,
in
a
great
measure
,
extirpated
by
the
vigilance
of
the
Thames
Police
,
but
at
this
period
flourishing
in
vast
numbers
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
plunderers
,
there
were
others
with
whom
the
disposal
of
their
pillage
necessarily
brought
them
into
contact
,
and
who
seldom
failed
to
attend
them
during
their
hours
of
relaxation
and
festivity;--to
wit
,
dealers
in
junk
,
old
rags
,
and
marine
stores
,
purchasers
of
prize
-
money
,
crimps
,
and
Jew
receivers
.
<EOS>
The
latter
formed
by
far
the
most
knavish
-
looking
and
unprepossessing
portion
of
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
One
or
two
of
the
tables
were
occupied
by
groups
of
fat
frowzy
women
in
flat
caps
,
with
rings
on
their
thumbs
,
and
baskets
by
their
sides
;
and
no
one
who
had
listened
for
a
single
moment
to
their
coarse
language
and
violent
abuse
of
each
other
,
would
require
to
be
told
they
were
fish
-
wives
from
Billingsgate
.
 
<EOS>
The
present
divinity
of
the
cellar
was
a
comely
middle
-
aged
dame
,
almost
as
stout
,
and
quite
as
shrill
-
voiced
,
as
the
Billingsgate
fish
-
wives
above
-
mentioned
<EOS>
,
Mrs.
Spurling
,
for
so
was
she
named
,
had
a
warm
nut
-
brown
complexion
,
almost
as
dark
as
a
Creole
;
and
a
moustache
on
her
upper
lip
,
that
would
have
done
no
discredit
to
the
oldest
dragoon
in
the
King
's
service
.
<EOS>
This
lady
was
singularly
lucky
in
her
matrimonial
connections
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
married
four
times
:
three
of
her
husbands
died
of
hempen
fevers
;
and
the
fourth
,
having
been
twice
condemned
,
was
saved
from
the
noose
by
Jonathan
Wild
,
who
not
only
managed
to
bring
him
off
,
but
to
obtain
for
him
the
situation
of
under
-
turnkey
in
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
appearance
of
the
thief
-
taker
,
Mrs.
Spurling
was
standing
near
the
fire
superintending
some
culinary
preparation
;
but
she
no
sooner
perceived
him
,
than
hastily
quitting
her
occupation
,
she
elbowed
a
way
for
him
and
the
knight
through
the
crowd
,
and
ushered
them
,
with
much
ceremony
,
into
an
inner
room
,
where
they
found
the
objects
of
their
search
,
Quilt
Arnold
and
Rykhart
Van
Galgebrok
,
seated
at
a
small
table
,
quietly
smoking
.
<EOS>
This
service
rendered
,
without
waiting
for
any
farther
order
,
she
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
Both
the
janizary
and
the
skipper
arose
as
the
others
entered
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
gentleman
,
"
observed
Jonathan
,
introducing
Trenchard
to
the
Hollander
,
"
<EOS>
who
is
about
to
intrust
his
young
relation
to
your
care
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
De
gentleman
may
rely
on
my
showing
his
relation
all
de
attention
in
my
power
,
"
replied
Van
Galgebrok
,
bowing
profoundly
to
the
knight
;
"
but
if
any
unforseen
accident
--
such
as
a
slip
overboard
--
should
befal
de
jonker
on
de
voyage
,
he
mushn't
lay
de
fault
entirely
on
my
shoulders
--
haw
!
<EOS>
haw
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Sir
Rowland
,
glancing
uneasily
around
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
see
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
De
jonker
.
<EOS>
He
's
here
,
"
returned
the
skipper
,
pointing
significantly
downwards
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
him
out
,
Quilt
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
pushed
aside
the
table
,
and
the
janizary
stooping
down
,
undrew
a
bolt
and
opened
a
trap
-
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
out
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Quilt
,
looking
into
the
aperture
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
wanted
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
as
no
answer
was
returned
,
he
trust
his
arm
up
to
the
shoulder
into
the
hole
,
and
with
some
little
difficulty
and
exertion
of
strength
,
drew
forth
Thames
Darrell
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
boy
,
whose
hands
were
pinioned
behind
him
,
looked
very
pale
,
but
neither
trembled
,
nor
exhibited
any
other
symptom
of
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
you
come
out
when
I
called
you
,
you
young
dog
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Quilt
in
a
savage
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
I
knew
what
you
wanted
me
for
!
"
answered
Thames
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
you
did
,
did
you
?
"
said
the
janizary
.
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
suppose
we
mean
to
do
with
you
,
eh
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
mean
to
kill
me
,
"
replied
Thames
,
"
by
my
cruel
uncle
's
command
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
there
he
stands
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
as
his
eye
fell
for
the
first
time
upon
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
my
mother
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
regarding
the
knight
with
a
searching
glance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
mother
is
dead
,
"
interposed
Wild
,
scowling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
"
echoed
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
--
no
!
<EOS>
You
say
this
to
terrify
me
--
to
try
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
believe
you
.
<EOS>
Inhuman
as
he
is
,
he
would
not
kill
her
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
,
Sir
,
"
he
added
,
advancing
towards
the
knight
,
"
tell
me
has
this
man
spoken
falsely?--Tell
<EOS>
me
my
mother
is
alive
,
and
do
what
you
please
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
so
,
and
have
done
with
him
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
observed
Jonathan
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
the
truth
,
I
implore
you
,
"
cried
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
alive
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
,
"
replied
Trenchard
,
overcome
by
conflicting
emotions
,
and
unable
to
endure
the
boy
's
agonized
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
answered
?
"
said
Jonathan
,
with
a
grin
worthy
of
a
demon
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
mother!--my
poor
mother
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Thames
,
falling
on
his
knees
,
and
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
never
see
that
sweet
face
<EOS>
again,--never
feel
the
pressure
of
those
kind
hands
more
--
nor
listen
to
that
gentle
voice
!
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
yes
,
we
shall
meet
again
in
Heaven
,
where
I
shall
speedily
join
you
.
<EOS>
Now
then
,
"
he
added
more
calmly
,
"
I
am
ready
to
die
.
<EOS>
The
only
mercy
you
can
show
me
is
to
kill
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
we
wo
n't
even
show
you
that
mercy
,
"
retorted
the
thief
-
taker
brutally
.
"
<EOS>
So
get
up
,
and
leave
off
whimpering
.
<EOS>
Your
time
is
n't
come
yet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wild
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
"
I
shall
proceed
no
further
in
this
business
.
<EOS>
Set
the
boy
free
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
disobey
you
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
the
thief
-
taker
,
"
you
'll
thank
me
for
it
hereafter
.
<EOS>
Gag
him
,
"
he
added
,
pushing
Thames
rudely
toward
Quilt
Arnold
,
"
and
convey
him
to
the
boat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
word
,
"
cried
the
boy
,
as
the
janizary
was
preparing
to
obey
his
master
's
orders
.
<EOS>
"
What
has
become
of
Jack
Sheppard
?
"
 
"
Devil
knows
!
"
<EOS>
answered
Quilt
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
believe
he
's
in
the
hands
of
Blueskin
,
so
there
's
no
doubt
he
'll
soon
be
on
the
high
-
road
to
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
Jack
!
"
sighed
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
gag
me
,
"
he
added
,
"
I
'll
not
cry
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
wo
n't
trust
you
,
my
youngster
,
"
answered
the
janizary
.
<EOS>
And
,
thrusting
a
piece
of
iron
into
his
mouth
,
he
forced
him
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
witnessed
these
proceedings
like
one
stupified
.
<EOS>
He
neither
attempted
to
prevent
his
nephew
's
departure
,
nor
to
follow
him
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
kept
his
keen
eye
fixed
upon
him
,
as
he
addressed
himself
for
a
moment
to
the
Hollander
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
case
of
watches
on
board
?
"
he
asked
in
an
under
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
,
"
replied
the
skipper
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
the
rings
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
.
<EOS>
You
must
dispose
of
the
goldsmith
's
note
<EOS>
I
gave
you
yesterday
,
as
soon
as
you
arrive
at
Rotterdam
.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
advertised
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
De
duivel
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Van
Galgebrok
,
"
Very
well
.
<EOS>
It
shall
be
done
as
you
direct
.
<EOS>
But
about
dat
jonker
,
"
he
continued
,
lowering
his
voice
;
"
have
you
anything
to
add
consarnin
'
him
?
<EOS>
It
's
almosht
a
pity
to
put
him
onder
de
water
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
sloop
ready
to
sail
?
"
asked
Wild
,
without
noticing
the
skipper
's
remark
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
,
"
answered
Van
;
"
at
a
minut
's
nodish
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
are
your
despatches
,
"
said
Jonathan
with
a
significant
look
,
and
giving
him
a
sealed
packet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Open
them
when
you
get
on
board
--
not
before
,
and
act
as
they
direct
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
ondershtand
,
"
replied
the
skipper
,
putting
his
finger
to
his
nose
;
"
it
shall
be
done
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Rowland
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
turning
to
the
knight
,
"
will
it
please
you
to
remain
here
till
I
return
,
or
will
you
accompany
us
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
with
you
,
"
answered
Trenchard
,
who
,
by
this
time
,
had
regained
his
composure
,
and
with
it
all
his
relentlessness
of
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
then
,
"
said
Wild
,
marching
towards
the
door
,
"
we
've
no
time
to
lose
.
"
 
<EOS>
Quitting
the
night
-
cellar
,
the
trio
soon
arrived
at
the
riverside
.
<EOS>
Quilt
Arnold
was
stationed
at
the
stair
-
head
,
near
which
the
boat
containing
the
captive
boy
was
moored
.
<EOS>
A
few
words
passed
between
him
and
the
thief
-
taker
as
the
latter
came
up
;
after
which
,
all
the
party
--
with
the
exception
of
Quilt
,
who
was
left
on
shore
--
embarked
within
the
wherry
,
which
was
pushed
from
the
strand
and
rowed
swiftly
along
the
stream
--
for
the
tide
was
in
its
favour
--
by
a
couple
of
watermen
.
<EOS>
Though
scarcely
two
hours
past
midnight
,
it
was
perfectly
light
.
<EOS>
The
moon
had
arisen
,
and
everything
could
be
as
plainly
distinguished
as
during
the
day
.
<EOS>
A
thin
mist
lay
on
the
river
,
giving
the
few
craft
moving
about
in
it
a
ghostly
look
.
<EOS>
As
they
approached
London
Bridge
,
the
thief
-
taker
whispered
Van
Galgebrok
,
who
acted
as
steersman
,
to
make
for
a
particular
arch
--
near
the
Surrey
shore
.
<EOS>
The
skipper
obeyed
,
and
in
another
moment
,
they
swept
through
the
narrow
lock
.
<EOS>
While
the
watermen
were
contending
with
the
eddies
occasioned
by
the
fall
below
the
bridge
,
Jonathan
observed
a
perceptible
shudder
run
through
Trenchard
's
frame
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
remember
that
starling
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
said
maliciously
,
"
and
what
occurred
on
it
,
twelve
years
ago
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Too
well
,
"
answered
the
knight
,
frowning
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
is
that
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
pointing
to
a
dark
object
floating
near
them
amid
the
boiling
waves
,
and
which
presented
a
frightful
resemblance
to
a
human
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
,
"
returned
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
And
,
stretching
out
his
hand
,
he
lifted
the
dark
object
from
the
flood
.
 
<EOS>
It
proved
to
be
a
human
head
,
though
with
scarcely
a
vestige
of
the
features
remaining
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
patches
of
flesh
adhered
to
the
bones
,
and
the
dank
dripping
hair
hanging
about
what
had
once
been
the
face
,
gave
it
a
ghastly
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
skull
of
a
_
rebel
_
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
with
marked
emphasis
on
the
word
,
"
blown
by
the
wind
from
a
spike
on
the
bridge
above
us
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whose
brainless
head
it
may
be
,
but
it
'll
do
for
my
collection
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
tossed
it
carelessly
into
the
bottom
of
the
boat
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
occurence
,
not
a
word
was
exchanged
between
them
until
they
came
in
sight
of
the
sloop
,
which
was
lying
at
anchor
off
Wapping
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
her
side
,
it
was
soon
evident
,
from
the
throng
of
seamen
in
Dutch
dresses
that
displayed
themselves
,
that
her
crew
were
on
the
alert
,
and
a
rope
having
been
thrown
down
to
the
skipper
,
he
speedily
hoisted
himself
on
deck
.
<EOS>
Preparations
were
next
made
for
taking
Thames
on
board
.
<EOS>
Raising
him
in
his
arms
,
Jonathan
passed
the
rope
round
his
body
,
and
in
this
way
the
poor
boy
was
drawn
up
without
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
swinging
in
mid
air
,
Thames
regarded
his
uncle
with
a
stern
look
,
and
cried
in
a
menacing
voice
,
"
We
shall
meet
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in
this
world
,
"
returned
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Weigh
anchor
,
Van
!
"
<EOS>
he
shouted
to
the
skipper
,
"
and
consult
your
despatches
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ja
--
ja
,
"
returned
the
Hollander
.
<EOS>
And
catching
hold
of
Thames
,
he
quitted
the
deck
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards
,
he
re
-
appeared
with
the
information
that
the
captive
was
safe
below
;
and
giving
the
necessary
directions
to
his
crew
,
before
many
minutes
had
elapsed
,
the
Zeeslang
spread
her
canvass
to
the
first
breeze
of
morning
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
thief
-
taker
's
command
,
the
boat
was
then
rowed
toward
a
muddy
inlet
,
which
has
received
in
more
recent
times
the
name
of
Execution
Dock
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
reached
this
spot
,
Wild
sprang
ashore
,
and
was
joined
by
several
persons,--among
whom
was
Quilt
Arnold
,
leading
a
horse
by
the
bridle,--he
hastened
down
the
stairs
to
meet
him
.
<EOS>
A
coach
was
also
in
attendance
,
at
a
little
distance
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
,
who
had
continued
absorbed
in
thought
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
sloop
,
as
she
made
her
way
slowly
down
the
river
,
disembarked
more
leisurely
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
length
I
am
my
own
master
,
"
murmured
the
knight
,
as
his
foot
touched
the
strand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
returned
Jonathan
;
"
you
are
my
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Trenchard
,
starting
back
and
drawing
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
arrested
for
high
treason
,
"
rejoined
Wild
,
presenting
a
pistol
at
his
head
,
while
he
drew
forth
a
parchment,--"here
<EOS>
is
my
warrant
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Traitor
!
"
cried
Sir
Rowland--"damned
--
double
-
dyed
traitor
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Away
with
him
,
"
vociferated
Jonathan
to
his
myrmidons
,
who
,
having
surrounded
Trenchard
,
hurried
him
off
to
the
coach
before
he
could
utter
another
word,--"first
to
Mr.
Walpole
,
and
then
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
Quilt
,
"
he
continued
,
addressing
the
janizary
,
who
approached
him
with
the
horse
,
"
fly
to
St.
Giles
's
round
-
house
,
and
if
,
through
the
agency
of
that
treacherous
scoundrel
,
Terry
O'Flaherty
,
whom
I
've
put
in
my
Black
List
,
old
Wood
should
have
found
his
way
there
,
and
have
been
detained
by
Sharpies
as
I
directed
,
you
may
release
him
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
how
soon
he
learns
that
he
has
lost
his
adopted
son
.
<EOS>
When
I
've
escorted
you
proud
fool
to
his
new
quarters
,
I
'll
proceed
to
the
Mint
and
look
after
Jack
Sheppard
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
mounted
his
steed
and
rode
off
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XVIII
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
broke
out
of
the
Cage
at
Willesden
.
  
<EOS>
The
heart
-
piercing
scream
uttered
by
Mrs.
Sheppard
after
the
commission
of
the
robbery
in
Willesden
church
was
productive
of
unfortunate
consequences
to
her
son
.
<EOS>
Luckily
,
she
was
bereft
of
consciousness
,
and
was
thus
spared
the
additional
misery
of
witnessing
what
afterwards
befell
him
.
<EOS>
Startled
by
the
cry
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
the
attention
of
the
whole
congregation
was
drawn
towards
the
quarter
whence
it
proceeded
.
<EOS>
Amongst
others
,
a
person
near
the
door
,
roused
by
the
shriek
,
observed
a
man
make
his
exit
with
the
utmost
precipitation
.
<EOS>
A
boy
attempted
to
follow
;
but
as
the
suspicions
of
the
lookers
-
on
were
roused
by
the
previous
circumstances
,
the
younger
fugitive
was
seized
and
detained
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Mr.
Kneebone
,
having
been
alarmed
by
something
in
the
widow
's
look
before
her
feelings
found
vent
in
the
manner
above
described
,
thrust
his
hand
instinctively
into
his
coat
in
search
of
his
pocket
-
book,--about
the
security
of
which
,
as
it
contained
several
letters
and
documents
implicating
himself
and
others
in
the
Jacobite
plot
,
he
was
,
not
unnaturally
,
<EOS>
solicitous,--and
finding
it
gone
<EOS>
,
he
felt
certain
he
had
been
robbed
.
<EOS>
Turning
quickly
round
,
in
the
hope
of
discovering
the
thief
,
he
was
no
less
surprised
than
distressed
--
<EOS>
for
in
spite
of
his
faults
,
the
woollen
-
draper
was
a
good
-
natured
fellow
--
to
perceive
Jack
Sheppard
in
custody
.
<EOS>
The
truth
at
once
flashed
across
his
mind
.
<EOS>
This
,
then
,
was
the
cause
of
the
widow
's
wild
inexplicable
look,--of
<EOS>
her
sudden
shriek
!
<EOS>
Explaining
his
suspicious
in
a
whisper
to
Jack
's
captor
,
who
proved
to
be
a
church
-
warden
and
a
constable
,
by
name
John
Dump,--Mr
.
<EOS>
Kneebone
begged
him
to
take
the
prisoner
into
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
Dump
instantly
complied
,
and
as
soon
as
Jack
was
removed
from
the
sacred
edifice
,
his
person
was
searched
from
head
to
foot
--
but
without
success
.
<EOS>
Jack
submitted
to
this
scrutiny
with
a
very
bad
grace
,
and
vehemently
protested
his
innocence
.
<EOS>
In
vain
did
the
woollen
-
draper
offer
to
set
him
free
if
he
would
restore
the
stolen
article
,
or
give
up
his
associate
,
to
whom
it
was
supposed
he
might
have
handed
it
.
<EOS>
He
answered
with
the
greatest
assurance
,
that
he
knew
nothing
whatever
of
the
matter
--
had
seen
no
pocket
-
book
,
and
no
associate
to
give
up
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
content
himself
with
declaring
his
guiltlessness
of
the
crime
imputed
to
him
,
but
began
in
his
turn
to
menace
his
captor
and
accuser
,
loading
the
latter
with
the
bitterest
upbraidings
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
churchyard
was
crowded
with
spectators
,
some
of
whom
dispersed
in
different
directions
in
quest
of
the
other
robber
.
<EOS>
But
all
that
could
be
ascertained
in
the
village
was
,
that
a
man
had
ridden
off
a
short
time
before
in
the
direction
of
London
.
<EOS>
Of
this
man
Kneebone
resolved
to
go
in
pursuit
;
and
leaving
Jack
in
charge
of
the
constable
,
he
proceeded
to
the
small
inn,--which
bore
then
,
as
it
bears
now
,
the
name
of
the
Six
Bells,--where
,
summoning
the
hostler
,
his
steed
was
instantly
brought
him
,
and
,
springing
on
its
back
,
he
rode
away
at
full
speed
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
after
a
consultation
between
Mr.
Dump
and
the
village
authorities
,
it
was
agreed
to
lock
up
the
prisoner
in
the
cage
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
conveyed
thither
,
an
incident
occurred
that
produced
a
considerable
impression
on
the
feelings
of
the
youthful
offender
.
<EOS>
Just
as
they
reached
the
eastern
outlet
of
the
churchyard
--
where
the
tall
elms
cast
a
pleasant
shade
over
the
rustic
graves
--
a
momentary
stoppage
took
place
.
<EOS>
At
this
gate
two
paths
meet
.
<EOS>
Down
that
on
the
right
the
young
culprit
was
dragged
--
along
that
on
the
left
a
fainting
woman
was
borne
in
the
arms
of
several
females
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
mother
,
and
as
he
gazed
on
her
pallid
features
and
motionless
frame
,
Jack
's
heart
severely
smote
him
.
<EOS>
He
urged
his
conductors
to
a
quicker
pace
to
get
out
of
sight
of
the
distressing
spectacle
,
and
even
felt
relieved
when
he
was
shut
out
from
it
and
the
execrations
of
the
mob
by
the
walls
of
the
little
prison
.
 
<EOS>
The
cage
at
Willesden
was
,
and
is
--
for
it
is
still
standing
--
<EOS>
a
small
round
building
about
eight
feet
high
,
with
a
pointed
tiled
roof
,
to
which
a
number
of
boards
,
inscribed
with
the
names
of
the
parish
officers
,
and
charged
with
a
multitude
of
admonitory
notices
to
vagrants
and
other
disorderly
persons
,
are
attached
.
<EOS>
Over
these
boards
the
two
arms
of
a
guide
-
post
serve
to
direct
the
way
-
farer
--
on
the
right
hand
to
the
neighbouring
villages
of
Neasdon
and
Kingsbury
,
and
on
the
left
to
the
Edgeware
Road
and
the
healthy
heights
of
Hampstead
.
<EOS>
The
cage
has
a
strong
door
,
with
an
iron
grating
at
the
top
,
and
further
secured
by
a
stout
bolt
and
padlock
.
<EOS>
It
is
picturesquely
situated
beneath
a
tree
on
the
high
road
,
not
far
from
the
little
hostel
before
mentioned
,
and
at
no
great
distance
from
the
church
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
time
after
he
was
locked
up
in
this
prison
<EOS>
Jack
continued
in
a
very
dejected
state
.
<EOS>
Deserted
by
his
older
companion
in
iniquity
,
and
instigator
to
crime
,
he
did
not
know
what
might
become
of
him
;
nor
,
as
we
have
observed
,
was
the
sad
spectacle
he
had
just
witnessed
,
without
effect
.
<EOS>
Though
within
the
last
two
days
he
had
committed
several
heinous
offences
,
and
one
of
a
darker
dye
than
any
with
which
the
reader
has
been
made
acquainted
,
his
breast
was
not
yet
so
callous
as
to
be
wholly
insensible
to
the
stings
of
conscience
.
<EOS>
Wearied
at
length
with
thinking
on
the
past
,
and
terrified
by
the
prospect
of
the
future
,
he
threw
himself
on
the
straw
with
which
the
cage
was
littered
,
and
endeavoured
to
compose
himself
to
slumber
.
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
,
it
was
late
in
the
day
;
but
though
he
heard
voices
outside
,
and
now
and
then
caught
a
glimpse
of
a
face
peeping
at
him
through
the
iron
grating
over
the
door
,
no
one
entered
the
prison
,
or
held
any
communication
with
him
.
<EOS>
Feeling
rather
exhausted
,
it
occurred
to
him
that
possibly
some
provisions
might
have
been
left
by
the
constable
;
and
,
looking
about
,
he
perceived
a
pitcher
of
water
and
a
small
brown
loaf
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
He
ate
of
the
bread
with
great
appetite
,
and
having
drunk
as
much
as
he
chose
of
the
water
,
poured
the
rest
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
His
hunger
satisfied
,
his
spirits
began
to
revive
,
and
with
this
change
of
mood
all
his
natural
audacity
returned
.
<EOS>
And
here
he
was
first
visited
by
that
genius
which
,
in
his
subsequent
career
,
prompted
him
to
so
many
bold
and
successful
attempts
.
<EOS>
Glancing
around
his
prison
,
he
began
to
think
it
possible
he
might
effect
an
escape
from
it
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
too
strong
,
and
too
well
secured
,
to
break
open,--the
walls
too
thick
:
but
the
ceiling,--if
he
could
reach
it
--
there
,
he
doubted
not
,
he
could
make
an
outlet
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
meditating
flight
in
this
way
,
and
tossing
about
on
the
straw
,
he
chanced
upon
an
old
broken
and
rusty
fork
.
<EOS>
Here
was
an
instrument
which
might
be
of
the
greatest
service
to
him
in
accomplishing
his
design
.
<EOS>
He
put
it
carefully
aside
,
resolved
to
defer
the
attempt
till
night
.
<EOS>
Time
wore
on
somewhat
slowly
with
the
prisoner
,
who
had
to
control
his
impatience
in
the
best
way
he
could
;
but
as
the
shades
of
evening
were
darkening
,
the
door
was
unlocked
,
and
Mr.
Dump
popped
his
head
into
the
cage
.
<EOS>
He
brought
another
small
loaf
,
and
a
can
with
which
he
replenished
the
pitcher
,
recommending
Jack
to
be
careful
,
as
he
would
get
nothing
further
till
morning
.
<EOS>
To
this
Jack
replied
,
that
he
should
be
perfectly
contented
,
provided
he
might
have
a
small
allowance
of
gin
.
<EOS>
The
latter
request
,
though
treated
with
supreme
contempt
by
Mr.
Dump
,
made
an
impression
on
some
one
outside
;
for
not
long
after
the
constable
departed
,
Jack
heard
a
tap
at
the
door
,
and
getting
up
at
the
summons
,
he
perceived
the
tube
of
a
pipe
inserted
between
the
bars
.
<EOS>
At
once
divining
the
meaning
of
this
ingenious
device
,
he
applied
his
mouth
to
the
tube
,
and
sucked
away
,
while
the
person
outside
poured
spirit
into
the
bowl
.
<EOS>
Having
drunk
as
much
as
he
thought
prudent
,
and
thanked
his
unknown
friend
for
his
attention
,
Jack
again
lay
down
on
the
straw
,
and
indulged
himself
with
another
nap
,
intending
to
get
up
as
soon
as
it
was
perfectly
dark
.
<EOS>
The
strong
potation
he
had
taken
,
combined
with
fatigue
and
anxiety
he
had
previously
undergone
,
made
him
oversleep
himself
,
and
when
he
awoke
it
was
just
beginning
to
grow
light
.
<EOS>
Cursing
himself
for
his
inertness
,
Jack
soon
shook
off
this
drowsiness
,
and
set
to
work
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
Availing
himself
of
certain
inequalities
in
the
door
,
he
soon
managed
to
climb
up
to
the
roof
;
and
securing
his
feet
against
a
slight
projection
in
the
wall
,
began
to
use
the
fork
with
great
effect
.
<EOS>
Before
many
minutes
elapsed
,
he
had
picked
a
large
hole
in
the
plaster
,
which
showered
down
in
a
cloud
of
dust
;
and
breaking
off
several
laths
,
caught
hold
of
a
beam
,
by
which
he
held
with
one
hand
,
until
with
the
other
he
succeeded
,
not
without
some
difficulty
,
in
forcing
out
one
of
the
tiles
.
<EOS>
The
rest
was
easy
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
more
he
had
made
a
breach
in
the
roof
wide
enough
to
allow
him
to
pass
through
.
<EOS>
Emerging
from
this
aperture
,
he
was
about
to
descend
,
when
he
was
alarmed
by
hearing
the
tramp
of
horses
'
feet
swiftly
approaching
,
and
had
only
time
to
hide
himself
behind
one
of
the
largest
sign
-
boards
before
alluded
to
when
two
horsemen
rode
up
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
passing
on
,
as
Jack
expected
,
these
persons
stopped
opposite
the
cage
,
when
one
of
them
,
as
he
judged
from
the
sound
,
for
he
did
not
dare
to
look
out
of
his
hiding
place
,
dismounted
.
<EOS>
A
noise
was
next
heard
,
as
if
some
instrument
were
applied
to
the
door
with
the
intent
to
force
it
open
,
and
Jack
's
fears
were
at
once
dispelled
,
At
first
,
he
had
imagined
they
were
officers
of
justice
,
come
to
convey
him
to
a
stronger
prison
:
but
the
voice
of
one
of
the
parties
,
which
he
recognised
,
convinced
him
they
were
his
friends
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
quick
,
Blueskin
,
and
be
cursed
to
you
!
"
was
growled
in
the
deep
tones
of
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
have
the
whole
village
upon
us
while
you
're
striking
the
jigger
.
<EOS>
Use
the
gilt
,
man
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
need
of
picklock
or
crow
-
bar
,
here
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
cried
Jack
,
placing
his
hat
on
the
right
arm
of
the
guide
-
post
,
and
leaning
over
the
board
,
"
I
've
done
the
trick
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
devil
's
this
?
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Jonathan
,
looking
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
broken
out
of
the
cage
,
Jack
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Something
like
it
,
"
replied
the
lad
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"
cried
the
thief
-
taker
approvingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
that
beats
all
I
ever
heard
of
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
are
you
really
there
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
'm
here
,
"
answered
Jack
,
leaping
down
.
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
he
added
,
laughing
,
"
it
must
be
a
stronger
prison
than
Willesden
cage
that
can
hold
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
"
observed
Jonathan
,
"
you
'll
give
the
keepers
of
his
Majesty
's
jails
some
trouble
before
you
're
many
years
older
<EOS>
,
I
'll
warrant
you
.
<EOS>
But
get
up
behind
,
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
Some
one
may
observe
us
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
jump
up
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
mounting

,
"
and
I
'll
soon
wisk
you
to
town
.
<EOS>
Edgeworth
Bess
and
Poll
Maggot
are
dying
to
see

.
<EOS>
I
thought
Bess
would
have
cried
her
pretty

out
when
she
heard
you
was
nabbed
.
<EOS>
You
need
give
yourself
no
more
concern
about
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wild
has
done
his
business
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
--
ay
,
"
laughed
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
pocket
-
book
you
prigged
contained
the
letters
I
wanted
.
<EOS>
He
's
now
in
spring
-
ankle
warehouse
with
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
So
get
up
,
and
let
's
be
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
leave
this
place
,
I
must
see
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
"
returned
Jonathan
gruffly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
you
expose
yourself
to
fresh
risk
?
<EOS>
If
it
had
n't
been
for
her
you
would
n't
have
been
placed
in
your
late
jeopardy
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
for
that
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
See
her
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
_
will
_
.
<EOS>
Leave
me
behind
:
<EOS>
I
'm
not
afraid
.
<EOS>
I
'll
be
at
the
Cross
Shovels
in
the
course
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
if
you
're
bent
upon
this
folly
,
"
observed
Wild
,
who
appeared
to
have
his
own
reasons
for
humouring
the
lad
,
"
I
sha
n't
hinder
you
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
will
take
care
of
the
horses
,
and
I
'll
go
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
dismounted
;
and
flinging
his
bridle
to
his
companion
,
and
ordering
him
to
ride
off
to
a
little
distance
,
he
followed
Jack
,
who
had
quitted
the
main
road
,
and
struck
into
a
narrow
path
opposite
the
cage
.
<EOS>
This
path
,
bordered
on
each
side
by
high
privet
hedges
of
the
most
beautiful
green
,
soon
brought
them
to
a
stile
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
house
,
"
said
Jack
,
pointing
to
a
pretty
cottage
,
the
small
wooden
porch
of
which
was
covered
with
roses
and
creepers
,
with
a
little
trim
garden
in
front
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
be
back
in
a
minute
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
hurry
yourself
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
"
I
'll
wait
for
you
here
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XIX
.
 
<EOS>
Good
and
Evil
.
  
<EOS>
As
Jack
opened
the
gate
,
and
crossed
the
little
garden
,
which
exhibited
in
every
part
the
neatness
and
attention
of
its
owner
,
he
almost
trembled
at
the
idea
of
further
disturbing
her
peace
of
mind
.
<EOS>
Pausing
with
the
intention
of
turning
back
,
he
glanced
in
the
direction
of
the
village
church
,
the
tower
of
which
could
just
be
seen
through
the
trees
.
<EOS>
The
rooks
were
cawing
amid
the
boughs
,
and
all
nature
appeared
awaking
to
happiness
.
<EOS>
From
this
peaceful
scene
Jack
's
eye
fell
upon
Jonathan
,
who
,
seated
upon
the
stile
,
under
the
shade
of
an
elder
tree
,
was
evidently
watching
him
.
<EOS>
A
sarcastic
smile
seemed
to
play
upon
the
chief
-
taker
's
lips
;
and
abashed
at
his
own
irresolution
,
the
lad
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
After
knocking
for
some
time
at
the
door
without
effect
,
he
tried
the
latch
,
and
to
his
surprise
found
it
open
.
<EOS>
He
stepped
in
with
a
heavy
foreboding
of
calamity
.
<EOS>
A
cat
came
and
rubbed
herself
against
him
as
he
entered
the
house
,
and
seemed
by
her
mewing
to
ask
him
for
food
.
<EOS>
That
was
the
only
sound
he
heard
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
was
almost
afraid
of
speaking
;
but
at
length
he
summoned
courage
to
call
out
"
Mother
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
asked
a
faint
voice
from
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
son
,
"
answered
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
exclaimed
the
widow
,
starting
up
and
drawing
back
the
curtain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
it
indeed
you
,
or
am
I
dreaming
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
dreaming
,
mother
,
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
come
to
say
good
<EOS>
bye
to
you
,
and
to
assure
you
of
my
safety
before
I
leave
this
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
asked
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
,
"
returned
Jack
;
"
but
it
's
not
safe
for
me
to
remain
much
longer
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
upon
whom
all
the
terrible
recollections
of
the
day
before
crowded
,
"
I
know
it
is
n't
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
keep
you
long
.
<EOS>
But
tell
me
how
have
you
escaped
from
the
confinement
in
which
you
were
placed
--
come
and
sit
by
me
--
here
--
upon
the
bed
--
give
me
your
hand
--
and
tell
me
all
about
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Her
son
complied
,
and
sat
down
upon
the
patch
-
work
coverlet
beside
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
clasping
him
with
a
hand
that
burnt
with
fever
,
"
I
have
been
ill
--
dreadfully
ill
--
<EOS>
I
believe
delirious
<EOS>
--
I
thought
I
should
have
died
last
night
--
I
wo
n't
tell
you
what
agony
<EOS>
you
have
caused
me
--
I
wo
n't
reproach
you
.
<EOS>
Only
promise
me
to
amend
--
to
quit
your
vile
companions
--
and
I
will
forgive
you
--
will
bless
you
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
my
dear
,
dear
son
,
be
warned
in
time
.
<EOS>
You
are
in
the
hands
of
a
wicked
,
a
terrible
man
,
who
will
not
stop
till
he
has
completed
your
destruction
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
your
mother
's
prayers
,
and
do
not
let
her
die
broken
-
hearted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
,
"
returned
Jack
,
sullenly
;
"
I
ca
n't
be
honest
if
I
would
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
not
say
so
,
"
replied
his
wretched
parent
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
never
too
late
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
are
in
Jonathan
Wild
's
power
,
<EOS>
for
I
saw
him
near
you
in
the
church
;
and
if
ever
the
enemy
of
mankind
was
permitted
to
take
human
form
,
I
beheld
him
then
.
<EOS>
Beware
of
him
,
my
son
!
<EOS>
Beware
of
him
!
<EOS>
You
know
not
what
villany
he
is
capable
of
.
<EOS>
Be
honest
,
and
you
will
be
happy
.
<EOS>
You
are
yet
a
child
;
and
though
you
have
strayed
from
the
right
path
,
a
stronger
hand
than
your
own
has
led
you
thence
.
<EOS>
Return
,
I
implore
of
you
,
to
your
master,--to
Mr.
Wood
.
<EOS>
Acknowledge
your
faults
.
<EOS>
He
is
all
kindness
,
and
will
overlook
them
for
your
poor
father
's
sake
--
for
mine
.
<EOS>
Return
to
him
,
I
say--
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
,
"
replied
Jack
,
doggedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
!
"
repeated
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
I
'll
_
tell
you
,
"
cried
a
deep
voice
from
the
back
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
And
immediately
afterwards
the
curtain
was
drawn
aside
,
and
disclosed
the
Satanic
countenance
of
Jonathan
Wild
,
who
had
crept
into
the
house
unperceived
,
"
I
'll
tell
you
,
why
he
ca
n't
go
back
to
his
master
,
"
cried
the
thief
-
taker
,
with
a
malignant
grin
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
robbed
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Robbed
him
!
"
screamed
the
widow
.
"
<EOS>
Jack
!
"
 
<EOS>
Her
son
averted
his
gaze
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
robbed
him
,
"
reiterated
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
night
before
last
,
Mr.
Wood
's
house
was
broken
into
and
plundered
.
<EOS>
Your
son
was
seen
by
the
carpenter
's
wife
in
company
with
the
robbers
.
<EOS>
Here
,
"
he
added
,
throwing
a
handbill
on
the
bed
,
"
are
the
particulars
of
the
burglary
,
with
the
reward
for
Jack
's
apprehension
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
ejaculated
the
widow
,
hiding
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said
Wild
,
turning
authoritatively
to
Jack,--"you
have
overstayed
your
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
go
with
him
,
Jack
!
"
shrieked
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
--
do
not
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
_
must
!
<EOS>
_
"
thundered
Jonathan
,
"
or
he
goes
to
jail
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
must
go
to
prison
,
I
will
go
with
you
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
:
"
but
avoid
that
man
as
you
would
a
serpent
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
"
thundered
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Jack
!
"
shrieked
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
not
what
you
do
.
<EOS>
The
wretch
you
confide
in
has
sworn
to
hang
you
.
<EOS>
As
I
hope
for
mercy
,
I
speak
the
truth!--let
<EOS>
him
deny
it
if
he
can
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
said
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
hang
him
now
if
I
liked
.
<EOS>
But
he
may
remain
with
you
if
he
pleases
:
_
<EOS>
I
_
sha'n't
hinder
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
,
my
son
,
"
said
the
widow
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Choose
between
good
and
evil;--between
him
and
me
.
<EOS>
And
mind
,
your
life,--more
than
your
life
--
hangs
upon
your
choice
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
so
,
"
said
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Choose
,
Jack
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
lad
made
no
answer
,
but
left
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
gone
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
despairingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
ever
!
"
said
the
thief
-
taker
,
preparing
to
follow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Devil
!
"
cried
the
widow
,
catching
his
arm
,
and
gazing
with
frantic
eagerness
in
his
face
,
"
how
many
years
will
you
give
my
son
before
you
execute
your
terrible
threat
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
NINE
!
"
answered
Jonathan
sternly
.
  
<EOS>
END
OF
THE
SECOND
EPOCH
.
       
<EOS>
EPOCH
THE
THIRD
.
 
<EOS>
1724
 
<EOS>
THE
PRISON
-
BREAKER
.
       
<EOS>
CHAPTER
I.
 
<EOS>
The
Return
.
  
<EOS>
Nearly
nine
years
after
the
events
last
recorded
,
and
about
the
middle
of
May
,
1724
,
a
young
man
of
remarkably
prepossessing
appearance
took
his
way
,
one
afternoon
,
along
Wych
Street
;
and
,
from
the
curiosity
with
which
he
regarded
the
houses
on
the
left
of
the
road
,
seemed
to
be
in
search
of
some
particular
habitation
.
<EOS>
The
age
of
this
individual
could
not
be
more
than
twenty
-
one
;
his
figure
was
tall
,
robust
,
and
gracefully
proportioned
;
and
his
clear
gray
eye
and
open
countenance
bespoke
a
frank
,
generous
,
and
resolute
nature
.
<EOS>
His
features
were
regular
,
and
finely
-
formed
;
his
complexion
bright
and
blooming,--a
<EOS>
little
shaded
,
however
,
by
travel
and
exposure
to
the
sun
;
and
,
with
a
praiseworthy
contempt
for
the
universal
and
preposterous
fashion
then
prevailing
,
of
substituting
a
peruke
for
the
natural
covering
of
the
head
,
he
allowed
his
own
dark
-
brown
hair
to
fall
over
his
shoulders
in
ringlets
as
luxuriant
as
those
that
distinguished
the
court
gallant
in
Charles
the
Second
's
days
--
a
fashion
,
which
we
do
not
despair
of
seeing
revived
in
our
own
days
.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
French
military
undress
of
the
period
,
with
high
jack
-
boots
,
and
a
laced
hat
;
and
,
though
his
attire
indicated
no
particular
rank
,
he
had
completely
the
air
of
a
person
of
distinction
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
effect
produced
upon
the
passengers
by
his
good
looks
and
manly
deportment
,
<EOS>
that
few
--
especially
of
the
gentler
and
more
susceptible
sex
--
failed
to
turn
round
and
bestow
a
second
glance
upon
the
handsome
stranger
.
<EOS>
Unconscious
of
the
interest
he
excited
,
and
entirely
occupied
by
his
own
thoughts
--
which
,
if
his
bosom
could
have
been
examined
,
would
have
been
found
composed
of
mingled
hopes
and
fears
--
the
young
man
walked
on
till
he
came
to
an
old
house
,
with
great
projecting
bay
windows
on
the
first
floor
,
and
situated
as
nearly
as
possible
at
the
back
of
St.
Clement
's
church
.
<EOS>
Here
he
halted
;
and
,
looking
upwards
,
read
,
at
the
foot
of
an
immense
sign
-
board
,
displaying
a
gaudily
-
painted
angel
with
expanded
pinions
and
an
olive
-
branch
,
not
the
name
he
expected
to
find
,
but
that
of
WILLIAM
KNEEBONE
,
WOOLLEN
-
DRAPER
.
 
<EOS>
Tears
started
to
the
young
man
's
eyes
on
beholding
the
change
,
and
it
was
with
difficulty
he
could
command
himself
sufficiently
to
make
the
inquiries
he
desired
to
do
respecting
the
former
owner
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
As
he
entered
the
shop
,
a
tall
portly
personage
advanced
to
meet
him
,
whom
he
at
once
recognised
as
the
present
proprietor
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
was
attired
in
the
extremity
of
the
mode
.
<EOS>
A
full
-
curled
wig
descended
half
-
way
down
his
back
and
shoulders
;
a
neckcloth
of
"
right
Mechlin
"
was
twisted
round
his
throat
so
tightly
as
almost
to
deprive
him
of
breath
,
and
threaten
him
with
apoplexy
;
he
had
lace
,
also
,
at
his
wrists
and
bosom
;
gold
clocks
to
his
hose
,
and
red
heels
to
his
shoes
.
<EOS>
A
stiff
,
formally
-
cut
coat
of
cinnamon
-
coloured
cloth
,
with
rows
of
plate
buttons
,
each
of
the
size
of
a
crown
piece
,
on
the
sleeves
,
pockets
,
and
skirts
,
reached
the
middle
of
his
legs
;
and
his
costume
was
completed
by
the
silver
-
hilted
sword
at
his
side
,
and
the
laced
hat
under
his
left
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Bowing
to
the
stranger
,
the
woollen
-
draper
very
politely
requested
to
know
his
business
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
almost
afraid
to
state
it
,
"
<EOS>
faltered
the
other
;
"
but
,
may
I
ask
whether
Mr.
Wood
,
the
carpenter
,
who
formerly
resided
here
,
is
still
living
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
feel
any
anxiety
on
his
account
,
Sir
,
I
'm
happy
to
be
able
to
relieve
it
,
"
answered
Kneebone
,
readily
.
<EOS>
"
My
good
friend
,
Owen
Wood,--Heaven
preserve
him!--_is
_
still
living
.
<EOS>
And
,
for
a
man
who
'll
never
see
sixty
again
,
he
's
in
excellent
preservation
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
delight
me
with
the
intelligence
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
entirely
recovering
his
cheerfulness
of
look
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
began
to
fear
,
from
his
having
quitted
the
old
place
,
that
some
misfortune
must
have
befallen
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
the
contrary
,
"
rejoined
the
woollen
-
draper
,
laughing
good
-
humouredly
.
<EOS>
"
Everything
has
prospered
with
him
in
an
extraordinary
manner
.
<EOS>
His
business
has
thriven
;
legacies
have
unexpectedly
dropped
into
his
lap
;
and
,
to
crown
all
,
he
has
made
a
large
fortune
by
a
lucky
speculation
in
South
-
Sea
stock,--made
it
,
too
,
where
so
many
others
have
lost

,
your
humble
servant
amongst
the
number
--
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
Sir
,
Mr.
Wood
is
now
in
very

.
<EOS>
He
stuck
to
the
shop

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

rent

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood

"

"

<EOS>
"
Well
,

"

<EOS>
"
His
wife
is

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

"

"

,

"
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

hem
!

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>
Winifred
Wood

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why

<EOS>
_

"

--

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
is

.
<EOS>
The

ca
n't

;

.
<EOS>
He
's

.
<EOS>
He

;

,

.
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
At

,

Jonathan
Wild
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Does

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

Kneebone
,
"
and
,

,

.
<EOS>
Jonathan
completely
baffles
and
derides

.
<EOS>
It

to

,

.
<EOS>
Some

,

,

,

by

got

,

I

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

,

,

;
but

--

could

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
fared

.
<EOS>
Bribed

,

kidnapped

,

,

,

;

,

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
One

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
's

?
<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>
Gracious

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She

,

,
"

"

<EOS>
Alas

.
<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
she

;

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

Jonathan
,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

've

,

,

.
<EOS>
That
,
Sir
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
The
stranger
said

,

.
<EOS>
Perceiving
<EOS>
he

about

,

<EOS>
Before

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
As

<EOS>
"
Do

,

I
'm

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
've

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

,
Poll
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

his
name
.
"
<EOS>
And

as

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

's

"

,
eyeing

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
Poll
,
"

,

red
,
"
you

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"

Maggot
,

;
"
because

,

man,--especially

so
much

?
<EOS>
Do

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,
Madam
,
"
said

,

"
if

ca

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
That
for

!
"
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
"
Zounds
!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Make

"

,

<EOS>
"
Try
!
"
 
<EOS>
Enraged

,

<EOS>
At

<EOS>
"
There
!
"
she

"
that

.
<EOS>
You
should

,
before

,

,

,
I

,

you
--
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Poll
!
<EOS>
"
said
Kneebone
,
picking
himself
up
,
"
I
entreat
you
to
moderate
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Entreat
a
fiddlestick
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mrs.
Maggot
:
"
<EOS>
I
'm
tired
of
you
,
and
will
go
back
to
my
old
lover
,
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
He
's
worth
a
dozen
of
you
.
<EOS>
Or
,
if
this
good
-
looking
young
fellow
will
only
say
the
word
,
I
'll
go
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
go
,
and
welcome
,
Madam
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Kneebone
,
spitefully
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
I
should
think
,
after
the
specimen
you
've
just
given
of
your
amiable
disposition
,
no
person
would
be
likely
to
saddle
himself
with
such
an
incumbrance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
say
you
,
Sir
?
"
said
the
Amazon
,
with
an
engaging
leer
at
the
stranger
.
"
<EOS>
_
You
_
will
find
me
tractable
enough
;
and
,
with
_
me
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
by
,
your
side
you
need
fear
<EOS>
neither
constable
nor
watchman
.
<EOS>
I
've
delivered
Jack
Sheppard
from
many
an
assault
.
<EOS>
I
can
wield
a
quarterstaff
as
well
as
a
prize
-
fighter
,
and
have
beaten
Figg
himself
at
the
broadsword
.
<EOS>
Will
you
take
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
However

Mrs.
Maggot
's
offer
may
appear
,
the
young
man
thought

to
decline

,
and
,
after

well
-
merited

on
her

,
and
renewed

Mr.
Kneebone
,
he
took
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
bye
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Maggot
,
kissing
her
hand
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
find
you
out
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
she
added
,
glancing
contemptuously
at
the
woollen
-
draper
,
"
I
'll
go
to
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
first
go
to
Bridewell
,
you
jade
!
"
rejoined
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Tom
,
"
he
added
,

to
a

,
"
run

fetch

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
had
better
bring
half
-
a
-
dozen
,
"
said
the
Amazon
,
taking
up
a
cloth
-
yard
wand
,
and
quietly
seating

;
"
one
wo
n't
do
.
"
 
<EOS>
On
leaving
Mr.
Kneebone
's
house
,
the
young
man
hastened
to
a
hotel
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Covent
Garden
,
where
,
having
procured
a
horse
,
he
shaped
his
course
towards
the
west
end
of
the
town
.
<EOS>
Urging
his
steed
along
Oxford
Road,--as
<EOS>
that
great
approach
to
the
metropolis
was
then
<EOS>
termed,--he
soon
passed
Marylebone
Lane
,
beyond
which
,
with
the
exception
of
a
few
scattered
houses
,
the
country
was
completely
open
on
the
right
,
and
laid
out
in
pleasant
fields
and
gardens
;
nor
did
he
draw
in
the
rein
until
he
arrived
at
Tyburn
-
gate
,
where
,
before
he
turned
off
upon
the
Edgeware
Road
,
he
halted
for
a
moment
,
to
glance
at
the
place
of
execution
.
<EOS>
This
"
fatal
retreat
for
the
unfortunate
brave
"
was
marked
by
a
low
wooden
railing
,
within
which
stood
the
triple
tree
.
<EOS>
Opposite
the
gallows
was
an
open
gallery
,
or
scaffolding
,
like
the
stand
at
a
racecourse
,
which
,
on
state
occasions
,
was
crowded
with
spectators
.
<EOS>
Without
the
inclosure
were
reared
several
lofty
gibbets
,
with
their
ghastly
burthens
.
<EOS>
Altogether
,
it
was
a
hideous
and
revolting
sight
.
<EOS>
Influenced
,
probably
,
by
what
he
had
heard
from
Mr.
Kneebone
,
respecting
the
lawless
career
of
Jack
Sheppard
,
and
struck
with
the
probable
fate
that
awaited
him
,
the
young
man
,
as
he
contemplated
this
scene
,
fell
into
a
gloomy
reverie
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
musing
,
two
horsemen
rode
past
him
;
and
,
proceeding
to
a
little
distance
,
stopped
likewise
.
<EOS>
One
of
them
was
a
stout
square
-
built
man
,
with
a
singularly
swarthy
complexion
,
and
harsh
forbidding
features
.
<EOS>
He
was
well
mounted
,
as
was
his
companion
;
and
had
pistols
in
his
holsters
,
and
a
hanger
at
his
girdle
.
<EOS>
The
other
individual
,
who
was
a
little
in
advance
,
was
concealed
from
the
stranger
's
view
.
<EOS>
Presently
,
however
,
a
sudden
movement
occurred
,
and
disclosed
his
features
,
which
were
those
of
a
young
man
of
nearly
his
own
age
.
<EOS>
The
dress
of
this
person
was
excessively
showy
,
and
consisted
of
a
scarlet
riding
-
habit
,
lined
and
faced
with
blue
,
and
bedizened
with
broad
gold
lace
,
a
green
silk
-
knit
waistcoat
,
embroidered
with
silver
,
and
decorated
with
a
deep
fringe
,
together
with
a
hat
tricked
out
in
the
same
gaudy
style
.
<EOS>
His
figure
was
slight
,
but
well
-
built
;
and
,
in
stature
he
did
not
exceed
five
feet
four
.
<EOS>
His
complexion
was
pale
;
and
there
was
something
sinister
in
the
expression
of
his
large
black
eyes
.
<EOS>
His
head
was
small
and
bullet
-
shaped
,
and
he
did
not
wear
a
wig
,
but
had
his
sleek
black
hair
cut
off
closely
round
his
temples
.
<EOS>
A
mutual
recognition
took
place
at
the
same
instant
between
the
stranger
and
this
individual
.
<EOS>
Both
started
.
<EOS>
The
latter
seemed
inclined
to
advance
and
address
the
former
;
but
suddenly
changing
his
mind
,
he
shouted
to
his
companion
in
tones
familiar
to
the
stranger
's
ear
;
and
,
striking
spurs
into
his
steed
,
dashed
off
at
full
speed
along
the
Edgeware
Road
.
<EOS>
Impelled
by
a
feeling
,
into
which
we
shall
not
pause
to
inquire
,
the
stranger
started
after
them
;
but
they
were
better
mounted
,
and
soon
distanced
him
.
<EOS>
Remarking
that
they
struck
off
at
a
turning
on
the
left
,
he
took
the
same
road
,
and
soon
found
himself
on
Paddington
-
Green
.
<EOS>
A
row
of
magnificent
,
and
even
then
venerable
,
elms
threw
their
broad
arms
over
this
pleasant
spot
.
<EOS>
From
a
man
,
who
was
standing
beneath

of
one
<EOS>
these
noble
trees
,
information
was
obtained
that
the
horsemen
had
ridden
along
the
Harrow
Road
.
<EOS>
With
a
faint
view
of
overtaking
them
the
pursuer
urged
his
steed
to
a
quicker
pace
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
Westbourne
-
Green
--
then
nothing
more
than
a
common
covered
with
gorse
and

,
and

only
a

--
he
perceived
through
the
hedges
the
objects
of
his
search
slowly
ascending
the
gentle
hill
that
rises
from
Kensall
-
Green
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
he
had
reached
the

this

,

had
lost
all

of

;

the

of

having
in

,

himself
for
his

,
in
having

--
as

--

.
<EOS>
Before

,
however
,
he

to

over
the
vast

spread
out

,
which
is
now
hidden
,
from
the
traveller
's
view
by
the
high

of
the
General
Cemetery
,
and
can
,

,
only

from

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
After

,

was
about

,
when

ascertained

his

Willesden

down

,

.
<EOS>
Following

,

opened

,

most

imaginable
;

,

,

into
a

,

to

.
<EOS>
Glancing

finger
-

over

,
which
has

as

,
and
seeing
no

to
Dollis

,

as

,
from

,

near

.
 
<EOS>
"
Whose

,

?
"

man
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
's
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,

,

,
"

,

"

's
.
<EOS>
If

,

,

<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
young
man

,

,

<EOS>
"
I

,

,

of

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

Lunnun
,

.
<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
If

o
'

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
'

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Jack
's

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
young
man
heard
no

.
<EOS>
Taking
the
direction
pointed
out
,
he
rode
off
.
<EOS>
As
he
passed
the
Six
Bells
,
he
noticed
the
steeds
of
the
two
horsemen
at
the
door
;
and
glancing
into
the
house
,
perceived
the
younger
of
the
two
in
the
passage
.
<EOS>
The
latter
no
sooner
beheld
him
than
he
dashed
hastily
into
an
adjoining
room
.
<EOS>
After
debating
with
himself
whether
he
should
further
seek
an
