,
which
,
though
,
now
in
his
power
,
was
so
sedulously
shunned
by
the
other
party
,
he
decided
in
the
negative
;
and
contenting
himself
with
writing
upon
a
slip
of
paper
<EOS>
the
hasty
words,--"You
are
known
by
the
villagers,--be
upon
your
guard,"--he
<EOS>
gave
it
to
the
ostler
,
with
instructions
to
deliver
it
instantly
to
the
owner
of
the
horse
he
pointed
out
,
and
pursued
his
course
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
the
old
rectory
,
and
still
older
church
,
with
its
reverend
screen
of
trees
,
and
slowly
ascending
a
hill
side
,
<EOS>
from
whence
he
obtained
enchanting
peeps
of
the
spire
and
college
of
Harrow
,
he
reached
the
cluster
of
well
-
built
houses
which
constitute
the
village
of
Neasdon
.
<EOS>
From
this
spot
a
road
,
more
resembling
the
drive
through
a
park
than
a
public
thoroughfare
,
led
him
gradually
to
the
brow
of
Dollis
Hill
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
serene
and
charming
evening
,
and
twilight
was
gently
stealing
over
the
face
of
the
country
.
<EOS>
Bordered
by
fine
timber
,
the
road
occasionally
offered
glimpses
of
a
lovely
valley
,
until
a
wider
opening
gave
a
full
view
of
a
delightful
and
varied
prospect
.
<EOS>
On
the
left
lay
the
heights
of
Hampstead
,
studded
with
villas
,
while
farther
off
a
hazy
cloud
marked
the
position
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
The
stranger
concluded
he
could
not
be
far
from
his
destination
,
and
a
turn
in
the
road
showed
him
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Beneath
two
tall
elms
,
whose
boughs
completely
overshadowed
the
roof
,
stood
Mr.
Wood
's
dwelling,--a
plain
,
substantial
,
commodious
farm
-
house
.
<EOS>
On
a
bench
at
the
foot
of
the
trees
,
with
a
pipe
in
his
mouth
,
and
a
tankard
by
his
side
,
sat
the
worthy
carpenter
,
looking
the
picture
of
good
-
heartedness
and
benevolence
.
<EOS>
The
progress
of
time
was
marked
in
Mr.
Wood
by
increased
corpulence
and
decreased
powers
of
vision,--by
deeper
wrinkles
and
higher
shoulders
,
by
scantier
breath
and
a
fuller
habit
.
<EOS>
Still
he
looked
hale
and
hearty
,
and
the
country
life
he
led
had
imparted
a
ruddier
glow
to
his
cheek
.
<EOS>
Around
him
were
all
the
evidences
of
plenty
.
<EOS>
A
world
of
haystacks
,
bean
-
stacks
,
and
straw
-
ricks
flanked
the
granges
adjoining
his
habitation
;
the
yard
was
crowded
with
poultry
,
pigeons
were
feeding
at
his
feet
,
cattle
were
being
driven
towards
the
stall
<EOS>
,
horses
led
to
the
stable
,
a
large
mastiff
was
rattling
his
chain
,
and
stalking
majestically
in
front
of
his
kennel
,
while
a
number
of
farming
-
men
were
passing
and
repassing
about
their
various
occupations
.
<EOS>
At
the
back
of
the
house
,
on
a
bank
,
rose
an
old
-
fashioned
terrace
-
garden
,
full
of
apple
-
trees
and
other
fruit
-
trees
in
blossom
,
and
lively
with
the
delicious
verdure
of
early
spring
.
 
<EOS>
Hearing
the
approach
of
the
rider
,
Mr.
Wood
turned
to
look
at
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
getting
dusk
,
and
he
could
only
imperfectly
distinguish
the
features
and
figure
of
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
need
not
ask
whether
this
is
Mr.
Wood
's
,
"
said
the
latter
,
"
since
I
find
him
at
his
own
gate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
worthy
carpenter
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
Owen
Wood
,
at
your
service
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
remember
me
,
I
dare
say
,
"
observed
the
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
I
do
,
"
replied
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
Your
voice
seems
familiar
to
me
--
and
--
but
I
'm
getting
a
little
deaf
--
and
my
eyes
do
n't
serve
me
quite
so
well
as
they
used
to
do
,
especially
by
this
light
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
returned
the
stranger
,
dismounting
;
"
you
'll
recollect
me
by
and
by
<EOS>
,
I
've
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
I
bring
you
tidings
of
an
old
friend
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
're
heartily
welcome
,
Sir
,
whoever
you
are
.
<EOS>
Pray
,
walk
in
.
<EOS>
Here
,
Jem
,
take
the
gentleman
's
horse
to
the
stable
--
see
him
dressed
and
fed
directly
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Sir
,
will
you
please
to
follow
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
then
led
the
way
up
a
rather
high
and
,
according
to
modern
notions
,
incommodious
flight
of
steps
,
and
introduced
his
guest
to
a
neat
parlour
,
the
windows
of
which
were
darkened
by
pots
of
flowers
and
creepers
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
light
in
the
room
;
but
,
notwithstanding
this
,
the
young
man
did
not
fail
to
detect
the
buxom
figure
of
Mrs.
Wood
,
now
more
buxom
and
more
gorgeously
arrayed
than
ever,--as
<EOS>
well
as
a
young
and
beautiful
female
,
in
whom
he
was
at
no
loss
to
recognise
the
carpenter
's
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Winifred
Wood
was
now
in
her
twentieth
year
.
<EOS>
Her
features
were
still
slightly
marked
by
the
disorder
alluded
to
in
the
description
of
her
as
a
child,--but
<EOS>
that
was
the
only
drawback
to
her
beauty
.
<EOS>
Their
expression
was
so
amiable
,
that
it
would
have
redeemed
a
countenance
a
thousand
times
plainer
than
hers
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
was
perfect,--tall
,
graceful
,
rounded,--and
,
then
,
she
had
deep
liquid
blue
eyes
,
that
rivalled
the
stars
in
lustre
.
<EOS>
On
the
stranger
's
appearance
,
she
was
seated
near
the
window
busily
occupied
with
her
needle
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
wife
and
daughter
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
carpenter
,
introducing
them
to
his
guest
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wood
,
whose
admiration
for
masculine
beauty
was
by
no
means
abated
,
glanced
at
the
well
-
proportioned
figure
of
the
young
man
,
and
made
him
a
very
civil
salutation
.
<EOS>
Winifred
's
reception
was
kind
,
but
more
distant
,
and
after
the
slight
ceremonial
she
resumed
her
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
gentleman
brings
us
tidings
of
an
old
friend
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
And
who
may
that
be
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
whom
you
may
perhaps
have
forgotten
,
"
replied
the
stranger
,
"
but
who
can
never
forget
the
kindness
he
experienced
at
your
hands
,
or
at
those
of
your
excellent
husband
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
the
sound
of
his
voice
every
vestige
of
colour
fled
from
Winifred
's
cheeks
,
and
the
work
upon
which
she
was
engaged
fell
from
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
token
to
deliver
to
you
,
"
continued
the
stranger
,
addressing
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
me
?
"
gasped
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
locket
,
"
he
said
,
taking
a
little
ornament
attached
to
a
black
ribband
from
his
breast
,
and
giving
it
her,--"do
<EOS>
you
remember
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
--
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
all
this
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Wood
in
amazement
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
not
know
me
,
father
?
"
said
the
young
man
,
advancing
towards
him
,
and
warmly
grasping
his
hand
.
"
<EOS>
Have
nine
years
so
changed
me
,
that
there
is
no
trace
left
of
your
adopted
son
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
God
bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
the
carpenter
,
rubbing
his
eyes
,
"
can
--
can
it
be
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
"
screamed
Mrs.
Wood
,
joining
the
group
,
"
it
is
n't
Thames
Darrell
come
to
life
again
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
--
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Winifred
,
rushing
towards
him
,
and
flinging
her
arms
round
his
neck,--"it
<EOS>
is
my
dear
--
dear
brother
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
this
is
what
I
never
expected
to
see
,
"
said
the
carpenter
,
wiping
his
eyes
;
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
'm
not
dreaming
!
<EOS>
Thames
,
my
dear
boy
,
as
soon
as
Winny
has
done
with
you
,
let
me
embrace
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
turn
comes
before
yours
,
Sir
,
"
interposed
his
better
half
.
<EOS>
"
Come
to
my
arms
,
Thames
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
dear
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
dear
!
"
 
<EOS>
To
repeat
the
questions
and
congratulations
which
now
ensued
,
or
describe
the
extravagant
joy
of
the
carpenter
,
who
,
after
he
had
hugged
his
adopted
son
to
his
breast
with
such
warmth
as
almost
to
squeeze
the
breath
from
his
body
,
capered
around
the
room
,
threw
his
wig
into
the
empty
fire
-
grate
,
and
committed
various
other
fantastic
actions
,
in
order
to
get
rid
of
his
superfluous
satisfaction
--
to
describe
the
scarcely
less
extravagant
raptures
of
his
spouse
,
or
the
more
subdued
,
but
not
less
heartfelt
delight
of
Winifred
,
would
be
a
needless
task
,
as
it
must
occur
to
every
one
's
imagination
.
<EOS>
Supper
was
quickly
served
;
the
oldest
bottle
of
wine
was
brought
from
the
cellar
;
the
strongest
barrel
of
ale
was
tapped
;
but
not
one
of
the
party
could
eat
or
drink
--
their
hearts
were
too
full
.
 
<EOS>
Thames
sat
with
Winifred
's
hand
clasped
in
his
own
,
and
commenced
a
recital
of
his
adventures
,
which
may
be
briefly
told
.
<EOS>
Carried
out
to
sea
by
Van
Galgebrok
,
and
thrown
overboard
,
while
struggling
with
the
waves
,
he
had
been
picked
up
by
a
French
fishing
-
boat
,
and
carried
to
Ostend
.
<EOS>
After
encountering
various
hardships
and
privations
for
a
long
time
,
during
which
he
had
no
means
of
communicating
with
England
,
he
,
at
length
,
found
his
way
to
Paris
,
where
he
was
taken
notice
of
by
Cardinal
Dubois
,
who
employed
him
as
one
of
his
secretaries
,
and
subsequently
advanced
to
the
service
of
Philip
of
Orleans
,
from
whom
he
received
a
commission
.
<EOS>
On
the
death
of
his
royal
patron
,
he
resolved
to
return
to
his
own
country
;
and
,
after
various
delays
,
which
had
postponed
it
to
the
present
time
,
he
had
succeeded
in
accomplishing
his
object
.
 
<EOS>
Winifred
listened
to
his
narration
with
the
profoundest
attention
;
and
,
when
it
concluded
,
her
tearful
eye
and
throbbing
bosom
told
how
deeply
her
feelings
had
been
interested
.
 
<EOS>
The
discourse
,
then
,
turned
to
Darrell
's
old
playmate
,
Jack
Sheppard
;
and
Mr.
Wood
,
in
deploring
his
wild
career
,
adverted
to
the
melancholy
condition
to
which
it
had
reduced
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
my
part
,
it
's
only
what
I
expected
of
him
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Wood
,
"
and
I
'm
sorry
and
surprised
he
has
n't
swung
for
his
crimes
before
this
.
<EOS>
The
gallows
has
groaned
for
him
for
years
.
<EOS>
As
to
his
mother
,
I
've
no
pity
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
deserves
what
has
befallen
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
mother
,
do
n't
say
so
,
"
returned
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
consequences
of
criminal
conduct
,
is
the
shame
and
disgrace
which
--
worse
than
any
punishment
the
evil
-
doer
can
suffer
--
is
brought
by
it
upon
the
innocent
relatives
;
and
,
if
Jack
had
considered
this
,
perhaps
he
would
not
have
acted
as
he
has
done
,
and
have
entailed
so
much
misery
on
his
unhappy
parent
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
always
detested
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
cried
the
carpenter
's
wife
bitterly
;
"
and
,
I
repeat
,
<EOS>
Bedlam
's
too
good
for
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
observed
Wood
,
"
you
should
be
more
charitable--
<EOS>
"
 
"
Charitable
!
"
repeated
his
wife
,
"
that
's
your
constant
cry
.
<EOS>
Marry
,
come
up
!
<EOS>
I
've
been
a
great
deal
too
charitable
.
<EOS>
Here
's
Winny
always
urging
you
to
go
and
visit
Mrs.
Sheppard
in
the
asylum
,
and
take
her
this
,
and
send
her
<EOS>
that;--and
<EOS>
I
've
never
prevented
you
,
though
such
mistaken
liberality
's
enough
to
provoke
a
saint
.
<EOS>
And
,
then
,
forsooth
,
she
must
needs
prevent
your
hanging
Jack
Sheppard
after
the
robbery
in
Wych
Street
,
when
you
might
have
done
so
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
'll
call
that
charity
:
<EOS>
_
I
<EOS>
_
call
it
defeating
the
ends
of
justice
.
<EOS>
See
what
a
horrible
rascal
you
've
let
loose
upon
the
world
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
,
mother
,
"
rejoined
Winifred
,
"
if
any
one
was
likely
to
feel
resentment
,
I
was
;
for
no
one
could
be
more
frightened
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
sorry
for
poor
Jack
--
as
I
am
still
,
and
hoped
he
would
mend
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mend
!
"
echoed
Mrs.
Wood
,
contemptuously
,
"
he
'll
never
mend
till
he
comes
to
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
I
will
hope
so
,
"
returned
Winifred
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
was
saying
,
I
was
most
dreadfully
frightened
on
the
night
of
the
robbery
!
<EOS>
Though
so
young
at
the
time
,
I
remember
every
circumstance
distinctly
.
<EOS>
I
was
sitting
up
,
lamenting
your
departure
,
dear
Thames
,
when
,
hearing
an
odd
noise
,
I
went
to
the

,
and
,

the

,

Jack
Sheppard
,
stealing
up

,
followed
by
two
men
with

on

.
<EOS>
I
'm
ashamed
to
say
that
I
was
too
much
terrified
to
scream
out
--
but
ran
and
hid
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
I
declare
you
throw
me
into
an
ague
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
_
<EOS>
I
_
forget
it
?
<EOS>
Did
n't
they
help
themselves
to
all
the
plate
and
the
money
--
to
several
of
my
best
dresses
,
and
amongst

,
to
my
favourite
kincob
gown
;
and
I
've
never
been
able
to
get
another
like

!
<EOS>
Marry
,
come
up
!
<EOS>
I
'd
hang
'em
all
,
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
Were
such
a
thing
to
happen
again
,
I
'd
never
let
Mr.
Wood
rest
till
he
brought
the
villains
to
justice
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
such
a
thing
never
_
will
_
happen
again
,
my
dear
,
"
observed
Wood
,
mildly
,
"
<EOS>
but
,
when
it
does
,
it
will
be
time
to
consider
what
course
we
ought
to
pursue
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
them
attempt
it
,
if
they
dare
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Wood
,
who
had
worked
herself
into
a
passion
;
"
and
,
I
'll
warrant
'em
,
<EOS>
the
boldest
robber
among
'em
shall
repent
it
,
if
he
comes

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
my
dear
,
"
acquiesced
the
carpenter
,
"
no
doubt
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
,
who
had
been
more
than
once
on
the
point
of
mentioning
his
accidental
rencounter
with
Jack
Sheppard
,
not
being
altogether
without
apprehension
,
from
the
fact
of
his
being
in
the
neighbourhood,--now
judged
it
more
prudent
to
say
nothing
on
the
subject
,
from
a
fear
of
increasing
Mrs.
Wood
's
displeasure
;
and
he
was
the
more
readily
induced
to
do
this
,
as
the
conversation
began
to
turn
upon
his
own
affairs
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
could
give
him
no
further
information
respecting
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
than
what
he
had
obtained
from
Kneebone
;
but
begged
him
to
defer
the
further
consideration
of
the
line
of
conduct
he
meant
to
pursue
until
the
morrow
,
when
he
hoped
to
have
a
plan
to
lay
before
him
,
of
which
he
would
approve
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
was
now
advancing
,
and
the
party
began
to
think
of
separating
.
<EOS>
As
Mrs.
Wood
,
who
had
recovered
her
good
humour
,
quitted
the
room
she
bestowed
a
hearty
embrace
on
Thames
,
and
she
told
him
laughingly
,
that
she
would
"
defer
all
_
she
_
had
to
propose
to
him
until
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
!
<EOS>
She
never
beheld
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
an
affectionate
parting
with
Winifred
,
Thames
was
conducted
by
the
carpenter
to
his
sleeping
apartment
--
a
comfortable
cosy
chamber
;
such
a
one
,
in
short
,
as
can
only
be
met
with
in
the
country
,
with
its
dimity
-
curtained
bed
,
its
sheets
fragrant
of
lavender
,
its
clean
white
furniture
,
and
an
atmosphere
breathing
of
freshness
.
<EOS>
Left
to
himself
,
he
took
a
survey
of
the
room
,
and
his
heart
leaped
as
he
beheld
over
the
,
chimney
-
piece
,
a
portrait
of
himself
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
copy
of
the
pencil
sketch
taken
of
him
nine
years
ago
by
Winifred
,
and
awakened
a
thousand
tender
recollections
.
 
<EOS>
When
about
to
retire
to
rest
,
the
rencounter
with
Jack
Sheppard
again
recurred
to
him
,
and
he
half
blamed
himself
for
not
acquainting
Mr.
Wood
with
the
circumstances
,
and
putting
him
upon
his
guard
against
the
possibility
of
an
attack
.
<EOS>
On
weighing
the
matter
over
,
he
grew
so
uneasy
that
he
resolved
to
descend
,
and
inform
him
of
his
misgivings
.
<EOS>
But
,
when
he
got
to
the
door
with
this
intention
,
he
became
ashamed
of
his
fears
;
and
feeling
convinced
that
Jack
--
bad
as
he
might
be
--
was
not
capable
of
such
atrocious
conduct
as
to
plunder
his
benefactor
twice
,
he
contented
himself
with
looking
to
the
priming
of
his
pistols
,
and
placing
them
near
him
,
to
be
ready
in
case
of
need
,
he
threw
himself
on
the
bed
and
speedily
fell
asleep
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
II
.
 
<EOS>
The
Burglary
at
Dollis
Hill
.
  
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
's
fears
were
not
,
however
,
groundless
.
<EOS>
Danger
,
in
the
form
he
apprehended
,
was
lurking
outside
:
nor
was
he
destined
to
enjoy
long
repose
.
<EOS>
On
receiving
the
warning
note
from
the
ostler
,
Jack
Sheppard
and
his
companion
left
Willesden
,
and
taking
--
as
a
blind
--
the
direction
of
Harrow
,
returned
at
night
-
fall
by
a
by
-
lane
to
Neasdon
,
and
put
up
at
a
little
public
-
house
called
the
Spotted
Dog
.
<EOS>
Here
they
remained
till
midnight
when
,
calling
for
their
reckoning
and
their
steeds
,
they
left
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
night
well
-
fitted
to
their
enterprise
,
calm
,
still
,
and
profoundly
dark
.
<EOS>
As
they
passed
beneath
the
thick
trees
that
shade
the
road
to
Dollis
Hill
,
the
gloom
was
almost
impenetrable
.
<EOS>
The
robbers
proceeded
singly
,
and
kept
on
the
grass
skirting
the
road
,
so
that
no
noise
was
made
by
their
horses
'
feet
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
neared
the
house
,
Jack
Sheppard
,
who
led
the
way
,
halted
and
addressed
his
companion
in
a
low
voice:--
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
half
like
this
job
,
Blueskin
,
"
he
said
;
"
it
always
went
against
the
grain
.
<EOS>
But
,
since
I
've
seen
the
friend
and
companion
of
my
childhood
,
Thames
Darrell
,
I
've
no
heart
for
it
.
<EOS>
Shall
we
turn
back
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
And
disappoint
Mr.
Wild
,
Captain
?
"
<EOS>
remonstrated
the
other
,
in
a
deferential
tone
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
this
is
a
pet
project
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
dangerous
to
thwart
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pish
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
:
"
I
do
n't
value
his
anger
a
straw
.
<EOS>
All
our
fraternity
are
afraid
of
him
;
but
_
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
_
laugh
at
his
threats
.
<EOS>
He
dare
n't
quarrel
with
me
:
and
if
he
does
,
let
him
look
to
himself
.
<EOS>
I
've
my
own
reasons
for
disliking
this
job
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
know
I
always
act
under
your
orders
,
Captain
,
"
returned
Blueskin
;
"
and
if
you
give
the
word
to
retreat
,
I
shall
obey
,
of
course
:
<EOS>
but
I
know
what
Edgeworth
Bess
will
say
when
we
go
home
empty
-
handed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
what
will
she
say
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
we
were
afraid
,
"
replied
the
other
;
"
but
never
mind
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
;
but
<EOS>
I
do
mind
her
,
"
cried
Jack
upon
whom
his
comrade
's
observation
had
produced
the
desired
effect
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
do
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
Captain
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
You
pledged
yourself
to
<EOS>
Mr.
Wild--
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
"
interrupted
Jack
;
"
and
I
never
yet
broke
an
engagement
.
<EOS>
Though
a
thief
,
Jack
Sheppard
is
a
man
of
his
word
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
he
is
,
"
acquiesced
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
meet
the
man
who
would
dare
to
gainsay
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
One
word
before
we
begin
,
Blueskin
,
"
said
Jack
,
authoritatively
;
"
in
case
the
family
should
be
alarmed
--
mind
,
no
violence
.
<EOS>
There
's
one
person
in
the
house
whom
I
would
n't
frighten
for
the
world
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wood
's
daughter
,
I
suppose
?
"
observed
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
hit
it
,
"
answered
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
say
you
to
carrying
her
off
,
Captain
?
"
suggested
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
've
a
fancy
for
the
girl
,
we
might
do
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
no
,
"
laughed
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Bess
would
n't
bear
a
rival
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
wish
to
do
old
Wood
a
friendly
turn
,
you
may
bring
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
mind
ridding
him
of
her
,
"
said
Blueskin
,
gruffly
;
"
<EOS>
and
if
she
comes
in
my
way
,
may
the
devil
seize
me
if
I
do
n't
make
short
work
with
her
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
forget
,
"
rejoined
Jack
,
sternly
,
"
<EOS>
I
've
just
said
I
'll
have
no
violence
--
<EOS>
mind
that
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
they
dismounted
;
and
fastening
their
horses
to
a
tree
,
proceeded
towards
the
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
so
dark
,
that
nothing
could
be
distinguished
except
the
heavy
masses
of
timber
by
which
the
premises
were
surrounded
;
but
as
they
advanced
,
lights
were
visible
in
some
of
the
windows
.
<EOS>
Presently
they
came
to
a
wall
,
on
the
other
side
of
which
the
dog
began
to
bark
violently
;
but
Blueskin
tossed
him
a
piece
of
prepared
meat
,
and
uttering
a
low
growl
,
he
became
silent
.
<EOS>
They
then
clambered
over
a
hedge
,
and
scaling
another
wall
,
got
into
the
garden
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
Treading
with
noiseless
step
over
the
soft
mould
,
they
soon
reached
the
building
.
<EOS>
Arrived
there
,
Jack
felt
about
for
a
particular
window
;
and
having
discovered
the
object
of
his
search
,
and
received
the
necessary
implements
from
his
companion
,
he
instantly
commenced
operations
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
seconds
,
the
shutter
flew
open,--then
<EOS>
the
window,--and
<EOS>
they
were
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
Jack
now
carefully
closed
the
shutters
,
while
Blueskin
struck
a
light
,
with
which
he
set
fire
to
a
candle
.
<EOS>
The
room
they
were
in
was
a
sort
of
closet
,
with
the
door
locked
outside
;
but
this
was
only
a
moment
's
obstacle
to
Jack
,
who
with
a
chisel
forced
back
the
bolt
.
<EOS>
The
operation
was
effected
with
so
much
rapidity
and
so
little
noise
,
that
even
if
any
one
had
been
on
the
alert
,
he
could
scarcely
have
detected
it
.
<EOS>
They
then
took
off
their
boots
,
and
crept
stealthily
up
stairs
,
treading
upon
the
point
of
their
toes
so
cautiously
,
that
not
a
board
creaked
beneath
their
weight
.
<EOS>
Pausing
at
each
door
on
the
landing
,
Jack
placed
his
ear
to
the
keyhole
,
and
listened
intently
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
by
the
breathing
which
room
Thames
occupied
,
he
speedily
contrived
to
fasten
him
in
.
<EOS>
He
then
tried
the
door
of
Mr.
Wood
's
bed
-
chamber
--
it
was
locked
,
with
the
key
left
in
it
.
<EOS>
This
occasioned
a
little
delay
;
but
Jack
,
whose
skill
as
a
workman
in
the
particular
line
he
had
chosen
was
unequalled
,
and
who
laughed
at
difficulties
,
speedily
cut
out
a
panel
by
means
of
a
centre
-
bit
and
knife
,
took
the
key
from
the
other
side
,
and
unlocked
the
door
.
<EOS>
Covering
his
face
with
a
crape
mask
,
and
taking
the
candle
from
his
associate
,
Jack
entered
the
room
;
and
,
pistol
in
hand
,
stepped
up
to
the
bed
,
and
approached
the
light
to
the
eyes
of
the
sleepers
.
<EOS>
The
loud
noise
proceeding
from
the
couch
proved
that
their
slumbers
were
deep
and
real
;
and
unconscious
of
the
danger
in
which
she
stood
,
Mrs.
Wood
turned
over
to
obtain
a
more
comfortable
position
.
<EOS>
During
this
movement
,
Jack
grasped
the
barrel
of
his
pistol
,
held
in
his
breath
,
and
motioned
to
Blueskin
,
who
bared
a
long
knife
,
to
keep
still
.
<EOS>
The
momentary
alarm
over
<EOS>
,
he
threw
a
piece
of
-
wash
leather
over
a
bureau
,
so
as
to
deaden
the
sound
,
and
instantly
broke
it
open
with
a
small
crow
-
bar
.
<EOS>
While
he
was
filling
his
pockets
with
golden
coin
from
this
store
,
Blueskin
had
pulled
the
plate
-
chest
from
under
the
bed
,
and
having
forced
it
open
,
began
filling
a
canvass
bag
with
its
contents,--silver
coffee
-
pots
,
chocolate
-
dishes
,
waiters
trays
,
tankards
,
goblets
,
and
candlesticks
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
supposed
that
these
articles
,
when
thrust
together
into
the
bag
,
would
have
jingled
;
but
these
skilful
practitioners
managed
matters
so
well
that
no
noise
was
made
.
<EOS>
After
rifling
the
room
of
everything
portable
,
including
some
of
Mrs.
Wood
's
ornaments
and
wearing
apparel
,
they
prepared
to
depart
.
<EOS>
Jack
then
intimated
his
intention
of
visiting
Winifred
's
chamber
,
in
which
several
articles
of
value
were
known
to
be
kept
;
but
as
,
notwithstanding
his
reckless
character
,
he
still
retained
a
feeling
of
respect
for
the
object
of
his
boyish
affections
,
he
would
not
suffer
Blueskin
to
accompany
him
,
so
he
commanded
him
to
keep
watch
over
the
sleepers
--
strictly
enjoining
him
,
however
,
to
do
them
no
injury
.
<EOS>
Again
having
recourse
to
the
centre
-
bit,--for
Winifred
's
door
was
locked,--Jack
had
nearly
cut
out
a
panel
,
when
a
sudden
outcry
was
raised
in
the
carpenter
's
chamber
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
a
struggle
was
heard
,
and
Blueskin
appeared
at
the
door
,
followed
by
Mrs.
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
instandly
extinguished
the
light
,
and
called
to
his
comrade
to
come
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
Blueskin
found
it
impossible
to
make
off,--at
least
with
the
spoil,--Mrs
.
<EOS>
Wood
having
laid
hold
of
the
canvass
-
bag
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
back
the
things
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
,
lady
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Help!--help
,
Mr.
Wood
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
go
!
"
<EOS>
thundered
<EOS>
Blueskin--"leave
go
--
<EOS>
you'd
better!"--and
he
held
the
sack
as
firmly
as
he
could
with
one
hand
,
while
with
the
other
he
searched
for
his
knife
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
wo
n't
leave
go
!
"
screamed
Mrs.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fire!--murder
--
thieves!--I've
got
one
of
'
em
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
"
cried
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
,
"
answered
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
This
she
-
devil
has
got
hold
of
the
sack
.
<EOS>
Leave
go
,
I
tell
you
!
"
<EOS>
and
he
forced
open
the
knife
with
his
teeth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Help!--murder!--thieves
!
"
screamed
Mrs.
Wood;--"Owen
--
Owen!--Thames
,
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Coming
!
"
cried
Mr.
Wood
,
leaping
from
the
bed
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
Help
--
I'll
hold
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
her
,
"
cried
Jack
,
darting
down
stairs
,
amid
a
furious
ringing
of
bells,--"the
house
<EOS>
is
alarmed,--follow
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Curses
light
on
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Blueskin
,
savagely
;
"
since
you
wo
n't
be
advised
,
take
your
fate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
seizing
her
by
the
hair
,
he
pulled
back
her
head
,
and
drew
the
knife
with
all
his
force
across
her
throat
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
dreadful
stifled
groan
,
and
she
fell
heavily
upon
the
landing
.
 
<EOS>
The
screams
of
the
unfortunate
woman
had
aroused
Thames
from
his
slumbers
.
<EOS>
Snatching
-
up
his
pistols
,
he
rushed
to
the
door
,
but
to
his
horror
found
it
fastened
.
<EOS>
He
heard
the
struggle
on
the
landing
,
the
fall
of
the
heavy
body
,
the
groan,--and
excited
almost
to
frenzy
by
his
fears
,
he
succeeded
in
forcing
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
several
of
the
terrified
domestics
appeared
with
lights
.
<EOS>
A
terrible
spectacle
was
presented
to
the
young
man
's
gaze:--the
floor
deluged
with
blood
--
the
mangled
and
lifeless
body
of
Mrs.
Wood,--Winifred
fainted
in
the
arms
of
a
female
attendant,--and
Wood
standing
beside
them
almost
in
a
state
of
distraction
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
in
a
few
minutes
,
had
this
happy
family
been
plunged
into
the
depths
of
misery
.
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
a
cry
was
raised
by
a
servant
from
below
,
that
the
robbers
were
flying
through
the
garden
.
<EOS>
Darting
to
a
window
looking
in
that
direction
,
Thames
threw
it
up
,
and
discharged
both
his
pistols
,
but
without
effect
.
<EOS>
In
another
minute
,
the
tramp
of
horses
'
feet
told
that
the
perpetrators
of
the
outrage
had
effected
their
escape
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
III
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
's
Quarrel
with
Jonathan
Wild
.
  
<EOS>
Scarcely
an
hour
after
the
horrible
occurrence
just
related
,
as
Jonathan
Wild
was
seated
in
the
audience
-
chamber
of
his
residence
at
the
Old
Bailey
,
occupied
,
like
Peachum
,
(
for
whose
portrait
he
sat
,
)
with
his
account
-
books
and
registers
,
he
was
interrupted
by
the
sudden
entrance
of
Quilt
Arnold
,
who
announced
Jack
Sheppard
and
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
cried
Wild
,
laying
down
his
pen
and
looking
up
with
a
smile
of
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
just
thinking
of
you
Jack
.
<EOS>
What
news
.
<EOS>
Have
you
done
the
trick
at
Dollis
Hill?--brought
off
the
swag
--
eh
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
answered
Jack
,
flinging
himself
sullenly
into
a
chair
,
"
I
've
not
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
how
's
this
?
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
.
"
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
failed
!
<EOS>
I
'd
not
believe
it
,
if
any
one
but
himself
told
me
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I'v
not
failed
,
"
returned
Jack
,
angrily
;
"
but
we
've
done
too
much
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
no
reader
of
riddles
,
"
said
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Speak
plainly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
this
speak
for
me
,
"
said
Sheppard
,
tossing
a
heavy
bag
of
money
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
generally
understand
that
language
.
<EOS>
There
's
more
than
I
undertook
to
bring
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
purchased
by
blood
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
have
you
cut
old
Wood
's
throat
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Wild
,
with
great
unconcern
,
as
he
took
up
the
bag
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
_
had
_
,
you
'd
not
have
seen
me
here
,
"
replied
Jack
,
sullenly
.
<EOS>
"
The
blood
that
has
been
spilt
is
that
of
his
wife
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
her
own
fault
,
"
observed
Blueskin
,
moodily
.
<EOS>
"
She
would
n't
let
me
go
.
<EOS>
I
did
it
in
self
-
defence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
care
not
why
you
did
it
,
"
said
Jack
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
We
work
together
no
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
Captain
,
"
remonstrated
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
'd
have
got
rid
of
your
ill
-
humour
by
this
time
.
<EOS>
You
know
as
well
as
I
do
that
it
was
accident
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Accident
or
not
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
;
"
you
're
no
longer
pall
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
this
is
my
reward
for
having
made
you
the
tip
-
top
cracksman
you
are
,
"
muttered
Blueskin;--"to
be
turned
off
at
a
moment
's
notice
,
because
I
silenced
a
noisy
woman
.
<EOS>
It
's
too
hard
.
<EOS>
Think
better
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
mind
's
made
up
,
"
rejoined
Jack
,
coldly,--"we
part
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not
go
,
"
answered
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
I
love
you
like
a
son
,
and
will
follow
you
like
a
dog
.
<EOS>
You
'd
not
know
what
to
do
without
me
,
and
sha
n't
drive
me
off
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
remarked
Jonathan
,
who
had
paid
little
attention
to
the
latter
part
of
the
conversation
:
"
this
is
an
awkward
business
certainly
:
but
we
must
do
the
best
we
can
in
it
.
<EOS>
You
must
keep
out
of
the
way
till
it
's
blown
over
.
<EOS>
I
can
accommodate
you
below
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
require
it
,
"
returned
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
tired
of
the
life
I
'm
leading
.
<EOS>
I
shall
quit
it
and
go
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
with
you
,
"
said
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
either
of
you
go
,
you
will
ask
my
permission
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
coolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
!
"
exclaimed
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
say
you
will
interfere--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
say
this
,
"
interrupted
Wild
,
with
contemptuous
calmness
,
"
that
I
'll
neither
allow
you
to
leave
England
nor
the
profession
you
've
engaged
in
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
allow
you
to
be
honest
even
if
you
could
be
so,--which
<EOS>
I
doubt
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
slave
--
and
such
you
shall
continue
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Slave
?
<EOS>
"
echoed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dare
to
disobey
<EOS>
,
"
continued
Jonathan
:
"
neglect
my
orders
,
and
I
will
hang
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
started
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
"
he
cried
,
restraining
himself
with
difficulty
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
time
you
should
know
whom
you
have
to
deal
with
.
<EOS>
Henceforth
,
I
utterly
throw
off
the
yoke
you
have
laid
upon
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
neither
stir
hand
nor
foot
for
you
more
.
<EOS>
Attempt
to
molest
me
,
and
I
split
.
<EOS>
You
are
more
in
my
power
than
I
am
in
yours
.
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
is
a
match
for
Jonathan
Wild
,
any
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
he
is
,
"
added
Blueskin
,
approvingly
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
smiled
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
motive
alone
shall
induce
me
to
go
on
with
you
,
"
said
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
asked
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
youth
whom
you
delivered
to
Van
Galgebrok,--Thames
Darrell
,
is
returned
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
!
"
cried
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
thrown
overboard
,
and
perished
at
sea
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
alive
,
"
replied
Jack
,
"
I
have
seen
him
,
and
might
have
conversed
with
him
if
I
had
chosen
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
know
you
can
restore
him
to
his
rights
,
if
you
choose
.
<EOS>
Do
so
;
and
I
am
yours
as
heretofore
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
answer
!
"
cried
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
or
no
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
no
terms
with
you
,
"
rejoined
Wild
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
defied
me
,
and
shall
feel
my
power
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
useful
to
me
,
or
I
would
not
have
spared
you
thus
long
.
<EOS>
I
swore
to
hang
you
two
years
ago
,
but
I
deferred
my
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Deferred
!
"
echoed
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
out
,
"
said
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
You
came
hither
under
my
protection
,
and
you
shall
depart
freely,--nay
,
more
<EOS>
,
you
shall
have
an
hour
's
grace
.
<EOS>
After
that
time
,
I
shall
place
my
setters
on
your
heels
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
prevent
my
departure
,
"
replied
Jack
,
dauntlessly
,
"
and
therefore
your
offer
is
no
favour
.
<EOS>
But
I
tell
you
in
return
,
I
shall
take
no
pains
to
hide
myself
.
<EOS>
If
you
want
me
,
you
know
where
to
find
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
An
hour
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
looking
at
his
watch,--"remember
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
send
for
me
to
the
Cross
Shovels
in
the
Mint
,
where
I
'm
going
with
Blueskin
,
I
will
surrender
myself
without
resistance
,
"
returned
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
spare
the
officers
a
labour
then
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
I
settle
this
business
,
Captain
,
"
muttered
Blueskin
,
drawing
a
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
harm
him
,
"
said
Jack
,
carelessly
:
"
he
dares
not
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
left
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Blueskin
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
as
that
worthy
was
about
to
follow
,
"
I
advise
you
to
remain
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
answered
the
ruffian
,
moodily
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
arrest
him
,
you
must
arrest
me
also
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
will
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
seating
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
and
his
comrade
went
to
the
Mint
,
where
he
was
joined
by
Edgeworth
Bess
,
with
whom
he
sat
down
most
unconcernedly
to
supper
.
<EOS>
His
revelry
,
however
,
was
put
an
end
at
the
expiration
of
the
time
mentioned
by
Jonathan
,
by
the
entrance
of
a
posse
of
constables
with
Quilt
Arnold
and
Abraham
Mendez
at
their
head
.
<EOS>
Jack
,
to
the
surprise
of
all
his
companions
,
at
once
surrendered
himself
:
but
Blueskin
would
have
made
a
fierce
resistance
,
and
attempted
a
rescue
if
he
had
not
been
ordered
by
his
leader
to
desist
.
<EOS>
He
then
made
off
.
<EOS>
Edgeworth
Bess
,
who
passed
for
Sheppard
's
wife
,
was
secured
.
<EOS>
They
were
hurried
before
a
magistrate
,
and
charged
by
Jonathan
Wild
with
various
robberies
;
but
,
as
Jack
Sheppard
stated
that
he
had
most
important
disclosures
to
make
,
as
well
as
charges
to
bring
forward
against
his
accuser
,
he
was
committed
with
his
female
companion
to
the
New
Prison
in
Clerkenwell
for
further
examination
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
IV
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
's
Escape
from
the
New
Prison
.
  
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
Jack
Sheppard
's
desperate
character
,
it
was
judged
expedient
by
the
keeper
of
the
New
Prison
to
load
him
with
fetters
of
unusual
weight
,
and
to
place
him
in
a
cell
which
,
from
its
strength
and
security
,
was
called
the
Newgate
Ward
.
<EOS>
The
ward
in
which
he
was
confined
,
was
about
six
yards
in
length
,
and
three
in
width
,
and
in
height
,
might
be
about
twelve
feet
.
<EOS>
The
windows
which
were
about
nine
feet
from
the
floor
,
had
no
glass
;
but
were
secured
by
thick
iron
bars
,
and
an
oaken
beam
.
<EOS>
Along
the
floor
ran
an
iron
bar
to
which
Jack
's
chain
was
attached
,
so
that
he
could
move
along
it
from
one
end
of
the
chamber
to
the
other
.
<EOS>
No
prisoner
except
Edgeworth
Bess
was
placed
in
the
same
cell
with
him
.
<EOS>
Jack
was
in
excellent
spirits
;
and
by
his
wit
,
drollery
and
agreeable
demeanour
,
speedily
became
a
great
favourite
with
the
turnkey
,
who
allowed
him
every
indulgence
consistent
with
his
situation
.
<EOS>
The
report
of
his
detention
caused
an
immense
sensation
.
<EOS>
Numberless
charges
were
preferred
against
him
,
amongst
others
,
information
was
lodged
of
the
robbery
at
Dollis
Hill
,
and
murder
of
Mrs.
Wood
,
and
a
large
reward
offered
for
the
apprehension
of
Blueskin
;
and
as
,
in
addition
to
this
,
Jack
had
threatened
to
impeach
Wild
,
his
next
examination
was
looked
forward
to
with
the
greatest
interest
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
before
this
examination
was
appointed
to
take
place
--
the
third
of
the
prisoner
's
detention
--
an
old
man
,
respectably
dressed
,
requested
permission
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
Jack
's
friends
were
allowed
to
visit
him
,
;
but
as
he
had
openly
avowed
his
intention
of
attempting
an
escape
,
their
proceedings
were
narrowly
watched
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
was
conducted
to
Jack
's
cell
by
the
turnkey
,
who
remained
near
him
during
their
interview
.
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
be
a
stranger
to
the
prisoner
,
and
the
sole
motive
of
his
visit
,
curiosity
.
<EOS>
After
a
brief
conversation
,
which
Sheppard
sustained
with
his
accustomed
liveliness
,
the
old
man
turned
to
Bess
and
addressed
a
few
words
of
common
-
place
gallantry
to
her
.
<EOS>
While
this
was
going
on
,
Jack
suddenly
made
a
movement
which
attracted
the
turnkey
's
attention
;
and
during
that
interval
the
old
man
slipped
some
articles
wrapped
in
a
handkerchief
into
Bess
's
hands
,
who
instantly
secreted
them
in
her
bosom
.
<EOS>
The
turnkey
looked
round
the
next
moment
,
but
the
manoeuvre
escaped
his
observation
.
<EOS>
After
a
little
further
discourse
the
old
man
took
his
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Left
alone
with
Edgeworth
Bess
<EOS>
,
Jack
burst
into
a
loud
laugh
of
exultation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Blueskin
's
a
friend
in
need
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
His
disguise
was
capital
;
but
I
detected
it
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Has
he
given
you
the
tools
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
,
"
replied
Bess
,
producing
the
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bravo
,
"
cried
Sheppard
,
examining
its
contents
,
which
proved
to
be
a
file
,
a
chisel
,
two
or
three
gimblets
,
and
a
piercer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
shall
find
it
's
not
easy
to
detain
me
.
<EOS>
As
sure
as
he
is
now
living
,
I
'll
pay
him
a
visit
in
the
Old
Bailey
before
morning
.
<EOS>
And
then
I
'll
pay
off
old
scores
.
<EOS>
It
's
almost
worth
while
being
sent
to
prison
to
have
the
pleasure
of
escaping
.
<EOS>
I
shall
now
be
able
to
test
my
skill
.
"
<EOS>
And
running
on
in
this
way
,
he
carefully
concealed
the
tools
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
the
turnkey
entertained
any
suspicion
of
the
old
man
,
Jack
could
not
tell
,
but
that
night
he
was
more
than
usually
rigorous
in
his
search
;
and
having
carefully
examined
the
prisoners
and
finding
nothing
to
excite
his
suspicions
,
he
departed
tolerably
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
certain
he
should
be
disturbed
no
more
,
Jack
set
to
work
,
and
with
the
aid
of
the
file
in
less
than
an
hour
had
freed
himself
from
his
fetters
.
<EOS>
With
Bess
's
assistance
he
then
climbed
up
to
the
window
,
which
,
as
has
just
been
stated
,
was
secured
by
iron
bars
of
great
thickness
crossed
by
a
stout
beam
of
oak
.
<EOS>
The
very
sight
of
these
impediments
,
would
have
appalled
a
less
courageous
spirit
than
Sheppard's
--
but
nothing
could
daunt
him
.
<EOS>
To
work
then
he
went
,
and
with
wonderful
industry
filed
off
two
of
the
iron
bars
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
completed
this
operation
,
the
file
broke
.
<EOS>
The
oaken
beam
,
nine
inches
in
thickness
,
was
now
the
sole
but
most
formidable
obstacle
to
his
flight
.
<EOS>
With
his
gimblet
he
contrived
to
bore
a
number
of
holes
<EOS>
so
close
together
that
at
last
one
end
of
the
bar
,
being
completely
pierced
through
,
yielded
;
and
pursuing
the
same
with
the
other
extremity
,
it
fell
out
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
This
last
operation
was
so
fatiguing
,
that
for
a
short
time
he
was
obliged
to
pause
to
recover
the
use
of
his
fingers
.
<EOS>
He
then
descended
;
and
having
induced
Bess
to
take
off
some
part
of
her
clothing
,
he
tore
the
gown
and
petticoat
into
shreds
and
twisted
them
into
a
sort
of
rope
which
he
fastened
to
the
lower
bars
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
With
some
difficulty
he
contrived
to
raise
her
to
the
window
,
and
with
still
greater
difficulty
to
squeeze
her
through
it
--
her
bulk
being
much
greater
than
his
own
.
<EOS>
He
then
made
a
sort
of
running
noose
,
passed
it
over
her
body
,
and
taking
firmly
hold
of
the
bars
,
prepared
to
guide
her
descent
.
<EOS>
But
Bess
could
scarcely
summon
resolution
enough
to
hazard
the
experiment
;
and
it
was
only
on
Jack
's
urgent
intreaties
,
and
even
threats
,
that
she
could
be
prevailed
on
to
trust
herself
to
the
frail
tenure
of
the
rope
he
had
prepared
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
she
threw
herself
off
;
and
Jack
carefully
guiding
the
rope
she
landed
in
safety
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
moment
he
was
by
her
side
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
great
point
was
still
unaccomplished
.
<EOS>
They
had
escaped
from
the
New
Prison
,
it
is
true
;
but
the
wall
of
Clerkenwell
Bridewell
,
by
which
that
jail
was
formerly
surrounded
,
and
which
was
more
than
twenty
feet
high
,
and
protected
by
formidable
and
bristling
_
chevaux
de
frise
_
,
remained
to
be
scaled
.
<EOS>
Jack
,
however
,
had
an
expedient
for
mastering
this
difficulty
.
<EOS>
He
ventured
to
the
great
gates
,
and
by
inserting
his
gimblets
into
the
wood
at
intervals
,
so
as
to
form
points
upon
which
he
could
rest
his
foot
,
he
contrived
,
to
ascend
them
;
and
when
at
the
top
,
having
fastened
a
portion
of
his
dress
to
the
spikes
,
he
managed
,
not
without
considerable
risk
,
to
draw
up
his
female
companion
.
<EOS>
Once
over
the
iron
spikes
,
Bess
exhibited
no
reluctance
to
be
let
down
on
the
other
side
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
Having
seen
his
mistress
safe
down
,
Jack
instantly
descended
,
leaving
the
best
part
of
his
clothes
,
as
a
memorial
of
his
flight
,
to
the
jailor
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
he
effected
his
escape
from
the
New
Prison
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
V.
 
<EOS>
The
Disguise
.
  
<EOS>
In
a
hollow
in
the
meadows
behind
the
prison
whence
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
had
<EOS>
escaped,--for
,
at
this
time
,
the
whole
of
the
now
thickly
-
peopled
district
north
of
Clerkenwell
Bridewell
was
open
country
,
stretching
out
in
fertile
fields
in
the
direction
of
Islington
--
and
about
a
quarter
of
a
mile
off
,
stood
a
solitary
hovel
,
known
as
Black
Mary
's
Hole
.
<EOS>
This
spot
,
which
still
retains
its
name
,
acquired
the
appellation
from
an
old
crone
who
lived
there
,
and
who
,
in
addition
to
a
very
equivocal
character
for
honesty
,
enjoyed
the
reputation
of
being
a
witch
.
<EOS>
Without
inquiring
into
the
correctness
of
the
latter
part
of
the
story
,
it
may
be
sufficient
to
state
,
that
Black
Mary
was
a
person
in
whom
Jack
Sheppard
thought
he
could
confide
,
and
,
as
Edgeworth
Bess
was
incapable
of
much
further
exertion
,
he
determined
to
leave
her
in
the
old
woman
's
care
till
the
following
night
,
while
he
shifted
for
himself
and
fulfilled
his
design
--
for
,
however
rash
or
hazardous
a
project
might
be
,
if
once
conceived
,
Jack
always
executed
it,--of
visiting
Jonathan
Wild
at
his
house
in
the
Old
Bailey
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
precisely
two
o'clock
on
the
morning
of
Whit
-
monday
,
the
25th
of
May
1724
,
when
the
remarkable
escape
before
detailed
was
completed
:
and
,
though
it
wanted
full
two
hours
to
daybreak
,
the
glimmer
of
a
waning
moon
prevented
it
from
being
totally
dark
.
<EOS>
Casting
a
hasty
glance
,
as
he
was
about
to
turn
an
angle
of
the
wall
,
at
the
great
gates
and
upper
windows
of
the
prison
,
and
perceiving
no
symptoms
of
pursuit
,
Jack
proceeded
towards
the
hovel
at
a
very
deliberate
pace
,
carefully
assisting
his
female
companion
over
every
obstacle
in
the
road
,
and
bearing
her
in
his
arms
when
,
as
was
more
than
once
the
case
,
she
sank
from
fright
and
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
he
crossed
one
or
two
public
gardens
and
a
bowling
-
green,--the
neighbourhood
of
Clerkenwell
then
abounded
in
such
places
of
amusement,--passed
the
noted
Ducking
Pond
,
where
Black
Mary
had
been
frequently
immersed
;
and
,
striking
off
to
the
left
across
the
fields
,
arrived
in
a
few
minutes
at
his
destination
.
 
<EOS>
Descending
the
hollow
,
or
rather
excavation,--for
<EOS>
it
was
an
old
disused
clay
-
pit
,
at
the
bottom
of
which
the
cottage
was
situated,--he
speedily
succeeded
in
arousing
the
ancient
sibyl
,
and
having
committed
Edgeworth
Bess
to
her
care
,
with
a
promise
of
an
abundant
reward
in
case
she
watched
diligently
over
her
safety
,
and
attended
to
her
comforts
till
his
return,--to
all
which
Black
Mary
<EOS>
readily
agreed,--he
departed
with
a
heart
lightened
of
half
its
load
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
's
first
object
was
to
seek
out
Blueskin
,
whom
he
had
no
doubt
he
should
find
at
the
New
Mint
,
at
Wapping
,
for
the
Old
Mint
no
longer
afforded
a
secure
retreat
to
the
robber
;
and
,
with
this
view
,
he
made
the
best
of
his
way
along
a
bye
-
lane
leading
towards
Hockley
-
in
-
the
-
Hole
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
was
alarmed
by
the
tramp
of
a
horse
,
which
seemed
to
be
rapidly
approaching
,
and
he
had
scarcely
time
to
leap
the
hedge
and
conceal
himself
behind
a
tree
,
when
a
tall
man
,
enveloped
in
an
ample
cloak
,
with
his
hat
pulled
over
his
brows
,
rode
by
at
full
speed
.
<EOS>
Another
horseman
followed
quickly
at
the
heels
of
the
first
;
but
just
as
he
passed
the
spot
where
Jack
stood
,
his
steed
missed
its
footing
,
and
fell
.
<EOS>
Either
ignorant
of
the
accident
,
or
heedless
of
it
,
the
foremost
horseman
pursued
his
way
without
even
turning
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
Conceiving
the
opportunity
too
favourable
to
be
lost
,
Jack
sprang
suddenly
over
the
hedge
,
and
before
the
man
,
who
was
floundering
on
the
ground
with
one
foot
in
the
stirrup
,
could
extricate
himself
from
his
embarrassing
position
,
secured
his
pistols
,
which
he
drew
from
the
holsters
,
and
held
them
to
his
head
.
<EOS>
The
fellow
swore
lustily
,
in
a
voice
which
Jack
instantly
recognised
as
that
of
Quilt
Arnold
,
and
vainly
attempted
to
rise
and
draw
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dog
!
"
thundered
Sheppard
,
putting
the
muzzle
of
the
pistol
so
close
to
the
janizary
's
ear
,
that
the
touch
of
the
cold
iron
made
him
start
,
"
do
n't
you
know
me
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Blood
and
thunder
!
"
exclaimed
Quilt
,
opening
his
eyes
with
astonishment
.
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't
be
Captain
Sheppard
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
<EOS>
_
is
_
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Jack
;
"
and
you
had
better
have
met
the
devil
on
your
road
than
me
.
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
what
I
said
when
you
took
me
at
the
Mint
four
days
ago
?
<EOS>
I
told
you
my
turn
would
come
.
<EOS>
It
_
has
_
<EOS>
come,--and
sooner
than
you
expected
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
find
,
Captain
,
"
rejoined
Quilt
,
submissively
;
"
but
you
're
too
noble
-
hearted
to
take
advantage
of
my
situation
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
acted
for
others
,
and
not
for
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
"
and
therefore
I
spare
your
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
sure
you
would
n't
injure
me
,
Captain
,
"
remarked
Quilt
,
in
a
wheedling
tone
,
while
he
felt
about
for
his
sword
;
"
you
're
far
too
brave
to
strike
a
fallen
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
traitor
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
who
had
noticed
the
movement
;
"
make
such
another
attempt
,
and
it
shall
cost
you
your
life
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
unbuckled
the
belt
to
which
the
janizary
's
hanger
was
attached
,
and
fastened
it
to
his
own
girdle
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
he
continued
,
sternly
,
"
was
it
your
master
who
has
just
ridden
by
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
answered
Quilt
,
sullenly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
,
then
?
"
demanded
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Speak
,
or
I
fire
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
you
_
will
_
have
it
,
it
's
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Jack
,
in
amazement
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
with
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
long
story
,
Captain
,
and
I
've
no
breath
to
tell
it,--unless
<EOS>
you
choose
to
release
me
,
"
rejoined
Quilt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
up
,
then
,
"
said
Jack
,
freeing
his
foot
from
the
stirrup
.
<EOS>
"
Now
--
begin
.
"
 
<EOS>
Quilt
,
however
,
seemed
unwilling
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
sorry
to
proceed
to
extremities
,
"
continued
Sheppard
,
again
raising
the
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
since
you
force
me
to
betray
my
master
's
secrets
,
"
replied
Quilt
,
sullenly
,
"
I
've
ridden
express
to
Manchester
to
deliver
a
message
to
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Respecting
Thames
Darrell
?
"
observed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
the
devil
did
you
happen
to
guess
that
?
"
cried
the
janizary
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
,
"
replied
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
to
find
I
'm
right
.
<EOS>
You
informed
Sir
Rowland
that
Thames
Darrell
was
returned
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Exactly
so
,
"
replied
Quilt
,
"
and
he
instantly
decided
upon
returning
to
London
with
me
.
<EOS>
We
've
ridden
post
all
the
way
,
and
I
'm
horribly
tired
,
or
you
would
n't
have
mastered
me
so
easily
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
replied
Jack
,
to
whom
an
idea
had
suddenly
occurred
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
Sir
,
I
'll
trouble
you
for
your
coat
.
<EOS>
I
've
left
mine
on
the
spikes
of
the
New
Prison
,
and
must
borrow
yours
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
surely
you
ca
n't
be
in
earnest
,
Captain
.
<EOS>
You
would
n't
rob
Mr.
Wild
's
chief
janizary
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
rob
Mr.
Wild
himself
if
I
met
him
,
"
retorted
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
off
with
it
,
sirrah
,
or
I
'll
blow
out
your
brains
,
in
the
first
place
,
and
strip
you
afterwards
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
rather
than
you
should
commit
so
great
<EOS>
a
crime
,
Captain
<EOS>
,
here
it
is
,
"
replied
Quilt
,
handing
him
the
garment
in
question
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Anything
else
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
waistcoat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
Zounds
!
<EOS>
Captain
,
I
shall
get
my
death
of
cold
.
<EOS>
I
was
in
hopes
you
'd
be
content
with
my
hat
and
wig
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
require
them
as
well
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
;
"
and
your
boots
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
boots
!
<EOS>
Fire
and
fury
!
<EOS>
They
wo
n't
fit
you
;
they
are
too
large
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
how
am
I
to
ride
home
without
them
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
distress
yourself
,
"
returned
Jack
,
"
you
shall
walk
.
<EOS>
Now
,
"
he
added
,
as
his
commands
were
reluctantly
obeyed
,
"
help
me
on
with
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
Quilt
knelt
down
,
as
if
he
meant
to
comply
;
but
,
watching
his
opportunity
,
he
made
a
sudden
grasp
at
Sheppard
's
leg
,
with
the
intention
of
overthrowing
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
Jack
was
too
nimble
for
him
.
<EOS>
Striking
out
his
foot
,
he
knocked
half
a
dozen
teeth
down
the
janizary
's
throat
;
and
,
seconding
the
kick
with
a
blow
on
the
head
from
the
butt
-
end
of
the
pistol
,
stretched
him
,
senseless
and
bleeding
on
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
Like
master
like
man
,
"
observed
Jack
as
he
rolled
the
inanimate
body
to
the
side
of
the
road
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
Jonathan
Wild
's
confidential
servant
what
could
be
expected
but
treachery
?
"
 
With
this
,
he
proceeded
to
dress
himself
in
Quilt
Arnold
's
clothes
,
pulled
the
wig
over
his
face
and
eyes
so
as
completely
to
conceal
his
features
,
slouched
the
hat
over
his
brows
,
drew
the
huge
boots
above
his
knees
,
and
muffled
himself
up
in
the
best
way
he
could
.
<EOS>
On
searching
the
coat
,
he
found
,
amongst
other
matters
,
a
mask
,
a
key
,
and
a
pocket
-
book
.
<EOS>
The
latter
appeared
to
contain
several
papers
,
which
Jack
carefully
put
by
,
in
the
hope
that
they
might
turn
out
of
importance
in
a
scheme
of
vengeance
which
he
meditated
against
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
He
then
mounted
the
jaded
hack
,
which
had
long
since
regained
its
legs
,
and
was
quietly
browsing
the
grass
at
the
road
-
side
,
and
,
striking
spurs
into
its
side
,
rode
off
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
encountered
Sir
Rowland
,
who
,
having
missed
his
attendant
,
had
returned
to
look
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
has
delayed
you
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
knight
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
horse
has
had
a
fall
,
"
replied
Jack
,
assuming
to
perfection
--
<EOS>
for
he
was
a
capital
<EOS>
mimic,--the
tones
of
Quilt
Arnold
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
some
time
before
I
could
get
him
to
move
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
fancied
I
heard
voices
,
"
rejoined
Sir
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
did
I
,
"
answered
Jack
;
"
we
had
better
move
on
.
<EOS>
This
is
a
noted
place
for
highwaymen
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
told
me
that
the
rascal
who
has
so
long
been
the
terror
of
the
town
--
Jack
Sheppard
--
was
in
custody
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
he
is
,
"
returned
Jack
;
"
but
there
's
no
saying
how
long
he
may
remain
so
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
there
are
greater
rascals
than
Jack
Sheppard
at
liberty
,
Sir
Rowland
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
made
no
reply
,
but
angrily
quickened
his
pace
.
<EOS>
The
pair
then
descended
Saffron
-
hill
,
threaded
Field
-
lane
,
and
,
entering
Holborn
,
passed
over
the
little
bridge
which
then
crossed
the
muddy
waters
of
Fleet
-
ditch
,
mounted
Snow
-
hill
,
and
soon
drew
in
the
bridle
before
Jonathan
Wild
's
door
.
<EOS>
Aware
of
Quilt
Arnold
's
mode
of
proceeding
,
Jack
instantly
dismounted
,
and
,
instead
of
knocking
,
opened
the
door
with
the
pass

key
.
<EOS>
The
porter
instantly
made
his
appearance
,
and
Sheppard
ordered
him
to
take
care
of
the
horses
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
what
sort
of
journey
have
you
had
,
Quilt
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
man
as
he
hastened
to
assist
Sir
Rowland
to
dismount
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
we
've
lost
no
time
,
as
you
perceive
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Is
the
governor
within
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
you
'll
find
him
in
the
audience
-

.
<EOS>
He
has
got
Blueskin
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
indeed
!
<EOS>
what
's
he
doing

?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
to
buy
off
Jack
Sheppard
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
replied

fellow
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wild
has
made

,
and
,
when

's

,
all

on
earth
wo
n't

.
<EOS>
Jack
will
be
tried
to
-
morrow
;
and
,
as

my
name
's
Obadiah
Lemon
he
'll

at
the
King's
-
Head
,
"
pointing
to
Newgate
,
"
over

way
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
we
shall
see
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Look
to
the
horses
,
Obadiah
.
<EOS>
This
way
,
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
familiar
as
Quilt
Arnold
himself
with
every

of
Wild
's

,
as
well
as
with
the
ways
of
its

,
Jack
,
without
a
moment
's

,
took

which

in

,
and
led

up

.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
audience
-
chamber
,
he
set
down

light
upon

,
threw

,
and
announced
in

,
but

the
perfect

of

Rowland
Trenchard
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
who
was
engaged
in
conversation
with
Blueskin
,
instantly
arose
,
and
bowed
with
cringing

to
the
knight
.
<EOS>
The
latter
haughtily
returned
his
salutation
,
and
flung
himself
,
as
if

,
into
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
arrived
sooner
than
I
expected
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
observed
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lost
no
time
on
the
road
--
eh!--I
did
n't
expect
you
till
to
-
morrow
at
the
earliest
.
<EOS>
Excuse
me
an
instant
while
I
dismiss
this
person.--You've
your
answer
,
Blueskin
,
"
he
added
,
pushing
that
individual
,
who
seemed

,
towards

;
"
it
's
useless
to
urge
the
matter
further
.
<EOS>
Jack
is
registered
in
the
Black
Book
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
One
word
before
I
go
,
"
urged
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a

,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
talk
as
long
as
an
Old
Bailey
counsel
,
you
'll
not
alter
my
determination
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
my
life
do
as
well
as
his
?
"
supplicated

.
 
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
,
doubtfully
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
would
surrender
yourself
--
eh
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
surrender
myself
at
once
,
if
you
'll
engage
to
bring
him
off
;
and
you
'll
get
the
reward
from
old
Wood
.
<EOS>
It
's
two
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
Recollect
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Faithful
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
forgive
him
his
disobedience
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
do
it
?
"
<EOS>
persisted
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Wild
;
"
and
I
've
only
listened
to
your
absurd
proposal
to
see
how
far
your
insane
attachment
to
this
lad
would
carry
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
do
_
love
him
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
"
and
that
's
the
long
and
short
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
've
taught

all
he
can
do
;
and
there
is
n't
his
fellow
,
and
never
will
be
again
.
<EOS>
I
've
seen
many
a
clever

,
but
never
one
like

.
<EOS>
If
you
hang
Jack
Sheppard
,
you
'll
cut

the
flower
<EOS>
o
'
the
purfession
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
not
believe
it
of

.
<EOS>
It
's

to
read
him

,
and

;
but
you
've

for

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
,
"
rejoined
the
thief
-
taker
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
growled
Blueskin
,
"
you
've

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
my
warning
,
"
retorted
Wild
.
"
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Blueskin
,
"
whispered

,
in

,

,
"
wait
without
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Power
o
'
mercy
!
"
cried
Blueskin
starting
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Jonathan
,
harshly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothin'--nothin
'
,
"
returned
Blueskin
;
"
only
I
thought--
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
saw
the
hangman
,
no

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Take
courage
,
man
;
it

Quilt
Arnold
.
<EOS>
Come
,

.
<EOS>
Do

Mr.
Wild
's
busy
.
"
<EOS>
And

,

,
"
Conceal

,
and
be

call
.
"
 
<EOS>
Blueskin
nodded
,
and
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
Jack
affected
to
close
the
door
,
but
left
it
slightly
ajar
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
say
to
him
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jonathan
,
suspiciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
advised
him
not
to

farther
about
Jack
Sheppard
,
"
answered
the
supposed

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
seems
infatuated
about
the
lad
,
"
observed
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
obliged
to
hang
him
to
keep
him
company
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
he
continued
,
turning
to
the
knight
,
"
to
our
own
concerns
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
long
time
since
we
met
,
eight
years
and
more
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
've
enjoyed
your
health
.
'
<EOS>
Slife
!
<EOS>
you
are
wonderfully
altered
.
<EOS>
I
should
scarcely
have
known
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
knight
was
indeed
greatly
changed
.
<EOS>
Though
not
much
passed
the
middle
term
of
life
,
he
seemed
prematurely
stricken
with
old
age
.
<EOS>
His
frame
was
wasted
,
and
slightly
bent
;
his
eyes
were
hollow
,
his
complexion
haggard
,
and
his
beard
,
which
had
remained
unshorn
during
his
hasty
journey
,
was
perfectly
white
.
<EOS>
His
manner
,
however
,
was
as
stern
and
haughty
as
ever
,
and
his
glances
retained
their
accustomed
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
come
hither
to
consult
you
as
to
the
state
of
my
health
,
Sir
,
"
he
observed
,
displeased
by
Jonathan
's
allusion
to
the
alteration
in
his
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
no
doubt
surprised
by
the
unlooked
-
for
intelligence
I
sent
you
of
your
nephew
's
return
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Was
it
<EOS>
_
unlooked
-
for
_
<EOS>
on
your
part
?
"
demanded
the
knight
,
distrustfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
my
soul
,
yes
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
as
soon
have
expected
the
bones
of
Tom
Sheppard
to
reunite
themselves
and
walk
out
of
that
case
,
as
Thames
Darrell
to
return
.
<EOS>
The
skipper
,
Van
Galgebrok
,
affirmed
to
me,--nay
,
gave
me
the
additional

of
two
of
his
crew,--that
he
was
thrown
overboard
.
<EOS>
But
it
appears
he
was
picked
up
by
fishermen
,
and
carried
to
France
,
where
he
has
remained
ever
since
,
and
where
it
would
have
been
well
for
him
if
he
had
remained
altogether
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
him
?
"
asked
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
replied
Wild
;
"
and
nothing
but
the
evidence
of
my
senses
would
have
made
me
believe
he
was
living
,
after
the
positive
assurance
I
received
to
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
He
is
at
present
with
Mr.
Wood,--the
person
whom
you
may
remember
adopted
him,--at
Dollis
Hill
,
near
Willesden
;
and
it
's
a
singular
but
fortunate
circumstance
,
so
far
as
we
are
concerned
,
that
Mrs.
Wood
chanced
to
be
murdered
by
Blueskin
,
the
fellow
who
just
left
the
room
,
on
the
very
night
of
his
return
,
as
it
has
thrown
the
house
into
such
confusion
,
and
so
distracted
them
,
that
he
has
had
no
time
as
yet
for
hostile
movements
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
course
do
you
propose
to
pursue
in
reference
to
him
?
"
asked
Sir
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
plan
is
a
very
simple
one
,
"
rejoined
the
thief
-
taker
smiling
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
treat
him
as
you
treated
his
father
,
Sir
Rowland
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Murder
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Trenchard
shuddering
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
murder
him
,
if
you
like
the
term
,
"
returned
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
call
it
putting
him
out
of
the
way
.
<EOS>
But
no
matter
how
you
phrase
it
,
the
end
is
the
same
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
consent
to
it
,
"
replied
Sir
Rowland
firmly
.
"
<EOS>
Since
the
sea
has
spared
him
,
I
will
spare
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
in
vain
to
struggle
against
the
arm
of
fate
.
<EOS>
I
will
shed
no
more
blood
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
perish
upon
the
gibbet
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Flight
is
still
left
me
,
"
replied
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
escape
to
France
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
do
you
think
I
'll
allow
you
to
depart
,
"
cried
Jonathan
in
a
menacing
tone
,
"
and
compromise
_
<EOS>
my
_
safety
?
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
<EOS>
We
are
linked
together
in
this
matter
,
and
must
go
through
with
it
.
<EOS>
You
cannot
--
shall
not
retreat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Death
and
hell
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Sir
Rowland
,
rising
and
drawing
his
sword
;
"
do
you
think
you
can
shackle
my
free
will
,
villain
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
this
particular
instance
I
do
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
calmly
,
"
because
you
are
wholly
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
But
be
patient
,
I
am
your
fast
friend
.
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
MUST
die
.
<EOS>
Our
mutual
safety
requires
it
.
<EOS>
Leave
the
means
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
More
blood
!
<EOS>
more
blood
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Trenchard
,
passing
his
hand
with
agony
across
his
brow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
never
banish
those
horrible
phantoms
from
my
couch
--
the
father
with
his
bleeding
breast
and
dripping
hair!--the
mother
with
her
wringing
hands
and
looks
of
vengeance
and
reproach!--And
<EOS>
must
another
be
added
to
their
number
--
their
son
!
<EOS>
Horror!--let
<EOS>
me
be
spared
this
new
crime
!
<EOS>
And
yet
the
gibbet
--
my
name
tarnished
--
my
escutcheon
blotted
by
the
hangman!--No
,
I
can
not
submit
to
that
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
not
,
"
observed
Jonathan
,
who
had
some
practice
in
the
knight
's
moods
,
and
knew
how
to
humour
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
miserable
weakness
to
be
afraid
of
bloodshed.--The
general
who
gives
an
order
for
wholesale
carnage
never
sleeps
a
wink
the
less
soundly
for
the
midnight
groans
of
his
victims
,
and
we
should
deride
him
as
a
coward
if
he
did
.
<EOS>
And
life
is
much
the
same
,
whether
taken
in
battle
,
on
the
couch
,
or
by
the
road
-
side
.
<EOS>
Besides
those
whom
I
've
slain
with
my
own
hands
,
I
've
brought
upwards
of
thirty
persons
to
the
gallows
.
<EOS>
Most
of
their
relics
are
in
yonder
cases
;
but
I
do
n't
remember
that
any
of
them
have
disturbed
my
rest
.
<EOS>
The
mode
of
destruction
makes
no
difference
.
<EOS>
It
's
precisely
the
same
thing
to
me
to
bid
my
janizaries
cut
Thames
Darrell
's
throat
,
as
to
order
Jack
Sheppard
's
execution
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
Jonathan
said
this
,
Jack
's
hand
involuntarily
sought
a
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
to
the
point
,
"
continued
Wild
,
unconscious
of
the
peril
in
which
the
remark
had
placed
him,--"to
the
point
.
<EOS>
On
the
terms
that
procured
your
liberation
from
Newgate
,
I
will
free
you
from
this
new
danger
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Those
terms
were
a
third
of
my
estate
,
"
observed
Trenchard
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
that
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Any
price
was
better
than
your
head
.
<EOS>
If
Thames
Darrell
escapes
,
you
will
lose
both
life
and
property
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
true
,
"
replied
the
knight
,
with
an
agonized
look
;
"
there
is
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
,
"
rejoined
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
a
bargain
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
half
of
my
estate
--
take
all
--
my
life
,
if
you
will
--
I
am
weary
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Trenchard
passionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
"
I
'll
not
take
you
at
your
word
,
as
regards
the
latter
proposition
.
<EOS>
We
shall
both
,
I
hope
,
live
to
enjoy
our
shares
--
long
after
Thames
Darrell
is
forgotten
--
ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
A
third
of
your
estate
I
accept
.
<EOS>
And
as
these
things
should
always
be
treated
as
matters
of
business
,
I
'll
just
draw
up
a
memorandum
of
our
arrangement
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
as
he
spoke
,
he
took
up
a
sheet
of
paper
,
and
hastily
traced
a
few
lines
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sign
this
,
"
he
said
,
pushing
the
document
towards
Sir
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
The
knight
mechanically
complied
with
his
request
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonathan
,
eagerly
pocketing
the
memorandum
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
in
return
for
your
liberality
,
I
'll
inform
you
of
a
secret
with
which
it
is
important

should
be
acquainted
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
secret
!
"
exclaimed
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
Concerning
whom
?
"
 
"
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
mysteriously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Sheppard
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Jack
,
surprised
out
of
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Wild
,
looking
angrily
towards
his
supposed

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
pardon
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Jack
,
with
the
accent
and

of
the

;
"
I
was
betrayed
into
the

by
my
surprise
that
anything
in
which
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
was
interested
could
have
reference
to

humble

as
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
pleased
,
then
,
in
future
not
to
let
your
surprise
find
vent
in
words
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
My
servants
,
like
Eastern

,
must
have
eyes
,
and
ears,--and
<EOS>
_
hands
<EOS>
_
,
if
need
<EOS>
be,--but
<EOS>
no
tongues
.
<EOS>
You
understand
me
,
sirrah
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
dumb
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
secret
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Trenchard
,
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
need
not
remind
you
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
Wild
,
"
that
you
had
two
sisters
--
Aliva
and
Constance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Both
are
dead
,
"
observed
the
knight
,
gloomily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
;
"
answered
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Constance
is
yet
living
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Constance
alive
?
<EOS>
Impossible
!
"
ejaculated
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
proofs
to
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
is
the
case
,
where
is
she
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
Bedlam
,
"
replied
the
thief
-
taker
,
with
a
Satanic
grin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gracious
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
knight
,
upon
whom
a
light
seemed
suddenly
to
break
.
<EOS>
"
You
mentioned
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
What
has
she
to
with
Constance
Trenchard
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Sheppard
_
is
_
Constance
Trenchard
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
maliciously
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Jack
Sheppard
was
unable
to
repress
an
exclamation
of
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Again
,
"
cried
Jonathan
,
sternly
:
"
beware
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
My
sister
the
wife
of
one
condemned
felon
!
<EOS>
the
parent
of
another
!
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
_
is
_
<EOS>
so
,
nevertheless
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Stolen
by
a
gipsy
when
scarcely
five
years
old
,
Constance
Trenchard
,
after
various
vicissitudes
,
was
carried
to
London
,
where
she
lived
in
great
poverty
,
with
the
dregs
of
society
.
<EOS>
It
is
useless
to
trace
out
her
miserable
career
;
though
I
can
easily
do
so
if
you
require
it
.
<EOS>
To
preserve
herself
,
however
,
from
destitution
,
or
what
she
considered
worse
,
she
wedded
a
journeyman
carpenter
,
named
Sheppard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
that
one
so
highly
born
should
submit
to
such
a
degradation
?
<EOS>
"
groaned
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
nothing
surprising
in
it
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
she
had
no
knowledge
of
her
birth
;
and
,
consequently
,
no
false
pride
to
get
rid
of
.
<EOS>
In
the
second
,
she
was
wretchedly
poor
,
and
assailed
by
temptations
of
which
you
can
form
no
idea
.
<EOS>
Distress
like
hers
might
palliate
far
greater
offences
than
she
ever
committed
.
<EOS>
With
the
same
inducements
we
should
all
do
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
Poor
girl
!
<EOS>
she
was
beautiful
once
;
so
beautiful
as
to
make
<EOS>
_
me
_
,
who
care
little
for
the
allurements
of
women
,
fancy
myself
enamoured
of
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
again
sought
his
pistol
,
and
was
only
withheld
from
levelling
it
at
the
thief
-
taker
's
head
,
by
the
hope
that
he
might
gather
some
further
information
respecting
his
mother
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
good
reason
before
long
to
congratulate
himself
on
his
forbearance
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
proof
have
you
of
the
truth
of
this
story
?
"
inquired
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
taking
a
paper
from
a
portfolio
,
and
handing
it
to
the
knight
,
"
this
written
evidence
,
signed
by
Martha
Cooper
,
the
gipsy
,
by
whom
the
girl
was
stolen
,
and
who
was
afterwards
executed
for
a
similar
crime
.
<EOS>
It
is
attested
,
you
will
observe
,
by
the
Reverend
Mr.
Purney
,
the
present
ordinary
of
Newgate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
acquainted
with
Mr.
Purney
's
hand
-
writing
,
"
said
Jack
,
advancing
,
"
and
can
at
once
decide
whether
this
is
a
forgery
or

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
it
,
then
,
"
said
Wild
,
giving
him
the
portfolio
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
ordinary
's
signature
,
undoubtedly
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
gave
back

to
Sir
Rowland
he
contrived
,
unobserved
,
to
slip
the
precious
document
into
his

,
and
from

into
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
does
any
of
our
bright
blood
flow
in
the
veins
of
a
ruffianly
housebreaker
?
"
cried
Trenchard
,
with
a
look
of
bewilderment
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not
believe
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Others
may
,
if
you
wo
n't
,
"
muttered
Jack
,
retiring
.
"
<EOS>
Thank
Heaven
!
<EOS>
I
'm
not
basely
born
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
mark
me
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
"
and
you
'll
find
I
do
n't
do
things
by
halves
.
<EOS>
By
your
father
,
Sir
Montacute
Trenchard
's
will
,
you
are
aware,--and
,
therefore
,
I
need
not

,
except

<EOS>
the

I
have
in
view,--you
are
aware
,
I
say
,
that
,
by
this
will
,
in
case

Aliva
,
died
without
issue
,
or
,
on
the
death
of
such

,
the

reverts
to
Constance
and
_
her
_
issue
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hear
,
"
said
Sir
Rowland
,
moodily
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
,
"
muttered
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
Darrell
once
destroyed
,
"
pursued
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Constance
--
or
,
rather
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
--
becomes
entitled
to
the
estates
;
which
eventually
--
provided
he
escaped
the
gallows
--
would
descend
to
her
son
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
drawing
in
his
breath
,
and
leaning

with
intense

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
?
"
gasped
Sir
Rowland
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
this
need
give
you
no
uneasiness
,
"
pursued
Jonathan
;
"
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
as
I
told

,
is
in
Bedlam
,
an
incurable

;
while
her
son
is
in
the
New

,
whence
he
will
only
be
removed
to
Newgate
and
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
you
think
,
"
muttered
Jack
,
between
his
ground

.
 
<EOS>
"
To
make
your
mind
perfectly
easy
on
the
score
of
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
continued
Jonathan
;
"
after
we
've
disposed
