Thames
Darrell
,
I
'll
visit
her
in
Bedlam
;
and
,
as
I
understand
I
form
one
of
her
chief
terrors
<EOS>
,
I
'll
give
her
such
a
fright
that
I
'll
engage
she
sha
n't
long
survive
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Devil
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Jack
,
again
grasping
his
pistol
.
<EOS>
But
,
feeling
secure
of
vengeance
,
he
determined
to
abide
his
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
having
got
rid
of
the
minor
obstacles
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
"
I
'll
submit
a
plan
for
the
removal
of
the
main
difficulty
.
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
,
I
've
said
,
is
at
Mr.
Wood
's
at
Dollis
Hill
,
wholly
unsuspicious
of
any
designs
against
him
,
and
,
in
fact
,
entirely
ignorant
of
your
being
acquainted
with
his
return
,
or
even
of
his
existence
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
,
it
will
be
easy
to
draw
him
into
a
snare
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
night
--
or
rather
to
-
night
,
for
we
are
fast
verging
on
another
day
--
I
propose
to
lure
him
out
of
the
house
by
a
stratagem
which
I
am
sure
will
prove
infallible
;
and
,
then
,
what
so
easy
as
to
knock
him
on
the
head
.
<EOS>
To
make
sure
work
of
it
,
I
'll
superintend
the
job
myself
.
<EOS>
Before
midnight
,
I
'll
answer
for
it
,
it
shall
be
done
.
<EOS>
My
janizaries
shall
go
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
hear
what
I
say
,
Quilt
?
"
he
added
,
looking
at
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Abraham
Mendez
will
like
the
task,--for
<EOS>
he
has
entertained
a
hatred
to
the
memory
of
Thames
Darrell
ever
since
he
received
the
wound
in
the
head
,
when
the
two
lads
attempted
to
break
out
of
St.
Giles
's
round
-
house
.
<EOS>
I
've
despatched
him
to
the
New
Prison
.
<EOS>
But
I
expect
him
back
every
minute
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
New
Prison
!
"
exclaimed
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
he
gone
there
for
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
With
a
message
to
the
turnkey
to
look
after
his
prisoner
,
"
replied
Wild
,
with
a
cunning
smile
.
"
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
had
a
visitor
,
I
understand
,
yesterday
,
and
may
make
an
attempt
to
escape
.
<EOS>
It
's
as
well
to
be
on
the
safe
side
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
his
quick
ears
detected
the
sound
of
footsteps
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
He
drew
both
his
pistols
,
and
prepared
for
a
desperate
encounter
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
another
mystery
I
would
have
solved
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
addressing
Wild
;
"
you
have
told
me
much
,
but
not
enough
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
require
further
?
"
asked
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
name
and
rank
of
Thames
Darrell
's
father
,
"
said
the
knight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Another
time
,
"
replied
the
thief
-
taker
,
evasively
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
have
it
now
,
"
rejoined
Trenchard
,
"
or
our
agreement
is
void
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
help
yourself
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
replied
the
knight
,
drawing
his
sword
,
"
the
secret
,
villain
,
or
I
will
force
it
from
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Before
Wild
could
make
any
reply
,
the
door
was
thrown
violently
open
,
and
Abraham
Mendez
rushed
into
the
room
,
with
a
face
of
the
utmost
consternation
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
hash
eshcaped
!
"
cried
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
?
Jack
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yesh
,
"
replied
Abraham
.
<EOS>
"
I
vent
to
de
New
Prish'n
,
and
on
wishitin
'
his
shel
vid
de
turnkey
,
vot
should
ve
find
but
de
shains
on
de
ground
,
de
vinder
broken
,
and
Jack
and
Agevorth
Besh
gone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Damnation
!
"
cried
Jonathan
,
stamping
his
foot
with
uncontrollable
rage
.
<EOS>
"
I
'd
rather
have
given
a
thousand
pounds
than
this
had
happened
.
<EOS>
But
he
might
have
broken
out
of
prison
,
and
yet
not
got
over
the
wall
of
Clerkenwell
Bridewell
.
<EOS>
Did
you
search
the
yard
,
fool
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
Ve
did
,
"
replied
Abraham
;
"
and
found
his
fine
goat
and
ruffles
torn
to
shtrips
on
de
shpikes
near
de
creat
cate
.
<EOS>
It
vosh
plain
he
vent
dat
vay
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
gave
utterance
to
a
torrent
of
imprecations
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
thus
vented
his
rage
,
the
door
again
opened
,
and
Quilt
Arnold
rushed
into
the
room
,
bleeding
,
and
half
-
dressed
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sblood
!
<EOS>
what
's
this
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonathan
,
in
the
utmost
surprise
.
"
<EOS>
Quilt
Arnold
,
is
that
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
Sir
,
"
sputtered
the
janizary
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
robbed
,
maltreated
,
and
nearly
murdered
by
Jack
Sheppard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
Jack
Sheppard
!
"
exclaimed
the
thief
-
taker
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
and
I
hope
you
'll
take
ample
vengeance
upon
him
,
"
said
Quilt
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
when
I
catch
him
,
rely
on
it
,
"
rejoined
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
go
far
to
do
that
,
"
returned
Quilt
;
"
there
he
stands
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
here
I
am
,
"
said
Jack
,
throwing
off
his
hat
and
wig
,
and
marching
towards
the
group
,
amongst
whom
there
was
a
general
movement
of
surprise
at
his
audacity
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
,
I
salute
you
as
your
nephew
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Back
,
villain
!
"
said
the
knight
,
haughtily
.
<EOS>
"
I
disown
you
.
<EOS>
The
whole
story
of
your
relationship
is
a
fabrication
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Time
will
show
,
"
replied
Jack
with
equal
haughtiness
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
however
,
it
may
turn
out
,
I
disown
_
<EOS>
you
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Jack
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
who
had
looked
at
him
with
surprise
not
unmixed
with
admiration
,
"
you
are
a
bold
and
clever
fellow
,
I
must
allow
.
<EOS>
Were
I
not
Jonathan
Wild
,
I
'd
be
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
I
'm
almost
sorry
<EOS>
I
've
sworn
to
hang
you
.
<EOS>
But
,
it
ca
n't
be
helped
.
<EOS>
I
'm
a
slave
to
my
word
.
<EOS>
Were
I
to
let
you
go
<EOS>
,
you
'd
say
I
feared
you
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
you
've
secrets
which
must
not
be
disclosed
.
<EOS>
Nab
and
Quilt
to
the
door
!
<EOS>
Jack
,
you
are
my
prisoner
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
flatter
yourself
<EOS>
you
can
detain
me
?
"
<EOS>
laughed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
I
'll
try
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
sarcastically
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
a
cleverer
lad
than
even
_
<EOS>
I
_
take
you
for
,
if
you
get
out
of
this
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
ho
!
<EOS>
Blueskin
!
<EOS>
"
shouted
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
,
Captain
,
"
cried
a
voice
from
without
.
<EOS>
And
the
door
was
suddenly
thrown
open
,
and
the
two
janizaries
felled
to
the
ground
by
the
strong
arm
of
the
stalwart
robber
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
boast
,
you
see
,
was
a
little
premature
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
said
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
Adieu
,
my
worthy
uncle
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
I
've
secured
the
proof
of
my
birth
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Confusion
!
"
thundered
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Close
the
doors
below
!
<EOS>
Loose
the
dogs
!
<EOS>
Curses
!
<EOS>
they
do
n't
hear
me
!
<EOS>
I
'll
ring
the
alarm
-
bell
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
raised
his
arm
with
the
intention
of
executing
his
purpose
,
when
a
ball
from
Jack
's
pistol
passed
through
the
back
of
his
hand
,
shattering
the
limb
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Aha
!
<EOS>
my
lad
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
without
appearing
to
regard
the
pain
of
the
wound
;
"
now
I
'll
show
you
no
quarter
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
with
the
uninjured
hand
he
drew
a
pistol
,
which
he
fired
,
but
without
effect
,
at
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fly
,
Captain
,
fly
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Blueskin
;
"
I
sha
n't
be
able
to
keep
these
devils
down
.
<EOS>
Fly
!
<EOS>
they
shall
knock
me
on
the
head
--
curse
'
em!--before
<EOS>
they
shall
touch
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
darting
through
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
key
's
on
the
outside
--
quick
!
<EOS>
quick
!
"
 
<EOS>
Instantly
alive
to
this
chance
,
Blueskin
broke
away
.
<EOS>
Two
shots
were
fired
at
him
by
Jonathan
;
one
of
which
passed
through
his
hat
,
and
the
other
through
the
fleshy
part
of
his
arm
;
but
he
made
good
his
retreat
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
closed
--
<EOS>
locked,--and
the
pair
were
heard
descending
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hell
's
curses
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
They
'll
escape
.
<EOS>
Not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
took
hold
of
a
ring
in
the
floor
,
and
disclosed
a
flight
of
steps
,
down
which
he
hurried
,
followed
by
the
janizaries
.
<EOS>
This
means
of
communication
instantly
brought
them
to
the
lobby
.
<EOS>
But
Jack
and
his
companion
were
already
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
threw
open
the
street
-
door
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
pavement
near
the
court
lay
the
porter
,
who
had
been
prostrated
by
a
blow
from
the
butt
-
end
of
a
pistol
.
<EOS>
The
man
,
who
was
just
able
to
move
,
pointed
towards
Giltspur
-
street
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
looked
in
that
direction
,
and
beheld
the
fugitives
riding
off
in
triumph
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
it
is
_
their
_
turn
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
binding
up
his
wounded
fingers
with
a
handkerchief
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
it
will
be
_
mine
_
.
"
    
CHAPTER
VI
.
 
<EOS>
Winifred
receives
two
Proposals
.
  
<EOS>
The
tragical
affair
at
Dollis
Hill
,
it
need
scarcely
be
said
,
was
a
dreadful
blow
to
the
family
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wood
bore
up
with
great
fortitude
against
the
shock
,
attended
the
inquest
,
delivered
his
evidence
with
composure
,
and
gave
directions
afterwards
for
the
funeral
,
which
took
place
on
the
day
but
one
following
--
Sunday
.
<EOS>
As
soon
,
however
,
as
the
last
solemn
rites
were
over
,
and
the
remains
of
the
unfortunate
woman
committed
to
their
final
resting
-
place
in
Willesden
churchyard
,
his
firmness
completely
deserted
him
,
and
he
sank
beneath
the
weight
of
his
affliction
.
<EOS>
It
was
fortunate
that
by
this
time
Winifred
had
so
far
recovered
,
as
to
be
able
to
afford
her
father
the
best
and
only
solace
that
,
under
the
circumstances
,
he
could
have
received,--her
personal
attentions
.
 
<EOS>
The
necessity
which
had
previously
existed
of
leaving
the
ghastly
evidence
of
the
murderous
deed
undisturbed,--the
presence
of
the
mangled
corpse,--the
bustle
of
the
inquest
,
at
which
her
attendance
was
required,--all
these
circumstances
produced
a
harrowing
effect
upon
the
young
girl
's
imagination
.
<EOS>
But
when
all
was
over
,
a
sorrowful
calm
succeeded
,
and
,
if
not
free
from
grief
,
she
was
tranquil
.
<EOS>
As
to
Thames
,
though
deeply
and
painfully
affected
by
the
horrible
occurrence
that
had
marked
his
return
to
his
old
friends
,
he
was
yet
able
to
control
his
feelings
,
and
devote
himself
to
the
alleviation
of
the
distress
of
the
more
immediate
sufferers
by
the
calamity
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Sunday
evening
--
a
soft
delicious
evening
,
and
,
from
the
happy
,
<EOS>
_
cheerful
<EOS>
_
look
of
the
house
,
none
would
have
dreamed
of
the
dismal
tragedy
so
lately
acted
within
its
walls
.
<EOS>
The
birds
were
singing
blithely
amid
the
trees,--the
lowing
of
the
cows
resounded
from
the
yard,--a
delicious
perfume
from
the
garden
was
wafted
through
the
open
window,--at
a
distance
,
the
church
-
bells
of
Willesden
were
heard
tolling
for
evening
service
.
<EOS>
All
these
things
spoke
of
<EOS>
peace;--but
there
are
seasons
when
the
pleasantest
external
influences
have
a
depressing
effect
on
the
mind
,
by
painfully
recalling
past
happiness
.
<EOS>
So
,
at
least
,
thought
one
of
two
persons
who
were
seated
together
in
a
small
back
-
parlour
of
the
house
at
Dollis
Hill
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
lovely
girl
,
attired
in
deep
mourning
,
and
having
an
expression
of
profound
sorrow
on
her
charming
features
.
<EOS>
Her
companion
was
a
portly
handsome
man
,
also
dressed
in
a
full
suit
of
the
deepest
mourning
,
with
the
finest
of
lace
at
his
bosom
and
wrists
,
and
a
sword
in
a
black
sheath
by
his
side
.
<EOS>
These
persons
were
Mr.
Kneebone
and
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
The
funeral
,
it
has
just
been
said
,
took
place
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
Amongst
others
who
attended
the
sad
ceremony
was
Mr.
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
Conceiving
himself
called
upon
,
as
the
intimate
friend
of
the
deceased
,
to
pay
this
last
tribute
of
respect
to
her
memory
,
he
appeared
as
one
of
the
chief
mourners
.
<EOS>
Overcome
by
his
affliction
,
Mr.
Wood
had
retired
to
his
own
room
,
where
he
had
just
summoned
Thames
.
<EOS>
Much
to
her
annoyance
,
therefore
,
Winifred
was
left
alone
with
the
woollen
-
draper
,
who
following
up
a
maxim
of
his
own
,
"
that
nothing
was
gained
by
too
much
bashfulness
,
"
determined
to
profit
by
the
opportunity
.
<EOS>
He
had
only
been
prevented
,
indeed
,
by
a
fear
of
Mrs.
Wood
from
pressing
his
suit
long
ago
.
<EOS>
This
obstacle
removed
,
he
thought
he
might
now
make
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
Happen
what
might
,
he
could
not
be
in
a
worse
position
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
had
a
sad
loss
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Winifred
,
"
<EOS>
he
began,--"for
<EOS>
I
must
use
the
privilege
of
an
old
friend
,
and
address
you
by
that
familiar
name,--we
have
had
a
sad
loss
in
the
death
of
your
lamented
parent
,
whose
memory
I
shall
for
ever
revere
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Winifred
's
eyes
filled
with
tears
.
<EOS>
This
was
not
exactly
what
the
woollen
-
draper
desired
.
<EOS>
So
he
resolved
to
try
another
tack
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
very
remarkable
thing
it
is
,
"
he
observed
,
applying
to
his
snuff
-
box
,
"
that
Thames
Darrell
,
whom
we
all
supposed
dead,"--Kneebone
in
his
heart
sincerely
wished
he
_
had
_
been
so,--"should
turn
out
to
be
alive
after
all
.
<EOS>
Strange
,
I
should
n't
know
him
when
he
called
on
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
<EOS>
_
is
_
strange
,
"
replied
Winifred
,
artlessly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
_
I
_
knew
him
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
,
a
little
maliciously
,
"
but
that
's
easily
accounted
for
.
<EOS>
May
I
be
permitted
,
as
a
very
old
and
very
dear
friend
of
your
lamented
parent
,
whose
loss
I
shall
ever
deplore
,
to
ask
you
one
question
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
answer
it
frankly
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Now
for
it
,
"
thought
the
woollen
-
draper
,
"
I
shall
,
at
least
,
ascertain
how
the
land
lies.--Well
,
then
,
my
dear
,
"
he
added
aloud
,
"
do
you
still
entertain
the
strong
attachment
you
did
to
Captain
Darrell
?
"
 
<EOS>
Winifred
's
cheeks
glowed
with
blushes
,
and
fixing
her
eyes
,
which
flashed
with
resentment
,
upon
the
questioner
,
she
said
:
 
"
I
have
promised
to
answer
your
question
,
and
I
will
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
love
him
as
a
brother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
Only
_
as
a
brother
?
<EOS>
"
persisted
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
If
Winifred
remained
silent
,
her
looks
would
have
disarmed
a
person
of
less
assurance
than
the
woollen
-
draper
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
knew
how
much
importance
I
attach
to
your
answer
,
"
he
continued
passionately
,
"
you
would
not
refuse
me
one
.
<EOS>
Were
Captain
Darrell
to
offer
you
his
hand
,
would
you
accept
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
impertinence
deserves
very
different
treatment
,
Sir
,
"
said
Winifred
;
"
but
,
to
put
an
end
to
this
annoyance
,
I
will
tell
you
--
I
would
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
?
"
asked
Kneebone
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
submit
to
be
thus
interrogated
,
"
said
Winifred
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
name
of
your
lamented
parent
,
whose
memory
I
shall
for
ever
revere
,
I
implore
you
to
answer
me
,
"
urged
Kneebone
,
"
why
--
why
would
you
not
accept
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
our
positions
are
different
,
"
replied
Winifred
,
who
could
not
resist
this
appeal
to
her
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
paragon
of
prudence
and
discretion
,
"
rejoined
the
woollen
-
draper
,
drawing
his
chair
closer
to
hers
.
<EOS>
"
Disparity
of
rank
is
ever
productive
of
unhappiness
in
the
married
state
.
<EOS>
When
Captain
Darrell
's
birth
is
ascertained
,
I
've
no
doubt
he
'll
turn
out
a
nobleman
's
son
.
<EOS>
At
least
,
I
hope
so
for
his
sake
as
well
as
my
own
,
"
he
added
,
mentally
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
quite
the
air
of
one
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
my
angel
,
that
I
am
acquainted
with
your
sentiments
on
this
subject
,
I
shall
readily
fulfil
a
promise
which
I
made
to
your
lamented
parent
,
whose
loss
I
shall
ever
deplore
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
promise
to
my
mother
?
"
said
Winifred
,
unsuspiciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
angel
,
to
_
her_--rest
her
soul
!
<EOS>
She
extorted
it
from
me
,
and
bound
me
by
a
solemn
oath
to
fulfil
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
name
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
party
concerned
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
that
you
will
not
disobey
the
injunctions
of
her
whose
memory
we
must
both
of
us
ever
revere
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
in
my
power
--
certainly
.
<EOS>
But
,
what
is
it
!
<EOS>
What
_
did
_
<EOS>
you
promise
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
offer
you
my
heart
,
my
hand
,
my
life
,
"
replied
Kneebone
,
falling
at
her
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
exclaimed
Winifred
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
Inequality
of
rank
can
be
no
bar
to
_
our
_
union
,
"
continued
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
,
_
I
_
am
not
the
son
of
a
nobleman
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
spite
of
her
displeasure
,
Winifred
could
not
help
smiling
at
the
absurdity
of
this
address
.
<EOS>
Taking
this
for
encouragement
,
her
suitor
proceeded
still
more
extravagantly
.
<EOS>
Seizing
her
hand
he
covered
it
with
kisses
.
 
<EOS>
"
Adorable
girl
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
in
the
most
impassioned
tone
,
and
with
the
most
impassioned
look
he
could
command
.
"
<EOS>
Adorable
girl
,
I
have
long
loved
you
to
desperation
.
<EOS>
Your
lamented
mother
,
whose
loss
I
shall
ever
deplore
,
perceived
my
passion
and
encouraged
it
.
<EOS>
Would
she
were
alive
to
back
my
suit
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
beyond
all
endurance
,
"
said
Winifred
,
<EOS>
striving
to
withdraw
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Leave
me
,
Sir
;
I
insist
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Never
!
"
rejoined
Kneebone
,
with
increased
ardour,--"never
,
till
I
receive
from
your
own
lips
the
answer
which
is
to
make
me
the
happiest
or
the
most
miserable
of
mankind
.
<EOS>
Hear
me
,
adorable
girl
!
<EOS>
You
know
not
the
extent
of
my
devotion
.
<EOS>
No
mercenary
consideration
influences
me
.
<EOS>
Love
--
admiration
for
your
matchless
beauty
alone
sways
me
.
<EOS>
Let
your
father
--
if
he
chooses
,
leave
all
his
wealth
to
his
adopted
son
.
<EOS>
I
care
not
.
<EOS>
Possessed
of
_
you
_
,
I
shall
have
a
treasure
such
as
kings
could
not
boast
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
cease
this
nonsense
,
"
said
Winifred
,
"
and
quit
the
room
,
or
I
will
call
for
assistance
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
door
opened
,
and
Thames
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
As
the
woollen
-
draper
's
back
was
towards
him
,
he
did
not
perceive
him
,
but
continued
his
passionate
addresses
.
 
<EOS>
"
Call
as
you
please
,
beloved
girl
,
"
he
cried
,
"
I
will
not
stir
till
I
am
answered
.
<EOS>
You
say
that
you
only
love
Captain
Darrell
as
a
brother--
"
 
"
Mr.
Kneebone
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
you
would
not
accept
him
were
he
to
offer--
<EOS>
"
 
"
Be
silent
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
then
,
"
continued
the
woollen
-
draper
,
"
is
no
longer
considered--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
,
Sir
?
"
cried
Thames
,
advancing
,
"
what
is
the
meaning
of
your
reference
to
my
name
?
<EOS>
Have
you
dared
to
insult
this
lady
?
<EOS>
If
so--
"
 
"
Insult
her
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Kneebone
,
rising
,
and
endeavouring
to
hide
his
embarrassment
under
a
look
of
defiance
.
<EOS>
"
Far
from
,
it
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
have
made
her
an
honourable
proposal
of
marriage
,
in
compliance
with
the
request
of
her
lamented
parent
,
whose
memory--
"
 
"
Dare
to
utter
that
falsehood
in
my
hearing
again
,
scoundrel
,
"
interrupted
Thames
fiercely
,
"
and
I
will
put
it
out
of
your
power
to
repeat
the
offence
.
<EOS>
Leave
the
room
!
<EOS>
leave
the
house
,
Sir
!
and
enter
it
again
at
your
peril
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
do
neither
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Kneebone
,
"
unless
I
am
requested
by
this
lady
to
withdraw,--in
<EOS>
which
case
I
shall
comply
with
her
request
.
<EOS>
And
you
have
to
thank
her
presence
,
hot
-
headed
boy
,
that
I
do
not
chastise
your
insolence
as
it
deserves
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
,
Mr.
Kneebone,--pray
go
!
"
<EOS>
implored
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
Thames
,
I
entreat--
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
wishes
are
my
laws
,
beloved
,
girl
,
"
replied
Kneebone
,
bowing
profoundly
.
"
<EOS>
Captain
Darren
,
"
he
added
,
sternly
,
"
you
shall
hear
from
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
When
you
please
,
Sir
,
"
said
Thames
,
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
woollen
-
draper
departed
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
all
this
,
dear
Winny
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Thames
,
as
soon
as
they
were
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
--
nothing
,
"
she
answered
,
bursting
into
tears
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
ask
me
about
it
now
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Winny
,
"
said
Thames
,
tenderly
,
"
something
which
that
self
-
sufficient
fool
has
said
has
so
far
done
me
a
service
in
enabling
me
to
speak
upon
a
subject
which
I
have
long
had
upon
my
lips
,
but
have
not
had
courage
to
utter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
seem
to
doubt
my
love
,
"
he
continued,--"you
seem
to
think
that
change
of
circumstances
may
produce
some
change
in
my
affections
.
<EOS>
Hear
me
then
,
now
,
before
I
take
one
step
to
establish
my
origin
,
or
secure
my
rights
.
<EOS>
Whatever
those
rights
may
be
,
whoever
I
am
,
my
heart
is
yours
.
<EOS>
Do
you
accept
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
Thames
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
this
ill
-
timed
avowal
of
my
love
.
<EOS>
But
,
answer
me
.
<EOS>
Am
I
mistaken
?
<EOS>
Is
your
heart
mine
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
--
it
is
;
and
has
ever
been
,
"
replied
Winifred
,
falling
upon
his
neck
.
 
<EOS>
Lovers
'
confidences
should
be
respected
.
<EOS>
We
close
the
chapter
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
VII
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
warns
Thames
Darrell
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
night
--
namely
Monday,--the
family
assembled
together
,
for
the
first
time
since
the
fatal
event
,
in
the
chamber
to
which
Thames
had
been
introduced
on
his
arrival
at
Dollis
Hill
.
<EOS>
As
this
had
been
Mrs.
Wood
's
favourite
sitting
-
room
,
and
her
image
was
so
intimately
associated
with
it
,
neither
the
carpenter
nor
his
daughter
could
muster
courage
to
enter
it
before
.
<EOS>
Determined
,
however
,
to
conquer
the
feeling
as
soon
as
possible
,
Wood
had
given
orders
to
have
the
evening
meal
served
there
;
but
,
notwithstanding
all
his
good
resolutions
upon
his
first
entrance
,
he
had
much
ado
to
maintain
his
self
-
command
.
<EOS>
His
wife
's
portrait
had
been
removed
from
the
walls
,
and
the
place
it
had
occupied
was
only
to
be
known
by
the
cord
by
which
it
had
been
suspended
.
<EOS>
The
very
blank
,
however
,
affected
him
more
deeply
than
if
it
had
been
left
.
<EOS>
Then
a
handkerchief
was
thrown
over
the
cage
,
to
prevent
the
bird
from
singing
;
it
was
_
<EOS>
her
_
favourite
canary
.
<EOS>
The
flowers
upon
the
mantel
-
shelf
were
withered
and
drooping--_she
_
had
gathered
them
.
<EOS>
All
these
circumstances,--slight
in
themselves
,
but
powerful
in
their
effect,--touched
the
heart
of
the
widowed
carpenter
,
and
added
to
his
depression
.
 
<EOS>
Supper
was
over
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
discussed
in
silence
.
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
removed
,
and
Wood
,
drawing
the
table
as
near
the
window
as
possible
--
for
it
was
getting
dusk
--
put
on
his
spectacles
,
and
opened
that
sacred
volume
from
which
the
best
consolation
in
affliction
is
derived
,
and
left
the
lovers
--
for
such
they
may
now
be
fairly
termed
--
to
their
own
conversation
.
<EOS>
Having
already
expressed
our
determination
not
to
betray
any
confidences
of
this
sort
,
which
,
however
interesting
to
the
parties
concerned
,
could
not
possibly
be
so
to
others
,
we
shall
omit
also
the
"
love
passages
,
"
and
proceeding
to
such
topics
as
may
have
general
interest
,
take
up
the
discourse
at
the
point
when
Thames
Darrell
expressed
his
determination
of
starting
for
Manchester
,
as
soon
as
Jack
Sheppard
's
examination
had
taken
place
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
surprised
we
have
received
no
summons
for
attendance
to
-
day
,
"
he
remarked
;
"
perhaps
the
other
robber
may
be
secured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Or
Jack
have
escaped
,
"
remarked
Winny
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
that
's
likely
.
<EOS>
But
,
this
sad
affair
disposed
of
<EOS>
,
I
will
not
rest
till
I
have
avenged
my
murdered
parents
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
'
_
<EOS>
The
avenger
of
blood
himself
shall
slay
the
murderer
_
'
,
"
said
Wood
,
who
was
culling
for
himself
certain
texts
from
the
scriptures
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
voice
of
inspiration
,
"
said
Thames
;
"
and
I
receive
it
as
a
solemn
command
.
<EOS>
The
villain
has
enjoyed
his
security
too
long
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
_
Bloody
and
deceitful
men
shall
not
live
half
their
days
_
'
,
"
said
Wood
,
reading
aloud
another
passage
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
yet
,
_
he
_
has
been
spared
thus
long
;
perhaps
with
a
wise
purpose
,
"
rejoined
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
though
the
storm
has
spared
him
,
_
<EOS>
I
_
will
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
_
No
doubt
_
,
'
"
said
Wood
,
who
had
again
turned
over
the
leaves
of
the
sacred
volume--
'
,
"
_
<EOS>
no
doubt
this
man
is
a
murderer
,
<EOS>
whom
,
though
he
escaped
the
seas
,
yet
vengeance
suffereth
not
to
live
_
'
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
feelings
of
consanguinity
shall
stay
my
vengeance
,
"
said
Thames
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
have
no
satisfaction
but
his
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
_
Thou
shalt
take
no
satisfaction
for
the
life
of
a
murderer
which
is
guilty
of
death
,
but
he
shall
surely
be
put
to
death
_
'
,
"
said
Wood
referring
to
another
text
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
steel
your
heart
against
him
,
dear
Thames
,
"
interposed
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
_
And
thine
eye
shall
not
pity
_
,
'
"
said
her
father
,
in
a
tone
of

,
"
'
_
<EOS>
but
,
life
shall
be
for
life
,
eye
for
eye
,
tooth
for
tooth
,
hand
for
hand
,
foot
for
foot
_
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
these
words
were
delivered
by
the
carpenter
with
stern
emphasis
,
a
female
servant
entered
the
room
,
and
stated
that
a
gentleman
was
at
the
door
,
who
wished
to
speak
with
Captain
Darell
on
business
of
urgent

.
 
<EOS>
"
With
me
?
"
said
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
did
n't
give
his
name
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
maid
;
"
but
he
's
a
young
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
near
him
,
dear
Thames
,
"
said
Winifred
;
"
he
may
have
some
ill
intention
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
What
!
refuse
to
see
a
person
who
desires
to
speak
with
me
.
<EOS>
Say
I
will
come
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Law
!
<EOS>
Miss
,
"
observed
the
maid
,
"
there
's
nothing
mischievous
in
the
person
's
appearance
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
He
's
as
nice
and
civil
-
spoken

as
need

;
by
the
same
token
,
"
she
added
,
in
an
under
tone
,
"
that
he
gave
me
a
span
new
crown

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
_
The
thief
cometh
in
the
night
,
and
the
troop
of
robbers
spoileth
without
_
,
'
"
said
Wood
,
who
had
a
text
for
every
emergency
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lor
'
ha
'
mussy
,
Sir!--how
you
<EOS>
_
do
_
talk
,
"
said
the
woman
;
"
this
is
no
robber
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
known
at
a
glance
if
it
was
.
<EOS>
He
's
more
like
a
lord
than--
<EOS>
"
 
As
she
spoke
,
steps
were
heard
approaching
;
the
door
was
thrown
open
,
and
a
young
man
marched
boldly
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
intruder
was
handsomely
,
even
richly
,
attired
in
a
scarlet
riding
-
suit
,
embroidered
with
gold
;
a
broad
belt
,
to
which
a
hanger
was
attached
,
crossed
his
shoulders
;
his
boots
rose
above
his
knee
,
and
he
carried
a
laced
hat
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Advancing
to
the
middle
of
the
chamber
,
he
halted
,
drew
himself
up
,
and
fixed
his
dark
,
expressive
eyes
,
on
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
His
appearance
excited
the
greatest
astonishment
and
consternation
amid
the
group
.
<EOS>
Winifred
screamed
.
<EOS>
Thames
sprang
to
his
feet
,
and
half
drew
his
sword
,
while
Wood
,
removing
his
spectacles
to
assure
himself
that
his
eyes
did
not
deceive
him
,
exclaimed
in
a
tone
and
with
a
look
that
betrayed
the
extremity
of
surprise--"Jack
Sheppard
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
Sheppard
!
"
echoed
the
maid
.
<EOS>
"
Is
this
Jack
Sheppard
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
la
!
<EOS>
I
'm
undone
!
<EOS>
We
shall
all
have
our
throats
cut
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
oh
!
"
<EOS>
And
she
rushed
,
screaming
,
into
the
passage
where
she
fell
down
in
a
fit
.
 
<EOS>
The
occasion
of
all
this
confusion
and
dismay
,
meanwhile
,
remained
perfectly
motionless
;
his
figure
erect
,
and
with
somewhat
of
dignity
in
his
demeanour
.
<EOS>
He
kept
his
keen
eyes
steadily
fixed
on
Thames
,
as
if
awaiting
to
be
addressed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
audacity
passes
belief
,
"
cried
the
latter
,
as
soon
as
his
surprise
would
allow
him
utterance
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
contrived
to
break
out
of
your
confinement
,
villain
,
this
is
the
last
place
where
you
ought
to
show
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
therefore
,
the
first
I
would
visit
,
"
replied
Jack
,
boldly
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
pardon
my
intrusion
.
<EOS>
I
was
_
resolved
_
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
And
,
fearing
you
might
not
come
to
me
,
I
forced
my
way
hither
,
even
with
certainty
of
discomposing
your
friends
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
villain
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Thames
,
"
I
know
not
the
motive
of
your
visit
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
have
come
to
surrender
yourself
to
justice
,
it
is
well
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
depart
hence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
not
?
"
echoed
Jack
,
a
slight
smile
crossing
his
features
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
let
that
pass
.
<EOS>
My
motive
in
coming
hither
is
to
serve
you
,
and
save
your
life
.
<EOS>
If
you
choose
to
requite
me
by
detaining
me
,
you
are
at
liberty
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
shall
make
no
defence
.
<EOS>
That
I
am
not
ignorant
of
the
reward
offered
for
my
capture
this
will
show
,
"
he
added
,
taking
a
large
placard
headed
'
_
Murder
_
'
from
his
pocket
,
and
throwing
it
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
"
My
demeanour
ought
to
convince
you
that
I
came
with
no
hostile
intention
.
<EOS>
And
,
to
show
you
that
I
have
no
intention
of
flying
,
I
will
myself
close
and
lock
the
door
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
key
.
<EOS>
Are
you
now
satisfied
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
interposed
Wood
,
furiously
,
"
I
shall
never
be
satisfied
till
I
see
you
hanged
on
the
highest

at
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
time
may
come
when
you
will
be
gratified
,
Mr.
Wood
,
"
replied
Jack
,
calmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
come!--it
_
will
_
come!--it
_
shall
_
come
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
carpenter
,
shaking
his

at
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
some

in
preventing
myself
from
becoming

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
I
should
have
nursed
such

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear

,
Sir
,
"
said
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
wo
n't

you
,
murderer
,
"
rejoined
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
no
murderer
,
"
replied
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
no
thought
of
injuring
your
wife
,
and
would
have
died
rather
than
commit
so

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Think
not
to
delude

,

,
"
cried

.
<EOS>
"
Even

are

,
you

.
<EOS>
If

had
not

,

.
<EOS>
But
you
shall
swing
,

shall
swing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
conscience
acquits
me
of
all

in

,
"
replied
Jack
,

.
"
<EOS>
But
the
past
is

,
and
I
did
not
come

myself
,
I
came
to
save
_
your
_
life
,
"
he

,

to
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
aware
it
was

danger
,
"
rejoined
Darrell
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
ought
to
be

to
me

.
<EOS>
You
_
are
_
in
danger
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
From
some

your

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
From
your
uncle
,
from
_
my
_
uncle,--Sir
Rowland

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
means
this
idle

,
villain
?
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Your
_
uncle
,
Sir
Rowland
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
no
idle

,
"
replied

.
<EOS>
"
You
are
cousin
to
the
housebreaker
,
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
it
were
so
,
he
would
have
great

to
be
proud
of
the
relationship
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is

to

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

Jack
,

from
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Read
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames

his

over

,
and
transferred

,
with

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Gracious
Heavens
!
<EOS>
this
is

rest
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Thames
,
this
is

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
believe
it
,
father
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
From
the
bottom
of
my
heart
.
<EOS>
I
always
thought
Mrs.
Sheppard
superior
to
her

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So

I
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
at
the
paper
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
soul!--poor
soul
!
"
groaned
Wood
,
brushing

from

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
'm
glad
she
's

this
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Jack
,
Jack
,
you
've
much
to

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,

,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
in
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
If
this
document
is
correct
,
"
continued
Wood
,
"
and
I
am

it
is
so,--you
are
as

as

.
<EOS>
See
what
your
misconduct
has
deprived
you
of
--
<EOS>
see
what
you
might
have
been
.
<EOS>
This
is
retribution
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel
it
,
"
replied
Jack
,
in
a
tone

,
"
and
I
feel
it
more
on
my
poor
mother
's

than

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
suffered
enough
for

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
,
she
has
,
"
said
Jack
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Weep
on
,

,
"
cried
the
carpenter
,
a

.
<EOS>
"
Those
tears
will
do
you
good
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
distress
him
,
dear
father
,
"
said
Winifred
;
"
he
suffers
deeply
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Jack
!
<EOS>
repent
,
while
it
is
yet
time
,
of
your
evil

.
<EOS>
I
will
pray
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
repent,--I
can
not
pray
,
"
replied
Jack
,
recovering
his
hardened
demeanour
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
never
have
been
what
I
am
,
but
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
so
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
loved
you
,
"
replied
Jack,--"don't
start
--
<EOS>
it
is
over
now
--
<EOS>
I
loved
you
,
I
say
,
as
a
boy
.
<EOS>
_
hopelessly
_
,
<EOS>
and
it
made
me
desperate
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
find
,
when
it
is
too
late
,
that
I
_
might
_
have
deserved
you
--
that
I
am
as
well
born
as
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
n't
think
of
these
things
,
or
I
shall
grow
mad
.
<EOS>
I
have
said
your
life
is
in
danger
,
Thames
.
<EOS>
Do
not
slight
my
warning
.
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
is
aware
of
your
return
to
England
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
last
night
at
Jonathan
Wild
's
,
after
my
escape
from
the
New
Prison
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
arrived
from
Manchester
,
whence
he
had
been
summoned
by
that
treacherous
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
I
overheard
them
planning
your
assassination
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
take
place
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
O
Heavens
!
"
screamed
Winifred
,
while
her
father
lifted
up
his
hands
in
silent
horror
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
when
I
further
tell
you
,
"
continued
Jack
,
"
that
,
after
yourself
and
my
mother
,
_
<EOS>
I
_
am
the
next
heir
to
the
estates
of
my
grandfather
,
<EOS>
Sir
Montacute
Trenchard
,
you
will
perhaps
own
that
my
caution
is
sufficiently
disinterested
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Could
I
credit
your
wild
story
,
I
might
do
so
,
"
returned
Thames
,
with
a
look
of
perplexity
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
are
Jonathan
Wild
's
written
instructions
to
Quilt
Arnold
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
,
producing
the
pocket
-
book
he
had
found
in
the
janizary
's

.
<EOS>
"
This
letter
will
vouch
for
me
that
a
communication
has
taken
place
between
your
enemies
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
glanced
at
the
despatch
,
and
,
after
a
moment
's
reflection
,
inquired
,
"
In
what
way
is
the
attempt
upon
my
life
to
be
made
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
could
n't
ascertain
,
"
replied
Jack
;
"
but
I
advise
you
to
be
upon
your
guard
.
<EOS>
For
aught
I
know
,
they
may
be
in
the
neighbourhood
at
this
moment
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
!
"
ejaculated
Wood
,
with
a
look
of
alarm
.
"
<EOS>
Oh
lord
!
<EOS>
I
hope
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
I
do
know
,
"
continued
Jack,--"Jonathan
Wild
superintends
the
attack
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jonathan
Wild
!
"
repeated
the
carpenter
,
trembling
.
"
<EOS>
Then
it
's
all
over
with
us
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear!--how
<EOS>
sorry
I
am
<EOS>
I
ever
left
Wych
Street
.
<EOS>
We
may
be
all
murdered
in
this
unprotected
place
,
and
nobody
be
the
wiser
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
some
one
in
the
garden
at
this
moment
,
"
cried
Jack
;
"
I
saw
a
face
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
--
where
?
"
cried
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stir
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
at
once
convince
you
of
the
truth
of
my
assertions
,
and
ascertain
whether
the
enemy
really
is
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
advanced
towards
the
window
,
threw
open
the
sash
,
and
called
out
in
the
voice
of
Thames
Darrell
,
"
Who
's
there
?
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
answered
by
a
shot
from
a
pistol
.
<EOS>
The
ball
passed
over
his
head
,
and
lodged
in
the
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
right
,
"
replied
Jack
,
returning
as
coolly
as
if
nothing
had
happened
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
Your
uncle--_our
_
uncle
is
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
saw
them
both
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
trust
you
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
,
"
replied
Jack
:
"
<EOS>
I
'll
fight
for
you
to
the
last
gasp
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Follow
me
,
then
,
"
cried
Thames
,
drawing
his
sword
,
and
springing
through
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
the
world
's
end
,
"
answered
Jack
,
darting
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thames!--Thames
!
"
cried
Winifred
,
rushing
to
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
He
will
be
murdered!--Help
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
child!--my
love
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
,
dragging
her
forcibly
back
.
 
<EOS>
Two
shots
were
fired
,
and
presently
the
clashing
of
swords
was
heard
below
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
time
,
the
scuffle
grew
more
and
more
distant
,
until
nothing
could
be
heard
.
 
<EOS>
Wood
,
meanwhile
,
had
summoned
his
men
-
servants
,
and
having
armed
them
with
such
weapons
as
could
be
found
,
they
proceeded
to
the
garden
,
where
the
first
object
they
encountered
was
Thames
Darrell
,
extended
on
the
ground
,
and
weltering
in
his
blood
.
<EOS>
Of
Jack
Sheppard
or
the
assailants
they
could
not
discover
a
single
trace
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
body
was
borne
to
the
house
in
the
arms
of
the
farming
-
men
,
Mr.
Wood
fancied
he
heard
the
exulting
laugh
of
Jonathan
Wild
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
VIII
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Bedlam
.
  
<EOS>
When
Thames
Darrell
and
Jack
Sheppard
sprang
through
the
window
,
they
were
instantly
assailed
by
Wild
,
Trenchard
,
and
their
attendants
.
<EOS>
Jack
attacked
Jonathan
with
such
fury
,
that
he
drove
him
into
a
shrubbery
,
and
might
perhaps
have
come
off
the
victor
,
if
his
foot
had
not
slipped
as
he
made
a
desperate
lunge
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
it
would
have
been
all
over
with
him
,
as
,
being
stunned
by
the
fall
,
it
was
some
moments
before
he
could
recover
himself
,
if
another
party
had
not
unexpectedly
come
to
his
rescue
.
<EOS>
This
was
Blueskin
,
who
burst
through
the
trees
,
and
sword
in
hand
assaulted
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Jack
gained
his
legs
,
he
perceived
Blueskin
lying
,
as
he
thought
,
dead
in
the
plantation
,
with
a
severe
cut
across
his
temples
,
and
while
he
was
stooping
to
assist
him
,
he
heard
groans
at
a
little
distance
.
<EOS>
Hastening
in
the
direction
of
the
sound
,
he
discovered
Thames
Darrell
,
stretched
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
hurt
,
Thames
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Jack
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
dangerously
,
I
hope
,
"
returned
Thames
;
"
but
fly
--
save
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
the
assassins
?
"
cried
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gone
,
"
replied
the
wounded
man
.
<EOS>
"
They
imagine
their
work
is
done
.
<EOS>
But
I
may
yet
live
to
thwart
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
carry
you
to
the
house
,
or
fetch
Mr.
Wood
,
"
urged
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
rejoined
Thames
;
"
fly
--
or
I
will
not
answer
for
your
safety
.
<EOS>
If
you
desire
to
please
me
,
you
will
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
leave
you
thus
?
"
rejoined
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
,
I
insist
,
"
cried
Thames
,
"
or
take
the
consequences
upon
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
protect
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
urged
,
Jack
reluctantly
departed
.
<EOS>
Hastening
to
the
spot
where
he
had
tied
his
horse
to
a
tree
,
he
vaulted
into
the
saddle
,
and
rode
off
across
the
fields,--for
he
was
fearful
of
encountering
the
hostile
party,--till
he
reached
the
Edgeware
Road
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
Paddington
,
he
struck
across
Marylebone
Fields,--for
as
yet
<EOS>
the
New
Road
was
undreamed
of,--and
never
moderated
his
speed
until
he
reached
the
city
.
<EOS>
His
destination
was
the
New
Mint
.
<EOS>
At
this
place
of
refuge
,
situated
in
the
heart
of
Wapping
,
near
the
river
-
side
,
he
arrived
in
less
than
an
hour
,
in
a
complete
state
of
exhaustion
.
 
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
the
infamous
abuse
of
its
liberties
,
an
act
for
the
entire
suppression
of
the
Old
Mint
was
passed
in
the
ninth
year
of
the
reign
of
George
the
First
,
not
many
months
before
the
date
of
the
present
epoch
of
this
history
;
and
as
,
after
the
destruction
of
Whitefriars
,
which
took
place
in
the
reign
of
Charles
the
Second
,
owing
to
the
protection
afforded
by
its
inmates
to
the
Levellers
and
Fifth
-
monarchy
-
men
,
when
the
inhabitants
of
Alsatia
crossed
the
water
,
and
settled
themselves
in
the
borough
of
Southwark,--so
now
,
driven
out
of
their
fastnesses
,
they
again
migrated
,
and
recrossing
the
Thames
,
settled
in
Wapping
,
in
a
miserable
quarter
between
Artichoke
Lane
and
Nightingale
Lane
,
which
they
termed
the
New
Mint
.
<EOS>
Ousted
from
his
old
retreat
,
the
Cross
Shovels
,
Baptist
Kettleby
opened
another
tavern
,
conducted
upon
the
same
plan
as
the
former
,
which
he
denominated
the
Seven
Cities
of
Refuge
.
<EOS>
His
subjects
,
however
,
were
no
longer
entirely
under
his
control
;
and
,
though
he
managed
to
enforce
some
little
attention
to
his
commands
,
it
was
evident
his
authority
was
waning
fast
.
<EOS>
Aware
that
they
would
not
be
allowed
to
remain
long
unmolested
,
the
New
Minters
conducted
themselves
so
outrageously
,
and
with
such
extraordinary
insolence
,
that
measures
were
at
this
time
being
taken
for
their
effectual
suppression
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
Seven
Cities
of
Refuge
Jack
proceeded
.
<EOS>
Having
disposed
of
his
steed
and
swallowed
a
glass
of
brandy
,
without
taking
any
other
refreshment
,
he
threw
himself
on
a
couch
,
where
he
sank
at
once
into
a
heavy
slumber
.
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
it
was
late
in
the
day
,
and
he
was
surprised
to
find
Blueskin
seated
by
his
bed
-
side
,
watching
over
him
with
a
drawn
sword
on
his
knee
,
a
pistol
in
each
hand
,
and
a
blood
-
stained
cloth
bound
across
his
brow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
disturb
yourself
,
"
said
his
follower
,
motioning
him
to
keep
still
;
"
it
's
all
right
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
time
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Past
noon
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
awake
you
,
because
you
seemed
tired
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
did
you
escape
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Sheppard
,
who
,
as
he
shook
off
his
slumber
,
began
to
recall
the
events
of
the
previous
night
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
easily
enough
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
must
have
been
senseless
for
some
time
;
for
,
on
coming
to
myself
,
I
found
this
gash
in
my
head
,
and
the
ground
covered
with
blood
.
<EOS>
However
,
no
one
had
discovered
me
,
so
I
contrived
to
drag
myself
to
my
horse
.
<EOS>
I
thought
if
you
were
living
,
and
not
captured
,
I
should
find
you
<EOS>
here,--and
<EOS>
I
was
right
.
<EOS>
I
kept
watch
over
you
,
for
fear
of
a
surprise
on
the
part
of
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
But
what
's
to
be
done
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
first
thing
I
do
,
"
replied
Jack
,
"
will
be
to
visit
my
poor
mother
in
Bedlam
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'd
better
take
care
of
your
mother
's
son
instead
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
runnin
'
a
great
risk
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Risk
,
or
no
risk
,
I
shall
go
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Jonathan
has
threatened
to
do
her
some
mischief
.
<EOS>
I
am
resolved
to
see
her
,
without
delay
,
and
ascertain
if
it
's
possible
to
remove
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
hopeless
job
,
"
grumbled
Blueskin
,
"
and
<EOS>
harm
will
come
of
it
.
<EOS>
What
are
you
to
do
with
a
mad
mother
at
a
time
when
you
need
all
your
wits
to
take
care
of
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
n't
concern
yourself
further
about
me
,
"
returned
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Once
for
all
,
I
shall
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
take
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
;
you
must
await
my
return
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
must
wait
a
long
time
,
"
grumbled
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
never
return
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
if
I
should
_
not
_
return
,
take
this
purse
to
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
her
at
Black
Mary
's
Hole
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
having
partaken
of
a
hasty
breakfast
,
he
set
out
.
<EOS>
Taking
his
way
along
East
Smithfield
,
mounting
Little
Tower
-
hill
,
and
threading
the
Minories
and
Hounsditch
,
he
arrived
without
accident
or
molestation
,
at
Moorfields
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Bethlehem
,
or
Bedlam,--every
trace
of
which
has
been
swept
away
,
and
the
hospital
for
lunatics
removed
to
Saint
George
's
Field,--was
a
vast
and
magnificent
structure
.
<EOS>
Erected
in
Moorfields
in
1675
,
upon
the
model
of
the
Tuileries
,
it
is
said
that
Louis
the
Fourteenth
was
so
incensed
at
the
insult
offered
to
his
palace
,
that
he
had
a
counterpart
of
<EOS>
St.
James
's
built
for
offices
of
the
meanest
description
.
<EOS>
The
size
and
grandeur
of
the
edifice
,
indeed
,
drew
down
the
ridicule
of
several
of
the
wits
of
the
age
:
by
one
of
whom
--
the
facetious
Tom
Brown
--
it
was
said
,
"
Bedlam
is
a
pleasant
place
,
and
abounds
with
amusements;--the
<EOS>
first
of
which
is
the
building
,
so
stately
a
fabric
for
persons
wholly
insensible
of
the
beauty
and
use
of
it
:
the
outside
being
a
perfect
mockery
of
the
inside
,
and
admitting
of
two
amusing
<EOS>
queries,--Whether
<EOS>
the
persons
that
ordered
the
building
of
it
,
or
those
that
inhabit
it
,
were
the
maddest
?
<EOS>
and
,
whether
the
name
and
thing
be
not
as
disagreeable
as
harp
and
harrow
.
<EOS>
"
By
another
--
the
no
less
facetious
Ned
Ward
--
it
was
termed
,
"
A
costly
college
for
a
crack
-
brained
society
,
raised
in
a
mad
age
,
when
the
chiefs
of
the
city
were
in
a
great
danger
of
losing
their
senses
,
and
so
contrived
it
the
more
noble
for
their
own
reception
;
or
they
would
never
have
flung
away
so
much
money
to
so
foolish
a
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
The
cost
of
the
building
exceeded
seventeen
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
However
the
taste
of
the
architecture
may
be
questioned
,
which
was
the
formal
French
style
of
the
period
,
the
general
effect
was
imposing
.
<EOS>
Including
the
wings
,
it
presented
a
frontage
of
five
hundred
and
forty
feet
.
<EOS>
Each
wing
had
a
small
cupola
;
and
,
in
the
centre
of
the
pile
rose
a
larger
dome
,
surmounted
by
a
gilded
ball
and
vane
.
<EOS>
The
asylum
was
approached
by
a
broad
gravel
walk
,
leading
through
a
garden
edged
on
either
side
by
a
stone
balustrade
,
and
shaded
by
tufted
trees
.
<EOS>
A
wide
terrace
then
led
to
large
iron
gates
,
'
over
which
were
placed
the
two
celebrated
figures
of
Raving
and
Melancholy
Madness
,
executed
by
the
elder
Cibber
,
and
commemorated
by
Pope
in
the
Dunciad
,
in
the
well
-
known
lines:--
     
"
Close
to
those
walls
where
Folly
holds
her
throne
,
    
And
laughs
to
think
Monroe
would
take

down
,
    
<EOS>
Where
,
o'er
the
gates
,
by
his

's

,
    
_
Great
Cibber
's
brazen
,
brainless
brothers
stand
_
.
"
 
<EOS>
Internally
,
it
was
divided
by
two
long

,
one
over

other
.
<EOS>
These

were
separated
in

iron

.
<EOS>
The
wards

occupied
by

patients
,
on

by

.
<EOS>
In

of

upper
gallery
was
a
spacious

,
appropriated
to
the
governors
of
the
asylum
.
<EOS>
But
the
besetting
evil
of
the
place
,
and
that
which
drew
down
the
severest
censures
of
the
writers
above
-
mentioned
,
was
that
this
spot,--which
of
all
others
should

been
most
free
from
such

--
was
made
a
public

.
<EOS>
There
all
the
loose

thronged
,
assignations
were
openly
made
,
and
the
spectators
diverted
themselves
with
the
vagaries
of
its

.
 
<EOS>
Entering

,
and

before
-
mentioned
,

,

,
on
feeing

by

,
into
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
Here

was
almost

deafening

.
<EOS>
Some

were

;
some

;
some

;
<EOS>
some

against

.
<EOS>
Altogether
,

was
the
most

he
had

.
<EOS>
Amidst

all
,

,

appeared
matter

.
<EOS>
The
doors
of

of

wards
were
thrown

for
these

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
Here
was
a
poor

,

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
There

,

from

.
<EOS>
Here

a

figure

,
and

a
lover
,
with

together

.
<EOS>
In

was

,

,

the
most

the

"
moody

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Her

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Those

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
But

--

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
Her

,

.
<EOS>
Her

,

,

.
<EOS>
Her

had

,

,

.
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
The

was
about

;

,
short

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

an
angel

,

"

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"
she

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Off
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

her
head
from
under
the
straw
,
and
peeping
round
the
room
,
asked
in
a
low
voice
,
"
If
they
were
gone
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
inquired
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
nurses
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
they
treat
you
ill
?
"
<EOS>
asked
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
putting
her
lean
fingers
to
her
lips
.
"
<EOS>
Hush!--come
hither
,
and
I
'll
tell
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
approached
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
beside
me
,
"
continued
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
now
I
'll
tell
you
what
they
do
.
<EOS>
Stop
!
<EOS>
we
must
shut
the
door
,
or
they
'll
catch
us
.
<EOS>
See
!
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
tearing
the
rag
from
her
head,--"I
<EOS>
had
beautiful
black
hair
once
.
<EOS>
But
they
cut
it
all
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
mad
myself
if
I
listen
to
her
longer
,
"
said
Jack
,
attempting
to
rise
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
stir
,
or
they
'll
chain
you
to
the
wall
,
"
said
his
mother
detaining
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
tell
me
why
they
brought
you
here
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
came
to
see
you
,
dear
mother
!
"
<EOS>
answered
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
<EOS>
she
echoed,--"mother
!
<EOS>
why
do
you
call
me
by
that
name
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Because
you
are
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
staring
eagerly
in
his
face
.
"
<EOS>
Are
you
my
son
?
<EOS>
Are
you
Jack
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Heaven
be
praised
she
knows
me
at
last
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Jack
!
"
cried
his
mother
,
falling
upon
his
neck
,
and
covering
him
with
kisses
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
--
dear
mother
!
"
said
Jack
,
bursting
into
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
never
leave
me
,
"
sobbed
the
poor
woman
,
straining
him
to
her
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
--
never
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
words
were
scarcely
pronounced
,
when
the
door
was
violently
thrown
open
,
and
two
men
appeared
at
it
.
<EOS>
They
were
Jonathan
Wild
and
Quilt
Arnold
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
starting
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Just
in
time
,
"
said
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
prisoner
,
Jack
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
take
my
life
first
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
as
he
was
about
to
put
himself
into
a
posture
of
defence
,
his
mother
clasped
him
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
shall
not
harm
you
,
my
love
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
The
movement
was
fatal
to
her
son
.
<EOS>
Taking
advantage
of
his
embarrassed
position
,
Jonathan
and
his
assistant
rushed
upon
him
,
and
disarmed
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
cried
the
thief
-
taker
,
as
he
slipped
a
pair
of
handcuffs
over
Jack
's
wrists
,
"
for
the
help
you
have
given
us
in
capturing
your
son
.
<EOS>
Without
you
,
we
might
have
had
some
trouble
.
"
 
<EOS>
Aware
apparently
in
some
degree
,
of
the
mistake
she
had
committed
,
the
poor
maniac
sprang
towards
him
with
frantic
violence
,
and
planted
her
long
nails
in
his
cheek
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
off
,
you
accursed
jade
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Jonathan
,
"
--off
,
I
say
,
or--
"
<EOS>
And
he
struck
her
a
violent
blow
with
his
clenched
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
miserable
woman
staggered
,
uttered
a
deep
groan
,
and
fell
senseless
on
the
straw
.
 
<EOS>
"
Devil
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
;
"
that
blow
shall
cost
you
your
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
'll
not
need
to
be
repeated
,
at
all
events
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
looking
with
a
smile
of
malignant
satisfaction
at
the
body
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
now,--to
Newgate
.
"
    
CHAPTER
IX
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Newgate
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
beginning
of
the
twelfth
century,--whether
in
the
reign
of
Henry
the
First
,
or
Stephen
is
uncertain,--a
fifth
gate
was
added
to
the
four
principal
entrances
of
the
city
of
London
;
then
,
it
is
almost
needless
to
say
,
surrounded
by
ramparts
,
moats
,
and
other
defences
.
<EOS>
This
gate
,
called
_
Newgate
_
,
"
as
being
latelier
builded
than
the
rest
,
"
continued
,
for
upwards
of
three
hundred
years
,
to
be
used
as
a
place
of
imprisonment
for
felons
and
trespassers
;
at
the
end
of
which
time
,
having
grown
old
,
ruinous
,
and
"
horribly
loathsome
,
"
it
was
rebuilt
and
enlarged
by
the
executors
of
the
renowned
Sir
Richard
Whittington
,
the
Lord
Mayor
of
London
:
whence
<EOS>
it
afterwards
obtained
amongst
a
certain
class
of
students
,
whose
examinations
were
conducted
with
some
strictness
at
the
Old
Bailey
,
and
their
highest
degrees
taken
at
Hyde
-
park
-
corner
,
the
appellation
of
Whittington
's
College
,
or
,
more
briefly
,
the
Whit
.
<EOS>
It
may
here
be
mentioned
that
this
gate
,
destined
to
bequeath
its
name
--
a
name
,
which
has
since
acquired
a
terrible
significance,--to
every
successive
structure
erected
upon
its
site
,
was
granted
,
in
1400
,
by
charter
by
Henry
the
Sixth
to
the
citizens
of
London
,
in
return
for
their
royal
services
,
and
thenceforth
became
the
common
jail
to
that
city
and
the
county
of
Middlesex
.
<EOS>
Nothing
material
occurred
to
Newgate
,
until
the
memorable
year
1666
,
when
it
was
utterly
destroyed
by
the
Great
Fire
.
<EOS>
It
is
with
the
building
raised
after
this
direful
calamity
that
our
history
has
to
deal
.
 
<EOS>
Though
by
no
means
so
extensive
or
commodious
as
the
modern
prison
,
Old
Newgate
was
a
large
and
strongly
-
built
pile
.
<EOS>
The
body
of
the
edifice
stood
on
the
south
side
of
Newgate
Street
,
and
projected
at
the
western
extremity
far
into
the
area
opposite
Saint
Sepulchre
's
Church
.
<EOS>
One
small
wing
lay
at
the
north
of
the
gate
,
where
Giltspur
Street
Compter
now
stands
;
and
the
Press
Yard
,
which
was
detached
from
the
main
building
,
was
situated
at
the
back
of
Phoenix
Court
.
<EOS>
The
south
or
principal
front
,
looking
,
_
down
_
the
Old
Bailey
,
and
not
_
upon
it
<EOS>
_
,
as
is
the
case
of
the
present
structure
,
with
its
massive
walls
of
roughened
freestone,--in
<EOS>
some
places
darkened
by
the
smoke
,
in
others
blanched
,
by
exposure
to
the
weather,--its
heavy
projecting
cornice
,
its
unglazed
doubly
-
grated
windows
,
its
gloomy
porch
decorated
with
fetters
,
and
defended
by
an
enormous
iron
door
,
had
a
stern
and
striking
effect
.
<EOS>
Over
the
Lodge
,
upon
a
dial
was
inscribed
the
appropriate
motto
,
"
_
Venio
sicut
fur
_
.
"
<EOS>
The
Gate
,
which
crossed
Newgate
Street
,
had
a
wide
arch
for
carriages
,
and
a
postern
,
on
the
north
side
,
for
foot
-
passengers
.
<EOS>
Its
architecture
was
richly
ornamental
,
and
resembled
the
style
of
a
triumphal
entrance
to
a
capital
,
rather
than
a
dungeon
having
battlements
and
hexagonal
towers
,
and
being
adorned
on
the
western
side
with
a
triple
range
of
pilasters
of
the
Tuscan
order
,
amid
the
intercolumniations
of
which
were
niches
embellished
with
statues
.
<EOS>
The
chief
of
these
was
a
figure
of
Liberty
,
with
a
cat
at
her
feet
,
in
allusion
to
the
supposed
origin
of
the
fortunes
of
its
former
founder
,
Sir
Richard
Whittington
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
of
the
postern
against
the
wall
was
affixed
a
small
grating
,
sustaining
the
debtor
's
box
;
and
any
pleasure
which
the
passer
-
by
might
derive
from
contemplating
the
splendid
structure
above
described
was
damped
at
beholding
the
pale
faces
and
squalid
figures
of
the
captives
across
the
bars
of
its
strongly
-
grated
windows
.
<EOS>
Some
years
after
the
date
of
this
history
,
an
immense
ventilator
was
placed
at
the
top
of
the
Gate
,
with
the
view
of
purifying
the
prison
,
which
,
owing
to
its
insufficient
space
and
constantly
-
crowded
state
,
was
never
free
from
that
dreadful
and
contagious
disorder
,
now
happily
unknown
,
the
jail
-
fever
.
<EOS>
So
frightful
,
indeed
,
were
the
ravages
of
this
malady
,
to
which
debtors
and
felons
were
alike
exposed
,
that
its
miserable
victims
were
frequently
carried
out
by
cart
-
loads
,
and
thrown
into
a
pit
in
the
burial
-
ground
of
Christ
-
church
,
without
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Newgate
was
divided
into
three
separate
prisons,--the
Master
's
Side
,
the
Common
Side
,
and
the
Press
Yard
.
<EOS>
The
first
of
these
,
situated
a
the
south
of
the
building
,
with
the
exception
of
one
ward
over
the
gateway
,
was
allotted
to
the
better
class
of
debtors
,
whose
funds
enabled
them
to
defray
their
chamber
-
rent
,
fees
,
and
garnish
.
<EOS>
The
second
,
comprising
the
bulk
of
the
jail
,
and
by
many
degrees
worse
in
point
of
accommodation
,
having
several
dismal
and
noisome
wards
under
ground
,
was
common
both
to
debtors
and
malefactors,--an
association
little
favourable
to
the
morals
or
comforts
of
the
former
,
who
,
if
they
were
brought
there
with
any
notions
of
honesty
,
seldom
left
with
untainted
principles
.
<EOS>
The
last,--in
all
respects
the
best
and
airiest
of
the
three
,
standing
,
as
has
been
before
observed
,
in
Phoenix
Court
,
at
the
rear
of
the
main
fabric,--was
<EOS>
reserved
for
state
-
offenders
,
and
such
persons
as
chose
to
submit
to
the
extortionate
demands
of
the
keeper
:
from
twenty
to
five
hundred
pounds
premium
,
according
to
the
rank
and
means
of
the
applicant
,
in
addition
to
a
high
weekly
rent
,
being
required
for
accommodation
in
this
quarter
.
<EOS>
Some
excuse
for
this
rapacity
may
perhaps
be
found
in
the
fact
,
that
five
thousand
pounds
was
paid
for
the
purchase
of
the
Press
Yard
by
Mr.
Pitt
,
the
then
governor
of
Newgate
.
<EOS>
This
gentleman
,
tried
for
high
treason
,
in
1716
,
on
suspicion
of
aiding
Mr.
Forster
,
the
rebel
general
's
escape
,
but
acquitted
,
reaped
a
golden
harvest
during
the
occupation
of
his
premises
by
the
Preston
rebels
,
when
a
larger
sum
was
obtained
for
a
single
chamber
than
(
in
the
words
of
a
sufferer
on
the
occasion
)
"
would
have
paid
the
rent
of
the
best
house
in
Saint
James
's
Square
or
Piccadilly
for
several
years
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
all
.
<EOS>
Other
,
and
more
serious
impositions
,
inasmuch
as
they
affected
a
poorer
class
of
persons
,
were
practised
by
the
underlings
of
the
jail
.
<EOS>
On
his
first
entrance
,
a
prisoner
,
if
unable
or
unwilling
to
comply
with
the
exactions
of
the
turnkeys
,
was
thrust
into
the
Condemned
Hold
with
the
worst
description
of
criminals
,
and
terrified
by
threats
into
submission
.
<EOS>
By
the
old
regulations
,
the
free
use
of
strong
liquors
not
being
interdicted
,
a
tap
-
house
was
kept
in
the
Lodge
,
and
also
in
a
cellar
on
the
Common
Side,--under
the
superintendence
of
Mrs.
Spurling
,
formerly
,
it
may
be
remembered
,
the
hostess
of
the
Dark
House
at
Queenhithe,--whence
wine
,
ale
,
and
brandy
of
inferior
quality
were
dispensed
,
in
false
measures
,
and
at
high
prices
,
throughout
the
prison
,
which
in
noise
and
debauchery
rivalled
,
if
it
did
not
surpass
,
the
lowest
tavern
.
 
<EOS>
The
chief
scene
of
these
disgusting
orgies,--the
cellar
,
just
referred
to,--was
a
large
low
-
roofed
vault
,
about
four
feet
below
the
level
of
the
street
,
perfectly
dark
,
unless
when
illumined
by
a
roaring
fire
,
and
candles
stuck
in
pyramidal
lumps
of
clay
,
with
a
range
of
butts
and
barrels
at
one
end
,
and
benches
and
tables
at
the
other
,
where
the
prisoners
,
debtors
,
and
malefactors
male
and
female
,
assembled
as
long
as
their
money
lasted
,
and
consumed
the
time
in
drinking
,
smoking
,
and
gaming
with
cards
and
dice
.
<EOS>
Above
was
a
spacious
hall
,
connected
with
it
by
a
flight
of
stone
steps
,
<EOS>
at
the
further
end
of
which
stood
an
immense
grated
door
,
called
in
the
slang
of
the
place
"
The
Jigger
,
"
through
the
bars
of
which
the
felons
in
the
upper
wards
were
allowed
to
converse
with
their
friends
,
or
if
they
wished
to
enter
the
room
,
or
join
the
revellers
below
,
they
were
at
liberty
to
do
so
,
on
payment
of
a
small
fine
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
the
same
system
of
plunder
was
everywhere
carried
on
.
<EOS>
The
jailers
robbed
the
prisoners
:
the
prisoners
robbed
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
Two
large
wards
were
situated
in
the
Gate
;
one
of
which
,
the
Stone
Ward
,
appropriated
to
the
master
debtors
,
looked
towards
Holborn
;
the
other
called
the
Stone
Hall
,
from
a
huge
stone
standing
in
the
middle
of
it
,
upon
which
the
irons
of
criminals
under
sentence
of
death
were
knocked
off
previously
to
their
being
taken
to
the
place
of
execution
,
faced
Newgate
Street
.
<EOS>
Here
the
prisoners
took
exercise
;
and
a
quaint
,
but
striking
picture
has
been
left
of
their
appearance
when
so
engaged
,
by
the
author
of
the
English
Rogue
.
<EOS>
"
At
my
first
being
acquainted
with
the
place
,
"
says
this
writer
,
in
the
'
Miseries
of
a
Prison
,
'
"
the
prisoners
,
methought
,
walking
up
and
down
the
Stone
Hall
,
looked
like
so
many
wrecks
upon
the
sea
.
<EOS>
Here
the
ribs
of
a
thousand
pounds
beating
against
the
Needles
--
those
dangerous
rocks
,
credulity
here
floated
,
to
and
fro
,
silks
,
stuffs
,
camlets
,
and
velvet
,
without
giving
place
to
each
other
,
according
to
their
dignity
;
here
rolled
so
many
pipes
of
canary
,
whose
bungholes
lying
open
,
were
so
damaged
that
the
merchant
may
go
hoop
for
his
money
,
"
<EOS>
A
less
picturesque
,
but
more
truthful
,
and
,
therefore
,
more
melancholy
description
of
the
same
scene
,
is
furnished
by
the
shrewd
and
satirical
Ned
Ward
,
who
informs
us
,
in
the
"
Delectable
History
of
Whittington
's
College
,
"
that
"
When
the
prisoners
are
disposed
to
recreate
themselves
with
walking
,
they
go
up
into
a
spacious
room
,
called
the
Stone
Hall
;
where
,
when
you
see
them
taking
a
turn
together
,
it
would
puzzle
one
to
know
which
is
the
gentleman
,
which
the
mechanic
,
and
which
the
beggar
,
for
they
are
all
suited
in
the
same
garb
of
squalid
poverty
,
making
a
spectacle
of
more
pity
than
executions
;
only
to
be
out
at
the
elbows
is
in
fashion
here
,
and
a
great
indecorum
not
to
be
threadbare
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
an
angle
of
the
Stone
Hall
was
the
Iron
Hold
,
a
chamber
containing
a
vast
assortment
of
fetters
and
handcuffs
of
all
weights
and
sizes
.
<EOS>
Four
prisoners
,
termed
"
The
Partners
,
"
had
charge
of
this
hold
.
<EOS>
Their
duty
was
to
see
who
came
in
,
or
went
out
;
to
lock
up
,
and
open
the
different
wards
;
to
fetter
such
prisoners
as
were
ordered
to
be
placed
in
irons
;
to
distribute
the
allowances
of
provision
;
and
to
maintain
some
show
of
decorum
;
for
which
latter
purpose
they
were
allowed
to
carry
whips
and
truncheons
.
<EOS>
When
any
violent
outrage
was
committed,--and
<EOS>
such
matters
were
of
daily
,
sometimes
hourly
,
occurrence,--a
bell
,
the
rope
of
which
descended
into
the
hall
,
brought
the
whole
of
the
turnkeys
to
their
assistance
.
<EOS>
A
narrow
passage
at
the
north
of
the
Stone
Hall
led
to
the
Bluebeard
's
room
of
this
enchanted
castle
,
a
place
shunned
even
by
the
reckless
crew
who
were
compelled
to
pass
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
sort
of
cooking
-
room
,
with
an
immense
fire
-
place
flanked
by
a
couple
of
cauldrons
,
and
was
called
Jack
Ketch
's
Kitchen
,
because
the
quarters
of
persons
executed
for
treason
were
there
boiled
by
the
hangman
in
oil
,
pitch
,
and
tar
,
before
they
were
affixed
on
the
city
gates
,
or
on
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
Above
this
revolting
spot
was
the
female
debtor
's
ward
;
below
it
a
gloomy
cell
,
called
Tangier
;
and
,
lower
still
,
the
Stone
Hold
,
a
most
terrible
and
noisome
dungeon
,
situated
underground
,
and
unvisited
by
a
single
ray
of
daylight
.
<EOS>
Built
and
paved
with
stone
,
without
beds
,
or
any
other
sort
of
protection
from
the
cold
,
this
dreadful
hole
,
accounted
the
most
dark
and
dismal
in
the
prison
,
was
made
the
receptacle
of
such
miserable
wretches
as
could
not
pay
the
customary
fees
.
<EOS>
Adjoining
it
was
the
Lower
<EOS>
Ward,--"Though
,
in
what
degree
of
latitude
it
was
situated
,
"
observes
Ned
Ward
,
"
I
can
not
positively
demonstrate
,
unless
it
lay
ninety
degrees
beyond
the
North
Pole
;
for
,
instead
of
being
dark
there
<EOS>
but
half
a
year
,
it
is
dark
all
the
year
round
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
only
a
shade
better
than
the
Stone
Hold
.
<EOS>
Here
were
imprisoned
the
fines
;
and
,
"
perhaps
,
"
adds
the
before
-
cited
authority
,
"
if
he
behaved
himself
,
an
outlawed
person
might
creep
in
among
them
.
"
<EOS>
Ascending
the
gate
once
more
on
the
way
back
,
we
find
over
the
Stone
Hall
another
large
room
,
called
Debtors
'
Hall
,
facing
Newgate
Street
,
with
"
very
good
air
and
light
.
"
<EOS>
A
little
too
much
of
the
former
,
perhaps
;
as
the
windows
being
unglazed
,
the
prisoners
were
subjected
to
severe
annoyance
from
the
weather
and
easterly
winds
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
women
felons
'
rooms
nothing
has
yet
been
said
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
.
<EOS>
One
called
Waterman
's
Hall
,
a
horrible
place
adjoining
the
postern
under
the
gate
,
whence
,
through
a
small
barred
aperture
,
they
solicited
alms
from
the
passengers
:
<EOS>
the
other
,
a
large
chamber
,
denominated
My
Lady
's
Hold
,
was
situated
in
the
highest
part
of
the
jail
,
at
the
northern
extremity
.
<EOS>
Neither
of
these
wards
had
beds
,
and
the
unfortunate
inmates
were
obliged
to
take
their
rest
on
the
oaken
floor
.
<EOS>
The
condition
of
the
rooms
was
indescribably
filthy
and
disgusting
;
nor
were
the
habits
of
the
occupants
much
more
cleanly
.
<EOS>
In
other
respects
,
they
were
equally
indecorous
and
offensive
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
is
with
no
small
concern
,
"
writes
an
anonymous
historian
of
Newgate
,
"
that
I
am
obliged
to
observe
that
the
women
in
every
ward
of
this
prison
are
exceedingly
worse
than
the
worst
of
the
men
not
only
in
respect
to
their
mode
of
living
,
but
more
especially
as
to
their
conversation
,
which
,
to
their
great
shame
,
is
as
profane
and
wicked
as
hell
itself
can
possibly
be
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
Condemned
Holds,--one
for
each
sex
.
<EOS>
That
for
the
men
lay
near
the
Lodge
,
with
which
it
was
connected
by
a
dark
passage
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
room
,
about
twenty
feet
long
and
fifteen
broad
,
and
had
an
arched
stone
roof
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
it
had
been
anciently
the
right
hand
postern
under
the
gate
leading
towards
the
city
.
<EOS>
The
floor
was
planked
with
oak
,
and
covered
with
iron
staples
,
hooks
,
and
ring
-
bolts
,
with
heavy
chains
attached
to
them
.
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
small
grated
window
in
this
hold
,
which
admitted
but
little
light
.
 
<EOS>
Over
the
gateway
towards
Snow
Hill
,
were
two
strong
wards
,
called
the
Castle
and
the
Red
Room
.
<EOS>
They
will
claim
particular
attention
hereafter
.
 
<EOS>
Many
other
wards,--especially
on
the
Master
Debtor
's
side,--have
been
necessarily
omitted
in
the
foregoing
hasty
enumeration
.
<EOS>
But
there
were
two
places
of
punishment
which
merit
some
notice
from
their
peculiarity
.
<EOS>
The
first
of
these
,
the
Press
Room
,
a
dark
close
chamber
,
near
Waterman
's
Hall
,
obtained
its
name
from
an
immense
wooden
machine
kept
in
it
,
with
which
such
prisoners
as
refused
to
plead
to
their
indictments
were
pressed
to
death
--
<EOS>
a
species
of
inquisitorial
torture
not
discontinued
until
so
lately
as
the
early
part
of
the
reign
of
George
the
Third
,
when
it
was
abolished
by
an
express
statute
.
<EOS>
Into
the
second
,
denominated
the
Bilbowes,--also
a
dismal
place,--refractory
prisoners
were
thrust
,
and
placed
in
a
kind
of
stocks
,
whence
the
name
.
 
<EOS>
The
Chapel
was
situated
in
the
south
-
east
angle
of
the
jail
;
the
ordinary
at
the
time
of
this
history
being
the
Reverend
Thomas
Purney
;
the
deputy
chaplain
,
Mr.
Wagstaff
.
 
<EOS>
Much
has
been
advanced
by
modern
writers
respecting
the
demoralising
effect
of
prison
society
;
and
it
has
been
asserted
,
that
a
youth
once
confined
in
Newgate
,
is
certain
to
come
out
a
confirmed
thief
.
<EOS>
However
this
may
be
now
,
it
was
unquestionably
true
of
old
Newgate
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
grand
nursery
of
vice.--"A
famous
university
,
"
observes
Ned
Ward
,
in
the
London
Spy
,
"
where
,
if
a
man
has
a
mind
to
educate
a
hopeful
child
in
the
daring
science
of
padding
;
the
light
-
fingered
subtlety
of
shoplifting
:
the
excellent
use
of
jack
and
crow
;
for
the
silently
drawing
bolts
,
and
forcing
barricades
;
with
the
knack
of
sweetening
;
or
the
most
ingenious
dexterity
of
picking
pockets
;
let
him
but
enter
in
this
college
on
the
Common
Side
,
and
confine
him
close
to
his
study
<EOS>
but
for
three
months
;
and
if
he
does
not
come
out
qualified
to
take
any
degree
of
villainy
,
he
must
be
the
most
honest
dunce
that
ever
had
the
advantage
of
such
eminent
tutors
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
To
bring
down
this
imperfect
sketch
of
Newgate
to
the
present
time
,
it
may
be
mentioned
,
that
,
being
found
inadequate
to
the
purpose
required
,
the
old
jail
was
pulled
down
in
1770
.
<EOS>
Just
at
the
completion
of
the
new
jail
,
in
1780
,
it
was
assailed
by
the
mob
during
the
Gordon
riots
,
fired
,
and
greatly
damaged
.
<EOS>
The
devastations
,
however
,
were
speedily
made
good
,
and
,
in
two
years
more
,
it
was
finished
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
cheering
reflection
,
that
in
the
present
prison
,
with
its
clean
,
well
-
whitewashed
,
and
well
-
ventilated
wards
,
its
airy
courts
,
its
infirmary
,
its
improved
regulations
,
and
its
humane
and
intelligent
officers
,
many
of
the
miseries
of
the
old
jail
are
removed
.
<EOS>
For
these
beneficial
changes
society
is
mainly
indebted
to
the
unremitting
exertions
of
the
philanthropic
HOWARD
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
X.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
got
out
of
the
Condemned
Hold
.
  
<EOS>
Monday
,
the
31st
of
August
1724,--a
day
long
afterwards
remembered
by
the
officers
of
Newgate,--was
distinguished
by
an
unusual
influx
of
visitors
to
the
Lodge
.
<EOS>
On
that
morning
the
death
warrant
had
arrived
from
Windsor
,
ordering
Sheppard
for
execution
,
(
since
his
capture
by
Jonathan
Wild
in
Bedlam
,
as
related
in
a
former
chapter
,
Jack
had
been
tried
,
convicted
,
and
sentenced
to
death
,
)
together
with
three
other
malefactors
on
the
following
Friday
.
<EOS>
Up
to
this
moment
,
hopes
had
been
entertained
of
a
respite
,
strong
representations
in
his
favour
having
been
made
in
the
highest
quarter
;
but
now
that
his
fate
seemed
sealed
,
the
curiosity
of
the
sight
-
seeing
public
to
behold
him
was
redoubled
.
<EOS>
The
prison
gates
were
besieged
like
the
entrance
of
a
booth
at
a
fair
;
and
the
Condemned
Hold
where
he
was
confined
,
and
to
which
visitors
were
admitted
at
the
moderate
rate
of
a
guinea
a
-
head
,
had
quite
the
appearance
of
a
showroom
.
<EOS>
As
the
day
wore
on
,
the
crowds
diminished,--many
who
would
not
submit
to
the
turnkey
's
demands
were
sent
away
ungratified,--and
at
five
o'clock
,
only
two
strangers
,
Mr.
Shotbolt
,
the
head
turnkey
of
Clerkenwell
Prison
,
and
Mr.
Griffin
,
who
held
the
same
office
in
Westminster
Gatehouse
were
left
in
the
Lodge
.
<EOS>
Jack
,
who
had
formerly
been
in
the
custody
of
both
these
gentlemen
,
gave
them
a
very
cordial
welcome
;
apologized
for
the
sorry
room
he
was
compelled
to
receive
them
in
;
and
when
they
took
leave
,
insisted
on
treating
them
to
a
double
bowl
of
punch
,
which
they
were
now
discussing
with
the
upper
jailer
,
Mr.
Ireton
,
and
his
two
satellites
,
Austin
and
Langley
.
<EOS>
At
a
little
distance
from
the
party
,
sat
a
tall
,
sinister
-
looking
personage
,
with
harsh
inflexible
features
,
a
gaunt
but
muscular
frame
,
and
large
bony
hands
.
<EOS>
He
was
sipping
a
glass
of
cold
gin
and
water
,
and
smoking
a
short
black
pipe
.
<EOS>
His
name
was
Marvel
,
and
his
avocation
,
which
was
as
repulsive
as
his
looks
,
was
that
of
public
executioner
.
<EOS>
By
his
side
sat
a
remarkably
stout
dame
,
to
whom
he
paid
as
much
attention
as
it
was
in
his
iron
nature
to
pay
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
nut
-
brown
skin
,
a
swarthy
upper
lip
,
a
merry
black
eye
,
a
prominent
bust
,
and
a
tun
-
like
circumference
of
waist
.
<EOS>
A
widow
for
the
fourth
time
,
Mrs.
Spurling
,
(
for
she
it
was
,
)
either
by
her
attractions
of
purse
or
person
,
had
succeeded
in
moving
the
stony
heart
of
Mr.
Marvel
,
who
,
as
he
had
helped
to
deprive
her
of
her
former
husbands
,
thought
himself
in
duty
bound
to
offer
to
supply
their
place
.
<EOS>
But
the
lady
was
not
so
easily
won
;
and
though
she
did
not
absolutely
reject
him
,
gave
him
very
slight
hopes
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Marvel
,
therefore
,
remained
on
his
probation
.
<EOS>
Behind
Mrs.
Spurling
stood
her
negro
attendant
,
Caliban
;
a
hideous
,
misshapen
,
malicious
monster
,
with
broad
hunched
shoulders
,
a
flat
nose
,
and
ears
like
those
of
a
wild
beast
,
a
head
too
large
for
his
body
,
and
a
body
too
long
for
his
legs
.
<EOS>
This
horrible
piece
of
deformity
,
who
acted
as
drawer
and
cellarman
,
and
was
a
constant
butt
to
the
small
wits
of
the
jail
,
was
nicknamed
the
Black
Dog
of
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
general
survey
of
the
prison
,
taken
in
the
preceding
chapter
,
but
little
was
said
of
the
Lodge
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
well
,
therefore
,
before
proceeding
farther
,
to
describe
it
more
minutely
.
<EOS>
It
was
approached
from
the
street
by
a
flight
of
broad
stone
steps
,
leading
to
a
ponderous
door
,
plated
with
iron
,
and
secured
on
the
inner
side
by
huge
bolts
,
and
a
lock
,
with
wards
of
a
prodigious
size
.
<EOS>
A
little
within
stood
a
second
door
,
or
rather
wicket
,
lower
than
the
first
,
but
of
equal
strength
,
and
surmounted
by
a
row
of
sharp
spikes
.
<EOS>
As
no
apprehension
was
entertained
of
an
escape
by
this
outlet,--nothing
of
the
kind
having
been
attempted
by
the
boldest
felon
ever
incarcerated
in
Newgate,--both
doors
were
generally
left
open
during
the
daytime
.
<EOS>
At
six
o'clock
,
the
wicket
was
shut
;
and
at
nine
,
the
jail
was
altogether
locked
up
.
<EOS>
Not
far
from
the
entrance
,
on
the
left
,
was
a
sort
of
screen
,
or
partition
-
wall
,
reaching
from
the
floor
to
the
ceiling
,
formed
of
thick
oaken
planks
riveted
together
by
iron
bolts
,
and
studded
with
broad
-
headed
nails
.
<EOS>
In
this
screen
,
which
masked
the
entrance
of
a
dark
passage
communicating
with
the
Condemned
Hold
,
about
five
feet
from
the
ground
,
was
a
hatch
,
protected
by
long
spikes
set
six
inches
apart
,
and
each
of
the
thickness
of
an
elephant
's
tusk
.
<EOS>
The
spikes
almost
touched
the
upper
part
of
the
hatch
:
scarcely
space
enough
for
the
passage
of
a
hand
being
left
between
their
points
and
the
beam
.
<EOS>
Here
,
as
has
already
been
observed
,
condemned
malefactors
were
allowed
to
converse
with
such
of
their
guests
as
had
not
interest
or
money
enough
to
procure
admission
to
them
in
the
hold
.
<EOS>
Beyond
the
hatch
,
an
angle
,
formed
by
a
projection
in
the
wall
of
some
three
or
four
feet
,
served
to
hide
a
door
conducting
to
the
interior
of
the
prison
.
<EOS>
At
the
farther
end
of
the
Lodge
,
the
floor
was
raised
to
the
height
of
a
couple
of
steps
;
whence
the
whole
place
,
with
the
exception
of
the
remotest
corner
of
the
angle
before
-
mentioned
,
could
be
commanded
at
a
single
glance
.
<EOS>
On
this
elevation
a
table
was
now
placed
,
around
which
sat
the
turnkeys
and
their
guests
,
regaling
themselves
on
the
fragrant
beverage
provided
by
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
A
brief
description
will
suffice
for
them
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
stout
ill
-
favoured
men
,
attired
in
the
regular
jail
-
livery
of
scratch
wig
and
snuff
-
coloured
suit
;
and
had
all
a
strong
family
likeness
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
The
only
difference
between
the
officers
of
Newgate
and
their
brethren
was
,
that
they
had
enormous
bunches
of
keys
at
their
girdles
,
while
the
latter
had
left
their
keys
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
've
seen
many
a
gallant
fellow
in
my
time
,
Mr.
Ireton
,
"
observed
the
chief
turnkey
of
Westminster

,
as
he
helped
himself
to
his
third
glass

;
"
but
I
never
saw

like
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
,
"
returned
Ireton
,
following
his
example
:
"
and
I
've
had
some
experience
too
.
<EOS>
Ever

he
came
here
,
three
months
ago
,
he
has
been
the
life

place
;
and
now

has
arrived
,
instead

,

,

_

_
,

.
<EOS>
Well
,
_
I
_
shall

,
Mr.
Griffin
.
<EOS>
We
've
made
a
pretty
penny
by

--
<EOS>
sixty

this
blessed

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No

!
"
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
<EOS>
I

,

_

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
At

<EOS>
"

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

my

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

Bah

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I

Jack
cut

.
<EOS>
What

ran

as

!
<EOS>
And
,

!
<EOS>
Everybody

such

stripling
could

.
<EOS>
His

never

till

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

_

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
ago,--was

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
_
<EOS>

_

,

.
<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Wild
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Right
,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.

,

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

"

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.

pretty
dears
,
"
he
added
,
"
--to
see
your
husband
,
eh
?
<EOS>
You
must
make
the
most
of
your
time
.
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
have
him
long
.
<EOS>
You
've
heard
the
news
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
That
the
death
warrant
's
arrived
,
"
returned
Edgeworth
Bess
,
bursting
into
a
flood
of
tears
;
"
<EOS>
oh
,
yes
!
<EOS>
we
've
heard
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
does
Jack
bear
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mrs.
Maggot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Like
a
hero
,
"
answered
Austin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
he
would
,
"
replied
the
Amazon
.
"
<EOS>
Come
Bess,--no
whimpering
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
unman
him
.
<EOS>
Are
we
to
see
him
here
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
lose
no
time
in
bringing
him
to
us
,
"
said
Mrs.
Maggot
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
guinea
to
drink
our
health
,
"
she
added
,
slipping
a
piece
of
money
into

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Caliban
,
"
shouted
the
under
-
turnkey
,
"
<EOS>
unlock
Captain
Sheppard
's
padlock
,
and
tell
him
his
wives
are
in
the
Lodge
waiting
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Iss
,
Massa
Austin
,
"
replied
the
black
.
<EOS>
And
taking
the
keys
,
he
departed
on
the
errand
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
the
two
women
divested
themselves
of
their
hoods
and
cloaks
,
and
threw
them
,
as
if
inadvertently
,
into
the
farthest
part
of
the
angle
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
Their
beautifully
proportioned
figures
and
rather
over
-
displayed
shoulders
attracted
the
notice
of
Austin
,
who
inquired
of
the
chief
turnkey
"
whether
he
should
stand
by
them
during
the
interview
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
never
mind
them
,
"
said
Mrs.
Spurling
,
who
had
been
hastily
compounding
another
bowl
of
punch
.
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
and
enjoy
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
'll
keep
a
look
out
that
nothing
happens
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
Caliban
had
returned
,
and
Jack
appeared
at
the
hatch
.
<EOS>
He
was
wrapped
in
a
loose
dressing
-
gown
of
light
material
,
and
stood
near
the
corner
where
the
women
's
dresses
had
just
been
thrown
down
,
quite
out
of
sight
of
all
the
party
,
except
Mrs.
Spurling
,
who
sat
on
the
right
of

.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
Jonathan
out
of
the
way
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
,
in
an
eager

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
replied
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
"
Patience
Kite
has
lured
him
to
Enfield
on
a
false
scent
after
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
You
need
fear
no
interruption
from
him
,
or
any
of
his
myrmidons
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Now
stand
before
me
,
Poll
.
<EOS>
I
've
got
the
watch
-
spring
saw
in
my
sleeve
.
<EOS>
Pretend
to
weep
both
of
you
as
loudly
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
This
spike
is
more
than
half
cut
through
.
<EOS>
I
was
at
work
at
it
yesterday
and
the
day
before
.
<EOS>
Keep
up
the
clamour
for
five
minutes
,
and
I
'll
finish
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
urged
,
the
damsels
began
to
raise
their

in
loud

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
are
you
howling
about
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Langley
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
we
are
to
be

in
this

?
<EOS>
Make
less
noise
,
hussies
,
or
<EOS>
I
'll
turn
you

of
the
Lodge
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
shame
,
Mr.
Langley
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Spurling
:
"
<EOS>
I
blush
for
you
,
Sir
!
<EOS>
To
call
yourself
a
man
,
and
interfere
with
the
natural
course

!
<EOS>
Have
you
no
feeling
for
the
situation
of
those
poor
disconsolate

,
about

be

all
they
hold

?
<EOS>
Is

nothing
to
part
with
a

?
<EOS>
I
've
lost
four
in
the
same
way
,
and
know
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
she
began
to

for

.
 
<EOS>
"
Comfort
yourself
,
my
charmer
,
"
said
Mr.
Marvel
,
in
a
tone
intended
to
be
consolatory
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
be
their

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
You
!
<EOS>
_
"
cried
the
tapstress
,
with
a
look
of

:
"
Never
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Confusion
!
"
<EOS>
muttered
Jack
,
suddenly

in

task
,
"
the
saw
has
broken
just
as
I
am
through
the
spike
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
we
break
it
off
?
"

Mrs.
Maggot
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear

,
"

Jack
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
's
try
,
at
all

,
"
returned
the
Amazon
.
 
<EOS>
And
grasping
the
thick
iron
rod
,
she
pushed
with
all

force
against

,
while
Jack
seconded

from

.
<EOS>
After
great

on
both

,
the
spike
yielded
to

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Holloa
--
what
's

?
<EOS>
"

Austin
,

up
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
my
darbies
,
"
returned
Jack
,
clinking
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
was
all
,
was

?
"
said
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,

to

,
"

Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quick
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
"

Edgeworth
Bess
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give

your

,
Poll
,
to

,
"

Jack
,
as

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Keep
a

,
Bess
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>

Edgeworth
Bess
;
"
Mr.
Langley
is

,

this

.
<EOS>
We
're
lost
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Help
me
through
at
all

,
Poll
,
"

Jack
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
danger
's
past
,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Spurling
has
induced

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
she
looks
this

,

.
<EOS>
She
comprehends
what
we
're
about
.
<EOS>
We
're
all

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
!
"

Mrs.
Maggot
,

;
"
you
're

so

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,

,
"

,
"
it

.
<EOS>
I

Wild
here

.
<EOS>
Cut

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Only

,
Sir
,
"

,

in
such

to

Jack
,
who
crept
into
the
farthest

of

angle,--"only

,

we
've

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
I
'm
not

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
never
