,
Jack
,
"
whispered

Maggot
.
<EOS>
"
You
must

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
in

.
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
certain

.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
run
in

.
<EOS>
No
:
I
must
face
it
out
.
<EOS>
Tell
Bess
to

,

I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,

party
at

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
thinking
of
Jack
Sheppard
's

Kneebone
,
"
observed
Shotbolt
,

;
"
I
'm

he
's
meditating

,
and

to
-

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poh
!
<EOS>
poh
!
"
rejoined
Ireton
;
"
it
was
mere
idle
boasting
.
<EOS>
I
examined
the
Condemned
Hold
myself
carefully
this
morning
,
and
did
n't
find
a
nail
out
of
its
place
.
<EOS>
Recollect
,
he
's
chained
to
the
ground
by
a
great
horse
-
padlock
,
and
is
never
unloosed
except
when
he
comes
to
that
hatch
.
<EOS>
If
he
escapes
at
all
,
it
must
be
before

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
n't
surprise
me
if
he
did
,
"
remarked
Griffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
audacity
enough
for
anything
.
<EOS>
He
got
out
in
much
the
same
way
from
the
Gatehouse,--stole
the
keys
,
and
passed
through
a
room
where
I
was
sitting
half
-
asleep
in
a
chair
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Caught
you
napping
,
eh
?
"

Ireton
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
he
wo
n't
do
that
here
.
<EOS>
I
'll
forgive
him
if
he
does
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
will
I
,
"

Austin
.
<EOS>
"
We
're
too
wide

for

.
<EOS>
Ai
n't
we
,
partner
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
appealing
to
Langley
,
whom
punch
had
made

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
so
,
"
responded
the
lethargic

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
During
this
colloquy
,
Jack
had
contrived
unobserved
to
put
on
the
hood
and
cloak
,
and
being
about
the
size
of
the
rightful
owner
,
presented
a
very
tolerable
resemblance
to
her
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
Edgeworth
Bess
,
who
watched
her
opportunity
,
slipped
out
of
the
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Austin
,
who
had
caught
a
glimpse
of
her
departing
figure
,
"
one
of
the
women
is
gone
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
no
,
"
hastily

Mrs.
Spurling
;
"
they
're
both
here
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
they
're
putting
on
their
cloaks
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
false
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Marvel
,
in
a
low
tone
<EOS>
;
"
I
perceive
what
has
taken
place
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
goodness
!
<EOS>
"
ejaculated
the
tapstress
,
in
alarm
.
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
betray
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Say
the
word
,
and
I
'm
mum
,
"
returned
the
executioner
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
be
mine
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
very
unfair
advantage
to
take
--
<EOS>
very
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Spurling
;
"
however
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'll
lend
a
helping
hand
.
<EOS>
I
shall
lose
my
fees
and
the
laced

.
<EOS>
But
it
's
better
to
have
the
bride
without
the
weddin
'
dress
,
than
the
weddin
'
dress
without
the
bride
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Saint
Sepulchre
's
clock
struck
six
.
 
<EOS>
"
Close
the
wicket
,
Austin
,
"
vociferated

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
bye
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
as
if

leave
of
his
mistresses
,
"
to
-
morrow
,
at
the
same

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
be
punctual
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Maggot
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
bye
,
Jack
!
<EOS>
Keep
up
your
spirits
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Now
for
it!--life
or
death
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Jack
,
assuming
the
gait
of
a
female
,
and
stepping
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
As
Austin
rose
to
execute
his
principal
's
commands
,
and
usher
the
women
to
the
gate
,
Mrs.
Spurling
and
Marvel
rose
too
.
<EOS>
The
latter
walked
carelessly
towards
the
hatch
,
and
leaning
his
back
against
the
place
<EOS>
whence
the
spike
had
been
removed
,
so
as
completely
to
hide
it
,
continued
smoking
his
pipe
as
coolly
as
if
nothing
had
happened
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
Jack
gained
the
entrance
,
he
heard
a
man
's
footstep
behind
him
,
and
aware
that
the
slightest
indiscretion
would
betray
him
,
he
halted
,
uncertain
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
minute
,
my
dear
,
"
cried
Austin
.
<EOS>
"
You
forget
that
you
promised
me
a
kiss
the
last
time
you
were
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
one
from
me
do
as
well
?
<EOS>
"
interposed
Mrs.
Maggot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
better
,
"
said
Mrs.
Spurling
,
hastening
to
the
rescue
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
speak
to
Edgeworth
Bess
myself
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
planted
herself
between
Jack
and
the
turnkey
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
moment
of
breathless
interest
to
all
engaged
in
the
attempt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
--
the
kiss
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Austin
,
endeavouring
to
pass
his
arm
familiarly
round
the
Amazon
's
waist
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hands
off
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
"
or
you
'll
repent
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
'll
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Teach
you
to
keep
your
distance
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mrs.
Maggot
,
dealing
him
a
buffet
that
sent
him
reeling
several
yards
backwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
!
<EOS>
off
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mrs.
Spurling
,
squeezing
Jack
's
arm
,
and
pushing
him
towards
the
door
,
"
and
,
do
n't
come
here
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Before
Austin
could
recover
himself
,
Jack
and
Mrs.
Maggot
had
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bolt
the
wicket
!
"
<EOS>
shouted
Ireton
,
who
,
with
the
others
,
had
been
not
a
little
entertained
by
the
gallant
turnkey
's
discomfiture
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
done
,
and
Austin
returned
with
a
crest

to

.
<EOS>
Upon
which
Mrs.
Spurling
,
and
her

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
as
good
as
your
word
,
my

,
"
whispered
the
executioner
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
responded
the
widow
,
heaving
a
deep

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Jack
!
<EOS>
Jack!--you
<EOS>
little
know
what
a
price
I
've
paid
for
you
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm
glad
those
women
are
gone
,
"
remarked
Shotbolt
.
<EOS>
"
Coupling
their
presence
with
Jack
's
speech
,
I
could
n't
help
fearing
some
mischief
might
ensue
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
reminds
me
<EOS>
he
's
still
at
large
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Caliban
,
go
and

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Iss
,
Massa
Ireton
,
"
replied
the
black
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
Caliban
,
"
interposed
Mrs.
Spurling
,
who
wished
to
protract
the
discovery
of

as

.
<EOS>
"
Before
you
go
,

pine

rum
I

.
<EOS>
I
should

Mr.
Ireton
and
his

to

.
<EOS>
It

the

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
have

the
key
<EOS>
--
then
_
I
_

,

.
<EOS>
How
provoking
!
"
<EOS>
she

,

;
"
<EOS>
one
never
_
can
_
find
a

when

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never

,

,
"

;
"
we

.
<EOS>
We

Wild

,

I

--
Zounds
!
"
<EOS>

,

"

.
<EOS>
Off

,

!
<EOS>
Fly
,

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wild
here
!
"

Mrs.
Spurling
in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>
he
's

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
key
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
All

rose
to

the
thief

,
whose
habitually
-

countenance
looked

than

.
<EOS>
Ireton
rushed
forward
to
open

for

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
Blueskin
,
I
perceive
,
Sir
,
"
he

,
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
moodily
.
<EOS>
"
I
've

deceived
by
false

.
<EOS>
But
the
wench
who

me
shall
bitterly

.
<EOS>
I

this

.
<EOS>
I

purposely
go

.
<EOS>
Nothing

wrong
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Jack

just

back
to

.
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"

Jonathan
,

;
"
what
's

!
<EOS>
a

!
'
<EOS>
Sdeath
!
<EOS>
the

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

he

.

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
O

!
<EOS>

"

,
"
<EOS>
Shack

!
"
 
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
you

.
 
<EOS>
"
Iss
,

.
<EOS>
Caliban
sarch

hole

,

<EOS>
Shack
no

.
<EOS>
Only
him
big

--

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
Ireton

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

_
,

<EOS>

"

sha

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
And

I

"

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs.

,
"

,

"

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
And

sha

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
hussy
,

?
"
<EOS>

;

,
"
How

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Scarcely

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
One

"

;
"

;

.
<EOS>
Disperse

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
A

.
"
 
<EOS>
So

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
hundred

!
"
exclaimed
Shotbolt
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
glorious

.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
he
'll
pay

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'll

before
to
-

,
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
Jack
Sheppard
sups
with
Mr.
Kneebone
,
I
'll
make
one
of
the
party
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XI
.
 
<EOS>
Dollis
Hill
revisited
.
  
<EOS>
About
an
hour
after
the
occurrences
at
Newgate
,
the
door
of
the
small
back
-
parlour
already
described
at
Dollis
Hill
was
opened
by
Winifred
,
who
,
gliding
noiselessly
across
the
room
,
approached
a
couch
,
on
which
was
extended
a
sleeping
female
,
and
,
gazing
anxiously
at
her
pale
careworn
countenance
,
murmured,--"Heaven
be
praised
!
<EOS>
she
still
slumbers
--
slumbers
peacefully
.
<EOS>
The
opiate
has
done
its
duty
.
<EOS>
Poor
thing
!
<EOS>
how
beautiful
she
looks
!
<EOS>
but
how
like
death
!
"
 
<EOS>
Deathlike
,
indeed
,
was
the
repose
of
the
sleeper,--deathlike
and
deep
.
<EOS>
Its
very
calmness
was
frightful
.
<EOS>
Her
lips
were
apart
,
but
no
breath
seemed
to
issue
from
them
;
and
,
but
for
a
slight
--
very
slight
palpitation
of
the
bosom
,
the
vital
principle
might
be
supposed
to
be
extinct
.
<EOS>
This
lifeless
appearance
was
heightened
by
the
extreme
sharpness
of
her
features
--
especially
the
nose
and
chin,--and
by
the
emaciation
of
her
limbs
,
which
was
painfully
distinct
through
her
drapery
.
<EOS>
Her
attenuated
arms
were
crossed
upon
her
breast
;
and
her
black
brows
and
eyelashes
contrasted
fearfully
with
the
livid
whiteness
of
her
skin
.
<EOS>
A
few
short
,
dark
locks
,
escaping
from
beneath
her
head
-
dress
,
showed
that
her
hair
had
been
removed
,
and
had
only
been
recently
allowed
to
grow
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
Mrs.
Sheppard
!
<EOS>
"
sighed
Winifred
,
as
she
contemplated
the
beautiful
wreck
before
her,--"Poor
Mrs.
Sheppard
!
<EOS>
when
I
see
her
thus
,
and
think
of
all
she
has
endured
,
of
all
she
may
yet
have
to
endure
,
I
could
almost
pray
for
her
release
from
trouble
.
<EOS>
I
dare
not
reflect
upon
the
effect
that
her
son
's
fate,--if
the
efforts
to
save
him
are
<EOS>
ineffectual,--may
have
upon
her
enfeebled
frame
,
and
still
worse
upon
her
mind
.
<EOS>
What
a
mercy
that
the
blow
aimed
at
her
by
the
ruffian
,
Wild
,
though
it
brought
her
to
the
brink
of
the
grave
,
should
have
restored
her
to
reason
!
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
she
stirs
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
said
this
,
she
drew
a
little
aside
,
while
Mrs.
Sheppard
heaved
a
deep
sigh
,
and
opened
her
eyes
,
which
now
looked
larger
,
blacker
,
and
more
melancholy
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
am
I
?
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
passing
her
hand
across
her
brow
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
your
friends
,
dear
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
replied
Winifred
,
advancing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
are
there
,
my
dear
young
lady
,
"
said
the
widow
,
smiling
faintly
;
"
when
I
first
waken
,
I
'm
always
in
dread
of
finding
myself
again
in
that
horrible
asylum
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
never
be
afraid
of
that
,
"
returned
Winifred
,
affectionately
;
"
my
father
will
take
care
<EOS>
you
never
leave
him
more
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
how
much
I
owe
him
!
"
said
the
widow
,
with
fervour
,
"
for
bringing
me
here
,
and
removing
me
from
those
dreadful
sights
and
sounds
,
that
would
have
driven
me
distracted
,
even
if
I
had
been
in
my
right
mind
.
<EOS>
And
how
much
I
owe
_
<EOS>
you
_
<EOS>
,
too
,
dearest
Winifred
,
for
your
kindness
and
attention
.
<EOS>
Without
you
I
should
never
have
recovered
either
health
or
reason
.
<EOS>
I
can
never
be
grateful
enough
.
<EOS>
But
,
though
_
I
_
can
not
reward
you
,
Heaven
will
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
n't
say
anything
about
it
,
dear
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
rejoined
Winifred
,
controlling
her
emotion
,
and
speaking
as
cheerfully
as
she
could
;
"
I
would
do
anything
in
the
world
for
you
,
and
so
would
my
father
,
and
so
would
Thames
;
but
he
_
ought
_
,
for
he
's
your
nephew
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
We
all
love
you
dearly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
!
<EOS>
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
averting
her
face
to
hide
her
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
n't
tell
you
what
Thames
means
to
do
for
you
if
ever
he
gains
his
rights
,
"
continued
Winifred
;
"
but
I
_
may
_
tell
you
what
my
father
means
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
done
too
much
already
,
"
answered
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
need
little
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
_
do
_
hear
what
it
is
,
"
rejoined
Winifred
;
"
you
know
I
'm
shortly
to
be
united
to
your
nephew,--that
is
,
"
she
added
,
blushing
,
"
when
he
can
be
married
by
his
right
name
,
for
my
father
wo
n't
consent
to
it
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
father
will
never
oppose
your
happiness
,
my
dear
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
"
but
,
what
has
this
to
do
with
me
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
hear
,
"
replied
Winifred
;
"
when
this
marriage
takes
place
,
you
and
I
shall
be
closely
allied
,
but
my
father
wishes
for
a
still
closer
alliance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
unterstand
you
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
plain
,
then
,
"
said
Winifred
,
"
he
has
asked
me
whether
I
have
any
objection
to
you
as
a
mother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
--
what
was
your
answer
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
widow
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
you
guess
?
"
returned
Winifred
,
throwing
her
arms
about
her
neck
.
<EOS>
"
That
he
could
n't
choose
any
one
so
agreeable
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Winifred
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
after
a
brief
pause
,
during
which
she
appeared
overcome
by
her
feelings,--she
said
,
gently
disengaging
herself
from
the
young
girl
's
embrace
,
and
speaking
in
a
firm
voice
,
"
you
must
dissuade
your
father
from
this
step
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
exclaimed
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Can
you
not
love
him
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Love
him
!
"
echoed
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
The
feeling
is
dead
within
my
breast
.
<EOS>
My
only
love
is
for
my
poor
lost
son
.
<EOS>
I
can
esteem
him
,
regard
him
;
but
,
love
him
as
he
_
ought
_
to
be
loved
--
that
I
can
not
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
esteem
is
all
he
will
require
,
"
urged
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
it
,
and
will
ever
have
it
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
passionately,--"he
has
my
boundless
gratitude
,
and
devotion
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
worthy
to
be
any
man
's
wife
--
far
less
<EOS>
_
his
_
wife
.
<EOS>
Winifred
,
you
are
deceived
in
me
.
<EOS>
You
know
not
what
a
wretched
guilty
thing
I
am
.
<EOS>
You
know
not
in
what
dark
places
my
life
has
been
cast
;
with
what
crimes
it
has
been
stained
.
<EOS>
But
the
offences
I
_
have
_
committed
are
venial
in
comparison
with
what
I
should
commit
were
I
to
we
d
your
father
.
<EOS>
No
--
<EOS>
no
,
it
must
never
be
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
paint
yourself
worse
than
you
are
,
dear
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
rejoined
Winifred
kindly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
faults
were
the
faults
of
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Palliate
them
as
you
may
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
gravely
,
"
they
_
were
_
faults
;
and
as
such
,
can
not
be
repaired
by
a
greater
wrong
.
<EOS>
If
you
love
me
,
do
not
allude
to
this
subject
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
I
mentioned
it
at
all
,
since
it
distresses
you
,
"
returned
Winifred
;
"
but
,
as
I
knew
my
father
intended
to
propose
to
you
,
if
poor
Jack
should
be
respited--
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
If
_
he
should
be
respited
?
"
repeated
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
with
startling
eagerness
.
"
<EOS>
Does
your
father
doubt
it
?
<EOS>
Speak
!
<EOS>
tell
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Winifred
made
no
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
hesitation
convinces
me
he
does
,
"
replied
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
Thames
returned
from
London
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
"
replied
the
other
;
"
but
I
expect
him
every
minute
.
<EOS>
My
father
's
chief
fear
,
I
must
tell
you
,
is
from
the
baneful
influence
of
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
fiend
is
ever
in
my
path
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
with
a
look
,
the
wildness
of
which
greatly
alarmed
her
companion
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
scare
him
thence
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Winifred
,
"
<EOS>
Thames
is
arrived
.
<EOS>
I
hear
the
sound
of
his
horse
's
feet
in
the
yard
.
<EOS>
Now
you
will
learn
the
result
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
support
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Breathe
at
this
phial
,
"
said
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
afterwards,--it
seemed
an
age
to
the
anxious
mother,--Mr
.
<EOS>
Wood
entered
the
room
,
followed
by
Thames
.
<EOS>
The
latter
looked
very
pale
,
either
from
the
effect
of
his
wound
,
which
was
not
yet
entirely
healed
,
or
from
suppressed
emotion,--partly
,
perhaps
,
from
both
causes,--and
wore
his
left
arm
in
a
sling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
raising
herself
,
and
looking
at
him
as
if
her
life
depended
upon
the
answer
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
respited
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
no
,
"
replied
Thames
,
sadly
.
<EOS>
"
The
warrant
for
his
execution
is
arrived
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
further
hope
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
poor
son
!
"
groaned
the
widow
,
sinking
backwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
have
mercy
on
his
soul
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
Jack
!
"
cried
Winifred
,
burying
her
face
in
her
lover
's
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
uttered
for
some
time
,
nor
any
sound
heard
except
the
stilled
sobs
of
the
unfortunate
mother
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
she
suddenly
started
to
her
feet
;
and
before
Winifred
could
prevent
her
,
staggered
up
to
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
is
he
to
suffer
?
<EOS>
"
she
demanded
,
fixing
her
large
black
eyes
,
which
burnt
with
an
insane
gleam
,
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
Friday
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Friday
!
"
echoed
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
"
and
to
-
day
is
Monday
.
<EOS>
He
has
three
days
to
live
.
<EOS>
Only
three
days
.
<EOS>
Three
short
days
.
<EOS>
Horrible
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
soul
!
<EOS>
her
senses
are
going
again
,
"
said
Mr.
Wood
,
terrified
by
the
wildness
of
her
looks
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
afraid
it
would
be
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Only
three
days
,
"
reiterated
the
widow
,
"
three
short
short
<EOS>
days,--and
then
all
is
over
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
's
wicked
threat
is
fulfilled
at
last
.
<EOS>
The
gallows
is
in
view
--
I
see
it
with
all
its
hideous
apparatus!--ough
!
"
and
shuddering
violently
,
she
placed
her
hands
before
her
,
as
if
to
exclude
some
frightful
vision
from
her
sight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
despair
,
my
sweet
soul
,
"
said
Wood
,
in
a
soothing
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
despair
!
"
echoed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
with
a
laugh
that
cut
the
ears
of
those
who
listened
to
it
like
a
razor,--"Do
not
despair
!
<EOS>
And
who
or
what
shall
give
me
comfort
when
my
son
is
gone
?
<EOS>
I
have
wept
till
my
eyes
are
dry,--suffered
<EOS>
till
my
heart
is
broken,--prayed
till
the
voice
of
prayer
is
dumb,--and
all
of
no
avail
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
hanged
--
hanged
--
hanged
.
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
left
but
despair
and
madness
?
<EOS>
Promise
me
one
thing
,
Mr.
Wood
,
"
she
continued
,
with
a
sudden
change
of
tone
,
and
convulsively
clutching
the
carpenter
's
arm
,
"
promise
it
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
Wood
,
"
What
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bury
us
together
in
one
grave
in
Willesden
churchyard
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
small
yew
-
tree
west
of
the
church
.
<EOS>
Beneath
that
tree
let
us
lie
.
<EOS>
In
one
grave
,
mind
.
<EOS>
Do
you
promise
to
do
this
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Solemnly
,
"
rejoined
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
said
the
widow
,
gratefully
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
him
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,
dear
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
said
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
I
will
take
you
to
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
will
be
too
late
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
in
a
hollow
voice
,
"
I
feel
it
will
.
<EOS>
I
must
go
to
-
night
,
or
I
shall
never
behold
him
again
.
<EOS>
I
must
bless
him
before
I
die
.
<EOS>
I
have
strength
enough
to
drag
myself
there
,
and
I
do
not
want
to
return
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
pacified
,
sweet
soul
,
"
said
Wood
,
looking
meaningly
at
Thames
;
"
you
_
shall
_
go
,
and
I
will
accompany
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
mother
's
blessing
on
you
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
fervently
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
she
added
,
with
somewhat
more
composure
,
"
leave
me
,
dear
friends
,
I
entreat
,
for
a
few
minutes
to
collect
my
scattered
thoughts
--
to
prepare
myself
for
what
I
have
to
go
through
--
to
pray
for
my
son
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
do
so
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Winifred
to
her
father
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
,
"
returned
Wood
;
"
do
n't
delay
an
instant
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
followed
by
the
young
couple
,
who
gazed
wistfully
at
the
poor
sufferer
,
he
hastily
quitted
the
room
,
and
locked
the
door
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
was
no
sooner
alone
than
she
fell
upon
her
knees
by
the
side
of
the
couch
,
and
poured
forth
her
heart
in
prayer
.
<EOS>
So
absorbed
was
she
by
her
passionate
supplications
that
she
was
insensible
to
anything
passing
around
her
,
until
she
felt
a
touch
upon
her
shoulder
,
and
heard
a
well
-
known
voice
breathe
in
her
ear--"Mother
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
started
at
the
sound
as
if
an
apparition
had
called
her
,
screamed
,
and
fell
into
her
son
's
outstretched
arms
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mother
!
<EOS>
dear
mother
!
"
cried
Jack
,
folding
her
to
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
son
!
<EOS>
my
dear
,
dear
son
!
"
returned
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
returning
his
embrace
with
all
a
parent
's
tenderness
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
was
completely
overcome
.
<EOS>
His
chest
heaved
violently
,
and
big
tears
coursed
rapidly
down
his
cheeks
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
deserve
it
,
"
he
said
,
at
length
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
would
have
risked
a
thousand
deaths
to
enjoy
this
moment
's
happiness
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
you
must
have
risked
much
to
obtain
it
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
I
have
scarcely
recovered
from
the
shock
of
hearing
of
your
condemnation
,
when
I
behold
you
free
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
two
hours
since
,
"
rejoined
Jack
,
"
I
was
chained
down
in
the
Condemned
Hold
in
Newgate
.
<EOS>
With
a
small
saw
,
conveyed
to
me
a
few
days
since
by
Thames
Darrell
,
which
I
contrived
to
conceal
upon
my
person
,
I
removed
a
spike
in
the
hatch
,
and
,
with
the
aid
of
some
other
friends
,
worked
my
way
out
.
<EOS>
Having
heard
from
Thames
that
you
were
better
,
and
that
your
sole
anxiety
was
about
me
,
I
came
to
give
you
the
_
first
_
intelligence
of
my
escape
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
stay
here
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
not
.
<EOS>
I
must
provide
for
my
safety
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood
will
protect
you
,
"
urged
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
not
the
power
--
perhaps
not
the
will
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
would
,
_
<EOS>
I
_
would
not
subject
him
to
the
annoyance
.
<EOS>
The
moment
my
escape
is
known
,
a
large
reward
will
be
placed
on
my
head
.
<EOS>
My
dress
,
my
person
will
be
minutely
described
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
and
his
bloodhounds
,
with
a
hundred
others
,
incited
by
the
reward
,
will
be
upon
my
track
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
for
aught
I
know
,
some
of
them
may
even
now
have
got
scent
of
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
terrify
me
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
this
is
the
case
,
do
not
stay
an
instant
.
<EOS>
Fly
!
fly
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
soon
as
I
can
do
so
with
safety
,
I
will
return
,
or
send
to
you
,
"
said
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
endanger
yourself
on
my
account
,
"
rejoined
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
easy
now
;
receive
my
blessing
,
my
dear
son
;
and
if
we
never
meet
again
,
rest
assured
my
last
prayer
shall
be
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
talk
thus
,
dear
mother
,
"
returned
Jack
,
gazing
anxiously
at
her
pale
countenance
,
"
or
I
shall
not
be
able
to
quit
you
.
<EOS>
You
must
live
for
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
try
to
do
so
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
forcing
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
One
last
embrace
.
<EOS>
I
need
not
counsel
you
to
avoid
those
fatal
courses
which
have
placed
you
in
such
fearful
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
not
,
"
replied
Jack
,
in
a
tone
of
the
deepest
compunction
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
oh
!
forgive
me
,
though
I
can
never
forgive
myself
,
for
the
misery
I
have
caused
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
you
!
"
echoed
his
mother
,
with
a
look
radiant
with
delight
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
to
forgive
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
she
screamed
,
with
a
sudden
change
of
manner
;
and
pointing
to
the
window
,
which
Jack
had
left
open
,
and
at
which
a
dark
figure
was
standing
,
"
there
is
Jonathan
Wild
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Betrayed
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Jack
,
glancing
in
the
same
direction
.
<EOS>
"
The
door!--the
door!--death
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
as
he
tried
the
handle
,
"
it
is
locked
--
and
I
am
unarmed
.
<EOS>
Madman
that
I
am
to
be
so
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Help
!
"
shrieked
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
silent
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
striding
deliberately
into
the
room
;
"
these
cries
will
avail
you
nothing
.
<EOS>
Whoever
answers
them
must
assist
me
to
capture
your
son
.
<EOS>
Be
silent
,
I
say
,
if
you
value
his
safety
.
"
 
<EOS>
Awed
by
Jonathan
's
manner
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
repressed
the
scream
that
rose
to
her
lips
,
and
both
mother
and
son
gazed
with
apprehension
at
the
heavy
figure
of
the
thief
-
taker
,
which
,
viewed
in
the
twilight
,
seemed
dilated
to
twice
its
natural
size
,
and
appeared
almost
to
block
up
the
window
.
<EOS>
In
addition
to
his
customary
arms
,
Jonathan
carried
a
bludgeon
with
a
large
heavy
knob
,
suspended
from
his
wrist
by
a
loop
;
a
favourite
weapon
,
which
he
always
took
with
him
on
dangerous
expeditions
,
and
which
,
if
any
information
had
been
requisite
,
would
have
told
Sheppard
that
the
present
was
one
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Jack
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
pause
,
"
are
you
disposed
to
go
back
quietly
with
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
ascertain
that
when
you
attempt
to
touch
me
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
,
resolutely
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
janizaries
are
within
call
,
"
returned
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
armed
;
you
are
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
matters
not
.
<EOS>
You
shall
not
take
me
alive
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Spare
him
!
<EOS>
spare
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
falling
on
her
knees
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
up
,
mother
,
"
cried
Jack
;
"
do
not
kneel
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
accept
my
life
from
him
.
<EOS>
I
've
foiled
him
hitherto
,
and
will
foil
him
yet
.
<EOS>
And
,
come
what
will
,
I
'll
balk
him
of
the
satisfaction
of
hanging
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
raised
his
bludgeon
,
but
controlled
himself
by
a
powerful
effort
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fool
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
do
you
think
I
would
n't
have
secured
you
before
this
if
I
had
n't
some
motive
for
my
forbearance
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
that
motive
is
fear
,
"
replied
Jack
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fear
!
"
echoed
Wild
,
in
a
terrible
tone,--"fear
!
<EOS>
Repeat
that
word
again
,
and
nothing
shall
save
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
anger
him
,
my
dear
son
,
"
implored
the
poor
widow
,
with
a
look
of
anguish
at
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
means
well
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mad
as
you
are
<EOS>
,
you
're
the
more
sensible
of
the
two
,
I
must
say
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Spare
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
,
Sheppard
,
who
fancied
she
had
made
some
impression
on
the
obdurate
breast
of
the
thief
-
taker,--"spare
him
!
<EOS>
and
I
will
forgive
you
,
will
thank
you
,
bless
you
.
<EOS>
Spare
him
!
<EOS>
spare
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
one
condition
I
_
will
_
spare
him
,
"
returned
Wild
;
"
on
one
condition
only
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
asked
the
poor
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Either
he
or
you
must
return
with
me
,
"
answered
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
_
me
_
,
then
,
"
replied
the
widow
.
<EOS>
And
she
would
have
rushed
to
him
,
if
she
had
not
been
forcibly
withheld
by
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
go
near
him
,
mother
,
"
cried
Jack
;
"
do
not
believe
him
.
<EOS>
There
is
some
deep
treachery
hidden
beneath
his
words
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
will
_
go
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
struggling
to
get
free
.
 
<EOS>
"
Attend
to
me
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
looking
calmly
on
at
this
distressing
scene
,
"
Attend
to
me
,
and
do
not
heed
him
.
<EOS>
I
swear
to
you
,
solemnly
swear
to
you
,
I
will
save
your
son
's
life
,
nay
more
,
will
befriend
him
,
will
place
him
out
of
the
reach
of
his
enemies
,
if
you
consent
to
become
my
wife
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Execrable
villain
!
"
exclaimed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
hear
that
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
;
"
he
swears
to
save
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
replied
her
son
;
"
and
you
spurn
the
proposal
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
;
she
accepts
it
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
triumphantly
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
I
've
a
carriage
within
call
<EOS>
shall
convey
you
swiftly
to
town
.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
come
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
mother
,
"
cried
Jack
,
"
and
I
will
explain
to
you
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
why
_
the
villain
makes
this
strange
and
revolting
proposal
.
<EOS>
He
well
knows
that
but
two
lives
--
those
of
Thames
Darrell
and
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard,--stand
between
you
and
the
vast
possessions
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
Those
lives
removed,--and
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
is
completely
in
his
power
,
the
estates
would
be
yours
--
HIS
!
<EOS>
if
he
were
your
husband
.
<EOS>
Now
do
you
see
his
motive
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
nothing
but
your
danger
,
"
replied
his
mother
,
tenderly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Granted
it
were
as
you
say
,
Jack
,
"
said
Wild;--"and
<EOS>
I
sha'n't
take
the
trouble
to
contradict
you
--
the
estates
would
be
_
yours
_
hereafter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Liar
!
"
cried
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
affect
ignorance
that
I
am
a
condemned
felon
,
and
can
inherit
nothing
?
<EOS>
But
do
not
imagine
that
under
any
circumstances
I
would
accept
your
terms
.
<EOS>
My
mother
shall
never
degrade
herself
by
a
connection
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Degrade
herself
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
brutally
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
would
take
a
harlot
to
my
bed
,
if
it
did
n't
suit
my
purposes
to
do
so
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
says
right
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
distractedly
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
only
fit
for
such
as
him
.
<EOS>
Take
me
!
<EOS>
take
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Before
an
hour
you
shall
be
mine
,
"
said
Jonathan
advancing
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Back
!
"
cried
Jack
fiercely
:
<EOS>
"
lay
a
finger
on
her
,
and
I
will
fell
you
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Mother
!
<EOS>
do
you
know
what
you
do
?
<EOS>
Would
you
sell
yourself
to
this
fiend
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
sell
myself
,
body
and
soul
,
to
save
you
,
"
rejoined
his
mother
,
bursting
from
his
grasp
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
caught
her
in
his
arms
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
away
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
with
the
roar
of
a
demon
.
 
<EOS>
This
laugh
and
his
looks
alarmed
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
_
is
_
the
fiend
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
,
recoiling
.
"
<EOS>
Save
me!--save
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Damnation
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Jonathan
,
savagely
.
<EOS>
"
We
've
no
time
for
any
Bedlam
scenes
now
.
<EOS>
Come
along
,
you
mad
jade
.
<EOS>
I
'll
teach
you
submission
in
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
endeavoured
to
force
her
off
;
but
,
before
he
could
accomplish
his
purpose
,
he
was
arrested
,
and
<EOS>
his
throat
seized
by
Jack
.
<EOS>
In
the
struggle
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
broke
from
him
,
and
filled
the
room
with
her
shrieks
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
now
pay
the
debt
I
owe
you
,
"
cried
Jack
,
tightening
his
grip
till
the
thief
-
taker
blackened
in
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dog
!
"
cried
Wild
,
freeing
himself
by
a
powerful
effort
,
and
dealing
Jack
a
violent
blow
with
the
heavy
bludgeon
,
which
knocked
him
backwards
,
"
you
are
not
yet
a
match
for
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
Neither
you
nor
your
mother
shall
escape
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
summon
my
janizaries
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
raised
a
whistle
to
his
lips
,
and
blew
a
loud
call
;
and
,
as
this
was
unanswered
,
another
still
louder
.
"
Confusion
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
;
"
something
has
happened
.
<EOS>
But
I
wo
n't
be
cheated
of
my
prize
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
<EOS>
"
shrieked
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
fleeing
from
him
to
the
farthest
corner
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
of
no
avail
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
again
seized
her
,
when
the
door
was
thrown
open
,
and
Thames
Darrell
,
followed
by
Mr.
Wood
and
several
serving
-
men
,
all
well
armed
,
rushed
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
A
glance
sufficed
to
show
the
young
man
how
matters
stood
.
<EOS>
He
flew
to
the
window
,
and
would
have
passed
his
sword
through
the
thief
-
taker
's
body
,
if
the
latter
had
not
quickly
interposed
the
person
of
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
so
that
if
the
blow
had
been
stricken
she
must
have
received
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quilt!--Mendez!--Where
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Wild
,
sounding
his
whistle
for
the
third
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
call
in
vain
,
"
rejoined
Thames
.
"
<EOS>
Your
assistants
are
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
Yield
,
villain
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
replied
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
down
your
burthen
,
monster
!
"
shouted
Wood
,
pointing
an
immense
blunderbuss
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
her
,
"
cried
Jonathan
;
and
,
flinging
the
now
inanimate
body
of
the
poor
widow
,
who
had
fainted
in
the
struggle
,
into
the
arms
of
Thames
<EOS>
,
he
leapt
through
the
window
,
and
by
the
time
the
latter
could
consign
her
to
Wood
,
and
dart
after
him
,
he
had
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pursue
him
,
"
cried
Thames
to
the
attendants
,
"
and
see
that
he
does
not
escape
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
order
was
promptly
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
continued
Thames
,
addressing
Sheppard
,
who
had
only
just
recovered
from
the
blow
,
and
regained
his
feet
,
"
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
_
how
_
you
came
here
,
nor
do
I
blame
your
rashness
in
doing
so
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
ever
since
Wild
's
late
murderous
attack
,
the
household
has
all
been
well
armed
.
<EOS>
A
post
-
chaise
seen
in
the
road
first
alarmed
us
.
<EOS>
On
searching
the
grounds
,
we
found
two
suspicious
-
looking
fellows
in
the
garden
,
and
had
scarcely
secured
them
,
when
your
mother
's
cries
summoned
us
hither
,
just
in
time
to
preserve
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
arrival
was
most
providential
,
"
said
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
remain
here
another
instant
,
"
replied
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
My
horse
is
at
the
door
,
saddled
,
with
pistols
in
the
holsters,--mount
him
and
fly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thames
,
I
have
much
to
say
,
"
said
Jack
,
"
much
that
concerns
your
safety
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
now
,
"
returned
Thames
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
I
cannot
--
will
not
suffer
you
to
remain
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
,
if
you
will
consent
to
meet
me
at
midnight
near
the
old
house
in
Wych
Street
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
By
that
time
,
I
shall
have
fully
considered
a
plan
which
occurs
to
me
for
defeating
the
schemes
of
your
enemies
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Before
that
time
you
will
be
captured
,
if
you
expose
yourself
thus
,
"
rejoined
Thames
.
"
<EOS>
However
,
I
will
be
there
.
<EOS>
Farewell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Till
midnight
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
And
imprinting
a
kiss
upon
his
mother
's
cold
lips
,
he
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
horse
where
Thames
told
him
he
would
find
him
,
mounted
,
and
rode
off
across
the
fields
in
the
direction
of
town
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Well
Hole
.
  
<EOS>
Jonathan
Wild
's
first
object
,
as
soon
as
he
had
made
good
his
retreat
,
was
to
ascertain
what
had
become
of
his
janizaries
,
and
,
if
possible
,
to
release
them
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
hurried
to
the
spot
where
he
had
left
the
post
-
chaise
,
and
found
it
drawn
up
at
the
road
-
side
,
the
postilion
dismounted
,
and
in
charge
of
a
couple
of
farming
-
men
.
<EOS>
Advancing
towards
them
,
sword
in
hand
,
Jonathan
so
terrified
the
hinds
by
his
fierce
looks
and
determined
manner
,
that
,
after
a
slight
show
of
resistance
,
they
took
to
their
heels
,
leaving
him
master
of
the
field
.
<EOS>
He
then
threw
open
the
door
of
the
vehicle
,
in
which
he
found
his
janizaries
with
their
arms
pinioned
,
and
,
leaping
into
it
,
ordered
the
man
to
drive
off
.
<EOS>
The
postilion
obeyed
,
and
dashed
off
as
hard
as
his
horses
could
gallop
along
the
beautiful
road
leading
to
Neasdon
and
Willesden
,
just
as
the
serving
-
men
made
their
appearance
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
latter
place
,
Jonathan
,
who
,
meanwhile
,
had
contrived
to
liberate
his
attendants
from
their
bonds
,
drew
up
at
the
Six
Bells
,
and
hiring
a
couple
of
horses
,
despatched
his
attendants
in
search
of
Jack
Sheppard
,
while
he
proceeded
to
town
.
<EOS>
Dismissing
the
post
-
chaise
at
the
Old
Bailey
,
he
walked
to
Newgate
to
ascertain
what
had
occurred
since
the
escape
.
<EOS>
It
was
just
upon
the
stroke
of
nine
as
he
entered
the
Lodge
,
and
Mr.
Austin
was
dismissing
a
host
of
inquirers
who
had
been
attracted
thither
by
the
news,--for
<EOS>
it
had
already
been
extensively
noised
abroad
.
<EOS>
Some
of
these
persons
were
examining
the
spot
where
the
spike
had
been
cut
off
;
others
the
spike
itself
,
now
considered
a
remarkable
object
;
and
all
were
marvelling
how
Jack
could
have
possibly
squeezed
himself
through
such
a
narrow
aperture
,
until
it
was
explained
to
them
by
Mr.
Austin
that
the
renowned
housebreaker
was
of
slender
bodily
conformation
,
and
therefore
able
to
achieve
a
feat
,
which
he
,
Mr.
Austin
,
or
any
man
of
similar
dimensions
,
would
have
found
wholly
impossible
.
<EOS>
Affixed
to
the
wall
,
in
a
conspicuous
situation
,
was
a
large
placard
,
which
,
after
minutely
describing
Sheppard
's
appearance
and
attire
,
concluded
thus:--"_Whoever
will
discover
or
apprehend
the
above
_
JOHN
SHEPPARD
,
_
so
that
he
be
brought
to
justice
,
shall
receive
_
ONE
HUNDRED
GUINEAS
REWARD
,
_
to
be
paid
by
_
MR
.
<EOS>
PITT
,
_
<EOS>
the
keeper
of
Newgate
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
placard
attracted
universal
attention
.
<EOS>
While
Jonathan
was
conversing
with
Austin
,
from
whom
he
took
care
to
conceal
the
fact
of
his
having
seen
Sheppard
since
his
escape
,
Ireton
entered
the
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
"
Altogether
unsuccessful
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
chief
turnkey
,
with
a
look
of
disappointment
,
not
unmixed
with
apprehension
,
as
he
approached
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
to
all
the
flash
cases
in
town
,
and
can
hear
nothing
of
him
or
his
wives
.
<EOS>
First
,
I
went
to
Country
Tom
's
,
the
Goat
,
in
Long
Lane
.
<EOS>
Tom
swore
he
had
n't
set
eyes
on
him
since
the
trial
.
<EOS>
I
next
proceeded
to
Jenny
Bunch
's
,
the
Ship
,
in
Trig
Lane
--
there
I
got
the
same
answer
.
<EOS>
Then
to
the
Feathers
,
in
Drury
Lane
.
<EOS>
Then
to
the
Golden
Ball
,
in
the
same
street
.
<EOS>
Then
to
Martin
's
brandy
-
shop
,
in
Fleet
Street
.
<EOS>
Then
to
Dan
Ware
's
,
in
Hanging
Sword
Court
.
<EOS>
Then
to
the
Dean
's
Head
,
in
St.
Martin
's
Le
Grand
.
<EOS>
And
,
lastly
,
to
the
Seven
Cities
o
'
Refuge
,
in
the
New
Mint
.
<EOS>
And
nowhere
could
I
obtain
the
slightest
information
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
exclaimed
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
more
successful
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
ventured
Ireton
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
shook
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Shotbolt
thinks
he
has
a
scheme
that
ca
n't
fail
,
"
interposed
Austin
;
"
but
he
wishes
to
know
whether
you
'll
be
as
good
as
your
word
,
in
respect
to
the
great
reward
you
offered
for
Jack
's
capture
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
ever
broken
my
word
in
such
matters
,
that
he
dares
put
the
question
?
"
rejoined
Jonathan
sternly
.
"
<EOS>
Tell
Mr.
Shotbolt
that
if
he
,
or
any
other
person
,
takes
Jack
Sheppard
before
to
-
morrow
morning
,
I
'll
double
it
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Austin
respectfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
hundred
pounds
,
if
he
's
lodged
in
Newgate
before
to
-
morrow
morning
,
"
continued
Wild
.
"
<EOS>
Make
it
known
among
your
friends
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
strode
out
of
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
hundred
pounds
!
"
exclaimed
Ireton
,
"
besides
the
governor
's
offer
--
that
's
three
hundred
.
<EOS>
I
must
go
to
work
again
.
<EOS>
Keep
a
sharp
look
out
,
Austin
,
and
see
that
we
lose
no
one
else
.
<EOS>
I
should
be
sorry
if
Shotbolt
got
the
reward
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Devilish
hard
!
<EOS>
I
'm
not
allowed
a
chance
,
"
grumbled
Austin
,
as
he
was
left
alone
.
"
<EOS>
However
,
some
one
_
must
_
look
after
the
jail
;
and
they
're
all
gone
but
<EOS>
me
.
<EOS>
It
's
fortunate
<EOS>
we
've
no
more
Jack
Sheppards
,
or
I
should
stand
but
a
poor
chance
.
<EOS>
Well
,
I
do
n't
think
they
'll
any
of
'em
nab
him
<EOS>
,
that
's
one
comfort
.
"
 
<EOS>
On
quitting
the
Lodge
,
Wild
repaired
to
his
own
habitation
.
<EOS>
Telling
the
porter
that
he
would
attend
to
the
house
himself
,
he
bade
him
go
in
search
of
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
Jonathan
's
manner
,
as
he
issued
this
command
,
that
struck
the
man
as
singular
,
and
he
afterwards
recalled
it
.
<EOS>
He
,
however
,
made
no
remark
at
the
time
,
but
instantly
prepared
to
set
out
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
gone
,
Jonathan
went
up
stairs
to
the
audience
-
chamber
;
and
,
sitting
down
,
appeared
for
some
time
buried
in
reflection
.
<EOS>
The
dark
and
desperate
thoughts
that
were
passing
through
his
mind
at
this
time
will
presently
be
shown
.
<EOS>
After
a
while
,
he
raised
his
eyes
;
and
,
if
their
glance
could
have
been
witnessed
at
the
moment
,
it
could
not
have
been
easily
forgotten
.
<EOS>
Muttering
something
to
himself
,
he
appeared
to
be
telling
upon
his
fingers
the
advantages
and
disadvantages
of
some
scheme
he
had
in
contemplation
.
<EOS>
That
he
had
resolved
upon
its
execution
,
whatever
it
might
be
,
was
evident
from
his
saying
aloud,--
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
it
.
<EOS>
So
good
an
opportunity
may
never
occur
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon
this
he
arose
,
and
paced
the
room
hastily
backwards
and
forwards
,
as
if
further
arranging
his
plans
.
<EOS>
He
then
unlocked
a
cabinet
,
opened
a
secret
drawer
,
and
,
lifter
ransacking
its
contents
,
discovered
a
paper
he
was
in
search
of
,
and
a
glove
.
<EOS>
Laying
these
carefully
aside
,
he
restored
the
drawer
to
its
place
.
<EOS>
His
next
occupation
was
to
take
out
his
pistols
,
examine
the
priming
,
and
rub
the
flints
.
<EOS>
His
sword
then
came
in
for
his
scrutiny
:
he
felt
at
,
and
appeared
satisfied
with
its
edge
.
<EOS>
This
employment
seemed
to
afford
him
the
highest
satisfaction
;
for
a
diabolical
grin
--
it
can
not
be
called
a
smile
--
played
upon
his
face
all
the
time
he
was
engaged
in
it
.
<EOS>
His
sword
done
with
,
he
took
up
the
bludgeon
;
balanced
it
in
his
hand
;
upon
the
points
of
his
fingers
;
and
let
it
fall
with
a
smash
,
intentionally
,
upon
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
"
he
said
,
"
this
is
the
safest
weapon
.
<EOS>
No
instrument
I
've
ever
used
has
done
me
such
good
service
.
<EOS>
It
_
shall
_
be
the
bludgeon
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
slung
it
upon
his
wrist
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
up
a
link
,
which
was
blazing
beside
him
,
he
walked
across
the
room
;
and
touching
a
spring
in
the
wall
,
a
secret
door
flew
open
.
<EOS>
Beyond
was
a
narrow
bridge
,
crossing
a
circular
building
,
at
the
bottom
of
which
lay
a
deep
well
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dark
mysterious
place
,
and
what
it
was
used
for
no
one
exactly
knew
;
but
it
was
called
by
those
who
had
seen
it
the
Well
Hole
.
<EOS>
The
bridge
was
protected
on
either
side
by
a
railing
with
bannisters
placed
at
wide
intervals
.
<EOS>
Steps
to
aid
the
descent
,
which
was
too
steep
to
be
safe
without
them
,
led
to
,
a
door
on
the
opposite
side
.
<EOS>
This
door
,
which
was
open
,
Jonathan
locked
and
took
out
the
key
.
<EOS>
As
he
stood
upon
the
bridge
,
he
held
down
the
light
,
and
looked
into
the
profound
abyss
.
<EOS>
The
red
glare
fell
upon
the
slimy
brick
-
work
,
and
tinged
the
inky
waters
below
.
<EOS>
A
slight
cough
uttered
by
Jonathan
at
the
moment
awakened
the
echoes
of
the
place
,
and
was
returned
in
hollow
reverberations
.
<EOS>
"
There
'll
be
a
louder
echo
here
presently
,
"
thought
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
Before
leaving
the
place
he
looked
upwards
,
and
could
just
discern
the
blue
vault
and
pale
stars
of
Heaven
through
an
iron
grating
at
the
top
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
return
to
the
room
,
Jonathan
purposely
left
the
door
of
the
Well
Hole
ajar
.
<EOS>
Unlocking
a
cupboard
,
he
then
took
out
some
cold
meat
and
other
viands
,
with
a
flask
of
wine
,
and
a
bottle
of
brandy
,
and
began
to
eat
and
drink
voraciously
.
<EOS>
He
had
very
nearly
cleared
the
board
,
when
a
knock
was
heard
below
,
and
descending
at
the
summons
,
he
found
his
two
janizaries
.
<EOS>
They
had
both
been
unsuccessful
.
<EOS>
As
Jonathan
scarcely
expected
a
more
satisfactory
result
,
he
made
no
comment
;
but
,
ordering
Quilt
to
continue
his
search
,
and
not
to
return
until
he
had
found
the
fugitive
,
called
Abraham
Mendez
into
the
house
,
and
shut
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
for
the
job
I
spoke
of
a
short
time
ago
,
Nab
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
have
no
one
but
yourself
in
it
.
<EOS>
Come
up
stairs
,
and
take
a
glass
of

.
"
 
<EOS>
Abraham
grinned
,
and
silently
followed
his
master
,
who
,
as
soon
as
they
reached
the
audience
-
chamber
,
poured
out
a
bumper
of
spirits
,
and
presented
it
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
Jew
swallowed
it
at
a
draught
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
my
shoul
!
"
he
exclaimed
,
smacking
his
lips
,
"
dat
ish
goot
--
very
goot
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
finish
the
bottle
when
the
job
's
done
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Vat
ish
it
,
Mishter
Vild
?
"
inquired
Mendez
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shir
Rowland
Trenchard
's
affair
--
eh
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
;
"
I
expect

here
every

.
<EOS>
When
you
've
admitted
him
,
steal
into
the
room
,
hide

,
and
do
n't
move
till
I
utter

,
'
<EOS>
You
've
a
long
journey
before
you
.
'
<EOS>
That
's
your
signal
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
a
famoush
goot
shignal
it
ish
,
"
laughed
Abraham
.
"
<EOS>
He
hash
a
long
journey
before
him
--
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
!
"
cried
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
his
knock
.
<EOS>
Go
,
and
let
him
in
.
<EOS>
And
mind
you
do
n't
arouse
his
suspicions
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
fear
--
never
fear
,
"
rejoined
Abraham
,
as
he
took
up
the
link
,
and
left
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
cast
a
hasty
glance
around
,
to
see
that
all
was
properly
arranged
for
his
purpose
;
placed
a
chair
with
its
back
to
the
door
;
disposed
the
lights
on
the
table
so
as
to
throw
the
entrance
of
the
room
more
into
shadow
;
and
then
flung
himself
into
a
seat
to
await
Sir
Rowland
's
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
to
wait
long
.
<EOS>
Enveloped
in
a
large
cloak
,
Sir
Rowland
stalked
into
the
room
,
and
took
the
seat
assigned
him
;
while
the
Jew
,
who
received
a
private
signal
from
Jonathan
,
set
down
the
link
near
the
entrance
of
the
Well
Hole
,
and
,
having
made
fast
the
door
,
crept
behind
one
of
the
cases
.
 
<EOS>
Fancying
they
were
alone
,
Sir
Rowland
threw
aside
his
cloak
,
and
produced
a
heavy
bag
of
money
,
which
he
flung
upon
the
table
;
and
,
when
Wild
had
feasted
his
greedy
eyes
sufficiently
upon
its
golden
contents
,
he
handed
him
a
pocket
-
book
filled
with
notes
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
behaved
like
a
man
of
honour
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
said
Wild
,
after
he
had
twice
told
over
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Right
to
a
farthing
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
an
acquittance
,
"
said
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
scarcely
necessary
,
"
replied
Wild
;
"
however
,
if
you
require
it
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
There
it
is
.
'
<EOS>
Received
from
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
,
15,000
£
.--Jonathan
<EOS>
Wild
:
<EOS>
August
31st
,
1724
.
'
<EOS>
Will
that
do
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
,
"
replied
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
our
last
transaction
together
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
replied
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
last
,
"
continued
the
knight
,
sternly
;
"
and
I
trust
we
may
never
meet
again
,
I
have
paid
you
this
large
sum
--
not
because
you
are
entitled
to
it
,
for
you
have
failed
in
what
you
undertook
to
do
,
but
because
I
desire
to
be
troubled
with
you
no
further
.
<EOS>
I
have
now
settled
my
affairs
,
and
made
every
preparation
for
my
departure
to
France
,
where
I
shall
spend
the
remainder
of
my
days
.
<EOS>
And
I
have
made
such
arrangements
that
at
my
decease
tardy
justice
will
be
done
my
injured
nephew
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
made
no
such
arrangements
as
will
compromise
me
,
I
hope
,
Sir
Rowland
?
"
said
Wild
,
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
While
I
live
you
are
safe
,
"
rejoined
Trenchard
;
"
after
my
death
I
can
answer
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sblood
!
"
exclaimed
Wild
,
uneasily
.
"
<EOS>
This
alters
the
case
materially
.
<EOS>
When
were
you
last
confessed
,
Sir
Rowland
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
abruptly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
ask
?
"
rejoined
the
other
haughtily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
--
because
I
'm
always
distrustful
of
a
priest
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
parted
from
one
,
"
said
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
worse
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
rising
and
taking
a
turn
,
as
if
uncertain
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
,
"
rejoined
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
He
who
stands
on
the
verge
of
the
grave
,
as
I
do
,
should
never
be
unprepared
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
strangely
superstitious
,
Sir
Rowland
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
halting
,
and
looking
steadfastly
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
so
,
I
should
not
be
here
,
"
returned
Trenchard
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
so
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Wild
,
curiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
a
terrible
dream
last
night
.
<EOS>
I
thought
my
sister
and
her
murdered
husband
dragged
me
hither
,
to
this
very
room
,
and
commanded
you
to
slay
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
terrible
dream
,
indeed
,
"
said
Jonathan
thoughtfully
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
must
n't
indulge
these
gloomy
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Let
me
recommend
a
glass
of
wine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
penance
forbids
it
,
"
said
Trenchard
,
waving
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
remain
here
long
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
remain
longer
than
you
anticipate
,
"
muttered
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Before
I
go
,
"
continued
Sir
Rowland
,
"
I
must
beg
of
you
to
disclose
to
me
all
you
know
relative
to
the
parentage
of
Thames
Darrell
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Willingly
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Thinking
it
likely
you
might
desire
to
have
this
information
,
I
prepared
accordingly
.
<EOS>
First
,
look
at
this
glove
.
<EOS>
It
belonged
to
his
father
,
and
was
worn
by
him
on
the
night
he
was
murdered
.
<EOS>
You
will
observe
that
a
coronet
is
embroidered
on
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
exclaimed
Trenchard
,
starting
,
"
is
he
so
highly
born
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
letter
will
inform
you
,
"
replied
Wild
,
placing
a
document
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
this
!
"
cried
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
the
hand
--
ha
!
<EOS>
my
friend
!
<EOS>
and
I
have
murdered
_
him
_
!
<EOS>
And
my
sister
was
thus
nobly
,
thus
illustriously
wedded
.
<EOS>
O
God
!
<EOS>
O
God
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
appeared
convulsed
with
agony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
I
had
known
this
,
"
he
exclaimed
,
"
what
guilt
,
what
remorse
might
have
been
spared
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Repentance
comes
too
late
when
the
deed
's
done
,
"
returned
Wild
,
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
too
late
to
repair
the
wrong
I
have
done
my
nephew
,
"
cried
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
set
about
it
instantly
.
<EOS>
He
shall
have
the
estates
.
<EOS>
I
will
return
to
Manchester
at
once
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
take
some
refreshment
before
you
start
,
"
rejoined
Wild
.
"
<EOS>
'
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
've
a
long
journey
before
you
.
<EOS>
_
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
the
signal
was
given
,
the
Jew
,
who
had
been
some
time
in
expectation
of
it
,
darted
swiftly
and
silently
behind
Sir
Rowland
,
and
flung
a
cloth
over
his
head
,
while
Jonathan
,
rushing
upon
him
in
front
,
struck
him
several
quick
and
violent
blows
in
the
face
with
the
bludgeon
.
<EOS>
The
white
cloth
was
instantly
dyed
with
crimson
;
but
,
regardless
of
this
,
Jonathan
continued
his
murderous
assault
.
<EOS>
The
struggles
of
the
wounded
man
were
desperate
--
so
desperate
,
that
in
his
agony
he
overset
the
table
,
and
,
in
the
confusion
,
tore
off
the
cloth
,
and
disclosed
a
face
horribly
mutilated
,
and
streaming
with
blood
.
<EOS>
So
appalling
was
the
sight
,
that
even
the
murderers
--
familiar
as
they
were
with
scenes
of
slaughter,--looked
aghast
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
During
this
dreadful
pause
the
wretched
man
felt
for
his
sword
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
removed
from
the
scabbard
by
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
He
uttered
a
deep
groan
,
but
said
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Despatch
him
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
Having
no
means
of
defence
,
Sir
Rowland
cleared
the
blood
from
his
vision
;
and
,
turning
to
see
whether
there
was
any
means
of
escape
,
he
descried
the
open
door
behind
him
leading
to
the
Well
Hole
,
and
instantly
darted
through
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
could
wish
!
"
cried
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
the
light
,
Nab
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
snatched
up
the
link
,
and
followed
him
.
 
<EOS>
A
struggle
of
the
most
terrific
kind
now
ensued
.
<EOS>
The
wounded
man
had
descended
the
bridge
,
and
dashed
himself
against
the
door
beyond
it
;
but
,
finding
it
impossible
to
force
his
way
further
,
he
turned
to
confront
his
assailants
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
aimed
a
blow
at
him
,
which
,
if
it
had
taken
place
,
must
have
instantly
terminated
the
strife
;
but
,
avoiding
this
,
he
sprang
at
the
thief
-
taker
,
and
grappled
with
him
.
<EOS>
Firmly
built
,
as
it
was
,
the
bridge
creaked
in
such
a
manner
with
their
contending
efforts
,
that
Abraham
durst
not
venture
beyond
the
door
,
where
he
stood
,
holding
the
light
,
a
horrified
spectator
of
the
scene
.
<EOS>
The
contest
,
however
,
though
desperate
,
was
brief
.
<EOS>
Disengaging
his
right
arm
,
Jonathan
struck
his
victim
a
tremendous
blow
on
the
head
with
the
bludgeon
,
that
fractured
his
skull
;
and
,
exerting
all
his
strength
,
threw
him
over
the
rails
,
to
which
he
clung
with
the
tenacity
of
despair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Spare
me
!
"
<EOS>
he
groaned
,
looking
upwards
.
"
<EOS>
Spare
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
however
,
instead
of
answering
him
,
searched
for
his
knife
,
with
the
intention
of
severing
his
wrist
.
<EOS>
But
not
finding
it
,
he
had
again
recourse
to
the
bludgeon
,
and
began
beating
the
hand
fixed
on
the
upper
rail
,
until
,
by
smashing
the
fingers
,
he
forced
it
to
relinquish
its
hold
.
<EOS>
He
then
stamped
upon
the
hand
on
the
lower
bannister
,
until
that
also
relaxed
its
gripe
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
then
fell
.
 
<EOS>
A
hollow
plunge
,
echoed
and
re
-
echoed
by
the
walls
,
marked
his
descent
into
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
the
link
,
"
cried
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
Holding
down
the
light
,
he
perceived
that
the
wounded
man
had
risen
to
the
surface
,
and
was
trying
to
clamber
up
the
slippery
sides
of
the
well
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shoot
him
!
<EOS>
shoot
him
!
<EOS>
Put
him
out
of
hish
mishery
,
"
cried
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
of
wasting
a
shot
?
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
savagely
.
"
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
get
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
making
several
ineffectual
attempts
to
keep
himself
above
water
,
Sir
Rowland
sunk
,
and
his
groans
,
which
had
become
gradually
fainter
and
fainter
,
were
heard
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
's
over
,
"
muttered
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
ve
go
back
to
de
other
room
?
"
asked
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
breathe
more
freely
dere
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Christ
!
<EOS>
de
door
's
shut
!
<EOS>
It
musht
have
schwung
to
during
de
schuffle
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shut
!
"
exclaimed
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Then
we
're
imprisoned
.
<EOS>
The
spring
ca
n't
be
opened
on
this
side
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dere
's
de
other
door
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mendez
,
in
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
only
leads
to
the
fencing
crib
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
outlet
that
way
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
ve
call
for
asshistanche
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
who
'll
find
us
,
if
we
do
?
"
rejoined
Wild
,
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
But
they
_
will
_
find
the
evidences
of
slaughter
in
the
other
room,--the
table
<EOS>
upset,--the
bloody
<EOS>
cloth,--the
dead
man
's
sword,--the
money,--and
<EOS>
my
memorandum
,
which
I
forgot
to
remove
.
<EOS>
Hell
's
curses
!
<EOS>
that
after
all
my
precautions
I
should
be
thus
entrapped
.
<EOS>
It
's
all
your
fault
,
you
shaking
coward
!
<EOS>
and
,
but
that
I
feel
sure
you
'll
swing
for
your
carelessness
,
I
'd
throw
you
into
the
well
,
too
.
"
    
CHAPTER
XIII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Supper
at
Mr.
Kneebone
's
.
  
<EOS>
Persuaded
that
Jack
Sheppard
would
keep
his
appointment
with
Mr.
Kneebone
,
and
feeling
certain
of
capturing
him
if
he
did
so
,
Shotbolt
,
on
quitting
Newgate
,
hurried
to
the
New
Prison
to
prepare
for
the
enterprise
.
<EOS>
After
debating
with
himself
for
some
time
whether
he
should
employ
an
assistant
,
or
make
the
attempt
alone
,
his
love
of
gain
overcame
his
fears
,
and
he
decided
upon
the
latter
plan
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
having
armed
himself
with
various
weapons
,
including
a
stout
oaken
staff
then
ordinarily
borne
by
the
watch
,
and
put
a
coil
of
rope
and
a
gag
in
his
pocket
,
to
be
ready
in
case
of
need
,
he
set
out
,
about
ten
o'clock
,
on
the
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
Before
proceeding
to
Wych
Street
,
he
called
at
the
Lodge
to
see
how
matters
were
going
on
,
and
found
Mrs.
Spurling
and
Austin
at
their
evening
meal
,
with
Caliban
in
attendance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr.
Shotbolt
,
"
cried
the
turnkey
,
"
I
've
good
news
for
you
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wild
has
doubled
his
offer
,
and
the
governor
has
likewise
proclaimed
a
reward
of
one
hundred
guineas
for
Jack
's
apprehension
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Shotbolt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Read
that
,
"
rejoined
Austin
,
pointing
to
the
placard
.
<EOS>
"
I
ought
to
tell
you
that
Mr.
Wild
's
reward
is
conditional
upon
<EOS>
Jack
's
being
taken
before
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
So
I
fear
there
's
little
chance
of
any
one
getting
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
think
so
,
eh
?
"
chuckled
Shotbolt
,
who
was
eagerly
perusing
the
reward
,
and
congratulating
himself
upon
his
caution
;
"
you
think
so
--
ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
<EOS>
Well
,
do
n't
go
to
bed
,
that
's
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
for
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
the
prisoner
's
arrival
might
disturb
you
--
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
lay
you
twenty
guineas
<EOS>
you
do
n't
take
him
to
-
night
,
"
rejoined
Austin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Done
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Shotbolt
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Spurling
,
you
're
a
witness
to
the
bet
.
<EOS>
Twenty
guineas
,
mind
.
<EOS>
I
sha
n't
let
you
off
a
farthing
.
<EOS>
Egad
!
<EOS>
I
shall
make
a
good
thing
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
count
your
chickens
till
they
're
hatched
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Spurling
,
drily
.
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
My
_
chickens
are
hatched
,
or
,
at
least
,
nearly
so
,
"
replied
Shotbolt
,
with
increased
merriment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Get
ready
your
heaviest
irons
,
Austin
.
<EOS>
I
'll
send
you
word
when
I
catch
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'd
better
send
_
him
_
,
"
jeered
the
turnkey
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
will
,
"
rejoined
Shotbolt
;
"
so
I
will
.
<EOS>
If
I
do
n't
,
you
shall
clap
me
in
the
Condemned
Hold
in
his
stead
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
for
the
pressent
--
<EOS>
ha
!
ha
!
"
<EOS>
And
,
laughing
loudly
at
his
own
facetiousness
,
he
quitted
the
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
lay
my
life
<EOS>
he
's
gone
on
a
fox
-
and
-
goose
-
chase
to
Mr.
Kneebone
's
,
"
remarked
Austin
,
rising
to
fasten
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
wonder
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Spurling
,
as
if
struck
by
a
sudden
idea
.
<EOS>
And
,
while
the
turnkey
was
busy
with

keys
,
she
whispered
to
the
black
,
"
Follow
him
,
Caliban
.
<EOS>
Take
care
<EOS>
he
do
n't
see
you,--and
bring
me
word
where
he
goes
,
and
what
he
does
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Iss
,
missis
,
"
grinned
the
black
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
so
good
as
to
let
Caliban
out
,
Mr.
Austin
,
"
continued
the
tapstress
;
"
he
's
only
going
on
an
errand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Austin
readily
complied
with
her
request
.
<EOS>
As
he
returned
to
the
table
,
he
put
his
finger
to
his
nose
;
and
,
though
he
said
nothing
,
he
thought
he
had
a
much
better
chance
of
winning
his
wager
.
 
<EOS>
Unconscious
that
his
movements
were
watched
,
Shotbolt
,
meanwhile
,
hastened
towards
Wych
Street
.
<EOS>
On
the
way
,
he
hired
a
chair
with
a
couple
of
stout
porters
,
and
ordered
them
to
follow
him
.
<EOS>
Arrived
within
a
short
distance
of
his
destination
,
he
came
to
a
halt
,
and
pointing
out
a
dark
court
nearly
opposite
the
woollen
-
draper
's
abode
,
told
the
chairmen
to
wait
there
till
they
were

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
peace
-
officer
,
"
he
added
,
"
about
to
arrest
a
notorious
criminal
.
<EOS>
He
'll
be
brought
out
at
this
door
,
and
may
probably
make
some
resistance
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
get
him
into
the
chair
as
fast
as
you
can
,
and
hurry
off
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
'll
we
get
for
the
job
,
yer
hon'r
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
foremost
chairman
,
who
,
like
most
of
his
tribe
at
the
time
,
was
an
Irishman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Five
guineas
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
couple
in
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Faix
,
then
we
'll
do
it
in
style
,
"
cried
the
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
Once
in
this
chair
,
yer
hon'r
,
and
I
'll
warrant
he
'll
not
get
out
<EOS>
so
aisily
as
Jack
Sheppard
did
from
the
New
Pris'n
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Hold
your

,

,
"

Shotbolt
,
not
over

by

,
"
and
mind
what
I
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
he

,
as
some

past

.
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
n't
just
left
him
,
I
could
have
sworn
it
was
Mrs.
Spurling
's
sooty
imp
,
Caliban
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
seen
the
chairmen
concealed
in

entry
,
Shotbolt
proceeded
to
Mr.
Kneebone
's
habitation
,
the
shutters
of
which
were
closed
,
and
knocked
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
summons
was
instantly
answered
by
a
shop
-
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
your
master
at
home
?
"
inquired
the
jailer
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
"
replied
a
portly

,
arrayed
in
a
gorgeous
yellow

,

,
and
having
a

,

,
on

.
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Kneebone
,
"
added
the
portly
personage
,
stepping
forward
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
with
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
word
in
private
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
aside
,
Tom
,
"
commanded
Kneebone
.
"
<EOS>
Now
Sir
,
"
he

,
glancing

at
the
applicant
"
your

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
business
is
to
acquaint
you
that
Jack
Sheppard
has
escaped
,
Mr.
Kneebone
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
deuce
he
has
!
<EOS>
Why
,
it
's
only
a
few
hours
since
I
beheld

chained
down
with

hundred
weight

,
in
the
strongest
ward

Newgate
.
<EOS>
It
's
almost

.
<EOS>
Are
you
sure

're

,
Sir
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
in
the
Lodge

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,

course
,
you
must
know
.
<EOS>
Well
,
it
's

.
<EOS>
When

to
supper
,
I
little

.
<EOS>
But
,

!
<EOS>
I

_
will
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
"

;
"
and

account
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
he

to

-

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Sir
,
"
said

when

,
"
I
shall

,

<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
If

keeps
_

_

,
I

_

_
.
<EOS>
You
must

's

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
you

,
Sir,--provided
you
do

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
'll

.
<EOS>
I
've

for
supposing
he
'll
pay

a
visit
.
<EOS>
I
refused

sign

in

to
the

;
not

,

--

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"

,
calling

shop

,
"
do

go
home
.
<EOS>
I
may

.
<EOS>
Light

.
<EOS>
And
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
in

,
Sir
,
"

Tom
,
in

,
and
with

was

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
Mr.
What's
-

-

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Shotbolt
,
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
Mr.
Slipshod
;
follow
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
led

to
an
inner

,
in
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
Sheppard
knows

,
I

,
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Every
inch

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
He
_
ought
_
to
do
,

served

in

to

Wood
,
by

formerly

.
<EOS>
His
name
is

.
"
 
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
said
Shotbolt
.
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Under

.
<EOS>
The
cloth
nearly

.
<EOS>
Give

.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
in

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose

.
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

,

;
"
there
's

.
<EOS>
Am

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not

.
<EOS>
Mind
<EOS>

do

's

.
<EOS>
I
'll
stamp

've

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
forgot
to
mention
there
's

,
"

Shotbolt
,

.
<EOS>
"
If
we
take

,
I
do

--
say

--
provided

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Curse
your
reward
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Kneebone
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
take

for

,

Jonathan
Wild
,

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No

,
Sir
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
did

for
a

that
you
'd

,
but
I

right

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
silent
,
and
conceal

.
<EOS>
I
'm
about
to
ring
for

.
"
 
<EOS>
The
woollen
-
draper
's
application
to
the
bell
was
answered
by
a
very
pretty
young
woman
,
with
dark
Jewish

,

,

,

,
and
a

:

,
in

,
of
a

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
Rachel
,
"
said
Mr.
Kneebone
,
addressing

comely

;
"
put
a
few
more
plates
on
the
table
,
and
bring
up
whatever
there
is
in
the
larder
.
<EOS>
I
expect
company
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Company
!
"
echoed
Rachel
;
"
at
this
time
of
night
?
<EOS>
"
 
"
Company
,
child
,
"
repeated
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
want
a
bottle
or
two
of
sack
,
and
a
flask
of
usquebaugh
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
else
,
Sir
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No:--stay
!
<EOS>
you
'd
better
not
bring

any

or

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
surely
you
do
n't
think
your
guests
would
steal
them
,
"
observed
Rachel
,
archly
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
sha
n't
have
the
opportunity
,
"
replied
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
And
,
by
way
of
checking
his
housekeeper
's

,
he
pointed

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Rachel
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
see
.
"
<EOS>
And
before
she
could

,
she
lifted
up
the
cloth
,
and
disclosed
Shotbolt
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Gemini
!
"
she

.
"
A
man
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
your
service
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
the
jailer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
your
curiosity
's
satisfied
,
child
,
"
continued

,
<EOS>
"
perhaps
,
you
'll
attend
to
my
orders
.
"
 
<EOS>
Not
a
little
perplexed
by
the

she
had
seen
,
Rachel
left
the
room
,
and
,
shortly

returned
with
the
materials
of
a
tolerably
good

wit
,
a

of
cold

,
a
tongue
,
the
best
part
of
a
sirloin
of

,

,
and
two

.
<EOS>
To
these
she
added
the
wine
and
spirits
directed
,
and
when
all
was
arranged
looked
inquisitively
at
her
master
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
expect
a
very
extraordinary
person
to
supper
,
Rachel
,
"
he
remarked
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
under
the
table
,
"
she
answered
.
<EOS>
"
He
_
does
_
seem
a
very
extraordinary
person
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
;
another
still
more
extraordinary
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed!--who
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
the
famous
housebreaker
.
<EOS>
I
thought
he
was
in
Newgate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
let
out
for
a
few
hours
,
"
laughed

;
"
but
he
's
going
back
again

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
!
<EOS>
how
I
should
like
to
see

.
<EOS>
I
'm
told
he
's
so
handsome
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
I
ca
n't
indulge
you
,
"
replied
her
master
,
a
little

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
want
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
go
to
bed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
use
going
to
bed
,
"
answered
Rachel
.
<EOS>
"
I
sha
n't
sleep
a
wink
while
Jack
Sheppard
's
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
in
your
own
room
,

all

,
"

Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
Rachel
,
with

her
pretty
head
,
"
very
well
.
<EOS>
I
'll
have
a
peep
at
him
,
if
I
die
for
it
,
"
she
muttered
,
as
she

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
,
then
,
sat
down
to
await
the
arrival
of
his
expected
guest
.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
passed
,
but
Jack
did
not
make
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
The
woollen
-
draper
looked
at
his
watch
.
<EOS>
It
was
eleven
o'clock
.
<EOS>
Another
long
interval
elapsed
.
<EOS>
The
watch
was
again
consulted
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
a
quarter
past
twelve
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kneebone
,
who
began
to
feel
sleepy
,
wound
it
up
,
and
snuffed
the
candles
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suspect
our
friend
has
thought
better
of
it
,
and
wo
n't
come
,
"
he
remarked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
a
little
patience
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
the
jailer
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
off
there
,
Shoplatch
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
Rather
cramped
,
eh
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
so
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
other
,
altering
his
position
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
able
to
stretch
my
limbs
presently
--
<EOS>
ha
!
ha
!
"
 
"
Hush
!
"
cried
Kneebone
,
"
I
hear
a
noise
without
.
<EOS>
He
's
coming
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
caution
was
scarcely
uttered
,
when
the
door
opened
,
and
Jack
Sheppard
presented
himself
.
<EOS>
He
was
wrapped
in
a
laced
roquelaure
,
which
he
threw
off
on
his
entrance
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
already
intimated
that
Jack
had
an
excessive
passion
for
finery
;
and
it
might
have
been
added
,
that
the
chief
part
of
his
ill
-
gotten
gains
was
devoted
to
the
embellishment
of
his
person
.
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
,
he
appeared
to
have
bestowed
more
than
ordinary
attention
on
his
toilette
.
<EOS>
His
apparel
was
sumptuous
in
the
extreme
,
and
such
as
was
only
worn
by
persons
of
the
highest
distinction
.
<EOS>
It
consisted
of
a
full
-
dress
coat
of
brown
flowered
velvet
,
laced
with
silver
;
a
waistcoat
of
white
satin
,
likewise
richly
embroidered
;
shoes
with
red
heels
,
and
large
diamond
buckles
;
pearl
-
coloured
silk
stockings
with
gold
clocks
;
a
muslin
cravat
,
or
steen
-
kirk
,
as
it
was
termed
,
edged
with
the
fine
point
lace
;
ruffles
of
the
same
material
,
and
so
ample
as
almost
to
hide
the
tips
of
his
fingers
;
and
a
silver
-
hilted
sword
.
<EOS>
This
costume
,
though
somewhat
extravagant
,
displayed
his
slight
,
but
perfectly
-
proportioned
figure
to
the
greatest
advantage
.
<EOS>
The
only
departure
which
he
made
from
the
fashion
of
the
period
,
was
in
respect
to
the
peruke
--
an
article
he
could
never
be
induced
to
wear
.
<EOS>
In
lieu
of
it
,
he
still
adhered
to
the
sleek
black
crop
,
which
,
throughout
life
,
formed
a
distinguishing
feature
in
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
Ever
since
the
discovery
of
his
relationship
to
the
Trenchard
family
,
a
marked
change
had
taken
place
in
Jack
's
demeanour
and
looks
,
which
were
so
much
refined
and
improved
that
he
could
scarcely
be
recognised
as
the
same
person
.
<EOS>
Having
only
seen
him
in
the
gloom
of
a
dungeon
,
and
loaded
with
fetters
,
Kneebone
had
not
noticed
this
alteration
:
but
he
was
now
greatly
struck
by
it
.
<EOS>
Advancing
towards
him
,
he
made
him
a
formal
salutation
,
which
was
coldly
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
expected
,
I
find
,
"
observed
Jack
,
glancing
at
the
well
-
covered
board
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
"
replied
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
heard
of
your
escape
,
I
felt
sure
I
should
see
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
judged
rightly
,
"
rejoined
Jack
;
"
I
never
yet
broke
an
engagement
with
friend
or
foe
--
and
never
will
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
bold
resolution
,
"
said
the
woollen
-
draper
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
made
some
exertion
to
keep
your
present
appointment
.
<EOS>
Few
men
could
have
done
as
much
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
replied
Jack
,
carelessly
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
have
done
more
,
if
necessary
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
take
a
chair
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
waited
supper
,
you
perceive
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
First
,
let
me
introduce
my
friends
,
"
returned
Jack
,
stepping
to
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Friends
!
<EOS>
"
echoed
Kneebone
,
with
a
look
of
dismay
.
<EOS>
"
My
invitation
did
not
extend
to
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
Further
remonstrance
,
however
,
was
cut
short
by
the
sudden
entrance
of
Mrs.
Maggot
and
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
Behind
them
stalked
Blueskin
,
enveloped
in
a
rough
great
-
coat
,
called
--
appropriately
enough
in
this
instance,--a
wrap
-
rascal
.
<EOS>
Folding
his
arms
,
he
placed
his
back
against
the
door
,
and
burst
into
a
loud
laugh
.
<EOS>
The
ladies
were
,
as
usual
,
very
gaily
dressed
;
and
as
usual
,
also
,
had
resorted
to
art
to
heighten
their
attractions--
     
From
patches
,
justly
placed
<EOS>
,
they
borrow'd
graces
,
    
<EOS>
And
with
vermilion
lacquer'd
<EOS>
o'er
their
faces
.
 
<EOS>
Edgeworth
Bess
wore
a
scarlet
tabby
<EOS>
negligée,--a
sort
of
undress
,
or
sack
,
then
much
in
vogue,--which
suited
her
to
admiration
,
and
upon
her
head
had
what
was
called
a
fly
-
cap
,
with
richly
-
laced
lappets
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Maggot
was
equipped
in
a
light
blue
riding
-
habit
,
trimmed
with
silver
,
a
hunting
-
cap
and
a
flaxen
peruke
,
and
,
instead
of
a
whip
,
carried
a
stout
cudgel
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
moment
,
Kneebone
had
hesitated
about
giving
the
signal
to
Shotbolt
,
but
,
thinking
a
more
favourable
opportunity
might
occur
,
he
determined
not
to
hazard
matters
by
undue
precipitation
.
<EOS>
Placing
chairs
,
therefore
,
he
invited
the
ladies
to
be
seated
,
and
,
paying
a
similar
attention
to
Jack
,
began
to
help
to
the
various
dishes
,
and
otherwise
fulfil
the
duties
of
a
host
.
<EOS>
While
this
was
going
on
,
Blueskin
,
seeing
no
notice
whatever
taken
of
him
,
coughed
loudly
and
repeatedly
.
<EOS>
But
finding
his
hints
totally
disregarded
,
he
,
at
length
,
swaggered
up
to
the
table
,
and
thrust
in
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
"
he
said
,
plunging
his
fork
into
a
fowl
,
and
transferring
it
to
his
plate
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
tongue
looks
remarkably
nice
,
"
he
added
,
slicing
off
an
immense
wedge
,
"
excuse
me
--
ho
!
<EOS>
ho
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
make
yourself
at
home
,
I
perceive
,
"
observed
Kneebone
,
with
a
look
of
ineffable
disgust
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
generally
do
,
"
replied
Blueskin
,
pouring
out
a
bumper
of
sack
.
"
<EOS>
Your
health
,
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
to
offer
you
a
glass
of
usquebaugh
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Kneebone
,
turning
from
him
,
and
regarding
Edgeworth
Bess
with
a
stare
<EOS>
so
impertinent
,
that
even
that
not
over
-
delicate
young
lady
summoned
up
a
blush
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
pleasure
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
as
she
pledged
the
amorous
woollen
-
draper
,
"
what
a
beautiful
ring
that
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
so
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Kneebone
,
taking
it
off
,
and
placing
it
on
her
finger
,
which
he
took
the
opportunity
of
kissing
at
the
same

;
"
wear
it
for
my
sake
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
!
<EOS>
"
simpered
Edgeworth
Bess
,
endeavouring
to
hide
her
confusion
by
looking
steadfastly
at
her
plate
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
eat
,
"
continued
Kneebone
,
addressing
Jack
,
who
had
remained
for
some
time
thoughtful
,
and
pre
-
occupied
with
his
head
upon
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Captain
has
seldom
much
appetite
,
"
replied
Blueskin
,
who
,
having
disposed
of
the
fowl
,
was
commencing
a
vigorous
attack
upon
the
sirloin
.
<EOS>
"
I
eat
for
both
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
So
it
seems
,
"
observed
the
woollen
-
draper
,
"
and
for
every
one
else
,
too
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Kneebone
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
,
as
he
washed
down
an
immense
mouthful
with
another
bumper
,
"
do
you
recollect
<EOS>
how
nearly
Mr.
Wild
and
I
were
nabbing
you
in
this
very
room
,
some
nine
years
ago
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Kneebone
;
"
and
now
,
"
he
added
,
aside
,
"
the
case
is
altered
.
<EOS>
I
'm
nearly
nabbing
_
<EOS>
you
_
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
good
deal
has
occurred
since
then
,
eh
,
Captain
!
"
said
Blueskin
,
nudging
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
that
I
would
willingly
forget
.
<EOS>
Nothing
that
I
desire
to
remember
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
that
night,--in
this
<EOS>
room,--in
<EOS>
your
presence
,
Blueskin,--in
yours
Mr.
Kneebone
,
Mrs.
Wood
struck
me
a
blow
which
made
me
a
robber
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
paid
dearly
for
it
,
"
muttered
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
wish
her
hand
had
been
as
deadly
as
yours
.
<EOS>
On
that
night,--that
fatal
night,--Winifred
crushed
all
the
hopes
that
were
rising
in
my
heart
.
<EOS>
On
that
night
,
I
surrendered
myself
to
Jonathan
Wild
,
and
became
--
what
I
am
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
that
night
,
you
first
met
me
,
love
,
"
said
Edgeworth
Bess
,
endeavouring
to
take
his
hand
,
which
he
coldly
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
me
,
"
added
Mrs.
Maggot
tenderly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Would
I
had
never
seen
either
of
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
rising
and
pacing
the
apartment
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm
sure
Winifred
could
never
have
loved
you
as
well
as
I
do
,
"
said
Mrs.
Maggot
.
 
<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
You
_
!
"
cried
Jack
,
scornfully
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
compare
_
your
_
love
--
a
love
which
all
may
purchase
--
with
_
hers
_
?
<EOS>
No
one
has
ever
loved
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Except
me
,
dear
,
"
insinuated
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
always
true
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Jack
,
with
increased
bitterness
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
your
dupe
no
longer
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
's
in
the
wind
now
,
Captain
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Blueskin
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
replied
Jack
,
with
forced
calmness
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Within
the
last
few
minutes
,
all
my
guilty
life
has
passed
before
me
.
<EOS>
Nine
years
ago
,
I
was
honest
--
was
happy
.
<EOS>
Nine
years
ago
,
I
worked
in
this
very
house
--
had
a
kind
indulgent
master
,
whom
I
robbed
--
twice
robbed
,
at
your
instigation
,
villain
;
a
mistress
,
whom
you
have
murdered
;
a
companion
,
whose
friendship
I
have
for
ever
forfeited
;
a
mother
,
whose
heart
I
have
well
-
nigh
broken
.
<EOS>
In
this
room
was
my
ruin
begun
:
in
this
room
it
should
be
ended
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
do
n't
take
on
thus
,
Captain
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
rising
and
walking
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
If
any
one
's
to
blame
,
it
's
me
.
<EOS>
I
'm
ready
to
bear
it
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
make
me
honest
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Can

make
me
other
than

?
<EOS>
Can
you
make
me
not
Jack
Sheppard
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Blueskin
;
"
and
I
would
n't
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Curse
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
furiously,--"curse
<EOS>
you!--curse
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Swear
away
,
Captain
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
,
coolly
.
<EOS>
"
It
'll
ease
your
mind
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mock
me
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
levelling
a

at

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
I
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
Take
my
life
,
if
you
're
so
disposed
.
<EOS>
You
're
welcome
to
it
.
<EOS>
And
let
's
see
if
either
of
these
women
,
who
prate
of
their
love
for
you
,
will
do
as
much
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
folly
,
"
cried
Jack
,
controlling
himself
by
a
powerful

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
worst
of
folly
,
"
replied
Blueskin
,

,
and
taking

;
"
and
,
to
put
an
end

,
I
shall
drink
the
health
of
Jack
Sheppard
,
the
housebreaker
,
and
success
to

in
all
his

.
<EOS>
And
now
,
let
's

who
'll
refuse

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
I
_
will
<EOS>
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
dashing

glass
from
his

.
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
fool
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
said
Kneebone
,
who
had
been

interested
by

,
"
are
these

for
your
past

sincere
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose

so
,
"
rejoined
Jack
,
"
<EOS>
what
then
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
--
nothing
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad

,

's

,
"
he

,
taking

his

box
,

-

in

.
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
do
to
betray
the
officer
,
"
he
