.
 
<EOS>
"
O
lud
!
<EOS>
what
an
exquisite
box
!
"
cried
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
gold
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pure
gold
,
"
replied
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
given
me
by
poor
dear
Mrs.
Wood
,
whose
loss
I
shall
ever
deplore
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
let
me
have
a
pinch
!
"
said
Edgeworth
Bess
,
with
a
captivating
glance
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
excessively
fond
of
snuff
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
woollen
-
draper
replied
by
gallantly
handing
her
the
box
,
which
was
instantly
snatched
from
her
by
Blueskin
,
who
,
after
helping
himself
to
as
much
of
its
contents
as
he
could
conveniently
squeeze
between
his
thumb
and
finger
,
put
it
very
coolly
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
The
action
did
not
pass
unnoticed
by
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Restore
it
,
"
he
cried
,
in
an
authoritative
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
O'ons
!
<EOS>
Captain
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
as
he
grumblingly
obeyed
the
command
;
"
if
you
've
left
off
business
yourself
,
you
need
n't
interfere
with
other
people
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
a
little
of
that
plum
-
tart
,
"
said
Mrs.
Maggot
;
"
but
I
do
n't
see
a
spoon
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
ring
for
one
,
"
replied
Kneebone
,
rising
accordingly
;
"
but
I
fear
my
servants
are
gone
to
bed
.
"
 
<EOS>
Blueskin
,
meanwhile
,
having
drained
and
replenished
his
glass
,
commenced
chaunting
a
snatch
of
a
ballad:--
     
Once
on
a
time
,
as
I
've
heard
tell
.
    
<EOS>
In
Wych
Street
Owen
Wood
did
dwell
;
    
<EOS>
A
carpenter
he
was
by
trade
,
    
And
money
,
I
believe
,
he
made
.
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
With
his
foodle
doo
_
!
     
<EOS>
This
carpenter
he
had
a
wife
,
    
The
plague
and
torment
of
his
life
,
    
<EOS>
Who
,
though
she
did
her
husband
scold
,
    
Loved
well
a
woollen
-
draper
bold
.
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
With
her
foodle
doo
_
!
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
a
toast
to
propose
,
"
cried
Sheppard
,
filling
a
bumper
.
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
refuse
it
,
Mr.
Kneebone
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
'd
better
not
,
"
muttered
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
the
woollen
-
draper
,
as
he
returned
to
the
table
,
and
took
up
a
glass
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
speedy
union
of
Thames
Darrell
with
Winifred
Wood
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
Kneebone
's
cheeks
glowed
with
rage
,
and
he
set
down
the
wine
untasted
,
while
Blueskin
resumed
his
song
.
     
<EOS>
Now
Owen
Wood
had
one
fair
child
,
    
<EOS>
Unlike
her
mother
,
meek
and
mild
;
    
Her
love
the
draper
strove
to
gain
,
    
<EOS>
But
she
repaid
him
with
disdain
.
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
With
his
foodle
doo
_
!
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
!
"
cried
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
But
Blueskin
was
not
to
be
silenced
.
<EOS>
He
continued
his
ditty
,
in
spite
of
the
angry
glances
of
his
leader
.
     
<EOS>
In
vain
he
fondly
urged
his
suit
,
    
<EOS>
And
,
all
in
vain
,
the
question
put
;
    
She
<EOS>
answered,--"Mr
.
<EOS>
William
Kneebone
,
    
Of
me
,
Sir
,
you
shall
never
be
bone
.
"
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
With
your
foodle
doo
_
!
     
<EOS>
"
Thames
Darrell
has
my
heart
alone
,
    
A
noble
youth
,
e'en
<EOS>
_
you
_
must
own
;
    
<EOS>
And
,
if
from
him
my
love
could
stir
,
    
Jack
Sheppard
I
should
much
prefer
!
"
        
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
With
his
foodle
doo
_
!
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
refuse
my
toast
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
replied
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Drink
this
,
then
,
"
roared
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
And
pouring
the
contents
of
a
small
powder
-
flask
into
a
bumper
of
brandy
,
he
tendered
him
the
mixture
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
door
was
opened
by
Rachel
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
ring
for
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
,
eyeing
the
group
with
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
master
wants
a
few
table
-
spoons
,
child
,
"
said
Mrs.
Maggot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
the
room
,
"
interposed
Kneebone
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
sha
n't
,
"
replied
Rachel
,
saucily
.
<EOS>
"
I
came
to
see
Jack
Sheppard
,
and
I
wo
n't
go
till
you
point
him
out
to
me
.
<EOS>
You
told
me
he
was
going
back
to
Newgate
after
supper
,
so
I
may
n't
have
another
opportunity
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
he
told
you
that
,
did
he
?
"
<EOS>
said
Blueskin
,
marching
up
to
her
,
and
chucking
her
under
the
chin
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
show
you
Captain
Sheppard
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
There
he
stands
.
<EOS>
I
'm
his
lieutenant,--Lieutenant
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
We
're
two
good
-
looking
fellows
,
ai
n't
we
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
good
-
looking
,
"
replied
Rachel
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
where
's
the
strange
gentleman
I
saw
under
the
table
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Under
the
table
!
"
echoed
Blueskin
,
winking
at
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
When
did
you
see
him
,
my
love
?
"
 
"
A
short
time
ago
,
"
replied
the
housekeeper
,
unsuspiciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
plot
's
out
!
"
cried
Jack
.
<EOS>
And
,
without
another
word
,
he
seized
the
table
with
both
hands
,
and
upset
it
;
scattering
plates
,
dishes
,
bottles
,
jugs
,
and
glasses
far
and
wide
.
<EOS>
The
crash
was
tremendous
.
<EOS>
The
lights
rolled
over
,
and
were
extinguished
.
<EOS>
And
,
if
Rachel
had
not
carried
a
candle
,
the
room
would
have
been
plunged
in
total
darkness
.
<EOS>
Amid
the
confusion
,
Shotbolt
sprang
to
his
feet
,
and
levelling
a
pistol
at
Jack
's
head
,
commanded
him
to
surrender
;
but
,
before
any
reply
could
be
made
,
the
jailer
's
arm
was
struck
up
by
Blueskin
,
who
,
throwing
himself
upon
him
,
dragged
him
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
In
the
struggle
the
pistol
went
off
,
but
without
damage
to
either
party
.
<EOS>
The
conflict
was
of
short
duration
;
for
Shotbolt
was
no
match
for
his
athletic
antagonist
.
<EOS>
He
was
speedily
disarmed
;
and
the
rope
and
gag
being
found
upon
him
,
were
exultingly
turned
against
him
by
his
conqueror
,
who
,
after
pinioning
his
arms
tightly
behind
his
back
,
forced
open
his
mouth
with
the
iron
,
and
effectually
prevented
the
utterance
of
any
further
outcries
.
<EOS>
While
the
strife
was
raging
,
Edgeworth
Bess
walked
up
to
Rachel
,
and
advised
her
,
if
she
valued
her
life
,
not
to
scream
or
stir
from
the
spot
;
a
caution
which
the
housekeeper
,
whose
curiosity
far
outweighed
her
fears
,
received
in
very
good
part
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
interim
,
Jack
advanced
to
the
woollen
-
draper
,
and
regarding
him
sternly
,
thus
addressed
him
:
 
"
You
have
violated
the
laws
of
hospitality
,
Mr.
Kneebone
,
I
came
hither
as
your
guest
.
<EOS>
You
have
betrayed
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
faith
is
to
be
kept
with
a
felon
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
woollen
-
draper
,
disdainfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
who
breaks
faith
with
his
benefactor
may
well
justify
himself
thus
,
"
answered
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
trusted
you
.
<EOS>
Others
who
have
done
,
have
found
you
false
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
"
replied
Kneebone
,
in
some
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
soon
shall
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
the
packets
committed
to
your
charge
by
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
packets
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Kneebone
,
in
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
to
deny
it
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
watched
to
-
night
by
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
You
met
Sir
Rowland
at
the
house
of
a
Romisch
priest
,
Father
Spencer
.
<EOS>
Two
packets
were
committed
to
your
charge
,
which
you
undertook
to
deliver,--one
to
another
priest
,
Sir
Rowland
's
chaplain
,
at
Manchester
,
the
other
to
Mr.
Wood
.
<EOS>
Produce
them
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
replied
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
by
Heaven
!
<EOS>
you
are
a
dead
man
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Jack
,
cocking
a
pistol
,
and
pointing
it
deliberately
at
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
give
you
one
minute
for
reflection
.
<EOS>
After
that
time
nothing
shall
save
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
brief
,
breathless
pause
.
<EOS>
Even
Blueskin
looked
on
with
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
past
,
"
said
Jack
,
placing
his
finger
on
the
trigger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Kneebone
,
flinging
down
the
packets
<EOS>
;
"
they
are
nothing
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
they
are
everything
to
me
,
"
cried
Jack
,
stooping
to
pick
them
up
.
<EOS>
"
These
packets
will
establish
Thames
Darrell
's
birth
,
win
him
his
inheritance
,
and
procure
him
the
hand
of
Winifred
Wood
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
too
sure
of
that
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
,
snatching
up
the
staff
,
and
aiming
a
blow
at
his
head
,
which
was
fortunately
warded
off
by
Mrs.
Maggot
,
who
promptly
interposed
her
cudgel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Defend
yourself
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
drawing
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
his
punishment
to
me
,
Jack
,
"
said
Mrs.
Maggot
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
the
Bridewell
account
to
settle
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
,
"
replied
Jack
,
putting
up
his
blade
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
a
good
deal
to
do
.
<EOS>
Show
him
no
quarter
,
Poll
.
<EOS>
He
deserves
none
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
shall
find
none
,
"
replied
the
Amazon
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr.
Kneebone
,
"
she
added
,
drawing
up
her
magnificent
figure
to
its
full
height
,
and
making
the
heavy
cudgel
whistle
through
the
air
,
"
look
to
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
off
,
Poll
,
"
rejoined
the
woollen
-
draper
;
"
I
do
n't
want
to
hurt
you
.
<EOS>
It
shall
never
be
said
that
I
raised
my
arm
willingly
against
a
woman
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
forgive
you
all
the
harm
you
do
me
,
"
rejoined
the
Amazon
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
you
still
hesitate
!
<EOS>
Will
that
rouse
you
,
coward
?
"
<EOS>
And
she
gave
him
a
smart
rap
on
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Coward
!
"
cried
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Neither
man
nor
woman
shall
apply
that
term
to
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
forget
your
sex
,
jade
,
I
must
forget
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
attacked
her
vigorously
in
his
turn
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
curious
sight
to
see
how
this
extraordinary
woman
,
who
,
it
has
been
said
,
was
not
less
remarkable
for
the
extreme
delicacy
of
her
features
,
and
the
faultless
symmetry
of
her
figure
,
than
for
her
wonderful
strength
and
agility
,
conducted
herself
in
the
present
encounter
;
with
what
dexterity
she
parried
every
blow
aimed
against
her
by
her
adversary
,
whose
head
and
face
,
already
marked
by
various
ruddy
streams
<EOS>
,
showed
how
successfully
her
own
hits
had
been
made;--how
<EOS>
she
drew
him
hither
and
thither
,
now
leading
him
on
,
now
driving
him
suddenly
back
;
harassing
and
exhausting
him
in
every
possible
way
,
and
making
it
apparent
that
she
could
at
any
moment
put
an
end
to
the
fight
,
and
only
delayed
the
finishing
stroke
to
make
his
punishment
the
more
severe
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
,
meanwhile
,
with
Blueskin
's
assistance
,
had
set
the
table
once
more
upon
its
legs
,
and
placing
writing
materials
,
which
he
took
from
a
shelf
,
upon
it
,
made
Shotbolt
,
who
was
still
gagged
,
but
whose
arms
were
for
the
moment
unbound
,
sit
down
before
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Write
as
I
dictate
,
"
he
cried
,
placing
a
pen
in
the
jailer
's
hand
and
a
pistol
to
his
ear
.
 
<EOS>
Shotbolt
nodded
in
token
of
acquiescence
,
and
emitted
an
odd
guttural
sound
.
 
<EOS>
"
Write
as
follows
,
"
continued
Jack
.
"
<EOS>
'
I
have
succeeded
in
capturing
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
The
reward
is
mine
.
<EOS>
Get
all
ready
for
his
reception
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
after
the
delivery
of
this
note
he
will
be
in
Newgate
.
'
<EOS>
Sign
it
,
"
he
added
,
as
,
after
some
further
threats
,
the
letter
was
indited
according
to
his
dictation
,
"
and
direct
it
to
Mr.
Austin
.
<EOS>
That
's
well
.
<EOS>
And
,
now
,
to
find
a
messenger
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Kneebone
's
man
is
in
the
shop
,
"
said
Rachel
;
"
he
'll
take
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
trust
him
?
"
<EOS>
mused
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
he
'll
suspect
nothing
.
<EOS>
Give
him
this
letter
,
child
,
and
bid
him
take
it
to
the
Lodge
at
Newgate
without
loss
of
time
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
will
go
with
you,--for
fear
of
a
mistake
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
might
trust
me
,
"
said
Rachel
,
in
an
offended
tone
;
"
but
never
mind
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
left
the
room
with
Blueskin
,
who
very
politely
offered
her
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
combat
between
Kneebone
and
Mrs.
Maggot
had
been
brought
to
a
termination
.
<EOS>
When
the
woollen
-
draper
was
nearly
worn
out
,
the
Amazon
watched
her
opportunity
,
and
hitting
him
on
the
arm
,
disabled
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
Mrs.
Wood
,
"
she
cried
,
as
the
staff
fell
from
his
grasp
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
at
your
mercy
,
Poll
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
,
abjectly
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
Winifred
,
"
vociferated
the
Amazon
,
bringing
the
cudgel
heavily
upon
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
"
Damnation
!
"
cried
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
for
myself
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Maggot
,
dealing
him
a
blow
,
which
stretched
him
senseless
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bravo
,
Poll
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
who
having
again
pinioned
Shotbolt
,
was
now
tracing
a
few
hasty
lines
on
a
sheet
of
paper
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
given
him
a
broken
head
,
I
perceive
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
scarcely
need
a
plaister
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Maggot
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Bess
,
give
me
the
cord
,
and
I
'll
tie
him
to
this
chest
of
drawers
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
he
'll
come
to
himself
too
soon
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
best
to
be
on
the
safe
side
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Decidedly
so
,
"
replied
Edgeworth
Bess
;
"
and
I
'll
take
this
opportunity
,
while
Jack
's
back
is
turned,--for
he
's
grown
so
strangely
<EOS>
particular,--of
easing
him
of
his
snuff
-
box
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
"
she
added
,
in
a
whisper
,
as
she
appropriated
the
before
-
named
article
,
"
he
has
a
pocket
-
book
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
replied
Mrs.
Maggot
;
"
Jack
will
hear
you
.
<EOS>
We
'll
come
back
for
that
by
and
by
,
and
the
dressing
-
gown
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Rachel
and
Blueskin
returned
.
<EOS>
Their
momentary
absence
seemed
to
have
worked
wonders
;
for
now
the
most
perfect
understanding
appeared
to
subsist
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
sent
off
the
note
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
,
Captain
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
say
_
we
_
,
because
Miss
Rachel
and
I
have
struck
up
a
match
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
bring
off
anything
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
looking
eagerly
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Jack
,
peremptorily
.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
sealed
his
letter
,
Sheppard
took
a
handkerchief
,
and
tying
it
over
Shotbolt
's
face
,
so
as
completely
to
conceal
the
features
,
clapped
his
hat
upon
his
head
,
and
pushed
it
over
his
brows
.
<EOS>
He
,
next
,
seized
the
unlucky
jailer
,
and
forced
him
along
,
while
Blueskin
expedited
his
movements
by
administering
a
few
kicks
behind
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
got
to
the
door
,
Jack
opened
it
,
and
,
mimicking
the
voice
of
the
jailer
,
shouted
,
"
Now
,
my
lads
,
all
's
ready
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
we
are
,
"
cried
the
chairmen
,
hurrying
out
of
the
court
with
their
swinging
vehicle
,
"
where
is
he
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
dragging
out
Shotbolt
by
the
collar
,
while
Blueskin
pushed
him
behind
,
and
Mrs.
Maggot
held
up
a
lantern
,
which
she
found
in
the
shop
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
with
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
--
ay
,
yer
hon'r
,
"
cried
the
foremost
chairman
,
lending
a
helping
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Get
in
wid
ye
,
ye
villin
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
despite
his
resistance
,
Shotbolt
was
thrust
into
the
chair
,
which
was
instantly
fastened
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
,
he
's
as
safe
as
Jack
Sheppard
in
the
Condemned
Hould
,
"
laughed
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Off
with
you
to
Newgate
!
"
cried
Jack
,
"
and
do
n't
let
him
out
till
you
get
inside
the
Lodge
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
letter
for
the
head
turnkey
,
Mr.
Irreton
.
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yer
hon'r
,
"
replied
the
chairman
,
taking
the
note
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
waiting
for
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Jack
,
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gen'l'man
as
hired
us
,
"
replied
the
chairman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
he
'll
be
after
you
directly
.
<EOS>
He
's
settling
an
account
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Lose
no
time
.
<EOS>
The
letter
will
explain
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
chair
was
then
rapidly
put
in
motion
,
and
speedily
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
to
be
done
next
?
"
cried
Blueskin
,
returning
to
Rachel
,
who
was
standing
with
Edgeworth
Bess
near
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
back
and
finish
my
supper
,
"
said
Mrs.
Maggot
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
shall
I
,
"
replied
Edgeworth
Bess
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
minute
,
"
cried
Jack
,
detaining
his
mistresses
.
"
<EOS>
Here
we
part,--perhaps
for
ever
.
<EOS>
I
've
already
told
you
I
'm
about
to
take
a
long
journey
,
and
it
's
more
than
probable
<EOS>
I
shall
never
return
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Do
n't
say
so
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Maggot
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
perfectly
miserable
if
_
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
_
thought
you
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
idea
is
dreadful
,
"
whimpered
Edgeworth
Bess
.
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
embracing
them
.
<EOS>
"
Take
this
key
to
Baptist
Kettleby
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
it
,
he
'll
deliver
you
a
box
,
which
it
will
unlock
,
and
in
which
you
'll
find
a
matter
of
fifty
guineas
and
a
few
trinkets
.
<EOS>
Divide
the
money
between
you
,
and
wear
the
ornaments
for
my
sake
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
've
a
spark
of
love
for
me
,
do
n't
meddle
with
anything
in
that
house
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
for
worlds
!
"
exclaimed
both
ladies
together
.
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
breaking
from
them
,
and
rushing
down
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
shall
we
do
,
Poll
?
"
hesitated
Edgeworth
Bess
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
in
,
to
be
sure
,
simpleton
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Maggot
,
"
and
bring
off
all
we
can
.
<EOS>
I
know
where
everything
valuable
is
kept
.
<EOS>
Since
Jack
has
left
us
,
what
does
it
matter
whether
he
's
pleased
or
not
?
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
a
whistle
was
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Coming
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Blueskin
,
who
was
still
lingering
with
Rachel
.
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
in
such
a
desperate
hurry
,
that
there
's
no
time
for
love
-
making
.
<EOS>
Adieu
!
<EOS>
my
charmer
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
those
young
ladies
extremely
agreeable
acquaintances
.
<EOS>
Adieu
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
snatching
a
hasty
kiss
,
he
darted
after
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
The
chair
,
meanwhile
,
with
its
unhappy
load
,
was
transported
at
a
brisk
pace
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
Arrived
there
,
the
porter
thundered
at
the
massive
door
of
the
Lodge
,
which
was
instantly
opened
--
Shotbolt
's
note
having
been
received
just
before
.
<EOS>
All
the
turnkeys
were
assembled
.
<EOS>
Ireton
and
Langley
had
returned
from
a
second
unsuccessful
search
;
Marvel
had
come
thither
to
bid
good
-
night
to
Mrs.
Spurling
;
Austin
had
never
quitted
his
post
.
<EOS>
The
tapstress
was
full
of
curiosity
;
but
she
appeared
more
easy
than
the
others
.
<EOS>
Behind
her
stood
Caliban
,
chuckling
to
himself
,
and
grinning
from
ear
to
ear
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
who
'd
have
thought
of
Shotbolt
beating
us
all
in
this
way
!
"
said
Ireton
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
for
old
Newgate
that
another
jail
should
have
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
infernally
provoking
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Infernally
provoking
!
"
echoed
Langley
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nobody
has
so
much
cause
for
complaint
as
me
,
"
growled
Austin
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
lost
my
wager
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Twenty
pounds
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Spurling
.
<EOS>
"
I
witnessed
the
bet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ireton
,
as
the
knocking
was
heard
without
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Get
ready
the
irons
,
Caliban
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
bit
,
massa
,
"
replied
the
grinning
negro,--"lilly
bit
--
see
all
right
fust
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
chair
had
been
brought
into
the
Lodge
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
got
him
?
"
demanded
Ireton
.
 
<EOS>
"
Safe
inside
,
"
replied
the
chairman
,
wiping
the
heat
from
his
brow
;
"
we
've
run
all
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
Mr.
Shotbolt
?
"
asked
Austin
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gen'l'man'll
be
here
directly
.
<EOS>
He
was
detained
.
<EOS>
T
'
other
gen'l'man
said
the
letter
'
ud
explain
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Detained
!
"
echoed
Marvel
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
odd
.
<EOS>
But
,
let
's
see
the
prisoner
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
chair
was
then
opened
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shotbolt
!
by--
"
cried
Austin
,
as
the
captive
was
dragged
forth
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
won
,
after
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
Exclamations
of
wonder
burst
from
all
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Spurling
bit
her
lips
to
conceal
her
mirth
.
<EOS>
Caliban
absolutely
crowed
with
delight
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
the
letter
,
"
said
Ireton
,
breaking
the
seal
.
"
<EOS>
'
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
This
is
the
way
in
which
I
will
serve
all
who
attempt
to
apprehend
me
_
.
'
<EOS>
It
is
signed
JACK
SHEPPARD
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
so
Jack
Sheppard
has
sent
back
Shotbolt
in
this
pickle
,
"
said
Langley
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
it
appears
,
"
replied
Marvel
.
<EOS>
"
Untie
his
arms
,
and
take
off
that
handkerchief
.
<EOS>
The
poor
fellow
's
half
smothered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
guess
what
share
you
've
had
in
this
,
"
whispered
Austin
to
Mrs.
Spurling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
"
replied
the
tapstress
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
won
your
wager
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
after
this
occurrence
,
when
it
had
been
sufficiently
laughed
at
and
discussed
;
when
the
wager
had
been
settled
,
and
the
chairman
dismissed
with
the
remaining
three
guineas
,
which
Shotbolt
was
compelled
to
pay
;
Ireton
arose
,
and
signified
his
intention
of
stepping
across
the
street
to
inform
Mr.
Wild
of
the
circumstance
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
it
's
getting
late
,
and
the
porter
may
be
gone
to
bed
,
"
he
observed
;
"
I
'll
take
the
pass
-
key
,
and
let
myself
in
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wild
is
sure
to
be
up
.
<EOS>
He
never
retires
to
rest
till
daybreak
--
if
at
all
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
,
Langley
,
and
bring
the
lantern
.
"
    
CHAPTER
XIV
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
was
again
captured
.
  
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
,
after
whistling
to
Blueskin
,
hurried
down
a
short
thoroughfare
leading
from
Wych
Street
to
the
back
of
Saint
Clement
's
Church
,
where
he
found
Thames
Darrell
,
who
advanced
to
meet
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
just
going
,
"
said
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
parted
from
you
at
Mr.
Kneebone
's
door
,
you
begged
me
to
await
your
return
here
,
assuring
me
you
would
not
detain
me
five
minutes
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
which
,
more
than
half
an
hour
has
elapsed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
complain
of
the
delay
when
I
tell
you
what
I
've
done
,
"
answered
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
obtained
two
packets
,
containing
letters
from
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
,
which
I
've
no
doubt
will
establish
your
title
to
the
estates
.
<EOS>
Take
them
,
and
may
they
prove
as
serviceable
to
you
as
I
desire
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
replied
Thames
,
greatly
moved
,
"
I
wish
I
could
devise
any
means
of
brightening
your
own
dark
prospects
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
impossible
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
utterly
lost
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
utterly
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Utterly
,
"
reiterated
Jack
,
gloomily,--"as
regards
all
I
hold
dear
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
Thames
.
<EOS>
I
'm
about
to
leave
this
country
for
ever
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
that
a
vessel
sails
for
France
from
the
river
at
daybreak
to
-
morrow
morning
,
I
have
secured
a
passage
in
her
,
and
have
already
had
the
few
effects
I
possess
,
conveyed
on
board
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
goes
with
me
.
<EOS>
The
faithful
fellow
will
never
leave
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
while
I
've
breath
in
my
body
,
Captain
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
,
who
had
joined
them
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
England
or
France
,
London
or
Paris
,
it
's
all
one
to
me
,
so
I
've
you
to
command
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
out
of
earshot
,
"
rejoined
his
leader
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
call
you
when
you
're
wanted
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Blueskin
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
but
approve
the
course
you
are
about
to
take
,
Jack
,
"
said
Thames
,
"
though
on
some
accounts
I
regret
it
.
<EOS>
In
after
years
you
can
return
to
your
own
country
--
to
your
friends
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
replied
Sheppard
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
My
friends
need
not
fear
my
return
.
<EOS>
They
shall
hear
of
me
no
more
.
<EOS>
Under
another
name,--not
my
own
hateful
one,--I
will
strive
to
distinguish
myself
in
some
foreign
service
,
and
win
myself
a
reputation
,
or
perish
honourably
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
never
--
never
return
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
attempt
to
combat
your
resolution
,
Jack
,
"
returned
Thames
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
dread
the
effect
your
departure
may
have
upon
your
poor
mother
.
<EOS>
Her
life
hangs
upon
a
thread
,
and
this
may
snap
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had
n't
mentioned
her
,
"
said
Jack
,
in
a
broken
voice
,
while
his
whole
frame
shook
with
emotion
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
do
is
for
the
best
,
and
I
can
only
hope
she
may
have
strength
to
bear
the
separation
.
<EOS>
You
must
say
farewell
to
her
,
for
I
can
not
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
you
to
supply
my
place
--
for
that
is
,
perhaps
,
impossible
.
<EOS>
But
,
be
like
a
son
to
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
doubt
me
,
"
replied
Thames
,
warmly
pressing
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
I
've
one
further
request
,
"
faltered
Jack
;
"
though
I
scarcely
know
how
to
make
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
set
me
right
with
Winifred
.
<EOS>
Do
not
let
her
think
worse
of
me
than
I
deserve,--or
even
so
ill
.
<EOS>
Tell
her
,
that
more
than
once
,
when
about
to
commit
some
desperate
offence
,
I
have
been
restrained
by
her
gentle
image
.
<EOS>
If
hopeless
love
for
her
made
me
a
robber
,
it
has
also
saved
me
many
a
crime
.
<EOS>
Will
you
tell
her
that
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
replied
Thames
,
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
said
Jack
,
recovering
his
composure
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
to
your
own
concerns
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
,
who
has
been
on
the
watch
all
night
,
has
dogged
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
to
Jonathan
Wild
's
house
;
and
,
from
the
mysterious
manner
in
which
he
was
admitted
by
the
thief
-
taker
's
confidential
servant
,
Abraham
Mendez
,
and
not
by
the
regular
porter
,
there
is
little
doubt
but
they
are
alone
,
and
probably
making
some
arrangements
prior
to
our
uncle
's
departure
from
England
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
leaving
England
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Thames
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
sails
to
-
morrow
morning
in
the
very
vessel
by
which
I
start
,
"
replied
Jack
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
if
as
I
suspect,--from
the
documents
just
placed
in
your
possession,--Sir
<EOS>
Rowland
meditates
doing
you
justice
after
his
departure
<EOS>
,
it
is
possible
his
intentions
may
be
frustrated
by
the
machinations
of
Wild
,
whose
interest
is
obviously
to
prevent
such

,
unless
we
can
surprise

together
,
and
,
by
proving
to
Sir
Rowland
that
we
possess

of
compelling

of

,
force
the
other

villain
into
compliance
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
in
all
probability
,
knows
nothing
of
these
packets
;
and
their
production
may
serve
to
intimidate

.
<EOS>
Will
you
venture
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
hazardous
experiment
,
"
said
Thames
,
after
a
moment
's

;
"
but
I
will
make

.
<EOS>
You

not
,
however
,

me
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
The

is
nothing
to

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
care
for
no

,
provided
I
can
serve
you
,
"
rejoined
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
you
'll
not
be
able
to
get

without
me
.
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
do
to
knock
at
the
door
,
and
Jonathan
Wild
's

is
not
quite
so
easy

as
Mr.
Wood
's
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
,
"
replied
Thames
<EOS>
;
"
be
it
as
you
will
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
we
'll
lose
no
more
time
,
"
returned
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
Blueskin
.
"
 
<EOS>
Starting
at
a
rapid
pace
in
the
direction
of
the
Old
Bailey
,
and
crossing
Fleet
Bridge
,
"
for
oyster
tubs
renowned
,
"
the
trio
skirted
the
right
bank
of
the
muddy
stream
until
they
reached
Fleet
Lane
,
up
which
they
hurried
.
<EOS>
Turning
off
again
on
the
left
,
down
Seacoal
Lane
,
they
arrived
at
the
mouth
of
a
dark
,
narrow

,
into
which
they
plunged
;
and
,
at
the
farther
extremity
found
a
small
yard
,
overlooked
by
the
blank
walls
of
a
large
gloomy
habitation
.
<EOS>
A
door
in
this
house
opened
upon
the
yard
.
<EOS>
Jack
tried
it
,
and
found
it
locked
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
my
old
tools
with
me
,
we
'd
soon
master
this
obstacle
,
"
he
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
obliged
to
force
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Try
the
cellar
,
Captain
,
"
said
Blueskin
,
stamping
upon
a
large
board
in
the
ground
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
door
.
<EOS>
This
is
the
way
the
old
thief
brings
in
all
his
heavy
plunder
,
which
he
stows
in
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
holes
in
his
infernal
dwelling
.
<EOS>
I
've
seen
him
often
do
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
While
making
these
remarks
,
Blueskin
contrived
,
by
means
of
a
chisel
which
he
chanced
to
have
about
him
,
to
lift
up
the
board
,
and
,
introducing
his
fingers
beneath
it
,
with
Jack
's
assistance
speedily
opened
it
altogether
,
disclosing
a
dark
hole
,
into
which
he
leapt
.
 
<EOS>
"
Follow
me
,
Thames
,
"
cried
Jack
,
dropping
into
the
chasm
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
now
in
a
sort
of
cellar
,
at
one
end
of
which
was
a
door
.
<EOS>
It
was
fastened
inside
.
<EOS>
But
,
taking
the
chisel
from
Blueskin
,
Jack
quickly
forced
back
the
bolt
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
entered
the
room
beyond
,
a
fierce
growl
was
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
first
,
"
said
Blueskin
;
"
the
dogs
know
me
.
<EOS>
Soho
!
<EOS>
boys
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
walking
up
to
the
animals
,
which
were
chained
to
the
wall
,
they
instantly
recognised
him
,
and
suffered
the
others
to
pass
without
barking
.
 
<EOS>
Groping
their
way
through
one
or
two
dark
and
mouldy
-
smelling
vaults
,
the
party
ascended
a
flight
of
steps
,
which
brought
them
to
the
hall
.
<EOS>
As
Jack
conjectured
,
no
one
was
there
,
and
,
though
a
lamp
was
burning
on
a
stand
,
they
decided
upon
proceeding
without
it
.
<EOS>
They
then
swiftly
mounted
the
stairs
,
and
stopped
before
the
audience
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
Applying
his
ear
to
the
keyhole
,
Jack
listened
,
but
could
detect
no
sound
.
<EOS>
He
,
next
cautiously
tried
the
door
,
but
found
it
fastened
inside
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
we
're
too
late
,
"
he
whispered
to
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
But
,
we
'll
soon
see
.
<EOS>
Give
me
the
chisel
,
Blueskin
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
dexterously
applying
the
implement
,
he
forced
open
the
lock
.
 
<EOS>
They
then
entered
the
room
,
which
was
perfectly
dark
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
strange
,
"
said
Jack
,
under
his
breath
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Sir
Rowland
must
be
gone
.
<EOS>
And
,
yet
,
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
The
key
's
in
the
lock
,
on
the
inner
side
.
<EOS>
Be
on
your
guard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
,
"
replied
Thames
,
who
had
followed
him
closely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
fetch
the
light
,
Captain
?
"
whispered
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
"
he
added
in
a
low

to
Thames
,
as
they
were
left
alone
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
've
a
strange
foreboding
of
ill
.
<EOS>
My
heart
fails
me
.
<EOS>
I
almost
wish
we
had
n't
come
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
he
moved
forward
a
few
paces
,
when
,
finding
his
feet
glued
to
the
ground
by
some
adhesive
substance
,
he
stooped
to
feel
what
it
was
,
but
instantly
withdrew
his
hand
,
with
an

of

.
 
<EOS>
"
God
in
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
the
floor
is
covered
with
blood
.
<EOS>
Some
foul
murder
has
been
committed
.
<EOS>
The
light!--the
light
!
"
 
<EOS>
Astounded
at
his
cries
,
Thames
sprang
towards
him
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Blueskin
appeared
with
the
lamp
,
and
revealed
a
horrible
spectacle,--the
floor
deluged
with
blood,--various
articles
of
furniture
upset,--papers
scattered
about,--the
murdered
man
's
cloak
,
trampled
upon
,
and
smeared
with
gore,--his
hat
,
crushed
and
similarly
stained,--his
<EOS>
sword,--the
ensanguined
cloth,--with
<EOS>
several
other
ghastly
evidences
of
the
slaughterous
deed
.
<EOS>
Further
on
,
there
were
impressions
of
bloody
footsteps
along
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Rowland
is
murdered
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
as
soon
as
he
could
find
a
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
plain
he
has
been
destroyed
by
his
perfidious
accomplice
,
"
rejoined
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
God
!
<EOS>
how
fearfully
my
father
is
avenged
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
Jack
,
sternly
;
"
but
we
have
our
uncle
to
avenge
.
<EOS>
What
's
this
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
,
stooping
to
pick
up
a
piece
of
paper
lying
at
his
feet
--
it
was
Jonathan
's
memorandum
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
explanation
of
the
bloody
deed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
pocket
-
book
full
of
notes
,
and
a
heavy
bag
of
gold
,
"
said
Blueskin
,
examining

on

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
sum
which
incited
the
villain
to
the
murder
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
ca
n't
be
far
off
.
<EOS>
He
must
be
gone
to
dispose
of
the
body
.
<EOS>
We
shall
have
him
on
his
return
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
see
where
these
footsteps
lead
to
,
"
said
Blueskin
,
holding
the
light
to

floor
.
<EOS>
"
Here
are
some
more
papers
,
Captain
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
them
to
me
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
"
a
letter
,
beginning
'
dearest
<EOS>
Aliva,'--that
's
your
mother
's
name
,
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
it
,
"
cried
Thames
,
snatching
it
from
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
_
is
_
addressed
to
my
mother
,
"
he
added
,
as
his
eye
glanced
rapidly
over

,
"
and
by
my
father
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
I
shall
ascertain

name
.
<EOS>
Bring
the
light
this
way
--
quick
!
<EOS>
I
can
not
decipher
the
signature
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
was
about
to
comply
with
the
request
,
when
an
unlooked
-
for
interruption
occurred
.
<EOS>
Having
traced
the
footsteps
to
the
wall
,
and
perceiving
no
outlet
,
Blueskin
elevated
the
lamp
,
and
discovered
marks
of
bloody
fingers
on
the
boards
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
have
gone
this
way
,
"
muttered
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
often
heard
of
a
secret
door
in
this
room
,
though
I
never
saw
it
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
somewhere
hereabouts
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
as
his
eye
fell
upon
a
small
knob
in
the
wall
,
"
there
's
the
spring
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
touched
it
,
and
the
door
flew
open
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
he
was
felled
to
the
ground
by
Jonathan
Wild
,
who
sprang
into
the
room
,
followed
by
Abraham
bearing
the
link
.
<EOS>
A
single
glance
served
to
show
the
thief
-
taker
how
matters
stood
.
<EOS>
From
the
slight
sounds
that
had
reached
him
in
his
place
of
confinement
,
he
was
aware
that
some
persons
had
found
their
way
to
the
scene
of
slaughter
,
and
in
a
state
of
the
most
intense
anxiety
awaited
the
result
of
their
investigation
,
prepared
for
the
worst
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
spring
touched
,
he
dashed
through
on
the
instant
,
and
struck
down
the
person
who
presented
himself
,
with
his
bludgeon
.
<EOS>
On
beholding
the
intruders
,
his
fears
changed
to
exultation
,
and
he
uttered
a
roar
of
satisfaction
as
he
glared
at
them
,
which
could
only
be
likened
to
the
cry
of
some
savage
denizen
of
the
plains
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
appearance
,
Jack
levelled
a
pistol
at
his
head
.
<EOS>
But
his
hand
was
withheld
by
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
fire
,
"
cried
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
important
not
to
slay
him
.
<EOS>
He
shall
expiate
his
offences
on
the
gibbet
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
prisoner
,
murderer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
_
Your
_
prisoner
!
"
echoed
Jonathan
,
derisively
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
mistake,--you
are
mine
.
<EOS>
And
so
is
your
companion,--the
convict
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Waste
not
another
word
with
him
,
Thames
,
"
cried
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Upon
him
!
"
 
"
Yield
,
villain
,
or
die
!
"
shouted
Thames
,
drawing
his
sword
and
springing
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
my
answer
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Wild
,
hurling
the
bludgeon
at
him
,
with
such
fatal
effect
,
that
striking
him
on
the
head
it
brought
him
instantly
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
traitor
!
"
cried
Jack
,
pulling
the
trigger
of
his
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
Anticipating
this
,
Wild
avoided
the
shot
by
suddenly
,
ducking
his
head
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
narrow
escape
,
however
;
for
,
passing
within
an
inch
of
him
,
the
bullet
burried
itself
deeply
in
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
Before
he
could
fire
a
second
shot
,
Jack
had
to
defend
himself
from
the
thief
-
taker
,
who
,
with
his
drawn
hanger
,
furiously
assaulted
him
.
<EOS>
Eluding
the
blow
,
Jack
plucked
his
sword
from
the
scabbard
,
and
a
desperate
conflict
began
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pick
up
that
blade
,
Nab
,
"
vociferated
Wild
,
finding
himself
hotly
pressed
,
"
and
stab
him
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
give
him
a
chance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Cowardly
villain
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
as
the
Jew
,
obeying
the
orders
of
his
principal
,
snatched
up
the
weapon
of
the
murdered
man
,
and
assailed
him
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
'll
yet
disappoint
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
springing
backwards
,
he
darted
suddenly
through
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
him
,
"
cried
Wild
;
"
he
must
n't
escape
.
<EOS>
Dead
or
alive
,
I
'll
have
him
.
<EOS>
Bring
the
link
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
followed
by
Abraham
,
he
rushed
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
Jack
got
half
way
down
the
stairs
,
and
Wild
and
the
Jew
reached
the
upper
landing
,
the
street
-
door
was
opened
by
Langley
and
Ireton
,
the
latter
of
whom
carried
a
lantern
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
him
!
"
shouted
Jonathan
from
the
stair
-
head
,
"
stop
him
!
<EOS>
It
's
Jack
Sheppard
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
way
!
"
cried
Jack
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
cut
down
him
who
opposes
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
head
turnkey
,
in
all
probability
,
would
have
obeyed
.
<EOS>
But
,
being
pushed
forward
by
his
subordinate
officer
,
he
was
compelled
to
make
a
stand
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'd
better
surrender
quietly
,
Jack
,
"
he
cried
;
"
you
've
no
chance
.
"
<EOS>
'
 
Instead
of
regarding
him
,
Jack
glanced
over
the
iron
bannisters
,
and
measured
the
distance
.
<EOS>
But
the
fall
was
too
great
,
and
he
abandoned
the
attempt
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonathan
,
hurrying
down
the
steps
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
escape
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
this
was
said
,
Jack
turned
with
the
swiftness
of
thought
,
and
shortening
his
sword
,
prepared
to
plunge
it
into
the
thief
-
taker
's
heart
.
<EOS>
Before
he
could
make
the
thrust
,
however
,
he
was
seized
behind
by
Ireton
,
who
flung
himself
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Caught
!
"
shouted
the
head
-
turnkey
.
<EOS>
"
I
give
you
joy
of
the
capture
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
he
added
,
as
Jonathan
came
up
,
and
assisted
him
to
secure
and
disarm
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
coming
to
give
you
intelligence
of
a
comical
trick
played
by
this
rascal
,
when
I
find
him
here
--
<EOS>
the
last
place
,
I
own
,
where
I
should
have
expected
to
find
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
arrived
in
the
very
nick
of
time
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
;
"
and
I
'll
take
care
your
services
are
not
overlooked
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Ireton
,
"
cried
Jack
,
in
accents
of
the
most
urgent
entreaty
,
"
before
you
take
me
hence
<EOS>
,
I
implore
you
--
if
you
would
further
the
ends
of
justice
--
search
this
house
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
most
barbarous
murders
ever
committed
has
just
been
perpetrated
by
the
monster
Wild
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
proofs
of
the
bloody
deed
in
his
room
.
<EOS>
But
go
thither
at
once
,
I
beseech
you
,
before
he
has
time
to
remove
them
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Ireton
is
welcome
to
search
every
room
in
my
house
if
he
pleases
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
in
a
tone
of
bravado
.
<EOS>
"
As
soon
as
we
've
conveyed
you
to
Newgate
,
I
'll
accompany
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Ireton
will
do
no
such
thing
,
"
replied
the
head
-
turnkey
.
<EOS>
"
Bless
your
soul
!
d'ye
<EOS>
think
I
'm
to
be
gammoned
by
such
nonsense
.
<EOS>
Not
I.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
quite
such
a
greenhorn
as
Shotbolt
,
Jack
,
whatever
you
may
think
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
mercy
's
sake
go
up
stairs
,
"
implored
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
told
you
half
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
man
dying
--
Captain
Darrell
.
<EOS>
Take
me
with
you
.
<EOS>
Place
a
pistol
at
my
ear
,
and
shoot
me
,
if
I
've
told
you
false
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
what
good
would
that
do
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Ireton
,
sarcastically
.
<EOS>
"
To
shoot
you
would
be
to
lose
the
reward
.
<EOS>
You
act
your
part
capitally
,
but
it
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
go
?
"
cried
Jack
passionately
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Langley
,
I
appeal
to
you
.
<EOS>
Murder
,
I
say
,
has
been
done
!
<EOS>
Another
murder
will
be
committed
if
you
do
n't
prevent
it
.
<EOS>
The
blood
will
rest
on
your
head
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
me
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
Wo
n't
you
stir
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
step
,
"
replied
Langley
,
gruffly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Off
with
him
to
Newgate
!
"
cried
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ireton
,
as
you
captured
him
,
the
reward
is
yours
.
<EOS>
But
I
request
that
a
third
may
be
given
to
Langley
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Ireton
,
bowing
.
"
<EOS>
Now
come
along
,
Jack
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Miscreants
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sheppard
,
almost
driven
frantic
by
the
violence
of
his
emotions
;
"
you
're
all
in
league
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Away
with
him
!
"
cried
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
see
him
fettered
myself
.
<EOS>
Remain
at
the
door
,
Nab
<EOS>
,
"
he
added
,
loitering
for
a
moment
behind
the
others
,
"
and
let
no
one
in
,
or
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
,
meanwhile
,
was
carried
to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
Austin
could
scarcely
credit
his
senses
when
he
beheld
him
.
<EOS>
Shotbolt
,
who
had
in
some
degree
recovered
from
the
effects
of
his
previous
mortification
,
was
thrown
into
an
ecstacy
of
delight
,
and
could
not
sufficiently
exult
over
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Spurling
had
retired
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
Jack
appealed
to
the
new
auditors
,
and
again
detailed
his
story
,
but
with
no
better
success
than
heretofore
.
<EOS>
His
statement
was
treated
with
derision
.
<EOS>
Having
seen
him
heavily
ironed
,
and
placed
in
the
Condemned
Hold
,
Jonathan
recrossed
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
Abraham
on
guard
as
he
had
left
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Has
any
one
been
here
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
von
,
"
replied
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
well
,
"
replied
Wild
,
entering
the
house
,
and
fastening
the
door
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
to
dispose
of
our
dead
.
<EOS>
Why
,
Nab
,
you
shake
as
if
you
'd
got
an
ague
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
,
turning
to
the
Jew
,
whose
teeth
chattered
audibly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
quite
recovered
the
fright
<EOS>
I
got
in
the
Vell
-
Hole
,
"
replied
Abraham
.
 
<EOS>
On
returning
to
the
audience
-
chamber
,
Jonathan
found
the
inanimate
body
of
Thames
Darrell
lying
where
he
had
left
it
;
but
,
on
examining
it
,
he
remarked
that
the
pockets
were
turned
inside
out
,
and
had
evidently
been
rifled
.
<EOS>
Startled
by
this
circumstance
,
he
looked
around
,
and
perceived
that
the
trap
-
door,--which
has
been
mentioned
as
communicating
with
a
secret
staircase,--was
open
.
<EOS>
He
,
next
,
discovered
that
Blueskin
was
gone
;
and
,
pursuing
his
scrutiny
,
found
that
he
had
carried
off
all
the
banknotes
,
gold
,
and
letters,--including
,
what
Jonathan
himself
was
not
aware
<EOS>
of,--the
<EOS>
two
packets
which
he
had
abstracted
from
the
person
of
Thames
.
<EOS>
Uttering
a
terrible
imprecation
,
Jonathan
snatched
up
the
link
,
and
hastily
descended
the
stairs
,
leaving
the
Jew
behind
him
.
<EOS>
After
a
careful
search
below
,
he
could
detect
no
trace
of
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
But
,
finding
the
cellar
-
door
open
,
concluded
he
had
got
out
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
audience
-
chamber
in
a
by
-
no
-
means
enviable
state
of
mind
,
he
commanded
the
Jew
to
throw
the
body
of
Thames
into
the
Well
Hole
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
musht
do
dat
shob
yourself
,
Mishter
Vild
,
"
rejoined
Abraham
,
shaking
his
head
.
"
<EOS>
No
prize
shall
indushe
me
to
enter
dat
horrid
plashe
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Fool
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wild
,
taking
up
the
body
,
"
what
are
you
afraid
of
?
<EOS>
After
all
,
"
he
added
,
pausing
,
"
he
may
be
of
more
use
to
me
alive
than
dead
.
"
 
<EOS>
Adhering
to
this
change
of
plan
,
he
ordered
Abraham
to
follow
him
,
and
,
descending
the
secret
stairs
once
more
,
carried
the
wounded
man
into
the
lower
part
of
the
premises
.
<EOS>
Unlocking
several
doors
,
he
came
to
a
dark
vault
,
that
would
have
rivalled
the
gloomiest
cell
in
Newgate
,
into
which
he
thrust
Thames
,
and
fastened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
to
the
pump
,
Nab
,
"
he
said
,
when
this
was
done
,
"
and
fill
a
pail
with
water
.
<EOS>
We
must
wash
out
those
stains
up
stairs
,
and
burn
the
cloth
.
<EOS>
Blood
,
they
say
,
wo
n't
come
out
.
<EOS>
But
I
never
found
any
truth
in
the
saying
.
<EOS>
When
I
've
had
an
hour
's
rest
,
I
'll
be
after
Blueskin
.
"
    
CHAPTER
XV
.
 
<EOS>
How
Blueskin
underwent
the
Peine
Forte
et
Dure
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
it
became
known
,
through
the
medium
of
the
public
prints
on
the
following
day
,
that
Jack
Sheppard
had
broken
out
of
prison
,
and
had
been
again
captured
during
the
night
,
fresh
curiosity
was
excited
,
and
larger
crowds
than
ever
flocked
to
Newgate
,
in
the
hope
of
obtaining
admission
to
his
cell
;
but
by
the
governor
's
express
commands
,
Wild
having
privately
counselled
the
step
,
no
one
was
allowed
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
A
question
next
arose
whether
the
prisoner
could
be
executed
under
the
existing
warrant,--some
inclining
to
one
opinion
,
some
to
another
.
<EOS>
To
settle
the
point
,
the
governor
started
to
Windsor
,
delegating
his
trust
in
the
interim
to
Wild
,
who
took
advantage
of
his
brief
rule
to
adopt
the
harshest
measures
towards
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
He
had
him
removed
from
the
Condemned
Hold
,
stripped
of
his
fine
apparel
,
clothed
in
the
most
sordid
rags
,
loaded
with
additional
fetters
,
and
thrust
into
the
Stone
Hold,--already
described
as
the
most
noisome
cell
in
the
whole
prison
.
<EOS>
Here
,
without
a
glimpse
of
daylight
;
visited
by
no
one
except
Austin
at
stated
intervals
,
who
neither
answered
a
question
nor
addressed
a
word
to
him
;
fed
upon
the
worst
diet
,
literally
mouldy
bread
and
ditch
-
water
;
surrounded
by
stone
walls
;
with
a
flagged
floor
for
his
pillow
,
and
without
so
much
as
a
blanket
to
protect
him
from
the
death
-
like
cold
that
pierced
his
frame,--Jack
's
stout
heart
was
subdued
,
and
he
fell
into
the
deepest
dejection
,
ardently
longing
for
the
time
when
even
a
violent
death
should
terminate
his
sufferings
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
so
ordered
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Pitt
returned
with
intelligence
that
the
warrant
was
delayed
,
and
,
on
taking
the
opinion
of
two
eminent
lawyers
of
the
day
,
Sir
William
Thomson
and
Mr.
Serjeant
Raby
,
it
was
decided
that
it
must
be
proved
in
a
regular
and
judicial
manner
that
Sheppard
was
the
identical
person
who
had
been
convicted
and
had
escaped
,
before
a
fresh
order
could
be
made
for
his
execution
;
and
that
the
matter
must
,
therefore
,
stand
over
until
the
next
sessions
,
to
be
held
at
the
Old
Bailey
in
October
,
when
it
could
be
brought
before
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
prisoner
,
meanwhile
,
who
was
not
informed
of
the
respite
,
languished
in
his
horrible
dungeon
,
and
,
at
the
expiration
of
three
weeks
,
became
so
seriously
indisposed
that
it
was
feared
he
could
not
long
survive
.
<EOS>
He
refused
his
food,--and
even
when
better
provisions
were
offered
him
,
rejected
them
.
<EOS>
As
his
death
was
by
no
means
what
Jonathan
desired
,
he
resolved
to
remove
him
to
a
more
airy
ward
,
and
afford
him
such
slight
comforts
as
might
tend
to
his
restoration
,
or
at
least
keep
him
alive
until
the
period
of
execution
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
Jack
was
carried
--
for
he
was
no
longer
able
to
move
without
assistance
--
to
a
ward
called
the
Castle
,
situated
over
the
gateway
on
the
western
side
,
in
what
was
considered
the
strongest
part
of
the
jail
.
<EOS>
The
walls
were
of
immense
thickness
;
the
small
windows
double
-
grated
and
unglazed
;
the
fire
-
place
was
without
a
grate
;
and
a
barrack
-
bed
,
divided
into
two
compartments
,
occupied
one
corner
.
<EOS>
It
was
about
twelve
feet
high
,
nine
wide
,
and
fourteen
long
;
and
was
approached
by
double
doors
each
six
inches
thick
.
<EOS>
As
Jack
appeared
to
be
sinking
fast
,
his
fetters
were
removed
,
his
own
clothes
were
returned
to
him
,
and
he
was
allowed
a
mattress
and
a
scanty
supply
of
bed
-
linen
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Spurling
attended
him
as
his
nurse
,
and
,
under
her
care
,
he
speedily
revived
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
became
convalescent
,
and
all
fears
of
his
premature
dissolution
were
at
an
end
,
Wild
recommenced
his
rigorous
treatment
.
<EOS>
The
bedding
was
removed
;
Mrs.
Spurling
was
no
longer
allowed
to
visit
him
;
he
was
again
loaded
with
irons
;
fastened
by
an
enormous
horse
-
padlock
to
a
staple
in
the
floor
;
and
only
allowed
to
take
repose
in
a
chair
.
<EOS>
A
single
blanket
constituted
his
sole
covering
at
night
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
all
this
,
he
grew
daily
better
and
stronger
,
and
his
spirits
revived
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
no
visiters
had
been
permitted
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
As
the
time
when
his
identity
had
to
be
proved
approached
,
this
rigour
was
,
in
a
trifling
degree
,
relaxed
,
and
a
few
persons
were
occasionally
admitted
to
the
ward
,
but
only
in
the
presence
of
Austin
.
<EOS>
From
none
of
these
could
Jack
ascertain
what
had
become
of
Thames
,
or
learn
any
particulars
concerning
the
family
at
Dollis
Hill
,
or
of
his
mother
.
<EOS>
Austin
,
who
had
been
evidently
schooled
by
Wild
,
maintained
a
profound
silence
on
this
head
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
more
than
a
month
passed
over
.
<EOS>
October
arrived
;
and
in
another
week
the
court
would
be
sitting
at
the
Old
Bailey
.
 
<EOS>
One
night
,
about
this
time
,
just
as
Austin
was
about
to
lock
the
great
gate
,
Jonathan
Wild
and
his
two
janizaries
entered
the
Lodge
with
a
prisoner
bound
hand
and
foot
.
<EOS>
It
was
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
On
the
cords
being
removed
,
he
made
a
desperate
spring
at
Wild
,
bore
him
to
the
ground
,
clutched
at
his
throat
,
and
would
,
infallibly
,
have
strangled
him
,
if
the
keepers
had
not
all
thrown
themselves
upon
him
,
and
by
main
force
torn
him
off
.
<EOS>
His
struggles
were
so
violent
,
that
,
being
a
man
of
tremendous
strength
,
it
was
some
time
before
they
could
master
him
,
and
it
required
the
combined
efforts
of
all
the
four
partners
to
put
him
into
irons
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
from
what
he
said
that
he
had
been
captured
when
asleep,--that
his
liquor
had
been
drugged,--otherwise
,
he
would
never
have
allowed
himself
to
be
taken
alive
.
<EOS>
Wild
,
he
asserted
,
had
robbed
him
of
a
large
sum
of
money
,
and
till
it
was
restored
he
would
never
plead
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
that
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Take
him
to
the
bilbowes
.
<EOS>
Put
him
in
the
stocks
,
and
there
let
him
sleep
off
his
drunken
fit
.
<EOS>
Whether
he
pleads
or
not
,
he
shall
swing
with
his
confederate
,
Jack
Sheppard
.
"
 
<EOS>
At
this
allusion
to
his
leader
,
a
shudder
passed
through
Blueskin
's
athletic
frame
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
him
.
<EOS>
Let
me
have
a
word
with
him
,
and
you
may
take
all
the
money
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
made
no
answer
,
but
motioned
the
partners
to
take
him
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Blueskin
was
removed
,
Wild
intimated
his
intention
of
visiting
the
Castle
.
<EOS>
He
was
accompanied
by
Ireton
and
Austin
.
<EOS>
The
massive
door
was
unlocked
,
and
they
entered
the
cell
.
<EOS>
What
was
their
surprise
to
find
it
vacant
,
and
the
prisoner
gone
!
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
could
scarcely
believe
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
He
looked
fiercely
and
inquiringly
from
one
to
the
other
of
his
companions
;
but
,
though
both
of
them
were
excessively
frightened
,
neither
appeared
guilty
.
<EOS>
Before
a
word
could
be
said
,
however
,
a
slight
noise
was
heard
in
the
chimney
,
and
Jack
with
his
irons
on
descended
from
it
.
<EOS>
Without
betraying
the
slightest
confusion
,
or
making
a
single
remark
,
he
quietly
resumed
his
seat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amazement
!
"
cried
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
How
has
he
unfastened
his
padlock
?
<EOS>
Austin
,
it
must
be
owing
to
your
negligence
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
negligence
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
said
the
turnkey
,
trembling
in
every
joint
.
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
,
Sir
,
when
I
left
him
an
hour
ago
,
it
was
locked
.
<EOS>
I
tried
it
myself
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
I
'm
as
much
astonished
as
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
account
for
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
you
shall
answer
for
it
,
"
thundered
Wild
,
with
a
bitter
imprecation
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
not
to
blame
,
"
said
Jack
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
I
opened
the
padlock
with
this
crooked
nail
,
which
I
found
in
the
floor
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
arrived
ten
minutes
later
,
or
if
there
had
n't
been
an
iron
bar
in
the
chimney
,
that
hindered
my
progress
,
I
should
have
been
beyond
your
reach
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
talk
boldly
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Go
to
the
Iron
Hold
,
Austin
,
and
tell
two
of
the
partners
to
bring
another
padlock
of
the
largest
size
,
and
the
heaviest
handcuffs
they
can
find
.
<EOS>
We
'll
try
whether
he
'll
get
loose
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
said
nothing
,
but
a
disdainful
smile
curled
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
Austin
departed
,
and
presently
afterwards
returned
with
the
two
subordinate
officers
,
each
of
whom
wore
a
leathern
apron
round
his
waist
,
and
carried
a
large
hammer
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
manacles
were
slipped
over
the
prisoner
's
wrists
,
and
the
new
padlock
secured
to
the
staple
,
they
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
me
alone
with
him
a
moment
,
"
said
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
And
the
jailers
also
retired
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
,
"
said
Wild
,
with
a
glance
of
malignant
triumph
,
"
I
will
now
tell
you
what
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
All
my
plans
have
succeeded
.
<EOS>
Before
a
month
has
elapsed
,
your
mother
will
be
mine
.
<EOS>
The
Trenchard
estates
will
likewise
be
mine
,
for
Sir
Rowland
is
no
more
,
and
the
youth
,
Thames
,
will
never
again
see
daylight
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
,
who
had
evaded
me
with
the
papers
and
the
money
,
is
a
prisoner
here
,
and
will
perish
on
the
same
gallows
as
yourself
.
<EOS>
My
vengeance
is
completely
gratified
.
"
 
<EOS>
Without
waiting
for
a
reply
,
but
darting
a
malevolent
look
at
the
prisoner
,
he
quitted
the
cell
,
the
door
of
which
was
instantly
double
-
locked
and
bolted
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
not
quite
done
yet
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
as
he
joined
the
turnkeys
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
see
whether
Blueskin
is
a
little
more
composed
.
<EOS>
I
've
a
question
to
ask
him
.
<EOS>
Give
me
the
keys
and
the
light
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
alone
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
descended
a
short
spiral
staircase
,
and
,
entering
a
long
stone
gallery
,
from
which
several
other
passages
branched
,
took
one
of
them
,
and
after
various
turnings
--
for
he
was
familiar
with
all
the
intricacies
of
the
prison
--
arrived
at
the
cell
of
which
he
was
in
search
.
<EOS>
Selecting
a
key
from
the
heavy
bunch
committed
to
him
by
Austin
,
he
threw
open
the
door
,
and
beheld
Blueskin
seated
at
the
back
of
the
small
chamber
,
handcuffed
,
and
<EOS>
with
his
feet
confined
in
a
heavy
pair
of
stocks
.
<EOS>
He
was
asleep
when
Jonathan
entered
,
and
growled
at
being
disturbed
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
soon
as
he
perceived
who
it
was
,
he
roused
himself
,
and
glared
fiercely
at
the
intruder
from
under
his
bent
brows
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
,
in
a
gruff
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
what
you
've
done
with
the
rest
of
the
notes
--
with
the
gold
--
and
the
papers
you
took
away
from
my
room
!
<EOS>
"
rejoined
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
you
'll
never
know
more
than
this
,
"
retorted
Blueskin
,
with
a
grin
of
satisfaction;--"they're
in
a
place
of
safety
,
where
_
you_'ll
never
find
'em
,
but
where
somebody
else
_
will
_
,
and
that
before
long
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Blueskin
,
"
said
Jonathan
,
restraining
his
choler
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
'll
tell
me
where
to
look
for
these
things
,
and
I
_
do
_
find
them
,
I
'll
set
you
free
.
<EOS>
And
you
shall
have
a
share
of
the
gold
for
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
'll
do
,
"
rejoined
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Set
Captain
Sheppard
free
,
and
when
I
hear
he
's
<EOS>
safe,--not
before,--I'll
put
the
money
and
papers
into
your
possession
,
and
some
other
matters
,
too
,
that
you
know
nothing
about
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impracticable
dolt
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
,
furiously
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
'd
part
with
the
sweetest
morsel
of
revenge
on
those
terms
?
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
But
I
'll
have
the
secret
out
of
you
by
other
means
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
violently
shut
and
locked
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
About
ten
days
after
this
interview
,
Blueskin
,
having
been
indicted
by
Wild
for
several
robberies
,
and
true
bills
found
against
him
,
was
placed
at
the
bar
of
the
Old
Bailey
to
be
arraigned
;
when
he
declared
that
he
would
not
plead
to
the
indictment
,
unless
the
sum
of
five
hundred
pounds
,
taken
from
him
by
Jonathan
Wild
,
was
first
restored
to
him
.
<EOS>
This
sum
,
claimed
by
Wild
under
the
statute
4th
and
5th
of
William
and
Mary
,
entitled
"
_
<EOS>
An
act
for
encouraging
the
apprehending
of
Highwaymen
_
,
"
was
granted
to
him
by
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
As
Blueskin
still
continued
obstinate
,
the
judgment
appointed
to
be
executed
upon
such
prisoners
as
stood
mute
,
was
then
read
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
follows
,
and
,
when
uttered
,
produced
a
strong
effect
upon
all
who
heard
it
,
except
the
prisoner
,
who
,
in
no
respect
,
altered
his
sullen
and
dogged
demeanour
.
 
<EOS>
"
Prisoner
at
the
bar
,
"
thus
ran
the
sentence
,
"
you
shall
be
taken
to
the
prison
from
whence
you
came
,
and
put
into
a
mean
room
,
stopped
from
the
light
;
and
shall
there
be
laid
on
the
bare
ground
,
without
any
litter
,
straw
,
or
other
covering
,
and
without
any
garment
.
<EOS>
You
shall
lie
upon
your
back
;
your
head
shall
be
covered
;
and
your
feet
shall
be
bare
.
<EOS>
One
of
your
arms
shall
be
drawn
to
one
side
of
the
room
,
and
the
other
arm
to
the
other
side
,
and
your
legs
shall
be
served
in
the
like
manner
.
<EOS>
Then
,
there
shall
be
laid
upon
your
body
as
much
iron
,
or
stone
as
you
can
bear
,
and
more
.
<EOS>
And
the
first
day
,
you
shall
have
three
morsels
of
barley
bread
,
without
any
drink
;
and
the
second
day
,
you
shall
be
allowed
to
drink
as
much
as
you
can
,
at
three
times
,
of
the
water
that
is
next
to
the
prison
-
door
,
except
running
-
water
,
without
any
bread
.
<EOS>
And
this
shall
be
your
diet
till
you
die
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Prisoner
at
the
bar
,
"
continued
the
clerk
of
the
court
,
"
he
against
whom
this
judgment
is
given
,
forfeits
his
goods
to
the
king
.
"
 
<EOS>
An
awful
silence
prevailed
throughout
the
court
.
<EOS>
Every
eye
was
fixed
upon
the
prisoner
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
he
made
no
answer
,
he
was
removed
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
full
sentence
was
carried
into
execution
,
he
was
taken
into
a
small
room
adjoining
the
court
.
<EOS>
Here
Marvel
,
the
executioner
,
who
was
in
attendance
,
was
commanded
by
Wild
to
tie
his
thumbs
together
,
which
he
did
with
whipcord
so
tightly
,
that
the
string
cut
to
the
bone
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
this
produced
no
effect
,
and
did
not
even
elicit
a
groan
,
the
prisoner
was
carried
back
to
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
The
Press
Room
,
to
which
Blueskin
was
conveyed
on
his
arrival
at
the
jail
,
was
a
small
square
chamber
,
walled
and
paved
with
stone
.
<EOS>
In
each
corner
stood
a
stout
square
post
reaching
to
the
ceiling
.
<EOS>
To
these
a
heavy
wooden
apparatus
was
attached
,
which
could
be
raised
or
lowered
at
pleasure
by
pullies
.
<EOS>
In
the
floor
were
set
four
ring
-
bolts
,
about
nine
feet
apart
.
<EOS>
When
the
prisoner
was
brought
into
this
room
,
he
was
again
questioned
;
but
,
continuing
contumacious
,
preparations
were
made
for
inflicting
the
torture
.
<EOS>
His
great
personal
strength
being
so
well
known
,
it
was
deemed
prudent
by
Marvel
to
have
all
the
four
partners
,
together
with
Caliban
,
in
attendance
.
<EOS>
The
prisoner
,
however
,
submitted
more
quietly
than
was
anticipated
.
<EOS>
He
allowed
his
irons
and
clothes
to
be
taken
off
without
resistance
.
<EOS>
But
just
as
they
were
about
to
place
him
on
the
ground
,
he
burst
from
their
hold
,
and
made
a
desperate
spring
at
Jonathan
,
who
was
standing
with
his
arms
folded
near
the
door
watching
the
scene
.
<EOS>
The
attempt
was
unsuccessful
.
<EOS>
He
was
instantly
overpowered
,
and
stretched
upon
the
ground
.
<EOS>
The
four
men
fell
upon
him
,
holding
his
arms
and
legs
,
while
Caliban
forced
back
his
head
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
,
he
contrived
to
get
the
poor
black
's
hand
into
his
mouth
,
and
nearly
bit
off
one
of
his
fingers
before
the
sufferer
could
be
rescued
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
executioner
had
attached
strong
cords
to
his
ankles
and
wrists
,
and
fastened
them
tightly
to
the
iron
rings
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
unloosed
the
pulley
,
and
the
ponderous
machine
,
which
resembled
a
trough
,
slowly
descended
upon
the
prisoner
's
breast
.
<EOS>
Marvel
,
then
,
took
two
iron
weights
,
each
of
a
hundred
pounds
,
and
placed
them
in
the
press
.
<EOS>
As
this
seemed
insufficient
,
after
a
lapse
of
five
minutes
,
he
added
another
hundred
weight
.
<EOS>
The
prisoner
breathed
with
difficulty
.
<EOS>
Still
,
his
robust
frame
enabled
him
to
hold
out
.
<EOS>
After
he
had
endured
this
torture
for
an
hour
,
at
a
sign
from
Wild
another
hundred
weight
was
added
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
,
an
appalling
change
was
perceptible
.
<EOS>
The
veins
in
his
throat
and
forehead
swelled
and
blackened
;
his
eyes
protruded
from
their
sockets
,
and
stared
wildly
;
a
thick
damp
gathered
on
his
brow
:
and
blood
gushed
from
his
mouth
,
nostrils
,
and
ears
.
 
<EOS>
"
Water
!
"
<EOS>
he
gasped
.
 
<EOS>
The
executioner
shook
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
submit
?
<EOS>
"
interrogated
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
Blueskin
answered
by
dashing
his
head
violently
against
the
flagged
floor
.
<EOS>
His
efforts
at
self
-
destruction
were
,
however
,
prevented
.
 
<EOS>
"
Try
fifty
pounds
more
,
"
said
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
groaned
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
plead
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Wild
,
harshly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
answered
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
"
Release
him
,
"
said
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
cured
his
obstinacy
,
you
perceive
,
"
he
added
to
Marvel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
_
will
_
live
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
with
a
look
of
the
deadliest
hatred
at
Wild
,
"
to
be
revenged
on
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
as
the
weights
were
removed
,
he
fainted
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XVI
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
's
Portrait
was
painted
.
  
<EOS>
Early
in
the
morning
of
Thursday
,
the
15th
of
October
,
1724
,
the
door
of
the
Castle
was
opened
by
Austin
,
who
,
with
a
look
of
unusual
importance
,
announced
to
the
prisoner
that
four
gentlemen
were
shortly
coming
up
with
the
governor
to
see
him,--"four
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
such
_
gentlemen
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
tone
meant
to
impress
his
auditor
with
a
due
sense
of
the
honour
intended
him
,
"
as
you
do
n't
meet
every
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr.
Wood
among
them
?
"
asked
Jack
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wood!--no
,
"
replied
the
turnkey
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
'd
take
the
trouble
to
announce
_
him
_
?
<EOS>
These
are
persons
of
consequence
,
I
tell
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Who
are
they
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
first
,
"
rejoined
Austin
,
"
there
's
Sir
James
Thornhill
,
historical
painter
to
his
Majesty
,
and
the
greatest
artist
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
Those
grand
designs
in
the
dome
of
St.
Paul
's
are
his
work
.
<EOS>
So
is
the
roof
of
the
state
-
room
at
Hampton
Court
Palace
,
occupied
by
Queen
Anne
,
and
the
Prince
of
Denmark
.
<EOS>
So
is
the
chapel
of
All
Souls
at
Oxford
,
and
the
great
hall
at
Blenheim
,
and
I
do
n't
know
how
many
halls
and
chapels
besides
.
<EOS>
He
's
now
engaged
on
the
hall
at
Greenwich
Hospital
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
heard
of
him
,
"
replied
Jack
,
impatiently
.
<EOS>
"
Who
are
the
others
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
friend
of
Sir
James
--
a
young
man
,
an
engraver
of
masquerade
tickets
and
caricatures,--his
name
I
believe
is
Hogarth
.
<EOS>
Then
,
there
's
Mr.
Gay
,
the
poet
,
who
wrote
the
'
Captives
,
'
which
was
lately
acted
at
Drury
Lane
,
and
was
so
much
admired
by
the
Princess
of
Wales
.
<EOS>
And
,
lastly
,
there
's
Mr.
Figg
,
the
noted
prize
-
fighter
,
from
the
New
Amphitheatre
in
Marylebone
Fields
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Figg
's
an
old
friend
of
mine
,
"
rejoined
Jack
;
"
he
was
my
instructor
in
the
small
sword
and
back
sword
exercise
.
<EOS>
I
'm
glad
he
's
come
to
see
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
inquire
what
brings
Sir
James
Thornhill
here
?
"
said
Austin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Curiosity
,
I
suppose
,
"
returned
Jack
,
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
such
thing
,
"
rejoined
the
jailer
;
"
he
's
coming
on
business
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
On
what
business
,
in
the
name
of
wonder
?
"
asked
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
paint
your
portrait
,
"
answered
the
jailer
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
portrait
!
"
echoed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
desire
of
his
Majesty
,
"
said
the
jailer
,
consequentially
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
heard
of
your
wonderful
escapes
,
and
wishes
to
see
what
you
're
like
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
feather
in
your
cap
!
<EOS>
No
house
-
breaker
was
ever
so
highly
honoured
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
have
my
escapes
really
made
so
much
noise
as
to
reach
the
ear
of
royalty
?
"
<EOS>
mused
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
nothing
--
nothing
to
what
I
_
<EOS>
could
_
do
--
to
<EOS>
what
I
_
will
_
do
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
've
done
quite
enough
,
"
rejoined
Austin
;
"
more
than
you
'll
ever
do
again
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
then
to
be
taken
thus
,
in
these
disgraceful
bonds
!
"
<EOS>
continued
Jack
,
"
to
be
held
up
as
a
sight
for
ever
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
else
would
you
be
taken
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
jailer
,
with
a
coarse
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
well
Mr.
Wild
allowed
you
to
have
your
fine
clothes
again
,
or
you
might
have
been
taken
in
a
still
more
disgraceful
garb
.
<EOS>
For
my
part
,
I
think
those
shackles
extremely
becoming
.
<EOS>
But
,
here
they
are
.
"
 
<EOS>
Voices
being
heard
at
the
door
,
Austin
flew
to
open
it
,
and
admitted
Mr.
Pitt
,
the
governor
,
a
tall
pompous
personage
,
who
,
in
his
turn
,
ushered
in
four
other
individuals
.
<EOS>
The
first
of
these
,
whom
he
addressed
as
Mr.
Gay
,
was
a
stout
,
good
-
looking
,
good
-
humoured
man
,
about
thirty
-
six
,
with
a
dark
complexion
,
an
oval
face
,
fine
black
eyes
,
full
of
fire
and
sensibility
,
and
twinkling
with
roguish
humour
--
an
expression
fully
borne
out
by
the
mouth
,
which
had
a
very
shrewd
and
sarcastic
curl
.
<EOS>
The
poet
's
appearance
altogether
was
highly
prepossessing
.
<EOS>
With
a
strong
tendency
to
satire
,
but
without
a
particle
of
malice
or
ill
-
nature
in
its
display
.
<EOS>
Gay
,
by
his
strokes
of
pleasantry
,
whether
in
his
writings
or
conversation
,
never
lost
a
friend
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
he
was
a
universal
favourite
,
and
numbered
amongst
his
intimate
acquaintances
the
choicest
spirits
of
the
time,--Pope
,
Swift
,
Arbuthnot
,
and
"
all
the
better
brothers
.
<EOS>
"
His
demeanour
was
polished
;
his
manners
singularly
affable
and
gentle
;
and
he
was
remarkable
,
for
the
generosity
of
his
temper
.
<EOS>
In
worldly
matters
Gay
was
not
fortunate
.
<EOS>
Possessed
,
at
one
time
,
of
a
share
in
the
South
Sea
stock
,
he
conceived
himself
worth
twenty
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
But
,
on
the
bursting
of
that
bubble
,
his
hopes
vanished
with
it
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
his
interest,--which
was
by
no
means
<EOS>
inconsiderable,--nor
his
general
popularity
,
procure
him
the
preferment
he
desired
.
<EOS>
A
constant
attendant
at
court
,
he
had
the
mortification
to
see
every
one
promoted
but
himself
,
and
thus
bewails
his
ill
-
luck
.
     
<EOS>
Places
,
I
found
,
were
daily
given
away
,
    
And
yet
no
friendly
gazette
mentioned
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
The
prodigious
success
of
the
"
Beggars
'
Opera
,
"
which
was
produced
about
four
years
after
the
date
of
this
history
,
rewarded
him
for
all
his
previous
disappointments
,
though
it
did
not
fully
justify
the
well
-
known
epigram
,
alluding
to
himself
and
the
manager
,
and
"
make
Gay
_
rich
_
,
and
Rich
_
gay
_
.
<EOS>
"
At
the
time
of
his
present
introduction
,
his
play
of
"
The
Captives
,
"
had
just
been
produced
at
Drury
Lane
,
and
he
was
meditating
his
"
Fables
,
"
which
were
published
two
years
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
Behind
the
poet
came
Sir
James
Thornhill
.
<EOS>
The
eminent
painter
had
handsome
,
expressive
features
,
an
aquiline
nose
,
and
a
good
deal
of
dignity
in
his
manner
.
<EOS>
His
age
was
not
far
from
fifty
.
<EOS>
He
was
accompanied
by
a
young
man
of
about
seven
-
and
-
twenty
,
who
carried
his
easel
,
set
it
in
its
place
,
laid
the
canvass
upon
it
,
opened
the
paint
box
,
took
out
the
brushes
and
palette
,
and
,
in
short
,
paid
him
the
most
assiduous
attention
.
<EOS>
This
young
man
,
whose
features
,
though
rather
plain
and
coarse
,
bore
the
strongest
impress
of
genius
,
and
who
had
a
dark
gray
,
penetrating
eye
,
so
quick
in
its
glances
that
it
seemed
to
survey
twenty
objects
at
once
,
and
yet
only
to
fasten
upon
one
,
bore
the
honoured
name
of
William
Hogarth
.
<EOS>
Why
he
paid
so
much
attention
to
Sir
James
Thornhill
may
be
explained
anon
.
 
<EOS>
The
rear
of
the
party
was
brought
up
by
a
large
,
powerfully
-
built
man
,
with
a
bluff
,
honest
,
but
rugged
countenance
,
slashed
with
many
a
cut
and
scar
,
and
stamped
with
that
surly
,
sturdy
,
bull
-
dog
-
like
look
,
which
an
Englishman
always
delights
to
contemplate
,
because
he
conceives
it
to
be
characteristic
of
his
countrymen
.
<EOS>
This
formidable
person
,
who
was
no
other
than
the
renowned
Figg
,
the
"
Atlas
of
the
sword
,
"
as
he
is
termed
by
Captain
Godfrey
,
had
removed
his
hat
and
"
skull
covering
,
"
and
was
wiping
the
heat
from
his
bepatched
and
close
-
shaven
pate
.
<EOS>
His
shirt
also
was
unbuttoned
,
and
disclosed
a
neck
like
that
of
an
ox
,
and
a
chest
which
might
have
served
as
a
model
for
a
Hercules
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
flattish
,
perhaps
,
it
should
be
called
,
a
_
flattened
_
nose
,
and
a
brown
,
leathern
-
looking
hide
<EOS>
,
that
seemed
as
if
it
had
not
unfrequently
undergone
the
process
of
tanning
.
<EOS>
Under
his
arm
he
carried
a
thick
,
knotted
crab
-
stick
.
<EOS>
The
above
description
of
    
--the
great
Figg
,
by
the
prize
-
fighting
swains
    
<EOS>
Sole
monarch
acknowledged
of
Mary'bone
plains--
 
may
sound
somewhat
tame
by
the
side
of
the
glowing
account
given
of
him
by
his
gallant
biographer
,
who
asserts
that
"
there
was
a
majesty
shone
in
his
countenance
,
and
blazed
in
his
actions
,
beyond
all
I
ever
saw
;
"
but
it
may
,
possibly
,
convey
a
more
accurate
notion
of
his
personal
appearance
.
<EOS>
James
Figg
was
the
most
perfect
master
of
self
-
defence
of
his
day
.
<EOS>
Seconded
by
his
strength
and
temper
,
his
skill
rendered
him
invincible
and
he
is
reputed
never
to
have
lost
a
battle
.
<EOS>
His
imperturbable
demeanour
in
the
fight
has
been
well
portrayed
by
Captain
Godfrey
,
who
here
condescends
to
lay
aside
his
stilts
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
right
leg
bold
and
firm
,
and
his
left
,
which
could
hardly
ever
be
disturbed
,
gave
him
a
surprising
advantage
,
and
struck
his
adversary
with
despair
and
panic
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
peculiar
way
of
stepping
in
,
in
a
parry
;
knew
his
arm
,
and
its
just
time
of
moving
;
put
a
firm
faith
in
that
,
and
never
let
his
opponent
escape
.
<EOS>
He
was
just
as
much
a
greater
master
than
any
other
I
ever
saw
,
as
he
was
a
greater
judge
of
time
and
measure
.
<EOS>
"
Figg
's
prowess
in
a
combat
with
Button
has
been
celebrated
by
Dr.
Byrom,--a
poet
of
whom
his
native
town
,
Manchester
,
may
be
justly
proud
;
and
his
features
and
figure
have
been
preserved
by
the
most
illustrious
of
his
companions
on
the
present
occasion,--Hogarth,--in
the
levée
in
the
"
Rake
's
Progress
,
"
and
in
"
Southwark
Fair
.
"
 
<EOS>
On
the
appearance
of
his
visitors
,
Sheppard
arose,--his
gyves
clanking
heavily
as
he
made
the
movement,--and
folding
his
arms
,
so
far
as
his
manacles
would
permit
him
,
upon
his
breast
,
steadily
returned
the
glances
fixed
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
noted
house
-
breaker
and
prison
-
breaker
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr.
Pitt
,
pointing
to
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
"
Odd
's
life
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Gay
,
in
astonishment
;
"
is
this
slight
-
made
stripling
Jack
Sheppard
?
<EOS>
Why
,
I
expected
to
see
a
man
six
foot
high
at
the
least
,
and
as
broad
across
the
shoulders
as
our
friend
Figg
.
<EOS>
This
is
a
mere
boy
.
<EOS>
Are
you
sure
you
have
n't
mistaken
the
ward
,
Mr.
Pitt
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
mistake
,
Sir
,
"
rejoined
the
prisoner
,
drawing
himself
up
,
"
I
am
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
never
was
more
surprised
in
my
life
,
"
said
the
poet,--"never
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
just
the
man
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
I
_
expected
to
see
,
"
observed
Hogarth
,
who
,
having
arranged
everything
to
Thornhill
's
satisfaction
,
had
turned
to
look
at
the
prisoner
,
and
was
now
with
his
chin
upon
his
wrist
,
and
his
elbow
supported
by
the
other
hand
,
bending
his
keen
gray
eyes
upon
him
,
"
just
the
man
!
<EOS>
Look
at
that
light
,
lithe
<EOS>
figure,--all
muscle
and
activity
,
with
not
an
ounce
of
superfluous
flesh
upon
it
.
<EOS>
In
my
search
after
strange
characters
,
Mr.
Gay
,
I
've
been
in
many
odd
quarters
of
our
city
--
have
visited
haunts
frequented
only
by
thieves
--
the
Old
Mint
,
the
New
Mint
,
the
worst
part
of
St.
Giles
's
,
and
other
places
--
but
I
've
nowhere
seen
any
one
who
came
up
so
completely
to
my
notion
of
a
first
-
rate
housebreaker
as
the
individual
before
us
.
<EOS>
Wherever
I
saw
him
,
I
should
pick
him
out
as
a
man
designed
by
nature
to
plan
and
accomplish
the
wonderful
escapes
he
has
effected
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
a
smile
crossed
Sheppard
's
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
understands
me
,
you
perceive
,
"
said
Hogarth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
wo
n't
dispute
your
judgment
in
such
matters
,
Mr.
Hogarth
,
"
replied
Gay
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
appeal
to
you
,
Sir
James
,
whether
it
is
n't
extraordinary
that
so
very
slight
<EOS>
a
person
should
be
such
a
desperate
robber
as
he
is
represented
--
so
young
,
too
,
for
such
an
_
old
_
offender
.
<EOS>
Why
,
he
can
scarcely
be
twenty
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
one
-
and
-
twenty
,
"
observed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
-
and
-
twenty
,
ah
!
"
repeated
Gay
.
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm
not
far
from
the
mark
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
certainly
extremely
youthful
-
looking
and
very
slightly
made
,
"
said
Thornhill
,
who
had
been
attentively
studying
Sheppard
's
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
agree
with
Hogarth
,
that
he
is
precisely
the
person
to
do
what
he
has
done
.
<EOS>
Like
a
thorough
-
bred
racer
,
he
would
sustain
twice
as
much
fatigue
as
a
person
of
heavier
mould
.
<EOS>
Can
I
be
accommodated
with
a
seat
,
Mr.
Pitt
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Sir
James
,
certainly
,
"
replied
the
governor
.
<EOS>
"
Get
a
chair
,
Austin
.
"
 
While
this
order
was
obeyed
,
Figg
,
who
had
been
standing
near
the
door
,
made
his
way
to
the
prisoner
,
and
offered
him
his
huge
hand
,
which
Jack
warmly
grasped
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Jack
,
"
said
the
prize
-
fighter
,
in
a
rough
,
but
friendly
voice
,
and
with
a
cut
-
and
-
thrust
abrupt
manner
peculiar
to
himself
;
"
how
are
you
,
lad
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Sorry
to
see
you
here
.
<EOS>
Would
n't
take
my
advice
.
<EOS>
Told
you
how
it
would
be
.
<EOS>
One
mistress
enough
to
ruin
a
man,--two
,
the
devil
.
<EOS>
Laughed
at
me
,
then
.
<EOS>
Laugh
on
the
wrong
side
of
your
mouth
,
now
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
come
here
to
insult
me
,
Mr.
Figg
?
"
said
Jack
,
peevishly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Insult
you
!
<EOS>
not
I
;
"
returned
Figg
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Heard
of
your
escapes
.
<EOS>
Everybody
talking
of
you
.
<EOS>
Wished
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
Old
pupil
.
<EOS>
Capital
swordsman
.
<EOS>
Shortly
to
be
executed
.
<EOS>
Come
to
take
leave
.
<EOS>
Trifle
useful
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
slipping
a
few

pieces
into
Jack
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
,
"
said
Jack
,
returning
the

;
"
but
I
do
n't
require

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Too
proud
,
eh
?
"
rejoined
the
prize
-
fighter
.
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
be
under
an
obligation
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
're
wrong
,
Mr.
Figg
,
"
replied
Jack
,
smiling
;
"
for
,
before
I
'm
taken
to
Tyburn
,
I
mean
to
borrow
a
shirt
for

from
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Have
it
,
and

,
"
rejoined
Figg
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Always
plenty
to
spare
.
<EOS>
Never
bought
a
shirt
in
my
life
,
Mr.
Gay
,
"
he
added
,
turning
to
the

.
"
<EOS>
Sold
a
good
many
,
though
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
manage
that
,
Mr.
Figg
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Thus
,
"
replied
the
prize
-
fighter
.
<EOS>
"
Proclaim
a
public
fight
.
<EOS>
Challenge
accepted
.
<EOS>
Fifty
pupils
.
<EOS>
Day
before
,
send
round
to
each
to
borrow
a
shirt
.
<EOS>
Fifty
sent
home
.
<EOS>
All
superfine
holland
.
<EOS>
Wear
one
on
the
stage
on
the
following
day
.
<EOS>
Cut
to
pieces
--
slashed
--
bloodied
.
<EOS>
Each
of
my
scholars
thinks
it
his
own
shirt
.
<EOS>
Offer
to
return
it
to
each
in
private
.
<EOS>
All
make
the
same
answer--'d
--
<EOS>
n
<EOS>
you
,
keep
it
.
'
"
 
<EOS>
"
An
ingenious
device
,
"
laughed
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
James
Thornhill
's
preparations
being
completed
,
Mr.
Pitt
desired
to
know
if
he
wanted
anything
further
,
and
being
answered
in
the
negative
,
he
excused
himself
on
the

that
his
attendance
was
required
in
the
court
at
the
Old
Bailey
,
which
was
then
sitting
,
and
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
me
the
favour
to
seat
yourself
,
Jack
,
"
said
Sir
James
.
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
a
little
further
off
,
if
you
please
.
"
 
Sheppard
immediately
complied
with
the
painter
's
request
;
while
Gay
and
Figg
drew
back
on
one
side
,
and
Hogarth
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
The
latter
took
from
his
pocket
a
small
note
-
book
and
pencil
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
make
a
sketch
,
too
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Jack
Sheppard
's
face
is
well
worth
preserving
.
<EOS>
"
 
After
narrowly
examining
the
countenance
of
the
sitter
,
and
motioning
him
with
his
pencil
into
a
particular
attitude
,
Sir
James
Thornhill
commenced
operations
;
and
,
while
he
rapidly
transferred
his
lineaments
to
the
canvass
,
engaged
him
in
conversation
,
in
the
course
of
which
he
artfully
contrived
to
draw
him
into
a
recital
of
his
adventures
.
<EOS>
The
_
ruse
_
succeeded
almost
beyond
his
expectation
.
<EOS>
During
the
narration
Jack
's
features
lighted
up
,
and
an
expression
,
which
would
have
been
in
vain
looked
for
in
repose
,
was
instantly
caught
and
depicted
by
the
skilful
artist
.
<EOS>
All
the
party
were
greatly
interested
by
Sheppard
's
history
--
especially
Figg
,
who
laughed
loud
and
long
at
the
escape
from
the
Condemned
Hold
.
<EOS>
When
Jack
came
to
speak
of
Jonathan
Wild
,
his
countenance
fell
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
change
the
subject
,
"
remarked
Thornhill
,
pausing
in
his
task
;
"
this
will
never
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
right
,
Sir
James
,
"
said
Austin
.
<EOS>
"
We
never
suffer
him
to
mention
Mr.
Wild
's
name
.
<EOS>
He
never
appears
to
so
little
advantage
as
when
speaking
of
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
wonder
at
it
,
"
rejoined
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Hogarth
received
a
private

Thornhill
to
attract

's
attention
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
you
've
given
up
all

of

,

,
Jack
?
"
remarked
Hogarth
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
scarcely
a
fair

,
Mr.
Hogarth
,
before
the
jailer
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
tell
you
frankly
,
and
Mr.
Austin
,
may
repeat

if
he
pleases
to
his

,
Jonathan
Wild,--I
have
_
not
_
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
said
,
Jack
,
"
cried
Figg
.
<EOS>
"
Never
give
in
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
observed
Hogarth
,
"
if
,
fettered
as
you
are
,
you
contrive
to
break
out
of
this
dungeon
<EOS>
,
you
'll
do
what
no
man
ever
did
before
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
peculiar

illuminated
Jack
's
features
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sir
James
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
exact
expression
I
want
.
<EOS>
For
the
love
of
Heaven
,
Jack
,
do
n't
move!--Don't
alter
a
muscle
,
if
you
can
help
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
with
a
few
magical

,
he
stamped
the
fleeting
expression
on
the
canvass
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
it
too
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Hogarth
,
busily
plying

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Gad
!
<EOS>
it
's
a
devilish
fine
face
when
lit
up
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
like
as
life
,
Sir
,
"
observed
Austin
,
peeping
over
Thornhill
's

at

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
like
as
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
face
,
"
exclaimed
Gay
,
advancing
to
look
at
it;--"with
all
the
escapes
written
in

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
flatter

,
"
smiled

James
.
<EOS>
"
But
,
I
own
,
I
think

_

_

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

_
<EOS>
my
_

,

?
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But
it
wants
something
_
here
_
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
pointed
significantly
to

hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
,
"
rejoined
Hogarth
,
rapidly

,

in

.
<EOS>
"
Will
that
do
?
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
better
,
"
observed
Sheppard
,

.
<EOS>
"
But
you
've
given
me
what
I

n't

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
<EOS>
"
said
Hogarth
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

how
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
look

,
Sir
!
"
said
Austin
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

Hogarth
,
hastily

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
never
satisfied
with

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Egad
,
Jack
,
"
said
Gay
,
"
you
should
write
your
adventures
.
<EOS>
They
would
be
quite
as

as

of
Guzman
D'Alfarache
,
Lazarillo
de
Tormes
,
Estevanillo

,
Meriton
Latroon
,
or
any

my

<EOS>
rogues,--and
<EOS>
far

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
had

write

,
Mr.
Gay
,
"
rejoined
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
'll
write

,
I
'll
