,
"
observed
Hogarth
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
idea
has
just
occurred
to
me
,
"
said
Gay
,
"
which
Jack
's
narrative
has
suggested
.
<EOS>
I
'll
write
an
opera
the
scene
of
which
shall
be
laid
altogether
in
Newgate
,
and
the
principal
character
shall
be
a
highmaywan
.
<EOS>
I
'll
not
forget
your
two
mistresses
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
Jonathan
Wild
,
I
hope
,
"
interposed
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
replied
Gay
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
gibbet
the
rascal
.
<EOS>
But
I
forget
,
"
he
added
,
glancing
at
Austin
;
"
it
's
high
treason
to
speak
disrespectfully
of
Mr.
Wild
in
his
own
domain
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
hear
nothing
,
Sir
,
"
laughed
Austin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
about
to
add
,
"
continued
Gay
,
"
that
my
opera
shall
have
no
music
except
the
good
old
ballad
tunes
.
<EOS>
And
we
'll
see
whether
it
wo
n't
put
the
Italian
opera
out
of
fashion
,
with
Cutzoni
,
Senesino
,
and
the
'
divine
'
Farinelli
at
its
head
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
do
a
national
service
,
then
,
"
said
Hogarth
.
<EOS>
"
The
sums
lavished
upon
those
people
are
perfectly
disgraceful
,
and
I
should
be
enchanted
to
see
them
hooted
from
the
stage
.
<EOS>
But
I
've
an
idea
as
well
as
you
,
grounded
in
some
measure
upon
Sheppard
's
story
.
<EOS>
I
'll
take
two
apprentices
,
and
depict
their
career
.
<EOS>
One
,
by
perseverance
and
industry
shall
obtain
fortune
,
credit
,
and
the
highest
honours
;
while
the
other
by
an
opposite
course
,
and
dissolute
habits
,
shall
eventually
arrive
at
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
's
will
be
nearer
the
truth
,
and
have
a
deeper
moral
,
Mr.
Hogarth
,
"
remarked
Jack
,
dejectedly
.
"
<EOS>
But
if
my
career
were
truly
exhibited
,
it
must
be
as
one
long
struggle
against
destiny
in
the
shape
of--
"
 
"
Jonathan
Wild
,
"
interposed
Gay
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
.
<EOS>
By
the
by
,
Mr.
Hogarth
,
did
n't
I
see
you
last
night
at
the
ridotto
with
Lady
Thornhill
and
her
pretty
daughter
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Me!--no
,
Sir
,
"
stammered
Hogarth
,
colouring
.
<EOS>
And
he
hazarded
a
wink
at
the
poet
over
the
paper
on
which
he
was
sketching
.
<EOS>
Luckily
,
Sir
James
was
so
much
engrossed
by
his
own
task
,
that
both
the
remark
and
gesture
escaped
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
was
mistaken
,
"
returned
Gay
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
quizzing
my
friend
Kent
<EOS>
,
I
perceive
,
in
your
Burlington
Gate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
capital
caricature
that
,
"
remarked
Thornhill
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
What
does
Mr.
Kent
say
to
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
thinks
so
highly
of
it
,
that
he
says
if
he
had
a
daughter
he
would
give
her
to
the
artist
,
"
answered
Gay
,
a
little
maliciously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Sir
James
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sdeath
!
"
cried
Hogarth
,
aside
to
the
poet
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
ruined
my
hopes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Advanced
them
rather
,
"
replied
Gay
,
in
the
same
tone
.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Thornhill
's
a
charming
girl
.
<EOS>
_
I
_
think
a
wife
a
needless
incumbrance
,
and
mean
to
die
a
bachelor
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
I
were
in
your
place
,
I
know
what
I
'd
do--
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
--
what
would
you
do
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Hogarth
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Run
away
with
her
,
"
replied
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pish
!
"
exclaimed
Hogarth
.
<EOS>
But
he
afterwards
acted
upon
the
suggestion
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-
b'ye
,
Jack
,
"
said
Figg
,
putting
on
his
hat
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
in
the
way
.
<EOS>
Send
you
the
shirt
.
<EOS>
Here
,
turnkey
.
<EOS>
Couple
of
guineas
to
drink
Captain
Sheppard
's
speedy

.
<EOS>
Thank
him
,
not
me
,
man
.
<EOS>
Give
this
fellow
the
slip
,
if
you
can
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
If
not
,
keep
up
your
spirits
.
<EOS>
Die
game
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
fear
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
If
I

,
I
'll
have
a

with

at

.
<EOS>
If
not
,
I
'll
take

cheerful

with

at

of
Oxford
,
on

Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Give
you
the
best

have
in
either

,
"

Figg
.
<EOS>
"
Good
-
b'ye
!
"
<EOS>
And
with
a
cordial
shake
of
the
hand
he

his

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
James
Thornhill
,
then
,
rose
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
trouble
you
further
,
Jack
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
've
done
all
I
can
to
the

here
.
<EOS>
I
must
finish
it
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Permit
me
to
see
it
,
Sir
James
!
"
requested
Jack
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
as
the
painting
was
turned
towards
him
.
"
<EOS>
What
would
my
poor
mother
say
to
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
sorry
to
see
that
about
your
mother
,
Jack
,
"
observed
Hogarth
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
her
?
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
starting
up
.
<EOS>
"
Is
she
dead
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
no
,
"
answered
Hogarth
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
alarm
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
saw
it
this
morning
in
the
Daily
Journal
--
an
advertisement
,
offering
a
reward--
"
 
"
A
reward
!
"
echoed
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
what
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
the
paper
with
me
.
'
<EOS>
Sdeath
!
<EOS>
what
can
I
have
done
with
it
?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
here
it
is
,
"
cried
Hogarth
,
picking
it
from
the
ground
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
dropped
it
when
I
took
out
my
note
-
book
.
<EOS>
There
's
the
paragraph
.
'
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Mrs
.
Sheppard
left
Mr.
Wood
's
house
at
Dollis
Hill
on
Tuesday_'--that
's
two
days
ago,--'_hasn't
been
heard
of
since
_
.
'
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
"
cried
Jack
,
snatching
the
paper
,
and
eagerly
perusing
the
advertisement
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
,
in
a
tone
of
anguish
.
"
<EOS>
She
has
fallen
into
the
villain
's
hands
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
villain
?
"
cried
Hogarth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jonathan
Wild
,
I
'll
be
sworn
,
"
said
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
"
Right!--right
!
"
cried
Jack
,
striking
his
fettered
hands
against
his
breast
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
in
his
power
,
and
I
am
here
,
chained
hand
and
foot
,
unable
to
assist
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
make
a
fine
sketch
of
him
now
,
"
whispered
Hogarth
to
Gay
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
how
it
was
,
Sir
James
,
"
said
Austin
,
addressing
the
knight
,
who
was
preparing
for
his
departure
,
"
he
attributes
every
misfortune
that
befals
him
to
Mr.
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
with
some
justice
,
"
replied
Thornhill
,
drily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
to
assist
you
,
Sir
James
,
"
said
Hogarth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Many
thanks
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Thornhill
,
with
freezing
politeness
;
"
but
I
d
not
require
assistance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
Jack
,
"
said
Gay
,
"
<EOS>
I
've
several
urgent
engagements
this
morning
;
but
I
'll
return
to
-
morrow
,
and
hear
the
rest
of
your
story
.
<EOS>
And
,
if
I
can
render
you
any
service
,
you
may
command
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
will
be
too
late
,
"
said
Sheppard
,
moodily
.
 
<EOS>
The
easel
and
palette
having
been
packed
up
,
and
the
canvass
carefully
removed
by
Austin
,
the
party
took
leave
of
the
prisoner
,
who
was
so
much
abstracted
that
he
scarcely
noticed
their
departure
.
<EOS>
Just
as
Hogarth
got
to
the
door
,
the
turnkey
stopped
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
forgotten
your
knife
,
Mr.
Hogarth
,
"
he
observed
,
significantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
,
"
replied
Hogarth
,
glancing
at
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
do
without
it
,
"
muttered
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
then
locked
,
and
he
was
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
At
three
o'clock
,
on
the
same
day
,
Austin
brought
up
Jack
's
provisions
,
and
,
after
carefully
examining
his
fetters
,
and
finding
all
secure
,
told
him
if
he
wanted
anything
further
he
must
mention
it
,
as
he
should
not
be
able
to
return
in
the
evening
,
his
presence
being
required
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
Jack
replied
in
the
negative
,
and
it
required
all
his
mastery
over
himself
to
prevent
the
satisfaction
which
this
announcement
afforded
him
from
being
noticed
by
the
jailer
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
usual
precautions
,
Austin
then
departed
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
cried
Jack
,
leaping
up
,
"
for
an
achievement
,
compared
with
which
all
I
have
yet
done
shall
be
as
nothing
!
"
    
CHAPTER
XVII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Iron
Bar
.
  
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
's
first
object
was
to
free
himself
from
his
handcuffs
.
<EOS>
This
he
accomplished
by
holding
the
chain
that
connected
them
firmly
between
his
teeth
,
and
squeezing
his
fingers
as
closely
together
as
possible
,
succeeded
in
drawing
his
wrists
through
the
manacles
.
<EOS>
He
next
twisted
the
heavy
gyves
round
and
round
,
and
partly
by
main
strength
,
partly
by
a
dexterous
and
well
-
applied
jerk
,
sapped
asunder
the
central
link
by
which
they
were
attached
to
the
padlock
.
<EOS>
Taking
off
his
stockings
,
he
then
drew
up
the
basils
as
far
as
he
was
able
,
and
tied
the
fragments
of
the
broken
chain
to
his
legs
,
to
prevent
them
from
clanking
,
and
impeding
his
future
exertions
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
's
former
attempt
to
pass
up
the
chimney
,
it
may
be
remembered
,
was
obstructed
by
an
iron
bar
.
<EOS>
To
remove
this
obstacle
it
was
necessary
make
an
extensive
breach
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
With
the
broken
links
of
the
chain
,
which
served
him
in
lieu
of
more
efficient
implements
,
he
commenced
operations
just
above
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
soon
contrived
to
pick
a
hole
in
the
plaster
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
the
wall
,
as
he
suspected
,
solidly
constructed
of
brick
and
stone
;
and
with
the
slight
and
inadequate
tools
which
he
possessed
,
it
was
a
work
of
infinite
labour
and
skill
to
get
out
a
single
brick
.
<EOS>
That
done
,
however
,
he
was
well
aware
the
rest
would
be
comparatively
easy
,
and
as
he
threw
the
brick
to
the
ground
,
he
exclaimed
triumphantly
,
"
The
first
step
is
taken
--
the
main
difficulty
is
overcome
.
"
 
<EOS>
Animated
by
this
trifling
success
,
he
proceeded
with
fresh
ardour
,
and
the
rapidity
of
his
progress
was
proclaimed
by
the
heap
of
bricks
,
stones
,
and
mortar
which
before
long
covered
the
floor
.
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
an
hour
,
by
dint
of
unremitting
exertion
,
he
had
made
so
large
a
breach
in
the
chimney
,
that
he
could
stand
upright
in
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
within
a
foot
of
the
bar
,
and
introducing
himself
into
the
hole
,
speedily
worked
his
way
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Regardless
of
the
risk
he
incurred
from
some
heavy
stone
dropping
on
his
head
or
feet,--regardless
also
of
the
noise
made
by
the
falling
rubbish
,
and
of
the
imminent
danger
which
he
consequently
ran
of
being
interrupted
by
some
of
the
jailers
,
should
the
sound
reach
their
ears
,
he
continued
to
pull
down
large
masses
of
the
wall
,
which
he
flung
upon
the
floor
of
the
cell
.
 
<EOS>
Having
worked
thus
for
another
quarter
of
an
hour
without
being
sensible
of
fatigue
,
though
he
was
half
stifled
by
the
clouds
of
dust
which
his
exertions
raised
,
he
had
made
a
hole
about
three
feet
wide
,
and
six
high
,
and
uncovered
the
iron
bar
.
<EOS>
Grasping
it
firmly
with
both
hands
,
he
quickly
wrenched
if
from
the
stones
in
which
it
was
mortised
,
and
leapt
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
On
examination
it
proved
to
be
a
flat
bar
of
iron
,
nearly
a
yard
in
length
,
and
more
than
an
inch
square
.
"
<EOS>
A
capital
instrument
for
my
purpose
<EOS>
,
"
thought
Jack
,
shouldering
it
,
"
and
worth
all
the
trouble
I
have
had
in
procuring
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
musing
,
he
fancied
he
heard
the
lock
tried
.
<EOS>
A
chill
ran
through
his
frame
,
and
,
grasping
the
heavy
weapon
with
which
chance
had
provided
him
,
prepared
to
strike
down
the
first
person
who
should
enter
the
cell
.
<EOS>
After
listening
attentively
for
a
short
time
without
drawing
breath
,
he
became
convinced
that
his
apprehensions
were
groundless
,
and
,
greatly
relieved
,
sat
down
upon
the
chair
to
rest
himself
and
prepare
for
further
efforts
.
 
<EOS>
Acquainted
with
every
part
of
the
jail
,
Jack
well
knew
that
his
only
chance
of
effecting
an
escape
must
be
by
the
roof
.
<EOS>
To
reach
it
would
be
a
most
difficult
undertaking
.
<EOS>
Still
it
was
possible
,
and
the
difficulty
was
only
a
fresh
incitement
.
 
<EOS>
The
mere
enumeration
of
the
obstacles
that
existed
would
have
deterred
any
spirit
less
daring
than
Sheppard
's
from
even
hazarding
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
Independently
of
other
risks
,
and
of
the
chance
of
breaking
his
neck
in
the
descent
,
he
was
aware
that
to
reach
the
leads
he
should
have
to
break
open
six
of
the
strongest
doors
of
the
prison
.
<EOS>
Armed
,
however
,
with
the
implement
he
had
so
fortunately
obtained
,
he
did
not
despair
of
success
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
name
will
only
be
remembered
as
that
of
a
robber
,
"
he
mused
;
"
but
it
shall
be
remembered
as
that
of
a
bold
one
:
and
<EOS>
this
night
's
achievement
,
if
it
does
nothing
else
,
shall
prevent
me
from
being
classed
with
the
common
herd
of
depredators
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Roused
by
this
reflection
,
filled
with
the
deepest
anxiety
for
his
mother
,
and
burning
to
be
avenged
upon
Jonathan
Wild
,
he
grasped
the
iron
bar
,
which
,
when
he
sat
down
,
he
had
laid
upon
his
knees
,
and
stepped
quickly
across
the
room
.
<EOS>
In
doing
so
,
he
had
to
clamber
up
the
immense
heap
of
bricks
and
rubbish
which
now
littered
the
floor
,
amounting
almost
to
a
car
-
load
,
and
reaching
up
nearly
to
the
top
of
the
chimney
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
"
Austin
will
stare
,
"
thought
Jack
,
"
when
he
comes
here
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
It
will
cost
them
something
to
repair
their
stronghold
,
and
take
them
more
time
to
build
it
up
again
than
I
have
taken
to
pull
it
down
.
"
 
<EOS>
Before
proceeding
with
his
task
,
he
considered
whether
it
would
be
possible
to
barricade
the
door
;
but
,
reflecting
that
the
bar
would
be
an
indispensable
assistant
in
his
further
efforts
,
he
abandoned
the
idea
,
and
determined
to
rely
implicitly
on
that
good
fortune
which
had
hitherto
attended
him
on
similar
occasions
.
 
<EOS>
Having
once
more
got
into
the
chimney
,
he
climbed
to
a
level
with
the
ward
above
,
and
recommenced
operations
as
vigorously
as
before
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
aided
with
a
powerful
implement
,
with
which
he
soon
contrived
to
make
a
hole
in
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
"
Every
brick
I
take
out
,
"
cried
Jack
,
as
fresh
rubbish
clattered
down
the
chimney
,
"
brings
me
nearer
my
mother
.
"
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XVIII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Red
Room
.
  
<EOS>
The
ward
into
which
Jack
was
endeavouring
to
break
was
called
the
Red
Room
,
from
the
circumstance
of
its
walls
having
once
been
painted
in
that
colour
;
all
traces
of
which
had
,
however
,
long
since
disappeared
.
<EOS>
Like
the
Castle
,
which
it
resembled
in
all
respects
except
that
it
was
destitute
even
of
a
barrack
-
bedstead
,
the
Red
Room
was
reserved
for
state
-
prisoners
,
and
had
not
been
occupied
since
the
year
1716
,
when
the
jail
,
as
has
before
been
mentioned
,
was
crowded
by
the
Preston
rebels
.
 
<EOS>
Having
made
a
hole
in
the
wall
sufficiently
large
to
pass
through
,
Jack
first
tossed
the
bar
into
the
room
and
then
crept
after
it
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
gained
his
feet
,
he
glanced
round
the
bare
blank
walls
of
the
cell
,
and
,
oppressed
by
the
musty
,
close
atmosphere
,
exclaimed
,
<EOS>
"
I
'll
let
a
little
fresh
air
into
this
dungeon
.
<EOS>
They
say
it
has
n't
been
opened
for
eight
years
--
but
I
wo
n't
be
eight
years
in
getting
out
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
stepping
across
the
room
,
some
sharp
point
in
the
floor
pierced
his
foot
,
and
stooping
to
examine
it
<EOS>
,
he
found
that
the
wound
had
been
inflicted
by
a
long
rusty
nail
,
which
projected
from
the
boards
.
<EOS>
Totally
disregarding
the
pain
,
he
picked
up
the
nail
,
and
reserved
it
for
future
use
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
long
in
making
it
available
.
 
<EOS>
On
examining
the
door
,
he
found
it
secured
by
a
large
rusty
lock
,
which
he
endeavoured
to
pick
with
the
nail
he
had
just
acquired
;
but
all
his
efforts
proving
ineffectual
,
he
removed
the
plate
that
covered
it
with
the
bar
,
and
with
his
fingers
contrived
to
draw
back
the
bolt
.
 
<EOS>
Opening
the
door
he
then
stepped
into
a
dark
narrow
passage
leading
,
as
he
was
well
aware
,
to
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
On
the
left
there
were
doors
communicating
with
the
King
's
Bench
Ward
and
the
Stone
Ward
,
two
large
holds
on
the
Master
Debtors
'
side
.
<EOS>
But
Jack
was
too
well
versed
in
the
geography
of
the
place
to
attempt
either
of
them
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
if
he
had
been
ignorant
of
it
,
the
sound
of
voices
which
he
could
faintly
distinguish
,
would
have
served
as
a
caution
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrying
on
,
his
progress
was
soon
checked
by
a
strong
door
,
several
inches
in
thickness
,
and
nearly
as
wide
as
the
passage
.
<EOS>
Running
his
hand
carefully
over
it
in
search
of
the
lock
,
he
perceived
to
his
dismay
that
it
was
fastened
on
the
other
side
.
<EOS>
After
several
vain
attempts
to
burst
it
open
,
he
resolved
,
as
a
last
alternative
,
to
break
through
the
wall
in
the
part
nearest
to
the
lock
.
<EOS>
This
was
a
much
more
serious
task
than
he
anticipated
.
<EOS>
The
wall
was
of
considerable
thickness
,
and
built
altogether
of
stone
;
and
the
noise
he
was
compelled
to
make
in
using
the
heavy
bar
,
which
brought
sparks
with
every
splinter
he
struck
off
,
was
so
great
,
that
he
feared
it
must
be
heard
by
the
prisoners
on
the
Debtors
'
side
.
<EOS>
Heedless
,
however
,
of
the
consequences
,
he
pursued
his
task
.
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
's
labour
,
during
which
he
was
obliged
more
than
once
to
pause
to
regain
breath
,
sufficed
to
make
a
hole
wide
enough
to
allow
a
passage
for
his
arm
up
to
the
elbow
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
he
was
able
to
force
back
a
ponderous
bolt
from
its
socket
;
and
to
his
unspeakable
joy
,
found
that
the
door
instantly
yielded
.
 
<EOS>
Once
more
cheered
by
daylight
,
he
hastened
forward
,
and
entered
the
chapel
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XIX
.
 
<EOS>
The
Chapel
.
  
<EOS>
Situated
at
the
upper
part
of
the
south
-
east
angle
of
the
jail
,
the
chapel
of
Old
Newgate
was
divided
on
the
north
side
into
three
grated
compartments
,
or
pens
as
they
were
termed
,
allotted
to
the
common
debtors
and
felons
.
<EOS>
In
the
north
-
west
angle
,
there
was
a
small
pen
for
female
offenders
,
and
,
on
the
south
,
a
more
commodious
enclosure
appropriated
to
the
master
-
debtors
and
strangers
.
<EOS>
Immediately
beneath
the
pulpit
stood
a
large
circular
pew
where
malefactors
under
sentence
of
death
sat
to
hear
the
condemned
sermon
delivered
to
them
,
and
where
they
formed
a
public
spectacle
to
the
crowds
,
which
curiosity
generally
attracted
on
those
occasions
.
 
<EOS>
To
return
.
<EOS>
Jack
had
got
into
one
of
the
pens
at
the
north
side
of
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
The
enclosure
by
which
it
was
surrounded
was
about
twelve
feet
high
;
the
under
part
being
composed
of
taken
planks
,
the
upper
of
a
strong
iron
grating
,
surmounted
by
sharp
iron
spikes
.
<EOS>
In
the
middle
there
was
a
gate
.
<EOS>
It
was
locked
.
<EOS>
But
Jack
speedily
burst
it
open
with
the
iron
bar
.
 
<EOS>
Clearing
the
few
impediments
in
his
way
,
he
soon
reached
the
condemned
pew
,
where
it
had
once
been
his
fate
to
sit
;
and
extending
himself
on
the
seat
endeavoured
to
snatch
a
moment
's
repose
.
<EOS>
It
was
denied
him
,
for
as
he
closed
his
eyes
--
though
but
for
an
instant
--
the
whole
scene
of
his
former
visit
to
the
place
rose
before
him
.
<EOS>
There
he
sat
as
before
,
with
the
heavy
fetters
on
his
limbs
,
and
beside
him
sat
his
three
companions
,
who
had
since
expiated
their
offences
on
the
gibbet
.
<EOS>
The
chapel
was
again
crowded
with
visitors
,
and
every
eye
--
even
that
of
Jonathan
Wild
who
had
come
thither
to
deride
him,--was
fixed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
So
perfect
was
the
illusion
,
that
he
could
almost
fancy
<EOS>
he
heard
the
solemn
voice
of
the
ordinary
warning
him
that
his
race
was
nearly
run
,
and
imploring
him
to
prepare
for
eternity
.
<EOS>
From
this
perturbed
state
he
was
roused
by
thoughts
of
his
mother
,
and
fancying
he
heard
her
gentle
voice
urging
him
on
to
fresh
exertion
,
he
started
up
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
side
of
the
chapel
there
was
a
large
grated
window
,
but
,
as
it
looked
upon
the
interior
of
the
jail
,
Jack
preferred
following
the
course
he
had
originally
decided
upon
to
making
any
attempt
in
this
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
proceeded
to
a
gate
which
stood
upon
the
south
,
and
guarded
the
passage
communicating
with
the
leads
.
<EOS>
It
was
grated
and
crested
with
spikes
,
like
that
he
had
just
burst
open
,
and
thinking
it
a
needless
waste
of
time
to
force
it
,
he
broke
off
one
of
the
spikes
,
which
he
carried
with
him
for
further
purposes
,
and
then
climbed
over
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
short
flight
of
steps
brought
him
to
a
dark
passage
,
into
which
he
plunged
.
<EOS>
Here
he
found
another
strong
door
,
making
the
fifth
he
had
encountered
.
<EOS>
Well
aware
that
the
doors
in
this
passage
were
much
stronger
than
those
in
the
entry
he
had
just
quitted
he
was
neither
surprised
nor
dismayed
to
find
it
fastened
by
a
lock
of
unusual
size
.
<EOS>
After
repeatedly
trying
to
remove
the
plate
,
which
was
so
firmly
screwed
down
that
it
resisted
all
his
efforts
,
and
vainly
attempting
to
pick
it
with
the
spike
and
nail
;
he
,
at
length
,
after
half
an
hour
's
ineffectual
labour
,
wrenched
off
the
box
by
means
of
the
iron
bar
,
and
the
door
,
as
he
laughingly
expressed
it
,
"
became
his
humble
servant
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
this
difficulty
was
only
overcome
to
be
succeeded
by
one
still
greater
.
<EOS>
Hastening
along
the
passage
he
came
to
the
sixth
door
.
<EOS>
For
this
he
was
prepared
;
but
he
was
not
prepared
for
the
almost
insurmountable
obstacles
which
it
presented
.
<EOS>
Running
his
hand
hastily
over
it
,
he
was
startled
to
find
it
one
complicated
mass
of
bolts
and
bars
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
all
the
precautions
previously
taken
were
here
accumulated
.
<EOS>
Any
one
less
courageous
than
himself
would
have
abandoned
the
attempt
from
a
conviction
of
its
utter
hopelessness
;
but
,
though
it
might
for
a
moment
damp
his
ardour
,
it
could
not
deter
him
.
 
<EOS>
Once
again
,
he
passed
his
hand
over
the
surface
and
carefully
noted
all
the
obstacles
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
lock
,
apparently
more
than
a
foot
wide
,
strongly
plated
,
and
girded
to
the
door
with
thick
iron
hoops
.
<EOS>
Below
it
a
prodigiously
large
bolt
was
shot
into
the
socket
,
and
,
in
order
to
keep
it
there
,
was
fastened
by
a
hasp
,
and
further
protected
by
an
immense
padlock
.
<EOS>
Besides
this
,
the
door
was
crossed
and
recrossed
by
iron
bars
,
clenched
by
broad
-
headed
nails
.
<EOS>
An
iron
fillet
secured
the
socket
of
the
bolt
and
the
box
of
the
lock
to
the
main
post
of
the
doorway
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
disheartened
by
this
survey
,
Jack
set
to
work
upon
the
lock
,
which
he
attacked
with
all
his
implements;--now
attempting
to
pick
it
with
the
nail;--now
to
wrench
it
off
with
the
bar
:
but
all
without
effect
.
<EOS>
He
not
only
failed
in
making
any
impression
,
but
seemed
to
increase
the
difficulties
,
for
after
an
hour
's
toil
he
had
broken
the
nail
and
slightly
bent
the
iron
bar
.
 
<EOS>
Completely
overcome
by
fatigue
,
with
strained
muscles
,
and
bruised
hands
;
streaming
with
perspiration
,
and
with
lips
so
parched
that
he
would
gladly
have
parted
with
a
treasure
if
he
had
possessed
it
for
a
draught
of
water
;
he
sank
against
the
wall
,
and
while
in
this
state
was
seized
with
,
a
sudden
and
strange
alarm
.
<EOS>
He
fancied
that
the
turnkeys
had
discovered
his
flight
and
were
in
pursuit
of
him,--that
<EOS>
they
had
climbed
up
the
chimney,--entered
<EOS>
the
Red
Room,--tracked
him
from
door
to
door
,
and
were
now
only
detained
by
the
gate
which
he
had
left
unbroken
in
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
He
even
thought
he
could
detect
the
voice
of
Jonathan
,
urging
and
directing
them
.
 
<EOS>
So
strongly
was
he
impressed
with
this
idea
,
that
grasping
the
iron
bar
with
both
hands
,
he
dashed
it
furiously
against
the
door
,
making
the
passage
echo
with
the
blows
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
his
fears
vanished
,
and
hearing
nothing
,
he
grew
calmer
.
<EOS>
His
spirits
revived
,
and
encouraging
himself
with
the
idea
that
the
present
impediment
,
though
the
greatest
,
was
the
last
,
he
set
himself
seriously
to
consider
how
it
might
best
be
overcome
.
 
<EOS>
On
reflection
,
it
occurred
to
him
that
he
might
,
perhaps
,
be
able
to
loosen
the
iron
fillet
;
a
notion
no
sooner
conceived
than
executed
.
<EOS>
With
incredible
labour
,
and
by
the
aid
of
both
spike
and
nail
,
he
succeeded
in
getting
the
point
of
the
bar
beneath
the
fillet
.
<EOS>
Exerting
all
his
energies
,
and
using
the
bar
as
a
lever
,
he
forced
off
the
iron
band
,
which
was
full
seven
feet
high
,
seven
inches
wide
,
and
two
thick
,
and
which
brought
with
it
in
its
fall
the
box
of
the
lock
and
the
socket
of
the
bolt
,
leaving
no
further
hinderance
.
 
<EOS>
Overjoyed
beyond
measure
at
having
vanquished
this
apparently
-
insurmountable
obstacle
,
Jack
darted
through
the
door
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XX
.
 
<EOS>
The
Leads
.
  
<EOS>
Ascending
a
short
flight
of
steps
,
Jack
found
at
the
summit
a
door
,
which
being
bolted
in
the
inside
he
speedily
opened
.
 
<EOS>
The
fresh
air
,
which
blew
in
his
face
,
greatly
revived
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
now
reached
what
was
called
the
Lower
Leads,--a
flat
,
covering
a
part
of
the
prison
contiguous
to
the
gateway
,
and
surrounded
on
all
sides
by
walls
about
fourteen
feet
high
.
<EOS>
On
the
north
stood
the
battlements
of
one
of
the
towers
of
the
gate
.
<EOS>
On
this
side
a
flight
of
wooden
steps
,
protected
by
a
hand
-
rail
,
led
to
a
door
opening
upon
the
summit
of
the
prison
.
<EOS>
This
door
was
crested
with
spikes
,
and
guarded
on
the
right
by
a
bristling
semicircle
of
spikes
.
<EOS>
Hastily
ascending
these
steps
,
Jack
found
the
door
,
as
he
anticipated
,
locked
.
<EOS>
He
could
have
easily
forced
it
,
but
preferred
a
more
expeditious
mode
of
reaching
the
roof
which
suggested
itself
to
him
.
<EOS>
Mounting
the
door
he
had
last
opened
,
he
placed
his
hands
on
the
wall
above
,
and
quickly
drew
himself
up
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
he
got
on
the
roof
of
the
prison
,
St.
Sepulchre
's
clock
struck
eight
.
<EOS>
It
was
instantly
answered
by
the
deep
note
of
St.
Paul
's
;
and
the
concert
was
prolonged
by
other
neighbouring
churches
.
<EOS>
Jack
had
thus
been
six
hours
in
accomplishing
his
arduous
task
.
 
<EOS>
Though
nearly
dark
,
there
was
still
light
enough
left
to
enable
him
to
discern
surrounding
objects
.
<EOS>
Through
the
gloom
he
distinctly
perceived
the
dome
of
St.
Paul
's
,
hanging
like
a
black
cloud
in
the
air
;
and
nearer
to
him
he
remarked
the
golden
ball
on
the
summit
of
the
College
of
Physicians
,
compared
by
Garth
to
a
"
gilded
pill
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Other
towers
and
spires
--
St
.
<EOS>
Martin
's
on
Ludgate
-
hill
,
and
Christchurch
in
Newgate
Street
,
were
also
distinguishable
.
<EOS>
As
he
gazed
down
into
the
courts
of
the
prison
,
he
could
not
help
shuddering
,
lest
a
false
step
might
precipitate
him
below
.
 
<EOS>
To
prevent
the
recurrence
of
any
such
escape
as
that
just
described
,
it
was
deemed
expedient
,
in
more
recent
times
,
to
keep
a
watchman
at
the
top
of
Newgate
.
<EOS>
Not
many
years
ago
,
two
men
,
employed
on
this
duty
,
quarrelled
during
the
night
,
and
in
the
morning
their
bodies
were
found
stretched
upon
the
pavement
of
the
yard
beneath
.
 
<EOS>
Proceeding
along
the
wall
,
Jack
reached
the
southern
tower
,
over
the
battlements
of
which
he
clambered
,
and
crossing
it
,
dropped
upon
the
roof
of
the
gate
.
<EOS>
He
then
scaled
the
northern
tower
,
and
made
his
way
to
the
summit
of
that
part
of
the
prison
which
fronted
Giltspur
Street
.
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
extremity
of
the
building
,
he
found
that
it
overlooked
the
flat
-
roof
of
a
house
which
,
as
far
as
he
could
judge
in
the
darkness
,
lay
at
a
depth
of
about
twenty
feet
below
.
 
<EOS>
Not
choosing
to
hazard
so
great
<EOS>
a
fall
,
Jack
turned
to
examine
the
building
,
to
see
whether
any
more
favourable
point
of
descent
presented
itself
,
but
could
discover
nothing
but
steep
walls
,
without
a
single
available
projection
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
around
,
he
beheld
an
incessant
stream
of
passengers
hurrying
on
below
.
<EOS>
Lights
glimmered
in
the
windows
of
the
different
houses
;
and
a
lamp
-
lighter
was
running
from
post
to
post
on
his
way
to
Snow
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
it
impossible
to
descend
on
any
side
,
without
incurring
serious
risk
,
Jack
resolved
to
return
for
his
blanket
,
by
the
help
of
which
he
felt
certain
of
accomplishing
a
safe
landing
on
the
roof
of
the
house
in
Giltspur
Street
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
began
to
retrace
his
steps
,
and
pursuing
the
course
he
had
recently
taken
,
scaling
the
two
towers
,
and
passing
along
the
wall
of
the
prison
,
he
descended
by
means
of
the
door
upon
the
Lower
Leads
.
<EOS>
Before
he
re
-
entered
the
prison
,
he
hesitated
from
a
doubt
whether
he
was
not
fearfully
increasing
his
risk
of
capture
;
but
,
convinced
that
he
had
no
other
alternative
,
he
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
During
all
this
time
,
he
had
never
quitted
the
iron
bar
,
and
he
now
grasped
it
with
the
firm
determination
of
selling
his
life
dearly
,
if
he
met
with
any
opposition
.
<EOS>
A
few
seconds
sufficed
to
clear
the
passage
,
through
which
it
had
previously
cost
him
more
than
two
hours
to
force
his
way
.
<EOS>
The
floor
was
strewn
with
screws
,
nails
,
fragments
of
wood
and
stone
,
and
across
the
passage
lay
the
heavy
iron
fillet
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
disturb
any
of
this
litter
,
but
left
it
as
a
mark
of
his
prowess
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
now
at
the
entrance
of
the
chapel
,
and
striking
the
door
over
which
he
had
previously
climbed
a
violent
blow
with
the
bar
,
it
flew
open
.
<EOS>
To
vault
over
the
pews
was
the
work
of
a
moment
;
and
having
gained
the
entry
leading
to
the
Red
Room
he
passed
through
the
first
door
;
his
progress
being
only
impeded
by
the
pile
of
broken
stones
,
which
he
himself
had
raised
.
 
<EOS>
Listening
at
one
of
the
doors
leading
to
the
Master
Debtors
'
side
,
he
heard
a
loud
voice
chanting
a
Bacchanalian
melody
,
and
the
boisterous
laughter
that
accompanied
the
song
,
convinced
him
that
no
suspicion
was
entertained
in
this
quarter
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
Red
Room
,
he
crept
through
the
hole
in
the
wall
,
descended
the
chimney
,
and
arrived
once
more
in
his
old
place
of
captivity
.
 
<EOS>
How
different
were
his
present
feelings
compared
with
those
he
had
experienced
on
quitting
it
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Then
_
,
though
full
of
confidence
,
he
half
doubted
his
power
of
accomplishing
his
designs
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Now
_
,
he
_
had
_
achieved
them
,
and
felt
assured
of
success
.
<EOS>
The
vast
heap
of
rubbish
on
the
floor
had
been
so
materially
increased
by
the
bricks
and
plaster
thrown
down
in
his
attack
upon
the
wall
of
the
Red
Room
,
that
it
was
with
some
difficulty
he
could
find
the
blanket
which
was
almost
buried
beneath
the
pile
.
<EOS>
He
next
searched
for
his
stockings
and
shoes
,
and
when
found
,
put
them
on
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
employed
,
his
nerves
underwent
a
severe
shock
.
<EOS>
A
few
bricks
,
dislodged
probably
by
his
last
descent
,
came
clattering
down
the
chimney
,
and
as
it
was
perfectly
dark
,
gave
him
the
notion
that
some
one
was
endeavouring
to
force
an
entrance
into
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
fears
,
like
those
he
had
recently
experienced
,
speedily
vanished
,
and
he
prepared
to
return
to
the
roof
,
congratulating
himself
that
owing
to
the
opportune
falling
of
the
bricks
,
he
had
in
all
probability
escaped
serious
injury
.
 
<EOS>
Throwing
the
blanket
over
his
left
arm
and
shouldering
the
iron
bar
,
he
again
clambered
up
the
chimney
;
regained
the
Red
Room
;
hurried
along
the
first
passage
;
crossed
the
Chapel
;
threaded
the
entry
to
the
Lower
Leads
;
and
,
in
less
than
ten
minutes
after
quitting
the
Castle
,
had
reached
the
northern
extremity
of
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
Previously
to
his
descent
he
had
left
the
nail
and
spike
on
the
wall
,
and
with
these
he
fastened
the
blanket
to
the
stone
coping
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
let
himself
carefully
down
by
it
,
and
having
only
a
few
feet
to
drop
,
alighted
in
safety
.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
fairly
got
out
of
Newgate
for
the
second
time
,
with
a
heart
throbbing
with
exultation
,
he
hastened
to
make
good
his
escape
.
<EOS>
To
his
great
joy
he
found
a
small
garret
-
door
in
the
roof
of
the
opposite
house
open
.
<EOS>
He
entered
it
;
crossed
the
room
,
in
which
there
was
only
a
small
truckle
-
bed
,
over
which
he
stumbled
;
opened
another
door
and
gained
the
stair
-
head
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
about
to
descend
his
chains
slightly
rattled
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
lud
!
<EOS>
what
's
that
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
a
female
voice
,
from
an
adjoining
room
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
the
dog
,
"
replied
the
rough
tones
of
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
Securing
the
chain
in
the
best
way
he
could
,
Jack
then
hurried
down
two
pair
of
stairs
,
and
had
nearly
reached
the
lobby
,
when
a
door
suddenly
opened
,
and
two
persons
appeared
,
one
of
whom
held
a
light
.
<EOS>
Retreating
as
quickly
as
he
could
,
Jack
opened
the
first
door
he
came
to
,
entered
a
room
,
and
searching
in
the
dark
for
some
place
of
concealment
,
fortunately
discovered
a
skreen
,
behind
which
he
crept
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXI
.
 
<EOS>
What
befell
Jack
Sheppard
in
the
Turner
's
House
.
  
<EOS>
Jack
was
scarcely
concealed
when
the
door
opened
,
and
the
two
persons
of
whom
he
had
caught
a
glimpse
below
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
What
was
his
astonishment
to
recognise
in
the
few
words
they
uttered
the
voices
of
Kneebone
and
Winifred
!
<EOS>
The
latter
was
apparently
in
great
distress
,
and
the
former
seemed
to
be
using
his
best
efforts
to
relieve
her
anxiety
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
very
fortunate
it
is
,
"
he
observed
,
"
that
I
happened
to
call
upon
Mr.
Bird
,
the
turner
,
to
give
him
an
order
this
evening
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
an
unexpected
pleasure
to
meet
you
and
your
worthy
father
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
cease
these
compliments
,
"
returned
Winifred
,
"
and
,
if
you
have
any
communication
to
make
,
do
not
delay
it
.
<EOS>
You
told
me
just
now
that
you
wished
to
speak
a
few
words
to
me
in
private
,
concerning
Thames
Darrell
,
and
for
that
purpose
I
have
left
my
father
below
with
Mr.
Bird
and
have
come
hither
.
<EOS>
What
have
you
got
to
say
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Too
much
,
"
replied
Kneebone
,
shaking
his
head
;
"
sadly
too
much
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
needlessly
alarm
me
<EOS>
,
I
beseech
you
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
Whatever
your
intelligence
may
be
I
will
strive
to
bear
it
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
awaken
my
apprehension
,
unless
you
have
good
cause
for
<EOS>
so
doing.--What
<EOS>
do
you
know
of
Thames?--Where
<EOS>
is
he
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
agitate
yourself
,
dearest
girl
,
"
rejoined
the
woollen
-
draper
;
"
or
I
shall
never
be
able
to
commence
my
relation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
calm
--
perfectly
calm
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
make
no
further
mystery
;
but
tell
me
all
without
reserve
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Since
you
require
it
,
I
must
obey
,
"
replied
Kneebone
;
"
but
prepare
yourself
for
a
terrible
shock
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
For
mercy
's
sake
,
go
on
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
all
hazards
<EOS>
then
then
you
shall
know
the
truth
,
"
replied
the
woollen
-
draper
,
in
a
tone
of
affected
<EOS>
solicitude,--"but
<EOS>
are
you
really
prepared
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
--
quite
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
suspense
is
worse
than
torture
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
almost
afraid
to
utter
it
,
"
said
Kneebone
;
"
but
Thames
Darrell
is
murdered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Murdered
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
Basely
and
inhumanly
murdered
,
by
Jack
Sheppard
and
Blueskin
,
"
continued
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
no
--
no
<EOS>
--
no
,
"
cried
Winifred
,
"
<EOS>
I
can
not
believe
it
.
<EOS>
You
must
be
misinformed
,
Mr.
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
Jack
may
be
capable
of
much
that
is
wicked
,
but
he
would
never
lift
his
hand
against
his
friend,--of
that
I
am
assured
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Generous
girl
!
"
cried
Jack
from
behind
the
skreen
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
proofs
to
the
contrary
,
"
replied
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
The
murder
was
committed
after
the
robbery
of
my
house
by
Sheppard
and
his
accomplices
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
choose
to
mention
my
knowledge
of
this
fact
to
your
worthy
father
;
but
you
may
rely
on
its
correctness
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
right
not
to
mention
it
to
him
,
"
rejoined
Winifred
,
"
for
he
is
in
such
a
state
of
distress
at
the
mysterious
disappearance
of
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
<EOS>
that
I
fear
any
further
anxiety
might
prove
fatal
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
know
not
--
for
the
object
of
his
visit
here
to
-
night
was
to
serve
Jack
,
who
,
if
your
statement
is
correct
,
which
I
can
not
however
for
a
moment
believe
,
does
not
deserve
his
assistance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
rest
assured
<EOS>
he
does
not
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
,
emphatically
,
"
but
I
am
at
a
loss
to
understand
in
what
way
your
father
proposes
to
assist
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bird
,
the
turner
,
who
is
an
old
friend
of
our
's
,
has
some
acquaintance
with
the
turnkeys
of
Newgate
,
"
replied
Winifred
,
"
and
by
his
means
my
father
hoped
to
convey
some
implements
to
Jack
,
by
which
he
might
effect
another
escape
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
,
"
remarked
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
This
must
be
prevented
,
"
he
added
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
grant
<EOS>
you
may
have
been
wrongly
informed
with
respect
to
Thames
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Winifred
;
"
but
,
I
beseech
you
,
on
no
account
to
mention
what
you
have
told
me
to
my
poor
father
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
in
a
state
of
mind
to
bear
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Rely
on
me
,
"
rejoined
Kneebone
.
<EOS>
"
One
word
before
we
part
,
adorable
girl
--
only
one
,
"
he
continued
,
detaining
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
venture
to
renew
my
suit
while
Thames
lived
,
because
I
well
knew
your
affections
were
fixed
upon
him
.
<EOS>
But
now
that
this
bar
is
removed
,
I
trust
I
may
,
without
impropriety
,
urge
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
,
"
said
Winifred
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
this
a
season
to
speak
on
such
a
subject
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
rejoined
the
woollen
-
draper
;
"
but
the
uncontrollable
violence
of
my
passion
must
plead
my
excuse
.
<EOS>
My
whole
life
shall
be
devoted
to
you
,
beloved
girl
.
<EOS>
And
when
you
reflect
how
much
at
heart
your
poor
mother
,
whose
loss
we
must
ever
deplore
,
had
our
union
,
you
will
,
I
am
persuaded
,
no
longer
refuse
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
exclaimed
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
make
me
the
happiest
of
mankind
,
"
cried
the
woollen
-
draper
,
falling
on
his
knees
,
and
seizing
her
hand
,
which
he
devoured
with
kisses
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
"
cried
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
I
disbelieve
the
whole
story
you
have
told
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Kneebone
,
with
increasing
fervour
<EOS>
,
"
it
is
true
--
as
true
as
my
affection
for
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
doubt
it
,
"
retorted
Winifred
,
scornfully
;
"
because
I
attach
credit
neither
to
one
nor
the
other
.
<EOS>
If
Thames
_
is
_
murdered
,
you
are
his
assassin
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
woollen
-
draper
made
no
answer
,
but
hastily
starting
up
,
bolted
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
cried
Winifred
in
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
than
to
obtain
a
favourable
answer
to
my
suit
,
"
replied
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
the
way
to
obtain
it
,
"
said
Winifred
,
endeavouring
to
reach
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
go
,
adorable
girl
,
"
cried
Kneebone
,
catching
her
in
his
arms
,
"
till
you
have
answered
me
.
<EOS>
You
must
--
you
shall
be
mine
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Release
me
instantly
,
or
I
will
call
my
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
so
,
"
replied
Kneebone
;
"
but
remember
the
door
is
locked
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Monster
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
Help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
call
in
vain
,
"
returned
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so
,
"
replied
Jack
,
throwing
down
the
skreen
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Release
her
instantly
,
villain
!
"
 
<EOS>
Both
Winifred
and
her
suitor
started
at
this
sudden
apparition
.
<EOS>
Jack
,
whose
clothes
were
covered
with
dust
,
and
whose
face
was
deathly
pale
from
his
recent
exertion
,
looked
more
like
a
phantom
than
a
living
person
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
devil
's
name
,
is
that
you
,
Jack
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
uttered
a
wilful
and
deliberate
falsehood
in
asserting
that
I
have
murdered
Thames
,
for
whom
you
well
know
I
would
lay
down
my
life
.
<EOS>
Retract
your
words
instantly
,
or
take
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
should
I
retract
,
villain
?
"
cried
the
woollen
-
draper
,
who
at
the
sound
of
Jack
's
voice
had
regained
his
confidence
.
<EOS>
"
To
the
best
of
my
belief
,
Thames
Darrell
has
been
murdered
by
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
lie
!
"
exclaimed
Jack
in
a
terrible
tone
.
<EOS>
And
before
Kneebone
could
draw
his
sword
,
he
felled
him
to
the
ground
with
the
iron
bar
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
killed
him
,
"
cried
Winifred
in
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
answered
Jack
,
approaching
her
,
"
though
,
if
I
had
done
so
,
he
would
have
merited
his
fate
.
<EOS>
You
do
not
believe
his
statement
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
believe
you
capable
of
so
foul
a
deed
.
<EOS>
But
oh
!
by
what
wonderful
chance
have
you
come
hither
so
seasonably
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
escaped
from
Newgate
,
"
replied
Jack
;
"
and
am
more
than
repaid
for
the
severe
toil
I
have
undergone
,
in
being
able
to
save
you
.
<EOS>
But
tell
me
,
"
he
added
with
much
anxiety
,
"
has
nothing
been
heard
of
Thames
since
the
night
of
my
former
escape
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
whatever
,
"
answered
Winifred
.
"
<EOS>
He
left
Dollis
Hill
at
ten
o'clock
on
that
night
,
and
has
not
since
returned
.
<EOS>
My
father
has
made
every
possible
inquiry
,
and
offered
large
rewards
;
but
has
not
been
able
to
discover
the
slightest
trace
of
him
.
<EOS>
His
suspicions
at
first
fell
upon
you
.
<EOS>
But
he
has
since
acquitted
you
of
any
share
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Heaven
!
"
exclaimed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
indefatigable
in
his
search
,
<EOS>
"
continued
Winifred
,
"
and
has
even
journeyed
to
Manchester
.
<EOS>
But
though
he
visited
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
's
seat
,
Ashton
Hall
,
he
could
gain
no
tidings
of
him
,
or
of
his
uncle
,
Sir
Rowland
,
who
,
it
seems
,
has
left
the
country
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Never
to
return
,
"
remarked
Jack
,
gloomily
.
"
<EOS>
Before
to
-
morrow
morning
I
will
ascertain
what
has
become
of
Thames
,
or
perish
in
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
And
now
tell
me
what
has
happened
to
my
poor
mother
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ever
since
your
last
capture
,
and
Thames
's
mysterious
disappearance
,
she
has
been
dreadfully
ill
,
"
replied
Winifred
;
"
so
ill
,
that
each
day
was
expected
to
be
her
last
.
<EOS>
She
has
also
been
afflicted
with
occasional
returns
of
her
terrible
malady
.
<EOS>
On
Tuesday
night
,
she
was
rather
better
,
and
I
had
left
her
for
a
short
time
,
as
I
thought
,
asleep
on
the
sofa
in
the
little
parlour
of
which
she
is
<EOS>
so
fond--
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
exclaimed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
my
return
,
I
found
the
window
open
,
and
the
room
vacant
.
<EOS>
She
was
gone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
discover
any
trace
of
footsteps
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jack
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
were
some
marks
near
the
window
;
but
whether
recently
made
or
not
could
not
be
ascertained
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
God
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
in
a
tone
of
the
bitterest
anguish
.
<EOS>
"
My
worst
fears
are
realized
.
<EOS>
She
is
in
Wild
's
power
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
ought
to
add
,
"
continued
Winifred
,
"
that
one
of
her
shoes
was
picked
up
in
the
garden
,
and
that
prints
of
her
feet
were
discovered
along
the
soft
mould
;
whether
made
in
flying
from
any
one
,
or
from
rushing
forth
in
distracted
terror
,
it
is
impossible
to
say
.
<EOS>
My
father
thought
the
latter
.
<EOS>
He
has
had
the
whole
country
searched
;
but
hitherto
without
success
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
_
where
_
she
will
be
found
,
and
_
how
_
,
"
rejoined
Jack
with
a
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
something
further
to
tell
you
,
"
pursued
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shortly
after
your
last
visit
to
Dollis
Hill
,
my
father
was
one
evening
waylaid
by
a
man
,
who
informed
him
that
he
had
something
to
communicate
respecting
Thames
,
and
had
a
large
sum
of
money
,
and
some
important
documents
to
deliver
to
him
,
which
would
be
given
up
,
provided
he
would
undertake
to
procure
your
liberation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
Blueskin
,
"
observed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
my
father
thought
,
"
replied
Winifred
;
"
and
he
therefore
instantly
fired
upon
him
.
<EOS>
But
though
the
shot
took
effect
,
as
was
evident
from
the
stains
on
the
ground
,
the
villain
escaped
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
father
did
right
,
"
replied
Jack
,
with
some
bitterness
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
he
had
not
fired
that
shot
,
he
might
have
saved
Thames
,
and
possessed
himself
of
papers
which
would
have
established
his
birth
,
and
his
right
to
the
estates
of
the
Trenchard
family
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Would
you
have
had
him
spare
my
mother
's
murderer
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ho
,
no
,
"
replied
Jack
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
--
but
it
is
only
part
of
the
chain
of
ill
-
luck
that
seems
wound
around
me
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
Winifred
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
hastily
related
the
occurrences
in
Jonathan
Wild
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
account
of
the
discovery
of
Sir
Rowland
's
murder
filled
Winifred
with
alarm
;
but
when
she
learnt
what
had
befallen
Thames
--
how
he
had
been
stricken
down
by
the
thief
-
taker
's
bludgeon
,
and
left
for
dead
,
she
uttered
a
piercing
scream
,
fainted
,
and
would
have
fallen
,
if
Jack
had
not
caught
her
in
his
arms
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
had
well
-
nigh
fallen
too
.
<EOS>
The
idea
that
he
held
in
his
arms
the
girl
whom
he
had
once
so
passionately
loved
,
and
for
whom
he
still
retained
an
ardent
but
hopeless
attachment
,
almost
overcame
him
.
<EOS>
Gazing
at
her
with
eyes
blinded
with
tears
,
he
imprinted
one
brotherly
kiss
upon
her
lips
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
--
and
the
last
!
 
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
the
handle
of
the
door
was
tried
,
and
the
voice
of
Mr.
Wood
was
heard
without
,
angrily
demanding
admittance
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
heard
a
scream
.
<EOS>
Why
is
the
door
fastened
?
<EOS>
Open
it
directly
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
alone
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Jack
,
mimicking
the
voice
of
Kneebone
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
for
?
"
demanded
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Open
the
door
,
I
say
,
or
I
'll
burst
it
open
.
"
 
<EOS>
Carefully
depositing
Winifred
on
a
sofa
,
Jack
then
extinguished
the
light
,
and
,
as
he
unfastened
the
door
,
crept
behind
it
.
<EOS>
In
rushed
Mr.
Wood
,
with
a
candle
in
his
hand
,
which
Jack
instantly
blew
out
,
and
darted
down
stairs
.
<EOS>
He
upset
some
one
--
probably
Mr.
Bird,--who
was
rushing
up
stairs
,
alarmed
by
Mr.
Wood
's
cries
:
but
,
regardless
of
this
,
he
darted
along
a
passage
,
gained
the
shop
,
and
passed
through
an
open
door
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
he
was
once
more
free
,
having
effected
one
of
the
most
wonderful
escapes
ever
planned
or
accomplished
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXII
.
 
<EOS>
Fast
and
Loose
.
  
<EOS>
About
seven
o'clock
on
the
same
night
,
Jonathan
Wild
's
two
janizaries
,
who
had
been
for
some
time
in
attendance
in
the
hall
of
his
dwelling
at
the
Old
Bailey
,
were
summoned
to
the
audience
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
A
long
and
secret
conference
then
took
place
between
the
thief
-
taker
and
his
myrmidons
,
after
which
they
were
severally
dismissed
.
 
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
Jonathan
lighted
a
lamp
,
and
,
opening
the
trap
-
door
,
descended
the
secret
stairs
.
<EOS>
Taking
the
opposite
course
from
that
which
he
had
hitherto
pursued
when
it
has
been
necessary
to
attend
him
in
his
visits
to
the
lower
part
of
his
premises
,
he
struck
into
a
narrow
passage
on
the
right
,
which
he
tracked
till
he
came
to
a
small
door
,
like
the
approach
to
a
vault
.
<EOS>
Unlocking
it
,
he
entered
the
chamber
,
which
by
no
means
belied
its
external
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
On
a
pallet
in
one
corner
lay
a
pale
emaciated
female
.
<EOS>
Holding
the
lamp
over
her
rigid
but
beautiful
features
,
Jonathan
,
with
some
anxiety
,
placed
his
hand
upon
her
breast
to
ascertain
whether
the
heart
still
beat
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
with
his
scrutiny
,
he
produced
a
pocket
-
flask
,
and
taking
off
the
silver
cup
with
which
it
was
mounted
,
filled
it
with
the
contents
of
the
flask
,
and
then
seizing
the
thin
arm
of
the
sleeper
,
rudely
shook
it
.
<EOS>
Opening
her
large
black
eyes
,
she
fixed
them
upon
him
for
a
moment
with
a
mixture
of
terror
and
loathing
,
and
then
averted
her
gaze
.
 
<EOS>
"
Drink
this
,
"
cried
Jonathan
,
handing
her
the
cup
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
feel
better
after
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mechanically
raising
the
potion
to
her
lips
,
the
poor
creature
swallowed
it
without
hesitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
poison
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
with
a
brutal
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
going
to
get
rid
of
you
just
yet
.
<EOS>
It
's
gin
--
a
liquor
you
used
to
like
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
the
benefit
of
it
by
and
by
.
<EOS>
You
've
a
good
deal
to
go
through
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
"
are
you
come
to
renew
your
terrible
proposals
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
come
to
execute
my
threats
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
-
night
you
shall
be
my
wedded
wife
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
die
first
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
die
_
afterwards
_
as
soon
as
you
please
,
"
retorted
Jonathan
;
"
but
live
till
then
<EOS>
you
_
shall
<EOS>
_
.
<EOS>
I
've
sent
for
the
priest
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
vainly
trying
to
discover
a
gleam
of
compassion
in
the
thief
-
taker
's
inexorable
countenance,--"Mercy
!
<EOS>
mercy
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
rejoined
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
You
should
be
glad
to
be
made
an
honest
woman
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
let
me
die
,
"
groaned
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
many
days,--perhaps
,
not
many
hours
to
live
.
<EOS>
But
kill
me
rather
than
commit
this
outrage
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
would
n't
answer
my
purpose
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
savagely
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
carry
you
off
from
old
Wood
to
kill
you
,
but
to
we
d
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
motive
can
you
have
for
so
vile
a
deed
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
motive
well
enough
,
"
answered
Jonathan
.
"
<EOS>
However
,
I
'll
refresh
your
memory
.
<EOS>
I
once
might
have
married
you
for
your
<EOS>
beauty,--now
<EOS>
I
marry
you
for
your
wealth
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
wealth
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
heiress
to
the
Trenchard
property
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
"
one
of
the
largest
estates
in
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Not
while
Thames
Darrell
and
Sir
Rowland
live
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
Rowland
is
dead
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
gloomily
.
"
<EOS>
Thames
Darrell
only
waits
my
mandate
to
follow
him
.
<EOS>
Before
our
marriage
there
will
be
no
life
between
you
and
the
estates
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
"
cried
Jonathan
,
stooping
down
and
taking
hold
of
a
ring
in
the
floor
,
with
which
by
a
great
effort
he
raised
up
a
flag
.
<EOS>
"
In
this
pit
,
"
he
added
,
pointing
to
the
chasm
below
,
"
your
brother
is
buried
.
<EOS>
Here
your
nephew
will
speedily
be
thrown
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Horrible
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
shuddering
violently
.
"
<EOS>
But
your
dreadful
projects
will
recoil
on
your
own
head
.
<EOS>
Heaven
will
not
permit
the
continuance
of
such
wickedness
as
you
practise
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
my
chance
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
with
a
sinister
smile
.
<EOS>
"
My
schemes
have
succeeded
tolerably
well
hitherto
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
day
of
retribution
will
assuredly
arrive
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
Till
then
,
I
shall
remain
content
,
"
returned
Wild
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
attend
to
what
I
'm
about
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
Years
ago
,
when
you
were
a
girl
and
in
the
bloom
of
your
beauty
,
I
loved
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Loved
me
!
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
You
_
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
loved
you
,
"
continued
Jonathan
,
"
and
struck
by
your
appearance
,
which
seemed
above
your
station
,
inquired
your
history
,
and
found
you
had
been
stolen
by
a
gipsy
in
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
I
proceeded
to
Manchester
,
to
investigate
the
matter
further
,
and
when
there
ascertained
,
beyond
a
doubt
,
that
you
were
the
eldest
daughter
of
Sir
Montacute
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
This
discovery
made
,
I
hastened
back
to
London
to
offer
you
my
hand
,
but
found
you
had
married
in
the
mean
time
a
smock
-
faced
,
smooth
-
tongued
carpenter
named
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
The
important
secret
remained
locked
in
my
breast
,
but
I
resolved
to
be
avenged
.
<EOS>
I
swore
I
would
bring
your
husband
to
the
gallows,--would
plunge
you
in
such
want
,
<EOS>
such
distress
,
that
you
should
have
no
alternative
but
the
last
frightful
resource
of
misery,--and
<EOS>
I
also
swore
,
that
if
you
had
a
son
he
should
share
the
same
fate
as
his
father
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
terribly
you
have
kept
your
vow
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
now
coming
to
the
point
which
most
concerns
you
.
<EOS>
Consent
to
become
my
wife
,
and
do
not
compel
me
to
have
recourse
to
violence
to
effect
my
purpose
,
and
I
will
spare
your
son
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sheppard
looked
fixedly
at
him
,
as
if
she
would
penetrate
the
gloomy
depth
of
his
soul
.
 
<EOS>
"
Swear
that
you
will
do
this
,
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
swear
it
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
readily
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
is
an
oath
to
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
widow
,
distrustfully
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
hesitate
to
break
it
,
if
it
suits
your
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
have
suffered
too
much
from
your
treachery
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
trust
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
sternly
.
<EOS>
"
Recollect
you
are
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
Jack
's
life
hangs
on
your
determination
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
do
?
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
in
a
voice
of
agony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Save
him
,
"
replied
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
You
_
can
_
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Bring
him
<EOS>
here,--let
<EOS>
me
see
him
--
let
me
embrace
him
--
let
me
be
assured
that
he
is
safe
,
and
I
am
yours
.
<EOS>
I
swear
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
"
exclaimed
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
hesitate
--
you
are
deceiving
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
no
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
with
affected
sincerity
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
see
him
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Delay
the
marriage
till
then
.
<EOS>
I
will
never
consent
till
I
see
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yon
ask
impossibilities
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
sullenly
.
<EOS>
"
All
is
prepared
.
<EOS>
The
marriage
cannot
--
shall
not
be
delayed
.
<EOS>
Yon
must
be
mine
to
-
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Force
shall
not
make
me
yours
till
Jack
is
free
,
"
replied
the
widow
,
resolutely
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
hour
hence
,
I
shall
return
with
the
priest
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
striding
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
with
a
glance
of
malignant
exultation
,
he
quitted
the
vault
,
and
locked
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
hour
hence
,
I
shall
be
beyond
your
malice
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
sinking
backwards
upon
the
pallet
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXIII
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
Meeting
between
Jack
Sheppard
and
his
Mother
.
  
<EOS>
After
escaping
from
the
turner
's
house
,
Jack
Sheppard
skirted
St.
Sepulchre
's
church
,
and
hurrying
down
Snow
Hill
,
darted
into
the
first
turning
on
the
left
.
<EOS>
Traversing
Angel
Court
,
and
Green
Arbour
Court,--celebrated
as
one
of
Goldsmith
's
retreats,--he
speedily
reached
Seacoal
Lane
,
and
pursuing
the
same
course
,
which
he
and
Thames
had
formerly
taken
,
arrived
at
the
yard
at
the
back
of
Jonathan
's
habitation
.
 
<EOS>
A
door
,
it
may
be
remembered
,
opened
from
Wild
's
dwelling
into
this
yard
.
<EOS>
Before
he
forced
an
entrance
,
Jack
tried
it
,
and
,
to
his
great
surprise
and
delight
,
found
it
unfastened
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
house
,
he
found
himself
in
a
narrow
passage
leading
to
the
back
stairs
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
taken
many
steps
when
he
perceived
Quilt
Arnold
in
the
upper
gallery
,
with
a
lamp
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Hearing
a
noise
below
,
Quilt
called
out
,
supposing
it
occasioned
by
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
Jack
hastily
retreated
,
and
taking
the
first
means
of
concealment
that
occurred
to
him
,
descended
the
cellar
steps
.
 
<EOS>
Quilt
,
meanwhile
,
came
down
,
examined
the
door
,
and
finding
it
unfastened
,
locked
it
with
a
bitter
imprecation
on
his
brother
-
janizary
's
carelessness
.
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
followed
the
course
which
Jack
had
just
taken
.
<EOS>
As
he
crossed
the
cellar
,
he
passed
so
near
to
Jack
who
had
concealed
himself
behind
a
piece
of
furniture
that
he
almost
touched
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
Jack
's
intention
to
have
knocked
him
down
with
the
iron
bar
;
but
he
was
so
struck
with
the
janizary
's
looks
,
that
he
determined
to
spare
him
till
he
had
ascertained
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
suffered
him
to
pass
on
.
 
<EOS>
Quilt
's
manner
,
indeed
,
was
that
of
a
man
endeavouring
to
muster
up
sufficient
resolution
for
the
commission
of
some
desperate
crime
.
<EOS>
He
halted,--looked
fearfully
around,--stopped
again
,
and
exclaimed
aloud
,
"
I
do
n't
like
the
job
;
and
yet
it
must
be
done
,
or
Mr.
Wild
will
hang
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
appeared
to
pluck
up
his
courage
,
and
stepped
forward
more
boldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
dreadful
deed
is
about
to
be
committed
,
which
I
may
perhaps
prevent
,
"
muttered
Jack
to
himself
.
"
<EOS>
Heaven
grant
<EOS>
I
may
not
be
too
late
!
"
 
<EOS>
Followed
by
Jack
Sheppard
,
who
kept
sufficiently
near
him
to
watch
his
proceedings
,
and
yet
not
expose
himself
,
Quilt
unlocked
one
or
two
doors
which
he
left
open
,
and
after
winding
his
way
along
a
gloomy
passage
,
arrived
at
the
door
of
a
vault
.
<EOS>
Here
he
set
down
the
lamp
,
and
took
out
a
key
,
and
as
he
did
so
the
expression
of
his
countenance
was
so
atrocious
,
that
Jack
felt
assured
he
was
not
wrong
in
his
suspicions
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
door
was
unlocked
,
and
drawing
his
sword
,
Quilt
entered
the
cell
.
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
an
exclamation
was
heard
in
the
voice
of
Thames
.
<EOS>
Darting
forward
at
this
sound
,
Jack
threw
open
the
door
,
and
beheld
Quilt
kneeling
over
Thames
,
who'se
hands
and
feet
were
bound
with
cords
,
and
about
to
plunge
his
sword
into
his
breast
.
<EOS>
A
blow
from
the
iron
bar
instantly
stretched
the
ruffian
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Jack
then
proceeded
to
liberate
the
captive
from
his
bondage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
!
"
exclaimed
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
Sheppard
,
as
he
untied
the
cords
.
<EOS>
"
I
might
return
the
question
.
<EOS>
Were
it
not
for
your
voice
,
I
do
n't
think
I
should
know
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
greatly
altered
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Captivity
had
,
indeed
,
produced
a
striking
alteration
in
Thames
.
<EOS>
He
looked
like
the
shadow
of
himself
--
thin
,
feeble
,
hollow
-
eyed
--
his
beard
unshorn
--
nothing
could
be
more
miserable
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
been
out
of
this
horrible
dungeon
since
we
last
met
,
"
he
said
;
"
<EOS>
though
how
long
ago
that
is
,
I
scarcely
know
.
<EOS>
Night
and
day
have
been
alike
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Six
weeks
have
elapsed
since
that
fatal
night
,
"
replied
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
that
time
I
have
been
a
close
prisoner
in
Newgate
,
whence
I
have
only
just
escaped
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Six
weeks
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Thames
,
in
a
melancholy
tone
.
<EOS>
"
It
seems
like
six
long
months
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
doubt
it
,
"
returned
Jack
;
<EOS>
"
none
but
those
who
have
experienced
it
can
understand
the
miseries
of
imprisonment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
speak
of
it
,
"
rejoined
Thames
,
with
a
look
of
horror
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
fly
from
this
frightful
place
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
conduct
you
to
the
outlet
,
"
replied
Jack
;
"
but
I
can
not
leave
it
till
I
have
ascertained
whether
my
mother
also
is
a
prisoner
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
answer
that
,
"
replied
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
.
<EOS>
The
monster
,
Wild
,
when
he
visited
my
dungeon
last
night
,
told
me
,
to
add
to
my
misery
,
that
she
occupied
a
cell
near
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Arm
yourself
with
that
ruffian
's
weapons
,
"
replied
Jack
,
"
and
let
us
search
for
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
Thames
complied
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
so
feeble
,
that
it
seemed
scarcely
possible
he
could
offer
any
effectual
resistance
in
case
of
an
attack
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lean
on
me
,
"
said
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
the
light
,
they
then
proceeded
along
the
passage
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
door
in
it
,
and
Jack
therefore
struck
into
another
entry
which
branched
off
to
the
right
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
proceeded
far
when
a
low
moan
was
heard
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
here
,
"
cried
Jack
,
darting
forward
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
steps
brought
him
to
the
door
of
the
vault
in
which
his
mother
was
immured
.
<EOS>
It
was
locked
.
<EOS>
Jack
had
brought
away
the
bunch
of
keys
which
he
had
taken
from
Quilt
Arnold
,
but
,
none
of
them
would
open
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
therefore
obliged
to
use
the
iron
bar
,
which
he
did
with
as
much
caution
as
circumstances
would
permit
.
<EOS>
At
the
first
blow
,
Mrs.
Sheppard
uttered
a
piercing
scream
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wretch
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
"
you
shall
not
force
me
to
your
hateful
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
will
never
we
d
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
weapon
--
a
knife
--
and
if
you
attempt
to
open
the
door
,
will
plunge
it
to
my
heart
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
God
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
paralysed
by
her
cries
.
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
do
?
<EOS>
If
I
persist
,
I
shall
destroy
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Get
hence
,
"
continued
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
with
a
frenzied
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
never
behold
me
alive
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
in
a
broken
voice
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
your
son
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
false
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
Think
not
to
deceive
me
,
monster
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
son
's
voice
too
well
.
<EOS>
He
is
in
Newgate
.
<EOS>
Hence
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
<EOS>
dear
mother
!
"
cried
Jack
,
in
a
voice
,
the
tones
of
which
were
altered
by
his
very
anxiety
to
make
them
distinct
,
"
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
broken
from
prison
,
and
am
come
to
save
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
_
not
_
Jack
's
voice
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
to
be
deceived
.
<EOS>
The
knife
is
at
my
breast
.
<EOS>
Stir
a
foot
,
and
I
strike
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
Heavens
!
"
cried
Jack
,
driven
to
his
wits
'
end
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mother
--
dear
mother
!
<EOS>
Once
again
,
I
beseech
you
to
listen
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
come
to
rescue
you
from
Wild
's
violence
.
<EOS>
I
must
break
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
Hold
your
hand
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
my
fixed
determination
,
villain
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
my
life
is
valuable
to
you
,
or
you
would
not
spare
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
disappoint
you
.
<EOS>
Get
you
gone
.
<EOS>
Your
purposes
are
defeated
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Footsteps
are
approaching
,
"
cried
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
Heed
her
not
.
<EOS>
It
is
but
a
wild
threat
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
how
to
act
,
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
almost
driven
to
desperation
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
plotting
with
your
wicked
associates
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
baffled
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Force
the
door
,
"
said
Thames
,
"
or
you
will
be
too
late
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Better
she
die
by
her
own
hand
,
than
by
that
monster
's
,
"
cried
Jack
,
brandishing
the
bar
.
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
I
come
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
this
,
he
struck
the
door
a
heavy
blow
.
 
<EOS>
He
listened
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
deep
groan
,
and
the
sound
of
a
fall
within
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
killed
her
,
"
exclaimed
Jack
,
dropping
the
bar,--"by
your
advice
,
Thames
.
<EOS>
Oh
God
!
<EOS>
pardon
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
delay
,
"
cried
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
She
may
yet
be
saved
.
<EOS>
I
am
too
weak
to
aid
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
again
seized
the
bar
,
and
,
dashing
it
furiously
against
the
door
,
speedily
burst
it
open
.
 
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
woman
was
stretched
upon
the
floor
,
with
a
bloody
knife
in
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
cried
Jack
,
springing
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
raising
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
you
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
her
son
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
why
would
you
not
listen
to
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
distracted
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
killed
you
,
"
cried
Jack
,
endeavouring
to
staunch
the
effusion
of
blood
from
her
breast
.
<EOS>
"
Forgive
--
forgive
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
to
forgive
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
I
alone
am
to
blame
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
not
carry
you
where
you
can
obtain
help
?
"
cried
Jack
in
a
agony
of
distress
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
:
"
nothing
can
save
me
.
<EOS>
I
die
happy
--
quite
happy
in
beholding
you
.
<EOS>
Do
not
remain
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
may
fall
into
the
hands
of
your
enemy
.
<EOS>
Fly
!
fly
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
think
of
me
,
mother
,
but
of
yourself
,
"
cried
Jack
,
in
an
agony
of
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
always
been
,
far
dearer
to
me
than
myself
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
one
last
request
to
make
.
<EOS>
Let
me
lie
in
Willesden
churchyard
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
--
you
shall
,
"
answered
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
meet
again
<EOS>
ere
long
,
my
son
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
fixing
her
glazing
eyes
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
God
!
<EOS>
she
is
dying
,
"
exclaimed
Jack
in
a
voice
suffocated
by
emotion
.
"
<EOS>
Forgive
me
--
oh
,
forgive
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
you
--
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
she
gasped
.
 
<EOS>
A
cold
shiver
ran
through
her
frame
,
and
her
gentle
spirit
passed
away
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
God
!
<EOS>
that
I
might
die
too
,
"
cried
Jack
,
falling
on
his
knees
beside
her
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
first
violent
outbreak
of
grief
had
in
some
degree
subsided
,
Thames
addressed
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
remain
here
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
render
no
further
service
to
your
poor
mother
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
avenge
her
,
"
cried
Jack
in
a
terrible
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
ruled
by
me
,
"
returned
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
act
most
in
accordance
with
her
wishes
,
could
she
dictate
them
,
by
compliance
.
<EOS>
Do
not
waste
time
in
vain
regrets
,
but
let
us
remove
the
body
,
that
we
may
fulfil
her
last
injunctions
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
After
some
further
arguments
,
Jack
assented
to
this
proposal
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
on
first
with
the
light
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
bear
the
body
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
raised
it
in
his
arms
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
they
reached
the
end
of
the
passage
,
they
heard
the
voices
of
Jonathan
and
the
Jew
in
Thames
's
late
place
of
confinement
.
<EOS>
Wild
had
evidently
discovered
the
body
of
Quilt
Arnold
,
and
was
loudly
expressing
his
anger
and
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Extinguish
the
light
,
"
cried
Jack
;
"
turn
to
the
left
.
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
Quick
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
order
was
only
just
given
in
time
.
<EOS>
They
had
scarcely
gained
the
adjoining
cellar
when
Jonathan
and
the
Jew
rushed
past
in
the
direction
of
the
vault
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
moment
is
to
be
lost
,
"
cried
Jack
:
"
follow
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
hurried
up
stairs
,
opened
the
back
door
,
and
was
quickly
in
the
yard
.
<EOS>
Having
ascertained
that
Thames
was
at
his
heels
,
he
hurried
with
his
ghastly
burthen
down
Seacoal
Lane
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
,
who
,
though
wholly
disencumbered
,
was
scarcely
able
to
keep
up
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
--
and
care
not
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
a
coach
passed
them
,
and
was
instantly
hailed
by
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
let
me
convey
her
to
Dollis
Hill
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
Luckily
it
was
so
dark
,
and
there
was
no
lamp
near
,
that
the
man
did
not
notice
the
condition
of
the
body
,
which
was
placed
in
the
vehicle
by
the
two
young
men
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
do
?
"
asked
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
me
to
my
fate
,
"
rejoined
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Take
care
of
your
charge
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Doubt
me
not
,
"
replied
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bury
her
in
Willesden
churchyard
,
as
she
requested
,
on
Sunday
,
"
said
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
there
at
the
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
closed
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
coachman
having
received
his
order
,
and
being
offered
an
extra
fare
if
he
drove
quickly
,
set
off
at
full
speed
.
 
<EOS>
As
Jack
departed
,
a
dark
figure
,
emerging
from
behind
a
wall
,
rushed
after
him
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXIV
.
 
<EOS>
The
Pursuit
.
  
<EOS>
After
running
to
some
distance
down
Seacoal
Lane
,
Jack
stopped
to
give
a
last
look
at
the
vehicle
which
was
bearing
away
the
remains
of
his
beloved
and
ill
-
fated
mother
.
<EOS>
It
was
scarcely
out
of
sight
,
when
two
persons
,
whom
,
he
instantly
recognised
as
Jonathan
and
Abraham
Mendez
,
turned
the
corner
of
the
street
,
and
made
it
evident
from
their
shouts
,
that
they
likewise
perceived
him
.
 
<EOS>
Starting
off
at
a
rapid
pace
,
Jack
dashed
down
Turnagain
-
lane
,
skirted
the
eastern
bank
of
Fleet
-
ditch
,
crossed
Holborn
Bridge
,
and
began
to
ascend
the
neighbouring
hill
.
<EOS>
By
the
time
he
had
reached
St.
Andrew
's
Church
,
his
pursuers
had
gained
the
bridge
,
and
the
attention
of
such
passengers
as
crowded
the
streets
was
attracted
towards
him
by
their
vociferations
.
<EOS>
Amongst
others
,
the
watchman
whose
box
was
placed
against
the
churchyard
wall
,
near
the
entrance
to
Shoe
-
lane
,
rushed
out
and
sprung
his
rattle
,
which
was
immediately
answered
by
another
rattle
from
Holborn
-
bars
.
 
<EOS>
Darting
down
Field
-
lane
,
Jack
struck
into
a
labyrinth
of
streets
on
the
left
;
but
though
he
ran
as
swiftly
as
he
could
,
he
was
not
unperceived
.
<EOS>
His
course
had
been
observed
by
the
watchman
,
who
directed
Wild
which
way
to
take
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
Jack
Sheppard
,
the
noted
housebreaker
,
"
cried
Jonathan
,
at
the
top
of
his
sonorous
voice
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
just
broken
out
of
Newgate
.
<EOS>
After
him
!
<EOS>
A
hundred
pounds
to
the
man
who
takes
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
's
name
operated
like
magic
on
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
The
cry
was
echoed
by
twenty
different
voices
.
<EOS>
People
ran
out
of
their
shops
to
join
the
pursuit
;
and
,
by
the
time
Wild
had
got
into
Field
-
lane
,
he
had
a
troop
of
fifty
persons
at
his
heels
--
all
eager
to
assist
in
the
capture
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stop
thief
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Jonathan
,
who
perceived
the
fugitive
hurrying
along
a
street
towards
Hatton
Garden
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
Sheppard
--
Jack
Sheppard
--
stop
him
!
"
<EOS>
And
his
shouts
were
reiterated
by
the
pack
of
bloodhounds
at
his
heels
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
,
meanwhile
,
heard
,
the
shouts
,
and
,
though
alarmed
by
them
,
held
on
a
steady
course
.
<EOS>
By
various
twistings
and
turnings
,
during
all
which
time
his
pursuers
,
who
were
greatly
increased
in
numbers
,
kept
him
in
view
,
he
reached
Gray's
-
Inn
-
lane
.
<EOS>
Here
he
was
hotly
pursued
.
<EOS>
Fatigued
by
his
previous
exertions
,
and
incumbered
by
his
fetters
,
he
was
by
no
means
--
though
ordinarily
remarkably
swift
of
foot
--
<EOS>
a
match
for
his
foes
,
who
were
fast
gaining
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
corner
of
Liquorpond
Street
stood
the
old
Hampstead
coach
-
office
;
and
,
on
the
night
in
question
,
a
knot
of
hostlers
,
waggoners
,
drivers
,
and
stable
-
boys
was
collected
in
the
yard
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
distant
shouts
,
these
fellows
rushed
down
to
the
entrance
of
the
court
,
and
arrived
there
just
as
Jack
passed
it
.
"
<EOS>
Stop
thief
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
Stop
thief
!
"
<EOS>
clamoured
the
rabble
behind
.
 
<EOS>
At
no
loss
to
comprehend
that
Jack
was
the
individual
pointed
out
by
these
outcries
,
two
of
the
nearest
of
the
group
made
a
dash
at
him
.
<EOS>
But
Jack
eluded
their
grasp
.
<EOS>
A
large
dog
was
then
set
at
him
by
a
stable
-
boy
;
but
,
striking
the
animal
with
his
faithful
iron
-
bar
,
he
speedily
sent
him
yelping
back
.
<EOS>
The
two
hostlers
,
however
,
kept
close
at
his
heels
;
and
Jack
,
whose
strength
began
to
flag
,
feared
he
could
not
hold
much
longer
.
<EOS>
Determined
,
however
,
not
be
taken
with
life
,
he
held
on
.
 
<EOS>
Still
keeping
ahead
of
his
pursuers
,
he
ran
along
the
direct
road
,
till
the
houses
disappeared
and
he
got
into
the
open
country
.
<EOS>
Here
he
was
preparing
to
leap
over
the
hedge
into
the
fields
on
the
left
,
when
he
was
intercepted
by
two
horsemen
,
who
,
hearing
the
shouts
,
rode
up
and
struck
at
him
with
the
butt
-
ends
of
their
heavy
riding
-
whips
.
<EOS>
Warding
off
the
blows
as
well
as
he
could
with
the
bar
,
Jack
struck
both
the
horses
on
the
head
,
and
the
animals
plunged
so
violently
,
that
they
not
only
prevented
their
riders
from
assailing
him
,
but
also
kept
off
the
hostlers
;
and
,
in
the
confusion
that
ensued
,
Jack
managed
to
spring
over
the
fence
,
and
shaped
his
course
across
the
field
in
the
direction
of
Sir
John
Oldcastle
's
.
 
<EOS>
The
stoppage
had
materially
lessened
the
distance
between
him
and
his
pursuers
,
who
now
amounted
to
more
than
a
hundred
persons
,
many
of
whom
carried
lanterns
and
links
.
<EOS>
Ascertaining
that
it
was
Sheppard
of
whom
this
concourse
was
in
pursuit
,
the
two
horsemen
leapt
the
hedge
,
and
were
presently
close
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Like
a
hare
closely
pressed
,
Jack
attempted
to
double
,
but
the
device
only
brought
him
nearer
his
foes
,
who
were
crossing
the
field
in
every
direction
,
and
rending
the
air
with
their
shouts
.
<EOS>
The
uproar
was
tremendous
--
men
yelling
--
dogs
<EOS>
barking,--but
<EOS>
above
all
was
heard
the
stentorian
voice
of
Jonathan
,
urging
them
on
.
<EOS>
Jack
was
so
harrassed
that
he
felt
half
inclined
to
stand
at
bay
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
straining
every
sinew
,
his
foot
slipped
,
and
he
fell
,
head
foremost
,
into
a
deep
trench
,
which
he
had
not
observed
in
the
dark
.
<EOS>
This
fall
saved
him
,
for
the
horsemen
passed
over
him
.
<EOS>
Creeping
along
quickly
on
his
hands
and
knees
,
he
found
the
entrance
to
a
covered
drain
,
into
which
he
crept
.
<EOS>
He
was
scarcely
concealed
when
he
heard
the
horsemen
,
who
perceived
they
had
overshot
their
mark
,
ride
back
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Jonathan
and
the
vast
mob
attending
him
,
had
come
up
,
and
the
place
was
rendered
almost
as
light
as
day
by
the
links
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
somewhere
hereabouts
,
"
cried
one
of
the
horsemen
,
dismounting
.
<EOS>
"
We
were
close
upon
him
when
he
suddenly
disappeared
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
made
no
answer
,
but
snatching
a
torch
from
a
bystander
,
jumped
into
the
trench
and
commenced
a
diligent
search
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
had
arrived
at
the
mouth
of
the
drain
,
and
Jack
felt
certain
he
must
be
discovered
,
a
loud
shout
was
raised
from
the
further
end
of
the
field
that
the
fugitive
was
caught
.
<EOS>
All
the
assemblage
,
accompanied
by
Jonathan
,
set
off
in
this
direction
,
when
it
turned
out
that
the
supposed
housebreaker
was
a
harmless
beggar
,
who
had
been
found
asleep
under
a
hedge
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
's
vexation
at
the
disappointment
was
expressed
in
the
bitterest
imprecations
,
and
he
returned
as
speedily
as
he
could
to
the
trench
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
now
lost
the
precise
spot
;
and
thinking
he
had
examined
the
drain
,
turned
his
attention
to
another
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
excitement
of
the
chase
had
in
some
degree
subsided
.
<EOS>
The
crowd
dispersed
in
different
directions
,
and
most
fortunately
a
heavy
shower
coming
on
,
put
them
altogether
to
flight
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
however
,
still
lingered
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
wholly
insensible
to
the
rain
,
though
it
presently
descended
in
torrents
,
and
continued
his
search
as
ardently
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
After
occupying
himself
thus
for
the
best
part
of
an
hour
,
he
thought
Jack
must
have
given
him
the
slip
.
<EOS>
Still
,
his
suspicions
were
so
strong
,
that
he
ordered
Mendez
to
remain
on
guard
near
the
spot
all
night
,
and
,
by
the
promise
of
a
large
reward
induced
two
other
men
to
keep
him
company
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
took
his
departure
,
he
whispered
to
the
Jew
:
"
Take
him
dead
or
alive
;
but
if
we
fail
now
,
and
you
heard
him
aright
in
Seacoal
Lane
,
we
are
sure
of
him
at
his
mother
's
funeral
on
Sunday
.
"
    
CHAPTER
XXV
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
got
rid
of
his
Irons
.
  
<EOS>
About
an
hour
after
this
,
Jack
ventured
to
emerge
from
his
place
of
concealment
.
<EOS>
It
was
still
raining
heavily
,
and
profoundly
dark
.
<EOS>
Drenched
to
the
skin,--in
fact
,
he
had
been
lying
in
a
bed
of
muddy
water,--and
chilled
to
the
very
bone
<EOS>
,
he
felt
so
stiff
,
that
he
could
scarcely
move
.
 
<EOS>
Listening
attentively
,
he
fancied
he
heard
the
breathing
of
some
one
near
him
,
and
moved
cautiously
in
the
opposite
direction
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
care
,
he
came
in
contact
with
a
man
,
who
,
endeavouring
to
grasp
him
,
cried
,
in
the
voice
of
Mendez
,
"
Who
goes
dere
?
<EOS>
Shpeak
!
<EOS>
or
I
fire
!
"
 
<EOS>
No
answer
being
returned
,
the
Jew
instantly
discharged
his
pistol
,
and
though
the
shot
did
no
damage
,
the
flash
discovered
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
next
moment
all
was
profound
darkness
,
Jack
easily
managed
to
break
away
from
them
.
 
<EOS>
Without
an
idea
where
he
was
going
,
Jack
pursued
his
way
through
the
fields
;
and
,
as
he
proceeded
,
the
numbness
of
his
limbs
in
some
degree
wore
off
,
and
his
confidence
returned
.
<EOS>
He
had
need
of
all
the
inexhaustible
energy
of
his
character
to
support
him
through
his
toilsome
walk
over
the
wet
grass
,
or
along
the
slippery
ploughed
land
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
he
got
into
a
lane
,
but
had
not
proceeded
far
when
he
was
again
alarmed
by
the
sound
of
a
horse
's
tread
.
 
<EOS>
Once
more
breaking
through
the
hedge
he
took
to
the
fields
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
almost
driven
to
despair
.
<EOS>
Wet
as
he
was
,
he
felt
if
he
lay
down
in
the
grass
,
he
should
perish
with
cold
;
while
,
if
he
sought
a
night
's
lodging
in
any
asylum
,
his
dress
,
stained
with
blood
and
covered
with
dirt
,
would
infallibly
cause
him
to
be
secured
and
delivered
into
the
hands
of
justice
.
<EOS>
And
then
the
fetters
,
which
were
still
upon
his
legs:--how
was
he
to
get
rid
of
them
?
 
<EOS>
Tired
and
dispirited
,
he
still
wandered
on
.
<EOS>
Again
returning
to
the
main
road
,
he
passed
through
Clapton
;
and
turning
off
on
the
left
,
arrived
at
the
foot
of
Stamford
Hill
.
<EOS>
He
walked
on
for
an
hour
longer
,
till
he
could
scarcely
drag
one
leg
after
another
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
he
fell
down
on
the
road
,
fully
expecting
each
moment
would
prove
his
last
.
 
<EOS>
How
long
he
continued
thus
he
scarcely
knew
;
but
just
before
dawn
,
he
managed
to
regain
his
legs
,
and
,
crawling
up
a
bank
,
perceived
he
was
within
a
quarter
of
a
mile
of
Tottenham
.
<EOS>
A
short
way
off
in
the
fields
he
descried
a
sort
of
shed
or
cow
-
house
,
<EOS>
and
thither
he
contrived
to
drag
his
weary
limbs
.
<EOS>
Opening
the
door
,
he
found
it
littered
with
straw
,
on
which
he
threw
himself
,
and
instantly
fell
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
it
was
late
in
the
day
,
and
raining
heavily
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
he
could
not
stir
,
but
felt
sick
and
exhausted
.
<EOS>
His
legs
were
dreadfully
swelled
;
his
hands
bruised
;
and
his
fetters
occasioned
him
intolerable
pain
.
<EOS>
His
bodily
suffering
,
however
,
was
nothing
compared
with
his
mental
anguish
.
<EOS>
All
the
events
of
the
previous
day
rushed
to
his
recollection
;
and
though
he
had
been
unintentionally
the
cause
of
his
mother
's
death
,
he
reproached
himself
as
severely
as
if
he
had
been
her
actual
murderer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Had
I
not
been
the
guilty
wretch
I
am
,
"
he
cried
,
bursting
into
an
agony
of
tears
,
"
she
would
never
have
died
thus
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
strong
feeling
of
remorse
having
found
a
natural
vent
,
in
some
degree
subsided
,
and
he
addressed
himself
to
his
present
situation
.
<EOS>
Rousing
himself
,
he
went
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
It
had
ceased
raining
,
but
the
atmosphere
was
moist
and
chill
,
and
the
ground
deluged
by
the
recent
showers
.
<EOS>
Taking
up
a
couple
of
large
stones
which
lay
near
,
Jack
tried
to
beat
the
round
basils
of
the
fetters
into
an
oval
form
,
so
as
to
enable
him
to
slip
his
heels
through
them
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
employed
a
farming
man
came
into
the
barn
.
<EOS>
Jack
instantly
started
to
his
feet
,
and
the
man
,
alarmed
at
his
appearance
,
ran
off
to
a
neighbouring
house
.
<EOS>
Before
he
could
return
,
Jack
had
made
good
his
retreat
;
and
,
wandering
about
the
lanes
and
hedges
,
kept
out
of
sight
as
much
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
On
examining
his
pockets
,
he
found
about
twenty
guineas
in
gold
,
and
some
silver
.
<EOS>
But
how
to
avail
himself
of
it
was
the
question
,
for
in
his
present
garb
he
was
sure
to
be
recognised
.
<EOS>
When
night
fell
,
he
crept
into
the
town
of
Tottenham
.
<EOS>
As
he
passed
along
the
main
thoroughfare
,
he
heard
his
own
name
pronounced
,
and
found
that
it
was
a
hawker
,
crying
a
penny
history
of
his
escapes
.
<EOS>
A
crowd
was
collected
round
the
fellow
,
who
was
rapidly
disposing
of
his
stock
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
full
,
true
,
and
particular
account
of
Jack
Sheppard
's
last
astonishing
and
never
-
to
-
be
-
forgotten
escape
from
the
Castle
of
Newgate
,
"
bawled
the
hawker
,
"
with
a
print
of
him
taken
from
the
life
,
showing
the
manner
,
how
he
was
shackled
and
handcuffed
.
<EOS>
Only
one
penny
--
two
copies
--
two
pence
--
thank
