you
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
Here
's
the----
<EOS>
"
 
"
Let
me
have
one
,
"
cried
a
servant
maid
,
running
across
the
street
,
and
in
her
haste
forgetting
to
shut
the
door,--"here
's
the
money
.
<EOS>
Master
and
missis
have
been
talking
all
day
long
about
Jack
Sheppard
,
and
I
'm
dying
to
read
his
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
you
have
it
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
the
hawker
.
<EOS>
"
Sold
again
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
get
back
quickly
,
Lucy
,
"
observed
a
bystander
,
"
Jack
Sheppard
will
be
in
the
house
before
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
sally
occasioned
a
general
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
Jack
would
come
to
my
house
,
I
'd
contrive
to
hide
him
,
"
remarked
a
buxom
dame
.
"
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
I
'm
glad
he
has
escaped
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Jack
seems
to
be
a
great
favourite
with
the
fair
sex
,
"
observed
a
smirking
grocer
's
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
rejoined
the
bystander
,
who
had
just
spoken
,
and
who
was
of
a
cynical
turn,--"the
greater
<EOS>
the
rascal
,
the
better
they
like
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
particular
account
of
Jack
's
many
robberies
and
escapes
,
"
roared
the
hawker,--"how
he
broke
into
the
house
of
his
master
,
Mr.
Wood
,
at
Dollis
<EOS>
Hill--
<EOS>
"
 
"
Let
me
have
one
,
"
said
a
carpenter
,
who
was
passing
by
at
the
moment,--"Mr
.
<EOS>
Wood
was
an
old
friend
of
mine
--
and
I
recollect
seeing
Jack
when
he
was
bound
'
prentice
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
A
penny
,
if
you
please
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
hawker.--"Sold
again
!
<EOS>
Here
you
have
the
full
,
true
,
and
particular
account
of
the
barbarous
murder
committed
by
Jack
Sheppard
and
his
associate
,
Joseph
Blake
,
_
alias
<EOS>
_
Blueskin
,
upon
the
body
of
Mrs.
Wood--
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
false
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
voice
behind
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
turned
at
the
exclamation
,
and
so
did
several
of
the
bystanders
;
but
they
could
not
make
out
who
had
uttered
it
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
,
who
had
been
lingering
near
the
group
,
now
walked
on
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
middle
of
the
little
town
stood
the
shop
of
a
Jew
dealer
in
old
clothes
.
<EOS>
The
owner
was
at
the
door
unhooking
a
few
articles
of
wearing
apparel
which
he
had
exposed
outside
for
sale
.
<EOS>
Amongst
other
things
,
he
had
just
brought
down
an
old
laced
bavaroy
,
a
species
of
surtout
much
worn
at
the
period
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
fot
that
coat
,
friend
?
"
asked
Jack
,
as
he
came
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
More
than
you
'll
pay
for
it
,
friend
,
"
snuffled
the
Jew
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
that
?
"
rejoined
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
a
guinea
for
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Double
that
sum
might
tempt
me
,
"
replied
the
Jew
;
"
it
's
a
nobleman
's
coat
,
upon
my
shoul
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
money
,
"
replied
Jack
,
taking
the
coat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
help
you
on
with
it
,
Sir
?
<EOS>
"
replied
the
Jew
,
becoming
suddenly
respectful
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
half
suspect
this
is
a
highwayman
,
"
thought
the
Jew
;
"
he
's
so
ready
with
his
cash
.
<EOS>
I
've
some
other
things
inside
,
Sir
,
which
you
might
wish
to
buy,--some
pistols
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
was
about
to
comply
;
but
not
liking
the
man
's
manner
,
he
walked
on
.
 
<EOS>
Further
on
,
there
was
a
small
chandler
's
shop
,
where
Jack
observed
an
old
woman
seated
at
the
counter
,
attended
by
a
little
girl
.
<EOS>
Seeing
provisions
in
the
window
,
Jack
ventured
in
and
bought
a
loaf
.
<EOS>
Having
secured
this,--for
<EOS>
he
was
almost
famished,--he
said
that
he
had
lost
a
hammer
and
wished
to
purchase
one
.
<EOS>
The
old
woman
told
him
she
had
no
such
article
to
dispose
of
,
but
recommended
him
to
a
neighbouring
blacksmith
.
 
<EOS>
Guided
by
the
glare
of
the
forge
,
which
threw
a
stream
of
ruddy
light
across
the
road
,
Jack
soon
found
the
place
of
which
he
was
in
search
.
<EOS>
Entering
the
workshop
,
he
found
the
blacksmith
occupied
in
heating
the
tire
of
a
cart
wheel
.
<EOS>
Suspending
his
labour
on
Jack
's
appearance
,
the
man
demanded
his
business
.
<EOS>
Making
up
a
similar
story
to
that
which
he
had
told
the
old
woman
,
he
said
he
wanted
to
purchase
a
hammer
and
a
file
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
looked
hard
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
one
question
first
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
;
"
I
half
suspect
you
're
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
replied
Jack
,
without
hesitation
;
<EOS>
for
he
felt
assured
from
the
man
's
manner
that
he
might
confide
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
bold
fellow
,
Jack
,
"
rejoined
the
blacksmith
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
've
done
well
to
trust
me
.
<EOS>
I
'll
take
off
your
irons
--
for
I
guess
that
's
the
reason
why
you
want
the
hammer
and
file
--
on
one
condition
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
you
give
'em
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Readily
.
"
 
<EOS>
Taking
Jack
into
a
shed
behind
the
workshop
the
smith
in
a
short
time
freed
him
from
his
fetters
.
<EOS>
He
not
only
did
this
,
but
supplied
him
with
an
ointment
which
allayed
the
swelling
of
his
limbs
,
and
crowned
all
by
furnishing
him
with
a
jug
of
excellent
ale
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
,
Jack
,
you
'll
come
to
the
gallows
,
"
observed
the
smith
;
"
buth
<EOS>
if
you
do
,
I
'll
go
to
Tyburn
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
never
part
with
your
irons
.
"
 
<EOS>
Noticing
the
draggled
condition
Jack
was
in
<EOS>
,
he
then
fetched
him
a
bucket
of
water
,
with
which
Jack
cleansed
himself
as
well
as
he
could
,
and
thanking
the
honest
smith
,
who
would
take
nothing
for
his
trouble
,
left
the
shop
.
 
<EOS>
Having
made
a
tolerably
good
meal
upon
the
loaf
,
overcome
by
fatigue
,
Jack
turned
into
a
barn
in
Stoke
Newington
,
and
slept
till
late
in
the
day
,
when
he
awakened
much
refreshed
.
<EOS>
The
swelling
in
his
limbs
had
also
subsided
.
<EOS>
It
rained
heavily
all
day
,
so
he
did
not
stir
forth
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
night
,
however
,
he
ventured
out
,
and
walked
on
towards
London
.
<EOS>
When
he
arrived
at
Hoxton
,
he
found
the
walls
covered
with
placards
offering
a
reward
for
his
apprehension
,
and
he
everywhere
appeared
to
be
the
general
subject
of
conversation
.
<EOS>
Prom
a
knot
of
idlers
at
a
public
-
house
,
he
learnt
that
Jonathan
Wild
had
just
ridden
past
,
and
that
his
setters
were
scouring
the
country
in
every
direction
.
 
<EOS>
Entering
London
,
he
bent
his
way
towards
the
west
-
end
;
and
having
some
knowledge
of
a
secondhand
tailor
's
shop
in
Rupert
Street
,
proceeded
thither
,
and
looked
out
a
handsome
suit
of
mourning
,
with
a
sword
,
cloak
,
and
hat
,
and
demanded
the
price
.
<EOS>
The
man
asked
twelve
guineas
,
but
after
a
little
bargaining
,
he
came
down
to
ten
.
 
<EOS>
Taking
his
new
purchase
under
his
arm
,
Jack
proceeded
to
a
small
tavern
in
the
same
street
,
where
,
having
ordered
dinner
,
he
went
to
a
bed
-
room
to
attire
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
completed
his
toilet
,
when
he
was
startled
by
a
noise
at
the
door
,
and
heard
his
own
name
pronounced
in
no
friendly
accents
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
the
window
was
not
far
from
the
ground
;
so
opening
it
gently
,
he
dropped
into
a
backyard
,
and
from
thence
got
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrying
down
the
Haymarket
,
he
was
arrested
by
a
crowd
who
were
collected
round
a
street
-
singer
.
<EOS>
Jack
paused
for
a
moment
,
and
found
that
his
own
adventures
formed
the
subject
of
the
ballad
.
<EOS>
Not
daring
,
however
,
to
listen
to
it
,
he
ran
on
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXVI
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
attended
his
Mother
's
Funeral
.
  
<EOS>
That
night
Jack
walked
to
Paddington
,
and
took
up
his
quarters
at
a
small
tavern
,
called
the
Wheat
-
sheaf
,
near
the
green
.
<EOS>
On
the
next
morning
--
Sunday
--
the
day
on
which
he
expected
his
mother
's
funeral
to
take
place
,
he
set
out
along
the
Harrow
Road
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
clear
,
lovely
,
October
morning
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
sharp
and
bracing
,
and
the
leaves
which
had
taken
their
autumnal
tints
were
falling
from
the
trees
.
<EOS>
The
road
which
wound
by
Westbourne
Green
,
gave
him
a
full
view
of
the
hill
of
Hampstead
with
its
church
,
its
crest
of
houses
,
and
its
villas
peeping
from
out
the
trees
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
's
heart
was
too
full
to
allow
him
to
derive
any
pleasure
from
this
scene
;
so
he
strolled
on
without
raising
his
eyes
till
he
arrived
at
Kensal
Green
.
<EOS>
Here
he
obtained
some
breakfast
,
and
mounting
the
hill
turned
off
into
the
fields
on
the
right
.
<EOS>
Crossing
them
,
he
ascended
an
eminence
,
which
,
from
its
singular
shape
,
seems
to
have
been
the
site
of
a
Roman
encampment
,
and
which
commands
a
magnificent
prospect
.
 
<EOS>
Leaning
upon
a
gate
he
looked
down
into
the
valley
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
very
spot
from
which
his
poor
mother
had
gazed
after
her
vain
attempt
to
rescue
him
at
the
Mint
;
but
,
though
he
was
ignorant
of
this
,
her
image
was
alone
present
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
beheld
the
grey
tower
of
Willesden
Church
,
embosomed
in
its
grove
of
trees
,
now
clothed
,
in
all
the
glowing
livery
of
autumn
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
cottage
she
had
inhabited
for
so
many
years,--in
<EOS>
those
fields
she
had
rambled,--at
that
church
she
had
prayed
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
destroyed
all
this
.
<EOS>
But
for
him
she
might
have
been
alive
and
happy
.
<EOS>
The
recollection
was
too
painful
,
and
he
burst
into
an
agony
of
tears
.
 
<EOS>
Aroused
by
the
sound
of
the
church
bells
,
he
resolved
,
at
whatever
risk
,
to
attend
Divine
service
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
descended
the
hill
and
presently
found
a
footpath
leading
to
the
church
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
destined
to
have
every
tide
of
feeling
awakened
--
every
wound
opened
.
<EOS>
The
path
he
had
selected
conducted
him
to
his
mother
's
humble
dwelling
.
<EOS>
When
she
occupied
,
it
,
it
was
neatness
itself
;
the
little
porch
was
overrun
with
creepers
--
the
garden
trim
and
exquisitely
kept
.
<EOS>
Now
,
it
was
a
wilderness
of
weeds
.
<EOS>
The
glass
in
the
windows
was
broken
--
the
roof
unthatched
--
<EOS>
the
walls
dilapidated
.
<EOS>
Jack
turned
away
with
an
aching
heart
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
an
emblem
of
the
ruin
he
had
caused
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
proceeded
,
other
painful
reminiscences
were
aroused
.
<EOS>
At
every
step
he
seemed
to
be
haunted
by
the
ghost
of
the
past
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
stile
on
which
Jonathan
had
sat
,
and
he
recollected
distinctly
the
effect
of
his
mocking
glance
--
how
it
had
hardened
his
heart
against
his
mother
's
prayer
.
"
<EOS>
O
God
!
<EOS>
"
he
exclaimed
,
"
I
am
severely
punished
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
had
now
gained
the
high
road
.
<EOS>
The
villagers
were
thronging
to
church
.
<EOS>
Bounding
the
corner
of
a
garden
wall
,
he
came
upon
his
former
place
of
imprisonment
.
<EOS>
Some
rustic
hand
had
written
upon
the
door
"
<EOS>
JACK
SHEPPARD
'S
CAGE
;
"
and
upon
the
wall
was
affixed
a
large
placard
describing
his
person
,
and
offering
a
reward
for
his
capture
.
<EOS>
Muffling
up
his
face
,
Jack
turned
away
;
but
he
had
not
proceeded
many
steps
when
he
heard
a
man
reading
aloud
an
account
of
his
escapes
from
a
newspaper
.
 
<EOS>
Hastening
to
the
church
,
he
entered
it
by
the
very
door
near
which
his
first
crime
had
been
committed
.
<EOS>
His
mother
's
scream
seemed
again
to
ring
in
his
ears
,
and
he
was
so
deeply
affected
that
,
fearful
of
exciting
attention
,
he
was
about
to
quit
the
sacred
edifice
,
when
he
was
stopped
by
the
entrance
of
Thames
,
who
looked
pale
as
death
,
with
Winifred
leaning
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
They
were
followed
by
Mr.
Wood
in
the
deepest
mourning
.
 
<EOS>
Shrinking
involuntarily
back
into
the
farthest
corner
of
the
seat
,
Jack
buried
his
face
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
The
service
began
.
<EOS>
Jack
who
had
not
been
in
a
place
of
worship
for
many
years
was
powerfully
affected
.
<EOS>
Accidentally
raising
his
eyes
,
he
saw
that
he
was
perceived
by
the
family
from
Dollis
Hill
,
and
that
he
was
an
object
of
the
deepest
interest
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
service
was
over
,
Thames
contrived
to
approach
him
,
and
whispered
,
"
Be
cautious,--the
funeral
will
take
place
after
evening
service
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
would
not
hazard
a
glance
at
Winifred
;
but
,
quitting
the
church
,
got
into
an
adjoining
meadow
,
and
watched
the
party
slowly
ascending
the
road
leading
to
Dollis
Hill
.
<EOS>
At
a
turn
in
the
road
,
he
perceived
Winifred
looking
anxiously
towards
him
,
and
when
she
discovered
him
,
she
waved
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
churchyard
,
he
walked
round
it
;
and
on
the
western
side
,
near
a
small
yew
-
tree
discovered
a
new
-
made
grave
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whose
grave
is
this
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquired
of
a
man
who
was
standing
near
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
,
"
answered
the
fellow
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
'll
inquire
from
the
sexton
,
William
Morgan
.
<EOS>
Here
,
Peter
,
"
he
added
to
a
curly
-
headed
lad
,
who
was
playing
on
one
of
the
grassy
tombs
,
"
ask
your
father
to
step
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
little
urchin
set
off
,
and
presently
returned
with
the
sexton
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
Mrs.
Sheppard
's
grave,--the
mother
of
the
famous
housebreaker
,
"
said
Morgan
,
in
answer
to
Jack
's
inquiry;--"and
<EOS>
it
's
well
<EOS>
they
let
her
have
Christian
burial
after
all
--
for
they
say
she
destroyed
herself
for
her
son
.
<EOS>
The
crowner
's
'
quest
sat
on
her
yesterday
--
and
if
she
had
n't
been
proved
out
of
her
mind
,
she
would
have
been
buried
at
four
lane
-
ends
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
could
stand
no
more
.
<EOS>
Placing
a
piece
of
money
in
Morgan
's
hands
,
he
hurried
out
of
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
"
said
the
sexton
,
"
that
's
as
like
Jack
Sheppard
as
any
one
I
ever
seed
<EOS>
i
'
my
born
days
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Hastening
to
the
Six
Bells
,
Jack
ordered
some
refreshment
,
and
engaged
a
private
room
,
where
he
remained
till
the
afternoon
absorbed
in
grief
.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
,
a
change
had
taken
place
in
the
weather
.
<EOS>
The
day
had
become
suddenly
overcast
.
<EOS>
The
wind
blew
in
fitful
gusts
,
and
scattered
the
yellow
leaves
from
the
elms
and
horse
-
chestnuts
.
<EOS>
Roused
by
the
bell
tolling
for
evening
service
,
Jack
left
the
house
.
<EOS>
On
reaching
the
churchyard
,
he
perceived
the
melancholy
procession
descending
the
hill
.
<EOS>
Just
then
,
a
carriage
drawn
by
four
horses
,
drove
furiously
up
to
the
Six
Bells
;
but
Jack
was
too
much
absorbed
to
take
any
notice
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
the
bell
began
to
toll
in
a
peculiar
manner
,
announcing
the
approach
of
the
corpse
.
<EOS>
The
gate
was
opened
;
the
coffin
brought
into
the
churchyard
;
and
Jack
,
whose
eyes
were
filled
with
tears
,
saw
Mr.
Wood
and
Thames
pass
him
,
and
followed
at
a
foot
's
pace
behind
them
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
clergyman
,
bare
-
headed
and
in
his
surplice
,
advanced
to
meet
them
.
<EOS>
Having
read
the
three
first
verses
of
the
impressive
service
appointed
for
the
burial
of
the
dead
,
he
returned
to
the
church
,
whither
the
coffin
was
carried
through
the
south
-
western
door
,
and
placed
in
the
centre
of
the
aisle
--
Mr
.
Wood
and
Thames
taking
their
places
on
either
side
of
it
,
and
Jack
at
a
little
distance
behind
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
had
been
touched
in
the
morning
,
but
he
was
now
completely
prostrated
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
the
holy
place
,
which
he
had
formerly
profaned
,
lay
the
body
of
his
unfortunate
mother
,
and
he
could
not
help
looking
upon
her
untimely
end
as
the
retributive
vengeance
of
Heaven
for
the
crime
he
had
committed
.
<EOS>
His
grief
was
so
audible
,
that
it
attracted
the
notice
of
some
of
the
bystanders
,
and
Thames
was
obliged
to
beg
him
to
control
it
.
<EOS>
In
doing
this
,
he
chanced
to
raise
his
eyes
and
half
fancied
he
beheld
,
shaded
by
a
pillar
at
the
extremity
of
the
western
aisle
,
the
horrible
countenance
of
the
thief
-
taker
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
congregation
separated
,
the
clergyman
descended
from
the
pulpit
;
and
,
followed
by
the
coffin
-
bearers
and
mourners
,
and
by
Jack
at
a
respectful
distance
,
entered
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
The
carriage
,
which
it
has
been
mentioned
drove
up
to
the
Six
Bells
,
contained
four
persons,--Jonathan
Wild
,
his
two
janizaries
,
and
his
porter
,
Obadiah
Lemon
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
they
had
got
out
,
the
vehicle
was
drawn
up
at
the
back
of
a
tree
near
the
cage
.
<EOS>
Having
watched
the
funeral
at
some
distance
,
Jonathan
fancied
he
could
discern
the
figure
of
Jack
;
but
not
being
quite
sure
,
he
entered
the
church
.
<EOS>
He
was
daring
enough
to
have
seized
and
carried
him
off
before
the
whole
congregation
,
but
he
preferred
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
Satisfied
with
his
scrutiny
,
he
returned
,
despatched
Abraham
and
Obadiah
to
the
northwest
corner
of
the
church
,
placed
Quilt
behind
a
buttress
near
the
porch
,
and
sheltered
himself
behind
one
of
the
mighty
elms
.
 
<EOS>
The
funeral
procession
had
now
approached
the
grave
,
around
which
many
of
the
congregation
,
who
were
deeply
interested
by
the
sad
ceremonial
,
had
gathered
.
<EOS>
A
slight
rain
fell
at
the
time
;
and
a
few
leaves
,
caught
by
the
eddies
,
whirled
around
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
mixed
with
the
group
,
and
,
sure
of
his
prey
,
abided
his
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
clergyman
,
meanwhile
,
proceeded
with
the
service
,
while
the
coffin
was
deposited
at
the
brink
of
the
grave
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
the
attendants
were
preparing
to
lower
the
corpse
into
the
earth
,
Jack
fell
on
his
knees
beside
the
coffin
,
uttering
the
wildest
exclamations
of
grief
,
reproaching
himself
with
the
murder
of
his
mother
,
and
invoking
the
vengeance
of
Heaven
on
his
own
head
.
 
<EOS>
A
murmur
ran
through
the
assemblage
,
by
several
of
whom
Jack
was
recognised
.
<EOS>
But
such
was
the
violence
of
his
grief,--such
the
compunction
he
exhibited
,
that
all
but
one
looked
on
with
an
eye
of
compassion
.
<EOS>
That
person
advanced
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
killed
her
,
"
cried
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
laying
a
forcible
grasp
on
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
prisoner
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
started
to
his
feet
;
but
before
he
could
defend
himself
,
his
right
arm
was
grasped
by
the
Jew
who
had
silently
approached
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hell
-
hounds
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
;
"
release
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
Quilt
Arnold
rushed
forward
with
such
haste
,
that
,
stumbling
over
William
Morgan
,
he
precipitated
him
into
the
grave
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wretch
!
"
cried
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Are
you
not
content
with
the
crimes
you
have
<EOS>
committed,--but
<EOS>
you
must
carry
your
villany
to
this
point
.
<EOS>
Look
at
the
poor
victim
at
your
feet
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
made
no
reply
,
but
ordered
his
myrmidons
to
drag
the
prisoner
along
.
 
<EOS>
Thames
,
meanwhile
,
had
drawn
his
sword
,
and
was
about
to
rush
upon
Jonathan
;
but
he
was
withheld
by
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
shed
more
blood
,
"
cried
the
carpenter
.
 
<EOS>
Groans
and
hoots
were
now
raised
by
the
crowd
,
and
there
was
an
evident
disposition
to
rescue
.
<EOS>
A
small
brickbat
was
thrown
,
which
struck
Jonathan
in
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
pass
,
"
cried
several
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
his
poor
mother
,
and
for
her
sake
I
'll
not
see
this
done
,
"
cried
John
Dump
.
 
<EOS>
"
Slip
on
the
handcuffs
,
"
cried
the
thief
-
taker
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
let
's
see
who
'll
dare
to
oppose
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
Jonathan
Wild
.
<EOS>
I
have
arrested
him
in
the
King
's
name
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
deep
indignant
groan
followed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
the
earth
thrown
over
her
,
"
implored
Jack
;
"
and
take
me
where
you
please
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
thundered
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
Allow
him
that
small
grace
,
"
cried
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
tell
you
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
shouldering
his
way
out
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
mother,--my
poor
mother
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
spite
of
his
outcries
and
resistance
,
he
was
dragged
along
by
Jonathan
and
his
janizaries
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
eastern
gate
of
the
churchyard
stood
the
carriage
with
the
steps
lowered
.
<EOS>
The
mob
pursued
the
thief
-
taker
and
his
party
all
the
way
,
and
such
missiles
as
could
be
collected
were
hurled
at
them
.
<EOS>
They
even
threatened
to
cut
the
traces
and
take
off
the
wheels
from
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
The
Jew
got
in
first
.
<EOS>
The
prisoner
was
then
thrust
in
by
Quilt
.
<EOS>
Before
Jonathan
followed
he
turned
to
face
his
assailants
.
 
<EOS>
"
Back
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
fiercely
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
an
officer
in
the
execution
of
my
duty
.
<EOS>
And
he
who
opposes
me
in
it
shall
feel
the
weight
of
my
hand
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
sprung
into
the
coach
,
the
door
of
which
was
closed
by
Obadiah
,
who
mounted
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
Newgate
,
"
cried
Jonathan
,
putting
his
head
out
of
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
A
deep
roar
followed
this
order
,
and
several
missiles
were
launched
at
the
vehicle
,
which
was
driven
off
at
a
furious
pace
.
 
<EOS>
And
while
her
son
was
reconveyed
to
prison
the
body
of
the
unfortunate
Mrs.
Sheppard
was
committed
to
the
earth
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXVII
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
was
brought
back
to
Newgate
.
  
<EOS>
Jack
Sheppard
's
escape
from
Newgate
on
the
night
of
the
15th
of
October
was
not
discovered
till
the
following
morning
;
for
although
the
intelligence
was
brought
by
several
parties
to
the
Lodge
in
the
course
of
the
night
,
Austin
,
who
was
the
officer
in
attendance
,
paid
no
attention
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
After
pursuing
the
fugitive
as
before
related
,
Jonathan
Wild
returned
to
his
own
habitation
,
where
he
was
occupied
during
the
remainder
of
the
night
with
Quilt
Arnold
and
Obadiah
Lemon
in
removing
everything
which
,
in
case
of
a
search
,
might
tend
to
criminate
him
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
in
this
respect
,
he
flung
himself
into
a
chair
,
for
his
iron
frame
seldom
required
the
indulgence
of
a
bed
,
and
sought
an
hour
's
repose
before
he
began
the
villanies
of
another
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
aroused
from
his
slumber
,
about
six
o'clock
,
by
the
return
of
Abraham
Mendez
,
who
not
choosing
to
confess
that
Jack
had
eluded
his
vigilance
,
contended
himself
with
stating
that
he
had
kept
watch
till
daybreak
,
when
he
had
carefully
searched
the
field
,
and
,
finding
no
trace
of
him
,
had
thought
it
better
to
return
.
 
<EOS>
This
information
was
received
by
Jonathan
with
a
lowering
brow
.
<EOS>
He
comforted
himself
,
however
,
with
the
certainty
which
he
felt
of
capturing
his
prey
on
the
Sunday
.
<EOS>
His
breakfast
despatched
,
which
he
ate
with
a
wolfish
appetite
,
he
walked
over
to
Newgate
,
chuckling
as
he
went
at
the
consternation
which
his
appearance
would
create
amongst
the
turnkeys
.
 
<EOS>
Entering
the
Lodge
,
the
first
person
he
beheld
was
Austin
,
who
was
only
just
up
,
and
whose
toilette
appeared
scarcely
completed
.
<EOS>
A
glance
satisfied
Jonathan
that
the
turnkey
was
not
aware
of
the
prisoner
's
escape
;
and
he
resolved
not
to
destroy
what
he
considered
a
good
jest
,
by
a
premature
disclosure
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
out
betimes
this
morning
,
Mr.
Wild
,
"
observed
Austin
,
as
he
put
on
his
coat
,
and
adjusted
his
minor
bob
.
<EOS>
"
Something
fresh
on
hand
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
come
to
inquire
after
Jack
Sheppard
,
"
returned
Jonathan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
alarm
yourself
about
him
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Austin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
safe
enough
,
I
assure
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
satisfy
myself
on
that
score
,
"
rejoined
Wild
,
drily
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
you
shall
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Austin
,
who
at
this
moment
recollected
,
with
some
uneasiness
,
the
applications
at
the
lodge
-
door
during
the
night
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
do
n't
imagine
anything
has
gone
wrong
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
matters
not
what
I
think
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Come
with
me
to
the
Castle
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Instantly
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Austin
;
"
instantly
.
<EOS>
Here
,
Caliban
,
attend
to
the
door
,
and
keep
the
wicket
locked
till
I
return
.
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Taking
the
keys
,
he
led
the
way
,
followed
by
Jonathan
,
who
chuckled
internally
at
the
shock
that
awaited
the
poor
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
was
opened
,
and
Austin
entered
the
cell
,
when
he
absolutely
recoiled
before
the
spectacle
he
beheld
,
and
could
scarcely
have
looked
more
alarmed
if
the
prison
had
tumbled
about
his
ears
.
<EOS>
Petrified
and
speechless
<EOS>
,
he
turned
an
imploring
look
at
Wild
,
who
was
himself
filled
with
astonishment
at
the
pile
of
rubbish
lying
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
'
Sdeath
!
"
cried
Jonathan
,
staring
at
the
breach
in
the
wall
.
<EOS>
"
Some
one
_
must
_
have
assisted
him
.
<EOS>
Unless
he
has
dealings
with
the
devil
,
he
could
never
have
done
this
alone
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
firmly
believe
he
_
has
_
dealings
with
the
devil
,
"
replied
Austin
,
trembling
from
head
to
foot
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
perhaps
,
he
has
not
got
beyond
the
room
above
.
<EOS>
It
's
as
strong
,
if
not
stronger
,
than
this
.
<EOS>
I
'll
see
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
scrambled
over
the
rubbish
,
and
got
into
the
chimney
.
<EOS>
But
though
the
breach
was
large
enough
to
admit
him
below
,
he
could
not
squeeze
his
bulky
person
through
the
aperture
into
the
Red
Room
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
he
's
gone
,
"
he
said
,
returning
to
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
door
's
open
,
and
the
room
empty
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
believe
--
you
_
know
_
it
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
fixing
one
of
his
sternest
and
most
searching
glances
upon
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nothing
you
can
say
to
the
contrary
will
convince
me
that
you
have
not
been
accessory
to
his
flight
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
,
Sir!--I
swear----
"
 
"
Tush
!
"
<EOS>
interrupted
Jonathan
,
harshly
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
state
my
suspicions
to
the
governor
.
<EOS>
Come
down
with
me
to
the
Lodge
directly
.
<EOS>
All
further
examinations
must
be
conducted
in
the
presence
of
proper
witnesses
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
strode
out
of
the
room
,
darted
down
the
stone
stairs
,
and
,
on
his
arrival
at
the
Lodge
,
seized
the
rope
of
the
great
bell
communicating
with
the
interior
of
the
prison
,
which
he
rang
violently
.
<EOS>
As
this
was
never
done
,
except
in
some
case
of
great
emergency
,
the
application
was
instantly
answered
by
all
the
other
turnkeys
,
by
Marvel
,
the
four
partners
,
and
Mrs.
Spurling
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
exceed
the
dismay
of
these
personages
when
they
learnt
why
they
had
been
summoned
.
<EOS>
All
seemed
infected
with
Austin
's
terrors
except
Mrs.
Spurling
,
who
did
not
dare
to
exhibit
her
satisfaction
otherwise
than
by
privately
pinching
the
arm
of
her
expected
husband
.
 
<EOS>
Headed
by
Jonathan
,
all
the
turnkeys
then
repaired
to
the
upper
part
of
the
jail
,
and
,
approaching
the
Red
Room
by
a
circuitous
route
,
several
doors
were
unlocked
,
and
they
came
upon
the
scene
of
Jack
's
exploits
.
<EOS>
Stopping
before
each
door
,
they
took
up
the
plates
of
the
locks
,
examined
the
ponderous
bolts
,
and
were
struck
with
the
utmost
astonishment
at
what
they
beheld
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
at
the
chapel
,
their
wonder
increased
.
<EOS>
All
the
jailers
declared
it
utterly
impossible
he
could
have
accomplished
his
astonishing
task
unaided
;
but
who
had
lent
him
assistance
was
a
question
they
were
unable
to
answer
.
<EOS>
Proceeding
to
the
entry
to
the
Lower
Leads
,
they
came
to
the
two
strong
doors
,
and
their
surprise
was
so
great
at
Jack
's
marvellous
performance
,
that
they
could
scarcely
persuade
themselves
that
human
ingenuity
could
have
accomplished
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
door
,
"
remarked
Ireton
,
when
he
got
to
that
nearest
the
leads
,
"
which
I
could
have
sworn
would
have
resisted
anything
.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
no
faith
in
future
in
bolts
and
bars
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mounting
the
roof
of
the
prison
,
they
traced
the
fugitive
's
course
to
the
further
extremity
of
the
building
,
where
they
found
his
blanket
attached
to
the
spike
proving
that
he
escaped
in
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
After
severely
examining
Austin
,
and
finding
it
proved
,
on
the
testimony
of
his
fellow
-
jailers
,
that
he
could
not
have
aided
Jack
in
his
flight
,
Jonathan
retracted
his
harsh
sentence
,
and
even
went
so
far
as
to
say
that
he
would
act
as
mediator
between
him
and
the
governor
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
some
satisfaction
to
the
poor
fellow
,
who
was
dreadfully
frightened
,
as
indeed
he
might
well
be
,
it
being
the
opinion
of
the
jailers
and
others
who
afterwards
examined
the
place
,
that
Jack
had
accomplished
,
single
-
handed
,
in
a
few
hours
,
and
,
as
far
as
it
could
be
ascertained
,
with
imperfect
implements
,
what
it
would
have
taken
half
a
dozen
men
several
days
,
provided
with
proper
tools
,
to
effect
.
<EOS>
In
their
opinion
a
hundred
pounds
would
not
repair
the
damage
done
to
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Jack
's
escape
became
known
,
thousands
of
persons
flocked
to
Newgate
to
behold
his
workmanship
;
and
the
jailers
reaped
am
abundant
harvest
from
their
curiosity
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
meanwhile
,
maintained
profound
secrecy
as
to
his
hopes
of
capturing
the
fugitive
;
and
when
Jack
was
brought
back
to
Newgate
on
the
Sunday
evening
,
his
arrival
was
wholly
unexpected
.
 
<EOS>
At
a
little
after
five
,
on
that
day
,
four
horses
dashed
round
the
corner
of
the
Old
Bailey
,
and
drew
up
before
the
door
of
the
Lodge
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
stoppage
,
Austin
rushed
out
,
and
could
scarcely
believe
his
eyes
when
he
beheld
Jack
Sheppard
in
the
custody
of
Quilt
Arnold
and
Abraham
Mendez
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
's
recapture
was
speedily
made
known
to
all
the
officers
of
the
jail
,
and
the
Lodge
was
instantly
crowded
.
<EOS>
The
delight
of
the
turnkeys
was
beyond
all
bounds
;
but
poor
Mrs.
Spurling
was
in
a
state
of
distraction
and
began
to
abuse
Jonathan
so
violently
that
her
future
husband
was
obliged
to
lay
forcible
hands
upon
her
and
drag
her
away
.
 
<EOS>
By
Wild
's
command
the
prisoner
was
taken
to
the
Condemned
Hold
,
whither
he
was
followed
by
the
whole
posse
of
officers
and
by
the
partners
;
two
of
whom
carried
large
hammers
and
two
the
fetters
.
<EOS>
There
was
only
one
prisoner
in
the
ward
.
<EOS>
He
was
chained
to
the
ground
,
but
started
up
at
their
approach
.
<EOS>
It
was
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
When
he
beheld
Jack
he
uttered
a
deep
groan
.
 
<EOS>
"
Captain
,
"
he
cried
,
in
a
voice
of
the
bitterest
anguish
,
"
have
these
dogs
again
hunted
you
down
?
<EOS>
If
you
had
n't
been
so
unlucky
,
I
should
have
been
with
you
before
to
-
morrow
night
.
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
made
no
answer
,
nor
did
he
even
cast
his
eyes
upon
his
follower
.
<EOS>
But
Jonathan
,
fixing
a
terrible
look
upon
him
,
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
say
you
so
?
<EOS>
You
must
be
looked
to
.
<EOS>
My
lads
,
"
he
continued
,
addressing
the
partners
;
"
when
you
've
finished
this
job
give
that
fellow
a
fresh
set
of
darbies
.
<EOS>
I
suspect
he
has
been
at
work
upon
those
he
has
on
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
link
of
the
chain
next
the
staple
is
sawn
through
,
"
said
Ireton
,
stooping
to
examine
Blueskin
's
fetters
.
 
<EOS>
"
Search
him
and
iron
him
afresh
;
"
commanded
Jonathan
.
"
<EOS>
But
first
let
us
secure
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
We
'll
then
remove
them
both
to
the
Middle
Stone
Hold
,
where
a
watch
shall
be
kept
over
them
night
and
day
till
they
're
taken
to
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
As
they
're
so
fond
of
each
other
's
society
<EOS>
they
sha
n't
part
company
even
on
that
occasion
,
but
shall
swing
from
the
same
tree
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
never
live
to
see
that
day
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
fixing
a
menacing
look
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
weight
are
these
irons
?
"
asked
Jonathan
,
coolly
addressing
one
of
the
partners
.
 
<EOS>
"
More
than
three
hundred
weight
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
They
're
the
heaviest
set
we
<EOS>
have,--and
were
forged
expressly
for
Captain
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
They
're
not
half
heavy
enough
,
"
replied
Wild
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
be
handcuffed
,
and
doubly
ironed
on
both
legs
;
and
when
we
get
him
into
the
Stone
Ward
,
he
shall
not
only
be
chained
down
to
the
ground
,
but
shall
have
two
additional
fetters
running
through
the
main
links
,
fastened
on
each
side
of
him
.
<EOS>
We
'll
see
whether
he
'll
get
rid
of
his
new
bonds
?
<EOS>
"
he
added
with
a
brutal
laugh
,
which
was
echoed
by
the
bystanders
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mark
me
,
"
said
Jack
,
sternly
;
<EOS>
"
I
have
twice
broken
out
of
this
prison
in
spite
of
all
your
precautions
.
<EOS>
And
were
you
to
load
me
with
thrice
<EOS>
the
weight
of
iron
you
have
ordered
you
should
not
prevent
my
escaping
a
third
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
Captain
,
"
cried
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
give
them
the
slip
yet
,
and
hang
that
butcherly
thief
-
taker
upon
his
own
gibbet
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Be
silent
dog
,
"
cried
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
And
with
his
clenched
hand
he
struck
him
a
violent
blow
in
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
,
perhaps
,
in
his
life
,
he
repented
of
his
brutality
.
<EOS>
The
blow
was
scarcely
dealt
,
when
,
with
a
bound
like
that
of
a
tiger
,
Blueskin
sprang
upon
him
.
<EOS>
The
chain
,
which
had
been
partially
cut
through
,
snapped
near
the
staple
.
<EOS>
Before
any
assistance
could
be
rendered
by
the
jailers
,
who
stood
astounded
,
Blueskin
had
got
Wild
in
his
clutches
.
<EOS>
His
strength
has
been
described
as
prodigious
;
but
now
,
heightened
by
his
desire
for
vengeance
,
it
was
irresistible
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
though
a
very
powerful
man
,
was
like
an
infant
in
his
gripe
.
<EOS>
Catching
hold
of
his
chin
,
he
bent
back
the
neck
,
while
with
his
left
hand
he
pulled
out
a
clasp
knife
,
which
he
opened
with
his
teeth
,
and
grasping
Wild
's
head
with
his
arm
,
notwithstanding
his
resistance
,
cut
deeply
into
his
throat
.
<EOS>
The
folds
of
a
thick
muslin
neckcloth
in
some
degree
protected
him
,
but
the
gash
was
desperate
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
drew
the
knife
across
his
throat
a
second
time
,
widening
and
deepening
the
wound
;
and
wrenching
back
the
head
to
get
it
into
a
more
favourable
position
,
would
infallibly
have
severed
it
from
the
trunk
,
if
the
officers
,
who
by
this
time
had
recovered
from
their
terror
,
had
not
thrown
themselves
upon
him
,
and
withheld
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
's
your
time
,
"
cried
Blueskin
,
struggling
desperately
with
his
assailants
and
inflicting
severe
cuts
with
his
knife
.
<EOS>
"
Fly
,
Captain
--
fly
!
"
 
<EOS>
Aroused
to
a
sense
of
the
possibility
of
escape
,
Jack
,
who
had
viewed
the
deadly
assault
with
savage
satisfaction
,
burst
from
his
captors
and
made
for
the
door
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
fought
his
way
towards
it
,
and
exerting
all
his
strength
,
cutting
right
and
left
as
he
proceeded
,
reached
it
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
Jack
in
all
probability
,
would
have
escaped
,
if
Langley
,
who
was
left
in
the
Lodge
,
had
not
been
alarmed
at
the
noise
and
rushed
thither
.
<EOS>
Seeing
Jack
at
liberty
,
he
instantly
seized
him
,
and
a
struggle
commenced
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
Blueskin
came
up
,
and
kept
off
the
officers
with
his
knife
.
<EOS>
He
used
his
utmost
efforts
to
liberate
Jack
from
Langley
,
but
closely
pressed
on
all
sides
,
he
was
not
able
to
render
any
effectual
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fly
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
;
"
escape
if
you
can
;
do
n't
mind
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Casting
one
look
of
anguish
at
his
leader
,
Blueskin
then
darted
down
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
persons
in
the
Lodge
were
Mrs.
Spurling
and
Marvel
.
<EOS>
Hearing
the
noise
of
the
scuffle
,
the
tapstress
,
fancying
it
was
Jack
making
an
effort
to
escape
,
in
spite
of
the
remonstrances
of
the
executioner
,
threw
open
the
wicket
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
therefore
had
nothing
to
stop
him
.
<EOS>
Dashing
through
the
open
door
,
he
crossed
the
Old
Bailey
,
plunged
into
a
narrow
court
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
and
was
out
of
sight
in
a
minute
,
baffling
all
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
On
their
return
,
the
jailers
raised
up
Jonathan
,
who
was
weltering
in
his
blood
,
and
who
appeared
to
be
dying
.
<EOS>
Efforts
were
made
to
staunch
his
wounds
and
surgical
assistance
sent
for
.
 
<EOS>
"
Has
he
escaped
?
"
asked
the
thief
-
taker
,
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Blueskin
,
"
said
Ireton
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
--
Sheppard
?
"
rejoined
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Ireton
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
here
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
replied
Wild
,
with
a
ghastly
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Remove
him
to
the
Middle
Stone
Hold,--watch
over
him
night
and
day
,
do
you
mind
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Irons
--
heavy
irons
--
night
and
day
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Depend
upon
it
,
Sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Go
with
him
to
<EOS>
Tyburn,--never
lose
sight
of
him
till
the
noose
is
tied
.
<EOS>
Where
's
Marvel
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,
Sir
,
"
replied
the
executioner
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
hundred
guineas
if
you
hang
Jack
Sheppard
.
<EOS>
I
have
it
about
me
.
<EOS>
Take
it
,
if
I
die
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Never
fear
,
Sir
,
"
replied
Marvel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
that
I
could
live
to
see
it
,
"
gasped
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
And
with
a
hideous
expression
of
pain
,
he
fainted
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
dead
,
"
exclaimed
Austin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
content
,
"
said
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
My
mother
is
avenged
.
<EOS>
Take
me
to
the
Stone
Room
.
<EOS>
Blueskin
,
you
are
a
true
friend
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
body
of
Jonathan
was
then
conveyed
to
his
own
habitation
,
while
Jack
was
taken
to
the
Middle
Stone
Room
,
and
ironed
in
the
manner
Wild
had
directed
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXVIII
.
 
<EOS>
What
happened
at
Dollis
Hill
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
length
this
tragedy
is
at
an
end
,
"
said
Mr.
Wood
,
as
,
having
seen
the
earth
thrown
over
the
remains
of
the
unfortunate
Mrs.
Sheppard
,
he
turned
to
quit
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hope
that
,
like
her
who
'
loved
much
,
'
her
sins
are
forgiven
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
Without
another
word
,
and
accompanied
by
Thames
,
he
then
took
his
way
to
Dollis
Hill
in
a
state
of
the
deepest
depression
.
<EOS>
Thames
did
not
attempt
to
offer
him
any
consolation
,
for
he
was
almost
as
much
dejected
.
<EOS>
The
weather
harmonized
with
their
feelings
.
<EOS>
It
rained
slightly
,
and
a
thick
mist
gathered
in
the
air
,
and
obscured
the
beautiful
prospect
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
arrival
at
Dollis
Hill
,
Mr.
Wood
was
so
much
exhausted
that
he
was
obliged
to
retire
to
his
own
room
,
where
he
continued
for
some
hours
overpowered
by
grief
.
<EOS>
The
two
lovers
sat
together
,
and
their
sole
discourse
turned
upon
Jack
and
his
ill
-
fated
mother
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
night
advanced
,
Mr.
Wood
again
made
his
appearance
in
a
more
composed
frame
of
mind
,
and
,
at
his
daughter
's
earnest
solicitation
,
was
induced
to
partake
of
some
refreshment
.
<EOS>
An
hour
was
then
passed
in
conversation
as
to
the
possibility
of
rendering
any
assistance
to
Jack
;
in
deploring
his
unhappy
destiny
;
and
in
the
consideration
of
the
course
to
be
pursued
in
reference
to
Jonathan
Wild
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
thus
occupied
,
a
maid
-
servant
entered
the
room
,
and
stated
that
a
person
was
without
who
had
a
packet
for
Captain
Darrell
,
which
must
be
delivered
into
his
own
hands
.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
remonstrances
of
Wood
and
Winifred
,
Thames
instantly
followed
the
domestic
,
and
found
a
man
,
with
his
face
muffled
up
,
at
the
door
,
as
she
had
described
.
<EOS>
Somewhat
alarmed
at
his
appearance
,
Thames
laid
his
hand
upon
his
sword
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fear
nothing
,
Sir
,
"
said
the
man
,
in
a
voice
which
Thames
instantly
recognised
as
that
of
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
to
render
you
a
service
.
<EOS>
There
are
the
packets
which
my
Captain
hazarded
his
life
to
procure
for
you
,
and
which
he
said
would
establish
your
right
to
the
estates
of
the
Trenchard
family
.
<EOS>
There
are
also
the
letters
which
were
scattered
about
Wild
's
room
after
the
murder
of
Sir
Rowland
.
<EOS>
And
there
,
"
he
added
,
placing
in
his
hands
a
heavy
bag
of
money
,
and
a
pocket
-
book
,
"
is
a
sum
little
short
of
fifteen
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
have
you
procured
these
things
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Thames
,
in
the
utmost
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
carried
them
off
on
the
fatal
night
when
we
got
into
Wild
's
house
,
and
you
were
struck
down
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
They
have
ever
since
been
deposited
in
a
place
of
safety
.
<EOS>
You
have
nothing
more
to
fear
from
Wild
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
How
so
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
saved
the
executioner
a
labour
,
by
cutting
his
throat
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
may
I
be
cursed
if
I
ever
did
anything
in
my
whole
life
which
gave
me
so
much
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Almighty
God
!
<EOS>
is
this
possible
?
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
it
true
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
regret
is
,
that
I
failed
in
liberating
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
got
off
,
they
might
have
hanged
me
,
and
welcome
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
can
be
done
for
him
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
an
easy
question
to
answer
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
watch
night
and
day
about
Newgate
,
in
the
hope
of
getting
him
out
.
<EOS>
He
would
n't
require
my
aid
,
but
before
I
stopped
Jonathan
's
mouth
,
he
had
ordered
him
to
be
doubly
-
ironed
,
and
constantly
watched
.
<EOS>
And
,
though
the
villain
ca
n't
see
his
orders
executed
,
I
've
no
doubt
some
one
else
will
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Poor
Jack
!
"
exclaimed
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
sacrifice
all
my
fortune
--
all
my
hopes
--
to
liberate
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
're
in
earnest
,
"
rejoined
Blueskin
,
"
give
me
that
bag
of
gold
.
<EOS>
It
contains
a
thousand
pounds
;
and
,
if
all
other
schemes
fail
,
I
'll
engage
to
free
him
on
the
way
to
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
May
I
trust
you
?
"
<EOS>
hesitated
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
did
I
not
keep
the
money
when
I
had
it
?
"
<EOS>
returned
Blueskin
,
angrily
.
"
Not
a
farthing
of
it
shall
be
expended
except
in
the
Captain
's
service
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
it
,
"
replied
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
saved
his
life
,
"
replied
Blueskin
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
mark
me
.
<EOS>
You
owe
what
I
have
done
for
you
,
to
him
,
not
to
me
.
<EOS>
Had
I
not
known
that
you
and
your
affianced
bride
are
dearer
to
him
than
life
<EOS>
I
should
have
used
this
money
to
secure
my
own
safety
.
<EOS>
Take
it
,
and
take
the
estates
,
in
Captain
Sheppard
's
name
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
one
thing
before
I
leave
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
asked
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
the
Captain
_
is
_
taken
to
Tyburn
,
be
near
the
place
of
execution
--
at
the
end
of
the
Edgeware
Road
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
In
case
of
need
you
will
lend
a
helping
hand
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
--
yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Swear
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
"
rejoined
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
And
he
departed
,
just
as
Wood
,
who
had
become
alarmed
by
Thames
's
long
absence
,
made
his
appearance
with
a
blunderbuss
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Hastily
acquainting
him
with
the
treasures
he
had
unexpectedly
obtained
,
Thames
returned
to
the
room
to
apprize
Winifred
of
his
good
fortune
.
<EOS>
The
packets
were
hastily
broken
open
;
and
,
while
Wood
was
absorbed
in
the
perusal
of
the
despatch
addressed
to
him
by
Sir
Rowland
,
Thames
sought
out
,
and
found
the
letter
which
he
had
been
prevented
from
finishing
on
the
fatal
night
at
Jonathan
Wild
's
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
read
it
,
he
let
it
fall
from
his
grasp
.
 
<EOS>
Winifred
instantly
picked
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
no
longer
Thames
Darrell
,
"
she
said
,
casting
her
eyes
rapidly
over
it
;
"
but
the
Marquis
de
Chatillon
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
father
was
of
the
blood
-
royal
of
France
,
"
exclaimed
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
-
day
!
<EOS>
what
's
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
,
looking
up
from
beneath
his
spectacles
.
<EOS>
"
Who
--
who
is
the
Marquis
de
Chatillon
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
adopted
son
,
Thames
Darrell
,
"
answered
Winifred
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
the
Marchioness
is
your
daughter
,
"
added
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
O
,
Lord
!
"
ejaculated
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
My
head
fairly
turns
round
.
<EOS>
So
many
distresses
--
so
many
joys
coming
at
the
same
time
are
too
much
for
me
.
<EOS>
Read
that
letter
,
Thames
--
my
lord
marquis
,
I
mean
.
<EOS>
Read
it
,
and
you
'll
find
that
your
unfortunate
uncle
,
Sir
Rowland
,
surrenders
to
you
all
the
estates
in
Lancashire
.
<EOS>
You
've
nothing
to
do
but
to
take
possession
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
strange
history
is
mine
!
"
said
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
Kidnapped
,
and
sent
to
France
by
one
uncle
,
it
was
my
lot
to
fall
into
the
hands
of
another,--my
father
's
own
brother
,
the
Marshal
Gaucher
de
Chatillon
;
to
whom
,
and
to
the
Cardinal
Dubois
,
I
owed
all
my
good
fortune
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
ways
of
Providence
are
inscrutable
,
"
observed
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
in
France
,
I
heard
from
the
Marshal
that
his
brother
had
perished
in
London
on
the
night
of
the
Great
Storm
.
<EOS>
It
was
supposed
he
was
drowned
in
crossing
the
river
,
as
his
body
had
never
been
found
.
<EOS>
Little
did
I
imagine
at
the
time
that
it
was
my
own
father
to
whom
he
referred
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
remember
reading
something
about
your
father
in
the
papers
,
"
observed
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Was
n't
he
in
some
way
connected
with
the
Jacobite
plots
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
,
"
replied
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
He
had
been
many
years
in
this
country
before
his
assassination
took
place
.
<EOS>
In
this
letter
,
which
is
addressed
to
my
ill
-
fated
mother
,
he
speaks
of
his
friendship
for
Sir
Rowland
,
whom
it
seems
he
had
known
abroad
;
but
entreats
her
to
keep
the
marriage
secret
for
a
time
,
for
reasons
which
are
not
fully
developed
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
Sir
Rowland
murdered
his
friend
,
"
remarked
Wood
.
<EOS>
"
Crime
upon
crime
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Unconsciously
,
perhaps
,
"
replied
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
But
be
it
as
it
may
,
he
is
now
beyond
the
reach
of
earthly
punishment
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
But
Wild
still
lives
,
"
cried
Wood
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
;
also
,
has
paid
the
penalty
of
his
offences
,
"
returned
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
fallen
by
the
hand
of
Blueskin
,
who
brought
me
these
packets
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
God
for
that
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wood
,
heartily
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
almost
forgive
the
wretch
the
injury
he
did
me
in
depriving
me
of
my
poor
dear
wife
--
No
,
not
quite
_
that
_
,
"
he
added
,
a
little
confused
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Thames
,
(
for
we
must
still
preserve
the
name
,
)
<EOS>
"
you
will
no
longer
defer
my
happiness
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Winifred
,
gravely
.
<EOS>
"
I
release
you
from
your
promise
.
<EOS>
A
carpenter
's
daughter
is
no
fit
match
for
a
peer
of
France
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
my
dignity
must
be
purchased
by
the
loss
of
you
,
I
renounce
it
,
"
cried
Thames
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
make
it
valueless
in
my
eyes
,
"
he
added
,
catching
her
in
his
arms
,
and
pressing
her
to
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
it
as
you
please
,
"
replied
Winifred
.
<EOS>
"
My
lips
would
belie
my
heart
were
I
to
refuse
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
father
,
your
blessing
--
your
consent
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Thames
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
both
,
"
replied
Wood
,
fervently
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
too
much
honoured
--
too
happy
in
the
union
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
I
should
live
to
be
father
-
in
-
law
to
a
peer
of
France
!
<EOS>
What
would
my
poor
wife
say
to
it
,
if
she
could
come
to
life
again
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
Thames!--my
lord
marquis
,
I
mean
--
you
have
made
me
the
happiest
--
the
proudest
of
mankind
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Not
many
days
after
this
event
,
on
a
bright
October
morning
,
the
bells
rang
a
merry
peal
from
the
old
gray
tower
of
Willesden
church
.
<EOS>
All
the
village
was
assembled
in
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
Young
and
old
were
dressed
in
their
gayest
apparel
;
and
it
was
evident
from
the
smiles
that
lighted
up
every
countenance
,
from
the
roguish
looks
of
the
younger
swains
,
and
the
demure
expression
of
several
pretty
rustic
maidens
,
that
a
ceremony
,
which
never
fails
to
interest
all
classes,--a
wedding,--was
about
to
take
place
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
gate
opening
upon
the
road
leading
to
Dollis
Hill
were
stationed
William
Morgan
and
John
Dump
.
<EOS>
Presently
,
two
carriages
dashed
down
the
hill
,
and
drew
up
before
it
.
<EOS>
From
the
first
of
these
alighted
Thames
,
or
,
as
he
must
now
be
styled
,
the
Marquis
de
Chatillon
.
<EOS>
From
the
second
descended
Mr.
Wood
--
and
after
him
came
his
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
never
shone
upon
a
lovelier
couple
than
now
approached
the
altar
.
<EOS>
The
church
was
crowded
to
excess
by
the
numbers
eager
to
witness
the
ceremony
;
and
as
soon
as
it
was
over
the
wedded
pair
were
followed
to
the
carriage
,
and
the
loudest
benedictions
uttered
for
their
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
In
spite
of
the
tumultuous
joy
which
agitated
him
,
the
bridegroom
could
not
prevent
the
intrusion
of
some
saddening
thoughts
,
as
he
reflected
upon
the
melancholy
scene
which
he
had
so
recently
witnessed
in
the
same
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
youthful
couple
had
been
seated
in
the
carriage
a
few
minutes
when
they
were
joined
by
Mr.
Wood
,
who
had
merely
absented
himself
to
see
that
a
public
breakfast
,
which
he
had
ordered
at
the
Six
Bells
for
all
who
chose
to
partake
of
it
,
was
in
readiness
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
gave
directions
that
in
the
after
part
of
the
day
a
whole
bullock
should
be
roasted
on
the
green
and
distributed
,
together
with
a
barrel
of
the
strongest
ale
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
evening
,
a
band
of
village
musicians
,
accompanied
by
most
of
the
young
inhabitants
of
Willesden
,
strolled
out
to
Dollis
Hill
,
where
they
formed
a
rustic
concert
under
the
great
elm
before
the
door
.
<EOS>
Here
they
were
regaled
with
another
plentiful
meal
by
the
hospitable
carpenter
,
who
personally
superintended
the
repast
.
 
<EOS>
These
festivities
,
however
,
were
not
witnessed
by
the
newly
-
married
pair
,
who
had
departed
immediately
after
the
ceremony
for
Manchester
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXIX
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jack
Sheppard
was
taken
to
Westminster
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
Loaded
with
the
heaviest
fetters
,
and
constantly
watched
by
two
of
the
jailers
'
assistants
,
who
neither
quitted
him
for
a
single
moment
,
nor
suffered
any
visitor
to
approach
him
,
Jack
Sheppard
found
all
attempts
to
escape
impracticable
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
confined
in
the
Middle
Stone
Ward
,
a
spacious
apartment
,
with
good
light
and
air
,
situated
over
the
gateway
on
the
western
side
,
and
allotted
to
him
,
not
for
his
own
convenience
,
but
for
that
of
the
keepers
,
who
,
if
he
had
been
placed
in
a
gloomier
or
more
incommodious
dungeon
,
would
have
necessarily
had
to
share
it
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Through
this
,
his
last
trial
,
Jack
's
spirits
never
deserted
him
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
resigned
but
cheerful
,
and
held
frequent
and
serious
discourses
with
the
ordinary
,
who
felt
satisfied
of
his
sincere
penitence
.
<EOS>
The
only
circumstance
which
served
to
awaken
a
darker
feeling
in
his
breast
was
,
that
his
implacable
foe
Jonathan
Wild
had
survived
the
wound
inflicted
by
Blueskin
,
and
was
slowly
recovering
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
could
be
moved
with
safety
,
Jonathan
had
himself
transported
to
Newgate
,
where
he
was
carried
into
the
Middle
Ward
,
that
he
might
feast
his
eyes
upon
his
victim
.
<EOS>
Having
seen
every
precaution
taken
to
ensure
his
safe
custody
,
he
departed
,
muttering
to
himself
,
"
I
shall
yet
live
to
see
him
hanged
--
I
shall
live
to
see
him
hanged
.
"
 
<EOS>
Animated
by
his
insatiate
desire
of
vengeance
,
he
seemed
to
gain
strength
<EOS>
daily,--so
<EOS>
much
so
,
that
within
a
fortnight
after
receiving
his
wound
he
was
able
to
stir
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
On
Thursday
,
the
12th
of
November
,
after
having
endured
nearly
a
month
's
imprisonment
,
Jack
Sheppard
was
conveyed
from
Newgate
to
Westminster
Hall
.
<EOS>
He
was
placed
in
a
coach
,
handcuffed
,
and
heavily
fettered
,
and
guarded
by
a
vast
posse
of
officers
to
Temple
Bar
,
where
a
fresh
relay
of
constables
escorted
him
to
Westminster
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
Jack
's
reputation
had
risen
to
such
a
height
with
the
populace,--his
exploits
having
become
the
universal
theme
of
discourse
,
that
the
streets
were
almost
impassable
for
the
crowds
collected
to
obtain
a
view
of
him
.
<EOS>
The
vast
area
in
front
of
Westminster
Hall
was
thronged
with
people
,
and
it
was
only
by
a
vigorous
application
of
their
staves
that
the
constables
could
force
a
passage
for
the
vehicle
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
the
prisoner
was
got
out
,
when
such
was
the
rush
of
the
multitude
that
several
persons
were
trampled
down
,
and
received
severe
injuries
.
 
<EOS>
Arrived
in
the
Hall
,
the
prisoner
's
handcuffs
were
removed
,
and
he
was
taken
before
the
Court
of
King
's
Bench
.
<EOS>
The
record
of
his
conviction
at
the
Old
Bailey
sessions
was
then
read
;
and
as
no
objection
was
offered
to
it
,
the
Attorney
-
General
moved
that
his
execution
might
take
place
on
Monday
next
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Jack
earnestly
and
eloquently
addressed
himself
to
the
bench
,
and
besought
that
a
petition
which
he
had
prepared
to
be
laid
before
the
King
might
be
read
.
<EOS>
This
request
,
however
,
was
refused
;
and
he
was
told
that
the
only
way
in
which
he
could
entitle
himself
to
his
Majesty
's
clemency
would
be
by
discovering
who
had
abetted
him
in
his
last
escape
;
the
strongest
suspicions
being
entertained
that
he
had
not
affected
it
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
replied
by
a
solemn
assertion
,
"
that
he
had
received
no
assistance
except
from
Heaven
.
<EOS>
"--An
answer
for
which
he
was
immediately
reprimanded
by
the
court
.
<EOS>
It
having
been
stated
that
it
was
wholly
impossible
he
could
have
removed
his
irons
in
the
way
he
represented
,
he
offered
,
if
his
handcuffs
were
replaced
,
to
take
them
off
in
the
presence
of
the
court
.
<EOS>
The
proposal
,
however
,
was
not
acceded
to
;
and
the
Chief
Justice
Powis
,
after
enumerating
his
various
offences
and
commenting
upon
their
heinousness
,
awarded
sentence
of
death
against
him
for
the
following
Monday
.
 
<EOS>
As
Jack
was
removed
,
he
noticed
Jonathan
Wild
at
a
little
distance
from
him
,
eyeing
him
with
a
look
of
the
most
savage
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
The
thief
-
taker
's
throat
was
bound
up
with
thick
folds
of
linen
,
and
his
face
had
a
ghastly
and
cadaverous
look
,
which
communicated
an
undefinable
and
horrible
expression
to
his
glances
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
mob
outside
had
prodigiously
increased
,
and
had
begun
to
exhibit
some
disposition
to
riot
.
<EOS>
The
coach
in
which
the
prisoner
had
been
conveyed
was
already
broken
to
pieces
,
and
the
driver
was
glad
to
escape
with
life
.
<EOS>
Terrific
shouts
were
raised
by
the
rabble
,
who
threatened
to
tear
Wild
in
pieces
if
he
showed
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Amid
this
tumult
,
several
men
armed
with
tremendous
bludgeons
,
with
their
faces
besmeared
with
grease
and
soot
,
and
otherwise
disguised
,
were
observed
to
be
urging
the
populace
to
attempt
a
rescue
.
<EOS>
They
were
headed
by
an
athletic
-
looking
,
swarthy
-
featured
man
,
who
was
armed
with
a
cutlass
,
which
he
waved
over
his
head
to
cheer
on
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
These
desperadoes
had
been
the
most
active
in
demolishing
the
coach
,
and
now
,
being
supported
by
the
rabble
,
they
audaciously
approached
the
very
portals
of
the
ancient
Hall
.
<EOS>
The
shouts
,
yells
,
and
groans
which
they
uttered
,
and
which
were
echoed
by
the
concourse
in
the
rear
,
were
perfectly
frightful
.
 
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
who
with
the
other
constables
had
reconnoitred
this
band
,
and
recognised
in
its
ring
-
leader
,
Blueskin
,
commanded
the
constables
to
follow
him
,
and
made
a
sally
for
the
purpose
of
seizing
him
.
<EOS>
Enfeebled
by
his
wound
,
Wild
had
lost
much
of
his
strength
,
though
nothing
of
his
ferocity
and
energy,--and
fiercely
assailing
Blueskin
,
he
made
a
desperate
but
unsuccessful
attempt
to
apprehend
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
,
however
,
instantly
beaten
back
;
and
the
fury
of
the
mob
was
so
great
that
it
was
with
difficulty
he
could
effect
a
retreat
.
<EOS>
The
whole
force
of
the
constables
,
jailers
and
others
was
required
to
keep
the
crowd
out
of
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
The
doors
were
closed
and
barricaded
,
and
the
mob
threatened
to
burst
them
open
if
Jack
was
not
delivered
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Things
now
began
to
wear
so
serious
a
aspect
that
a
messenger
was
secretly
despatched
to
the
Savoy
for
troops
,
and
in
half
an
hour
a
regiment
of
the
guards
arrived
,
who
by
dint
of
great
exertion
succeeded
in
partially
dispersing
the
tumultuous
assemblage
.
<EOS>
Another
coach
was
then
procured
,
in
which
the
prisoner
was
placed
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
's
appearance
was
hailed
with
the
loudest
cheers
,
but
when
Jonathan
followed
and
took
a
place
beside
him
in
the
vehicle
,
determined
,
he
said
,
never
to
lose
sight
of
him
,
the
abhorrence
of
the
multitude
was
expressed
by
execrations
,
hoots
,
and
yells
of
the
most
terrific
kind
.
<EOS>
So
dreadful
were
these
shouts
as
to
produce
an
effect
upon
the
hardened
feelings
of
Jonathan
,
who
shrank
out
of
sight
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
well
for
him
that
he
had
taken
his
place
by
Sheppard
,
as
regard
for
the
latter
alone
prevented
the
deadliest
missiles
being
hurled
at
him
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
the
mob
went
on
alternately
hooting
and
huzzaing
as
the
names
of
Wild
and
Sheppard
were
pronounced
,
while
some
individuals
,
bolder
than
the
rest
,
thrust
their
faces
into
the
coach
-
window
,
and
assured
Jack
that
he
should
never
be
taken
to
Tyburn
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
that
,
you
yelping
hounds
!
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
glaring
fiercely
at
them
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
Jack
was
brought
back
to
Newgate
,
and
again
chained
down
in
the
Middle
Ward
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
late
before
Jonathan
ventured
to
his
own
house
,
where
he
remained
up
all
night
,
and
kept
his
janizaries
and
other
assistants
well
armed
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXX
.
 
<EOS>
How
Jonathan
Wild
's
House
was
burnt
down
.
  
<EOS>
The
day
appointed
for
the
execution
was
now
close
at
hand
,
and
the
prisoner
,
who
seemed
to
have
abandoned
all
hopes
of
escape
,
turned
his
thoughts
entirely
from
worldly
considerations
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sunday
,
he
was
conveyed
to
the
chapel
,
through
which
he
had
passed
on
the
occasion
of
his
great
escape
,
and
once
more
took
his
seat
in
the
Condemned
Pew
.
<EOS>
The
Rev.
Mr.
Purney
,
the
ordinary
,
who
had
latterly
conceived
a
great
regard
for
Jack
,
addressed
him
in
a
discourse
,
which
,
while
it
tended
to
keep
alive
his
feelings
of
penitence
,
was
calculated
to
afford
him
much
consolation
.
<EOS>
The
chapel
was
crowded
to
excess
.
<EOS>
But
here,--even
here
,
the
demon
was
suffered
to
intrude
,
and
Jack
's
thoughts
were
distracted
by
Jonathan
Wild
,
who
stood
at
a
little
distance
from
him
,
and
kept
his
bloodthirsty
eyes
fixed
on
him
during
the
whole
of
the
service
.
 
<EOS>
On
that
night
,
an
extraordinary
event
occurred
,
which
convinced
the
authorities
that
every
precaution
must
be
taken
in
conducting
Jack
to
Tyburn,--a
fact
of
which
they
had
been
previously
made
aware
,
though
scarcely
to
the
same
extent
,
by
the
riotous
proceedings
near
Westminster
Hall
.
<EOS>
About
nine
o'clock
,
an
immense
mob
collected
before
the
Lodge
at
Newgate
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
dark
;
but
as
some
of
the
assemblage
carried
links
,
it
was
soon
ascertained
to
be
headed
by
the
same
party
who
had
mainly
incited
the
former
disturbance
.
<EOS>
Amongst
the
ring
-
leaders
was
Blueskin
,
whose
swarthy
features
and
athletic
figure
were
easily
distinguished
.
<EOS>
Another
was
Baptist
Kettleby
,
and
a
third
,
in
a
Dutch
dress
,
was
recognised
by
his
grizzled
beard
as
the
skipper
,
Van
Galgebrok
.
 
<EOS>
Before
an
hour
had
elapsed
,
the
concourse
was
fearfully
increased
.
<EOS>
The
area
in
front
of
the
jail
was
completely
filled
.
<EOS>
Attempts
were
made
upon
the
door
of
the
Lodge
;
but
it
was
too
strong
to
be
forced
.
<EOS>
A
cry
was
then
raised
by
the
leaders
to
attack
Wild
's
house
,
and
the
fury
of
the
mob
was
instantly
directed
to
that
quarter
.
<EOS>
Wrenched
from
their
holds
,
the
iron
palisades
in
front
of
the
thief
-
taker
's
dwelling
were
used
as
weapons
to
burst
open
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
Jonathan
opened
one
of
the
upper
windows
,
and
fired
several
shots
upon
the
assailants
.
<EOS>
But
though
he
made
Blueskin
and
Kettleby
his
chief
marks
,
he
missed
both
.
<EOS>
The
sight
of
the
thief
-
taker
increased
the
fury
of
the
mob
to
a
fearful
degree
.
<EOS>
Terrific
yells
rent
the
air
.
<EOS>
The
heavy
weapon
thundered
against
the
door
;
and
it
speedily
yielded
to
their
efforts
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
on
,
my
lads
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Blueskin
,
"
we
'll
unkennel
the
old
fox
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
several
shots
were
fired
from
the
upper
part
of
the
house
,
and
two
men
fell
mortally
wounded
.
<EOS>
But
this
only
incensed
the
assailing
party
the
more
.
<EOS>
With
a
drawn
cutlass
in
one
hand
and
a
cocked
pistol
in
the
other
,
Blueskin
rushed
up
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
landing
was
defended
by
Quilt
Arnold
and
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
The
former
was
shot
by
Blueskin
through
the
head
,
and
his
body
fell
over
the
bannisters
.
<EOS>
The
Jew
,
who
was
paralysed
by
his
companion
's
fate
,
offered
no
resistance
,
and
was
instantly
seized
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
your
accursed
master
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Blueskin
,
holding
the
sword
to
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
The
Jew
did
not
speak
,
but
pointed
to
the
audience
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
Committing
him
to
the
custody
of
the
others
,
Blueskin
,
followed
by
a
numerous
band
,
darted
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
locked
;
but
,
with
the
bars
of
iron
,
it
was
speedily
burst
open
.
<EOS>
Several
of
the
assailants
carried
links
,
so
that
the
room
was
a
blaze
of
light
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
however
,
was
nowhere
to
be
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Rushing
towards
the
entrance
of
the
well
-
hole
,
Blueskin
touched
the
secret
spring
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
Opening
the
trap
-
door
,
he
then
descended
to
the
vaults
--
searched
each
cell
,
and
every
nook
and
corner
separately
.
<EOS>
Wild
had
escaped
.
 
<EOS>
Robbed
of
their
prey
,
the
fury
of
the
mob
became
ungovernable
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
at
the
end
of
a
passage
,
next
to
the
cell
where
Mrs.
Sheppard
had
been
confined
,
Blueskin
discovered
a
trap
-
door
which
he
had
not
previously
noticed
.
<EOS>
It
was
instantly
burst
open
,
when
the
horrible
stench
that
issued
from
it
convinced
them
that
it
must
be
a
receptacle
for
the
murdered
victims
of
the
thief
-
taker
.
 
<EOS>
Holding
a
link
into
the
place
,
which
had
the
appearance
of
a
deep
pit
,
Blueskin
noticed
a
body
richly
dressed
.
<EOS>
He
dragged
it
out
,
and
perceiving
,
in
spite
of
the
decayed
frame
,
that
it
was
the
body
of
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
,
commanded
his
attendants
to
convey
it
up
stairs
--
an
order
which
was
promptly
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
audience
-
chamber
,
Blueskin
had
the
Jew
brought
before
him
.
<EOS>
The
body
of
Sir
Rowland
was
then
laid
on
the
large
table
.
<EOS>
Opposite
to
it
was
placed
the
Jew
.
<EOS>
Seeing
from
the
threatening
looks
of
his
captors
,
that
they
were
about
to
wreak
their
vengeance
upon
him
,
the
miserable
wretch
besought
mercy
in
abject
terms
,
and
charged
his
master
with
the
most
atrocious
crimes
.
<EOS>
His
relation
of
the
murder
of
Sir
Rowland
petrified
even
his
fierce
auditors
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
the
cases
in
Jonathan
's
museum
was
now
burst
open
,
and
a
rope
taken
from
it
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
shrieks
,
the
miserable
Jew
was
then
dragged
into
the
well
-
hole
,
and
the
rope
being
tied
round
his
neck
,
he
was
launched
from
the
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
The
vengeance
of
the
assailants
did
not
stop
here
.
<EOS>
They
broke
open
the
entrance
into
Jonathan
's
store
-
room
--
plundered
it
of
everything
valuable
--
ransacked
every
closet
,
drawer
,
and
secret
hiding
-
place
,
and
stripped
them
of
their
contents
.
<EOS>
Large
hoards
of
money
were
discovered
,
gold
and
silver
plate
,
cases
of
watches
,
and
various
precious
articles
.
<EOS>
Nothing
,
in
short
,
portable
or
valuable
was
left
.
<EOS>
Old
implements
of
housebreaking
were
discovered
;
and
the
thief
-
taker
's
most
hidden
depositories
were
laid
bare
.
 
<EOS>
The
work
of
plunder
over
,
that
of
destruction
commenced
.
<EOS>
Straw
and
other
combustibles
being
collected
,
were
placed
in
the
middle
of
the
audience
-
chamber
.
<EOS>
On
these
were
thrown
all
the
horrible
contents
of
Jonathan
's
museum
,
together
with
the
body
of
Sir
Rowland
Trenchard
.
<EOS>
The
whole
was
then
fired
,
and
in
a
few
minutes
the
room
was
a
blaze
.
<EOS>
Not
content
with
this
,
the
assailants
set
fire
to
the
house
in
half
-
a
-
dozen
other
places
;
and
the
progress
of
the
flames
was
rapid
and
destructive
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
object
of
all
this
fearful
disturbance
had
made
his
escape
to
Newgate
,
from
the
roof
of
which
he
witnessed
the
destruction
of
his
premises
.
<EOS>
He
saw
the
flames
burst
from
the
windows
,
and
perhaps
in
that
maddening
spectacle
suffered
torture
equivalent
to
some
of
the
crimes
he
had
committed
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
standing
,
the
flames
of
his
house
,
which
made
the
whole
street
as
light
as
day
,
and
ruddily
illumined
the
faces
of
the
mob
below
,
betrayed
him
to
them
,
and
he
was
speedily
driven
from
his
position
by
a
shower
of
stones
and
other
missiles
.
 
<EOS>
The
mob
now
directed
their
attention
to
Newgate
;
and
,
from
their
threats
,
appeared
determined
to
fire
it
.
<EOS>
Ladders
,
paviour
's
rams
,
sledge
-
hammers
,
and
other
destructive
implements
were
procured
,
and
,
in
all
probability
,
their
purpose
would
have
been
effected
,
but
for
the
opportune
arrival
of
a
detachment
of
the
guards
,
who
dispersed
them
,
not
without
some
loss
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
Several
prisoners
were
taken
,
but
the
ring
-
leaders
escaped
.
<EOS>
Engines
were
brought
to
play
upon
Wild
's
premises
,
and
upon
the
adjoining
houses
.
<EOS>
The
latter
were
saved
;
but
of
the
former
nothing
but
the
blackened
stone
walls
were
found
standing
on
the
morrow
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXXI
.
 
<EOS>
The
Procession
to
Tyburn
.
  
<EOS>
The
noise
of
this
disturbance
did
not
fail
to
reach
the
interior
of
the
prison
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
the
reflection
of
the
flames
lighted
up
the
ward
in
which
Jack
Sheppard
was
confined
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
his
execution
was
therefore
passed
in
a
most
anxious
state
of
mind
;
nor
was
his
uneasiness
allayed
by
the
appearance
of
Jonathan
Wild
,
who
,
after
he
had
been
driven
from
the
roof
of
the
jail
,
repaired
to
the
Middle
Stone
Ward
in
a
fit
of
ungovernable
passion
,
to
vent
his
rage
upon
the
prisoner
,
whom
he
looked
upon
as
the
cause
of
the
present
calamity
.
<EOS>
Such
was
his
fury
,
that
if
he
had
not
been
restrained
by
the
presence
of
the
two
turnkeys
,
he
might
perhaps
have
anticipated
the
course
of
justice
,
by
laying
violent
hands
upon
his
victim
.
 
<EOS>
After
venting
his
wrath
in
the
wildest
manner
,
and
uttering
the
most
dreadful
execrations
,
Jonathan
retired
to
another
part
of
the
prison
,
where
he
passed
the
night
in
consultation
with
the
governor
,
as
to
the
best
means
of
conveying
the
prisoner
securely
to
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Pitt
endeavoured
to
dissuade
him
from
attending
in
person
,
representing
the
great
risk
he
would
incur
from
the
mob
,
which
was
certain
to
be
assembled
.
<EOS>
But
Jonathan
was
not
to
be
deterred
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
sworn
to
see
him
hanged
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
nothing
shall
keep
me
away
--
nothing
,
by----
.
"
 
<EOS>
By
Wild
's
advice
,
the
usual
constabulary
force
was
greatly
augmented
.
<EOS>
Messengers
were
despatched
to
all
the
constables
and
head
-
boroughs
to
be
in
attendance,--to
the
sheriffs
to
have
an
extraordinary
number
of
their
officers
in
attendance,--and
to
the
Savoy
,
to
obtain
the
escort
of
a
troop
of
grenadier
-
guards
.
<EOS>
In
short
,
more
preparations
were
made
than
if
a
state
criminal
was
about
to
be
executed
.
 
<EOS>
The
morning
of
Monday
the
16th
of
November
1724
at
length
dawned
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dull
,
foggy
day
,
and
the
atmosphere
was
so
thick
and
heavy
,
that
,
at
eight
o'clock
,
the
curious
who
arrived
near
the
prison
could
scarcely
discern
the
tower
of
St.
Sepulchre
's
church
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
the
tramp
of
horses
'
feet
was
heard
slowly
ascending
Snow
Hill
,
and
presently
a
troop
of
grenadier
guards
rode
into
the
area
facing
Newgate
.
<EOS>
These
were
presently
joined
by
a
regiment
of
foot
.
<EOS>
A
large
body
of
the
constables
of
Westminster
next
made
their
appearance
,
the
chief
of
whom
entered
the
Lodge
,
where
they
were
speedily
joined
by
the
civic
authorities
.
<EOS>
At
nine
o'clock
,
the
sheriffs
arrived
,
followed
by
their
officers
and
javelin
-
men
.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
,
the
Stone
Hall
was
crowded
by
all
the
inmates
of
the
jail
,
debtors
,
felons
,
turnkeys
,
and
officers
who
could
obtain
permission
to
witness
the
ceremony
of
the
prisoner
's
irons
being
struck
off
.
<EOS>
Caliban
,
who
,
through
the
interest
of
Mr.
Ireton
,
was
appointed
to
the
office
,
stood
with
a
hammer
in
one
hand
,
and
a
punch
in
the
other
,
near
the
great
stone
block
,
ready
to
fulfil
his
duty
.
<EOS>
Close
behind
him
stood
the
tall
gaunt
figure
of
Marvel
,
with
his
large
bony
hands
,
his
scraggy
neck
,
and
ill
-
favoured
countenance
.
<EOS>
Next
to
the
executioner
stood
his
wife
--
the
former
Mrs.
Spurling
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marvel
held
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
,
and
appeared
in
great
distress
.
<EOS>
But
her
husband
,
whose
deportment
to
her
was
considerably
changed
since
the
fatal
knot
had
been
tied
,
paid
no
attention
whatever
to
her
grief
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
the
bell
of
Newgate
began
to
toll
,
and
was
answered
by
another
bell
from
St.
Sepulchre
's
.
<EOS>
The
great
door
of
the
Stone
Hall
was
thrown
open
,
and
the
sheriffs
,
preceded
by
the
javelin
-
men
,
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
They
were
followed
by
Jonathan
,
who
carried
a
stout
stick
under
his
arm
,
and
planted
himself
near
the
stone
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
uttered
by
the
assemblage
;
but
a
hush
of
expectation
reigned
throughout
.
 
<EOS>
Another
door
was
next
opened
,
and
,
preceded
by
the
ordinary
,
with
the
sacred
volume
in
his
hand
,
the
prisoner
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
Though
encumbered
by
his
irons
,
his
step
was
firm
,
and
his
demeanour
dignified
.
<EOS>
His
countenance
was
pale
as
death
,
but
not
a
muscle
quivered
;
nor
did
he
betray
the
slightest
appearance
of
fear
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
it
was
impossible
to
look
at
him
without
perceiving
that
his
resolution
was
unshaken
.
 
<EOS>
Advancing
with
a
slow
firm
step
to
the
stone
-
block
he
placed
his
left
foot
upon
it
,
drew
himself
up
to
his
full
height
,
and
fixed
a
look
so
stern
upon
Jonathan
,
that
the
thief
-
taker
quailed
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
black
,
meantime
,
began
to
ply
his
hammer
,
and
speedily
unriveted
the
chains
.
<EOS>
The
first
stroke
appeared
to
arouse
all
the
vindictive
passions
of
Jonathan
.
<EOS>
Fixing
a
ferocious
and
exulting
look
upon
Jack
Sheppard
,
he
exclaimed
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
length
,
my
vengeance
is
complete
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Wretch
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jack
,
raising
his
hand
in
a
menacing
manner
,
"
your
triumph
will
be
short
-
lived
.
<EOS>
Before
a
year
has
expired
,
you
will
share
the
same
fate
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
,
I
care
not
,
"
rejoined
Wild
;
"
I
shall
have
lived
to
see
you
hanged
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
O
Jack
,
dear
,
dear
Jack
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Marvel
,
who
was
now
quite
dissolved
in
tears
,
"
I
shall
never
survive
this
scene
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
hussy
!
"
cried
her
husband
gruffly
.
<EOS>
"
Women
ought
never
to
show
themselves
on
these
occasions
,
unless
they
can
behave
themselves
properly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
Jack
,
"
cried
twenty
voices
.
 
<EOS>
Sheppard
looked
round
,
and
exchanged
kindly
glances
with
several
of
those
who
addressed
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
limbs
feel
so
light
,
now
that
my
irons
are
removed
,
"
he
observed
with
a
smile
,
"
that
I
am
half
inclined
to
dance
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
dance
upon
nothing
,
presently
,
"
rejoined
Jonathan
,
brutally
.
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
for
ever
,
"
said
Jack
,
extending
his
hand
to
Mrs.
Marvel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
!
"
<EOS>
blubbered
the
executioner
's
wife
,
pressing
his
hand
to
her
lips
.
<EOS>
"
Here
are
a
pair
of
gloves
and
a
nosegay
for
you
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear!--oh
dear
!
<EOS>
Be
careful
of
him
,
"
she
added
to
her
husband
,
"
and
get
it
over
quickly
,
or
never
expect
to
see
me
again
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
,
fool
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Marvel
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
do
n't
know
my
own
business
?
"
 
<EOS>
Austin
and
Langley
then
advanced
to
the
prisoner
,
and
,
twinning
their
arms
round
his
,
led
him
down
to
the
Lodge
,
whither
he
was
followed
by
the
sheriffs
,
the
ordinary
,
Wild
,
and
the
other
officials
.
 
<EOS>
Meantime
,
every
preparation
had
been
made
outside
for
his
departure
.
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
two
long
lines
of
foot
-
guards
stood
the
cart
with
a
powerful
black
horse
harnessed
to
it
.
<EOS>
At
the
head
of
the
cart
was
placed
the
coffin
.
<EOS>
On
the
right
were
several
mounted
grenadiers
:
on
the
left
,
some
half
dozen
javelin
-
men
.
<EOS>
Soldiers
were
stationed
at
different
points
of
the
street
to
keep
off
the
mob
,
and
others
were
riding
backwards
and
forwards
to
maintain
an
open
space
for
the
passage
of
the
procession
.
 
<EOS>
The
assemblage
which
was
gathered
together
was
almost
countless
.
<EOS>
Every
house
-
top
,
every
window
,
every
wall
,
every
projection
,
had
its
occupants
.
<EOS>
The
wall
of
St.
Sepulchre
's
church
was
covered
--
so
was
the
tower
.
<EOS>
The
concourse
extended
along
Giltspur
Street
as
far
as
Smithfield
.
<EOS>
No
one
was
allowed
to
pass
along
Newgate
Street
,
which
was
barricaded
and
protected
by
a
strong
constabulary
force
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
person
who
issued
from
the
Lodge
was
Mr.
Marvel
,
who
proceeded
to
the
cart
,
and
took
his
seat
upon
the
coffin
.
<EOS>
The
hangman
is
always
an
object
of
peculiar
detestation
to
the
mob
,
a
tremendous
hooting
hailed
his
appearance
,
and
both
staves
and
swords
were
required
to
preserve
order
.
 
<EOS>
A
deep
silence
,
however
,
now
prevailed
,
broken
only
by
the
tolling
of
the
bells
of
Newgate
and
St.
Sepulchre
's
.
<EOS>
The
mighty
concourse
became
for
a
moment
still
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
such
a
shout
as
has
seldom
smitten
human
ears
rent
the
air
.
"
<EOS>
He
comes
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
thousand
voices
,
and
the
shout
ascended
to
Smithfield
,
descended
to
Snow
Hill
,
and
told
those
who
were
assembled
on
Holborn
Hill
that
Sheppard
had
left
the
prison
.
 
<EOS>
Between
the
two
officers
,
with
their
arms
linked
in
his
,
Jack
Sheppard
was
conducted
to
the
cart
.
<EOS>
He
looked
around
,
and
as
he
heard
that
deafening
shout,--as
<EOS>
he
felt
the
influence
of
those
thousand
eyes
fixed
upon
him,--as
he
listened
to
the
cheers
,
all
his
misgivings
--
if
he
had
any
--
vanished
,
and
he
felt
more
as
if
he
were
marching
to
a
triumph
,
than
proceeding
to
a
shameful
death
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
had
no
sooner
taken
his
place
in
the
cart
,
than
he
was
followed
by
the
ordinary
,
who
seated
himself
beside
him
,
and
,
opening
the
book
of
prayer
,
began
to
read
aloud
.
<EOS>
Excited
by
the
scene
,
Jack
,
however
,
could
pay
little
attention
to
the
good
man
's
discourse
,
and
was
lost
in
a
whirl
of
tumultuous
emotions
.
 
<EOS>
The
calvacade
was
now
put
slowly
in
motion
.
<EOS>
The
horse
-
soldiers
wheeled
round
and
cleared
a
path
:
the
foot
closed
in
upon
the
cart
.
<EOS>
Then
came
the
javelin
-
men
,
walking
four
abreast
,
and
lastly
,
a
long
line
of
constables
,
marching
in
the
same
order
.
 
<EOS>
The
procession
had
just
got
into
line
of
march
,
when
a
dreadful
groan
,
mixed
with
yells
,
hootings
,
and
execrations
,
was
heard
.
<EOS>
This
was
occasioned
by
Jonathan
Wild
,
who
was
seen
to
mount
his
horse
and
join
the
train
.
<EOS>
Jonathan
,
however
,
paid
no
sort
of
attention
to
this
demonstration
of
hatred
.
<EOS>
He
had
buckled
on
his
hanger
,
and
had
two
brace
of
pistols
in
his
belt
,
as
well
as
others
in
this
holsters
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
procession
had
reached
the
west
end
of
the
wall
of
St.
Sepulchre
's
church
,
where
,
in
compliance
with
an
old
custom
,
it
halted
.
<EOS>
By
the
will
of
Mr.
Robert
Dow
,
merchant
tailor
,
it
was
appointed
that
the
sexton
of
St.
Sepulchre
's
should
pronounce
a
solemn
exhortation
upon
every
criminal
on
his
way
to
Tyburn
,
for
which
office
<EOS>
he
was
to
receive
a
small
stipend
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
cavalcade
stopped
,
the
sexton
advanced
,
and
,
ringing
a
handbell
,
pronounced
the
following
admonition
.
 
<EOS>
"
_
All
good
people
pray
heartily
unto
God
for
this
poor
sinner
,
who
is
now
going
to
take
his
death
,
<EOS>
for
whom
this
great
bell
doth
toll
<EOS>
_
.
 
<EOS>
"
_
You
who
are
condemned
to
die
,
repent
with
lamentable
tears
.
<EOS>
Ask
mercy
of
the
Lord
for
the
salvation
of
your
own
soul
,
through
the
merits
of
the
death
and
passion
of
Jesus
Christ
,
who
now
sits
at
the
right
hand
of
God
,
to
make
intercession
for
you
,
if
you
penitently
return
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
Lord
have
mercy
upon
you
_
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
ceremony
concluded
,
the
calvacade
was
again
put
in
motion
.
 
<EOS>
Slowly
descending
Snow
Hill
,
the
train
passed
on
its
way
,
attended
by
the
same
stunning
vociferations
,
cheers
,
yells
,
and
outcries
,
which
had
accompanied
it
on
starting
from
Newgate
.
<EOS>
The
guards
had
great
difficulty
in
preserving
a
clear
passage
without
resorting
to
severe
measures
,
for
the
tide
,
which
poured
upon
them
behind
,
around
,
in
front
,
and
at
all
sides
,
was
almost
irresistible
.
<EOS>
The
houses
on
Snow
Hill
were
thronged
,
like
those
in
Old
Bailey
.
<EOS>
Every
window
,
from
the
groundfloor
to
the
garret
had
its
occupant
,
and
the
roofs
were
covered
with
spectators
.
<EOS>
Words
of
encouragement
and
sympathy
were
addressed
to
Jack
,
who
,
as
he
looked
around
,
beheld
many
a
friendly
glance
fixed
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
they
reached
Holborn
Bridge
.
<EOS>
Here
a
little
delay
occurred
.
<EOS>
The
passage
was
so
narrow
that
there
was
only
sufficient
room
for
the
cart
to
pass
,
with
a
single
line
of
foot
-
soldiers
on
one
side
;
and
,
as
the
walls
of
the
bridge
were
covered
with
spectators
,
it
was
not
deemed
prudent
to
cross
it
till
these
persons
were
dislodged
.
 
<EOS>
While
this
was
effected
,
intelligence
was
brought
that
a
formidable
mob
was
pouring
down
Field
Lane
,
the
end
of
which
was
barricaded
.
<EOS>
The
advanced
guard
rode
on
to
drive
away
any
opposition
,
while
the
main
body
of
the
procession
crossed
the
bridge
,
and
slowly
toiled
up
Holborn
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
The
entrance
of
Shoe
Lane
,
and
the
whole
line
of
the
wall
of
St.
Andrew
's
church
,
the
bell
of
which
was
tolling
,
was
covered
with
spectators
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
steps
leading
to
the
gates
of
the
church
stood
two
persons
whom
Jack
instantly
recognised
.
<EOS>
These
were
his
mistresses
,
Poll
Maggot
and
Edgeworth
Bess
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
latter
beheld
him
,
she
uttered
a
loud
scream
,
and
fainted
.
<EOS>
She
was
caught
by
some
of
the
bystanders
,
who
offered
by
her
every
assistance
in
their
power
.
<EOS>
As
to
Mrs.
Maggot
,
whose
nerves
were
more
firmly
strung
,
she
contented
herself
with
waving
her
hand
affectionately
to
her
lover
,
and
encouraging
him
by
her
gestures
.
 
<EOS>
While
this
was
taking
place
,
another
and
more
serious
interruption
occurred
.
<EOS>
The
advanced
guard
had
endeavoured
to
disperse
the
mob
in
Field
Lane
,
but
were
not
prepared
to
meet
with
the
resistance
they
encountered
.
<EOS>
The
pavement
had
been
hastily
picked
up
,
and
heaped
across
the
end
of
the
street
,
upon
which
planks
,
barrels
,
and
other
barricades
,
were
laid
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
mob
were
armed
with
pikes
,
staves
,
swords
,
muskets
,
and
other
weapons
,
and
offered
a
most
desperate
resistance
to
the
soldiery
,
whom
they
drove
back
with
a
shower
of
paving
-
stones
.
 
<EOS>
The
arrival
of
the
cart
at
the
end
of
Field
Lane
,
appeared
the
signal
for
an
attempt
at
rescue
.
<EOS>
With
a
loud
shout
,
and
headed
by
a
powerfully
-
built
man
,
with
a
face
as
black
as
that
of
a
mulatto
,
and
armed
with
a
cutlass
,
the
rabble
leapt
over
the
barricades
,
and
rushed
towards
the
vehicle
.
<EOS>
An
immediate
halt
took
place
.
<EOS>
The
soldiers
surrounded
the
cart
,
drew
their
swords
,
and
by
striking
the
rioters
first
with
the
blunt
edge
of
their
blades
,
and
afterwards
with
the
sharp
points
,
succeeded
in
driving
them
back
.
 
<EOS>
Amid
this
skirmish
Jonathan
greatly
distinguished
himself
.
<EOS>
Drawing
his
hanger
he
rode
amongst
the
crowd
,
trampled
upon
those
most
in
advance
,
and
made
an
attempt
to
seize
their
leader
,
in
whom
he
recognised
Blueskin
.
 
<EOS>
Baffled
in
their
attempt
,
the
mob
uttered
a
roar
,
such
as
only
a
thousand
angry
voices
can
utter
,
and
discharged
a
volley
of
missiles
at
the
soldiery
.
<EOS>
Stones
and
brickbats
were
showered
on
all
sides
,
and
Mr.
Marvel
was
almost
dislodged
from
his
seat
on
the
coffin
by
a
dead
dog
,
which
was
hurled
against
him
,
and
struck
him
in
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
by
dealing
blows
right
and
left
with
their
swords
,
and
even
inflicting
severe
cuts
on
the
foremost
of
the
rabble
,
the
soldiers
managed
to
gain
a
clear
course
,
and
to
drive
back
the
assailants
;
who
,
as
they
retreated
behind
the
barricades
,
shouted
in
tones
of
defiance
,
"
To
Tyburn
!
<EOS>
to
Tyburn
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
object
of
all
this
tumult
,
meanwhile
,
never
altered
his
position
,
but
sat
back
in
the
cart
,
as
if
resolved
not
to
make
even
a
struggle
to
regain
his
liberty
.
 
<EOS>
The
