procession
now
wound
its
way
,
without
further
interruption
,
along
Holborn
.
<EOS>
Like
a
river
swollen
by
many
currents
,
it
gathered
force
from
the
various
avenues
that
poured
their
streams
into
it
.
<EOS>
Fetter
Lane
,
on
the
left
,
Gray
's
Inn
,
on
the
right
,
added
their
supplies
.
<EOS>
On
all
hands
Jack
was
cheered
,
and
Jonathan
hooted
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
train
approached
St.
Giles
's
.
<EOS>
Here
,
according
to
another
old
custom
,
already
alluded
to
,
a
criminal
taken
to
execution
was
allowed
to
halt
at
a
tavern
,
called
the
Crown
,
and
take
a
draught
from
St.
Giles
's
bowl
,
"
as
his
last
refreshment
on
earth
.
"
<EOS>
At
the
door
of
this
tavern
,
which
was
situated
on
the
left
of
the
street
,
not
more
than
a
hundred
yards
distant
from
the
church
,
the
bell
of
which
began
to
toll
as
soon
as
the
procession
came
in
sight
,
the
cart
drew
up
,
and
the
whole
cavalcade
halted
.
<EOS>
A
wooden
balcony
in
one
of
the
adjoining
houses
was
thronged
with
ladies
,
all
of
whom
appeared
to
take
a
lively
interest
in
the
scene
,
and
to
be
full
of
commiseration
for
the
criminal
,
not
,
perhaps
,
unmixed
with
admiration
of
his
appearance
.
<EOS>
Every
window
in
the
public
house
was
filled
with
guests
;
and
,
as
in
the
case
of
St.
Andrew
's
,
the
churchyard
wall
of
St.
Giles
's
was
lined
with
spectators
.
 
<EOS>
A
scene
now
ensued
,
highly
characteristic
of
the
age
,
and
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
doleful
procession
at
once
assumed
a
festive
character
.
<EOS>
Many
of
the
soldiers
dismounted
,
and
called
for
drink
.
<EOS>
Their
example
was
immediately
imitated
by
the
officers
,
constables
,
javelin
men
,
and
other
attendants
;
and
nothing
was
to
be
heard
but
shouts
of
laughter
and
jesting,--nothing
seen
but
the
passing
of
glasses
,
and
the
emptying
of
foaming
jugs
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Marvel
,
who
had
been
a
little
discomposed
by
the
treatment
he
had
experienced
on
Holborn
Hill
,
very
composedly
filled
and
lighted
his
pipe
.
 
<EOS>
One
group
at
the
door
attracted
Jack
's
attention
,
inasmuch
as
it
was
composed
of
several
of
his
old
acquaintances
--
Mr
.
Kneebone
,
Van
Galgebrok
,
and
Baptist
Kettleby
--
all
of
whom
greeted
him
cordially
.
<EOS>
Besides
these
,
there
was
a
sturdy
-
looking
fellow
,
whom
he
instantly
recognised
as
the
honest
blacksmith
who
had
freed
him
from
his
irons
at
Tottenham
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
,
you
see
,
"
said
the
smith
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
I
perceive
,
"
replied
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
the
landlord
of
the
Crown
,
a
jovial
-
looking
stout
personage
,
with
a
white
apron
round
his
waist
,
issued
from
the
house
,
bearing
a
large
wooden
bowl
filled
with
ale
,
which
he
offered
to
Jack
,
who
instantly
rose
to
receive
it
.
<EOS>
Raising
the
bowl
in
his
right
hand
,
Jack
glanced
towards
the
balcony
,
in
which
the
group
of
ladies
were
seated
,
and
begged
to
drink
their
healths
;
he
then
turned
to
Kneebone
and
the
others
,
who
extended
their
hands
towards
him
,
and
raised
it
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
was
about
to
drain
it
,
he
encountered
the
basilisk
glance
of
Jonathan
Wild
,
and
paused
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
leave
this
bowl
for
you
,
"
he
cried
,
returning
it
to
the
landlord
untasted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
father
said
so
before
you
,
"
replied
Jonathan
,
malignantly
;
"
and
yet
it
has
tarried
thus
long
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
call
for
it
before
six
months
are
passed
,
"
rejoined
Jack
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
Once
again
the
cavalcade
was
in
motion
,
and
winding
its
way
by
St.
Giles
's
church
<EOS>
,
the
bell
of
which
continued
tolling
all
the
time
,
passed
the
pound
,
and
entered
Oxford
Road
,
or
,
as
it
was
then
not
unfrequently
termed
,
Tyburn
Road
.
<EOS>
After
passing
Tottenham
Court
Road
,
very
few
houses
were
to
be
seen
on
the
right
hand
,
opposite
Wardour
Street
it
was
open
country
.
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
now
dispersed
amongst
the
fields
,
and
thousands
of
persons
were
seen
hurrying
towards
Tyburn
as
fast
as
their
legs
could
carry
them
,
leaping
over
hedges
,
and
breaking
down
every
impediment
in
their
course
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
those
who
conducted
themselves
more
peaceably
,
the
conductors
of
the
procession
noticed
with
considerable
uneasiness
,
large
bands
of
men
armed
with
staves
,
bludgeons
,
and
other
weapons
,
who
were
flying
across
the
field
in
the
same
direction
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
feared
that
some
mischief
would
ensue
,
Wild
volunteered
,
if
he
were
allowed
a
small
body
of
men
,
to
ride
forward
to
Tyburn
,
and
keep
the
ground
clear
until
the
arrival
of
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
This
suggestion
being
approved
,
was
instantly
acted
upon
,
and
the
thief
-
taker
,
accompanied
by
a
body
of
the
grenadiers
,
rode
forward
.
 
<EOS>
The
train
,
meantime
,
had
passed
Marylebone
Lane
,
when
it
again
paused
for
a
moment
,
at
Jack
's
request
,
near
the
door
of
a
public
-
house
called
the
City
of
Oxford
.
 
<EOS>
Scarcely
had
it
come
to
a
halt
,
when
a
stalwart
man
shouldered
his
way
,
in
spite
of
their
opposition
,
through
the
lines
of
soldiery
to
the
cart
,
and
offered
his
large
horny
hand
to
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
I
would
call
to
bid
you
farewell
,
Mr.
Figg
,
"
said
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
you
did
,
"
replied
the
prize
-
fighter
.
<EOS>
"
Sorry
you
're
obliged
to
keep
your
word
.
<EOS>
Heard
of
your
last
escape
.
<EOS>
Hoped
you
'd
not
be
retaken
.
<EOS>
Never
sent
for
the
shirt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
want
it
,
"
replied
Jack
;
"
but
who
are
those
gentlemen
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Friends
of
yours
,
"
replied
Figg
;
"
come
to
see
you;--Sir
James
Thornhill
,
Mr.
Hogarth
,
and
Mr.
Gay
.
<EOS>
They
send
you
every
good
wish
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Offer
them
my
hearty
thanks
,
"
replied
Jack
,
waving
his
hand
to
the
group
,
all
of
whom
returned
the
salutation
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
farewell
,
Mr.
Figg
!
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
,
all
will
be
over
.
"
 
<EOS>
Figg
turned
aside
to
hide
the
tears
that
started
to
his
eyes,--for
the
stout
prize
-
fighter
,
with
a
man
's
courage
,
had
a
woman
's
heart,--and
<EOS>
the
procession
again
set
forward
.
    
<EOS>
CHAPTER
XXXII
.
 
<EOS>
The
Closing
Scene
.
  
<EOS>
Tyburn
was
now
at
hand
.
<EOS>
Over
the
sea
of
heads
arose
a
black
and
dismal
object
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
gallows
.
<EOS>
Jack
,
whose
back
was
towards
it
,
did
not
see
it
;
but
he
heard
,
from
the
pitying
exclamations
of
the
crowd
,
that
it
was
in
view
.
<EOS>
This
circumstance
produced
no
further
alteration
in
his
demeanour
except
that
he
endeavoured
to
abstract
himself
from
the
surrounding
scene
,
and
bend
his
attention
to
the
prayers
which
the
ordinary
was
reciting
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
he
had
succeeded
in
fixing
his
attention
,
it
was
again
shaken
,
and
he
was
almost
unnerved
by
the
sight
of
Mr.
Wood
,
who
was
standing
at
the
edge
of
a
raised
platform
,
anxiously
waving
his
hand
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Jack
instantly
sprang
to
his
feet
,
and
as
his
guards
construed
the
motion
into
an
attempt
to
escape
,
several
of
them
drew
their
swords
and
motioned
to
him
to
sit
down
.
<EOS>
But
Jack
did
not
heed
them
.
<EOS>
His
looks
were
fixed
on
his
old
benefactor
.
 
<EOS>
"
God
in
Heaven
bless
you
,
unhappy
boy
!
"
<EOS>
cried
.
<EOS>
Wood
,
bursting
into
tears
,
"
God
bless
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
Jack
extended
his
hand
towards
him
,
and
looked
anxiously
for
Thames
;
but
he
was
nowhere
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
A
severe
pang
shot
through
Jack
's
heart
,
and
he
would
have
given
worlds
if
he
possessed
them
to
have
seen
his
friend
once
more
.
<EOS>
The
wish
was
vain
:
and
,
endeavouring
to
banish
every
earthly
thought
,
he
addressed
himself
deeply
and
sincerely
to
prayer
.
 
<EOS>
While
this
was
passing
,
Jonathan
had
ridden
back
to
Marvel
to
tell
him
that
all
was
ready
,
and
to
give
him
his
last
instructions
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
lose
no
time
,
"
said
the
thief
-
taker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
hundred
pounds
if
you
do
it
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Rely
on
me
,
"
rejoined
the
executioner
,
throwing
away
his
pipe
,
which
was
just
finished
.
 
<EOS>
A
deep
dread
calm
,
like
that
which
precedes
a
thunderstorm
,
now
prevailed
amongst
the
assemblage
.
<EOS>
The
thousand
voices
which
a
few
moments
<EOS>
before
had
been
so
clamorous
were
now
hushed
.
<EOS>
Not
a
breath
was
drawn
.
<EOS>
The
troops
had
kept
a
large
space
clear
around
the
gallows
.
<EOS>
The
galleries
adjoining
it
were
crowded
with
spectators,--so
<EOS>
was
the
roof
of
a
large
tavern
<EOS>
,
then
the
only
house
standing
at
the
end
of
the
Edgeware
Road,--so
were
the
trees,--the
walls
of
Hyde
Park,--a
neighbouring
barn
,
a
shed,--in
short
,
every
available
position
.
 
<EOS>
The
cart
,
meantime
,
had
approached
the
fatal
tree
.
<EOS>
The
guards
,
horse
and
foot
,
and
constables
formed
a
wide
circle
round
it
to
keep
off
the
mob
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
awful
moment
--
so
awful
,
that
every
other
feeling
except
deep
interest
in
the
scene
seemed
suspended
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
terrible
juncture
,
Jack
maintained
his
composure,--a
smile
played
upon
his
face
before
the
cap
was
drawn
over
it,--and
<EOS>
the
last
words
he
uttered
were
,
"
My
poor
mother
!
<EOS>
I
shall
soon
join
her
!
"
<EOS>
The
rope
was
then
adjusted
,
and
the
cart
began
to
move
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
instant
,
he
was
launched
into
eternity
!
 
<EOS>
Scarcely
had
he
been
turned
off
a
moment
,
when
a
man
with
swarthy
features
leapt
into
the
cart
with
an
open
clasp
-
knife
in
his
hand
,
and
,
before
he
could
be
prevented
,
severed
the
rope
,
and
cut
down
the
body
.
<EOS>
It
was
Blueskin
.
<EOS>
His
assistance
came
too
late
.
<EOS>
A
ball
from
Wild
's
pistol
passed
through
his
heart
,
and
a
volley
of
musketry
poured
from
the
guards
lodged
several
balls
in
the
yet
breathing
body
of
his
leader
.
 
<EOS>
Blueskin
,
however
,
was
not
unattended
.
<EOS>
A
thousand
eager
assistants
pressed
behind
him
.
<EOS>
Jack
's
body
was
caught
,
and
passed
from
hand
to
hand
over
a
thousand
heads
,
till
it
was
far
from
the
fatal
tree
.
 
<EOS>
The
shouts
of
indignation
--
the
frightful
yells
now
raised
baffle
description
.
<EOS>
A
furious
attack
was
made
on
Jonathan
,
who
,
though
he
defended
himself
like
a
lion
,
was
desperately
wounded
,
and
would
inevitably
have
perished
if
he
had
not
been
protected
by
the
guards
,
who
were
obliged
to
use
both
swords
and
fire
-
arms
upon
the
mob
in
his
defence
.
<EOS>
He
was
at
length
rescued
from
his
assailants,--rescued
to
perish
,
seven
months
afterwards
,
with
every
ignominy
,
at
the
very
gibbet
to
which
he
had
brought
his
victim
.
 
<EOS>
The
body
of
Jack
Sheppard
,
meanwhile
,
was
borne
along
by
that
tremendous
host
,
which
rose
and
fell
like
the
waves
of
the
ocean
,
until
it
approached
the
termination
of
the
Edgeware
Road
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
point
a
carriage
with
servants
in
sumptuous
liveries
was
stationed
.
<EOS>
At
the
open
door
stood
a
young
man
in
a
rich
garb
with
a
mask
on
his
face
,
who
was
encouraging
the
mob
by
words
and
gestures
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
the
body
was
brought
towards
him
.
<EOS>
Instantly
seizing
it
,
the
young
man
placed
it
in
the
carriage
,
shut
the
door
,
and
commanded
his
servants
to
drive
off
.
<EOS>
The
order
was
promptly
obeyed
,
and
the
horses
proceeded
at
a
furious
pace
along
the
Edgeware
Road
.
 
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
afterwards
the
body
of
Jack
was
carefully
examined
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
cut
down
before
life
was
extinct
,
but
a
ball
from
one
of
the
soldiers
had
pierced
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
died
Jack
Sheppard
.
 
<EOS>
That
night
a
grave
was
dug
in
Willesden
churchyard
,
next
to
that
in
which
Mrs.
Sheppard
had
been
interred
.
<EOS>
Two
persons
,
besides
the
clergyman
and
sexton
,
alone
attended
the
ceremony
.
<EOS>
They
were
a
young
man
and
an
old
one
,
and
both
appeared
deeply
affected
.
<EOS>
The
coffin
was
lowered
into
the
grave
,
and
the
mourners
departed
.
<EOS>
A
simple
wooden
monument
was
placed
over
the
grave
,
but
without
any
name
or
date
.
<EOS>
In
after
years
,
some
pitying
hand
supplied
the
inscription
,
which
ran
thus--
 
<EOS>
[
Illustration
:
JACK
SHEPPARD
]
   
<EOS>
THE
END
.
